HEADLINE: Gates Orders a Revamping Of the C.I.A.'s File System

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31

 BODY:
Robert M. Gates, the Director of Central Intelligence, has ordered a sweeping overhaul of how the C.I.A. maintains its vast store of files, Government officials said today.
Mr. Gates's order is a result of the embarrassment suffered by the Central Intelligence Agency over its role in the criminal investigation of an Atlanta branch of an Italian bank. The Justice Department complained in the summer that the nation's prime intelligence and espionage agency failed to submit crucial information in the files about the bank, Banca Nazionale del Lavoro. 
 The C.I.A. said the failure stemmed from an unwieldy system of maintaining its secrets. In October Mr. Gates asked the agency's Office of Inspector General to review how the agency maintains both its computerized and paper files, and his decision to seek changes is in response to that report.
In addition to reporting on the agency's information retrieval systems, Mr. Gates also ordered the Inspector General to review the agency's performance in the criminal investigation of loans made to Iraq by the Atlanta branch of the Italian bank, which has close ties to the Government in Rome.
 
Questions About Reputation
 In a letter to employees of the C.I.A. in October, Mr. Gates lamented that the agency's reputation had been "once more called into question" over the bank fraud case and promised that the two reports would be completed by the end of the year. While the report on the agency's filing system, in which it keeps millions of pieces of information, was completed earlier this month, the companion report on the agency's role in the bank fraud case is not expected to be done for another two weeks, intelligence officials said today.
Specifics of the changes in the agency's information-retrieval systems are secret, the officials said, but the report recommends changes to insure that files are not so hidden from senior officials that they cannot be fully informed when asked for information.
Computer-security experts said the C.I.A.'s system of filing its secrets is so compartmentalized for security's sake that it is often difficult or impossible to track down all relevant information on a subject. At the same time, they said, the complicated system also provides a ready excuse for the agency when its officers want to withhold information.
 
Events Not Clear
 It has never been clear in the banking case, for example, if the agency was unable to locate all the information about the bank or simply declined to provide it to the Justice Department.
The Justice Department last year indicted the manager of the bank's Atlanta branch on charges that he defrauded the headquarters in Rome in approving sizable unsecured loans to Iraq. The indictment followed intense debate between the Justice Department lawyers in Washington and prosecutors in Atlanta over whether the bank's leaders in Rome were aware of the loans to Iraq. Because prosecutors were charging the branch manager, Christopher P. Drogoul, with fraud, it was crucial to know if the Rome officials knew what was happening.
The prosecution fell apart at a tumultuous court hearing in September when the Federal judge in the case, Marvin H. Shoob, allowed Mr. Drogoul to withdraw his guilty plea after the disclosures of how the C.I.A. withheld its information.
The agency often has found itself in the embarrassing position of belatedly finding information relevant to prosecutors and defendants in court cases. During the trial this summer of Clair E. George, a former head of the agency's covert operations branch, the C.I.A. reported on two occasions that it suddenly discovered relevant documents in boxes under some desks. (Mr. George, who was convicted of lying to Congress about the C.I.A.'s role in the Iran-contra affair, was among six officials implicated in the Iran-contra affair who were pardoned last week by President Bush.)
 
Plausible Explanations
 One senior Congressional aide said that the C.I.A.'s claims have a "the dog ate my homework" quality, but are actually quite plausible given the agency's compartmentalized filing system in which some information, like that on covert operations, is stored separately with limited access. Yet it is also true, the aide said, that the complicated filing system provides a cover for the C.I.A. to withhold information.
The C.I.A. currently has more than 10 separate computer information banks and more than a million pieces of paper, intelligence officials said.
Mr. Gates told reporters that when interest in the Italian bank affair first surfaced publicly six months ago, he had more than three dozen agency employees working full time just to gather the information from the C.I.A.'s separate filing spots.
In a sense, the C.I.A. is caught in a clash of cultures in which keeping secrets and making them accessible even to its own officials is inherently a conflict. The agency, with its origins in the pre-computer, paper age, still has tons of written files that have never been put into any information bank.
 
Hard Decisions
 Peter G. Neumann, an independent computer security expert, said intelligence administrators faced a dilemma as to how they want to fashion their computer systems.
One one hand, he said, they could put everything into separate compartments, on data banks that are not allowed to mingle with each other. But that would make for a highly inefficient system in which analysts and case officers are denied knowledge they need, said Mr. Neumann, the principal scientist in the computer science lab of SRI International of Menlo Park, Calif.
The second approach, he said, is to pool all the information and allow access to everybody with a security clearance.
Many of the C.I.A.'s data bases operate independently of the telephone lines or other common carriers and are thus supposedly impervious to penetration from outside. The agency also has always maintained that none of its systems of maintaining classified information are linked with any system containing nonclassified information.

HEADLINE: German Violence Worries Investors

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BERLIN, Dec. 31

 BODY:
The wave of violence against foreigners in Germany is beginning to affect the economy, scaring away investors and tourists and endangering Berlin's bid to attract the Olympic Games in 2000, business leaders say.
They are urging the Government to take stronger measures to combat the violence, which they say threatens efforts to pull Germany out of its recession. 
 "The spreading anti-foreigner violence is causing greater damage than any of us realize," Michael Fuchs, head of the German Association of Wholesalers and Exporters, told a recent meeting of the group in Bonn.
Another prominent business leader, Tyll Neckar, president of the German Chamber of Industry, told a business audience in Cologne that investors were turning away because they feared the growing violence. "Germany is strongly export-oriented," he said. "The view that Germany is hostile to foreigners can seriously damage our economy."
 
Small Cadres, Big Problems
 Attacks against foreigners and their homes have become almost daily occurrences in Germany. Many have been committed by young people who identify themselves as neo-Nazis.
Much of the violence, particularly in eastern Germany, has been attributed to existing economic problems. If investment and tourism drop substantially because of right-wing violence, Germany could find itself caught in a cycle in which unrest and economic problems reinforce each other.
According to the federal police, there are 6,000 to 7,000 Germans of the far right, a small number compared with the hundreds of thousands who have taken to the streets in recent weeks to repudiate their racist acts. Nonetheless, the violence has tarnished Germany's image in the world.
"The first question every foreign company asks is about hostility toward foreigners," said Walter Rogg, who directs efforts to attract investors to the eastern province of Saxony.
 
Turning Away
 Officials and business executives who until recently sought to play down their concerns are now increasingly speaking out to warn of the potential economic impact of the violence.
In Dresden, the capital of Saxony, officials said that they used to receive an inquiry from a foreign investor about once every 10 days, but that in recent months they have received none at all. Business leaders from Dresden recently announced that they had postponed a visit to the United States in search of investors, concluding that reports of violence here made any successes improbable.
In Brandenburg, the province that surrounds Berlin, at least one foreign company, which an official identified as a United States furniture concern, has withdrawn its offer to build a new factory. Brandenburg's economics minister, Walter Hirsche, said he believed the withdrawal was partly attributable to the recent violence. He also said he had had to face "unfriendly questions" from investors in Japan on a recent visit there.
 
Privatization Slows
 Administrators of Treuhand, the agency responsible for selling thousands of companies once owned by the East German Government, say their ability to attract foreign buyers has been damaged.
Treuhand officials denied recent news reports that two large United States banks had recently dropped plans to invest here, but Birgit Breuel, president of Treuhand, acknowledged that she was "being forced to explain the situation ever more intensively."
The Treuhand representative in Switzerland, Fritz Leutwiler, a former president of the Swiss National Bank, said he was worried that if the violence continued, Treuhand might have trouble raising money in the international market. That would pose a new burden on the economy, because Treuhand is a heavy borrower and expects to run up a deficit of over $150 billion by the time it completes privatization in 1994.
"It's important for Germany to show it can tackle this problem," Mr. Leutwiler said at a recent news conference. "If it can't, then I'd be concerned about the reaction in the very sensitive international markets."
 
Decline in Tourism
 Tourism officials report a decline, attributing it mainly to concern about rightist violence.
Visits by foreign tourists to eastern Germany have fallen by 6 percent to 10 percent from 1991, according to a Dresden-based tourism official, Kathrin Hillig. The greatest decline was among the Japanese, British and Americans, who feel "definitely insecure" about Germany, she said. There has been a smaller but noticeable drop in western Germany.
Among Germany's principal sources of international trade are the hundreds of expositions held here each year. Organizers now fear that exhibitors will drift toward competing events in other countries.
"Expositions in Germany are considered the most important ones in the world," said Claus Borner, director of the association that supervises most of the large expositions. "It is vital that foreigners feel they can rely on good service and a friendly atmosphere."
Many business executives support Berlin's bid to hold the Olympic Games in 2000, but some fear the city's chances are fading. A recent study by Berliner Bank predicted that the Olympics would inject about $3 billion into the German economy.
 
Competing for the Olympics
 The director of Berlin's effort to attract the Olympics, Axel Nawrocki, said questions about Germany's ability to protect foreign athletes and spectators were becoming "steadily more urgent."
"We have to get this situation under control quickly, or we can forget our bid for the Olympics," Mr. Nawrocki said in a television interview last month.
The International Olympic Committee is to choose the site in September; the leading competitors include Beijing, Sydney, Australia, and Manchester, England.
"I'm worried about the ever more pressing questions from my colleagues in the I.O.C. about anti-foreigner sentiment and right-wing radicalism in Germany," wrote Thomas Bach, a German who is a member of the committee, in a newspaper commentary this week. "This climate contradicts the Olympic spirit, since in the Olympic village everyone is a 'foreigner.' "
 
Cultural Erosion
 Even the Goethe Institute, which operates German-language schools and cultural centers around the world, has felt the effect of rightist violence here. The institute's president, Hans Heigert, said last month in his annual report to Parliament that enrollment was dropping because of an "enormous wave of antipathy" toward Germany.
According to Mr. Heigert's report, the Goethe Institute is losing students in Italy, Greece and the United States, and in many Asian countries. In Korea, the number of applicants for language courses reported fell 30 percent in 1992.
Business executives are taking steps to combat these trends.
Large companies like Porsche and public employers like the Frankfurt Airport Authority have announced that they will discipline or dismiss workers who speak against foreigners or are implicated in attacks.
In a joint statement last week, owners of large textile firms and leaders of textile trade unions said they would not tolerate actions against foreigners.
"We are in full agreement that the work environment is intolerably disturbed by employees who foment hatred of foreigners or participate in violence," the statement said. "We will separate ourselves from such employees."
 
'Each of Us Must Play a Part'
 Backers of Berlin's Olympic bid are distributing leaflets warning that the city "can only hope to tackle the tasks of the future through openness and through support of its multicultural lifestyle."
"In recent weeks, a small but dangerous group of extremists have launched cowardly attacks on asylum-seekers and other minorities in this country, injuring individuals and attacking property," the leaflets say. "The full power of the law must be applied against those who instigate and participate in such abominable crimes and senseless aggression. However, it is not sufficient simply to rely on others to solve the problem. Each one of us must play a part by standing up for human rights and speaking out for justice."
Edzard Reuter, the chairman of Daimler-Benz and perhaps the most powerful and widely respected businessman in Germany, sent a letter to his employees this month calling on them to do everything possible "to nip this evil in the bud."
"Criminal fanatics in our country want to get rid of foreigners," Mr. Reuter wrote. "They are not even stopping at murder. This ought to be a cause for serious alarm to everyone in Germany.
"Particularly when the signs of the times point to crisis because of the global recession, which is also hitting us in full force, irrational behavior and violence must not be allowed to take over. Tolerance and cosmopolitanism are the orders of the day."

HEADLINE: Now Bowing Out, a Busy, Busy Bush

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31

 BODY:
After 1,450 seamless days of state dinners, brush-fire wars, telephone diplomacy and global jet excursions, George Bush's Presidency is now rapidly winding down. The same cannot be said of George Bush.
Just 20 days remain until Bill Clinton takes the inaugural oath and his Oval Office desk, a period at which most lame ducks have stopped governing and begun untangling their fishing reels. 
 Mr. Bush is overseas, meeting with Arabian royalty and spending the holiday with American troops, in the style of his 1990 Thanksgiving visit to Saudi Arabia before the Persian Gulf war. On Saturday he is to fly to the Kremlin for a summit meeting with Boris N. Yeltsin, much as he did 18 months ago with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
 
Farewell Speech Weighed
 He is handing out medals and promotions with some abandon. He is working the phones to rally global support for new action against Serbia. Aides say he is mulling an Eisenhower-style farewell speech, perhaps for a television broadcast, and even considered -- briefly -- a State of the Union speech next month, just as if he were starting a second term.
Mr. Clinton has seen to that. But Mr. Bush is the Timex President: having taken a licking, he is still ticking, with no clear indication of stopping anytime soon.
One associate said: "The chance of accomplishing some substantive things before he goes out has energized him. He sees the possibility of leaving his successor a much better situation than he found when he came in in 1989."
The President's burst of activity can also be viewed more skeptically, as a final attempt by a proud and self-conscious leader to restore a gloss to his Presidency that economic hard times and his humbling election defeat have diminished.
At the urging of friends and advisers, Mr. Bush tried his hand at history writing two weeks ago, delivering a foreign-policy speech in Texas that effectively defended his strategy of projecting American political power -- and military force -- into the world's trouble spots.
Even some friends conclude that his overseas trip this weekend, however justified by events, was intended to remind the public of his Presidency's greatest triumphs on the battlefield and at cold-war negotiating tables.
"It's a victory lap," one said. "You go to the places that are winners. You don't see him going to Bosnia, do you?"
Whatever his motives, Mr. Bush's activity stands in sharp contrast to the rest of the White House, which that same associate described as "on auto-pilot, with most of the staff looking for jobs, a diminishing number coming to work, fewer cars parked on West Executive Avenue" next to the White House, "and those that are there arriving later every morning."
With no more budgets to prepare and no legislation to package, the Administration is reduced largely to handling foreign policy and its own public relations, and those offices have been the only busy ones at the White House during the holidays.
Mr. Bush himself seemed on auto-pilot barely a month ago. Shrouded in gloom after his defeat, he took secluded vacations, complained publicly about his irrelevance and seemed to grant Mr. Clinton early possession of the trappings of Presidential pomp and importance.
Time and some frank discussions in mid-November with advisers, who warned that he was endangering his public image and possibly his legacy, seem to have given Mr. Bush some perspective on his loss. Several aides also said Mr. Bush was roused by the need to deal with crises in Somalia and Bosnia, and the prospect that his Administration's signal accomplishment -- a treaty to reduce Russian and American nuclear stockpiles by two-thirds -- would collapse amid bickering over details.
With a lot to do and little time in which to do it, Mr. Bush became his old frenetic self, aides say, and he began serious work to make the last days of his term both more productive and more upbeat.
"He's enjoying his days," one aide said. "He's trying to do some things that he didn't have either the chance or the freedom to do during the campaign," when every act was seen through a political filter. It is a change, aides say, that has manifested itself in ways large and small.
Behind headline-making acts like foreign trips and military mobilizations, Mr. Bush has taken on the role of White House and Republican Party morale officer. Early in December he set aside an hour or so daily to invite employees and their families to the Oval Office, where he chatted while White House photographers snapped photos that Mr. Bush would later autograph and present as gifts. Next month he is to be host at a series of White House meetings with major groups of Republican financial supporters.
 
Coveted Promotions
 And he has rewarded some loyal aides with appointments that carry more symbolism than power, but are coveted nonetheless. At the suggestion of friends, he elevated Lawrence S. Eagleburger to Secretary of State, removing the "Acting" from his title by making a formal appointment while Congress was in recess, and assuring Mr. Eagleburger a more prominent place in history books.
He did the same for Sean O'Keefe, an acting Navy Secretary, who now will occupy that post for the second briefest stretch of time in military history. (The briefest occupant, described by a Pentagon spokesman as "the hapless Thomas W. Gilmer," served from Feb. 19 to 25, 1844.)
And he has dispensed favors and awards to a curious mix of personalities, some of whom were utterly unaware of Mr. Bush's fondness for them.
Two comedians who are Bush favorites, Dana Carvey and Johnny Carson, were rewarded this month with invitations to become overnight guests at the White House. Mr. Carson was granted the Medal of Freedom, the nation's highest civilian honor, given so far to 301 people "who have made especially meritorious contributions to the security or national interests of the United States, to world peace or to cultural or other significant public and private endeavors."
Among others who met that standard, and were awarded medals on Dec. 11, were Richard Petty, the retired stock-car driver who campaigned with Mr. Bush this fall; Ella Fitzgerald and Isaac Stern, who have performed at state dinners; Harry W. Shlaudeman, the diplomat; the journalist David Brinkley and the architect I. M. Pei.
 
Major Speech Planned
 To close out his term, aides say, the President is planning at least one more major speech reflecting on his years in public life, probably for delivery at the United States Naval Academy in Annapolis, Md.
Aides have suggested that he return to Congress for a final State of the Union Message or a farewell speech, adding that he could diminish any aura of grandstanding by inviting President-elect Clinton and his Cabinet to attend. But Mr. Bush is said to have emphatically rejected the idea.
Several aides, including his friend and chief of staff, James A. Baker 3d, are said to still be urging a more visible address on national television, but the President is said to favor a more muted approach to his last days in office.
The symbolic end to Mr. Bush's Presidency is likely to precede the official end by about a week. On Jan. 13, the President will escort his predecessor, Ronald Reagan, into the White House East Room and present him with the same Medal of Freedom granted Mr. Carson, Mr. Petty and others.
With the help of Mr. Reagan's old team of public-relations aides, who have assembled a glittering audience for the presentation, "it's turning out to be quite an event," a White House aide said today.

HEADLINE: Economic Pulse: The Washington Region;
Once-Booming Megalopolis Is Struggling With Harder Times

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEVERN, Md., Dec. 31

 BODY:
At first glance, it could be the good old days all over again, just the way things were a couple of years back, before the recession hit this little rural patch sandwiched between the suburbs of Baltimore and Washington.
Bulldozers are ripping out lots for new subdivisions. Concrete trucks are pouring foundations. Carpenters are hammering together wall frames, and the signs pounded into the raw earth in front of the new houses read, "Sold . . . Sold . . . Sold." 
 But while the signs may suggest some economic rejuvenation in this town 25 miles northeast of Washington, there is concern that the post-recession pace here and elsewhere in the heavily urbanized "Chesapeake Crescent" that stretches from Baltimore to Norfolk will never equal the raging boom of the 1980's, when it became one of the country's major megalopolises.
During that decade, the population grew at twice the national rate, to nine million people, driven more than anything else by growth in the Federal Government and in the industries that grew up around it. In the mid-1980's, for example, unemployment rates fell below 2 percent in the Virginia suburbs outside Washington, a level that labor experts say represented little more than people in the midst of changing jobs rather than people out of work.
In the Washington area per-capita income topped out at $26,000 in the mid-1980's, almost 50 percent more than the national average. Some residential and commercial real estate markets, especially those in and around Washington, heated up so much that the values of many homes jumped 30 percent or more in a single year and suburban wooded plots became condominium developments.
 
Sobering Changes In Area's Economy
 Today, battered by job layoffs, bankruptcies and general economic malaise, many of the region's residents are for the first time mulling the possibility that the soaring prosperity of the 1980's was a once-in-a-lifetime phenomenon. Increasingly they see the boom as having been sustained by real estate speculation, undisciplined consumer spending and unbridled growth in Federal spending on the region's heavy concentration of Government agencies, workers and military installations.
"It'll be a long time, if ever, before we see the likes of the 80's again in this region," says Steve Fuller, an urban planning consultant in Washington who specializes in economic and development trends in the region. "This recession has been the most sobering economic readjustment for this part of the country since the Great Depression."
This is a new kind of talk in a region whose 16 percent population growth in the 1980's left it ranking third in the nation in population, employment and retail sales, behind only the metropolitan areas of New York and Los Angeles.
No one thinks mortal economic danger now threatens the Crescent, as some have come to call the 250-mile-long megalopolis, which is centered on Washington and complete with cities bumping against one another, 30-mile strings of suburbs and hourlong rail commutes to work.
But the recession has left many of the region's once high-flying real estate speculators bankrupt, their subdivisions half finished, their office towers vacant. Many of the region's shop-till-you-drop baby boomers are deeply in debt, out of work and standing in long lines to apply for jobs. And while many here believe that the incoming Clinton Administration will continue and even increase some Federal expenditures, many agencies' budgets are likely to be cut severely, especially the mainstay military outlays.
The houses being built here are selling for less than $200,000, about half what many were bringing before the recession, and many businesses, including banks and retailers, are reshaping operations to reduce expenses.
Before the recession, for example, one of every five tellers at Crestar Bank, a Richmond-based regional financial institution, worked part time. Now that figure is almost one in three. The blunt rationale is that part-timers are less costly because most get no health or retirement benefits.
In Baltimore, Polk Audio, a manufacturer of stereo speakers, says it was forced to revise its business to handle cheaper lines, some as inexpensive as $200 a pair. In the 1980's, the company was selling speakers for $3,500 a pair as fast as it could make them.
 
Blurred Boundaries Form Megalopolis
 During the booming 1980's, the suburbs spilling north out of Washington and south out of Baltimore quickly collided, and the suburbs spilling south from Washington began to bump up against those creeping north from Fredericksburg, 50 miles away. A Fredericksburg-Washington commuter train line opened several months ago, helping to bind the megalopolis.
Farther down the region, Richmond stretched north almost to Ashland and south almost to Petersburg, while Norfolk became the center of a large urban area stretching from Virginia Beach almost up to Williamsburg.
The region has become so densely populated that the Federal Office of Management and Budget notified officials in Baltimore and Washington earlier this year that for statistical purposes it would view the region that stretches more than 100 miles from near the Pennsylvania border north of Baltimore south through Washington to Fredericksburg as a single urban entity. The western edge of that corridor extends into West Virginia.
As the population density has increased, social and economic links within the region have also grown. For example, in Severn and nearby towns residents may work in Washington, shop at a Severn mall and go to Baltimore for dining or entertainment. Federal transportation experts say the traffic jams now found in the Washington-Baltimore area rival some of the worst found in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles.
William F. Treacy, an economist, comes from one of those in-between towns, Burtonsville, Md. For many years he worked at a Baltimore bank but recently switched to a job with the Federal Reserve Bank in Washington.
"It's now just all one big region to me," he says. "The cities are different in lifestyles and tone, and that's the way I use them. And with the road and rail networks now available, it's easy to go either way."
 
Economy Tied To Federal Budgets
 Still, the dominant mood in the region is sober -- even in the Washington area, once thought to be recession-proof thanks to the Federal government. There is little expectation that the new Administration's faces and policies will recreate the conditions that led to the boom of the 1980's.
Only 18,000 new jobs were created in the Washington area during the first nine months of 1992, about one-third the yearly growth during the boom period.
There has been less unemployment in most parts of the region during the recession than elsewhere in the country. As of September, unemployment was running from a high of 7.6 percent in the Baltimore area to 5.1 percent in metropolitan Washington, compared with 7.2 percent nationally. Nevertheless, the region has suffered.
Richmond, a city whose diverse economy has cushioned the pain of earlier downturns, has just recorded the worst job loss of any metropolitan area in the state -- a 1.7 percent drop between September 1991 and September 1992, more than triple the loss in the state as a whole. Its unemployment rate now stands at 6.3 percent.
Any analysis of what drives the region's economy comes down to Federal money. During the last decade, according to the most recent surveys available, total Federal spending in the region increased more than 50 percent, reaching nearly $75 billion a year. In contrast, total Federal expenditures in New York City at the end of the decade were about $65 billion and slightly more than $50 billion in Los Angeles.
Some studies indicate that Federal spending and the buying and hiring they generate now account for two-thirds of the economy in the metropolitan Washington area and spill over to other parts of the megalopolis.
"Last year, right in the middle of a recession, the U.S. Government spent over $47 billion in all in the greater Washington area, 11 percent more than in 1990," says Philip M. Dearborn, who recently took a close look at Federal spending in the region for the Greater Washington Research Center. "In Baltimore and Norfolk the increase wasn't as sharp, but the overall expenditure still came to more than $23 billion, which means the Government poured more than $70 billion into the region in a single year, just counting three of its major cities."
 
Relative Wealth And Revised Hopes
 This Federal largess produced an average per-capita income throughout most of the region that easily topped the national average of $18,600. In the Washington area, where almost half the region's population lives, per-capita income has hit $26,000.
Even so, the recession hit hard, and many businesses that survived the downturn did so by making hard choices.
"We're coming out of it, but there are changes in the marketplace and in consumer patterns that will keep us from climbing back to where we were," says Alan M. Gayle, chief economist for Crestar Bank. "These changes are nobody's fault in a larger sense. They relate to competition and demographics and cutbacks in Government activity."
Matthew S. Polk, the chairman of Polk Audio, says he expects the 1990's to be a good decade. But he says he believes the voracious consumption of the past decade will not recur in the foreseeable future, because the baby boomers who accounted for much of it have satisfied many material desires and now face new responsibilities, like large mortgages and steep college tuitions. They have also been brought down to earth by unemployment, bankruptcies and a leveling of salaries, he said.
Here in Severn, the reformation of the housing market has resulted in construction of homes that are much more modest than those completed before the recession.
"Today's home buyers are looking for housing, not an investment," says Robert M. Lefenfeld, a housing specialist for the Legg Mason Realty Group in Baltimore. "When they buy now, they're buying no more than they need, with few frills."
Among recent home purchasers here is Mitch Everton, a 33-year-old intelligence specialist for the Defense Department. He had been looking for a new house for a number of years but waited until the recession drove down prices and interest rates.
"They were offering the right place at the right price at the right time," he says. "I wanted it simple. They said they had just the right new design and that they'd throw in some extras that I'd never otherwise have ordered, like an extra fireplace. I bought."
But when it comes to commercial real estate, hardly anybody is buying, renting or building in the region.
In downtown Baltimore and in the Northern Virginia suburbs across the Potomac River from Washington, pre-recession speculation in commercial buildings was white hot. Today, there is a huge surplus of commercial space.
But there is at least one bright spot. Even in hard times, the Federal Government and the lawyers and lobbyists who must deal with it require offices close to the White House, the Capitol and the major agencies. As a result, demand for commercial realty has been brisk in the Pennsylvania Avenue area throughout the recession, and it may pick up in the Clinton Administration.
In fact, throughout the recession office rents in downtown Washington have continued to rise, and that area now has the highest average office rents in the country -- $38 a square foot.

HEADLINE: A Single Market for Consumers Takes Effect Today in Europe

 BODY:
Today is the day a single market goes into effect in Western Europe, linking 345 million people in the 12 nations of the European Community by eliminating tariff and customs barriers. Most steps to reach this goal have been taken gradually over the past five years, so it will be hard for most people to tell what has changed, and indeed, much has not changed. Despite a European Parliament and an executive commission in Brussels, there is nothing resembling a European federal government, and a "United States of Europe" still seems a long way off.
 
 
What's Good for Business
 The big benefit is to business. Companies licensed to produce or sell financial services in one country can now do so in all the others; public-works contracts are to be offered to bidders in all countries, not just domestically. But whether this works in practice remains to be seen. 
 In the long run the absence of trade barriers should make European industries more competitive with rivals in North America and Asia; for consumers, increased competition among companies within Europe should lead to lower prices.
But the prospect of a boom seems dim: Britain has been in a recession since 1989 and Germany is entering one, and most of the rest of Europe is just holding its own.
Companies may now ship goods to other nations without time-consuming and costly border checks, and they can shift money from one country to another with little difficulty, providing financial flexibility and making it easier to treat Europe as a single market. But some nations still have restrictions on moving money.
Citizens of each of the 12 nations may purchase goods in other nations without having to pay export or import duties, within certain limits and as long as the goods are for personal use. This will increase cross-border shopping by consumers seeking bargains arising from different levels of domestic taxation or varying prices, but the same factors of distance, travel and so on that inhibit New York City customers from shopping in, say South Carolina, come into play, with the added complication of currency exchange fees. Most countries have guidelines for what constitutes personal use -- Britain puts the limit for wine at 144 bottles per trip -- but even those rules will be sparingly applied.
 
Standards Are Not Standard
 National regulatory restrictions remain on industries like airlines and telecommunications, limiting competition and keeping prices higher than they might be.
Some restrictions will be eliminated in coming years. Airlines, for example, will gain new freedom to operate across Europe in 1997.
The community has made considerable progress in harmonizing regulatory and safety standards. But it has not fully achieved its goal of allowing all products that can be legally sold in one nation to be sold in another. An automobile that meets emissions and safety requirements in one nation can be automatically registered in any other, though some changes may have to be made promptly to meet local requirements; vastly different rules apply, however, to sales of prescription drugs, for example.
 
Money Talks in Many Tongues
 There is no single European currency, nor any realistic prospect of one before the end of the century, if at all. There is an agreement on currency, the 1991 Treaty on European Political and Monetary Union, but it has not yet been ratified by Denmark and Britain.
Though corporate money can flow much more freely across borders, currency transfers by individuals are still cumbersome. Changing French francs into Belgian francs, guilders into marks, lire into drachmas, each transaction carries a fee. If a traveler went from one to another of all 12 countries and changed currencies in each one, the exchange fees would eat up the entire initial travel budget.
Citizens of one nation may open bank accounts and borrow from financial institutions in others, something that has not always been possible until now. But this procedure will be limited in Portugal and Greece for several years.
 
Passport, Passeport, Reisepass
 Passport checks will continue in most places for travelers arriving by air, because converting airports is complicated and expensive. Britain, Ireland, Denmark and Greece will also continue spot checks of European Community passports when travelers arrive, to prevent third-country stowaways.
All 12 nations retain normal passport controls on travelers arriving from outside the community. But once within the community, passport checks will be less rigorous than in the past, especially for road and rail travelers.
 
Travelers Stay Unplugged
 A traveler with an electric hair dryer or razor will continue to have problems -- not with voltage, which is basically 220 volts almost everywhere, but with plugs. In Britain they're three-pronged. In Germany, France, Italy and Spain, they're two-pronged. But German prongs are thicker than those in France, Italy, or Spain, so they won't fit.
Telephones and modems used to link computers remain much different from one country to another.
Nor is there a unified system of long-distance telephone codes, emergency or information numbers in Europe.
There are national codes -- Britain is 44, Germany is 49. But to dial Germany from Britain, the code is 01-049; to dial from Germany to Britain, it's 00-44.
 
Homes Away From Home
 Every citizen of a common market nation has the right to move to any of the others, provided this does not cause a financial drain on the new place of residence.
Thus, workers from Spain can apply for jobs in Stuttgart and move to Germany if they get jobs, which they have been able to do for some time. But they cannot move first and then collect unemployment benefits from Germany if they cannot find work.
Doctors licensed by one nation will be able to practice in another, as will most other professionals. But there are catches that make setting up business in another country difficult, or that reduce the potential for increased competition and lower prices for consumers. An architect seeking to practice in Spain, for example, must join a professional association that sets minimum fees.
Retired people may more from one country to another and collect their pensions; they are also expected to keep their medical benefits.
But mass migrations are not expected, mainly because of cultural and language difficulties.
 
Where the Tax Gaps Remain
 While almost all customs duties and other barriers will be eliminated as of today, excise taxes and differences in sales taxes remain, just as they do within the United States.
The value-added tax, or VAT, effectively a sales tax on almost all goods and services, varied from 19.5 percent in Belgium to 13 percent in Spain. As of today, the minimum basic rate is 15 percent, but the rates still vary from Belgium's 19.5 percent (and over 20 percent on some items in Denmark and Ireland) to 15 percent in Germany, Spain and Luxembourg.
Countries may levy a higher VAT on luxury goods and a lower one or none at all on a few necessities.
Excise taxes also continue to vary. In Denmark, for instance, a luxury tax triples the cost of automobiles. Taxes on alcohol are relatively low in Greece and Italy, high in Denmark.
Duty-free shops will remain. Eventually the community hopes to eliminate the need for them by harmonizing the level of duties on all products within each country, but that is not likely to be complete for years.
For travelers within the European Community, the volume of duty-free items will now effectively be doubled, since one lot of goods may be bought on the journey to another nation and another lot on the way home. (Limits on duty-free purchases will not change for travelers to and from other nations, including the United States.)
Automobiles remain a nightmare. In theory a car can be bought cheap in France and taken to Britain, but in practice there is an enormous amount of paperwork, the headlights have to be changed to white from yellow and the buyer must meet a host of other British requirements.
Britain also still requires a six-month quarantine for animals, which the continental nations do not.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Markets
It was a mixed year for many parts of Wall Street, with the mergers meager and the Dow Jones dowdy. But in the classic business of raising capital for corporations, the underwritings set another record as companies replaced high-interest debt they accumulated in the 1980's with lower-rate debt and equity. [D1.]
On overseas exchanges, "it was an entirely forgettable year," said one analyst, reflecting the view of many. True, there was money made on some stocks abroad. But the gains were confined to small markets whose currencies were either tied to the dollar or at least not tied to the German mark. For the third straight year, staying home turned out to be the best bet. [D1.] 
 The Nasdaq average marched to a third straight daily record, while the Dow fell under a last-minute barrage of program trading. The Nasdaq composite index of over-the-counter stocks was up 5.10 points, to 676.95. The Dow Jones industrial average, ahead several points with a half-hour to go, suddenly plunged about 25 points to close down 19.99 for the day, to 3301.11. [D2.]
Treasury bond prices sank in quiet, abbreviated trading. Analysts attributed the decline to a larger-than-expected drop in weekly unemployment claims and to traders' cashing in their year-end profits. [D9.]
Prices of cattle futures surged on forecasts of weekend snow in the Great Plains. Heating oil led energy futures lower after the American Petroleum Institute estimated an increase in United States supplies. [D10.]
The dollar ended the day mixed on world financial markets, in thin trading. Gold prices were mostly lower. [D10.]
 
The Economy
First-time unemployment claims tumbled 28,000, driving the four-week average to the lowest point since late 1989, the Labor Department reported, a sign that the economy's growing strength is spreading to the job market. A separate report indicated that factory orders climbed five-tenths of 1 percent in November, excluding transportation equipment. [D1.]
 
Companies
A judge explained her rejection of Zenith's Air Force contract, saying the $740 million worth of computers would have contained too many imported parts. [D1.]
Charter Medical settled with the Attorney General of Texas, agreeing to pay $550,000, to provide $1.6 million of charitable mental health services and to refrain from practices that had drawn a state investigation. [D3.]
A realty bonanza appears unlikely for Catellus Development, the company formed with fanfare when Santa Fe Pacific spun off real estate holdings two years ago. Catellus's stock has been limping near a 52-week low. [D3.]
A gadget market founded by Fuji Photo is booming in Japan: disposable cameras. Snap-happy Japanese consumers are rejecting their sophisticated, expensive equipment in favor of the throwaways. [D6.]

HEADLINE: Another Record Year for Wall St. Underwriters

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
The mergers were meager; the Dow Jones was dowdy; the trading was treacherous. It was a mixed year for many parts of Wall Street. Yet in its classic business of raising capital for companies, the underwritings were unbelievable.
Corporations sold a record $584.3 billion of securities in the United States' public markets in 1991. And to Wall Street's surprise, the total for 1992 increased 45 percent, with $744.4 billion in debt and $101.6 billion in equity, according to data provided by the Securities Data Corporation. 
 With the economy limping along, corporations were generally not raising money to finance new investments. Rather, they were replacing high-interest debt they accumulated in the 1980's with lower-rate debt and equity. More than a third of the bond issuers were simply corporations calling existing bonds and issuing new ones at lower interest rates, investment bankers said.
Conglomerates and leveraged-buyout firms that wanted to sell business units found the most eager buyers were in the public new-issue market, since corporations were loath to commit themselves to new acquisitions. At the same time, falling short-term rates encouraged both institutional and individual investors to search for more attractive opportunities like longer-term bonds, new stock issues and convertible securities. Investors poured more than $68 billion into equity mutual funds in the first 11 months of the year, and much of that wound up buying new issues.
"Mutual funds have driven the new-issue market this year," compared with previous years when there was a broader range of buyers, said Vikram S. Pandid, head of the equity syndicate desk at Morgan Stanley. "On most deals, 7 of the top 10 buyers were funds."
 For all the rosy totals, it was in fact a rocky year for both the equity and debt markets. The initial public offering market sizzled in the early part of the year, then screeched abruptly to a halt in the summer as investors balked at what they saw as overpriced deals of marginal quality. In the last few months, however, investors were again buying new issues, although at lower prices.
Similarly, after starting out the year with a boom, corporate bond issuance began to slow as interest rates paid to investors moved closer to Treasury issues of similar maturities. "There was turmoil in the market, and in October investors called a timeout," said Edson V. Mitchell, head of debt financing for Merrill Lynch.
In recent weeks, new issues have resumed after spreads widened somewhat.
To many investment bankers, one of the biggest surprises of the year was how easily the market absorbed huge issues. There were more than 25 debt and equity issues that each raised more than $1 billion in United States markets, including a number of exotic offerings that cannot be classified as either stocks or bonds.
 General Motors, despite its persistent losses and management turmoil, sold $1.56 billion of common stock in the United States in May as part of a $2.15 billion global issue, the largest common stock issue ever by an American company. And the Chemical Banking Corporation raised $1.23 billion in common stock after its merger with the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation.
The largest debt deals were bonds representing pools of credit card and auto loans, in which payments flow through to bondholders. Over all, however, issuance of these asset-backed securities was flat last year because banks were less willing to sell off loans with new lending opportunities scarce. As home owners continued to refinance mortgages, issuance of mortgage-backed securities shot up 51 percent, to $377.3 billion.
Among the most pronounced shifts last year, the junk bond market finally began to recover from the trauma of Drexel Burnham Lambert's 1990 collapse. Investors bought 232 junk issues last year for a total of $38 billion, more than three times the amount raised the previous year.
"There has been a convergence between the high-yield and the investment-grade markets in the types of buyers, the issuers and the way deals are done," said Mr. Mitchell of Merrill Lynch. "It used to be two separate markets, but it's becoming a single corporate bond market."
 
 
Merrill Leads Again
 Merrill Lynch was again the leading underwriter of all types of securities, managing the issuance of $140 billion of domestic issues, 16.5 percent of the total. Goldman, Sachs was second, followed in the same order as in 1991 by Lehman Brothers, First Boston and Kidder, Peabody.
Merrill continued to dominate all categories of debt except mortgage-backed and asset-backed issues, in which Kidder was the leading underwriter. Merrill also captured first place last year in the common-stock category from Goldman.
Salomon Brothers, which fell precipitously in the 1991 rankings in the wake of a Treasury bond auction scandal, edged up slightly last year, finishing in sixth place over all, up from seventh.
The new-issue boom was largely centered in the United States. Issuance of international debt and equity -- that is, deals outside of the United States involving issuers and investors in more than one country -- rose slightly, to $282 billion. As interest rates come down, investment bankers expect that some of the same trends that moved money into the capital markets in the United States will take hold in Europe.
As for the American market, most of the trends that caused last year's boom in new issues are likely to remain in place, at least for a few months, bankers said, but they remain cautious. "By historical standards, this year will be above average," said Thomas W. Davis, head of equity capital markets at Merrill Lynch. But, he added, "I would be surprised if it is as strong as 1992."

HEADLINE: A Disappointing 1992 for Many Global Investors

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
For most international investors, particularly those who placed their money in big, liquid foreign stock markets, 1992 promised much more than it delivered. For the third straight year, home -- not East or West -- was mostly best for American investors.
Money was made overseas, of course, but the gains were confined to small markets whose currencies were either tied to the dollar, like Mexico's, or not tied to the German mark, like Switzerland's. 
 "For most, it was an entirely forgettable year," said Jeffrey Russell, a manager of Smith Barney, Harris Upham's World Funds International Equity portfolio. "Economic conditions were difficult in many countries, European growth decelerated and in many parts of the world interest rates were extraordinarily high."
 
Greater Expectations
 Expectations were much different 12 months ago.
Nineteen ninety-two was to be the Year of Europe, of vigorous growth in Japan and a building recovery in the United States.
But the Danes, then the British, torpedoed Europe's timetable, with help from the Bundesbank in Germany, whose tight monetary policies and high interest rates caused pain across the Continent. Japan's economy, rather than growing, started to crack. And proof of America's recovery, such as it is, failed to materialize until late in the year.
With the exception of stocks in the United States, share prices were preyed upon by these various international woes.
Excluding the exchanges in the United States, prices on world stock markets fell by more than 15 percent in dollar terms last year, according to the world index of The Financial Times of London. In America, where equity investors took some comfort from steady declines in interest rates during the year, stock prices rose by 4.83 percent, according to The Financial Times.
"It was the year of the false dawn," said Marcus Grubb, an international equity strategist at Salomon Brothers in London. "But it was not until May that the season of hope ended and the season of reality began."
It was in May that Danish voters upset Europe's ambitious plans for monetary and economic unification by delivering a stunning "no" vote to the Maastricht treaty, the first in a chain of events that culminated in late September, when the British Government jolted international financial markets by pulling the pound out of the European Monetary System.
That decision gave the Bank of England latitude to push down interest rates, and in the fourth quarter British stock prices reacted favorably, rising by more than 12 percent in local currency. But the good news in the City of London was decidedly less than that for dollar-based investors in British stocks. Because of the sharp fourth-quarter rally in the dollar's value against the pound, those local currency gains turned into a decline of roughly 4.2 percent when share values were translated into dollars.
"I would be very confident the rest of the world will outperform the United States in 1993 but for two reasons," said David Testa, chairman of the T. Rowe Price International Stock Fund. "One is the dollar, and whether or not it is likely to get even stronger. The other is Japan, which we think is likely to remain troubled for much of the year."
 
Japan's 3-Year Slide
 The world's most highly capitalized stock market in 1989, the Tokyo exchange has had a disastrous performance ever since. Japanese stocks fell 22.67 percent last year in dollar terms, the third straight year of decline.
"Nobody expected that the slowdown in the Japanese economy would be as great as it was," said Sander Cseh, president of Cseh International, a Berwyn, Pa., money management firm.
Japan's problems were of little concern to investors in Hong Kong, whose market produced the world's highest return in 1992 -- 25.63 percent in dollar terms -- or in Malaysia, which placed second, with 22.07 percent.
"Hong Kong combines the attractive aspects of relatively inexpensive multiples, decent dividend yields and strongly growing corporate earnings," said Mr. Russell of Smith Barney. "When we look around, we keep coming back to Hong Kong."
Investors came back to Mexico in droves in the fourth quarter, as objections to the North American Free Trade Act were muted and President-elect Bill Clinton gave the treaty a qualified endorsement.
Mexican stocks rose by more than 34 percent in the final three months of 1992, in dollar terms. That gain reversed a tailspin earlier in the year, and left Mexico's market 18.45 percent higher for all of 1992.
 
Wait Until This Year
 Peering into the new year, analysts seem confident the expectations that did not play out in 1992 will be realized over the next 12 months.
This year, "predictions of recovery will begin to come true," Mr. Grubb at Salomon said. "We are going to see a proper recovery in the United States and a recovery of sorts in Britain. Germany will be in recession, but we think that German rates will get cut in the first quarter of the year."
Lower German interest rates would be a big help to countries whose currencies remain in the European Monetary System, especially France.
French stock prices fell by more than 8 percent in dollar terms last year, but portfolio managers said prices on the Paris Bourse could improve considerably after a cut in German rates, which would allow the French to lower their own.
And Mr. Testa's reservations notwithstanding, some analysts said they were optimistic about Japan's prospects for the new year.
"I feel relatively good about Japan," said John R. Hickling, who manages the International Growth and Income Fund at Fidelity Investments. "There will be more bad news there because corporate profits will take some more hits and there are still problems with real estate. But I think we have crossed a subtle psychological line where bad news becomes good news."
As bad as Japan's performance was in 1992, stock markets in some other countries fared worse.
South African shares were the biggest losers, dropping by more than 40 percent in dollar terms. And Denmark, the country that by a narrow margin said it did not want Maastricht's version of the European dream, saw its share prices fall by more than 30 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
A Railroad's Legacy: Land Rich and Cash Poor

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
In the 1860's, the Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe Railroad Company, which had gorged on Federal land grants, was particularly aggressive -- and fanciful -- in marketing land abutting its line. One advertisement likened land along the Santa Fe Trail to a tropical banana tree, "known by its fruits."
More people settled the West between 1879 and 1900 than in the previous two and a half centuries, and this lure was certainly a factor. But for the modern company that inherited much of the railroad's land, even a modest real estate bonanza appears, for now, unlikely.
 
Good Market Gone Bad
 Tight credit, wary purchasers and anemic land values have combined to constrain the ambitions of the San Francisco-based Catellus Development Corporation, formed with fanfare two years ago when the Santa Fe Pacific Corporation spun off some realty holdings. Its stock has been limping along on the New York Stock Exchange near a 52-week low of $6.125, closing the year at $6.625. 
 Having moved to conserve cash and limit development risks, Catellus now faces a new test as it moves toward an offering later this month of convertible preferred stock to raise as much as $125 million.
Catellus does have one measure of security that is the envy of many competitors. A debt-to-equity deal also due to close this month would increase the equity stake of the largest pension fund in the country, California Public Employees Retirement System, or Calpers, to 43 percent, from 20 percent.
 
 
Returns Won't Come Quickly
 "Do you think Calpers will let this go under?" asked Jon Fosheim of Green Street Advisors, a Newport Beach, Calif., firm that follows publicly traded real estate companies for institutional investors. "State employees have their hard-earned money in this company."
Unlike its railroad-era predecessors, Catellus is not promising an immediate harvest of exotic fruit. "Do we provide opportunities for short-term investors? No," Vernon B. Schwartz, Catellus's chairman, chief executive and president, said.
"This is a long-term journey," said Mr. Schwartz, 42, who arrived at Santa Fe Pacific in 1989 from the Hahn Company, a major mall developer, where he had been chief operating officer. "But Wall Street wants to see your ability to create value," he said, "and it's just been impossible" because of California's weakened economy. Seventy-three percent of the company's real estate holdings are in the state.
Still, unusual among real estate companies, Catellus owns its land free and clear as part of the terms of the spinoff from its parent.
When it was spun off in November 1990, Catellus took with it 1.3 million acres in 12 states. The bulk of that, 1.2 million acres, consists of long, lonely stretches of mountain and desert, considered too remote for development. Catellus has been selling pieces of this property to Federal land agencies or swapping them for parcels elsewhere, all to finance the company's 7,721 acres considered to have a commercial future.
Though cash to develop properties is tight, Catellus has posted stable operating results, and its existing business -- industrial and commercial leasing -- is sound. Rental revenue is rising, and net income for the first nine months of 1992 was $4.6 million, in contrast to a loss of $3 million in the corresponding period a year earlier.
The company's best prospects lie in San Francisco, San Diego and Los Angeles, where it holds prime land that could provide a big payoff if California's economy improves. Chief among these holdings is the 313-acre Mission Bay development one mile from downtown San Francisco.
Ten years in the planning, the Mission Bay project hopes to build an entirely new neighborhood, with open spaces and street-level retail development. Catellus's plan won city approval easily, in part because it agreed to dedicate nearly 40 percent of its 8,500 planned residential units to "affordable" housing. The company hopes to put the first units on the market by late 1994.
Mission Bay could become Catellus's crown jewel or its albatross. "They have one irreplaceable asset, which is Mission Bay, and they need a huge cash infusion every year to keep up with the development," Mr. Fosheim said. A cash sinkhole at the largely vacant site is a heap of hazardous waste, which Catellus has agreed to clean. Mr. Schwartz declined to discuss Mission Bay's operating costs, except to call one estimate of $40 million in annual losses incorrect.
Though San Francisco embraced Catellus, it was a different story in Santa Fe, N.M. After the company presented an ambitious plan for its 36 acres of railyards on the city's west side, Santa Fe residents rebelled. Fearful for their small-scale cityscape, residents persuaded city councilors to reject the proposal. Catellus has gone back to the drawing board.
 
The Calpers Recommitment
 Despite setbacks, Catellus may well have put to rest the biggest uncertainty about its future: that is, what Calpers intended to do with a $106.5 million convertible debenture due on Dec. 31, 1994. The Bay Area Real Estate Investment Associates, a limited partnership made up of Calpers and the JMB Realty Corporation, agreed in October to convert the debenture into $141 million worth of Catellus common stock. The conversion is conditional on the completion early this year of a public offering of convertible preferred shares worth between $50 million and $125 million.
The head of investment at Calpers, Dewitt Bowman, declined to comment on the conversion, citing the registration period under way for the new shares. The pension fund's original 20 percent equity stake in Catellus, about $400 million, was valued at $38 a share at the time of the spinoff, but is now only worth a small fraction of that. Converting its debentures to stock would effectively double the Calpers stake in Catellus.
Even with a new infusion of capital, Mr. Schwartz said, Catellus would proceed cautiously, hoping to integrate urban development and transportation systems, possibly to score as big a hit as Harbor Place in Baltimore or the recasting of Union Station in Washington. The old Union Station in Los Angeles could become a showpiece if Catellus's plans get back on track.

HEADLINE: First-Time Jobless Claims Decline by 28,000

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31

 BODY:
First-time claims for unemployment benefits tumbled 28,000 in the most recent four-week reporting period, Labor Department figures indicated today. The average number of claims for the period fell to the lowest level since late 1989.
The unexpectedly sharp decline, which followed a week in which storms kept many workers from claims offices, was regarded by many as evidence that the economy's growing strength was spreading into the job market. 
 "I think you're going to see further improvement," predicted Daniel Laufenberg, an economist for IDS Financial Services in Minneapolis. Gains in output, he added, have so far been mainly a result of unsustainably rapid increases in productivity, with new hiring expected to follow inevitably.
At the same time, however, analysts said that the drop in jobless claims, to an average of 341,250 over the latest four weeks, still owed more to a slowing in layoffs than to the generation of new jobs.
They also said jobs were still considered fairly hard to find, citing the Conference Board's report this week showing only a slight increase in help-wanted advertising.
Of the 28,000 decline in claims in the week that ended on Dec. 19, the data released today showed 11,200 were in California. That change reflected fewer layoffs in the state's construction and food-processing industries.
 A separate report today showed that new orders for factory goods fell nine-tenths of a percent in November. But this news left analysts unruffled, since figures published earlier on durable goods indicated that there was a big drop in aircraft orders, which tend to move erratically.
Excluding transportation equipment, factory orders climbed five-tenths of a percent.
The nondurables half of factory orders edged up one-tenth of a percent after a small October decline and a big September advance. The previously reported level of new orders for durable goods -- those that are intended to last at least three years -- was down 1.9 percent.
Shipments of manufactured goods posted a broad rise of 1.1 percent, but unfilled orders fell nine-tenths of a percent, the 13th decline in backlogs in the last 14 months.
Declining backlogs, now at their lowest point in four years, imply that the current work force has so far been adequate to handle the flow of new business.
 
 
Inventories Decline 0.5%
 Factory inventories declined five-tenths of a percent, the biggest decline of the year and a development suggesting that higher orders would promptly translate into fresh production.
In all, the Commerce Department report showed November orders of $242.6 billion, shipments of $247 billion, unfilled orders of $471.8 billion and inventories of $381.8 billion, all expressed in current dollars and adjusted for typical seasonal influences.
The general economic improvement, as reflected in various sets of figures in recent months, is "for real," said Roger M. Kubarych of Henry Kaufman & Company, but should not be seen as heralding more than moderate economic strength. "The drags are pretty heavy," he added, citing continued restructuring by large employers and dimming export prospects that Mr. Kubarych said included South America as well as Europe and Japan.
Today's claims figures, a rough predictor of the labor market, showed the first decline in three weeks but was the 17th time in 19 weeks that new applications were less than 400,000, the dividing line for many economists between an improving market and an eroding one. For the second and third quarters, the average was 410,000, according to calculations by J. P. Morgan.
 Economists also pointed to a buoyant set of monthly job statistics for December, to be reported on Jan. 8, despite the fact that today's figures covered the third week of the month while the monthly results will be based on a survey conducted in the preceding week.
In the week that included Dec. 12, today's report also found, 2,776,000 people were collecting jobless benefits under state programs, a decline of 87,000 from the revised total of 2,863,000 the week before.
In addition to the 332,000 initial claims in the Dec. 19 week, there were 24,625 people who filed under the Emergency Unemployment Compensation program, 312 more than in the preceding week.
Besides California, states reporting declines of more than 3,000 in first-time claims were Michigan, Ohio, North Carolina and Alabama. Pennsylvania posted the biggest increase, with 2,471 additional claims that reflected layoffs in textiles, apparel and primary metals.
"We certainly think it's still drifting down," Susan M. Hering, a Salomon Brothers economist, said of the trend in claims. But since the figures are notoriously volatile, she cautioned, "It's best to take it one week at a time."

HEADLINE: Purchasers' Index Rises

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TEMPE, Ariz., Dec. 31

 BODY:
The manufacturing sector grew in December for the third straight month, and the economy expanded at its fastest pace since May 1992, the National Association of Purchasing Management said today.
The group's purchasing managers index rose to 55.9 in December from 55 in November. A reading above 50 suggests the manufacturing economy is expanding. 
 The group, made up of purchasing managers at leading companies around the country, said new orders expanded in December at their fastest pace in five years.
Exports expanded, imports grew and production increased -- all signs that the manufacturing economy is continuing to grow as the overall economy gathers steam.
"The new-orders index rose to the highest level since October 1987 and was the third highest rate of growth reached in the past nine years," Robert Bretz, chairman of the group's business survey committee, said. "This high rate of growth in new orders, coupled with the low level of inventories and declining prices, should be sufficient to sustain economic growth into 1993."
One of the few dim spots in the report was the employment index, which declined in December, to 47.1, from 48.7 in November.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
30-Year Treasury Bond Prices Decline

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices sank yesterday in extremely quiet abbreviated trading on the last day of 1992.
The price of the Treasury's main 30-year bond fell 7/32 and its yield rose to 7.39 percent.
On Wednesday the bond's yield closed at 7.37 percent. Bond prices and yields move in opposite directions.
 
Effect of Jobless Claims
 Analysts attributed the market's decline to a Labor Department report showing a drop in weekly jobless claims that was larger than expected, as well as a cashing in of year-end profits by traders. 
 The Government said the number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits fell by 28,000 during the week that ended on Dec. 19. It was the first decline in three weeks but the ninth drop in 13 weeks and brought a closely watched four-week moving average of claims to a three-year low.
The decline in claims was a hint that "the recovery might be a little stronger than generally expected," heightening fears of inflation, said Douglas Schindewolf, a vice president at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.
Because trading was thin, the decline in bond prices might have been exaggerated. Trading in Government securities ceased around 1 P.M. as dealers headed out early to celebrate the New Year.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, short-term maturities fell 1/16 to 1/8 and intermediate maturities were off 1/4 to 1/8, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, fell 1.67, to 1,255.84.
The discount rate on three-month Treasury bills rose 2 basis points, to 3.08 percent. The rate on six-month bills rose 4 basis points, to 3.28 percent. On one-year bills, the discount rate rose 3 basis points, to 3.42 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, was 3 percent, up from 2 percent late Wednesday.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Has a Mixed Finish In Extremely Thin Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended mixed yesterday on world financial markets.
Gold prices were mostly lower. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery settled at $332.80 an ounce, unchanged from Wednesday. Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold at $333 an ounce, off 25 cents. 
 The final trading day of the year saw the dollar decline in foreign markets, but it reversed the trend when trading shifted to the United States.
Trading was extremely thin -- "practically nonexistent," according to Andrew Busch, a dealer with Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago. That meant that even modest selling or buying had a disproportionate impact on the currency's value.
 
 
Jobless Claims
 The dollar drew some mild support in United States markets from a Labor Department report showing a larger-than-expected drop in jobless claims for the week ended Dec. 19.
The report, which sent short-term interest rates higher, helped the dollar close at its highs for the day, Mr. Busch said. Higher interest rates make dollar-denominated securities more attractive to investors, thereby increasing their need for the United States currency.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 124.65 yen, up 0.15 yen from Wednesday's close. In later European trading, the dollar was lower at 124.55 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 124.85 yen, up from 124.60 yen on Wednesday.
In London, the pound was trading at $1.5140 at the close, up from $1.5125 on Wednesday. In New York it cost $1.5105 to buy 1, up from Wednesday's $1.5100.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates included: 1.6206 marks, up from 1.6108; 1.4670 Swiss francs, up from 1.4655; 5.5265 French francs, up from 5.5155; 1,472.50 Italian lire, down from 1,474.50, and 1.2710 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2688.
 
 
Rates in Europe
 Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday's rates included: 1.6135 marks, down from 1.6140; 1.4550 Swiss francs, down from 1.4590; 5.5000 French francs, down from 5.5045; 1.8100 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8130; 1,469.00 Italian lire, down from 1,472.00, and 1.2686 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2685.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Forecast of Snow on Plains Brings Jump in Cattle Prices

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Cattle futures prices surged yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange as meteorologists forecast snow in the Great Plains, which analysts said could disrupt livestock feeding and shipping.
The storm, predicted to drop 3 to 8 inches of snow on Sunday, would place more stress on herds already enduring below-normal temperatures in the northern Plains and freezing drizzle in the south, the analysts said. 
 "If it muddies up the feedlots again and creates more stress on the animals, who are still trying to recover from the weather, it just delays the finish of those cattle a little while longer," said Chuck Levitt, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers in Chicago.
Live cattle for February delivery surged 95 cents, to $77.12 per hundredweight. Feeder cattle for delivery in March, the most active month, rose 68 cents, to $84.68 per hundredweight.
 
Light Trading Before Holiday
 Analysts said light trading might have exaggerated gains. Trading ended an hour early because of the New Year's holiday.
Heating oil led energy futures lower after the American Petroleum Institute estimated an increase in United States supplies of the fuel. The institute said after the close of trading on Wednesday that distillate inventories had climbed 1.59 million barrels, or almost 1.2 percent, in the week that ended on Dec. 25, to 138.9 million barrels.
Heating oil for delivery in February, the most active month, fell 0.51 cent, to 57.21 cents a gallon. February West Texas intermediate crude oil fell 9 cents, to $19.50 a barrel.
Copper surged on the Commodity Exchange of New York after a Government report showed lower jobless claims, suggesting a stronger economy and greater demand for the industrial metal, analysts said.
"With employment improving, the outlook for the industrial sector brightens," said Peter Cardillo, research director for Westfalia Investments in New York.
Copper for delivery in March, the most active month, climbed 0.75 cent, to 103.60 cents an ounce on the Commodity Exchange of New York.
Pork belly prices fell on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange after a report after the close of trading on Wednesday indicated a growing hog population.
Pork bellies for February delivery fell 10 cents, to $37.75 per hundredweight. February live hogs gained 3 cents, to $43.62 per hundredweight.
