HEADLINE: Review/Art;
Homelessness Explored At El Museo del Barrio

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER

 BODY:
"House of Fire," 1 of the 12 installations by the Puerto Rican artist Antonio Martorell currently at El Museo del Barrio, is a skeletal structure of half-burned furniture parts and wooden planks charred black. The nearby "White House" is fashioned entirely from sheets of pristine Japanese paper decorated with cut-out patterns that suggest both the lace of a communion dress and a popular childhood handicraft raised to a level of grandeur.
These two works embody the double-sided theme of homelessness and shelter at the heart of "A House for Us All," as Mr. Martorell has titled his remarkable show, and they constitute popular art in the richest sense of that term. Collaborative in nature, materially alluring, specific in their references but expansive in their implications, they have the kinds of complexity and vitality that the installation format was invented for, but that it has rarely achieved in New York in the last few years. 
 Mr. Martorell, a 53-year-old printmaker, writer and performer who has exhibited widely in South America and the Caribbean, establishes his central metaphor in the show's opening work. Titled "Kamikaze," this house has a feather mattress for a floor, bedposts for walls and draped mosquito netting for a roof. The title, a sound-alike combination of the Spanish words for bed (cama) and house (casa), could easily refer to the king-size insects made of sequins and wire that seem to be dive-bombing the house from above and cling to the netting like Christmas ornaments.
The image is drawn from the artist's own past. When he was 5, his family was evicted from its home and forced to live in a single room behind a relative's shop. In the show's catalogue, Mr. Martorell says he remembers these cramped conditions fondly; he felt secure in a world of wall-to-wall beds enveloped by opaque tulle curtains. And, in a way that is characteristic of much of this artist's work, "Kamikaze" imbues the harsh facts of daily life with a childlike sweetness and an odd, delicately wrought magnificence.
The autobiographical strain continues in the tentlike "Singer House." Its thin frame structure is made of yardsticks hung with pairs of scissors, its sides of sewing patterns; ribbons and dress trimmings stream from its roof. At its center, raised on a big, heart-shaped pincushion of red velvet, sits a 1940's Singer sewing machine encrusted with pearls. A wall text says that the work is dedicated to Mr. Martorell's mother, who supported her family as a seamstress, and by extension to all the women who have earned their livelihood through sewing in the Caribbean or in Manhattan sweatshops, like those in SoHo that have only recently been displaced by art galleries.
The immigrant experience itself is one of the show's recurring motifs. Just as most of the installations in "A House for Us All" were created in Puerto Rico and are very likely to return there at the end of this exhibition's run, one of the defining features of the "Nuyorican" experience is the frequent shuttling from the island to the mainland and back. Mr. Martorell's work suggests that this commute has produced not only a vital hybrid culture, but also an odd sense of psychological suspension between the Caribbean home and the northern city that holds the possibility of economic survival.
Interestingly, this state of perpetual transience is most directly addressed by the show's only site-specific work, commissioned by El Museo del Barrio. Titled "House in Mid-Air," it simulates the tunnel-like interior of a small commercial shuttle plane, although here the seats are a collection of fabulously embroidered lawn chairs and rockers, the windows are mirrors framed with pom-pon tassels, the walls are covered with the text of a provocative story by the Puerto Rican writer Luis Rafael Sanchez, and a small plastic radio plays salsa throughout the trip. "House in Mid-Air" is a physically dense piece, although, like everything else here, it has a sense of improvisational deftness, as if it had been created in a single work-intensive session.
Other pieces in the show are more spare, even severe. Some of them are obviously political in meaning. The decorative window grilles that form "The Green House," for example, are used as security devices in Puerto Rican homes, but here they are ornamented with rows of pennies. And at least one installation is literally poetic. The paper "Rilke's House" takes the form of a huge air-mail envelope, with woodcut portraits of the German writer Rainer Maria Rilke stamped on the outside and passages from his "Letters to a Young Poet" written in flowing script on the interior. "Believe in a love that is being stored up for you like an inheritance," reads one of its lines.
In fact, it is exactly a sense of having been conceived and executed out of love and affirmation that makes this show so moving and puts it in an odd position in the present art climate. Although museums and academic art departments are paying lip service to exploring the contemporary art of all world cultures, there appears to be a firm institutional line drawn between the often didactic, ironic, theory-driven work that has dominated New York in the last decade and the emotionally open, intensely metaphorical art represented by "A House for Us All."
Whether that line holds or yields, the kind of art Mr. Martorell is creating -- based on the assumption that spiritual aspirations, political ideas, and personal and communal emotions are inextricably bound together -- is here to stay and deserves a long, careful look.
Antonio Martorell's exhibition "A House for Us All" remains at El Museo del Barrio, 1230 Fifth Avenue, at 104th Street, through Feb. 28.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Kamikaze," one of the works by the Puerto Rican artist Antonio Martorell in the show "A House for Us All," at El Museo del Barrio. (Frank Gimpaya)

HEADLINE: It's Time to Savor the First Tastes of Vintage '93;
Video

BYLINE: By CARYN JAMES

 BODY:
Can't find a cab? Stay home and rent Jim Jarmusch's "Night on Earth" (newly released on video by New Line), a 1991 film of five droll, often hilarious vignettes set in and around taxis. As these unconnected stories head east, from high-powered Los Angeles to frigid, boozy Helsinki, they display Mr. Jarmusch's unmistakable wit, warmth and intelligence.
Winona Ryder is the least likely driver, a tiny woman with a dirt-smudged face who dreams of becoming a mechanic. At a Los Angeles airport, she picks up an elegant agent, played by Gena Rowlands, and the two dish the dirt about problems with careers and men. The fine acting is a treat that holds up throughout the film. 
 Meanwhile, in Manhattan, a frantic Brooklyn-bound passenger named YoYo (played to comic perfection by Giancarlo Esposito) hails a cab driven by a confused circus clown from East Germany. Helmut (Armin Mueller-Stahl) doesn't speak much English, doesn't know his way around, doesn't drive so much as he lurches forward a few feet at a time. It's guaranteed that one day you will be sitting white-knuckled and lost in a taxi, thinking of him.
In a wildly funny segment, Roberto Benigni is a Roman driver who picks up a priest and feels compelled to confess his early sexual encounter with a pumpkin. Throughout this frenetic monologue, the driver remains hopelessly romantic. You never forget your first love affair, even if it was with a piece of fruit.
All the stories include fresh turns. When a black driver in Paris picks up a beautiful, angry blind woman, what might have been a mawkish tale about prejudice and insight turns out to be wonderfully unsentimental. The only weak segment is the last, in which a group of drunken friends try to get their unemployed colleague home in the dreary Helsinki dawn. That dreariness seems contagious. But always Mr. Jarmusch presents a clear-eyed yet sympathetic view of these people. The rich comedy of "Night on Earth" might be the flip side of "Taxi Driver," offering a vision of what is least threatening in us all.

HEADLINE: Feud Between Top Dinkins Aides Is Seen Hurting Social Programs

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

 BODY:
A feud between two of the Dinkins administration's top officials has become so bitter that it has undermined the city's ability to forge coherent strategies on social issues like homelessness, say advocates for the poor, union leaders and some city officials.
The animosity between First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel and Barbara J. Sabol, who heads the city's vast social services bureaucracy, has bubbled beneath the surface for more than a year. But it recently erupted in a bitter exchange of memos, which were obtained by advocates for the homeless through a legally enforceable request under the Freedom of Information Act. 
 In one memo to Mr. Steisel, Mrs. Sabol stated that she had "come to expect demeaning and inappropriate responses from your office." And she concluded by caustically suggesting that he call her at the Human Resources Administration, where she is the commissioner, if he had further questions about an audit they were arguing over.
"My telephone is 212-274-2664," she wrote to Mr. Steisel, the City Hall official she reported to directly for almost two years.
 
Policy Fights Boiling Over
 The feud is rooted in policy differences, with Mr. Steisel pressing to shake up the social-services bureaucracy and its management to improve services, while Mrs. Sabol insists that the city and state need to devote more money to the problems. But it has also become a clash of personalities. And pressure from the courts to improve the shelter system -- which led a state judge to hold both Mr. Steisel and Mrs. Sabol in contempt for the city's failure to shelter the homeless adequately -- has intensified the acrimony.
Neither Mr. Steisel nor Mrs. Sabol returned calls seeking comment Wednesday or yesterday. Leland T. Jones, a spokesman for the Mayor, said disagreements were just normal tensions in an administration of strong-willed people. "It's not unusual that those who run agencies and people at City Hall occasionally have strong disagreements, but that's government, not gossip," he said. "It's that tension which hopefully leads to a system that works better."
But advocates for the homeless and union officials say they see an administration at war with itself. "The Mayor doesn't have one administration, he has at least two," said Linda Schleicher, assistant to the president of the Social Services Employees Union, local 371. "They spend so much time fighting each other, they don't know where they're going. There's never been a team."
Some involved in the issue of homelessness say a number of city officials would be happy to see Mrs. Sabol go. George McDonald, who runs a nonprofit group and served on the mayoral commission on homelessness, said it is common knowledge that Mrs. Sabol and Mr. Steisel have "had a problem."
"The First Deputy Mayor would like a commissioner who gets the job done," Mr. McDonald said. "I don't think it's personal. It may be now, but I don't think it started out that way."
And other people familiar with the Human Resources Administration say it is commonly believed there that Mr. Steisel is engaged in a kind of bureaucratic guerrilla warfare to undermine Mrs. Sabol. He and his surrogates have wrongly depicted her as an obstacle to reforming the shelter system, they say.
Oddly, Mrs. Sabol herself has been virtually invisible in the press even though she is commissioner of an agency that serves more than one million poor New Yorkers. She has said she mistrusts the news media and has only rarely granted interviews, so her positions on various social policy disputes are sometimes enigmatic.
Her public silence has frustrated some advocates for the homeless who believe she is more liberal than Mr. Steisel.
 
Steisel Winning Policy Battles
 "The bunker mentality at H.R.A. has ill-served the agency," said Steven Banks, coordinating attorney for the Legal Aid Society's Homeless Family Rights Project. "The public discourse has emanated from City Hall, which has pulled the rug out from under H.R.A. on resources and funding."
Mr. Steisel is apparently winning some important policy battles. For example, the Mayor finally decided last month, nine months after a mayoral commission recommended it, to take the city's sprawling shelter system away from Mrs. Sabol's agency and to hire Mr. Steisel's hand-picked candidate, Charles V. Raymond, to create a new city department on homelessness.
Mr. Steisel was the point man in setting up the mayoral commission on homelessness, headed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's son Andrew, who runs a nonprofit group that operates shelters. The commission said the city needed to set up tougher rules on who qualifies for shelter and needed to require that the homeless participate in social service programs before they are placed in permanent housing. Its members were also harshly critical of how Mrs. Sabol's agency has managed the system to date.
Mrs. Sabol, a member of the panel, abstained on the issue of whether to create a new agency when the mayoral commission voted, but she has made it clear in letters to state officials that she thinks the problem of homelessness has more to do with a lack of money to tackle housing problems than with an inefficient bureaucracy.
While City Hall has stressed social problems like drug abuse and illiteracy as causes of homelessness, Mrs. Sabol has emphasized the lack of affordable housing. She has argued that the city should lobby the state to raise the monthly allowance that poor people receive for rent, which has not kept pace with inflation.
 
Bitter Fight Over Audit
 But City Hall officials say her position is unrealistic at a time when the state is in dire financial straits. And in a December memo, Mr. Steisel pointedly noted that proposals to increase the rental payments do "not represent a city position."
Without the usual courtesy of a phone call accorded an official who is part of the same administration, Mr. Steisel fired off a memo to Mrs. Sabol in September stating that he was "disturbed" by an audit finding that her agency had not satisfactorily carried out city policies to prevent the placement of homeless families in city shelters.
She responded angrily that Mr. Steisel himself was to blame for blocking full financing of prevention programs her agency had proposed and scolded him for putting such thoughts in writing at a time when she personally faced contempt charges.
"I fail to see why this comes as a surprise to you since OMB (at your directive) either did not or only partially funded many of the key elements of our plan," she wrote, referring to the city's Office of Management and Budget.
More broadly, the conflict between City Hall and the budget office, on the one hand, and H.R.A. on the other, appears to have undermined their ability to work together effectively on basic management issues.
A budget official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the social services agency often does not give the budget office enough information to make cuts intelligently. "We're at loggerheads," the official said. But H.R.A. officials say they communicate constantly with the budget office.
Budget officials and child welfare administrators also disagree about why the number of caseworkers who investigate child abuse reports has shrunk by about a quarter since Mayor David N. Dinkins took office, weakening protection of the city's most vulnerable children.
Mayor Dinkins, who has publicly made the fight against child abuse a major priority, on Tuesday asked Deputy Mayor Cesar A. Perales to find out whether caseloads are too high.
The City Budget Director, Philip R. Michael, said that the Child Welfare Administration, part of the H.R.A., was given sufficient resources to keep caseloads in line. The problem, he said, "is largely because they haven't used their personnel correctly."
But Robert L. Little, who heads the Child Welfare Administration, said the budget office has underestimated how many workers it needs.
 
Freeze Hurts Agency
 For example, he said, the budget office has not taken into account the need for more caseworkers to reflect the fact that new laws require workers to report more frequently to Family Court. When each case takes more time, each worker can handle fewer cases, he said.
A major point of disagreement between city budget officials and child welfare administrators involves how the city staffed a new program of 150 caseworkers who each spend eight weeks working intensively with only two troubled families at a time. The goal of the program is to keep families together and children out of foster care.
Mr. Michael said the agency was provided with enough hiring authority to staff this new program, strongly supported by the Mayor. But Mr. Little said the budget office has frozen hiring within the agency and insisted that he hire private agencies to start the new initiative.
Since he believed contracting with private groups would doom the program to failure, he instead diverted some workers who investigate child abuse to the new "family preservation" program. That decision worsened the shortage of child abuse investigators.

HEADLINE: Fortunate in Hard Times, Many Remember Neediest

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
The recession that has clung to the New York area wrought some of the more disturbing images of 1992: the newly unemployed lining up at soup kitchens, children packed into homeless shelters, more mentally ill people wandering the streets because of cuts in government aid.
With the economy foundering, New York City often seemed to face one crisis after another, upsetting many people who draw strength from its dynamism. Some reacted by committing themselves to helping the city through volunteer work or donations to charities like The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. 
 "Unlike a lot of people in this country, I didn't lose my job in '92 and my income went up," Virginia Suetholz Lawrence of Manhattan said in a letter to the fund that she enclosed with her $1,500 check. "Please use the money to help someone less fortunate than me."
Ann B. Kleinman of Manhattan included a similar message with her donation of $100. "I am sending this gift with the hope that it can help those who are less fortunate than we have been this past year," she wrote. "In spite of a bleak economy in the New York area, we have managed to weather the storm. We would like to share our good fortune."
 
'Increase in Homeless'
 And Toni Derman of Port Jefferson, L.I., sent $100 with a note that explained: "With the increase in homeless people and those struggling to survive the recession, I hope this contribution will be put to good use for those in need."
Other longtime benefactors of the fund said they raised their donation this year because so many people were facing hard times.
David Judson of Manhattan gave $500. Chester Ross of White Plains sent a check in memory of his parents, Adolph and Estelle Ross. "Mrs. Ross and myself have been donating to your most worthy cause for almost 50 years," Mr. Ross wrote. "In view of the increased need to help the less fortunate, we have decided to increase our gift this year to $150."
The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund gives assistance to seven charities that aid tens of thousands of people who lack food, clothing, shelter and health care. The New York Times pays the expenses of the Neediest Cases campaign, so all contributions are given directly to the charities. This year's appeal, the 81st, ends on Feb. 28.
 
'Global Note of Despondency'
 In a letter to the fund that she enclosed with her $25 check, Allison I. Mapp of St. Albans, Queens, said that the past year had left her saddened.
"Nineteen ninety-two has not been the very best of years for most of us," she wrote. "Homelessness, a soaring crime rate, heightened racial and ethnic tensions, indiscriminate deaths because of AIDS and a very bleak economy seem to have triggered a global note of despondency, especially at this time of year."
"So in these trying times," she added, "it is always comforting to read or hear of the little gestures of kindness and good will that still abound, in spite of the gloom."
But Nina Primer of Bedford, N.Y., who sent $25 to the fund, said the year had ended on a happy note.
"My husband recently found employment after a five-month search and we are grateful," she wrote. "For our children's health, we count our blessings. We pray that this donation will help lift someone's spirits at this holiday season."

HEADLINE: Loans Trickle to Residents After Heavy Storm Damage

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

 BODY:
Almost three weeks after a ferocious rainstorm swept the region, Federal loans and grants have begun to trickle out to residents whose homes and property were damaged. But the largest source of help so far has been private charity.
As of Wednesday, 9,143 residents of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut had applied for some form of Federal help, Federal relief officials said. The Small Business Administration had approved 21 low-interest loans, totaling $333,000, but it has disbursed only a part of the money, said Becky Brantley, a spokeswoman for the agency. The agency had issued 5,274 applications in all and received back 402. 
 A $10,000 loan, the first in New York, was given to a family in Laurel, L.I., yesterday. Most of the loans issued so far have been at 4 percent interest.
In Connecticut and New Jersey, the Federal Emergency Management Agency has distributed 551 grants totaling $516,010 for rent for temporary housing and minor repairs. In New York, the agency began distributing such grants on Wednesday, but the number of checks and the dollar amounts were not known, said George O. Thune, a spokesman for the agency.
While the Red Cross does not have cumulative statistics on the amount of relief it has distributed, it estimates that the total for the region will be $4 million. After visiting victims door to door or listening to their stories at Federal relief centers, Red Cross workers have provided everything from shelter to turkeys to vouchers for mattresses and clothing.
The effort has followed the usual pattern for relief in Federal disaster areas, in which the Government counts on families, friends and private organizations to provide short-term help, then follows up with long-term, and much more expensive, assistance.
Before the Federal Government releases any money, inspectors from the Emergency Management Agency and the Small Business Administration must examine residents' property to verify damage listed on grant or loan application forms. In addition, officials often must send applications back for more information. From the time applications are completed, the process takes at least one week for a grant and between two and eight weeks for a loan, officials said.
 
Estimate by Red Cross
 The Red Cross estimated that the storm, a northeaster that struck on Dec. 11, damaged 12,500 homes in New York, 10,500 in New Jersey and 2,300 in Connecticut. In applying for Federal disaster assistance, New York put the amount of public and private damage at $290 million; New Jersey estimated it at $76 million, and Connecticut put it at $60 million.
"We expect the figures to grow," said Donald L. Maurer, a spokesman for the New York State Emergency Management Office.
The response time by public relief officials to people who apply for help has varied. Joanna Nabet of Bayville, L.I., called the Federal emergency agency's toll-free number on Christmas Eve to apply for a grant. On Monday afternoon, the examiner, James R. Soucy, arrived at her house, an instant camera slung around his neck, to look over the wreckage left behind in the Nabets' once-flooded basement.
"It's amazing what the water will do," observed Mr. Soucy, a very weary veteran of recent disasters in Florida and Hawaii.
He took a picture of the Nabets standing in front of their home, urged them to file for a loan and told them that they would learn in seven days whether they were eligible for a grant.
 
Delays in Grants
 For Danny and Veronica Vooris of Long Beach, L.I., the service has not been so fast.
The day before the Nabets applied for help, the Voorises visited the relief center in their town after losing almost all their possessions in their basement apartment during the storm. Mrs. Vorris said they were told that their credit was not good enough for a loan and that they should wait until an examiner could come by to determine how much grant money they might receive.
"The people were so rude there," Mrs. Vooris said. "They said they'd get here when they get here."
Yesterday, more than a week after the Voorises applied, the examiner had not got there. But the Red Cross had given them $995 in vouchers for bedding and $495 for clothing.

GRAPHIC: Photo: As of Wednesday, 9,143 residents of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut had applied for Federal help since the Dec. 11 storm. Gloria Minkoff and Bill Donaldson, left, from the Federal Emergency Management Agency, inspected the basement of Felix and Dorothy Martinez, right, in Bayville, L.I. (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (95%);

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 1696 words

HEADLINE: Clinton's Challenge;
Starting the Decade -- at Last

 BODY:
The Nineties begin today. That it is possible to say this three years after the advent of the decade serves as a sad monument to President Bush's indifference to the nation's social and economic vitality. The statement also defines the task before Bill Clinton, a man of untested promise who has the opportunity and the obligation to shape the ethos of a decade.
New Year's Day is a good time for the President-elect to reflect on why we have been marking time. George Bush had a chance to shape the Nineties, just as two other Republicans, Dwight Eisenhower and Ronald Reagan, shaped their decades. He failed by bringing to the White House a notion of passive stewardship in domestic affairs that is better suited to service on a community board than to leadership of the most complex nation in history. 
 Mr. Bush's supporters argue that he was energetic and sure of hand in foreign affairs. They also point out that he possesses greater intelligence and personal sensitivity than his predecessor. Let Mr. Clinton ponder these testimonials and be reminded that in the job he sought so ardently it is performance that counts, not mannerly behavior within the tight little circle of friends and advisers.
Doing only the international or domestic half of the job will not suffice, either, and Mr. Clinton can apply that lesson to his own situation. He cannot ignore the task of guarding America's interests in a dangerous world. But his mandate runs toward correcting a domestic legacy of drift and neglect in many areas, including but not limited to the following questions of policy and spirit:
 
The Deficit
Depending on which economist you believe, deficits may or may not matter. But promises do matter, because they are linked to a President's political viability. As Mr. Bush learned by breaking his pledge not to raise taxes, the American people are not forgetful. But neither are they inflexible. They abandon Presidents only when their trust and intelligence are flagrantly abused, as was the case in the read-my-lips debacle cooked up by Mr. Bush, John Sununu and Richard Darman.
So Mr. Clinton may not have to hit his goal of reducing the deficit by half with arithmetical precision. The trick is to move toward that goal in a determined, undogmatic way consistent with the overriding goal of economic recovery. If Democrats had wanted a President who put deficit reduction ahead of everything else, they would have nominated Paul Tsongas. Moreover, deficit targets cannot become so sacrosanct that reaching them imperils the public-sector spending that history shows us is needed to recover from recession.
Mr. Clinton can be sure that the Reagan-Bush team and their talk-show cheerleaders will damn him for the deficits inherited from their heroes. But he should not forget that in this situation smart economics and smart politics are one. By keeping the spirit of his promise, he can convince voters that he has not been hit with the Bush amnesia.
 
Health Care
Mr. Bush might have been a two-term President if he had addressed the nation's health care problems with more conviction. If Mr. Clinton misses his chance to lay the foundation for a national health care system, he, too, could be a one-term President. As a candidate, Mr. Clinton had an advantage. Unlike Mr. Bush, he understood that a national consensus was driving this issue, a consensus as powerful as the one that produced Social Security in 1935. Mr. Clinton promised to respond. No commitment he made in the campaign is more central to the "new covenant" that he intends as his political hallmark. The Nineties cannot be a decade of success in social welfare if they end without health insurance that covers every citizen and protects families from financial destruction.
This page has argued throughout 1992 for the market-oriented system called managed competition as a workable if not flawless approach. In any event, 1993 is the time to switch from the surgical neatness of theoretical argument to the messy task of stitching together legislation. The burden is on Mr. Clinton to sort through the various theories for delivering care and containing its cost, come up with a plan that is both medically and politically viable, and shepherd it through Congress.
 
Justice
One of the saddest spectacles of the Eighties was the Reagan and Bush Administrations' systematic assault on both the effectiveness and the principles of the Justice Department. A first step must be to restore the pride and vitality of the Civil Rights Division, which had a strong bipartisan tradition as a beacon of orderly social change under Presidents Eisenhower, Kennedy, Johnson, Nixon, Ford and Carter.
To accomplish this, the Nineties must begin with a return to another bipartisan tradition, that of having the Attorney General as chief arbiter of legal policy in the Government. Mr. Bush allowed his undistinguished Attorneys General to be shoved aside by C. Boyden Gray, his strong-willed White House counsel whose outdated antipathy to civil rights contributed to historic levels of mistrust between the White House and minorities. It is time to release the pent-up energy of career employees ready to straighten up a department thrown into disarray under Presidents Reagan and Bush.
 
Homelessness
Throughout the Eighties it was possible to look from the windows of the White House family quarters and see a tableau of urban despair: the homeless people in Lafayette Park. Once the stands erected for the inaugural parade are dismantled, they will be back, and the Clintons will be able to watch them if they have the stomach for it.
Mr. Bush was a chief executive who could observe Lafayette Park and come up with nothing more forceful than "a thousand points of light." Will Mr. Clinton be a President who looks from the same windows and says to himself: "I am leader of the richest and most powerful nation on earth, and I choose to use some of that wealth and power to relieve this suffering. I may not be able to fix this overnight. But I have the resources to make a start, and I will"?
If he fails to see what is going on in Lafayette Park, will Hillary Clinton be the kind of First Lady who takes him to those windows and reminds him that Presidents can make a difference to the most vulnerable of us? If the answer to either of those questions is yes, the Nineties will be a better decade in every American city.
 
Values
 For this to be a healthy decade for America's political culture, we do need a return to traditional values -- as those values existed before the distorting effects of the 1988 and 1992 campaigns. These are the values of community and compassion that flowed from the New Deal and once animated the political life of both parties.
Starting with the George Wallace campaigns in the Sixties, the bottom feeders in the political strategy business learned that they could win votes by redefining values in a crabbed, divisive and hateful way. Some of Mr. Bush's hired hands, the late Lee Atwater and the rancorous Roger Ailes, carried out this work with a cold-blooded genius that was impressive but never admirable. In the year just ended, the final insult to language and political sense could be observed in the vacuous sallies of Vice President Dan Quayle and the venomous ones of Patrick Buchanan.
The "values" that they espoused under the banner of tradition ranged from the frat-house moralizing of Mr. Quayle to the nativist intolerance of Mr. Buchanan. America as defined by these men is not traditional. Theirs are the values of exclusion that the founders rejected with musket and pen. The new Congress, the President and people of good will in both parties must reclaim the idea of traditional values as a healing social prescription, not as an assault weapon.
 
Leadership
Any way you slice it, the fulfillment for most of our hopes for the foreshortened decade depend on Bill Clinton being big enough for the job he has won. Mr. Clinton no doubt understands that his victory was not, in the end, the doing of the band of strategists who have been busily congratulating themselves in television interviews and at the post-election seminars. He was the beneficiary of the good judgment of the American people. They rejected both the authoritarian prescriptions of the imitation populist from Dallas and the hang-tough economics of the gentleman from Kennebunkport.
Despite winning the election, Mr. Clinton still faces a campaign of reassurance. He comes to the Presidency having revealed less of himself than Mr. Carter, Mr. Reagan and Mr. Bush did in admittedly guarded autobiographies. If anything, the serious press has not been overly inquisitive, but too easily cowed by Mr. Clinton's complaints about "you people" who are always asking questions.
As a Southerner, Mr. Clinton had years to observe the time-honored tricks of running against the newspapers. His press bashing was effective as a tactic for fighting his way off the ropes in the primaries, but President Clinton needs to follow a higher road than that traveled by candidate Clinton.
He must avoid the temptation to use the Gennifer Flowers episode as an excuse to extend an unreasonable "zone of privacy" around all aspects of his character and personal history, including those areas of private behavior that raise legitimate questions of competence. Principled inquiry is one of the few ways for the voters to learn if Mr. Clinton is likely to grow in wisdom or fall victim to that Oval Office hubris that led Mr. Bush to think that one idle term deserved another.
So on this New Year's Day of 1993, let the Nineties begin at last. Let Jan. 20 be a day marking the advent of a President whose mature character will draw its shape from the hope, humility and dedication of the American people. Let those people and that leader forswear the divisiveness that was too often preached in high places throughout the Eighties. Let them move into the Nineties in unified dedication to the healing of a troubled land that needs nothing so much as -- and requires nothing less than -- a President and Congress determined to summon its goodness.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Finding an Economic System for a New Century

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Gar Alperovitz is correct that for nearly a century United States economic success has been associated with war or preparation for war (Op-Ed, Dec. 16). This country has yet to prove it can sustain long-term economic success without depending on a permanent war industry. 
 It is essential, looking at the larger picture and future needs, that we explore entirely new economic models. Communism is now relegated to the scrapheap of history, unable to provide the material needs for society. Capitalism, however, is also failing miserably in many areas.
It is a capitalist, free-market world, yet the inequities are brutal. More than a billion people live in shantytowns, garbage dumps and useless land. Moreover, the gap between rich and poor continues to widen, with the richest 20 percent of the world's population now owning 83 percent of the wealth.
Even in the United States the greed-oriented policy of the last decade has resulted in 1 percent of American households now controlling 37 percent of net worth. The top 4 percent of wage earners make more money than the bottom 51 percent combined. This gross inequity is the antithesis of democracy.
Athletes and entertainers make outrageous salaries, while many people who really contribute to the future of the country are grossly underpaid or have no work at all. Equally obscene, many company chief executive officers are paid millions of dollars in compensation, while they are laying off employees.
The country has become one big marketplace, where the main value is what sells. The most contemptible result is that children are the poorest age group, with one in every five children living below the official poverty line. Like the homeless and the unemployed, children have no buying power, so they come last. This is the ultimate disgrace of a system that neither comprehends what is important nor has a vision for the future.
Capitalism, as practiced today, is inherently inequitable. It is also an environmental disaster through dependence on mass consumption and constant expansion of markets. We must have a better system to meet the needs of the world community in the 21st century. Perhaps we must combine the best of capitalism with the best of socialism to make a truly democratic, equitable and workable system.
 
DOUGLAS MATTERN
President, Assn. of World Citizens
Palo Alto, Calif., Dec. 17, 1992

HEADLINE: Finding an Economic System for a New Century;
Never Better

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The foundation for most of Peter G. Peterson's "Hard Truths for Better Days" (Op-Ed, Dec. 1) is an almost universally accepted but increasingly flawed view of how the economy works and ought to work. Briefly, the core "truth" is the old saw that rising production will solve the problems of unemployment and poverty just as a rising tide lifts all boats. 
 One reason this view is likely to fail is that the planet can only support full employment of the world's growing labor force at a cost of worldwide environmental degradation.
Equally important is a related but more subtle truth that will undermine public support for averting environmental catastrophe.
While Bill Clinton and Mr. Peterson are correct that jobs lost in defense may well be created in industries that protect the environment, America's consumers cannot fill their shopping bags with the production of these industries, and they will perceive a further decline in living standards.
In contrast to the tangible realities of a car, videocassette recorder or compact-disk player, Mr. and Mrs. Public will be unaware of the cancer they did not suffer because the ozone layer was preserved; the arsenic their family didn't ingest because the ground water wasn't contaminated; the funerals they didn't attend because highway safety improved. The list of unperceived benefits can be extended, but the public will not be persuaded to support policies that force it to give up material rewards for invisible blessings.
Economists know that there are only two ways to improve living conditions: increase supplies of stuff or decrease demands for stuff. But only supply increase is within the purview of economic science. Hence, the prescription for growth, growth, growth (or jobs, jobs, jobs). Yet despite the worship of growth, no economist can imagine a demonstration that an individual is better off today with more stuff than a few years ago with less stuff. (We should exclude those who were starving or ill and are now filled and healthy. Anyway, these are not constituents usually addressed by commentators and politicians.)
Put another way: the essence of our admirable economic system is to create wants as fast as, or faster than it satisfies them. Thus the improvement of living conditions, meaning greater consumer satisfaction, is, by definition, impossible!
Jimmy Carter was unfairly maligned for speaking this harder truth, one that is ignored by Peter G. Peterson.
 
JOHN MAHER
Hamden, Conn., Dec. 7, 1992
 
The writer retired as professor of economics at Southern Connecticut State University.

HEADLINE: 30-Year Low Is Seen for Traffic Death Toll

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30

 BODY:
The Government estimates that traffic deaths will drop below 40,000 for 1992, the lowest annual figure in 30 years, as fewer Americans mix alcohol with driving and more use seat belts.
While the year is not quite over and official figures will not be available for months, Transportation Secretary Andrew H. Card Jr. said Tuesday that his department expected that the year's motor vehicle death toll would be 39,500. 
 That would continue a steady decline in traffic deaths since 1988, when the toll was 47,087. The 1992 total, if it holds up, would be a 5 percent decline from last year's 41,462 deaths.
The annual toll has not been below 40,000 since 1962. The record high was 54,589, in 1972.
Part of the decline may be a result of the recession, since people tend to travel less in economically hard times, transportation officials acknowledged.

HEADLINE: From Tea Leaves to Tarot Cards

BYLINE: By ADAM GREEN; Adam Green, who co-wrote and performed in the Off Broadway show "An Evening of Fun With Moynihan and Green" with his partner, Maura Moynihan, has most recently written for Walt Disney Television.

 BODY:
THE Gypsy Tea Kettle, a short flight of stairs above Lexington Avenue at 56th Street, reigns like a dowager empress over a block lined with discount electronics stores. The sign in its window advertising "Tea Leaves Read Gratis" adds a singular note of quaint, faintly archaic gentility to the hurdy-gurdy drone of the surrounding tawdry commerce.
In this milieu the casual passer-by might dismiss the Gypsy Tea Kettle as just another spurious fortune-telling parlor, one of the city's hundreds of fly-by-night operations whose signs proclaim the amazing powers of Madame Dora or Sister Rose and beckon with promises of "LOVE, LUCK, MONEY, $ UCCE$$" and "ALL TYPE PROBLEM SOLVED." 
 This would be a mistake. The Tearoom, as it is referred to by its habitues, has been a mecca to those seeking knowledge of the future for 62 years. It began as a spot for women to pause from a day of shopping, buy a sandwich and a cup of tea, and have their tea leaves read. In the intervening decades, social history, economics and the mercurial vagaries of popular taste have reshaped the basic premise to the point that, in defiance of its name, it no longer employs Gypsies or offers tea-leaf readings, having long since replaced them with tarot cards. The result is a peculiarly New York hybrid of fortune-telling boutique, refuge from the cold, just-for-a-lark lunchtime stop and psychoanalytic institute.
The cost of a 15-minute card reading at the Tearoom is fixed, as it has been for four years, at $10. (Tipping, however, is strongly encouraged.) What's more, you have your choice among several readers. Whether or not you believe that your future can be divined from the ancient symbols of the tarot, when you consider what you are getting -- someone talking exclusively about you and your problems for a quarter of an hour -- this is one of the greatest bargains in town.
The value-for-your-dollar equation cannot be fully calculated, however, until you consider the substance of the service provided. While readings at most fortune-telling establishments generally run to such meaningless catch-alls as "You wear a smile, but on the inside you are crying," readings at the Tearoom are specific, down to earth and, some say, accurate.
The entrance is at 137 East 56th Street. After walking upstairs, you find yourself inside a long, narrow room, wallpapered in a gold-hued fleur-de-lis pattern. The decorative touches, while spare, are designed to invoke the burnished glow of a more gracious era: beads, faux Tiffany lamps and, as an allusion to the room's more specific past, a large copper tea server with a spigot, mounted on the wall.
On your left, eager patrons wait for their appointments. A 30-ish woman with neatly trimmed hair and a tailored blue suit nervously shreds every piece of paper she can fish out of her purse. A banker in pin stripes paces with his hands clasped behind his back. A boyish actor in blue jeans reads Backstage. A model wearing all black flips through her Filofax as she talks on the pay phone.
On your right, small booths upholstered in green vinyl line the walls. At each one sits a card reader (who goes by his or her first name only), examining, gesturing, sighing and speaking in confidential tones to the rapt client sitting across the table. You can pick up snatches of conversation: "I see some health problems around your liver, but nothing too serious"; "No, he's not cheating on you, but he's very demanding, very willful."
This was the scene I encountered on my first visit to the Tearoom three years ago. I felt as if I had walked into a world that I had no idea existed. But I had no time to stand and gawk. I had a specific, rather shoddy, mission to carry out.
Back then I had a crush on a girl whose feelings toward me seemed, at best, unclear. She had been going on for weeks about a card reader named Liz who had accurately predicted all manner of improbable events in her life. One evening, it struck me that, true psychic or fake, this Liz must have the inside dope on whether my crush was reciprocated. The next morning, feeling like a high roller swaggering up to the parimutuel window with a thousand bucks and a can't-miss tip on a 20-to-1 long shot, I set out for the Gypsy Tea Kettle.
In contrast to my preconceived image of a heavyset, mustachioed woman, Liz turned out to be a trim, jazzy platinum blonde. The fact that she was past the first blush of youth, yet still shy of middle age, gave her a sympathetic quality that was not exactly motherly but, rather, suggested an unmarried aunt whom your parents slightly disapproved of, but who always understood your problems, brought you presents, and had boyfriends who wore sharp suits, did coin tricks and called you "champ."
The reading that Liz gave me was a mixture of mysticism, earthy humor, gentle teasing and robustly direct advice. One moment she was waving her hand over the tarot deck, saying, "Truth and honesty, come through the cards." The next, she was telling me that I should play it cool to make my friend "a little nervous." Finally, she gave me what I had come for: the cards indicated that this girl was definitely crazy about me.
I don't blame Liz that the romance never materialized. I'm just not very good at having my fortune told. My psyche is such a tangled web of often conflicting beliefs, emotions, hopes, fears, neuroses and picayune superstitions that the vibes I give off are probably scrambled beyond recognition, like pay-per-view sporting events on cable television.
 
Futures With a Past
 A few months ago, I came across an issue of an old magazine called The New York Woman -- a fashion and life-style weekly that came out only in 1936 -- and, leafing through it, found an article titled "You'll Meet a Tall Dark Man!" Accompanying it was a photo of the Gypsy Tea Kettle, at a different location, but looking much as it does today. I realized then that, although I had not been back since the romantic debacle, for some reason the Tearoom had remained in the back of my mind. I also realized that I had stumbled onto a living piece of the city's past, and I decided to go back for another visit.
I am greeted by the Tearoom's owner, Doris Haber, who, after 50 years, still keeps the books, interviews and hires the readers, and comes in twice a week from Long Island to make sure that things are running smoothly. A diminutive woman with curly gray hair and a maternal, if somewhat phlegmatic, demeanor, Ms. Haber must be in her mid-70's but looks 10 years younger. Her story, and the Gypsy Tea Kettle's, mirrors New York's evolution since the Depression.
The first Gypsy Tea Kettle opened on March 30, 1930, at 503 Fifth Avenue, opposite the New York Public Library. The Tearoom's founder and owner was M. C. Berg, a restaurateur and speculative investor. Fortune-telling seems to have provided the same escape from harsh reality as movies did because, despite the scattershot nature of the readings offered, Berg's enterprise was doing well enough to warrant opening two more outposts on Fifth Avenue, each bearing a sign advertising "Tea Leaves Read Gratis."
Don't let the "gratis" lead you to believe that this was a philanthropic enterprise. There was, at the time, a state law prohibiting the telling of fortunes for profit. To circumvent this, the Gypsy Tea Kettle sold tea and lettuce sandwiches for the inflated price of 35 cents. The profit margin on the victuals sold to curious housewives, shop girls and debutantes more than covered the dollar a day that the tea readers were paid.
By 1940, however, indifferent management had eroded business, and a group of four investors, led by Irving Haber, bought all the Gypsy Tea Kettles for $500 each. In 1943, Ms. Haber was hired as the bookkeeper, and a few years later she married her boss.
 
Switching to Tarot
 The golden age of postwar New York in the 1940's and 50's was also a golden age for the Gypsy Tea Kettle and for the Habers, who, in addition to their fortune-telling empire, operated restaurants and nightclubs. With business booming, they kept the Tearoom open until 11 P.M. during the week and until 1 A.M. on Friday and Saturday nights. (It is now open from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. on weekdays and until 5:30 P.M. on Saturdays.)
They also opened another Tearoom, at 200 West 50th Street, across from the back of the Winter Garden Theater. "Men used to come in and order a cup of tea just so they could look through the window and watch the showgirls getting dressed," Ms. Haber says. "They never pulled the blinds down, those kids."
In 1946, with the ban on fortune-telling for profit lifted, the Gypsy Tea Kettle laid the foundation for its future by starting to offer card readings for $1. Saddled with the burden of being classified as a restaurant because it served tea and cookies -- thus having to meet stringent health codes and pay stiff insurance premiums -- the Tearoom discontinued the practice of reading tea leaves. "How much can I charge for a cup of tea?" Ms. Haber asks rhetorically.
By the time her husband died in 1975, there was only one Tearoom left. A year later, she moved her business to its present location, where it has thrived. Reflecting current taste, readings at the Tearoom are conducted almost exclusively with tarot cards, which, Ms. Haber says, are "very popular with the whole age-of-Aquarius, what's-your-sign crowd." Still, it remains subject to its own vicissitudes, including days when readers call in sick and periods when trade is inexplicably slow. "It's like show business," Ms. Haber says. "Who knows?"
 
Guidance and Therapy
 Aside from the readers, Ms. Haber's only employee is Horace Hinds, a compact but powerful-looking man who, for 24 years, has been the Tearoom's utility infielder, a combination manager, maitre d'hotel, cashier, security guard and customer-relations liaison. He greets your arrival with the long-suffering dignity of an eminent professor whose studies have been interrupted by an overeager freshman. While never rude, his manner is efficient and businesslike, unadorned by extraneous niceties or false bonhomie.
Mr. Hinds does not generally offer his opinion on many subjects but, when asked, allows that the Tearoom's customers are "mostly intelligent." They are also diverse, representing a cross-section of citizens engaged in the life of a great metropolis in the waning years of the millennium. Reflecting this, everyone has his or her own reason for coming here.
One woman, an elegant art consultant in a houndstooth Chanel suit, says she comes a few times a year for professional guidance. Her reader predicted that a financially rewarding project would come her way last July. "I told her that was impossible, since I'd be out of the country," she says. "Then, when I was in France and I got that call -- well! It turned out to be very lucrative."
Although the themes are eternal -- love, money, personal fulfillment -- the baroque and labyrinthine specifics of some clients' lives often raise the readings to the level of high drama. One woman, a striking redhead who favors Tina Louise and does what she describes as "freelance promo work," used to come to the Tearoom almost every day, seeking advice about botched plastic surgery.
During this time, she says, she also learned she was being spied on (it turned out that an ex-boyfriend had learned her phone machine code and was eavesdropping on her using the "room monitor" feature) and that she would be arrested. (A few weeks later, after eating dinner at a restaurant, she discovered that she had forgotten her wallet, and the management called the police.)
Drew Sarancino, an acting student and waiter, comes here simply to sort out his feelings. "I lost a friend last year, and I couldn't speak to my parents about it," he says. "I couldn't explain the relationship." The permission he feels to speak freely here has kept him returning once a month for more than two years. "I can't afford a therapist," he says. "It takes a lot just to pay the bills." Then, with a rueful smile, he adds, "I call this my 15-minute shot of hope."
 
Vibrations of Hope
 Every client has a favorite among the six women and two men who read cards at the Tearoom. Half of them do not want to talk to me when they find out that I am writing an article. I get to know the other four in a whirlwind of predictions.
My first reading is with Kyle, a young man dressed in a button-down oxford shirt and khakis. Kyle grew up in Virginia Beach, where, starting at the age of 4, he both amazed and disturbed everyone around him by telling them things that he couldn't possibly have known.
Kyle says he once worked as a reservations agent for an airline, where he would try to guess customers' destinations before they told him. His accuracy convinced him that he could do this for a living. "I'm always right on the money," he says. "Right on the money."
With this in mind, when he asks me to shuffle the deck to get my vibrations on the cards, I hope that I am giving off vibrations that somehow bespeak personal triumph, public glory and lifelong virility. When he asks me to pick five cards, I do so with grave deliberation, aware that each is an irrevocable harbinger of things to come. Kyle remains matter-of-fact when he says, "It shows here that the next five months or so are not going to be very easy for you."
 
Spiritual Energy
 I don't fare much better in my next reading, with Iris, a Yugoslav emigre with effulgent red hair and sad brown eyes, who used to write a weekly column called "Secrets of the Tarot" for a newspaper back home. She tells me that I am not living up to my full potential, a view shared by Mrs. Long, my fourth-grade teacher.
Mercifully, I receive an upbeat account of my future from Lynn, a soft-spoken redhead who "draws spiritual energy from the universe" and uses regular playing cards for readings. Lynn says she realized that she had special abilities when she was 5 and, after being sent to a school for gifted children, began studying Tibetan Buddhism at 9 and the I Ching at 12.
Heartened by Lynn's soothing tone and sunny predictions ("Your whole life is coming together in a wonderful way you never thought possible"), I head to my last reading of the day, with Liz. She remembers me but seems wary. She quickly relaxes, however, and tells me about her life.
She tells me about discovering her abilities when she was 28 at a psychic development class given at the United Nations. She tells me about her preference for dating Jewish men. Then she reads my cards and tells me about the good things coming up in my life. But I am only half listening.
As she is talking, I recognize why the Gypsy Tea Kettle has such a persistent fascination for me. I realize that Liz, although much younger, reminds me of my grandmother, who told fortunes for a living, dyed her hair platinum blond, dressed flashily and had what used to be called a lively personality.
Sitting at this small booth with Liz brings back memories of sitting with my grandmother at her kitchen table; even the warmth and smell of the room seem familiar. Wearing a leopard-print housecoat, my grandmother would hold my hand and give me a reading that combined predictions tinged with wishful thinking about her grandson, stern advice, sly humor, folk psychology and grandmotherly love. During these times, I always felt that at least for the moment, I was safe and that everything would be O.K.
Buoyed by this, I decide to seek the answer to one final question. I ask Liz how she thinks this article will turn out. She waves her hand over the deck spread out on the table and says, "Truth and honesty come through the cards. We ask how this piece that Adam is writing will turn out." She turns to me. "O.K., now give me five."
With great caution, I choose five cards and push them toward Liz. She turns them over one by one, nods sagely and looks straight into my eyes. "Good, but not great. So-so."
You may judge her accuracy for yourself.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1177 words

HEADLINE: YELTSIN RECEIVING CRITICISM OF FOES ON NUCLEAR TREATY

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 1

 BODY:
On the eve of President Bush's arrival here to sign a nuclear arms reduction treaty, President Boris N. Yeltsin is being criticized for pushing through an accord that some say serves American interests and confirms Russia's subordinate status in a post-Communist world.
Mr. Yeltsin, his authority eroded by a bruising battle with the Legislature last month, pressed the White House into a rapid completion of the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, known as Start II. Mr. Bush had let it ride during his election campaign, but both sides were eager to complete the treaty. The terms were approved on Tuesday and the signing will be on Saturday. 
 For Mr. Bush, the treaty is an unexpected and dignified cap to a foreign-policy presidency. For Mr. Yeltsin, it is another challenge to his political skill.
 
Accusations of Selling Out
 Having been forced to abandon Yegor T. Gaidar, his choice for Prime Minister, in a rebellion against the pain of radical economic changes, Mr. Yeltsin is clearly using this summit as a chance to shore up his political stature and to remind his legislative opponents that the world is watching their actions. It will allow Mr. Yeltsin to begin the new year on an elevated, statesmanlike note after a year he described in his New Year's message as "the most difficult of my entire life."
But it will also give his opponents in Parliament, who must ratify the treaty, another big opportunity to criticize him for "selling out" for American cash and approbation. The assumption is that the treaty will be ratified in both countries but that there will be a fight, and a noisy one, in Russia.
 
Concessions to Sweeten
 While the treaty, which will cut both sides' strategic arsenals by two-thirds, is likely to save Russia many billions of rubles in the long run, it also undermines Russian assertions of superpower parity with the United States. The treaty bans the heavy, land-based, multiple-warhead missiles that were vital to the defense of the former Soviet Unions, but it preserves much of the sea-based missile force that the United States has relied on.
The Russian military already faces enormous budget difficulties and ethnic warfare within the old boundaries of the Soviet Union. The military formally supports the treaty, which Defense Minister Pavel S. Grachev helped to negotiate with Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev.
General Grachev, an admired veteran of the Soviet war in Afghanistan, provided important cover for Mr. Kozyrev, a primary target of criticism from Mr. Yeltsin's foes, who have considerable weight in the Legislature.
Together, they were able to negotiate some important concessions from Washington on preserving more of Russia's existing nuclear investment and new inspections of America's most modern Stealth bombers. The concessions should make the new treaty more palatable to a legislature still touchy about the collapse of the Soviet Union.
If the coming battle over the treaty is expressed in military terms, its fundamental territory will be political.
But Mr. Yeltsin is being criticized now for behaving like the former Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who was ridiculed for making concessions to insure successes abroad while his country disintegrated at home.
President Bush is expected to spend only about 24 hours in Moscow, arriving at about 2 P.M. on Saturday for the signing. Officials announced today that he would leave about the same time on Sunday for Paris, where he will meet and have dinner with President Francois Mitterrand.
As officials of both Russia and the United States struggled today to hastily reorganize a hastily organized summit meeting and move it from Sochi, on the Black Sea, to Moscow, they were working to deflect criticism that in this matter, too, America was calling the tune. Russian officials said the decision was mutual and based solely on bad weather in Sochi, but White House advance teams were said to have been unhappy about the services in Sochi, including the lack of de-icing at the airport.
With Russia's newspapers silent for the New Year holiday and prominent politicians out of touch at dachas and bathhouses, discussion of this issue, at least, was muted, but lines were being drawn for what will be an energetic debate over ratification. The powerful speaker of the Russian Legislature, Ruslan I. Khasbulatov, has already said the treaty is too advantageous to the United States and permits too much access to Russian secrets.
These issues were taken up at the December sessions of the Congress of People's Deputies, with some conservative lawmakers echoing Deputy Mikhail G. Astafiyev, of Moscow, who accused Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Kozyrev of "high treason" and a "pro-American foreign policy."
The deputies' complaints were about a June agreement on American help to transport and dismantle Russian nuclear missiles safely. But the themes were of humiliation and subordination, tones struck on Thursday by Pravda in the headline, "They will have to answer to the Fatherland."
Pravda said the treaty, finished "secretly and in haste," held "grave dangers" to Russian security, which depended on its land-based strategic missiles. And it suggested that Mr. Yeltsin and the Government had no "independent military policy" but favored "a reckless subordination to American military strategists."
The treaty faces other difficulties. Ukraine, which inherited 176 missiles and some nuclear bombers from the Soviet Union, is dragging its feet onratification of the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, known as Start I, and the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. Kiev, with its own severe economic problems, wants to insure that it will receive its fair share for the nuclear material extracted from its weapons in a plant Washington has promised to help build for the Russians.
Washington has budgeted the first $400 million for transporting and destroying old Soviet weapons, including $175 million for Ukraine. But some Ukrainian nationalists are afraid to deliver their weapons to Russia, their only likely enemy, without stronger security guarantees.
Despite the fervor of Russian conservatives, the Russian military command tends to be realistic about its needs in a post-cold-war Russia. Less money for nuclear weapons will mean more for a long list of military needs.
But Western diplomats suggest that the military-defense complex, the still-powerful industrialists who have spent their lives building Soviet-American nuclear parity, may raise more troubling objections. They have significant support in the Russian Legislature and a sympathetic ear from powerful figures including Yuri Skokov, the chairman of the National Security Council. Mr. Skokov also heads a new presidential body to oversee all of Russia's foreign relations, both diplomatic and financial.
The diplomats suggest that the industrialists, in return for supporting the treaty, are likely to insist on new investments to modernize existing weaponry and further Government credits during the transition to a market economy.
