HEADLINE: An Increase in Bias Is Seen Against Pregnant Workers

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
Five weeks after giving birth to triplets last year, Joan Levine received a phone call from the head of FCB/Leber Katz Partners, the advertising agency in New York where she had worked for 12 years. He called to say another woman would get a chance at her job.
It was all part of a corporate reorganization, she was told, and when she returned in three weeks she should check with the personnel department. Instead of her old position, supervising 20 workers, she was asked to take a new post with a staff of one. 
 The case, say employment lawyers who represent plaintiffs, is typical of the tough issues that characterize pregnancy discrimination cases in the 1990's. Staff cuts and management overhauls have given companies opportunities to save money by unloading workers whose personal circumstances, they think, may require special attention. New mothers, a group plagued by well-meaning misinformation as well as outright prejudice, are especially likely targets.
 
'Pushed Off the Fast Track'
 "It's usually not outright termination, but coming back to lesser functions," said Janice Goodman, the Manhattan lawyer who represents Ms. Levine. "They get pushed off the fast track."
With the offer of a new job, the advertising company fulfilled its obligation to allow Ms. Levine to return to work, with her $57,000 annual salary and benefits. But she contends that the position was invented to protect the agency from a lawsuit and that it was unlikely to survive the cutbacks sweeping the industry during the recession.
Leber Katz denies her charge. Sherry H. McGann, the agency's director of human resources, said, "The job is very real and fully functioning today."
Ms. Levine declined the position and filed a complaint with the New York State Division of Human Rights, contending that she was forced out.
 
Harder to Prove
 "Word is out that Federal and state law prohibits pregnancy discrimination," said Sally Goldfarb, senior staff lawyer for the NOW Legal Defense and Education Fund in New York. "So employers are typically more devious and couch discrimination in other terms. During an economic downturn, employers can mask pregnancy discrimination as layoffs and downsizing, which makes it harder to prove the underlying discriminatory motivation."
It is hard to find statistics on pregnancy-discrimination cases. But employment lawyers and women's organizations across the country say the problem is growing.
"It's raising its head again," said Kathleen M. Lucas, an employment lawyer in San Francisco who said the last time she got clusters of calls about pregnancy discrimination was after the passage of the Pregnancy Discrimination Act in 1978.
In 1992, for the first time in several years, the number of pregnancy discrimination complaints at the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission rose slightly, to 3,186. But the numbers do not tell the whole story. Many women's groups, plaintiffs' lawyers and complainants themselves say the commission is slow to move and often ineffective -- charges the E.E.O.C. has repeatedly denied over the years.
"The number of cases the E.E.O.C. or other agencies gets are a very small tip of the iceberg," said Prof. Ann C. Wendt, who does research on employment discrimination. A 1991 study she did with William Slonaker, a colleague at Wright State University in Dayton, Ohio, found that almost a quarter of the women who filed complaints with the commission reported losing their jobs when they tried to return to work.
At last count, 58 percent of women 16 or older -- 57 million -- were in the work force, and each year 2 million have babies. More than four-fifths of employed pregnant women have full-time jobs and 85 percent of working women are likely to become pregnant during their careers.
The problem appears to affect women of all occupation and class categories. "Pregnancy cases really span the economic spectrum," said Maria Blanco, a staff lawyer at Equal Rights Associates, a public-interest law firm in San Francisco that runs a discrimination advice and counseling phone line. The most egregious cases -- " 'you're pregnant, you're fired' -- are in lower-paying work where the jobs are fungible," she said. "Bank tellers, waitresses -- where they can get someone else."
Up the occupational ladder, discrimination changes character. Ms. Blanco is seeing more and more "return-to-work cases," when women begin to have problems after they return to work. "Those are hard legally, because the person's not pregnant anymore," Ms. Blanco said.
 
Fallout of A.T.& T. Case
 Certainly employers do not now impose policies like the one that led to a class-action discrimination suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. During the 1960's and 70's, A.T.& T. -- like other companies of the era -- required women to leave their jobs six or seven months into their pregnancies, restricted the amount of seniority they could accrue and gave no guarantee that they could return to work.
A.T.& T., now widely regarded as a corporate leader on family issues, changed its policies in 1978 and settled the discrimination case last year for $66 million. Burke Stinson, an A.T.& T. spokesman, said: "The policy was very much in keeping with the times. For us, the hurdle was getting pregnancy out of the 'I Love Lucy' protect-the-woman frame of mind and into the temporary-disability frame of mind."
Employers were prodded into that frame of mind by lawmakers. Since the mid-70's, a layer cake of state and Federal protections has developed for pregnant workers. The Pregnancy Discrimination Act made it illegal for employers to treat pregnancy differently from any other disability. If a company holds a job for a man who has a heart attack, for example, it must do so for a woman who is pregnant.
Several states have passed maternal leave or family-leave laws that extend to workers the right to leave for birth or adoption. Some states, including New York, include pregnant women in their temporary-disability insurance coverage.
President Bush twice vetoed the Family and Medical Leave Act, which requires companies with 50 or more employees to grant up to three months of unpaid leave to care for newborn infants or sick relatives without losing their jobs. President-elect Bill Clinton has promised to sign such a measure.
The act, which will probably be reintroduced on the first day of the new legislative session next week, represents a compromise between advocates of more extensive paid leave and business interests that complain about potential costs.
Protections extended to pregnant workers are based on the premise that pregnancy is a disability, an approach that can prove awkwardly for women returning to work.
 
The European Example
 In Europe, pregnancy is treated as a normal part of life, and support services, including extensive day-care networks, are available. "Europeans laugh at us, treating pregnancy like a disability, as if you broke your arm," said Dana Friedman, co-director of the Families and Work Institute, a New York research organization. "You come back, and you're cured from having a child. You're supposed to return as if nothing has changed."
Yet change does occur, and research, as well as the experiences of particular women, suggests that it is more likely to be in the minds and behavior of managers than in the returning worker.
"One problem is the lingering perception that women who are pregnant or who have recently given birth are not reliable," said Ms. Goldfarb of the NOW Legal Defense and Education Fund. Employers are generally sophisticated enough not to attribute any post-return changes in a woman's circumstances -- including dismissal -- to pregnancy.
Often, women who have received excellent ratings for years will suddenly get a bad review. One woman who always received good reviews during several years of part-time work at a well-known baby-products company received lower evaluations and had her hours cut after the company learned she was pregnant. Fearful of losing what is left of her job, she asked that her name and her employer's name not be disclosed.
 
Recalling Past Examples
 In fact, studies of women and pregnancy leaves have found that the stereotype of the ambivalent new mother who cannot decide whether to return to work is just that -- a stereotype. A manager will say, " 'I once had a pregnant woman who didn't come back, so this one won't come back,' " Ms. Goodman said. "They dig back 20 years for examples."
A study by the Families and Work Institute found that 84 percent of women expecting children work into the final month of the pregnancy and two-thirds return to work within six months of the birth of their child, roughly a third are back within eight weeks, and half within three months.
Yet once they do return to work, women may find they have to prove themselves all over again, even while feeling guilty for taking time off. "I hear from women that they feel if they use a policy they are entitled to use, they won't get a promotion and won't be seen as a team player," said Ellen Bravo, national director of 9 to 5, an organization for working women.
When Lisa Buksbaum returned to her vice president's job at Lintas New York, a New York ad agency, she glued her nose to the grindstone. "I did the good girl thing," she said. "I came back and worked hard. I didn't want them to say they owed me anything."
Ms. Levine, who worked for FCB/ Leber Katz, is looking for work, taking care of her children and waiting for a state ruling on the results of a hearing in May.
The baby-products company worker, who is pregnant with twins, is on disability and does not know if she will return to work.
Ms. Buksbaum started her own company, Boxtree Communications, which, she says, is doing well. And once a month or so, as a sideline, she gives seminars on the emotions and psychology of being pregnant at work.

HEADLINE: Ashikaga Journal;
A Festival That Permits Japanese to Be Impolite

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ASHIKAGA, Japan, Jan. 1

 BODY:
The life of a typical Japanese -- working endless hours, enduring long commutes on packed trains and adhering to rigid rules of behavior -- would drive many Americans to the brink of rage. But Japanese seem to bottle up any anger and maintain their world-famous politeness.
Except just before midnight on New Year's Eve in Ashikaga. 
 In this city about 50 miles north of Tokyo, people take this one occasion to let it all hang out and say what they really think about the year gone by. In one of the strangest festivals in a country full of festivals, they walk up a dark mountain road to a temple screaming curses into the starry night sky that they would never say directly to their fellow man.
"Once a year, we can get rid of our pent-up frustrations," said Ryoken Numajiri, the head priest of the Saishoji Temple. The temple is the headquarters for the Akutare Matsuri, which might best be translated as the "naughty festival" or perhaps the "festival of abusive language."
 
Plenty Worth Abuse
 This year, of course, there was plenty for the roughly 400 participants to be abusive about, what with a national political scandal, the economy in the dumps and the stock market continuing its three-year slide. This city of 170,000 did not escape the pain, with the nearby electronics and automobile factories reducing overtime hours and part-time jobs.
"This is a chance to speak up," Mitsuo Arai, a 44-year-old clothing salesman, said before the procession began. Asked what he would be complaining about, he said, "Kanemaru, of course," referring to Shin Kanemaru, a political kingmaker who resigned last year after he admitted taking millions of dollars from a company linked to mobsters. Politicians in general, Mr. Arai said, "just want to earn money for themselves."
But other marchers complained about daily life, about too much schoolwork, or poor grades on tests. For some it was just an opportunity to escape from normal social strictures. "Women are not allowed to say such words," said Miyoko Kuwako, a housewife. "But it's O.K. tonight."
The festival, which is the only one of its kind in Japan, originated more than 200 years ago as a relief valve for repressed workers, Mr. Numajiri said. At that time, he said, women were brought in from the surrounding countryside to work in factories making material for kimonos. The work was arduous, and the hours were long. But in return for persevering through the year, their boss would take them to the temple once a year so they could let off steam.
Japanese place a high value on patience and perseverance. Even when they do let loose, Japanese curses are mild by American standards, with a more limited selection of swear words.
 
A Traditional Curse
 The main word shouted by the festival participants was "bakayaro!" which might be literally translated as "you idiot" but sometimes has the connotation of "God damn it." It is the expletive a Japanese driver might yell out the window when another car suddenly cuts in front of his. It might not seem so bad, but it is one of the closest things here to a four-letter word.
New Year's Eve and New Year's Day are traditionally times when millions of Japanese, some clad in traditional kimonos, flock to Buddhist temples or Shinto shrines. But not in the way they do it in Ashikaga.
At 11 P.M., about 200 people began walking up a mountain road to the Saishoji temple led by a man blowing a shell known as a horagai, which is supposed to fend off bad tidings. Many were carrying lanterns and wearing cardboard hats bearing the picture of Bishamonten, one of the seven gods of fortune in Japanese Buddhism and the god in whose honor Mr. Numajiri's temple was built 1,200 years ago. Another 200 people or so followed in buses.
Cries of "bakayaro!" split the night, the extended final "o" sound trailing off into the sky like a coyote's howl. Occasionally there was a more specific complaint like "My teacher is an idiot!" or "Give me a raise!"
After a 40-minute walk, the crowd stormed up the steps to the temple, which is situated atop a 1,000-foot-high hill. The crowd rang the temple bell, clapped their hands and prayed, and bellowed a few more lusty bakayaro's to exorcise the year gone by.
 
Insults Disappear
 But at the stroke of 12, the insults turned to cries of "congratulations" and "Happy New Year." Many of the worshipers went inside for another ceremony that is unique to this temple, in which people drink sake that is poured onto their foreheads and drips down their faces. The ceremony is supposed to insure that happiness will flow in the year ahead.
Mr. Numajiri, wearing a billowing green robe, called out the name of each worshiper and read aloud his or her wishes for the new year, which the visitors had conveniently circled on multiple-choice lists handed them at the door.
The person whose name was called knelt on the floor and raised a wide red lacquer bowl to his or her lips. As a big taiko drum was pounded, Mr. Numajiri poured the sake onto the person's forehead, and the sake ran down the nose and into the bowl and was consumed.
After venting their anger over the year past and drinking to the year to come, participants said they felt relieved, ready once again to do battle in the factories and offices and crowded trains of modern Japan.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Once a year, we can get rid of our pent-up frustrations," said Ryoken Numajiri, the head priest of the Saishoji Temple in Japan. The temple is the headquarters for the Akutare Matsuri, the "naughty festival" or the "festival of abusive language." Mr. Numajiri poured sake onto the forehead of a worshiper who drank as it poured down his face. (Kasumi Wauke for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Paraguay Raises Its Profile As a Center for Investment

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ASUNCION, Paraguay

 BODY:
For decades, the only press Paraguay received was a bad press: a stereotyped Latin American dictatorship where unrepentant Nazis mingled with fugitive heroin dealers and homegrown cigarette smugglers.
Then in 1989, the aged dictator fell and democracy sprouted. Stripped of notoriety, Paraguay saw its image problem become one of no press. Landlocked and located in South America's heart, Paraguay seemed fated to once again become "an island surrounded by land." 
 To break this insularity, a group of young American-trained technocrats has opened a computer-equipped office here dedicated to raising Paraguay's profile in the world's highly competitive investment and trade markets. The office, emblematic of free-market changes sweeping this California-sized nation, is so new that workers have yet to raise a sign introducing the group, Pro Paraguay, to the masses.
 
Entering the Modern Era
 "Pro Paraguay is dedicated to helping to bring Paraguay into the modern era by promoting trade and diversifying exports," said Deputy Commerce Minister Martin Burt. Looking to Chile for inspiration, Mr. Burt said, he modeled Pro Paraguay after Pro Chile, a Government agency that in the last two decades has helped Chile triple exports and attract billions of dollars in foreign investment.
But Paraguay may have a harder time attracting investors than its neighbor has had. "Pro Paraguay still has not come up with a persuasive answer to the question, 'Why Paraguay?' " one American economist here said. "The fact is that they haven't attracted any major investments. Even in Communist China, you can get a 10-year tax holiday."
What the promotion office is counting on as its selling points are cheap power, transportation improvements, free-market changes and, perhaps most important, a new common market with Argentina, Brazil and Uruguay that will take shape at the end of 1994.
Already, Paraguay simplified its tax code last year, reducing the number of taxes from 84 to 7. The number of bureaucratic steps needed to export goods was also cut sharply, from 86 to 19. Guided by technicians borrowed from Pro Chile, Paraguay plans to open a one-stop office for exporters this year.
To lure foreign investors, Paraguay's new Government has lifted foreign exchange controls, has exempted new foreign investments from taxes and customs duties for five years and has passed laws erasing distinctions between foreign and domestic investors and allowing international arbitration of disputes involving foreign investors.
 
U.S. Restored Trade Incentives
 Encouraging these economic moves and recognizing Paraguay's move from dictatorship to democracy, the United States restored trade and investment incentives in 1991. After a hiatus of several years, Paraguay was reinstated as a beneficiary of Washington's Generalized System of Preferences and the Overseas Private Investment Corporation.
On March 1 the Asuncion stock exchange is scheduled to open, connecting Paraguay with capital markets in Argentina, Brazil and Chile. Later in the year, Paraguay expects to join the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
"Paraguayan laws on foreign investment are among the most liberal in Latin America," the latest American Embassy report on economic trends here says.
Rare for Latin America, Paraguay has benefited from years of sober macroeconomic management. In 1991, Paraguay's 12 percent annual inflation rate was Latin America's lowest. In 1992, it rose to about 18 percent, still below the monthly rate in neighboring Brazil.
The foreign debt, $1.7 billion, is also Latin America's lowest, when measured per capita. Reserves of $850 million are equal to half the foreign debt. Reflecting widespread global approval of economic policies here, Paraguay is expected to receive an unprecedented level of multilateral bank financing from 1993 to 1995 -- $250 million a year.
But, damaged by droughts and floods, Paraguay's largely agricultural economy grew by only about 1 percent in 1992, falling below population growth for the first time in seven years.
"Despite the incentives offered to investors, private investment was sluggish," said the American Embassy report, which noted that American investment here totaled only $35 million.
Indeed, during the first half of 1992, Paraguay's National Investment Council approved 235 investment projects, totaling only $133 million.
Accustomed to such skepticism, Peter Jones, the agency's American deputy director, replied with a word still unfamiliar to most American business people: Mercosur.
Under the Treaty of Asuncion, signed here in 1991, the Presidents of Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay promised to institute a Southern Cone Common Market, called Mercosur in Spanish, by the end of 1994. Already, Paraguay, has reduced its top external tariff, for imported consumer goods, to 10 percent.
"Obviously, there is very little interest in putting a factory in a country with four million consumers," Mr. Jones said. "But when you start talking about the Mercosur common market, the picture changes."
Indeed, on Dec. 31, 1994, Paraguayan exporters will see their tariff-free market expand to 200 million people, 50 times its present size. Paraguayan products will be two days by container from a huge share of a gross regional product of $420 billion.
"Paraguay will be very close to the filet mignon of the Brazilian market," said Brazil's Ambassador here, Carlos Eduardo Alves de Souza. A few weeks ago, the Ambassador accompanied a Pro Paraguay trade and investment mission to Porto Alegre to discuss opportunities with business executives from southern Brazil.
Mercosur, coupled with an improving transportation network and some of Latin America's lowest electricity rates, is expected to encourage industrialization in areas where Paraguay has a competitive advantage.
Cotton and soybeans, largely unprocessed, account for about 70 percent of Paraguay's exports. A Brazilian group is completing a plant that will convert 600,000 tons of soybeans a year into meal and oil. Taiwanese investors are studying projects to convert Paraguayan cotton into thread and cloth.
"We need to industrialize our primary products," President Andres Rodriguez said in an interview. "We export cotton in bales, and then we import cloth."
A major attraction is a wealth of electric power flowing from the Itaipu dam, which Paraguay shares with Brazil. In 1995, when Yacyreta dam is completed with Argentina, Paraguay is to become the world's largest exporter of hydroelectric power.
Attracted by cheap and plentiful power, one Japanese aluminum company and three Southern Cone ferroalloy companies are negotiating setting up operations in Paraguay.
To reduce landlocked Paraguay's isolation, planners are turning to the Paraguay River, a waterway once described by a local poet as the nation's "liquid spinal cord."
 
Accord on Regional Waterway
 In June, the Foreign Ministers of Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay signed an agreement to convert the Paraguay-Parana river system into a regional "Hidrovia." To be opened over the next decade, this 2,400-mile long waterway will allow barges to bring containers from central Brazil through Paraguay to deepwater ports on the South Atlantic coast.
Financed in large part by the Inter-American Development Bank, the Hidrovia is expected to spur Paraguay's development. Initially, construction employment will expand because most dredging and straightening work will have to be performed on the 785-mile stretch of river that cuts through central Paraguay. Then, Paraguayan ports will benefit from increased river traffic and Paraguayan exporters will benefit from lower transportation costs.
"The Hidrovia will cut container transportation costs in half," Mr. Burt, the Deputy Commerce Minister, predicted.
Paraguayans make no secret of their hope that their free-market policies, abundant power, improved transportation and aggressive promotion will make their country an agro-industrial Chile of the 1990's.
"We believe very strongly in Pro Paraguay," said President Rodriguez, whose term expires next August. "We hope it will work just the way Pro Chile did in Chile, creating enormous, very positive results for our country."

Its greatest draw is cheap power, and the richest source is the Itaipu dam, a $20.5 billion hydroelectric project it shares with Brazil. (Reuters) (pg. 38)

HEADLINE: INSURANCE;
Policies for Covering Cost of Long-Term Care

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane

 BODY:
MORE and more Americans are becoming aware of the possibility that at some point in their lives they will require extended care in a nursing home or their own homes because of a prolonged illness or disability. As a result, purchases of long-term-care insurance policies, intended to cover part of the increasingly high costs of such care, are rapidly increasing.
More than 2.5 million of these policies, which protect against risks that are not covered by other categories of health insurance, have already been sold by about 130 insurance companies. Yet while consumers are being bombarded with literature outlining the merits of long-term care insurance, there are many elements to consider in determining whether and what kind to buy. 
 Price is among the most important elements for many buyers, and it makes sense to check with several companies or agents.
A crucial factor is your age at the time the policy is bought, since premiums generally do not go up as you get older unless they are raised for all policyholders. The same policy that costs around $250 a year at age 50 might cost approximately $2,000 a year at age 70.
"Long-term care insurance is good for some people and is probably unnecessary for others," said Bob Jackson, senior program specialist of the American Association of Retired Persons. "Folks need to fully understand the benefit options."
The best policies pay for all medically necessary levels of nursing home care, including skilled, intermediate and custodial care, for as short as one year or as long as a lifetime. They are guaranteed renewable and do not require a hospital stay before paying nursing home benefits. And they also cover certain types of home health care, ranging from homemaking and chore services to physical and occupational therapy. Benefits of long-term care insurance are typically capped at a maximum amount.
Most long-term care policies are indemnity policies that pay a fixed dollar amount for every day that you receive specified care, rather than a percentage of the usual, customary and reasonable fees. But unless the insurance provides a way for benefits to rise as inflation rises -- like automatic increases annually at a specified rate for a specified time -- payments may be too low.
"A person buying a policy at 65 that pays $60 a day would need $180 a day for comparable purchasing power at 85," said Joshua M. Wiener of the Brookings Institution. "You have to pay for inflation adjustments."
Another important consideration is the choice of a deductible, or elimination, period, which can last up to 100 days, in which you are required to pay for covered expenses before the insurance begins. The rule of thumb is: the longer the deductible period, the lower the premium.
"First-day coverage is going to increase the premium tremendously," said Gail P. Schaeffer, a second vice president of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company.
Exclusions and limitations vary among insurers. Nevertheless, a number of experts are now calling for state insurance regulators to require that all long-term-care policies contain mandatory nonforfeiture benefits. This provision assures those who have paid premiums for a minimum number of years that they are vested and will receive benefits for a shortened period, even if they are unable or unwilling to pay any more and thus let the policy lapse.
"Without nonforfeiture protection, long-term-care insurance is priced like a whole-life product, but provides the protection of a term product," said James P. Firman, president of United Seniors Health Cooperative. "No matter how much prefunded investment a consumer makes, nothing vests and the consumer is perpetually at risk."

HEADLINE: Shouts and Murmurs in Free Slovakia

 BODY:
It's not clear that most Czechs or Slovaks really favored the velvet divorce that became final on New Year's Day. But Czechoslovakia, once the model democracy in middle Europe, is no more. Knocking on wood, and with a nervous glance at the disintegrating Balkans, Americans can only join the celebrants and wish a prosperous life to the new Slovak Republic and the new Czech Republic.
Smaller, poorer Slovakia, with 5 million people and an 11 percent jobless rate, faces the more bruising readjustment. Yet 10 million Czechs may soon discover that when there's frost in Bratislava, the chill will be felt in Prague. The two Slavic republics are linked together not only by history, but in the perception of foreign investors. 
 The bittersweet end of the 74-year-old federation has been achieved with impressive civility. The Czech Prime Minister, Vaclav Klaus, and the Slovak Prime Minister, Vladimir Meciar, amicably settled on a 2-to-1 division of public property, including the armed forces and its weaponry. Sensibly, they have agreed on a customs union that permits free movement of goods and labor. For at least six months, the two republics will share a common currency, giving Slovakia time to set up its bank.
Polls showed that majorities of Czechs and Slovaks did not favor complete divorce. An ardent free-market reformer, Mr. Klaus knows that peaceful relations with Slovakia can help win him favorable treatment from the European Community. Mr. Meciar, a hard-line nationalist, knows that stability is essential for foreign investment.
As a matter of sentiment, Americans will sympathize with underdog Slovaks, who for a thousand years have never enjoyed statehood with democracy. Still, that lack of experience gives pause. Mr. Meciar shows scant patience with critics. And Slovakia has a large, nervous Hungarian minority.
Small wonder that worried Slovak democrats plead with American and European friends, "Don't forget us, don't abandon us." The shouts on New Year's Day should not drown out those murmurs.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Let's Scrap the Council of Economic Advisers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Clintonomics Doesn't Need a Czar" (Op-Ed, Dec. 10), James Tobin and Robert M. Solow urge the new Administration not to make the President's Council of Economic Advisers a sideshow. What they ignore is that the council has, in fact, become a sideshow, particularly under the Bush Administration. 
 Although the council at first, under the chairmanship of Leon Keiserling, kept a low profile, under Prof. Walter Heller in the Kennedy-Johnson years, the council became most effective and met its promise as visualized in the Employment Act of 1946.
Under the bold leadership of Professor Heller, the Kennedy-Johnson Administrations cut personal and corporate income taxes substantially, with liberalized depreciation rules and 7 percent investment tax credit for the purchase of new plant and equipment. The immediate result was startling when the inflation rate came down to around 2 percent, the unemployment rate was 3.6 percent, and the real gross national product grew more than 6 percent a year.
But the aftermath of the Vietnam War and the attendant inflation and high unemployment, the so-called stagflation, led the council to decline in influence. The council was swept by the events and tried anything to stem the situation, such as wage-price control and the Nixon Administration's policy of "phases," all of which ended in failure.
With President-elect Clinton's decision to establish a National Economic Council to coordinate all economic policies, the Council of Economic Advisers will be duplicative and relegated further to the sideline. It is time to think of abolishing the council for a number of reasons.
The council has become redundant in economic information-gathering. The main background research for policy discussions is done by economists at the Commerce Department and the Office of Management and Budget, among others. They can carry on the research for providing economic information to the public and for formulating effective economic policy of the Administration.
Then, the Secretary of the Treasury, not the chairman of the council, has become the Administration's chief economic spokesman. With the rise of power and influence of the Office of Management and Budget in the Bush Administration, the council has been weakened further to become ineffectual in making policy.
Finally, with the exceptions of Professors Tobin, Solow and a few others, the council has rarely attracted the first-rate minds, mainly because they had little access to the President or independent input in policy debate. It is time for starting a bold and innovative policy-making apparatus, pragmatic and not theory-bound, as the council has become.
 
ARVIN GHOSH
Assoc. Prof., Economics and Finance, William Paterson College
Wayne, N.J., Dec. 18, 1992

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Some Highs and Lows Of Buying on Margin

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
IN September, John Appley, a businessman in Clearwater, Fla., sued his broker at Paine Webber, Robert Magnan, for losses from what he said were unauthorized trades of stocks and mutual funds in brokerage accounts worth more than half a million dollars. Mr. Appley seeks to recover $145,000 in portfolio losses plus $16,000 in interest that had accrued on nearly $375,000 in margin loans that Mr. Appley said he had not approved.
Paine Webber insists that Mr. Appley had signed documents authorizing his broker to buy for him on margin, but Mr. Appley is trying to establish in court that this was not made sufficiently clear to him. 
 Mr. Appley is not alone.
Today, margin disputes account for "hundreds and hundreds of cases" that investors bring against their brokers, said Samantha Rabin, editor of the Securities Arbitration Commentator in Maplewood, N.J.
At the same time, most investors are not aware that the tax breaks that made margin borrowing a good deal evaporated in 1991. Couple that with the risks present in borrowing on stocks or bonds whose value can always decline, and more and more financial advisers are steering clients away from margin loans.
The chief advantage of margin debt, of course, is the interest rate. Margin loan rates average 7 percent, a sharp discount from the 18 percent on the average credit card. Given the rate advantage, some people use margin borrowing as a low-cost loan or for overdraft protection on checking accounts. More traditional borrowers use margin loans to leverage their investment portfolios to make quick profits in fast-moving markets.
Whatever the reason, investors held $43.6 billion in margin debt at the end of September, the largest amount since just before the October 1987 stock market crash, according to the New York Stock Exchange.
Margin loans are funds borrowed from a broker, who asks for securities or cash as collateral. Investors usually can borrow up to 50 percent of the value of common stocks, mutual funds and corporate bonds and up to 90 percent or more of the value of Treasury securities. To protect themselves, however, brokers can ask for a higher initial margin and normally can increase the required collateral.
Buying on the margin doubles your money when the market soars, but losses pile up quicker when stock prices slide -- a risk that few people fully understand. Most investors who were hurt when stocks collapsed in 1987 were customers who bought shares on margin. As the market eroded, brokerage firms gave customers only minutes to cover their accounts before liquidating them, and most forced liquidations were upheld in subsequent arbitration and court proceedings because the firms relied on clauses that permitted them to liquidate whenever they felt uncomfortable, said Theodore G. Eppenstein, a New York lawyer who specializes in securities and commodities.
Although brokerage customers legally are required to sign margin agreements that outline the terms of the loan, "most people don't read the statements, let alone understand them," said Henry Sanchez Jr., a partner in the Tampa, Fla., law firm of Page & Bacek, who specializes in securities arbitration.
Brokers often tell customers they must sign the papers to open an account. As for the margin clause, "brokers say it means you can buy more stock, and we'll lend you the money if you don't have cash -- without explaining that if you get stretched out on margin, you can end up losing everything," Mr. Sanchez said.
Today, brokerage firms are pushing margin accounts more forcefully than ever. Like Mr. Appley, the Paine Webber customer, many people who have authorized margin buying may not realize it. For example, permission is built into papers used to set up the Merrill Lynch Cash Management Account. If investors do not specifically reject the margin clause, it takes effect automatically.
From a tax point of view, margin accounts used to be a smart way to borrow because borrowers could write off all margin interest up to the extent of their net investment income plus $10,000. But the 1986 tax act phased out the $10,000 allowance over five years, completely eliminating it by 1991. Now you can deduct interest only up to net investment income, including net capital gains. Nonetheless, most people mistakenly assume that all margin debt is still deductible, says William G. Brennan, partner in charge of personal financial counseling, in the Washington office of Ernst & Young.
Now, whether margin interest is deducted depends solely on how the money is used. For example, if you take a $50,000 margin loan to pay your child's college tuition, you cannot deduct interest on the loan. Interest can be deducted when the money is used to buy shares of stock, and then only up to the amount of interest, dividends and other investment income in your portfolio.
Because of the reduced tax benefits and the risks, fewer clients now use margin loans, Mr. Brennan said.
Mr. Eppenstein's advice is to avoid margin accounts unless you have a diversified portfolio and can withstand market fluctuations. They are not suited for people who are retired or living on fixed incomes, he said.
People who do use margin loans should take steps to protect themselves. To reduce the risk of margin calls, borrow against blue-chip issues, government securities and other conservative investments and borrow less than the full loan value of your securities.
Read your statements carefully, and if you do not understand them, ask your broker or the broker's manager. Or ask a competing broker -- who will probably be happy to explain what's wrong with your account.

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES;
For the Do-It-Yourself Financial Planner, Software to the Rescue

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
People who keep careful financial records, tracking how much they have spent and comparing the outflow with their budgets, are apt to spend less and save more than people who simply buy now and pay later.
But who has time for all that tedious record-keeping? Ah, computer software to the rescue. New versions of popular personal finance programs make it easy to keep those New Year's resolutions about getting organized financially. 
 The fastest such program to learn and use is Quicken from Intuit, and not surprisingly, it is also the best-selling personal finance program. It is based on a standard checkbook. Users simply fill out an on-screen check that the program prints out. Checks written by hand and deposits are entered into the on-screen check register. The program also provides a link to the Checkfree Electronic Payment Service. Quicken uses all these data to produce a variety of instant financial reports and graphs.
Intuit has joined with Visa U.S.A. and the Primerica Bank to offer a new feature, Intellicharge, to keep track of credit card spending in its new versions of Quicken, 6.0 for Microsoft's DOS system and 2.0 for Microsoft's Windows.
To use Intellicharge customers must apply for a Quicken Visa issued by Primerica. There is no annual fee, and the card's interest rate is 8.75 percentage points above the prime rate, or 14.75 percent at present. Intellicharge data are sent over a modem for $3 a month or by diskette for $4.50 a month, with the first six months free in either case.
The program, which has a suggested retail price of $69.95, but at most retail stores actually sells at about half that, also tracks investments and works with multiple accounts, giving users a quick grasp of their financial situations and providing some financial planning simulations.
For people who want to spend a bit more time -- say an hour or two a week -- and do more comprehensive financial planning, Andrew Tobias's Managing Your Money 9.0 from Meca Software is the program of choice. It is packed with features, as well as pithy comments, that guide and instruct users as they track their spending, portfolios and tax data. The program generally retails for less than $50 and is available in DOS, Windows and Macintosh versions.
A less-well-known alternative is Moneycounts from Parsons Technology. A flexible program, it gives users a choice of single- or double-entry accounting, and it handles cash, checking, savings and investments and credit card transactions.
The program lists for $49, but Parsons (800-223-6925) is offering people who have bought an I.B.M. or compatible personal computer since June 1, its new Version 7.0 and Procalc 3D spreadsheet program for $8.

HEADLINE: Q & A

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane

 BODY:

Converting Savings Bonds
Q What are the benefits, if any, of exchanging Series EE bonds for Series HH bonds?
 
 PAUL PELLETIER, SALEM, MASS.
A Series HH savings bonds, which pay interest semiannually, can be acquired only by converting Series EE savings bonds with a value of $500 or more. "When you convert your Series EE bonds to Series HH bonds, any accrued interest on the Series EE bonds is deferred for tax purposes as long as you hold the HH bonds," said Thomas Anfinson, executive director of United States Savings Bonds. 
 "Theoretically you can take 30 years of accrued interest on Series EE bonds and defer it for another 20 years while holding the Series HH bonds," he said. The interest paid semiannually on any Series HH bonds you have acquired is taxable as received.
According to Mr. Anfinson, "Those who want some sort of a regular return would be better off with Series HH bonds." In addition, Series HH Bonds pay interest at the rate of 6 percent annually, while Series EE Bonds, which currently cannot pay less than 6 percent if held for at least five years, may rise or fall depending on Treasury rates.
 
Direct Stock Purchases
Q Is it possible to buy stock in a company directly from that company?
 
 ARTO DeMIRJIAN JR., MANHATTAN.
A Dividend reinvestment plans, which are offered by about 1,000 companies, let you reinvest your dividends, sometimes at a discount, without paying commissions. Most of these programs also allow you to purchase additional shares through the plan.
 "This is an easy and cheap way to accumulate more shares," said John Markese, the president of the American Association of Individual Investors.
Mr. Markese added that "there are about 10 companies that allow you to buy the shares directly from them even when you do not own any already, also without commission." Many libraries have directories of corporations that offer dividend reinvestment plans and sell shares to investors who do not already own stock in the company.
 
 
Buying Foreign Bonds
Q Is it possible for United States citizens to buy foreign government bonds directly from the treasuries of those countries?
 
 JAMES H. TRUMAN, CHAMPAIGN, ILL.
A Most people buy foreign government bonds through the brokerage firms or banks that participate in this business. "The reasons are convenience, safekeeping and ease of record-keeping," according to Allen Sinai, the chief economist of the Boston Company Economic Advisers.
The bonds of Canada and Mexico are the foreign bonds most often purchased by individual investors in the United States.
Some countries sell their bonds directly to foreign individuals, while others will not permit such tranactions. In addition, the countries that do so may have large minimum-denomination requirements that preclude many people from buying, Mr. Sinai added.
Information about a particular country's requirements is usually available from a brokerage firm or bank from that country with a branch in the United States.

HEADLINE: In a Striving Section of the Bronx, The Races Mix, but Don't Mingle

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER

 BODY:
Joe Kraus tries not to think about race, but being retired, he's got time on his hands. The other day, as he sat near two other elderly white men playing cards in a Bronx social club, Mr. Kraus allowed himself this simple proposition: People can live together peaceably, more or less.
He did not have to look far for proof. As his friends played rummy, Jose Rivera sat across the hall explaining the invention he hopes will make him rich: United States Patent No. 4,598,918, the sideways-skating roller skate. Behind a partition, eight children grunted as Kevin Hall, a black kung fu teacher, said to them, once again: concentrate, concentrate. 
 The building, which Mr. Kraus calls "the Triangle," is in a part of the Williamsbridge section of the Bronx, a noteworthy place when the subject is the true state of race relations in the nation's largest city. Demographers say there are few places in New York quite like this, with white, black and Hispanic residents living in almost equal proportions.
While it is a statistically unusual place, it could be that Williamsbridge and its people, tolerant if sometimes personally distant from one another, might be a better stand-in for the overall nature of race relations in New York City than neighborhoods with widely publicized troubles, like Crown Heights.
It is not that love or closeness link the groups. What exists is a cordial standoff in which blocks of tidy homes are fully integrated but the mixing rarely extends to church socials and community functions. What also exists is a respect built on common economic status and aspirations. This is a neighborhood of hard-working middle-class people, many of them homeowners, striving to get ahead.
Raising families on safe streets with the help of secure jobs is a common goal. Protecting hard-won assets and the neighborhood's quality of life, residents say, is more important than squabbling over color.
"You are always going to have bias," said Mr. Kraus, a 67-year-old former airplane mechanic who wears a short gray ponytail. "But in this particular area, I think you have as little of it as anywhere in the city."
Mark Naison, an urban studies professor at Fordham University, describes Williamsbridge as a place of "grudging tolerance" or "grudging cosmopolitanism." And so life there is much more mosaic than melting pot.
"There is not much interaction," said Robert Potter, a retired postal worker who was one of the first blacks to move into his block on Adee Avenue 31 years ago. "That may be a reason why we get along. Everybody takes care of his own property. We respect each other."
 
Upward Mobility
 For decades, this area of the Bronx has been a place where poor but upwardly mobile people from the South Bronx and upper Manhattan have bought homes and carved out a quiet middle-class existence. This section comprises roughly 85 blocks, bordered on the south by Allerton Avenue, the north by Burke Avenue, the west by the Botanical Garden and the east by East Gun Hill Road. To the north of Burke Avenue, the area becomes more heavily black. To the south of Allerton, it is mostly white.
Fifty years ago, it was Jews, Germans, Irish and Italians. Beginning 30 years ago, black Americans and West Indian blacks began moving up, followed more recently by Hispanic immigrants and a few Asians.
Through this change, the area has remained remarkably stable, even as whites have moved to the suburbs, died or retired out of the city. Median household income is $25,625, well above the figure for the Bronx of $21,944. Household median income for New York City is $29,823.
The number of people owning homes is also above the borough average. And in the 20 years after 1970, when the population of the Bronx dropped by nearly 270,000 to 1,204,000, this neighborhood has held steady at 25,000.
"That's the formula," said Dominick Castore, the chairman of Community Board 10, which encompasses most of the area. "It's everybody being in the same boat and finally getting to know that they have the same aspirations, the same hurts and the same blood. There is no difference."
The 49th Precinct, which covers most of the 85-block area, has one of the lowest crime rates in the Bronx. For instance, when compared with a South Bronx precinct, there are about half as many robberies, considered an indicator of street safety.
Though generally peaceful, Williamsbridge is one of 13 neighborhoods in the city being monitored closely by the city's Human Rights Commission as a potential spot for bias crimes. Last January, two black children were attacked by four white teen-agers and squirted with white paint, in an incident that community leaders worried might upset the area's good relations.
The reason for concern is that the white population has dropped significantly during the last 20 years, and such shifts frequently breed instability. In 1990, the Census Bureau recorded these proportions: white, 27 percent; non-Hispanic black, 34 percent; Hispanic, almost nonexistent in 1970, 35 percent.
North of Allerton Avenue and south of Burke Avenue, the residential blocks are racially mixed, according to 1990 census figures. It is a mix that Arthur Grant, a 53-year-old mail carrier, sees every day as he pushes his canvas sack around the neighborhood, stopping at houses where white, black and Hispanic families live next door to one another.
"It would be great if the city would be like this," he said on Allerton Avenue. "As a black man, I am treated equally by the blacks, the Spanish and the whites. I'm from Panama and I've seen people live like this regardless of color."
Mr. Grant waved over to a group of four men on the corner of Allerton and Barnes Avenue. The men were Italian, Jewish, Puerto Rican and Dominican. The Dominican, Rafael Diaz, a 54-year-old building superintendent on Barnes Avenue, was holding a big pair of clippers. He had just used them to pry off the toilet seat at the house of a friend, a Jewish man who lives south of Allerton.
"There are no problems," said Mr. Diaz, whose building is home to Nigerians, Jamaicans, Jews, Germans, Poles, Argentines and others. "Everything is quiet and the people are nice."
 
Can't See a Rainbow
 Professor Naison said that basic amity, though underlaced with fear and friction, is more the norm for race relations in New York City. Despite troubles in neighborhoods like Crown Heights, most ethnic groups tend to tolerate one another, he said, even if there is little understanding. Deeper social integration, the dream of a racial rainbow, remains out of the question for most groups.
"Some ideal of racial harmony is totally abstract from their lives because they are using ethnic networks for jobs, housing, credit," Professor Naison said. "There is a kind of very pragmatic aspect in terms of their survival in whom they choose as friends and and business partners. Some melting pot notion, it's coming from outer space."
Andrew Hacker, a political-science professor at Queens College and author of "Two Nations" (Scribners), a pessimistic look at American race relations, agreed that "the issue is not whether people socialize."
"It's not whether they have dinner or barbecue with other people," he said. "The question is can they simply say, 'This is a nice neighborhood. Our home doesn't feel threatened. It's safe enough for us and it is pleasant enough for us.' "
White residents say that this is true, an assertion that appears to be backed up by census data. Though the area has changed considerably during the last 20 years, the change has come slowly. Whites are not fleeing.
But Mr. Castore, the community board chairman, acknowledged that there was some resentment among older whites as they have become the minority. Resentment flares up occasionally in white pockets around the city, in Williamsbridge and Throgs Neck in the Bronx, in Canarsie and Flatbush in Brooklyn. Five years ago, for example, the son of one of Mr. Castore's board members, who is black, was chased near Christopher Columbus High School by nine young white men with bats.
Added to the mix in Williamsbridge, community leaders say, is an influx of Albanians, Russians and Central Europeans, whites who are in many cases unused to living side by side with other races. In the paint attack last January, a group called "the Albanian Boys" was suspected, though the police never made any arrests.
The neighborhood's strength, residents and officials said, is that beyond the incidents, there appear to be real efforts to adjust to diversity, efforts that have gone on for three decades since the first black families began moving in.
After the attack last January, for example, people of all colors marched side by side. Adele Maldonado, a 39-year-old housewife who is of Puerto Rican descent, said that she has never felt unwelcome since she moved from the South Bronx 19 years ago. She is trying to pass that feeling to her 11-year-old daughter, Amy, a fifth grader at Public School 89, an elementary school on Mace Avenue in Williambridge.
"I always explain to her that I wouldn't want her to be called spic or just off the banana boat," said Ms. Maldonado, who lives on Paulding Avenue at Allerton Avenue, one of the most mixed blocks in the area. "So I expect her to respect other people."
Ms. Maldonado said she was friendly, though not friends, with her neighbors. And many in the area said that while the barriers to living next to one another had dropped, there were still barriers to social interaction.
Though community organizations have banded together for specific causes -- the bias attack and to oppose the construction of a transient hotel on Boston Road, for instance -- individually many are stratified by race. There are divisions in churches: The congregation of Holy Rosary Church on Adee Avenue is 60 percent white, 30 percent black and 10 percent Hispanic, and many worship together, especially at the 11:30 A.M. folk Mass on Sundays.
But the pastor, the Rev. Francis X. Toner, said that of the 200 parishioners attending a recent dance, about 20 were black. At a steel drum concert, it was nearly all black. He believes the church has made great progress over the years, but in social events, "I'd like to see better."
Ted Finkelstein, director of the office of the Commission on Human Rights in the North Bronx, agreed. "The least one should expect is tolerance and there certainly is tolerance in that community," he said. "But that is a starting-off point."
But many residents said they did not think this lack of mixing was a problem. They said they were treated equally buying houses or shopping, either in Italian bakeries or places like Harry's Jerk Center, a new West Indian restaurant on Burke Avenue.
Mr. Potter, the retired postal worker, said he believed that true integration was simply not realistic.
In some imagined suburb, he said he could imagine children of all races, "like you see on television, where they run inside and drink juice and play football and so forth."
"But in the city itself, it doesn't happen," he added. "Things are polarized."

HEADLINE: MUSEUMGOERS;
Outreach Could Be A Way Out

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Carol Vogel's article on the budding romance between art museums and their public ["Dear Museumgoer: What Do You Think?," Dec. 20] notes that the institutions are seeking ways to draw in large numbers of visitors to make ends meet. While informative, the account omits some of the most important aspects of the problem. 
 If the only goal of museums is to fill their halls with the same kinds of visitors who have been coming to them, the situation is indeed serious. Missing from the article is any suggestion that museums have an obligation to expand their public beyond the highly educated, white middle class and to turn their attention to the less-educated, ethnically and racially diverse peoples of modest economic standing. This policy, formulated as outreach, was an important element of the Great Society programs of President Lyndon B. Johnson.
In a conference held at the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam early last month, under the auspices of the leading Dutch foundation for studies of the arts and cultural policy, many of the participating museum directors, scholars and policy makers were dismayed to learn that in some 15 countries fewer than 25 percent of the population had actually gone to an art museum.
It was suggested that one way of attracting less-conventional museumgoers is to organize exhibits likely to appeal to them. Even more important, it is essential to bring such programs to the attention of influential community leaders, so they can encourage their peers to attend.
Although certain museum watchers feel threatened by the very idea that artworks not usually highlighted will be given pride of place in what they have come to view as their museums, they must bear in mind that in democratic societies, their taste is not the only one that should count. Furthermore, as institutions such as the Brooklyn Museum, with its important African artworks, and the Corcoran Gallery, whose exhibit "Facing History: Images of Blacks Refracted in a White Mirror," have shown, esthetic quality need not be compromised by such efforts.
 
VERA L. ZOLBERG
New York
 
The writer teaches at the New School for Social Research in Manhattan and is a visiting professor in the sociology of art at the University of Amsterdam.

HEADLINE: OFF THE COUCH

 BODY:
If modern psychiatry has grown up to join its cousins in the medical and surgical specialities, then it, too, faces the practical constraints of governmental agencies and insurance companies. The author neglects the fact that such regulations often dictate the type of treatment patients receive or the length of time they may remain in treatment. If there is a perception that modern psychiatry is about medication, or that the battle is about whether to medicate or not to medicate, then we should understand that psychiatrists, as doctors, are influenced (and often compromised) by political and economic realities. The bottom line may be that a bottle of pills is worth more than an empathetic ear. Whoever still thinks "talk is cheap" should have his head examined.
 
MITCHELL S. NOBLER, M.D.
New York, N.Y.

HEADLINE: Council's Land-Use Procedures Emerging

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
TWO years after the Board of Estimate was disbanded and the ultimate authority for planning and zoning passed to the City Council, patterns have begun to emerge in how land-use decisions are made. Perhaps most striking is the way the Council has given up some of the reflexive parochialism that characterized its predecessor.
While borough presidents on the Board of Estimate generally followed the lead of the colleague in whose borough a given project was situated, Council members have shown no such inclination, at least in certain key votes. "The parochial issues, while important, are not controlling," said the Speaker of the Council, Peter F. Vallone of Queens. 
 Not everyone is cheered by this trend. "Nobody knows my district better than me," said Councilman Michael DeMarco of the Bronx, whose opposition to a condominium development on City Island did not sway the Council, which approved it. "Why should a person in Brooklyn or Queens tell me what I should have in my district?" he asked.
The Board of Estimate passed out of existence in August 1990, when the Council replaced it as the final authority in the uniform land-use review procedure, known by the ungainly acronym Ulurp (pronounced YOO-lurp). It is too early to tell how much these traits are governed by personalities, rather than process, or whether they would survive in a development boom.
Almost everyone agrees that the new procedure is more complicated, and that frustrates both developers and neighborhood leaders. The City Planning Department may take at least six months to certify that an application is ready for review. Then the community board has 60 days to consider it. The Borough President has another 30 days, the City Planning Commission another 60 days, the Council another 50 days, and the Mayor another 5 days. And the Council has another 10 days to override a mayoral veto.
Negotiations, which amounted to 11th-hour, late-night combat at the Board of Estimate, now seem to occur earlier in the process. That gives elected officials more opportunity to shape a project's broad outlines at the beginning but less chance to craft the critical details at the end.
There are many more participants than before. Yet the Council is much more firmly under the control of one person -- Mr. Vallone -- than the board ever was.
One similarity between the two is that the Council, like the board, tends to leave all but the most high-profile matters pretty much the way they arrive from city planners. The planning chairman, Richard L. Schaffer, said, "I can probably count on one hand, with fingers left over, the number of commission actions that have been turned down by the Council." And he said the number of modifications was "very, very small."
OF all the developments in the new process, however, perhaps most striking is the degree to which the Council has turned its back on the tradition of "legislative courtesy." Instead of following the lead of colleagues whose districts are most affected, many Council members take their cues from Mr. Vallone, his staff and allies.
"People don't know what they're voting on," said Councilwoman Ronnie M. Eldridge, of the Upper West Side of Manhattan. "They're very busy. They don't know the communities. So they defer to the leadership. It's actually a very strange procedure."
She watched last month as the Council voted 42 to 8 in favor of Donald J. Trump's Riverside South project in her district.
In August, the Council approved a plan to build a garbage-burning incinerator in the Brooklyn Navy Yard by a vote of 36 to 15, despite the opposition of the local member, Kenneth K. Fisher, and colleagues from a wide geographical ring around the yard.
An expanded municipal parking lot, garage, vehicle maintenance and fueling center on Piers 35-36 on the Lower East Side was opposed by Kathryn E. Freed and Antonio Pagan, both of whose districts would be affected. But it passed the Council.
"The prediction was that the Council would be very parochial," said Frederick A.O. Schwarz Jr., who was the chairmain of the Charter Revision Commission in 1989. "We didn't think that would be the case, but it was a responsible worry."
Instead, he said, the Council's "record so far is reasonably good." One reason he cited is that the Council has 51 members, compared to eight on the board, and "therefore any given member -- leaving the Speaker aside -- is going to have less influence."
For his part, Mr. Vallone downplays his role. "By the time you get to me, I'm just another Council member voting," he said. "I'm not going to exercise my position as Speaker to do anything other than support a fair and honest legislative process."
Mr. Vallone allowed that the dynamics of the new process were a bit surprising. "The strange part of this," he said, "the learning experience to me, was that we seem to be doing better forging a consensus, because everyone knows that if you want to stop a project in your district, it's more than saying, 'I'm opposed to it.' "
Mr. Trump found himself traveling to parts of New York City that he had never before visited, as he courted Council members in their district offices.
"Under this process, everybody is a free agent and that's a much tougher aspect," Mr. Trump said. "You can have the Borough President on board and that's very helpful. But the fact is, it doesn't necessarily mean you're going to get something approved. Whereas, in the Board of Estimate, it was tantamount -- unwrittenly -- to approval."
The waning of parochialism may be a case of the "right result for the wrong reason," said Councilman Charles Millard, a Manhattan Republican.
"I don't like the fact that people vote so often out of support for the Speaker," he said. "But the result -- as we saw in the piers on the Lower East Side and in the Trump project -- is that instead of supporting the local member, there is a somewhat greater support for the overall good of the city."
Mr. Vallone cited Sea Breeze, a 55-unit condominium proposed on City Island, which was opposed by Councilman DeMarco.
"Mike said, 'I'm opposed and, as a matter of legislative courtesy, you should oppose it,' " Mr. Vallone recalled. "But I made it a leadership matter and said, 'That's not a reason to vote against it.' "
Mr. DeMarco said his opposition to Sea Breeze had to do with overcrowding in the neighborhood, sanitation problems and public access to waterways.
"This is not like a school or a hospital or some sort of municipal thing that will give service to everybody but nobody wants it in their back yard," he said. "We didn't need additional, middle-class housing on City Island. If anything, we probably need less."
In the case of the Lower East Side piers, Councilwoman Freed noted that they were "directly across from a huge population" in several large housing projects, and near Gouverneur Hospital -- "the worst possible place to put a facility that's going to increase traffic, air pollution and noise pollution."
Councilwoman June M. Eisland of the Bronx, head of the Land Use Committee, said she was "never comfortable coming out with a decision that's in opposition to a member." But she said there was an issue of citywide importance, the rehabilitation of the Williamsburg Bridge, which required moving garages from under the bridge to the piers. She said the Council improved the project by turning a proposed esplanade -- "Muggers' Alley," she called it -- into a park on Pier 35.
Had legislative courtesy prevailed, Riverside South would have been defeated. Six Council members from the West Side opposed it: Thomas K. Duane, Ms. Eldridge, C. Virginia Fields, Guillermo Linares, Stanley E. Michels and Adam C. Powell.
Yet it was approved by everyone else, except Una Clarke and Annette M. Robinson of Brooklyn (and Carolyn B. Maloney of Manhattan, who was in Washington setting up her new Congressional office and was counted as absent in the tally).
"There's an unspoken feeling that Brooklyn knows what's best for Brooklyn and Queens knows what's best for Queens," Mr. Powell said. "But when it comes to Manhattan, it's like: 'We don't care what the Manhattan leadership wants. We're going to do what we feel is right for Manhattan.' "
Perhaps most frustrating to the community was that Riverside South's density -- it may house up to 11,350 people -- was barely touched upon, although the Council conditioned Mr. Trump's plan for a television studio on a special permit, perhaps dooming it.
"The leadership heard from their friends, contributors and allies that the residential density was what was needed for the project," Ms. Eldridge said. "Then they took care of what they could negotiate." Mr. Trump's studio, she noted, was seen as potential competition to the Kaufman-Astoria studios in Mr. Vallone's district.
BUT Ms. Eisland said the Council's action on the studio was part of the effort to reduce density. And, she added, it was "significant" that Riverside South arrived with the endorsement of Borough President Ruth W. Messinger, who made no specific recommendation about density, and the unanimous approval of the City Planning Commission, which left residential density untouched.
Marla G. Simpson, director of land-use planning for Ms. Messinger, said it was "assumed, as had always been the case with the Board of Estimate, that the end game would focus on density."
"Since density is really the fundamental issue that drives the economics of the project," she said, "you can't really know what the break-even point is until you know what the rest of your package looks like. We assumed that there needed to be some real attention to density. We never, in our initial agreement with the Trump Organization, endorsed the density of their proposal."
"It turned to be something that the Council didn't want to deal with at all," she said.
In other ways, however, the Borough President arguably helped shape the agenda at the planning commission and in the Council. Ms. Messinger bargained for concessions from Mr. Trump, signed a memorandum of understanding with him and prepared a 95-page report on Riverside South.
Ms. Messinger believes Borough Presidents have more influence in the new system. One reason is that each Borough President appoints a member to the planning commission and is formally involved at the earliest stage of the review procedure, as its very scope is being determined.
"When you get a seat at the table to discuss what is going to be the scope of the environmental review, you can use that as an opportunity to signal what are going to be your ultimate concerns," Ms. Messinger said.
"While that's obviously a complicated process and one that requires a little bit of strategic planning for the developer," she said, "it's much better than the late-night, one-hour gladiatorial window of opportunity, when everybody jumps in the ring and the question is, who's standing at the end?"
But even if no one is sporting a "Bring Back the Board" button, those gladiatorial sessions served a purpose.
"If the Planning Commission fell down, we could get planning done at the Board of Estimate," said Sally Goodgold, chairwoman of the City Club of New York, a civic group. "We did reduce density and change things."
Moreover, she said, because the Comptroller had a seat on the board, budgetary considerations were woven into land-use review. "Now, a lot of things fall through the cracks," Ms. Goodgold said, "primarily issues of fiscal importance."
Marilyn Gelber, executive assistant to Borough President Howard Golden of Brooklyn, noted the board's role as a "unifying body" whose authority covered not only land-use matters but city contracts. "That gave you the ability to look comprehensively at a project," she said, "and, if there were problems, nothing was out of bounds."
"IF you were asked to approve the disposition of property for a day-care center," Ms. Gelber said, "you would also vote on the business terms of the lease and the social-service contract."
But Ms. Eisland said the Council was trying to forge an equally broad role and its insistence on examining safety and budgetary matters when it reviewed day-care center leases was a source of "considerable contention" with the Dinkins administration.
The question of what is in and out of bounds for review is a sore point.
"You go through so many groups," Mr. Trump said, "and everybody takes a slice. It's such a long process and such an unwieldy process. It would be nice if it could somehow be consolidated so there is one bite out of the apple instead of three or four or five or six."
"Issues can come up for the first time at a very, very late point in the process," said Shelly S. Friedman of Brown & Wood, who represented Stephen Muss, the developer of the Brighton by the Sea project in Brooklyn.
"There are players who are tangential to the process but for the requirement that they vote," Mr. Friedman said. "They prefer to remain uninformed about an application, then we show up at the City Council and it becomes an opportunity for a certain amount of street theater. That's not something that happened often in the Board of Estimate."
But Mr. Duane, who was one of those raising last-minute objections, blamed a process in which basic issues are settled at the outset, leaving Council members and community boards "to tinker at the sides."
"The old Board of Estimate was undemocratic," he said. "The potential for a better process is with the Council. We're part of the way there, but we have a way to go yet."

HEADLINE: Talking: Superliens;
A Condo's Foreclosure Rights

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
THE drive to insure more effective collection of delinquent common charges and monthly maintenance payments is moving into the political arena.
Only there, say lawyers and officials who have been involved, can many of the problems that have plagued condominiums, homeowner associations and co-ops since the start of the recession be sorted out, since legal remedies are proving inadequate. 
 In New York State the difficulties have been compounded by the state's lengthy foreclosure procedures. It can take up to three years, about three times longer than anywhere else, to evict someone who is in default. This is a burden on neighbors who must pick up the shortfall.
"The boards think it's our fault when we can't get the person out sooner," said Stuart Saft, a lawyer and chairman of the Council of New York Cooperatives. "But unless they help us fight for change, it's going to stay that way."
For 15 years, efforts have been made all across the country to give a condominium or homeowner association "superlien" powers -- the right to dip into the proceeds of any foreclosure and take out at least six months' worth of unpaid common charges ahead of the lender who normally holds priority rights. Such powers are needed, say the advocates, because it is one of the few means open to associations in a foreclosure to recover unpaid common charges. They can't even charge the new owner because a foreclosure usually wipes out all debts against a unit.
But only a handful of states -- Alabama, Colorado, Connecticut, Florida, Nevada, Pennsylvania, Washington and West Virginia and the District of Columbia -- have passed such legislation, and it's getting tough to tempt others.
Robert Diamond, a lawyer in Falls Church, Va., who represents both lenders and associations and who helped draft model legislation in 1976, said the current rise in unit owner defaults, coupled with tighter banking regulation, had cooled lenders to this concession. They now want to hang onto every penny they can get and oppose any superlien bill that comes up for consideration.
Thus, he said, unless individual associations make their concerns known to their legislators, it is doubtful that the list will get much longer.
Barbara Beach, staff vice president for public affairs with the Condominium Associations Institute in Alexandria, Va., the national network of people in the common ownership field, recommends combining individual letter-writing campaigns with personal meetings with local representatives. In addition, she said, associations should form coalitions and work collectively through such groups as the state chapters of C.A.I., which are forming legislative action committees.
Politicians agree. "We might not have lost the opportunity in the past if these people had been more vocal," said Oliver Koppell, chairman of the Judiciary Committee of the New York State Assembly.
But Gurdon Buck, a lawyer in Hartford and the supervisory council member of the Six Committees on Housing of the American Bar Association, warned that any attempt to win superlien powers should be tied to a total overhaul of condominium legislation and achieved through the passage of model legislation known as the Uniform Common Interest Ownership Act.
He said that when superlien legislation was attempted as a separate issue it ran into roadblocks, normally because of lender objections. By contrast, a total overhaul of common ownership legislation normally includes added protection for lenders on other issues, such as construction loans and greater certainty of title on individual units. In exchange, lenders are more willing to concede the priority lien.
James L. Winokur, a professor of law at the University of Denver College of Law, who has also been involved in the adoption of a superlien nationwide, further warned lobbyists not be greedy. Any new bill, he said, must contain a limit on that right, usually six months' worth of unpaid charges.
"ANYTHING more and lenders will stop making condo loans," he warned. When Rhode Island provided its condominiums with up to five years' in arrears ahead of the mortgage holder last year, he noted, the outcry from lenders was so intense that the state had to quickly amend the provision to the usual six months.
This is why it's becoming so important for condominium leaders in New York State to lobby for a streamlining of foreclosure proceedings. Without this, six months' worth of unpaid charges would represent no more than a drop in the bucket, since a delinquent owner could remain in the unit more than another two years.
New York co-ops need to react to a different obstacle. Ironically, co-ops have long enjoyed superlien powers of unlimited duration because of their different legal structure. But in the last few months lenders who make individual share loans, led by representatives of the Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, have been seeking the removal of those powers.
They also want to curtail the right of co-op boards to screen prospective buyers following a foreclosure. The lenders' aim is to make it easier to recoup their losses when their loans go bad.
William Jay Lippman, a Manhattan lawyer who has been involved in these discussions, recommends compromise.
Without some sign of flexibility by co-ops, he warned, even the few lenders still active in the co-op lending market may disappear, which could further erode values and prolong the gridlock.
His suggestion is therefore to agree to limit current superlien powers to six months. This would bring co-ops in line with condominiums. He further suggested that a co-op corporation require its board to provide a "reasonable" basis for refusing a lender's applicant -- something they do not now have to do.
"But those lenders are not going to ring any doorbells telling you to make these changes," he said. Nor will they be changed through legislation. It's going to be up to the board to get it done through amendments to the co-op's governing documents.
And it won't be easy. Such changes normally require the approval of two-thirds, sometimes even three-quarters, of the shareholders.
Alternatively, the boards could heed the advice of Mr. Saft, who argues that even without the recommended changes lenders will eventually return to the co-op market because it's too lucrative a source of banking profits to write off.
