HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Phipps Houses President;
A Developer Retires

 BODY:
"I'm not sick," said Lynda Simmons. "I'm not being fired. I just decided that this is the time."
The 58-year-old Ms. Simmons was talking about her retirement last Thursday as president of Phipps Houses, New York's oldest and largest developer of low- and moderate-income communities. She had worked at Phipps for 23 years, the last 10 as president. Phipps owns and manages 3,600 apartments for homeless and low- and moderate-income tenants and, through a subsidiary, manages 5,800 other apartments. 
 Ms. Simmons also headed the Phipps Community Development Corporation, which organizes human and educational services as well as job-training programs. In the 1970's, she helped pioneer the concept of coordinated community renewal with Phipps Houses' involvement in the comprehensive renewal of the West Farms area of the South Bronx, an involvement that continues.
"My contribution, I believe, has been in reconceptualizing 'housing' as 'community,' Ms. Simmons said. "In my years at Phipps Houses we have moved steadily toward designing each building or group of buildings as a physical community, with indoor meeting rooms and outdoor 'living rooms,' and a deliberate social community." At Phipps, Ms. Simmons also developed Phipps Plaza West, a complex of 894 apartments completed in 1976 on Second Avenue between 26th and 29th Streets in Manhattan. "I think that there we have proved that beauty is biologically important," she said, "and that beauty pays off in terms of reduced real-estate maintenance costs as well as better lives for residents."
She decided to retire now, she said, because "it seems the least disruptive time for me to leave the organization, because it allows a new Phipps Houses leader to begin the new developments he or she will carry out under a new Federal administration." A search committee has been formed to find that leader, with a target date of this summer.
Her plans? "I'm certainly not retiring in the sense of never doing anything," she said. "I am redeploying my efforts."

HEADLINE: SEEN;
The Straight-Faced Revs and Cost

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER

 BODY:
REVS and Cost -- two men whose nicknames, printed on signs all over Manhattan from the Battery to 96th Street, have puzzled New Yorkers for a year -- are as enigmatic as their posters.
The signs, with cryptic messages like "Who killed Revs" and "Hello my name is Cost," first appeared almost a year ago in SoHo, and soon spread to St. Marks Place, Sheridan Square, Lincoln Center and points north. 
 In a recent interview in Washington Square Park, the two spoke on condition that they be identified only by their nicknames. They kept secret even their ages -- they appear to be in their mid-20's -- and the neighborhoods where they lived.
"We want people to say, 'What the hell is going on?' " said Cost, who is unemployed and was wearing jeans, high-top sneakers, a red baseball cap over his close-cut black hair and headphones around his neck.
So, what is going on? "There is no direct answer," Cost said, smirking. "Once you've figured us out, game over. If you could give us the meaning of life, I'd give you the meaning of us."
Revs, his hair short and blond, wore an Army-style field jacket, faded jeans and a pair of battered canvas sneakers. He works in an office by day and goes on postering missions, as he called them, by night.
"Real art is not hanging in the Louvre," Revs said morosely. "It's in the gutter."
Revs and Cost met several years ago when they were both writing graffiti on buildings and walls in the city. Cost got his name from the tag that he was spray-painting. The two met again a year ago, only to discover that each was wheat-pasting posters with his name around the city, using a mixture of flour and water.
Revs said he adopted his name about a year ago, after almost jumping off the Manhattan Bridge late one night. "Revs is short for Revs Suicide," he said, adding that it stands for many things but declining to elaborate. "I just walked down from the bridge, and ever since that day, I've known what to do."
Cost said: "We both started the campaign by ourselves. I was doing mine, and he was doing his."
Revs and Cost, aware that their signs were arousing curiosity around the city, began putting a telephone number on them. "I like to be incognito, but we have to have some way of contacting the public," Cost explained.
Those who expect to be enlightened over the phone will be disappointed. On an answering machine, the voice of a woman who calls herself "the infamous grandma of graff" (short for graffiti, Revs said), says: "My intuition tells me that you're asking yourselves who are Revs and Cost and what are they doing? What is it? What does it mean? What does it mean? What does it mean?"
Revs and Cost boasted about the calls. "We get 80 calls a day," Cost said. "We've gotten a marriage proposal on there."
"Was it the anti-Cost?" Revs asked his partner. "That chick?"
"Yup."
Revs and Cost warned that the posters are merely the first phase of a campaign that would "tear the city to pieces and rebuild it," Revs said.
"It's starting out as kind of abstract," Revs added mysteriously, "but soon, the pieces are going to form a clear picture."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Posters on this temporary structure in Times Square bear the names of the mysterious Cost and Revs. (Jim Pearson for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Stocks Are Expensive, But Does It Matter?

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
AS 1993 begins, the best thing that can be said for the American stock market is that most of the alternatives may be even worse.
It is not, of course, that stocks are cheap. By most valuation standards, they are far from that. A buyer of the stocks in the Standard and Poor's 500 now is getting a dividend yield of just 2.9 percent. That's less miserly than the 2.7 percent yield just before the 1987 crash, but it is well below historical averages. 
 Stocks don't look a lot cheaper when the current prices are compared to the shares' book value, or to corporate earnings.
But none of that seems to matter to those who are buying stocks. Last week brought the news that mutual fund investors had poured more money into stock funds in November than in any other month in history. The December figure looks like it will be close to that level as well.
One way to look at the $9.9 billion that went into stock funds in November is that it is more than went into all such funds, on a net basis, for the three years 1988 through 1990. And much of that money is going into the riskiest funds, the kind that buy small stocks and hope they will soar. Those hopes are coming true. The Nasdaq composite has risen 16 percent since the end of September, and ended 1992 at a record.
The big losers were professional short-sellers, who bet that stocks they deemed to be overvalued would decline. They typically run money for other people, and the funds they manage were showing decent profits for the year only three months ago. Now they show only red ink, and many fund investors chose to exercise their rights to bail out at year end. One result has been substantial buying of stocks by these funds, pushing prices of some of the least deserving stocks ever higher.
It is tempting to dismiss such things as euphoria and the kind of overconfidence that is present at market tops. And it may be correct to do so. But the question that bears have to answer is simple: If not American stocks, what? European stocks are suffering from weak economies and high German interest rates. Everybody on Wall Street knew a year ago that European bonds were a good investment, and they all lost money on the trade when currencies crumbled. This year the optimism is back, but it is tempered.
In this country real estate looks dubious, and everyone knows how illiquid it can be. Gold is all but forgotten as an investment. Bonds may be attractive, but there is real risk in buying long-term issues, and little reward from buying short-term ones. The banks don't want money, which is why they pay so little for it.
In the 1980's the idea spread that annual returns of 8 percent or more were an inalienable right. With interest rates low, many investors concluded they ought to buy stocks to have a hope of getting the returns they expected.
With that in mind, Wall Street has scheduled a flood of new stock offerings for early 1993. The demand for stocks, in other words, may be equalled by the supply. Or even exceeded.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Some Opportunities Abroad for 1993

BYLINE: By Kenneth N. Gilpin

 BODY:
FOR international equity investors, 1992 was largely a forgettable year, the third straight in which returns on American stocks outpaced gains in foreign markets.
Chances are slim that 1993 will produce a similar result, according to a sampling of portfolio managers here and abroad. Despite the mediocre returns of foreign markets, these professionals maintain that investing in them still makes a great deal of sense. 
 "We continue to be encouraged about 1993 and beyond because growth in many parts of the world continues to outstrip growth in the United States," said Jeffrey Russell, a portfolio manager at Smith Barney's World Funds International Equity portfolio.
"We think that over time you will earn commensurate rewards overseas, and that individual investors should have 15 percent to 20 percent of their assets" invested in foreign stocks.
Peering into 1993, the analysts say they see opportunities in a number of markets.
Despite strong gains over the last two years, Mr. Russell continues to like the prospects of the Mexican market and has 14 percent of his fund's assets invested there, his largest investment in any one country.
Strategists are also more optimistic about Europe's prospects, particularly those countries that have followed Britain's lead and decoupled their currencies from the European Monetary System. That decision has allowed the Bank of England and other central banks to ease interest rates, setting the stage for economic recovery.
"In Europe, we would be in countries that have ended or suspended their ties to the European Monetary System," said Marcus Grubb, an international strategist at Salomon Brothers in London.
As Britain slowly emerges from its long and painful recession this year, Mr. Grubb expects engineering companies like Siebeto to prosper, along with consumer-oriented stocks like Grand Metropolitan, Tate & Lyle and Hanson. He also favors interest-rate-sensitive bank stocks, especially Barclays.
"The markets that got hit the hardest by high interest rates should begin to return to normalcy in 1993," said Harold Sharon, an assistant portfolio manager at the Warburg-Pincus International Equity Fund. "Those markets, which include Finland, Norway, Sweden and Denmark, are the ones that will bounce back, and they are already doing so."
Analysts also expect interest rates to fall in France and Germany, the two remaining pillars of Europe's drive for monetary union.
A decline in French rates should help revive its economy and give stock prices a boost on the Paris Bourse. But the analysts see few gains in German stocks.
"We are not very positive on Germany, even though we think they will cut rates in 1993," said Sandor Cseh, president of Cseh International, a money management firm in Berwyn, Pa. "They have to assimilate East Germany, and that is not an easy task."
Falling European interest rates are not altogether good news for international investors, however, because they tend to strengthen the value of the dollar.
The problems of a stronger dollar were acutely felt by those who had money in the British market during the fourth quarter. As the Bank of England pushed down rates, British stocks rallied strongly in the final three months of 1992, rising by more than 14 percent in local currency terms. But the dollar appreciated even faster against the pound, leaving dollar-based investors with a negative return exceeding 6 percent.
Stability with the dollar is one reason that portfolio managers prefer Hong Kong, whose own dollar is tied to America's.
Despite political tensions between China and the British Governor of Hong Kong, the Hong Kong market was one of the stars of 1992, as share prices rose by more than 24 percent in American dollar terms.
Victoria Goodwin, a senior vice president at James Capel, said she expected a similar performance this year. "Hong Kong's link to the dollar, extremely attractive corporate earnings growth and its relationship with the rapidly developing Chinese economy were the reasons shares did well in 1992 and are the reasons Hong Kong will outperform in 1993," she said.
Elsewhere in Asia, Ms. Goodwin said the nascent American recovery should help lift stock prices in South Korea, whose economy is "highly geared" to consumer-products companies exporting to the United States.
And what of the the world's second-largest stock market, in steady decline for the last two years?
"The big question for any international investor is Japan," Mr. Sharon said.
In dollar terms, share prices fell by more than 20 percent in Tokyo last year. Amid a recession and continued problems in banking and real estate, analysts say, Japanese stocks may fall some more this year. But they also say the deterioration in prices since 1990 had made some issues very attractive.
"You may see some more weakness," said John R. Hickling, manager of Fidelity Investment's International Growth and Income Fund. "But I wouldn't be surprised if at some point six months to a year from now I will read articles saying that fund managers are getting their heads handed to them because they are underinvested in Japan."
Mr. Hickling says he has been buying shares in some Japanese insurers. He also likes Sega and Nintendo, whose computer games "are selling like gangbusters."
And Ms. Goodwin said: "Japan has to be one of the most interesting markets. The second half of 1993 could be the time to invest there."

HEADLINE: Investors' Sentiment Rises, but Are They Wrong?

BYLINE: BY FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
INVESTORS, like other consumers, are looking over the American economy and finding more to cheer about. That may be a reason for caution in buying stock.
The University of Michigan has been separating out the attitudes of investors, as opposed to more plebeian consumers, for only three years. But the university's survey is already beginning to look as though it might have some value as a contrary indicator. 
 The December survey, conducted for Fidelity Investments, showed an investor sentiment reading of 93.8, up sharply over the past two months. The figure, which measures the attitude of investors toward the economy, had not topped 90 since the summer of 1990, just before Iraq invaded Kuwait, and shortly before stock prices plunged.
By October of that year, when stock prices were bottoming, the survey showed investor sentiment down to 64.1. That was the lowest level in the three years the survey has been conducted, and it came at what proved to be the best time to buy stocks, just before an explosive rally began.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Careful Picks, Modest Expectations

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
DISAPPOINTED after 1991's big gains, when the average stock fund shot up 30.7 percent, only a handful of investors saw double-digit returns last year -- and 1993 looks like more of the same.
Post-election euphoria sent the stock market spinning up at yearend, but most analysts expect the afterglow to fade. In bonds, there is a chance of perhaps one more interest rate cut as the Federal Reserve gives the economy a final push. Call it a fund-picker's market, in which investors will have to thread their way carefully and should expect modest investment returns. 
 Even so, three investment advisers, asked to craft model portfolios for 1993, showed unusual unanimity. All rejected funds that buy big stocks in favor of those that hold small and mid-sized companies, which are expected to reassert their historic advantage in total return. All also opted for managers who use a value approach, seeking undervalued stocks, rather than growth managers, who buy companies with a potential for above-average earnings growth. Overseas, badly battered Europe was the favorite.
Stay away from the Standard & Poor's 500 in 1993, said Don Phillips, vice president of Morningstar Inc., mutual fund researchers in Chicago, who allocated 90 percent of his model portfolio to domestic stocks.
The big growth stocks that have led the market since 1988 have become very expensive, so Mr. Phillips would divide one-half the portfolio equally between the Strong Common Stock Fund and the Yacktman Fund, both diversified and both favoring small and mid-sized stocks. The funds' managers built good long-term track records elsewhere: Carlene Murphy and Richard Weiss at Stein Roe Special, and Don Yacktman at Selected American Shares. Mr. Phillips calls them good stock-pickers who rummage for value in sluggish markets rather than wait for trends to favor their strategies.
Mr. Phillips said he would invest 30 percent in the Fidelity Balanced Fund, partly as a defensive move because its manager, Robert Haber, "is particularly bearish on S.& P. stocks, so he combines bonds with esoteric stocks, primarily smaller ones with value orientations."
He would allocate 10 percent of the portfolio to the Third Avenue Fund which, because it invests primarily in distressed companies, does not move in synch with the overall market and should profit as the economy moves out of recession.
The final 10 percent is invested in the Financial Strategic European Fund. While there is some currency risk, European shares are cheap today as the region grapples with what some analysts call the equivalent of the 1973-1974 bear market in the United States. Well-known value managers like Warren Buffet and John Templeton are buying there.
Small-capitalization value funds occupy 40 percent of the portfolio constructed by Anthony J. Ogorek, an investment adviser based in Buffalo -- 25 percent in a brand-new fund, Oakmark, run by Robert Sandborn, a value manager who buys mainly smaller companies, and 15 percent to the T. Rowe Price Small Cap Value Fund, which buys and sells stocks more quickly than most others.
The United States stock portion (30 percent) is divided evenly between the Clipper Fund and Stratton Monthly Dividend. Clipper is a traditional value fund that buys mid-sized companies, but unlike most value funds has managed to outperform the S.& P. 500 by two-and-a-half percentage points a year, on average, during the last five years. Stratton, which invests mainly in electric utilities, is managed for yield, now roughly 6.8 percent.
Mr. Ogorek invests the remaining one-third of the portfolio in bond funds, planning to capture gains from what he believes will be another small drop in interest rates. The Fidelity Convertible Securities Fund (15 percent) avoids blue chips and yields about 4 percent. The Vanguard Intermediate Term Municipal Bond Fund, a diversified tax-free fund that holds high-rated issues, yields a little over 5 percent.
The big theme for 1993 is diversification because no one sector is outstanding, said Kenneth E. Gregory, a San Francisco-based investment adviser who edits the L/G No Load Fund Analyst. He would put one-third of his portfolio into United States stocks with a small-cap and value bias. Mutual Discovery (20 percent) is a new offering by Michael Price, whom Mr. Gregory calls a "savvy stock-picker." The fund has a bigger-than-usual exposure to overseas stocks, mainly in Europe. The Monetta Fund (15 percent) focuses primarily on small and mid-sized companies but takes more of a growth approach.
The foreign stock portion (20 percent) would be divided equally between Harbor International (two-thirds in Europe) and the Montgomery Emerging Markets Fund (Latin America and Asia), both of which avoid Japanese investments.
Mr. Gregory would put 15 percent into the Vanguard Corporate High-Yield Fund, which buys top-tier junk issues, to cash in on the improving economy. He would put 25 percent in the Harbor Bond Fund, which has some foreign exposure and a "barbell" strategy -- very short or very long maturities -- to balance the stock portion and because inflation should remain low in '93. The remaining 5 percent would go to the Fidelity REIT Fund, yielding about 6 percent from investments in rental properties.
 
 
 
BUYING THE MANAGERS THEMSELVES
 AS was the case in 1991, investors who bought shares in publicly traded mutual fund companies tended to earn bigger returns in 1992 than those with a portfolio of growth funds.
The Lipper mutual fund management company stock price index, a weighted average of the companies' stock price performance, showed a 16 percent gain in 1992, compared with a scant 7 percent for the Lipper growth fund index. (Franklin Resources and Eaton Vance, having split their shares two-for-one in 1992, are not listed individually.) The management company edge would have been even greater if dividends had been included, as they are in the growth fund index.
The equation is simple: "Assets expanded, and assets mean revenue, which means the stocks perform well," said Stephen A. Schoepke, an analyst with Lipper Analytical Services in Summit, N.J. Assets industrywide grew $250 billion to $1.6 trillion by the end of November, the latest data available.

HEADLINE: The Crucial Link for Labor Talks

 BODY:
With talks progressing between the city and its municipal unions, it's crucial that Mayor Dinkins and his negotiators stand firm on the central issue: linking wage increases to productivity gains and other concessions. Should the city abandon that demand, the public will bear the burden.
The latest reports are not encouraging. Initially Mr. Dinkins insisted on a fundamental principle: no increases larger than those in the city's long-range financial plan unless the unions pay for them with concessions and increased productivity. The plan calls for no increases for two years, then an increase of 1.5 percent in the third year and 2 percent in the fourth. 
 The city still wants concessions and productivity gains. But now news accounts indicate that officials are no longer insisting savings pay for the entire wage increase. Such backtracking raises the possibility that the contract won't contain any substantive concessions, which would be a lost opportunity for a city still struggling with recession.
It would also represent a retreat from the kind of leadership Mr. Dinkins displayed in the early going. By demanding productivity and work rule concessions in exchange for larger wage increases, Mr. Dinkins was finally trying to gain the upper hand with the unions that worked to elect him three years ago.
He cannot afford to give in now. Meaningful productivity gains and work rule concessions are essential first steps toward a labor policy that emanates from City Hall, not union halls.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Two Who Know Thin Ice Affirm a Thaw

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
ONE of them was arriving from a war zone, Yevgeny Ignatenko, Mikhail S. Gorbachev's old spokesman, observed the other day, and the other from the killing fields of political combat. One has lost his grip on office; the other lives in peril of doing so.
So when President Bush and Boris N. Yeltsin sit down in Moscow in these early hours of 1993 to sign the most sweeping arms reduction treaty of the nuclear age they do so at a moment when much about their countries' future relationship is hard to fathom. 
 This is George Bush's last hurrah, his final foreign trip as President. Remarkably, it celebrates two achievements that postdate his defeat at the polls, the arms agreement and the use of American and other foreign troops to make possible the effective distribution of food to the starving Somalis. Mr. Bush may have been stunned by his loss but he was not immobilized.
In Little Rock, Bill Clinton waits, just offstage. He has given the second Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, known as Start II, his tentative blessing. Better to strike a deal, one of his aides said last week, while the striking was good, than to wait until after Jan. 20, when the pressure on both sides to compromise would be greatly lessened by the onset of a new Administration.
Now Mr. Clinton must win Senate ratification for the new treaty, which should not be difficult. He will also have to establish a working relationship with Mr. Yeltsin or whoever succeeds him, which might be more problematical. Most difficult of all, he must decide what, if anything, the United States can do to help stave off economic or political disintegration in Russia and the other countries of the former Soviet Union, which would gravely undermine world stability.
Having made his way through fractious conferences and congresses and having achieved his first big treaty, Mr. Yeltsin still has to worry about his job. Like other Russian leaders before him, he will try to use the accord to suggest that he is the indispensable man who alone can insure a relatively comfortable place for his nation in an uncomfortable world. He can argue that arms reduction frees money for economic development. But conservatives can reply that it weakens the nation and wastes the billions that were spent to develop and produce the weapons now to be cast aside.
If he remains in office, the Russian President will have to take the measure of Mr. Clinton and of the new political climate in Washington and react accordingly. He has faced no such challenge before; Mr. Bush is the only President he has known.
In their rush, both sides have had to yield on what they had considered vital points. The United States, for example, agreed to permit the Russians to reuse 90 silos built for their gargantuan SS-18 missiles for newer, smaller missiles, provided that they are reduced in size by partly filling them with concrete, which would make reconversion much more difficult. Such concessions are the stuff of compromise, of course, but at a less harried moment their consequences could have been more carefully considered by both sides.
Few believe that this treaty is based on miscalculations as grievous as those that marked another momentous conference on Russian soil, the one held in February 1945 at Yalta. Time was short then, too. Churchill lived to rue his judgment of Stalin, delivered in a toast at the final dinner, that "friendship and intimacy with this great man" made the world a safer place for freedom and justice.
Yalta would have been a fine site for the Bush-Yeltsin meeting. It was not chosen because it is no longer in Russia but in Ukraine, which is not a party to the present agreement.
And therein lies one of the greatest threats to the efficacy not only of Start II but also its predecessor, Start I, and of arms reduction in general. A considerable proportion of the old Soviet nuclear arsenal is based in Kazakhstan, Belarus and Ukraine, which have made the right sounds but have not so far joined in either Start I or the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. Getting Ukraine aboard, given the reluctance of some key members of its parliament, poses a big challenge for Mr. Clinton.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Cutting Warheads" shows U.S. and Russia's current nuclear warheads and new limits under the treaty agreed to last week (Source: Arms Control Assoc.)

HEADLINE: America Veers Into 1993 Saying It Expects Better

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES

 BODY:
"NOW," said Satan, "you have seen your progress down to the present, and you must confess that it is wonderful -- in its way." Thus at the very beginning of this century did Mark Twain, wary celebrant of humanity, feel obliged to imagine Satan urging mankind to spare a moment for gloating darkly over the negative feats of human history, especially the purer malice of war and famine that, he predicted then, would ever trouble us in new forms, as now in Serbia's war and Somalia's starvation. These calamities last into the new year and serve as reminders that Twain's optimism is still to be preferred for the human planet's cycle across time, but that his secret, caustic fears also remain apt.
A reporter, free to wander America last summer and autumn, had to wonder what grotesque parodies of Huck Finn liberty might Twain find now in the urban American specter of young men with automatic pistols warring nightly on one another. "I'm not talking about urban America in the abstract," said Jack Calhoun, an appalled bystander in the machine-pistol combat on his tree-lined street in Washington. "I'm talking about my daily life, the gunfire, two killings in the last two months." 
 How might Twain illuminate the Detroit ghetto where able-bodied young men hold up cardboard pleas -- Will Work -- on the banks of the surrounding freeway each morning? Kenneth Anderson, a job counselor there in one of the nation's harshest areas of unemployment, said the outside nation had better understand that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s concern for a dream was fast being displaced from the minds of young black people by Malcolm X's warning of a nightmare. "We're on a battlefield here," Mr. Anderson testified quietly.
Even in that spark of fresh thoughtfulness in the land -- the confirmation of Malcolm X as a mythic hero -- there seemed reason to pause doubtfully, perhaps at the nation's tendency to merely market-entertain worthy ideas and indulge commerce over resolution, ostensibly producing still another line of the same consumables, of posters, sneakers and caps. As in Twain's time, America is a place to stagger as much as exult. "You think it would be better if I robbed you?" asked Vincent, a member of the growing national legion of beggars, persistently holding out his cup and answering a question with a question amid the street tumult of New York City.
 
Checkout Counter Egalitarians
 But after a stretch of wandering the nation, there seemed a certain sprightliness in comments like Vincent's, and a traveler had to ask whether the nation might be getting more candid about itself rather than darker, dark as Twain's despair about this land when he raged with his "pen warmed up in hell." For beyond the surface sights -- beyond the egalitarian mass marketing of the pathos of Amy Fisher and Queen Elizabeth side by side at the checkout counter, beyond the TV voyeurism of real cops taking the time in the midst of an actual crime wave to imitate TV cops' smashing into suspects' apartments (they truly do shout "Freeze!" simulating themselves), beyond the garnishing of this year's famine relief with a soupcon of chauvinism left from last year's war, beyond bottomless hyperbole for anyone remotely new (even yesteryear's spin doctors were briefly revivified as campaign mercenaries of Ross Perot), beyond even the grisliest examples of Americana -- there was this comfort: Ordinary people could still be searched out in the land, redemptively it seemed, for their honest comments on the status of being alive in a year where improvement was once more hoped for, and change promised and finally voted for in the national elections.
People wondered and grumbled and hoped, but so much more guardedly than a decade ago that they defied politics' usual black-and-white presumptions about hope itself. "He's suffered everything you can suffer, got pounded plenty with scandal, but he stands right there," said one voter, jobless and grizzled, but delighted with the advent of Bill Clinton because of the candidate's character scrapes, not despite them. Sondheim's cynical lyrics, tailored minimally for Mr. Clinton -- He got through all of last year; he's still here! -- could have served as a campaign theme for this champion survivor at taking over a government of the people that has already borrowed on unmade money clear beyond the millennial bend.
The people seemed to understand why President Bush was checking his watch while debate raged about him. In these dwindling days he is bringing a new sense of hurry to the transition of power, darting in a kind of grand loser's lap around the track, rattling his dried laurels in a bit of Desert Storm reprise and willing his successor ongoing intercessions in two of the main world problems ignored in the campaign debate, Somalia's starvation and Serbia's war.
And to the extent that satire is required, only Twain might have applied the proper American savor to the 11th-hour pardons Mr. Bush extended to a clutch of indicted and convicted Administration colleagues. He pronounced them guilty at most of an excess of patriotism in the woolly, mendacious Iran-contra affair that threatens to haunt the President beyond incumbency. At that, ordinary Americans like Doug Ford, resident of one of the nation's scattered tent cities, still might sympathize. "People out there don't realize how easy it is to go from something to nothing," he muttered in a soliloquy on how rough one human's year can get.
 
Nature's Low Priority
 In the more featured public debate, complicated new ideas were being offered by campaign specialists worrying over the economy, and one of them seemed particularly hard to understand in traveling about America's sinewy vastness and beauty -- that natural resources were no longer so important in the competitive world economy as are human resources, the work force's inscrutable talents and whims, and that new kinds of schooling and job creation were the urgent priority. In counterpoint, ordinary Americans were often to be found echoing a line of worry that was heard furiously a year ago in the freshly fallen Soviet empire, in the enduring land where Russians long ago learned to fret almost exclusively in terms of the next generation: My children must not have it worse than me.
"I can't let them down," Bill Belkner said, studying a photo of his two daughters as he waited in an unemployment line in Manchester, N.H. "I have to pick myself up and come back again," he said flatly as he fought off new levels of being down and out and continued waiting in line, patient as a Muscovite. Such troubled Americans were encountered regularly and were memorable for being among the least cynical about the promises being made hourly by the feverish candidates. "It's kind of hopeful, hearing the debates," Mr. Belkner insisted. "The talk of taking chances and turning things around."
Here was the campaign's undeniable optimism, far enough from the sound-bite trough to remind a witness that the people's choosing a leader is not so much an event for engineering the future as for wishing it well and at least getting ordinary people on record in some fashion against "this long array of crimson spectacles" that Twain had Satan smugly enjoy and anticipate as mankind's history and fate.
In the latest wintry transition of planet and politics, Mr. Belkner's hope for his daughters seems risky but unavoidable, the heightened expectations of the ordinary people needed to stoke nation and earth toward another spring. There were ordinary pessimists, too, who were interesting to witness brushing past the fading era's main questions of hope and politics. "All that doom and gloom just to get themselves elected," growled Tom Liston, a long-haul truck driver, descending from his dieseled perch to hurry on to his breakfast at the Sioux City Truck Haven. He seemed stuck with more work than worry, too busy with life's routine to despair of it. The man was brusque as Twain's Satan, but he was less celebratory about the squalor and doubt that remains in the running with human progress. "We will drink each other's health, and let civilization go," Twain had his Satan declare acidly in a challenge that turns forward with the earth.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
In Tune Now, U.N.'s Quintet Plays Themes Penned in '45

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS

 BODY:
WITH the cold war over, the United States appears to be calling the shots on a Security Council that is finally displaying the awesome powers the United Nations' founders endowed it with in the San Francisco Charter of 1945.
From driving the Iraqis out of Kuwait to providing famine relief to Somalia, American initiatives have been the essential catalyst for the council's renaissance. Now, as fears mount that the Balkan conflict could spread south from Bosnia, the United States is pressing for firmer Security Council measures against the Serbs. 
The council's new assertiveness and America's dominant position on it have worried some countries still used to a world paralyzed by superpower rivalry.
Some complain that Washington has hijacked the council for its own ends. And many now clamor for additional seats for themselves.
Nevertheless, America often seems ambivalent about its dominance. Badly behind in its payments to the organization, the United States has selectively sought the United Nations' blessing for its foreign policy initiatives, preferring to act unilaterally in Panama, for instance, and refusing to disarm the whole of Somalia -- as Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali has urged.
Yet the council's expanding role is hardly surprising now that the interests of its founding powers largely converge behind America's leadership. When the council was created by the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, France and China after World War II, the Big Five intended it to be the instrument through which they together would project their power to preserve peace.
This is why they gave it almost limitless authority to enforce its orders, and put themselves firmly in control, with permanent membership and individual vetoes over decisions. The combination was intended not only to make the Big Five an irresistible collective force as long as their interests coincided; it was also to prevent any of the five from using the council's awesome powers for any purpose that conflicted with the interests of another.
Writing in 1945, R. Keith Kane, an adviser to the American delegation at San Francisco, argued that peace would prevail so long as "the three powers of the first magnitude" -- the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union -- cooperated.
The cold war long prevented such cooperation, of course. But now the council has awakened, authorizing more peacekeeping operations in the last four years than in the previous 40, while expanding its authority.
Once peacekeeping forces merely monitored cease-fires with the agreement of the warring sides. Today they are increasingly used to disarm opposing forces and take over governing as free elections are organized.
The council has also slapped embargoes on a growing list of countries. It has overseen the destruction of Iraq's most dangerous weapons. And it has sent armed forces to safeguard relief deliveries in Bosnia, Somalia and Iraqi Kurdistan.
As the council flexes its muscles, the frontiers of national sovereignty are being rolled back. When it ordered Libya to surrender suspects in the bombings of American and French airliners, it effectively declared that country incapable of giving them a fair trial -- a decision the World Court upheld. And when it authorized sending forces into Somalia, it expanded its own jurisdiction by deciding that a "human tragedy" could threaten international peace. "The centuries- old doctrine of absolute and exclusive sovereignty no longer stands," Secretary General Boutros-Ghali wrote.
The United States has been the chief beneficiary of the council's growing authority because it can get its way in its deliberations and thus win legitimacy for American policies. Once Britain and France are on America's side, a weakened Russia, desperate for aid, joins their ranks while China, even if it has reservations, prefers to abstain rather than cross swords with the other four.
The council's 10 non-permanent members, which serve two-year terms, find it hard to resist the permanent five. In the council's current makeup, for example, Belgium aligns with Britain and France, fellow members of the European Community; two other council members, Austria and Hungary, have applied to join the community and follow the British-French lead.
Seven council seats are normally held by developing nations, and they theoretically can block any decision because passage requires at least 9 of the 15 votes. But the seven are reluctant to jeopardize relations with the more powerful, aid-giving countries; in any case, the developing world has temporarily lost its "sixth veto" because Japan is occupying one of the Asian seats usually filled by a poorer country.
Many countries without permanent seats now argue that they should have them, calling its present composition anachronistic. Germany and Japan, as industrial powers, want a permanent say, as do the larger developing countries like India, Nigeria and Brazil.
Originally, military prowess was considered necessary for permanent council membership, to enable the organization to prevent the rise of another Hitler. Today, threats to peace tend to be more local and often have their roots in poverty -- giving rise to arguments in favor of regional and economic powers.
This year's General Assembly took a first step toward enlarging the Security Council by adopting an Indian resolution asking the Secretary General to prepare a formal report this year on the issue.
One plan would add five new permanent seats without vetoes, giving one each to Germany and Japan and perhaps rotating the other three among the biggest developing countries in Asia, Africa and Latin America.
Fearful of opening a Pandora's box of reform demands, the permanent members have shown little enthusiasm for change. And Germany and Japan, the Second World War's two major losers, have hesitated to press their claims for permanent seats.
Even if the council is enlarged, American influence might not decline. Germany and Japan are likely to ally with the Big Five. That would leave the council's third- world members facing a bigger military-industrial bloc, accounting for most of their aid and trade. Quarreling with it could be even more dangerous than disagreeing with the permanent five.

HEADLINE: BALKAN FACTIONS BEGIN NEW TALKS

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, Jan. 2

 BODY:
Leaders of five factions involved in the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina today began preliminary discussions of a proposal to redraw the republic based on a detailed map that carves it into 10 provinces.
In presenting the just-completed map, Lord Owen of Britain, co-chairman of the talks here, told the leaders of three separate Bosnian delegations representing Serbs, Croats and Muslims, and representatives from Croatia and Serbia, that the proposal was based on an attempt to "arbitrate" the conflicting territorial claims of the three ethnic groups.
 
A Demilitarized Sarajevo
 Under the plan, Bosnia would relinquish most governmental functions to the provinces. Lord Owen said that if the plan was accepted, Sarajevo would be demilitarized and the new provinces would be "areas as geographically coherent as possible, taking into account ethnic, geographical, historical, communication, economic viability and other relevant factors." . 
 The map envisages three provinces in which the Muslims would be predominant, one in which the ethnic Serbs would be predominant, and five in which power would be shared by Muslims and Croats or Serbs. A United Nations spokesman said that none of the provinces would be "ethnically pure," an aspect the Bosnian Government had feared in any plan to redraw the former Yugoslav republic.
The Bosnian Government has said it wants to maintain the territorial integrity of the Bosnian state, but has been willing to support the idea of territorial entities if they are not based on ethnic partitioning.
Although the Serbs technically would have control of only one province, the area where it would share power is broad and includes two enclaves lying within or beside provinces where Muslim majorities prevail.
Under the proposal, Serbian and Croatian forces would be called upon to withdraw to specific provinces and the remainder of the provinces would have to reach local agreement on deployments. In addition, the United Nations ban on military flights over Bosnia would remain in force with the exception of medical evacuation flights.
The framework for a new constitution outlines provincial and central Government legislatures that would be elected democratically, "with most governmental functions carried out by its provinces." The presidency would be organized on the basis of parity among the ethnic groups, and a constitutional court would be created with a member from each ethnic group but with a majority of non-Bosnian judges chosen by the conference co-chairmen.
 
 
Artillery Duels Reported
 As 25 official delegates took their seats around a rectangular table at 11 A.M. today, there were reports of scattered artillery duels between Bosnian Muslim and Bosnian Serb forces from various regions of the republic.
Cyrus R. Vance, a former Secretary of State and the other co-chairman of the conference, told the delegates: "The process we are starting today can make the difference between peace and war, between life and death for thousands of people. Those gathered around this table have it in their power to prevent it from sliding into escalation or expansion of the conflict."
 The meeting was closed, but a United Nations official who attended said all sides "spoke quite moderately." None of their statements were released to the press.
Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb whose forces hold two-thirds of the mountainous republic's territory, warned that his side would not willingly give up what he called "Serb lands" in Bosnia, the United Nations official said. Mr. Karadzic did declare that he wanted a peace settlement and would "stay as long as necessary" to achieve that, the United Nations official said.
Mr. Karadzic also said he would close camps where some 1,333 Muslim and Croat prisoners are held, according to the official. In discussions with Mr. Vance and Lord Owen before the conference he made some territorial concessions.
 
Muslim Delegation 'Very Glum'
 President Alija Izetbegovic of Bosnia declared that all sides must accept the peace plan. He acknowledged holding 847 Serb prisoners and said he agreed to opening his detention camps to International Red Cross inspection.
The United Nations official said the Bosnian delegation was "very glum." He noted that on Friday night Mr. Izetbegovic had declared to his delegation, "We are under duress -- war is the only solution."
The leader of the Bosnian Croats, Mate Boban, whose forces have seized a large chunk of Bosnia, agreed with the principles behind the plan, a United Nations official said.
Lord Owen said that "Sarajevo should be demilitarized at the earliest possible date" and re-created as "an open city" with three access routes across lines of military confrontation. "These routes would effectively lift the siege of Sarajevo," he said.
He said the plan included a proposal for five "throughways" in the republic in which there would be "full freedom of movement" to be guaranteed by international forces. These forces would also control crossings between provinces to insure that military units did not transgress.
 
Observers at Border
 Under the plan, United Nations observers would be posted at border points, Lord Owen said, but the sanctity of the borders in terms of arms smuggling would also have to be guaranteed by the authorities of neighboring Croatia, Serbia and Montenegro.
Dobrica Cosic, the President of the Yugoslav Republic, consisting of Serbia and Montenegro, attended the talks, as did President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia.
 Mr. Cosic, said it was "high time the siege of Sarajevo should be ended." The siege is now in its ninth month. Mr. Cosic, whose republic is indirectly involved in the Bosnian fighting, also said that a settlement "could be the seed for a different future for the Balkans."
Mr. Tudjman thanked the United Nations for its efforts to bring peace to Bosnia, noting that Mr. Vance had succeeded in ending the war between Croatia and Serbia just one year ago.
The urgency of the talks was underscored here on Friday by Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali of the United Nations, who said this was "the last chance for peace" in the Balkans.
Mr. Boutros-Ghali and his deputies have discussed the mounting pressure for international military intervention from some Western leaders including President Bush, President Francois Mitterrand of France and Prime Minister John Major of Britain.
His deputies conducting the International Conference on Former Yugoslavia here have warned all week of a buildup of 10,000 mostly Muslim troops on Mount Igman, southwest of Sarajevo. They said the troops might try to break the nine-month siege of the capital by Bosnian Serb forces.
 
Working Groups Formed
 After the delegates heard the presentation by the co-chairmen and the comments of the delegation leaders, two working groups were formed to discuss the proposals, the first on lifting the siege of Sarajevo and disengaging military forces throughout the republic and the second on the drafting of the new constitution.
Characterizing the first day of talks, Fred Eckhard, the spokesman for the co-chairmen, said that leaders of all five delegations had demonstrated "a serious willingness to negotiate."
More working group meetings are scheduled on Sunday and the next full session is set for Monday.

HEADLINE: Trade Pact Threatens Puerto Rico's Economic Rise

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN JUAN, P.R.

 BODY:
Since becoming a self-governing commonwealth 40 years ago, Puerto Rico has built the most prosperous economy in the Caribbean, creating thousands of manufacturing jobs by offering companies a lower-paid work force and tax incentives not available on the American mainland.
But with the signing in December of the North American Free Trade Agreement, that economic strategy and the gains it has brought the island's 3.6 million people face daunting new challenges. If approved by Congress, the trade agreement will integrate the United States, Mexico and Canada into a single market and, officials here fear, encourage American companies here to take advantage of even lower wages in Mexico. 
 "What happens with Nafta and the other treaties that will surely follow is that the advantage Puerto Rico enjoys as a territory of the United States is no longer an exclusive advantage," said Pedro J. Rossello, the 48-year-old doctor who is Puerto Rico's new Governor. "Some of our advantages, such as lower wages, will simply disappear, and others will face constant threats."
 
Relying on Tax Benefits
 As an immediate consequence of the impending trade pact, Puerto Rico will become more reliant than ever on the benefits of Section 936 of the Internal Revenue Code, which exempts American corporations from paying taxes on the profits they earn here. The more than 600 such companies account for tens of thousands of jobs and generate an estimated $11 billion a year in earnings, which are allowed to be shifted to the mainland after paying a modest "tollgate tax."
But even that tax advantage is threatened. The incoming Clinton Administration has promised to reduce the Federal budget deficit and is also under pressure to halt the flight of jobs from the American mainland. Both Congress and the Treasury Department have shown interest in proposals to abolish or reduce Section 936 exemptions, a move that could raise as much as $2.6 billion a year in tax revenues.
Losing the tax benefits at the same time that the trade agreement is being carried out would be a "double whammy" that could lead to a "total collapse" of the economy, Rafael Hernandez Colon, Puerto Rico's previous Governor, said in an interview at the Governor's Mansion in December. "If there is no 936, there is nothing more to talk about," he said.
The tax benefits would also have to be eliminated, though, if Puerto Rico became a state, as advocated by Dr. Rossello's New Progressive Party, which resoundingly won November's elections. Dr. Rossello has promised to hold a plebiscite on Puerto Rico's political status sometime in 1993, a pledge that has compounded the uncertainty prevailing among policy makers and business executives here.
"What is at stake right now is the economic future of Puerto Rico," said Hector Jimenez Juarbe, executive director of the Puerto Rico Manufacturers' Association. "This is a defining moment for us in many respects, from the status of our relationship with the United States to what kind of social, education and investment policies we want to promote."
 
Worry Is Mexico
 For most decision makers in government and business here, the principal concern is how to compete with Mexico if, as expected, the trade agreement goes into effect. Not only is Mexico closer to California, Texas and other major American markets than Puerto Rico, which is 1,000 miles from the mainland and must ship its products by sea or air, but it has a much larger labor pool that is willing to work for considerably less than Puerto Rico's.
For a generation, Puerto Rico's relatively low wages have attracted employers. About 40 percent of the island's economic production now comes from industries like clothing, rum, food processing, or chemicals, and hundreds of thousands of families have been provided secure, well-paying jobs that enable them to own homes and cars and do their shopping amid an abundance of malls.
But "Puerto Rico can no longer compete on the basis of cheap wages," Dr. Rossello acknowledged in an interview at party headquarters in December. "Even though salaries here are half those on the American mainland, on average they are four times Mexican wages. In any industry that depends on cheap labor, we are going to be at a disadvantage."
Augusto Amato, an economic consultant and former head of the economic planning department at Banco Popular, the leading bank here, estimates that the average hourly wage in Puerto Rico is at about $6.50, with "peaks of up to $13 an hour in some industries." By his calculations, Mexican workers doing the same type of jobs earn an average of only $1.40 an hour.
 
Opposition to Pact
 Among the industries regarded as the most vulnerable are several that have been pillars of Puerto Rico's economic growth for decades. Government and private analysts predict the rum industry will continue to flourish, and may even benefit from access to the Mexican market, but worry that some jobs will be lost in textiles and apparel, tuna, leather and agriculture.
In December, the National Puerto Rican Coalition, which represents some 100 Puerto Rican community and advocacy groups here and on the mainland, became the first major Hispanic organization to publicly oppose the trade agreement. The president of the coalition, Lou Nunez, said that the agreement would "make a bad economic situation even worse, because Puerto Ricans rely on the very jobs that would be eliminated" both here and in urban areas in Northeast states.
"We're going to have to take a few hits, there's no question about it," said Mr. Hernandez Colon. Unemployment here ran well over 20 percent in the mid 1980's, but dropped to 16 percent by December. About 17.5 percent of the work force is employed in manufacturing, as against 28 percent in government and about 25 percent in services, which includes tourism.
 
Less Regulation Overseas
 Beyond the issue of wages, there are also concerns that some of the hundreds of companies operating here may find the Mexico's less-regulated economic environment an irresistible lure to relocate. "Don't forget about the F.D.A., E.P.A., OSHA and their rules," Mr. Jimenez said, referring to several Federal regulatory agencies. "All those things are in place here, but not in Mexico."
But many political and business leaders believe that in the long run the trade agreement will prove to be a boon to the economy of Puerto Rico, generating new jobs and raising living standards beyond the current per capita income of $6,000 a year. Their optimism is based on faith in a well-trained, stable and largely bilingual work force that could help Puerto Rico emerge as a regional base for American and foreign companies, particularly those making high-tech products, that want to export to Latin American countries.
"We have the American flag here, which is very important," said Manuel Casiano, publisher of "Caribbean Business" magazine and a former head of the Economic Development Administration, a Government agency. "It means we have the U.S. dollar, customs and immigration, and if you run into a problem, there are U.S. Federal courts here. That's a lot of stability."
In the past, economic policymakers might also have been able to reduce some of the impact of the trade agreement by emphasizing the benefits that the Section 936 tax benefits offered to potential investors. Given the political climate in Washington and Dr. Rossello's drive for statehood, however, "there is no way to predict what is going to happen with 936," said Arthur Mann, a professor of economics at the University of Puerto Rico. "It's a factor of instability as far as business is concerned, and business doesn't like instability of any sort."
Additional concerns have arisen from judicial challenges to the tax benefits, most notably a case in which the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers Union sued American Home Products, makers of Dristan, Advil, Anacin and other over-the-counter remedies, and Puerto Rican officials. The suit asserted that to gain tax benefits, the company and the officials conspired to claim falsely that the relocation of a factory from Indiana to Puerto Rico would not eliminate jobs on the mainland.
Two years after the Puerto Rico plant opened in Oct. 1988, the Indiana factory was closed, and 775 people, mostly union members, were laid off. This fall, the suit was settled out of court after American Home Products agreed to pay $24 million to workers. But the union continues to participate in A.F.L.-C.I.O. efforts to amend Section 936, arguing that tax incentives in Puerto Rico harm mainland jobs.
 
Issue of Parking Profits
 The case has had considerable impact here, not only on economic grounds but also as an unpleasant reminder of the island's second-class political status. Many Puerto Ricans who followed the case were wounded by remarks that appeared to classify the relocation not as a transfer from one American jurisdiction to another, but as another example of a third world country trying to steal American jobs.
"This is part of the United States, and we are American citizens too," Mr. Jimenez said. "If these plants don't come here, they are not going to remain on the mainland. They are going to take those jobs to other countries."
At the Federal level, in both Congress and the Treasury Department, there is also some irritation that companies may be parking profits in Puerto Rico to avoid taxes on the mainland. Speaking on condition he not be identified, an economist who regularly deals with government officials and businesses, acknowledged the problem, saying that "home offices do sell goods to their subsidiaries in Puerto Rico for low, low prices and then buy back the finished product at a high price, which allows them to show little or no profit on the mainland, and a large, nontaxable profit here."
Dr. Rossello has promised that, though he favors statehood, he will fight to maintain the tax benefits as long as Puerto Rico remains a commonwealth. But he made it clear that he is also thinking of long-range alternatives that will allow the island to wean itself from its dependence on the tax benefits.
"We have to rethink our economic model," he said. "Puerto Rico has obviously built an economy based on tax incentives, but we have to get away from the one dimensional posture of '936 or nothing,' because that is going to result in our getting nothing.
"You have to ask, what is the purpose of 936? Is it to create big profits, or is it to stimulate job creation?"
Dr. Rossello's Administration is expected to press for some sort of Federal mechanism that could substitute for the tax benefits if they are eliminated or reduced. "I don't think it is fair for Congress to suddenly eliminate all or part of 936 and not give us anything in return," said Marcos Rodriguez-Ema, the new head of the Government Development Bank.

HEADLINE: GROWING U.S. DEBT IS LIMITING OPTIONS OPEN FOR CLINTON

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2

 BODY:
America's vast and growing Federal debt is sharply narrowing the options available to President-elect Bill Clinton as he prepares to reshape the budget that President Bush will submit to Congress next week.
That process, which will take place in the coming weeks, will mark a turning point for the new President. The act of subjecting his campaign promises to the discipline of budget-making will give the country a first look at his real fiscal intentions, just as Ronald Reagan's first budget message of Feb. 18, 1981, provided a blueprint for the entire Reagan revolution. 
 Already some things are clear. Mr. Clinton's promises to create jobs and bolster investment to reinvigorate the economy will be tempered by the Federal debt, which is growing faster than the economy. And the costs of servicing the debt are consuming a larger portion of the Government's resources.
 
Doubts About the Deficit
 Since Mr. Reagan took office, the debt has quadrupled, to more than $3 trillion today from $735 billion in January 1981. Last year, for the first time since the late 1950's, the debt was more than half the size of the entire economy. The cost of interest, $199 billion in the last fiscal year, now exceeds the total of all Federal spending for education, science, law enforcement, transportation, housing, food stamps and welfare.
In comments that reflect troubling prospects for the President-elect, Clinton aides, members of Congress from both parties and private economists expressed general agreement on the following points:
*Mr. Clinton probably cannot "cut the deficit in half within four years," as he promised in his campaign manifesto. This task has become more difficult since the manifesto was issued in June, because assumptions about economic growth are less optimistic now. Health costs are also rising faster than expected, and Congress postponed costs associated with the savings and loan bail out.
*To impose fiscal austerity on a weak economy would abort the current recovery and lead to larger budget deficits in the long run. Congressional Democrats will support measures to reduce the deficit over five years, but see an urgent need for the Government to help create jobs and stimulate the economy in 1993.
*The Federal debt will reach the current legal limit in March or the first half of April. Congress must raise the ceiling on Government borrowing, or the Government cannot operate. Some members of Congress will try to use the debt-limit legislation as a vehicle for far-reaching changes in the Congressional budget process. Such efforts may disrupt Mr. Clinton's timetable and agenda with a bruising partisan debate over budget policy.
*Congress will probably be more willing than Mr. Clinton to cut military spending and foreign aid, but less willing to cut domestic programs.
The sluggish economy has contributed to the growth in the Federal debt. New calculations by the Congressional Budget Office show that the debt is now 51.1 percent of the gross domestic product, up from 47.8 percent in 1991 and 26.5 percent in 1981, when Mr. Reagan became President. The debt has not been so large, in relation to economic output, since the late 1950's, when it reflected much of the bill left over from World War II.
 
'Feeding on Itself'
 Statistics compiled by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development show that the ratio of public debt to economic output is higher in the United States than in Germany, France or Britain. For every dollar it spends, the United States Government takes in 79 cents.
Rudolph G. Penner, director of economic studies at KPMG Peat Marwick, the accounting concern, said the rising Federal debt was "the single most important indicator of our fiscal irresponsibility."
"As long as it's rising, the problem is feeding on itself," said Mr. Penner, who was director of the Congressional Budget Office from 1983 to 1987. "The interest bill is rising faster than our incomes or tax revenues. Interest is absorbing more and more of our resources."
As a result, economists say, there is less money available for the type of productive investment that Mr. Clinton wants to encourage. When the Government borrows, it diverts money from private savings that could otherwise be used for investment in housing, factories, new technology, education and job training.
The conventional wisdom of mainstream economists is that increased Government borrowing also tends to increase interest rates, especially long-term rates.
Mr. Reagan liked to quote Thomas Jefferson's description of public debt as "the greatest of the dangers to be feared" from Government. In 1982, Mr. Reagan cited the Federal debt, then $1 trillion, as a symptom of "the chaos, confusion and all-purpose mess left us by the failed policies of the past." Mr. Clinton made a similar argument against the Reagan and Bush Administrations in last year's Presidential campaign.
Mr. Bush's final budget will be an abbreviated version of the budget usually sent to Congress by a President. Instead of proposing tax increases or cuts, new programs and altered priorities, it will simply show the course of Federal spending over the next five years if current policies remain unchanged.
But in electing Mr. Clinton, voters said they wanted to change those policies. "What Bush sends up is generally irrelevant at this point," said Senator Jim Sasser, the Tennessee Democrat who is chairman of the Budget Committee.
So it will be up to Mr. Clinton to propose the program cuts or tax increases needed to supply the revenue he will need to finance new jobs and investment. With a Democratic Congress, he will have some help, though nobody says it will be easy.
Twelve years of partisan warfare between Congress and the White House over the Federal budget will presumably end this year. The new budget director, Leon E. Panetta, and his deputy, Alice M. Rivlin, are respected by Democrats and Republicans alike. They start with more good will than Mr. Bush's budget director, Richard G. Darman, or Mr. Reagan's first budget director, David A. Stockman, ever had.
Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, said: "With Leon and Alice, there should be much less gimmickry and fancy budgetary footwork. The budget should be much more easily understood."
Mr. Sasser went further. "For the first time in 12 years," he said, "you will see some Congressional input into the budget that evolves in the executive branch. Rather than presenting us with a fait accompli, I anticipate that the new Administration will be consulting Congress to ascertain what is doable and what is just not possible. We'll spend less time running down rabbit tracks that produce nothing but frustration and exhaustion, and more time examining viable options for reducing the deficit."
Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, the ranking Republican on the new House Budget Committee, said he was willing to cooperate with Mr. Clinton, but saw no need for tax increases, which are favored by many Democrats. Also, he said, he is suspicious of the way Mr. Clinton uses the term investment to justify certain types of Government spending.
"The idea of investment sounds calming and reassuring," Mr. Kasich said. "Many Democrats have latched onto it. But what does it really mean? Spending more Federal dollars on more Federal programs.

HEADLINE: Choice for National Security Adviser Has a Long-Awaited Chance to Lead

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2

 BODY:
As a youth working during the summer on a Connecticut farm, W. Anthony Lake would walk behind tractors and toss bales of hay into a wagon. "One day," he often promised himself, "I'm going to drive the tractor."
For several years, as a gentleman farmer raising 28 head of cattle on his 140-acre farm in Worthington, Mass., Mr. Lake has fulfilled his wish. Now, as President-elect Bill Clinton's choice to become national security adviser, he is about to climb into the driver's seat in his other field of endeavor: foreign policy. 
 After two stints as a chief lieutenant to others who formulated the nation's international policy, Mr. Lake is about the grasp the levers of power himself -- and hoping his new tour produces a happier ending than the last two.
 
Served Nixon and Carter
 The first time around his conscience drove him away from the prestige and power that came with being a trusted assistant to Henry A. Kissinger, then President Richard M. Nixon's national security adviser. The second time it was the voters who sent Mr. Lake packing when they turned out President Jimmy Carter -- a defeat that was, in part, a rejection of policies that Mr. Lake, as director of policy planning in the State Department, had helped devise.
"When the Carter Administration ended I thought he had been permanently tainted for mistakes that were not his fault," said Jenonne Walker, who worked with Mr. Lake in the State Department. "I'm really glad to have been proved wrong."
For Mr. Lake -- and thus for Mr. Clinton -- to avoid the fate of the last Democratic Administration, they will have to chart a new foreign policy and navigate a new bureaucratic landscape without the benefit of a map. The collapse of the Soviet Union, the rise of ethnic conflicts and the use of military intervention for humanitarian aims, as in Somalia, present nettlesome new challenges that will require innovative solutions sustained by popular support at home.
 
Career in Foreign Service
 Mr. Lake brings with him a set of experiences and a personality that set him apart from the men who have occupied the position in the past. Unlike Brent Scowcroft, General Colin L. Powell, Robert C. MacFarlane and John M. Poindexter, Mr. Lake is not a career military officer. Unlike Mr. Kissinger and Zbigniew Brzezinski, he is not viewed as a self-promoter.
A career foreign-service officer, Mr. Lake has argued in books and articles that the views of professional diplomats have not been given enough consideration in recent years.
He supported the idea of self-determination for developing countries, but also viewed "national liberation movements" with a jaundiced eye. During the 1992 campaign he was among the Clinton foreign-policy advisers who advocated a hawkish stance on Bosnia.
"If you look at the people who have been around Clinton, for the most part, they have had long-term relationships with him," said Richard Feinberg, who served with Mr. Lake in the State Department. "But here's a guy who Clinton hardly knows at all, and he makes him national security adviser. How how do you explain that?
"I think the answer is that Tony is really an extraordinarily intelligent guy who at the same time is self-effacing, not at all self-promoting and also very loyal to the people he works with."
But Mr. Lake also carries the legacy of the Carter foreign policy, including its successes and its shortcomings, especially its handling of the Iran hostage crisis.
He was intimately involved in the formulation of Mr. Carter's policy toward Rhodesia, where pressure by the United States and Britain finally forced the white-minority government of Ian Smith to cede power in a peaceful transition to majority rule.
On the other hand, Mr. Lake was part of the brain trust of Cyrus Vance, the Secretary of State who advocated a more accommodating stance toward the Soviet Union. That view took a beating from conservatives, and after the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan, Mr. Carter himself adopted a tougher policy.
The basic tenets of Mr. Lake's view of foreign policy are that with the end of the cold war, the terms "hawks" and "doves" are outmoded, and that with the defeat in the primaries of isolationist candidates like Patrick J. Buchanan, interventionism has won out.
The new foreign-policy debate, Mr. Lake has argued, is between those who, like President Bush, see the world through a classic balance-of-power prism and those who, like Mr. Clinton and himself, take a more "neo-Wilsonian" view in which the United States uses its military and economic power to intervene in promoting democracy.
Mr. Lake entered the foreign service in 1962 after completing post-graduate work at Cambridge. A believer in President John F. Kennedy's anti-communist policy in Southeast Asia, he volunteered to work in Vietnam.
In a revealing 1975 magazine article he wrote with his wife, Antonia, Mr. Lake recalled his initial heady attraction to operating around powerful men who were making important decisions -- for a time, he was a special assistant to Henry Cabot Lodge, then the ambassador to South Vietnam -- and around military men of action. In one passage he described his feelings when driving with soldiers in a jeep and being handed a carbine in case of ambush:
"With the gun came the hope that someone would fire at us from the clumps of trees lining the road, so I could fire back. Usually doubtful that I could shoot another person, at that moment I was emotionally prepared to do so."
But gradually Mr. Lake became skeptical that the Vietnam War could be won and more and more insecure about what prolonging the war was doing to the Vietnamese people. In the same article he wrote of encountering the bodies of North Vienamese soldiers who had been ripped apart by .50-caliber machine-gun fire. Focusing on the corpse of one young soldier, Mr. Lake wrote: "His thin, scholarly face seemed terribly out of place in the bloody mud of that ditch. He seemed about my age."
The article stood out from the bloodless descriptions typical of former foreign-service officers, especially since the Lakes wrote about how the war and Mr. Lake's "loyalty to the Department of State in the face of inhuman working hours and inhuman policies" had strained their marriage.
 
Top Kissinger Aide
 During the early years of the Nixon Administration, Mr. Lake was a special assistant to Mr. Kissinger, who he believed would end the war quickly. Considered a favorite of Mr. Kissinger, Mr. Lake was one of the aides who accompanied him to secret peace talks in Paris with North Vietnamese leaders.
But in 1970, Mr. Lake, along with two other security council staff members resigned in protest over the invasion of Cambodia. They went to work for Senator Edmund S. Muskie, a likely Democratic challenger to President Nixon in the 1972 election. Two weeks after he resigned, Mr. Kissinger authorized the tapping of Mr. Lake's home telephone.
Mr. Lake later sued Mr. Kissinger over the wiretapping. The suit was settled in 1989 with Mr. Kissinger writing a letter that was not quite an apology, but in which he admitted that the wiretap had been "unconstitutional."

HEADLINE: Bartender Training Rejected By Vermont's Liquor Board

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 1

 BODY:
A proposal that would have strengthened Vermont's training program for bartenders and others who may be held liable for drunken driving accidents has been rejected by the State Liquor Control Board on procedural grounds.
The board rejected the proposal on Nov. 10 on the advice of its counsel and the State Attorney General, said Norris Hoyt, the Commissioner of Liquor Control. Since Vermont already has a mandatory training program enacted by the Legislature in 1987, only the Legislature can amend it, Mr. Hoyt said. 
 The board's decision came as a blow to the parents of a college student who was killed by a drunken driver in 1985. The couple, Adam and Ann Clymer, had petitioned the liquor board to tighten the training regulations after their daughter's death.
The Clymers won a $250,000 settlement last May from the owners of two Burlington restaurants where the driver had been drinking before hitting their daughter, Jane emily, as she was walking her bicycle. The driver, Theron Webster, served 30 months in jail.
 
More Instruction Sought
 The Clymers had petitioned the liquor board to extend an agreement made with the two restaurants to all establishments licensed to serve or sell alcohol in the state. Among other things, the agreement would have strengthened Vermont's mandatory server-training program by requiring a minimum of six hours of formal instruction in how to spot potentially drunk customers and gracefully refuse them more drinks. The training was to be paid for by business owners.
Mr. Clymer, the chief Congressional correspondent for The New York Times, said he was disappointed by the decision because the three-member board appeared open to the proposals at a public hearing last summer.
"We hope Vermont generally doesn't give up on this cause," he said Monday.
One legislator has expressed interest in bringing the proposal to the floor of the State Senate next year.
Supporters of the changes criticized the state's existing program, noting that bar owners are simply required to give employees literature on the subject supplied by the State Department of Liquor Control. They also say bar owners may not be the best teachers because they have an economic stake in selling alcohol.
"As long as you have the owners doing the training, you're not going to get a very good program," said James F. Mosher, executive director of the Marin Institute, a organization in California that conducts research on alcohol and drugs.
