HEADLINE: Concessions on Arms Pact Made by U.S.

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 2

 BODY:
As President Bush arrived today in Moscow to sign a sweeping nuclear arms treaty with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, senior Administration officials said the United States, with Mr. Yeltsin's weakened domestic position in mind, had made significant concessions.
The officials said the Administration had tried to meet Russian concerns about the military and economic impact of the accord because Mr. Yeltsin may face a difficult fight to get the agreement ratified by the conservative Russian legislature, which recently forced him to abandon his choice for Prime Minister. 
 The officials said they were conscious of Mr. Yeltsin's need to defend the treaty as balanced. "One-sided treaties don't survive," one official said. Another said, "Unequal treaties don't get ratified."
 
'New Partnership'
 As the days of his Presidency dwindled down, Mr. Bush turned today from a moving celebration of the new year with United States troops helping to feed Somalis to the signing of what he called tonight "the most significant arms-control treaty ever."
In an exchange of toasts at a Kremlin state banquet in the 15th-century Hall of Facets, named for the angles of its white stone facings, Mr. Bush praised Mr. Yeltsin for his courage and dedication "to a new United States-Russian partnership," adding that President-elect Bill Clinton would be "a 100 percent partner."
Mr. Yeltsin said he looked forward to the day when "Russia's might as a great power is determined not by the quantity of its missiles, but by the living standards of its citizens and the development of culture, education and national traditions."
He then toasted the President and Barbara Bush with vodka and thanked them and all Americans for their support "in this extremely difficult period." Mr. Bush took a sip of his vodka, then chugged it down in the approved Russian style.
 
Terms of the Treaty
 The treaty, by banning all heavy, land-based, multiple-warhead nuclear missiles, is intended to eliminate both sides' confidence of achieving a successful first strike on the other. This should lessen the risk of sudden nuclear war.
The Americans are generally considered to have gained something of an advantage, since they retain a large number of their accurate, submarine-based, multiple-warhead missiles, the backbone of the American force, while the Russians must give up their prized land-based SS-18's.
That imbalance is the essence of complaints from the more conservative Russians, which make ratification by the Russian legislature something less than a given. Greeting Mr. Bush today at Moscow airport was a small group of protesters from the right-wing Nationalist Party with placards supporting Iraq and damning the arms treaty. One placard read: "Start II is Bush's final knot in the noose." The acronym Start has been used for each of the two Strategic Arms Reduction Treaties.
But in background briefings today, senior Administration officials involved in the negotiations said the United States had made significant concessions to help Mr. Yeltsin defend the treaty against criticism that it undermines Russia's national interests.
One official, speaking off the record, said Washington was not sure when Mr. Yeltsin planned to seek ratification. A constitutional referendum scheduled April 11, if it takes place, will alter Russia's system of government and may set up a new unicameral parliament. That is Mr. Yeltsin's next big political hurdle, and the official suggested that Mr. Yeltsin still had to decide whether he wanted to try to get the treaty ratified beforehand.
"We had all these feelings in mind when we sat down to negotiate," the official said. "I don't see it as a one-sided deal."
To answer Russian concerns about cost, Washington agreed in the closing negotiations to allow the Russians to convert 90 of the 308 SS-18 silos to house single-warhead missiles based on the currently mobile SS-25. These silos will be filled with 5 meters of concrete and fitted with a steel collar so that SS-18's, which are to be destroyed, could not be reinserted. The other SS-18 silos would be destroyed.
 
Down to One Warhead
 The United States also agreed that specific numbers of smaller, multiple-warhead, land-based missiles could be stripped to a single warhead if they were kept in their original silos.
While this also allows the United States to strip the older Minuteman III missiles and make the planned Midgetman a single-warhead missile, the Midgetman is unlikely ever to be built. Russia will be able to save many of its newest, smaller missiles and will not have to develop a new design and a new silo to put it in.
Asked if Moscow could quickly re-equip these missiles if a more aggressive Government took power, United States officials said that on-site inspections and spy satellites would be able to detect such changes, and that the United States "can redress any imbalance that might exist."
The United States intends the treaty to make it very difficult for any Russian Government to restore its first-strike potential quickly or in secrecy, which is why Washington insisted on destruction of SS-18 rockets and canisters. This was a major change from the first Start treaty, which did not call for the destruction of the missiles.
 
A Peek at the Bombers
 In the new treaty, Washington also agreed to answer long-standing Russian concerns about the United States bomber force.
In earlier treaties, nuclear weapons on bombers counted less than warheads on the more dangerous land-based missiles. Now, all warheads are treated as equal and each side will count actual nuclear weaponry installed on each bomber, and allow verification.
One senior official said that the B-52G carries 12 nuclear warheads, the B-52H carries 20, the B-1 carries 16 and the B-2 Stealth bomber carries 16.
In a concession stressed by United States officials, the Russians will have a single chance to inspect the new B-2 to count its nuclear weapons, though key parts of the plane will be shrouded. The Americans had always resisted any inspection of the Stealth.
 
The Other Republics
 The United States officials were sharp in their comments about Ukraine, which has delayed ratifying the Start I and nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaties; the treaties would make Ukraine a non-nuclear state within seven years. President Leonid Kravchuk has promised that Ukraine will ratify both, but the parliament is balking, asking for further United States aid and security guarantees.
The second Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty cannot come into effect until Ukraine ratifies the first, which it undertook to do last May, along with the other states that inherited Soviet weapons, Kazakhstan and Belarus. Belarus has not yet ratified the first pact, but it is expected to.
Ukraine needs "to get on with it," a senior United States official said. "The world at large, and not just the United States, looks to these countries to take these steps they've committed to."
On Sunday morning, when Mr. Bush and Mr. Yeltsin are to meet for talks before signing the treaty and holding a joint news conference, some discussion is also expected about the former Yugoslavia. The Russians have close ties to their fellow Slavs, the Serbs, and Mr. Yeltsin has also been criticized by Russian nationalists for betraying their "brethren."

HEADLINE: Town Builds a Prison and Stores Its Hopes There

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: APPLETON, Minn., Dec. 31

 BODY:
If the drug dealers and sex offenders ever arrive, many in this quiet farm town plan to celebrate.
"We've been waiting a long time for something good to happen around here," said Dianne Johnson, president of the local Chamber of Commerce and the editor of the weekly newspaper. 
 Two years ago Appleton, a job-hungry town of 1,552 residents on the snow-swept prairies of western Minnesota, broke ground for a municipally owned prison and what most here prayed was the beginning of an economic turnaround.
The town issued $28.5 million in bonds to build its "state of the art," medium-security prison in a soybean field. Then it went looking for overcrowded state prison systems willing to rent Appleton's cells and thereby create new jobs and business for local residents and merchants.
 
Vacancy Sign Is Out
 "The world has written us off," Mrs. Johnson said. "It's up to us and us alone. Nobody is going to help bail us out."
It seemed like a sure thing, with state-run prisons across the country bursting and Federal courts ordering them to do something to ease overcrowding. The phrase "If you build it, they will come," danced through Appleton like a summer breeze. It still does, even as the digital clock on the Farmers and Merchants State Bank says it is 4 degrees below zero.
But for-profit prisons have a checkered record in their 10-year history, a record marked with both hope and despair, as Appleton is learning. One prisons expert called them a fad, "like the hula hoop."
And so it is that months after the Appleton prison was scheduled to lock up its first convict, its cells remain empty.
 
Inmates or Bust
 Private and for-profit prisons are generally less costly to run than public prisons because they have nonunion staff. But rocked by recession, no state or county government, including Minnesota, has yet agreed to spend the money to send inmates to Appleton's prison, the Prairie Correctional Facility.
Minnesota officials say that the state's prisons are overcrowded but that the state is converting hospital space into prison use and has no need for the Appleton site. Some people here grumble that the state is waiting for Appleton to fail so it can take over its prison.
The 472-bed prison here, which already has staff in place, needs at least 200 inmates to open, and officials are extremely anxious for it to do so. Otherwise, the Appleton Prison Corporation, created by the town to run the project, faces the prospect of laying off the prison staff of 85 on Jan. 31 and wounding the faith and confidence built up since the project began.
Bondholders were recently notified that a principal payment of $85,000 due in February would not be paid and that an interest payment of $1.4 million might also be missed. The prison's largest bondholder, I.D.S. Financial Services Inc. of Minneapolis, has asked the corporation to research selling or leasing it to the State of Minnesota.
 
Town on Tenterhooks
 Town officials say a contract for inmates will be signed any day now, and they even talk of expanding the prison to 1,000 beds. But prison employees cannot go anywhere here without being peppered with questions about when the inmates are going to arrive.
When the prison received its state operating license last November, people bought the employees drinks and slapped their backs. Now a few voices are saying, "I told you so."
"The anticipation is driving everyone crazy," said a prison official, David C. Harris. "But once the inmates get here, we'll have to beat people off with sticks because they'll all be out here wanting to see them."
The prison is a gamble but one that many here said had to be taken. Appleton is fading fast. There are few new families and even fewer jobs. The town high school is closed, and much of downtown is abandoned. Even one of the town's two funeral parlors has died.
In these parts, the farmers grow mostly corn, soybeans and sugar beets. But people say the area's largest export is its young. Those left are desperate to stop the losses.
So Appleton embraced the new prison. Except for its 10 miles of razor wire twisting and looping around its 70 acres, the prison looks like a community college, with buildings the color of dirty snow. When it is operating fully, it should employ at least 160 people. And once that happens, people here figure, money will start flowing through town like a parade on the Fourth of July.
Some of that has already come true. The town finally renovated its tiny airport. A new Super 8 motel came to Appleton in 1991 because of the prison, and people for the first time in years are fixing up their houses again.
When Doug Moe, the town's new police chief, arrived in May 1991, construction on the prison had recently begun and the "town was just so full of energy."
But the delay in getting inmates is eroding the confidence. "You've kind of seen that go down and down," he said.
 
Quest for Survival
 The man behind the Appleton prison is the city coordinator, Robert Thompson, who has lost weight and many nights of sleep worrying about the lack of convicted felons in his town. Mr. Thompson's New Year's resolution is to quit smoking as soon as an inmate contract is signed.
Puffing on a cigarette the other day, Mr. Thompson said Appleton had long searched for other development projects. Like other small towns, it chased smokestack industries, offering them free lights, tax breaks, cheap labor. But a factory would come only to pick up and leave a couple of years later to another town that had even more tax breaks to dangle.
After trying to lure up to 100 different businesses to town in the last few years, Mr. Thompson started reading about privately managed prisons starting up across the country, primarily in Southern and Western states.
He took his idea for a for-profit prison to the Chamber of Commerce and to the City Council, which gave the go-ahead. Revenue bonds were issued to 900 investors. Once the bonds are paid off, in 30 years or less if all goes well, Appleton will have complete control of the prison and its profits.
"That's not a dream," Mr. Thompson said. "That's just being visionary."
 
Quelling the Doubts
 A seven-member board appointed by the City Council oversees the prison, and a private prison company from Kansas City acts as consultant and searches the country for inmates.
Early on, there was some concern among Appleton residents about prison escapes, or about inmates' choosing to stay in Appleton upon their release. But those fears were eased when prison officials said that inmates would be transferred back to the state of origin three to six months before release.
Moreover, the prison has the latest in security: motion detectors, guard towers within the cell blocks, listening devices in every cell and videocameras all over. The only part of Appleton most inmates will see is the cemetery and the Swift County Fairgrounds across the road.
There are also some lingering doubts about the rightness, both morally and fiscally, of relying on a prison for economic development. Dale Lien, a 34-year-old farmer and the program director for the area's public television station, said that his first reaction to the prison proposal was, "Are we that desperate?"
 
Simply Refusing to Die
 "But after you have time to think it over it's not such a bad thing," he said. "It's not a smokestack industry. It's a renewable resource."
It is the natural resources, the lakes, the geese, the friendly faces, that make people who live here and in other towns like it want to stay and those who have left want to return.
It also makes them willing to take deep cuts in pay. The starting salary for the nonunion guards is $14,000, compared with about $23,000 for state guards.
Sue Baker, the prison's program director, said there was no place better than a small town to raise children. Born in Appleton, she lived in Minneapolis for years then returned, only to be laid off from the Appleton schools because of declining enrollment.
She said she was proud of Appleton and its latest effort to survive so the next generation could have what she had.
"We refuse to just sit down and die," she said. "We love this town too much for that."
Then she sat back in the empty prison and waited for the criminals to come to town.

HEADLINE: Cash Theft Shows Risks of Armored Car Business

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL

 BODY:
They are routinely entrusted with the ultimate in valuables, prize cargoes more coveted than jewels or furs, antiquities, truffles or narcotics. But the largely unregulated courier services that collect and deliver billions of dollars of other people's money in the New York region and around the nation every day are dismayingly vulnerable to theft, particularly inside jobs, law-enforcement officials and industry experts say.
In the wake of last Sunday's suspiciously smooth robbery of $8.2 million from the Brooklyn depot of Hudson Armored Car and Courier Service -- the 31st time in the last two years that an armored car company or vehicle was hit in or around the city -- Federal investigators and company officials described an industry fraught with problems.
 
Lower Costs, Lessower Security
 There are no Federal or local regulations in the New York region on who may transport money or how, and many in the industry have long opposed such controls. Security guards require state licenses in New York, and New York City applicants for licenses to carry handguns for work are screened by the police. But otherwise, experts say, the money-courier business is free of outside supervision or regulation. 
 While a dozen or so top companies, led by Brink's and Wells Fargo, field fleets of armored behemoths and try to weed out employees with criminal records, other companies transport cash in ordinary minivans or private cars and allow convicted felons, many earning little more than the minimum wage of $4.25 an hour, to stand watch over colossal fortunes. Still other cash-movers, known in the business as "bagmen," use no vehicles of their own at all but transport money by messengers taking the subway.
"It is quite risky," said Don K. Clark, assistant special agent in charge of the F.B.I.'s criminal division in New York City, who is supervising the Hudson investigation. But he, like others, said the operative factor was cost.
"It's just logic," Mr. Clark said. "A van with no modifications is less expensive." But even the largest or best-run companies, Mr. Clark said, are not immune to theft, particularly inside jobs. In fact, the 10-year-old Hudson company is one of the area's bigger armored car services.
The Hudson robbery Dec. 27 had many of the earmarks of an inside job, James M. Fox, assistant director in charge of the F.B.I.'s New York office, said last week. Investigators voiced puzzlement at how a surveillance camera came to be disabled, how the robbers entered, and how the money vault came to be left open.
The sole guard on duty, whose name was not released, was said to have told investigators that he was surprised in his office shortly before midnight by an intruder who put a gun to the back of his head and bound his wrists and ankles. The guard has maintained that he did not get any glimpse of the intruder's face or clothes. Five or six robbers were then said to have entered and absconded with the money in 120-pound sacks of newly minted $100 bills, leaving another $30 million behind. They also ignored about $300,000 in far less traceable collected cash receipts.
 
Quality of Guards at Issue
 "This stuff is happening all over the country every week," said Ira A. Lipman, chairman and president of Guardsmark Inc., a large security-consulting company, and a vocal critic of industry practices. "You can't give a person a minimum wage, a badge and a gun and say, 'Do this job.' It's a menace to the public."
Because of the immense amounts of money they carry -- one New York armored car company alone transports up to $500 million a day -- the companies have long been close-mouthed about their business. But several executives agreed last week to interviews.
They described an industry crowded with new entrants struggling to attract clients by offering money-courier service at rock-bottom prices that established companies then feel pressured to meet at the expense of a higher-quality work force.
Yet to their frustration, these owners and others said, security is often a low priority, so the price-cutters can set the economic agenda. Some couriers charge by the trip or amount of money carried, while others set fixed monthly or annual fees.
"In the corporate world, security is always the first thing to go when budgets are cut, and the last thing to bring on when revenues spread," said Stephen Davis, a former New York City police captain and department spokesman who is now director of investigations for Fairfax Group Ltd., a leading security-consulting firm. But he warned, "You get what you pay for: when you're dealing with a guy at $4.50 an hour, loyalty is hard to control."
As long is a courier is insured to protect the client against losses due to theft, clients may be tempted to go with the lowest bidder. But given the lack of regulation, experts say, some less reputable couriers may not even carry insurance coverage.
 
Scores of Companies
 Since courier guards frequently gain access to clients' confidential operations, dishonesty by these employees may carry wider risks apart from any financial loss, some industry officials say. Conversely, the better -- and higher-priced -- companies are branching out far beyond mere pickups and dropoffs of cash to offer money-counting and auditing services, in some cases taking over these functions from the banks.
"You can do things if you want to do them," said Mr. Lipman of Guardsmark, who blamed courier services for not making a better case to their clients for the need to hire better workers at higher rates. He cited his own company's rise, despite premium fees, to a more than $100-million-a-year operation.
The industry, which traces its origins to a Chicago school bus armored with steel plate some 70 years ago, now has about 150 armored car services nationwide, with perhaps 40 operating in the New York area, officials say. Brink's and Wells Fargo lead the field, joined in the New York area by Loomis, Federal Armored Express, Revere, Coin Depot, Vets International and Hudson, among the large companies.
Some smaller companies have also carved out niches, among them the Manhattan-based Epic Security Corporation, founded by a criminologist, Mark J. Lerner, who limits his service to a modest $250,000 a run. His clients include government agencies like the Internal Revenue Service and the New York City Board of Education.
Security consultants frequently voice amazement at the unfettered operations of guard services, including the courier industry. "In New York State somebody wanting a barber's license is better checked out than someone wanting a guard's license," Mr. Lipman said. Although passage this year of a long-stalled bill increased the state's supervision over security employees, it was barely a start, Mr. Lipman said.
 
Call for More Oversight
 The problem will only grow more acute, he predicted, noting that there were already two-and-a-half times as many security guards in the country as police officers and that the ratio will soon reach three to one. His office keeps a file of news reports on security guards around the country charged with violent crime.
Mr. Clark of the F.B.I. said he too found the lack of regulation hard to explain. "If you look at the banking system, the F.D.I.C. cut down on bank robberies," he said, referring to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which sets standards for bank security. "I'm not sitting here to advocate government control of everything," Mr. Clark said, "but if we had more control we could cut down on armored car robberies."
He said that while other F.B.I. jurisdictions had one or two armored car holdups a year, his office recorded 12 last year and 19 in 1991. Nearly half, he said, were believed to be inside jobs by a company's own employees or confederates working with them.
Some industry leaders acknowledge a problem. "Statistically, 80 percent of these losses are inside jobs; you can count on it," said Kip Koehler, founder and chief operating officer of the Coin Depot Corporation, whose 150 trucks service some 250 customers with 4,000 stops a day in the New York area.
 
A Muddy Role
 "Most of us," he said, "try their best with all the resources at their command to screen people, but we're inhibited in our ability to do a decent background check." He blamed privacy statutes and other restrictions limiting an employer's ability to administer polygraph examinations and personality tests to prospective workers.
"People in the security business think we're in the trucking business, and people in the trucking business think we're in the security business," lamented James L. Dunbar, founder, chairman and chief operating officer of Federal Armored Express of Baltimore, which is among the five largest armored car companies doing business in New York City.
Although one of the industry leaders, the 35-year-old company still contends with a 25 percent annual staff turnover and was compelled this year to pay a nearly 50 percent increase in insurance rates, in part to make up losses of less proficient competitors.
If someone else is held up, Mr. Dunbar said, "I don't say, 'Great, that's my competitor.' " Instead, he said, because all the losses are ultimately underwritten by Lloyd's of London, he ends up helping to foot the bill in the form of higher insurance rates.

HEADLINE: PALESTINIANS EXIT LEBANON IN DROVES

BYLINE: By IHSAN A. HIJAZI, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 2

 BODY:
As many as two-thirds of Palestinians living in camps in Lebanon have left the country, Palestine Liberation Organization officials say, in a move that could affect P.L.O. negotiating strength and the nation's delicate balance of religious communities.
"As many as 100,000 Palestinians left refugee camps in Lebanon" since 1991, one official, Salah Salah, the P.L.O.'s political officer, said recently at Ain El Hilwe, a refugee camp 25 miles south of the capital on the outskirts of Sidon that is the largest of 12 in Lebanon. P.L.O. officials say the exodus is a response to worsening economic and security conditions in the camps, as well as Government restrictions on jobs for non-Lebanese. 
 Mr. Salah said the number of 100,000 came from statistics compiled by the P.L.O. and international agencies. Registration figures released in December by the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees, which assists them, showed a total of 321,000 Palestinians in Lebanon, with 144,400 living in the camps.
Lebanese Government statistics say that 400,000 Palestinians live in Lebanon, many of them unregistered, as a result of the flight from Palestine after the state of Israel was created there. Most have refused resettlement for fear of losing a right of return to their country of origin. Government officials said they could not confirm Mr. Salah's statements until they completed a census of Palestinian refugees in Lebanon.
 
Political Force Weakened
 Such a Palestinian exodus from Lebanon would weaken not only the P.L.O.'s position as sole representative of the Palestinians but also the political force that is inherent from their concentrated presence in the region. The right of return for Palestinian refugees is asserted by the Palestinian delegation at the Middle East peace negotiations, whose eighth round ended on Dec. 17 in Washington without a breakthrough. Israel has consistently refused to discuss the subject.
Some Lebanese, particularly Christians, fear that large numbers of Palestinians, who are predominantly Muslim, could upset the delicate religious balance in a country of 3.4 million people. Lebanese Christians feel that the resettlement of these Arabs in this country would further dilute the Christian presence in the Government, because it is based on a fine equilibrium of power sharing between Muslims and Christians. Parliament and Cabinet seats are distributed equally between the two communities even though Muslims represent an estimated 75 percent of the population.
For Palestinians living outside of the camps, the Government said an estimated 15,000 had emigrated this year, many to the United States, Canada and Australia.
 
'82 Exodus Scattered 12,000
 Another Palestinian exodus from this nation took place after the 1982 Israeli invasion of Lebanon, when hundreds of families followed guerrillas to other countries. As many as 12,000 P.L.O. fighters were forced to leave Lebanon then and were relocated in Iraq, Jordan, the Sudan, Yemen, Libya, Tunisia and Algeria.
Among those getting ready to leave this time is Amneh Abdel Kader al Daher, a 54-year-old widow who lives in the Shatila camp in Beirut. She says she is getting her passport ready to travel to Toronto to join her family. Her two daughters and son, all married with children, have been settled there for the last year.
Khalil al Farr, a 27-year-old electrician and resident of Ain el-Hilweh, said he was waiting for a visa to go to Sydney, Australia, to join a cousin who owns an electrical-appliance shop.
"The Lebanese do not like the Palestinians and do not want them here," Mr. Farr said. "If ever there is peace in the Middle East I will return, but not to Lebanon, only to Palestine."
 
Deliberate Scheme Charged
 Mr. Salah, who is also the top official in Lebanon of the hard-line Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, said the Palestinians had gone to Canada, Germany, Sweden and Denmark, which have liberal laws for accepting political refugees. He asserted that there was a deliberate scheme to induce Palestinians to emigrate.
The Palestinians faced problems after the Lebanese Government stalled on promises to provide them with employment and other social services. The United Nations refugee agency says as much as 40 percent of the Palestinian work force in Lebanon is unemployed. P.L.O. officials blamed strict Government restrictions that require Palestinians to obtain work permits from the Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs.
Moreover, the authorities here have prevented hundreds of Palestinians working abroad from returning to Lebanon by refusing to renew their travel papers. Under Government regulations, any Palestinian who acquires residency abroad automatically loses his or her permit to live in Lebanon.
Officials of the Lebanese Government said they did not interfere in the travel or emigration of Palestinians, any more than they interfere in travel plans of Lebanese citizens.
Mr. Salah asserted that Western Governments in general and the United States in particular were making it easy for Palestinian refugees to go abroad "so as to deprive them of their right to return to their homeland, Palestine." He criticized the P.L.O. for "its failure to provide the refugee with all needs of steadfastness to make them stay and fight for the right of return."

HEADLINE: Some County Officials Prepare for an Earful

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: KALAMAZOO, Mich., Jan. 2

 BODY:
Last year, some Kalamazoo County commissioners got so nervous over Fred Ruden's verbal attacks on the county's mental health system that they hired a security guard to keep an eye on him at board meetings.
This year the commissioners are going to have to deal more closely with Mr. Ruden, a former mental patient who is also a lawyer and an unemployed bill collector. 
 Mr. Ruden, 37, won a seat on the commission in November, defeating a 14-year incumbent, Terry Lander.
"I think it helped that people were beginning to be very skeptical of their government," Mr. Ruden said Tuesday. "I wasn't afraid to attack it head on and risk everything."
He now says he is going to try to tone down his oratory, but he is not promising anything. "Politics is dirty," he said. "When people really upset me, I can't guarantee I'll keep my emotions in check."

HEADLINE: Congress Is Hoping to Enter a New Era

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2

 BODY:
The 103d Congress convenes Tuesday, with Democrats hoping to prove that inaction in Washington can end now that they have a Democratic President to work with.
With solid majorities in the House and the Senate and promises from leaders and important committee chairmen that President-elect Bill Clinton's agenda is their agenda, the Democrats also know that if they fail to pass a hefty measure of legislation, they will have no plausible excuses. 
 The Republicans, meanwhile, will enjoy the luxury of opposing when they want to and compromising or even supporting some Democratic initiatives when they think it serves their interest. Their role may be both simpler and more important without the responsibility of supporting a Republican Administration that some of them found too rigidly conservative and others considered too accommodating.
 
Undoing Bush's Vetoes
 The first efforts to prove that things have changed may come this month. House committees will be ready to act right away on some of the same bills that died because of President Bush's vetoes, especially a measure to require employers to offer workers unpaid leave for family and medical emergencies and another that obliges states to permit voters to register when they apply for drivers' licenses, welfare or other social services.
The Senate is less committed to a sprinter's start on legislation, but it hopes to finish informal confirmation hearings on Mr. Clinton's most important Cabinet choices in time to confirm them on Inauguration Day, Jan. 20, or the day after. The first hearing will be Wednesday, when Ronald H. Brown, chairman of the Democratic National Committee goes before the Commerce Committee to begin his confirmation as Commerce Secretary.
Party ratios have not changed much. The Senate remains at 57 Democrats and 43 Republicans. The House went from 268 Democrats, 166 Republicans and 1 independent to 258 Democrats, 176 Republicans and 1 independent.
But the new Democrats seem more likely to support their leaders on major party issues than some of those they replaced, so there may be little real shift. The Republicans are about as conservative as they were in the last Congress; they had little room to move to the right.
 
Changes in Background
 However it votes, the new Congress will at least look different. It will have six female Senators, up from two, and 48 female Representatives, up from 29. In the House, there will be 38 blacks, up from 25. At 9 percent of the House, blacks will approach the 12 percent of the nation's population they account for. The number of Hispanic House members has increased even more sharply, to 17 from 10.
The House will have 110 new members, more than a fourth of its membership and the biggest freshman class since 1949. The new members are not especially young, and many have experience in state legislatures or other forms of government, blunting the image of change that many sought to cultivate in their campaigns. One difference between new and older lawmakers stands out; fewer than a fifth of the freshmen have military experience, while almost half of the returning representatives do.
But if there are sharp changes in the ranks of junior members, with 11 new Senators joining the 110 new Representatives, there are no changes at all in the top ranks of the leadership of either chamber.
In the Senate that probably promotes what passes for efficiency in that body, because Senators George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, and Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, know each other's moves. They understand that getting anything done in a body whose rules celebrate minorities, even minorities of one, requires accommodation.
In the House, leadership familiarity has bred, if not contempt, at least a certain tedious disdain. The Democrats think the Republicans under Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the minority leader, have caved in to their noisy, negative right and cannot keep a bargain.
The Republicans think the Democrats under Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader, bully them, deny them a decent share of staff and influence, and run the institution ineptly, both in terms of legislative schedules and of administering entities like the House bank and the House post office. The Republicans are especially frustrated that voter retribution for the scandal involving overdrafts at the House bank fell on both parties, not just on the Democrats.
There will be many shifts in power at the committee level. The House will have eight new committee chairmen, and the Senate will have five.
 
Contrasting Agendas
 The most important Senate change is almost certainly the expected succession of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York to the chairmanship of the Senate Finance Committee after the current chairman, Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, becomes Treasury Secretary. Mr. Moynihan will bring with him a set of urban concerns, like welfare, that differ from those of his predecessor.
In the House, Representative William H. Natcher of Kentucky will assume the chairmanship of the Appropriations Committee succeeding Representative Jamie L. Whitten of Mississippi, who is 82 and in poor health. Mr. Natcher was the committee's acting chairman last year. And Representative Ronald V. Dellums of California, a dedicated critic of military spending, is all but certain to succeed Representative Les Aspin of Wisconsin as chairman of the Armed Services Committee when Mr. Aspin is confirmed as Defense Secretary.
A different sort of change could have even more effect. Lawyers for House employees questioned about unusual stamp purchases in the post office scandal say they believe that Jay Stephens, the United States Attorney for the District of Columbia, is hurrying to persuade a grand jury here to indict Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.
 
Indictments Weigh In
 An indictment would matter not only to Mr. Rostenkowski and Mr. Stephens, but also to Mr. Clinton. House Democrats require any member under indictment to relinquish any chairmanship temporarily, and the new Administration could sorely miss Mr. Rostenkowski's skill in assembling majorities on tax, trade and health-care legislation. (The Republicans have no such rule and are keeping Representative Joseph M. McDade of Pennsylvania in his position as ranking minority member of the Appropriations Committee, despite indictments last year charging him with conspiracy, racketeering and bribery.)
There is no way of telling how the new members may affect the way the committees do their business. But in the Senate leaders are pressing to get one of the four new Democratic women to serve on the Judiciary Committee, whose all-male makeup was cited in their campaigns, especially because of the panel's treatment of Prof. Anita F. Hill during the hearings on the nomination of Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court.
Senate leaders are also hoping to persuade a woman to take on the thankless role of joining the Ethics Committee, which has to decide soon how it will deal with sexual harassment charges against Senator Bob Packwoood, Republican of Oregon.
 
Winning Back the Public
 The Democrats' fundamental analysis is that the public will put aside the scorn stirred by the House bank scandal and the questioning of Anita Hill if it can see the Congress passing laws that address the country's real problems.
They anxiously await Mr. Clinton's proposals on the economy and compete with each other in sight-unseen allegiance to his fiscal policies. They promise to do their best on health care, but in a chorus warned Mr. Clinton not to expect to pass health-care legislation quickly. "I told Bill Clinton," Mr. Rostenkowski said recently, " 'You haven't any idea of how many chits you have to play. You're going to have to work your buns off to get your health bill.' " .
But a lot less has been heard from Capitol Hill about lawmakers' wanting to pass new campaign-spending laws, another of Mr. Clinton's priorities. Last year, Democrats passed a bill to impose limits on spending and on contributions from political action committees, but they felt safe in doing so because they were sure Mr. Bush would veto them, as he did. A campaign-finance bill that might actually become law could be much harder to sell.
 
Top Priority: Confirmations
 The first week will be largely devoted to atmospherics. Democrats will make no effort to deny Mr. Packwood or Paul D. Coverdell, a Georgia Republican, their seats. Mr. Coverdell's election over Senator Wyche Fowler Jr. is being challenged in court, and some Oregon voters are urging that Mr. Packwood not be seated because of the sexual harassment issue. One reason for the Democratic reticence is that they want a civil atmosphere for the informal confirmation hearings. Actual nomination papers will not be sent to the Senate until Mr. Clinton has been sworn in, but if no problems have developed in the committee hearings, confirmation votes usually come quickly.
The House may be in for more of its usual wrangling. Democrats are pondering modifications of a rules change they proposed last month that would give the five Democratic delegates from the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa and the Virgin Islands voting power when the House considers amendments to bills.
That proposal has enraged Republicans, and the Democrats are wondering whether to back down a bit and whether to permit a separate vote on this issue, instead of including it with all other rules questions. The trouble with a separate vote, from their perspective, is that they might lose.

HEADLINE: Dinkins to Propose 15 More Beacon Centers

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON

 BODY:
As part of his State of the City Message, Mayor David N. Dinkins will propose financing 15 more Beacon community centers that will offer a mix of social services ranging from recreation and job training in New York City public schools after school hours.
The Mayor's proposal would bring the number of Beacon community social-service centers housed in the public schools to 36, guaranteeing at least one for each of the city's 32 community school districts, city officials said yesterday. 
 The expansion of the Beacon program, at a cost of $7.5 million, is one of the first initiatives that city officials have let trickle out about Mr. Dinkins's annual State of the City Message tomorrow.
 
Keeping Schools Open
 The Beacon program increased the hours that public schools are open by 300 percent in some of the city's most troubled neighborhoods last year, officials said. Last year, more than 30,000 children and adults were served by the centers, officials said.
Public School 15 in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn, where the principal, Patrick F. Daly, was slain last month, was one of the original sites to be designated a Beacon center when the program was established a year and a half ago.
The Beacon centers, supervised by the City Department of Youth Services, are managed by community-based organizations that work with local school boards, school principals and advisory boards that include parents, teachers, religious leaders and youths.
 
Community Centers
 When school is not in session, the centers provide services like tutoring, health education, exercise classes and parental skills at night and on weekends. They are also intended as centers of community revitalization, serving as cornerstones of stability and opportunity in deteriorating neighborhoods.
Several Beacon sites have become centers for community celebrations, playing host to weekly Family Nights, holiday parties for children and Thanksgiving dinners prepared by local restaurants and served by youths to their parents.
The program so far has received $11.5 million.
The Mayor originally proposed 10 Beacon centers in his Safe Streets, Safe City plan, all of which are currently operating. In last year's State of the City Message, the Mayor proposed doubling the number of the Beacon centers, of which eight will open in February and three in April.
Financing for 15 additional Beacon schools will be included in the Mayor's budget for fiscal-year 1994. The new centers would all be open by this August.
While the current Beacon centers are situated in poor neighborhoods buffeted by crime, drugs and AIDS, some of the new centers are to be situated in more stable, middle-class neighborhoods, said the Commissioner of Youth Services, Richard Murphy.
"This is addressing the issue that there are thousands of working parents out there who have no place for their children to go when they are out of school," the Commissioner said.
City and school officials have supported the financing in the past, officials said yesterday.
"You've heard of Nimby, this is Pimby, please in my backyard," Mr. Murphy said. "The problem I have is picking the schools. Everybody wants this program. This program brings a level of support that makes it easier for schools to concentrate on the business of teaching. It's like making a school into a settlement house."
Beacon schools are currently in the Bushwick, East New York and Red Hook sections of Brooklyn; the Highbridge/Melrose and Hunts Point sections of the Bronx; the Far Rockaway and South Jamaica sections of Queens; the Washington Heights and Central Harlem sections of Manhattan, and in the North Shore section on Staten Island.

HEADLINE: POLITICAL NOTES;
Dinkins May Have Regrets, but Not on Crown Hts.

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins, a man who rarely admits fault, reflected last week on his performance over the last year and rendered this judgment: he was right the first time.
In his annual year-end interview with reporters, Mr. Dinkins did not give an inch to his critics among Orthodox Jews who have repeatedly attacked him for his handling of the racial violence in Crown Heights, Brooklyn in August 1991. 
 "I know what I did and what I said and I am satisfied with my behavior," Mr. Dinkins said.
The critics, many of them from the Lubavitch Hasidim, have suggested that the police responded too slowly to the violence and that Mr. Dinkins did not intercede quickly enough. They have also said he should have condemned a jury that acquitted a young black man, Lemrick Nelson Jr., in the racially motivated killing of a Jewish student, Yankel Rosenbaum, during the turmoil, just as he condemned the jury that acquitted four Los Angeles police officers in the beating of Rodney G. King.
If Mr. Dinkins had any second thoughts about his decisions, he did not acknowledge them in public. Indeed, he suggested that his critics were rewriting history. The Mayor argued that from the time of the 1991 disturbances until the Nelson verdict, he was praised even by his political foes for keeping the peace.
"Then of course came the Nelson verdict and in the minds of some we had to go back to square one," he said. "People in a sense began to revise and re-question that which had gone on in the first three days of the riot."
Mr. Dinkins also steadfastly repeated his argument that the King beating differed from the stabbing death of Mr. Rosenbaum, because in the King case an amateur cameraman caught the beating on videotape.
"I am not satisfied that so many people in the Lubavitcher community felt that there was no distinction between the Nelson verdict and the Rodney King verdict," he said. "To me it is as clear as day and night. I still think there is a vast difference."
The Mayor dismissed the notion that his handling of the Crown Heights episodes would haunt his re-election campaign.
"Whether or not it -- quote -- haunts me in the campaign is a function of what you media do," he said. "I don't see it as a continuing issue unless you raise it as such."
 
New Albany Budget Experts
 As any state official will attest, negotiating a budget isn't much fun when the job consists entirely of cutting. That has been the case in Albany for the last three years and will be the case again in 1993, when the Governor and the Legislature will have to fill a budget gap that some analysts now believe will exceed $4 billion.
The task will only be made more difficult by the continued flight of the Legislature's most experienced budget experts from their jobs. Last week, Carl P. Carlucci, who has served for six years as the chief budget negotiator for the Democratic majority in the Assembly, announced that he was leaving his position as Secretary of the Ways and Means Committee.
Mr. Carlucci has accepted a job as vice president for finance and business at the State University of New York at Albany. A former administrator at both SUNY-Stony Brook and the City University of New York, Mr. Carlucci was also the Assembly's leading expert on redistricting.
His counterpart with the Republican majority in the State Senate, Eugene K. Tyksinski, also has left the Capitol. With Gov. Mario M. Cuomo scheduled to present his budget proposal to the Legislature on Jan. 19, replacements have yet to be announced by either Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin or the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino.
Senate aides say that Mr. Marino is looking both inside and outside his current staff. Assembly officials say a leading contender for Mr. Carlucci's job is his deputy, Janet Penksa.
 
Anti-Tax Democrats Gain

Call it revenge of the naysayers. In the Connecticut General Assembly, conservative Democrats who went against the grain of their own party in 1991 in opposing the creation of a state income tax are now increasingly among the leaders.
The new House Speaker-elect, Thomas D. Ritter, a Democrat from Hartford, has appointed conservative Democrats to significant posts throughout the new regime. The new tenor of the chamber was also expressed when the party -- which controls both the House and Senate -- chose a fiercely anti-income-tax Democrat, Thomas S. Luby of Meriden, as their majority leader.
Although few legislators these days speak seriously of repealing the tax, as Mr. Luby and others tried to do in 1991 and 1992, the new tone is unmistakable. In the House, liberal pro-tax firebrands like Representative Jonathan Pelto have been banished to minor posts, while the former House speaker, Richard J. Balducci, who left the House to run for the Senate, has similarly been given a low-totem job by Senate leaders.
And this week, a Senate Democrat who opposed the tax, James H. Maloney of Danbury, who has already been named co-chairman of the tax-writing committee, the Finance, Revenue and Bonding Committee, was given the additional post of assistant majority leader in the Senate.
"He has emerged as a leading voice for mainstream 'New Democratic' fiscal, economic development and social policies," said Senator John B. Larson, the president pro tempore, in announcing Mr. Maloney's appointment. Mr. Larson also voted a resounding no on the income tax.

HEADLINE: Late Checks Provide Aid To Neediest

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
When Christmas decorations begin to engulf New York City and radio stations start playing a marathon of seasonal selections, many people draw up lists of holiday chores: buy presents, mail cards, plan a special meal, pray for snow, send a donation to charity.
Sometimes that final item is overlooked amid the eat-until-you-burst parties and visits from old friends and shopping-mall expeditions and annual trips to distant relatives' homes. Late last month, though, a number of contributors remembered for the first time to send a check to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. 
 "I have meant to do this every year, but most of the time the pressures of Christmas put it out of my mind," Elizabeth J. R. Goodspeed of Fairfield, Conn., wrote in a letter to the fund that she enclosed with her $300 check. "This year I feel the need is so great that I couldn't let it go -- and have added some for having forgotten so often."
Naomi Talish of Manhattan, who sent $50 to the fund, also wrote that she was finally making good on a promise to herself.
"Like many New Yorkers, I have been meaning to donate for several years," she said. "The recent death of my grandfather Max Goldfrank, a man who instilled in my family a strong sense of duty to others, has prompted me to send you a donation in his name."
"Thank you," she added, "for giving me a perfect opportunity to honor him, although I know he would be disappointed in me for waiting so long to contribute to the fund."
Susan Schultheiss of Hamden, Conn., sent $20 with a note that explained: "I don't know why I didn't do this earlier. But I guess it's never too late." And Hilary Lieberman of Manhattan gave $10. "Last year, I put off writing this check -- and then it was too late to do so," she said. "Although it's not much, I hope it makes someone's holidays a tiny bit brighter."
Since the early years of this century, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has come to the aid of tens of thousands of people. The fund is now conducting its 81st appeal at a time when social-service organizations across New York City must meet growing responsibilities because of the recession.
The Times pays the fund's expenses, so all contributions go directly to seven charities. This year's campaign ends on Feb. 28.
In a letter to the fund that she included with her $15 check, Pauline Sasson of Manhattan said that she was proud that she was helping the Neediest Cases for the first time. "Somehow, I always forgot to do this," she said. "Other things intervened, but this cause is most important and wonderful."
Judith Rosenbaum of Manhattan, who gave $200, expressed similar sentiments.
"I missed last year's drive," she said. "Sorry. I'm glad you all were there, though. I know you made the difference between surviving and going under for many people. Maybe things will get a little easier for the world -- and the city -- this year. We can always hope!"

HEADLINE: Auguring Well: Trouble on Deck;
A Season Called On Account of Greed?

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY

 BODY:
Baseball has just staggered through such a gloomy season that one can imagine a future without booming home runs and dashing slides and warm summer nights at the ball park. A 1993 doomsday scenario for baseball goes something like this:
The owners force their labor negotiator, Richard Ravitch, to threaten a lockout to limit free agency. Since the commissionership was knee-capped, Ravitch is seen as a hired gun rather than an ombudsman. There is no spring training, which puts baseball out of sight. 
 Opening day in April comes and goes with fans watching the Final Four and Michael Jordan, as well as doing home repairs or reading hard-cover books again.
In mid-May, the owners and players get desperate and arrive at a compromise they could have reached in January. Baseball opens its doors but the fans stay away. CBS and ESPN, in the last year of their $1.5-billion national contract, announce they will not make a bid for 1994. Meanwhile, Congress is questioning baseball's cushy anti-trust exemption.
With attendance and television ratings down, a few local stations delay payment on their contracts with individual clubs. The Pittsburgh Pirates, struggling on the field and at the gate after letting star players go in economy moves, default on their payroll. Players demand their money, like a run on the banks during the Great Depression.
One day the Pirates refuse to work, and the club hires semiprofessionals, but union sympathizers throw up picket lines at all stadiums. The game shuts down. Television stations announce that baseball has broken its agreement and ask for givebacks. There is no 1993 World Series, no midnight games, no nothing. The owners blame the players. The players blame the owners. Americans get more sleep. Children practice their jump shots.

HEADLINE: Russian Economic Change Will Take Time;
Moscow's Pizza Hut

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Help Russia but Hold the Pizza" (Op-Ed, Nov. 23), Edward L. Keenan writes that people in the former Soviet Union do not need pizza parlors or automatic-teller machines so much as they need basic life-support systems. 
 During my family's stay in Moscow in July and August 1991, we lived around the corner from Pizza Hut on Tverskaya. Growing despondent at the extremely uneven supplies of fresh food, we relinquished our vow to experience the visit unsullied by fast-food vendors.
Forsaking the milelong lines to McDonald's (across from Pushkin's statue), we rounded the corner of our street to glance hesitantly but hungrily through the windows of Pizza Hut.
The takeaway menu, jauntily printed only in English, bids us to choose from the following and enjoy a refreshing drink with our takeaway meal. The prices marked next to the "Supreme" are a simple 18. The small print at the bottom informs us that the prices on the menu are in United States dollars, but that payment is also willingly accepted in pounds, marks and Finnish marks, as well as a variety of credit cards.
Apparently, the fledgling capitalists believed there were people desperate enough to fork over the equivalent of some $29 for pizza, should they wish to pay in pounds. No change given, I'm sure.
While this heady information left us reeling, we lined up with the rest of the former and future citizens, and waited at the outside window hatch, where one could pay in rubles, a definite bargain. Forty-five minutes later, still qualifying as lightning fast by certain standards, we placed our order, paying four rubles a slice, the equivalent of 15 cents.
The thrill of beating the system was increased by the front-line seats we were treated to a few days later at the attempted coup and the ever-with-us knowledge that we were now somehow part of history.
So, should you decide to forsake champagnsky and blinis for a delicious repast at Pizza Hut when next you are in Moscow, you may also need an automatic teller machine to pay for it.
 
JILL RUSSELL
New York, Dec. 14, 1992

HEADLINE: Come Join the Fight

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I was distressed to see myself listed in "Calls to Restrict Immigration Come From Many Quarters" (The Week in Review, Dec. 13) as a sponsor of a constitutional amendment that would deny United States citizenship to American-born children of undocumented parents. 
 I do not support any proposal of this sort. Last spring my name was added in error as a co-sponsor of the amendment. On learning this, I immediately requested that my name be removed.
Such an amendment would create a permanent underclass, born in this country but not entitled to the same rights as citizens.
Many civil rights leaders, you maintain, are torn between their conscience and their constituents, as African-Americans worry that immigrants are displacing them from jobs and political power. Our job as leaders is to bring attention to the real causes of unemployment and disenfranchisement among both groups and to insure that they are allies in the movement for economic and social justice.
 
CHARLES B. RANGEL
Member of Congress, 15th Dist., N.Y.
Washington, Dec. 23, 1992

HEADLINE: Let's Not Laud Mr. Greenspan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Regarding "Greenspan's Gift to the Nation: No Bank Crisis" (Dec. 20), it is good to know that American taxpayers may not be called upon to deal with a banking crisis. But the idea that this is a gift from Alan Greenspan is hard to digest.
As the article stated, after interest rates fell, "the banks found a way to make nice money without making loans . . . by buying two-year to five-year government securities." 
 The loans the banks did not make would have financed consumer durable goods purchases and small businesses, leading to an earlier, noninflationary and more typical economic recovery. The "gift," then, is sponsored by the American people.
Perhaps it would have been more appropriate had this unannounced banking industry bailout been authorized by Congress after reviewing why Federal Reserve regulations and banking industry oversight did not prevent the excesses of the 1980's.
 
GERALD L. MURPHY
Oak Brook, Ill., Dec. 20

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
That Airline Pillow May Be Well Traveled

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
PAUL EKMAN, a researcher in the School of Medicine at the University of California in San Francisco, asked for a pillow on a recent United Airlines flight home from Boston. When the flight attendant handed him a pillow, he saw hair on it and complained, only to be told that the pillowcases were not changed after every flight. Nor, he was told in response to a question, were the headsets changed or cleaned after every flight.
Mr. Ekman wrote to United about its "unhealthy" practice and received a letter from a customer relations official saying that the pillows and headsets were "checked and cleaned on regularly scheduled intervals" but if the items were "damaged or visibly dirty," they were replaced. 
 Inquiries among domestic airlines show that United is in the majority in not replacing its pillows after each flight segment or at the end of the flight. Most airlines replace pillowcases nightly and while other policies about headsets seem to be stricter than United's, it is not impossible that you may use a headset that has already been used by someone else. Both time and economic pressures were cited as reasons.
By phone, United confirmed the information Mr. Ekman received, issuing a statement from Dr. Gary M. Kohn, medical director of the airline:
"We are unaware of any diseases or infections caused by contact with either headsets or headrest covers or pillows. We think it is highly unlikely that diseases could be communicated through these materials in a normal environment. Certainly in cases where there is any evidence whatsoever of contamination, we will replace the unit immediately."
Joseph P. Hopkins, the airline's spokesman, said that headrest covers, which are used only on international flights, were changed after every flight in all three classes. He said that pillows were changed whenever they appeared to need it, but that cleaners replaced them all on a cycle with a maximum length of two days.
Dr. Mary E. Wilson, chief of infectious diseases at the Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass., author of "A World Guide to Infections" (Oxford University Press), believes that some micro-organisms are spread on shared pillows but that the risk is low of contracting a serious infection from a pillow that appears clean.
"If someone had an open sore on the neck or head," Dr. Wilson said, "it could contaminate something it came in contact with. But not many disease-producing bacteria can survive for long periods on a dry, unsoiled fabric. Some common skin bacteria like staphylococci or streptococci may remain on fabrics, however they do not easily pass through unbroken skin." Dr. Wilson added that passengers need not be concerned about HIV infections from any saliva on a pillowcase.
The headset is a problem of another dimension in Dr. Wilson's view. She took note of research by Dr. Itzhak Brook, "Changes in the Microbial Flora of Airline Headset Devices After Their Use," published in Laryngoscope in January 1992. Dr. Brook, who is a professor of pediatrics at the Georgetown School of Medicine and a senior investigator at the Armed Forces Radiobiology Research Institute in Bethesda, Md., was following up his 1985 research showing that the wearer's own bacteria are markedly increased by 60 minutes of wearing earphones that cover the whole ear.
 
Increase in Bacteria
 Dr. Brook's new work focused on the bacteria found on the headset after use for 60 minutes. In this test, he used sterile headsets of the type most often found, ones with the smaller earphones, usually covered with gray plastic foam. The research showed a 100- to 700-fold increase in bacteria on the set, including staphylococci of three types and streptococci of two types. After this conclusion, Dr. Brook said, he does not feel comfortable wearing the headsets, and he said that people whose immune systems are compromised, including those undergoing chemotherapy, should be quite concerned.
Dr. Brook also wrote United Airlines about his results, and Dr. Kohn, in his reply, said that the airline would watch closely for any signs that infections were transmitted by the headphones.
Regardless of the airline, the best advice for those who may be concerned is to take your own inflatable neck pillow in your carry-on luggage; in any case, it is certainly more restful than the thin pad the airlines provide. The medical evidence indicates that the earphones may be more cause for anxiety. If you have a cut or any other ear problem, listen to your own tape player or view the movie as a silent.
Here are other airlines' responses about pillows and headsets.
Continental Airlines, according to Peggy Mahoney, a spokeswoman, replaces the whole pillow nightly on all the planes. "They are also replaced, as needed, during the day," Ms. Mahoney said. She said that the headsets were replaced after each use.
America West has a different approach. For $4 the passenger buys the headset, which is the light-wire type that can be used with personal tape recorders, according to Dik Shimizu, the spokesman. If customers leave headsets behind, Mr. Shimizu said, the airline sends them to sheltered workshops where disabled workers replace the earpieces, then the headsets are used again. "Our pillow policy," Mr. Shimizu said, "is to change every case every night. We also have 25 to 30 extras aboard each flight for use as needed." Mr. Shimizu spoke for many lines in saying that trying to change cases between each flight would cut down on efficiency and "profit margins that barely exist."
Southwest Airlines changes all pillowcases every night, according to Ginger Hardage, a spokeswoman. This airline does not have plug-in earphones, she said.
USAir collects, cleans and recycles its headsets after each use, according to Nancy Vaughan, a spokeswoman. Pillowcases are replaced each night.
The Trans World Airlines spokeswoman said that pillowcases were replaced at each "layover cleaning," which is generally at night, and that headsets were either dipped in a sanitizing solution or replaced after each use, depending on the model.
Northwest changes the ear part of the headset after each flight. The pillowcases are replaced at every overnight cleaning, according to Jim Faulkner.
American, according to Tim Smith, a spokesman, changes its disposable pillowcases every night; the cloth cases on international flights are changed after every flight, he said. The earphones used on transcontinental flights are also replaced after each flight; plastic ones are cleaned nightly or replaced nightly.
Delta, according to Neil A. Monroe, a spokesman, disinfects the headsets after they have been unsealed and repackages them. If the pillows have been taken from the overhead bins, he said, the covers are replaced.
Another reader, in a letter to this section, raised a second issue concerning health in the aircraft cabin. On landing in Australia in 1988, she said, the flight attendant sprayed the cabin interior and the passengers sat in the spray for a half an hour before debarking. There was no warning about this occurence, important to her because of her acute allergies.
The Australian tourist organization confirms that the spray was d-phenothrin, an insecticide. Chermerdene N. Jordan of the Australian Tourist Commission said that the spray is used in a concentration approved by the World Health Organization. The passenger was nonetheless made ill by it and had to cut her trip short. According to Ms. Jordan, the passenger sued but lost the case in United States courts.
Ms. Jordan says the cabins of all flights to Australia are still sprayed, a Health Department requirement to "keep at bay" insects that may carry human, animal or plant diseases. Qantas now does it through the ventilation system.
One sharp memory of a trip to Hawaii in 1975 was that the cabin was suddenly sprayed before we disembarked, an unpleasant experience. The Hawaii Department of Health dropped this in 1979, but if I were sensitive to pesticides, I would ask airlines and consulates of places I had never visited if there are governmental requirements that cabins are to be sprayed on arrival.

HEADLINE: Rediscovering Rio, With Your Eyes Open

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE; JAMES BROOKE is the chief of the Times's Rio de Janeiro bureau.

 BODY:
IN an odd turn of the wheel, Rio as an international tourist destination has gone back to where it was when I first arrived here in 1976 as a college student exploring Brazil's long coastline by bus. Today, as before, Rio is off the beaten track.
In the intervening years, mass tourism discovered the city. Americans and Europeans disembarked by the jumbo jet load. One result of this encounter between first-world wealth and third-world poverty was a spiraling rate of street crime. By the late 1980's, tourism had declined; according to Embratur, Brazil's national tourism authority, in 1990 only half of the 1.07 million foreign visitors to Brazil passed through the city, compared with two-thirds of two million foreign visitors in 1987. And in an Embratur survey of foreign tourists taken in 1990, about a third said crime was the main reason for the decline in tourism to Rio. 
 While many tourists went elsewhere, the city stayed behind. And Rio's charms endured -- white sand beaches, bronzed bodies in minimal bathing suits, gray granite mountains cloaked in emerald green rain forest, smoky nightclubs reverberating with lyrics sung in Brazil's melodious Portuguese, and corner bars offering a plethora of tropical fruit juices, freshly squeezed at 40 cents a glass.
The difference is that, once again, the foreign visitor feels more like a pioneer, an individualist whose reward is often the thrill of discovery. And Rio, instead of trying to be the world's party capital, has returned to its old, more comfortable, self -- a Brazilian city for Brazilians.
The changes in the city were brought home to me on a Sunday afternoon in late December, when I had my pocket picked for the first time in a total of eight years of living here. As I walked to Ipanema's Banana Cafe to meet two friends for lunch, about three blocks past the headquarters of Rio's new Tourist Police, a pair of pickpockets deftly relieved me of my lunch money.
Like many urban experiences these days, a visit to Rio is an experience to be approached with eyes wide open. Just as you would not leave valuables unattended on a towel in New York's Central Park in July, don't leave your camera and hotel key on a towel on Ipanema Beach in January. Take to Rio accessories you don't mind losing -- a cheap watch and a plastic box for a camera. Leave wallets, passports and jewelry in the hotel safe. Explore the city with enough cash for the day, a photocopy of your passport in your pocket, and, maybe, to blend in, a copy of a local newspaper under your arm.
With a wariness for street crime, the city can be highly enjoyable. Indeed, as I walked home after lunch the day my pocket was picked, I saw one scene after another of the Rio I love at its best. In a newly refurbished park, a jazz band was warming up for the Ipanema Jazz Festival. Along the beach, the oceanfront avenues of Ipanema and Leblon were closed to cars and had surrendered to Rio's rich human comedy: roller skaters, bicyclists, families pushing prams, retirees out for their Sunday constitutional, bleached blond surfers chatting with their girlfriends, young men improvising a form of volleyball with their feet, and mustachioed policemen walking their beach beats dressed in summer uniforms of T-shirts and shorts.
It is also cheap. To the delight of visiting Americans, Brazil is one corner of the world where the dollar is still king. Our lunch -- carpaccio, pizza, orange juice, espresso, assorted bottles of water and and tip -- came to $34 for three people. Saturday night, my dinner for two at Torre de Babel, an Ipanema restaurant with live music -- appetizer, chicken and orange juice -- came to $16.40 for two. One block off Copacabana beach, a comfortable hotel room for two can easily be found for $50 a night.
As a legacy of the boom years, Rio enjoys an excellent tourist infrastructure: luxury hotels along the beaches, restaurants with bilingual menus, friendly, English-speaking tour guides and the new multilingual tourist police. To revive tourism, city authorities have undertaken a program of safety precautions and beautification: increased beach patrols, spruced up oceanfront boulevards, fenced-in city parks, and an eight-lane highway to speed visitors from the airport to the beaches in the city's south.
Over the years, I've found favorite amusements in Rio that remain compelling. In a city notorious for its narcissism, a principal source of entertainment is people watching. (Cariocas -- or Rio residents -- are one of the world's few peoples who generally look better out of their clothes than in. During the day, a leisurely way to take in the human spectacle is to rent a bicycle and to pedal the length of the brand new waterfront bicycle lanes. The routes are: Copacabana to Leblon, around Lagoa, and the length of Sao Conrado and Barra beaches.
For dinner, the beautiful people tend to congregrate about the following restaurants in Ipanema and Leblon: Banana Cafe, for light fare; Gattopardo, a pizzeria; Guilhermina, serving international cuisine; Mostarda, specializing in dishes with mustard; Arlecchino, for nouvelle Italian, and Caribe, serving a Brazilian version of West Indian cooking. (Taxis are recommended for getting around at night.) For moderately priced Brazilian cuisine, try Casa da Feijoada in Botafogo.
Before dinner, check the show listings of Rio's two major newspapers, Globo and Jornal do Brasil. Music is one of Brazil's best known and most endearing exports. A hotel concierge can usually help you find Rio's homegrown jazz, bossa nova, samba, Brazilian rock and Afro-beat. The houses that get the best acts include: Canecao, Imperator, Jazzmania, the Rio Jazz Club, People, Circo Voador and Mistura Fina. For disco dancing, the golden youth of the Southern Zone (Zona Sul) flock to Resumo da Opera, next to Gattopardo pizzeria in Lagoa.
If you feel uncertain about wading solo into a Portuguese-speaking evening crowd, Brazil Nuts, a Connecticut travel company, offers samba, jazz, lambada and Big Band nights on the town.
Now that I have three small boys with "Rio de Janeiro" printed on their birth certificates, my late-night pub crawling has largely been replaced by wholesome daylight activities.
The standard outings listed in guidebooks are definitely worthwhile. Views from Sugar Loaf Mountain and from the Christ statue atop Corcovado Mountain are not only breathtaking, they also help the visitor and the resident alike assemble the jigsaw puzzle of tunnels, hills and beaches that is Rio. But , over the years spent in Rio, I have developed some lesser-known favorites. Two are add-ons; both are well policed. At the base of Sugar Loaf, a paved trail leads around the southern flank of the mountain, providing unexpected views of Copacabana and about one mile's worth of exercise. On weekends, the Paineiras road is closed to cars beyond the entrance to the Christ statue. For about five miles, pedestrians, joggers and bicyclists can climb through Tijuca National Park, stopping to refresh themselves in mountain showers that erupt from rock formations.
Closer to town, the newly refurbished Botanical Garden offers one square kilometer of greenery and tranquillity. Containing 6,200 species of tropical plants and trees, the gardens are ideal for quiet walks and talks.
At the end of the day, there is a fascinating spectacle to be found at the southern end of Sao Conrado beach. In a classic Rio mix of risk and romance, hang gliders take off from Candida Pedra Bonita peak, 2,000 feet above, and circle through the sunset to land at dusk on the south Atlantic sand.
 
 
 
CONCERNS, FOOD AND FUN
Cautions
 The State Department's Consular Information Sheet on Brazil warns that crime against foreigners in the city is greatest in the most popular beaches and neighborhoods of Copacabana and Leme; robberies are most common at dusk and in the evening. The department also says nightclubs and discotheques in those areas of Rio are often the site of incidents.
Rio Tourist Police, Afranio de Melo Franco Avenue, Leblon; telephone 511-5767.
A tip on Brazil's magically vanishing cruzeiro: with monthly inflation at 25 percent, the cruzeiros in your pocket shrink in value by almost 1 percent a day. Since the free-floating exchange rate paces inflation, exchange only enough dollars to cover expenses for a day or two at a time.
