HEADLINE: CAMERA;
New Applications For Still Photography

BYLINE: By John Durniak; John Durniak is a freelance writer, editor and consultant on photography.

 BODY:
ROBERT PLEDGE, president of Contact Press Images in New York, is looking for new directions for the picture agency he helped to found in 1976.
"I've begun spending more time in Paris," he said, "because of the tremendous shift of the news in the last few years. The news has switched from the west side of the Atlantic Ocean to the east side. 
 "For a long period, the major stories were coming out of America, but now with Tiananmen Square, the crash of the Berlin wall, the split-up of the U.S.S.R., Desert Storm, Yugoslavia's problems, Somalia and Arab-Israeli tension, the focus for photography is on Europe, the Middle East, Africa and Asia."
There is also more money to be made in the magazine business overseas. Europeans are still buying picture magazines like Stern and Paris Match and their counterparts in other countries. But in the United States, magazines are commissioning fewer photographs and relying on stock images.
"The magazine photography business as we have known it is in shambles," Mr. Pledge said. "Thank God for Time and Newsweek. Where would we be without them? They have replaced the old Life and Look."
Mr. Pledge used to view his business only in terms of photojournalism. But he now sees new opportunities for selling photographs to institutions for educational purposes.
"The economy looks promising and ready for technological and sociological changes," he said. "We are entering an era where the world is getting smaller, people are closer together, because of incredibly fast communication systems like TV.
"There are also more people than ever before -- two billion in the 1950's, when many photo agencies were starting up -- and there will be six billion by the end of the century. Population growth is also creating a whole new communications problem."
The French Government has already begun working on the dilemma, launching a new way of storing and using electronic still pictures. The new Grande Bibliotheque de France in Paris will have a collection of hundreds of thousands of still images when its first section opens in the fall of 1994. The image library will be catalogued so that it can be scanned electronically by researchers and others studying subjects like history and anthropology, and viewed at computer terminals. All sections of the library -- which will also store films, video and books -- are expected to be open by the spring of 1995.
There is hope that it might be possible to hook up libraries like the Grande Bibliotheque via modems to homes and to work stations in industry and schools, making visual information available to almost anyone, anywhere, almost instantly. The French Government plans to have a computer-based AIDS-prevention campaign -- still pictures with voice-over -- developed for young people and administered through the library.
Mr. Pledge said he believes that a still image can be more powerful than a moving image. "When everything is moving, it is harder to learn," he said. "There has to be a departure from normal motion, where time stands still, allowing a chance for reflection, analysis and interaction."
The screen should not be a substitute for a teacher, he continued, but a place where the educator can practice new methods of teaching.
"TV could become the savior of still photography," Mr. Pledge added. "It's an incredible venue for the still image. Still pictures can be placed on CD-ROM disks, opening the door to TV picture/book disks that can be published by the hundreds of thousands."
In Mr. Pledge's view, the switch from paper to electronics will offer a solution to the problem of shooting pictures for two weeks and having only one picture published on a quarter of a page. With the CD-ROM disks, there will be more room for images because of the opportunity to use audio narration instead of traditional printed text.
If Mr. Pledge is right, there's a new world -- and a more profitable one -- coming for both still photography and picture agencies.

SECTION: Section 13CN; Page 1; Column 5; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1370 words

HEADLINE: Taxes and Gambling Top Lawmakers' List

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
PICTURE the Connecticut General Assembly as a majestic cruise ship, ready to embark this week on a stately five-month legislative tour of informed debate and eloquent discourse. Now throw on the cold water and a truer picture emerges: a boatload of rookie lawmakers heading for a storm, with uncharted reefs on every side and a yawning budget deficit off the bow ready to swallow the unwary.
"It's going to be tough," said Representative Reginald L. Jones, a Republican from Darien. 
 The numbers tell part of the story: of 187 members in the combined House and Senate, 67 are new to their jobs, or about one in three -- the highest proportion of new faces since the middle of the 1970's. And while the Democrats remain in control in both chambers, their leaders are new and untested, at least in the House, having been named in just the last few weeks since the election.
And they will be tested.
The legislature's Office of Fiscal Analysis has projected a shortfall of $424 million for the fiscal year that begins on July 1 in a general fund budget of about $8 billion, assuming all state services were left intact and adjusted for inflation. Negotiating that gap, through cuts in spending -- and the likelihood of increased taxes for at least some residents -- will mean getting around a whirlpool of related issues that offer substantial challenge of their own, including the following.
* An overhaul of the income tax. Supporters, mostly Democrats, say the idea is to make the one-year-old tax fairer, since many upper-income residents now pay a smaller proportion of their income in taxes than middle-income families. But Republicans fear that the pressure of the budget could transform fairness into a major tax increase disguised as a technical revision.
* Gambling. This is the legislature's toughest issue, cutting across all lines, from aid to troubled cities like Bridgeport and Hartford, to the battered economy of southeastern Connecticut, where the Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe's Foxwoods casino has become a major employer since it opened last year. Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. has vowed to veto any bill legalizing slot machines or casinos off the reservation lands, but the new majority leader in the Senate, William A. DiBella, a Democrat from Hartford, is a staunch supporter of casino gambling and a skilled practitioner of the art of hardball legislative politics.
* A cap on state spending. In November voters approved, by a 79 percent majority, a plan to write into the state Constitution a limit on how much the state budget could grow in any one year. Lawmakers will now have the task of translating the meaning of that mandate -- in particular which categories of spending are exempt from the cap and which are covered. Will it be a loose-fitting cap with little impact or a tight-fitting design with real restrictions?
Many of those who track the ebb and flow of state politics say the pressures of budget-related issues, and the sense that perhaps the state's economy could begin to recover from the recession this year, will create an environment of limits, making the 1993 session a time of making do.
The high proportion of new members, some legislators say, will also dampen initiatives while lawmakers gain confidence and knowledge of how things get done. Mr. Weicker, who will give his State of the State speech before the combined House and Senate on Wednesday at noon, has not tipped his hand at all about what he will propose.
 
No Exotic Initiatives
 "This is not going to be a session of innovative and exotic legislative initiatives," said John J. Carson, president of the Connecticut Policy and Economic Council, a nonprofit research group that monitors state government. "They'll say, 'let's keep things intact, keep things moving along, don't ruffle feathers, and by the time we meet again, we'll have enough of an economic advance in hand to undertake some new initiatives.' "
But lawmakers could also be forced into making some major decisions on some issues. The broad agenda of recommendations about increasing the efficiency of state government, for instance, which emerged last year from a series of commissions and studies, is scheduled to begin gearing up in 1993, and some of those plans have plenty of potential for upheaval.
Under one proposal, a new super-agency, the Department of Social Services, would emerge as the existing Departments of Income Maintenance, Human Resources and Aging are combined under one commissioner. Another proposed merger would meld the Department of Health Services with the Alcohol and Drug Abuse Commission. In both cases, questions of political and bureaucratic turf promise to resound in deciding the new lines of authority, not to mention the picking out of who will still have jobs when the cutting is done.
 
New Sources of Power
 New dynamics and voting blocs also seem likely to emerge in considering those moves. Lawmakers from Bridgeport and Hartford, for example, the state's two largest cities, have risen to roles of greatly increased power and influence in this legislature. Mr. DiBella, the new Senate leader, is from Hartford, as is the new Speaker in the House of Representatives, Thomas D. Ritter, while the President pro tem of the Senate, John B. Larson, is from East Hartford. The delegation from Bridgeport, meanwhile, will have the leadership positions on at least 3 of the General Assembly's 23 standing committees.
"We're going to play a major role," said Representative Ernest E. Newton 2d, a three-term Democrat from Bridgeport who is the new House chairman of the Executive and Legislative Nominations Committee. Mr. Newton conceded that the city's new clout might not immediately translate into money for the troubled city, but it couldn't hurt. "Perception is power," he said.
Lawmakers from southeastern Connecticut, which is likely to face some of the greatest disruptions from the downturn in the United States military contracts over the next few years, have also banded together in a new voting block. The new caucus will likely be a major participant in debates about economic relief for displaced military-industry workers, and also on the subject of gambling, since the Foxwoods casino would likely be hurt by a major gambling expansion elsewhere in the state.
The new Representative from the town of Ledyard, home of the Foxwoods casino and many of its 3,000 employees, Mary K. McGrattan, said that she for one would not be "leaning toward legalizing gambling in Connecticut." Ms. McGrattan said she might support a bill allowing video slot machines where gambling was already permitted, in places like the jai alai frontons, and would like to pursue the notion of getting some tax revenue from the Mashantucket Pequots if and when slot machines were operating at their casino.
 
Municipal Backgrounds
 The leanings of other members of the new legislature are also being pondered. Many first-time lawmakers are former municipal leaders (Ms. McGrattan was the Mayor of Ledyard for eight years), and some legislative leaders said that members from such such backgrounds could create another new force on behalf of aid to local government.
And some lawmakers have small agendas of their own. For instance, Representative-elect Dominic A. Buonocore, a Republican from Branford, has already proposed a bill that would prohibit candidates for office in Connecticut from being listed on the ballot more than once. Scores of legislators, mostly Democrats, benefited in November from an endorsement by Mr. Wiecker's independent third party, A Connecticut Party, which controls the top ballot line.
Mr. Buonocore's bill would make that double listing impossible. Each candidate would instead be listed just once. "This act would create a ballot which is a lot less confusing than the one voters were faced with in November," he said.
But Mr. Buonocore would also seem to have a distinct personal interest in the matter. His opponent, Joseph Giordano, was listed twice, as a Democrat and a candidate of A Connecticut Party, and got a combined total of 5,335 votes on those two lines. Mr. Buonocore, listed just once, squeaked by with a margin of only 134 votes.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: January 3, 1993

SECTION: Section 13LI; Page 1; Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 4156 words

HEADLINE: L.I. Looks to Washington For Revival in '93

 BODY:
On Long Island, as elsewhere in the country, attention is focusing on Bill Clinton as the year begins. When Mr. Clinton takes office as President will he unleash an array of economic programs that will spur Long Island's economy or will whatever Federal help arrives serve just to complement the true engines of regional economic recovery? And, Mr. Clinton aside, is recovery in the cards for Long Island this year or do more hard months lie ahead?
A panel of three economists agreed that a recovery is on the way and may have already begun. And whatever money Washington injects into the regional economy, they said, will only make things better. 
 The panelists were Thomas Conoscenti, director of the graduate program in management at Polytechnic University in Farmingdale; Gary Huth, senior economist in the State Labor Department, and Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. At the request of the Long Island Weekly, the economists met for a discussion at The New York Times bureau in Garden City. The roundtable was conducted by John Rather.
 
The Forecast
 Q. As we enter 1993 what kind of shape is our regional economy in? Is recovery on the way or will this be another grim year?
MS. SCANLON Will Long Island have recovery in 1993? I think yes. And it's essentially from the income overflow out of New York City which is being accumulated by Wall Street.
Combine that with pent-up demand for housing, and by 1993 I expect we'll see more construction in housing. I expect to see much more public construction, everything that has been in the planning stages.
Consumer confidence is up generally, in the sense that there is a sea change under way. And I think that most people have paid down the worst of their debt at this point. So I think we will see more retail spending. So right there are the ingredients for a recovery.
Probably local government will still be a drag, and so you may not have a lot of job growth, but that will not be the best measure of economic activity. It really will be income flows, wage flows.
The second point I would make is that this probably will happen without the usual engine of growth on Long Island. The engine of growth that I see is really in New York City. It's Wall Street. And coming up behind Wall Street in terms of recovery are business services in New York, the big elements of advertising and accounting and management consulting and law. And there is a spillover effect on Long Island. And I think that if we worry about an engine of growth, then the state to look at is Texas. Because Texas has had its recovery without a particular engine of growth, which would have been oil, and has managed to get some sort of recovery, a diversified one, with its banking system in shambles. Jobs probably don't pay as much as they used to during the heyday of oil. But nonetheless, you look at the Texas economy, and it is in recovery.
There is a readjustment process under way in Long Island's manufacturing economy, and I presume we will see more of that.
 
Clinton's Role
 Q. Will Bill Clinton help Long Island or will the focus be elsewhere?
MS. SCANLON The Clinton program will help Long Island. It's early, but if on top of everything else I have said they follow through with what they said they would do, there will be spending on public works. There will be more spending on the environment, which could be very targeted toward Long Island, for coastal waters, ground water, sludge, garbage, the whole thing. I think that will be very favorable.
We stand a chance of getting some antirecession types of investments out of the Clinton Administration, which should help our metropolitan area and Long Island in the process. There will be job training and retraining, which will help Long Island.
And above all I think we will probably see some new attitude toward reconversion strategy, though that is still a little bit nebulous. But I do think we are going to see something over the course of the next two years. And up until now we have seen very little discussion. So if there is a peace dividend and a reconversion strategy, we stand a chance of seeing something in the next two years, and we should hopefully start to see some of that favorably affect Long Island in terms of more research and development dollars to come, whether it's at Cold Spring Harbor, Brookhaven or Stony Brook.
Looking at the intermediate term and my outlook in the 1990's, I do think that there will be growth. It will be slower compared to everything Long Island has seen for three and a half decades. And it will be a different type of job growth, different in the sense that the measurements will be different. They may no longer only be these great units of more jobs, more housing, more miles of highway, and then they go this way with lanes.
What we will count as economic growth in the 1990's for a place like Long Island is very different. We look much more at income distribution, purchasing, reinvestment. We will pay more attention to income generally and types of investment, income as it is swung back through to the public sector, the so-called quality of life, the quality of the environment. We will have to change our measuring structure.
We will begin to look at 1987 as being an unattainable level of growth. We will have to go back to some other measurement in the index that will become a more sensible way of measuring what constitutes growth.
 
Employment Picture
 Q. Are we entering recovery, particularly in terms of employment?
MR. HUTH It looks at this point like we have bottomed out, although not in any dramatic way. I do expect to see some slow, gradual improvement in 1993. I agree with Rosemary, in that I don't see dramatic employment growth. Even before this recession started, we talked about how it was going to be slowing down in terms of employment numbers.
The high point for Long Island was actually 1985 in terms of really dramatic growth. I think it was something like 54,000 jobs gained in 1985. That's not only not going to happen. There is really no need for that to happen, because there is not the population growth to sustain that.
The labor force has shrunk considerably. The number of people who are searching for jobs is down because of the slow population growth and the aging of the population -- fewer young people coming in. So we will be able to lower the unemployment rate more easily. Obviously we need job growth. But it will not have to be as dramatic as it has been in the past.
What is important, while I am on that subject, is training, and not just training for dislocated workers, but training that advances skill levels. We have a dramatically changing workplace, in terms of the technology, forcing dramatic changes both in terms of how products are made and how companies operate. There is a whole different culture in terms of how companies operate.
Some of what seemed to be kind of esoteric discussions two or three years ago is really starting to play out in business. The fact that things are done on a group basis, for instance, means there is a lot more decision making on the job. The type of skills that people need on the job are changing as the structure of business becomes much less hierarchical.
 
Job Training
 Q. Do you expect Federal support for the kind of training you are speaking of?
MR. HUTH Clinton talks about this. It's probably one of his main points. Aside from additional money, though, I think how things are done is going to be just as important.
I think the alliances between business and schools are going to tighten up considerably. I think there will be relationships between community colleges and business. I see those school-business alliances as being very important in terms of preparing people for the work climate.
Q. What types of jobs will they be preparing for?
Mr. HUTH Well, the advantage of Long Island's small-business structure is that it is adaptable. I think general services will continue to be probably the area where there is the largest job growth. But there will be other industries. Some in electronics, some in medical instruments, some in the broad category of information-related industries, where you can lump together things like Computer Associates in terms of software; Symbol Technologies in terms of bar-code scanning, Cablevision, fax machines. That's just a very inclusive area. Anything related to computers is going to be important.
If you talk about what skills people are going to need to train for, computer skills continue to be important. Critical-thinking skills, your ability to make your own decision on the job, that is important. Again, any kind of communication skills, both writing and verbal communication skills, those are very strong points. Math and science, obviously.
I think you will see a lot more people looking for people with an engineering background who will be in their marketing department. They will not just want midlevel managers who don't know what kind of product their company is producing. They will want people who have technical abilities. So people who have dual skills like that, that's important.
I might just add in terms of what is important about the Clinton Administration that Rosemary touched on is not just the infrastructure stimulants, but the research and development funds. It's very important for Long Island how these funds get distributed. That's the big if. It's very important that Long Island be preparing itself to make sure that it gets its appropriate disbursement.
Some of it should go to our research institutes, Cold Spring Harbor, the State University at Stony Brook, and we have also this year the formation of the Long Island Research Institute, a perfect vehicle. The institute is probably a model for things happening around the country.
I would certainly like to see the Clinton Administration take a nice chunk of money and take a role in plant conversion to civilian products. That's a crucial area.
MR. CONOSCENTI I am looking at the transition that is occurring, and I see the Computer Associates and the Canons wanting to stay on Long Island and other companies that are going to be coming down the pike as the kinds of companies that are replacing the heavily tied-in defense-related manufacturers.
I think sometimes we may say, well, we should do this, we should do that. But sometimes I have to think in terms of what these people are doing in those industries. Take the navigation industry, and all of that heavy navigational equipment was designed for defense. They would have certain kinds of magnetic bars on the top of a battleship, a plane would fly over, and it would give a reading as to what ship it was without ever having a direct communication. Well, in the shipping industry that's not important. You have Loran, telephones. So maybe that technology is just really not applicable to these other industries.
At Polytech I keep seeing these engineers that are coming back to school to be retrained into the management field. They don't want to stay in engineering. The way to climb the executive ladder in an engineering firm is to become section head, and then you become manager. What happens is that when you get a good engineer you make him section head, and if he is still a good engineer you make him a manager.
Then when you get to that point you have a problem. You lost a good engineer and you have a lousy manager. But yet they want to move out of that particular area.
Q. Out and up?
MR. CONOSCENTI Out and up, right. If you have an engineer who has been in the system for 25 years, and you say well you are a great design engineer and now on you can design navigational equipment for the defense industry. Do something with that technology that you learned, that you understand and you know well. But he doesn't have a market to do it, and so he is an aerospace engineer, and there is this kind of a mind-set. Well that's all I am, I'm a snake charmer. Period. And I don't want to move out. And we saw that with Grumman in the early 1980's with the bus company. It totally fell apart.
 
Grumman's Future
 Q. Mr. Conoscenti, what will be the role of Grumman in Long Island's economy?
MR. CONOSCENTI Grumman's role in the Long Island economy has been a planned role, although Grumman may not state it publicly. I think that they have in other parts of the country maintained a policy of not participating more than 10 percent in the local economy's labor force. And I think that Grumman will ultimately move in that direction here.
But the residual to that will be that the people who will be left here will be the high-tech-oriented types of people who are really involved in what I call the high-tech service-sector economy. We are talking about what Gary just alluded to, the Computer Associates types of people, programmers, systems analysts and those types of people who have an ability to export their knowledge to some other part of the country.
In the 70's the whole idea of an export-based economy was that we would manufacture a product, like a paper plate, and we can go to Texas and sell it and bring the income in. And we have forgotten about the knowledge industry, which we can sell our knowledge to another part of the country. I think Computer Associates, in effect, is that kind of a company. It sells a diskette, and someone else is selling it somewhere else in the country or parts of the world.
The economy, from where I have been looking at it for a couple of years, is like the letter "u" in 1992. It sort of fell down and got to the bottom of that "u," and it's been a long bottom. Now it's starting to pull itself back up now. I think we are going to see the result of that in maybe the first or second quarter of 1993. We will see some growth in 1993.
If we are lucky, and we do have some change in Federal policy -- say, for example, that Mr. Gore and his proposals for targeting high-tech industries go forward -- Long Island may be a beneficiary of those proposals, whatever they ultimately may be.
MR. HUTH Certainly we have the profile for it.
MR. CONOSCENTI We have the profile for it, and we have a lot of companies that were defense oriented that were in the transition between defense and consumer products or intermediate-industry products beginning in the mid-1970's right through to the present day. So those industries are profiled for it and will add a little zip to the region's economic base.
One point we mentioned earlier were retail sales. An area of retail sales that seems to be developing is seen if we look at the school industry on Long Island, a $4 billion industry. That's a lot of money. But if you look at the people served in kindergarten through 12th grades this last September, you have seen significant increases in those grade levels, which is a very strong indication that housing turnover has begun, that empty nesters are selling out their homes, and if these K through 12, and even pre-K, are starting to get filled up, they are the people who go out and buy the sneakers and the shirts and the jeans and whatever else helps move retail sales.
 
Family Income
 Q. And people who buy those goods are not using disposable income. Aren't they using income that they have to have to clothe the family?
MR. CONOSCENTI Right. That's a driving force in the system. The graying population doesn't need to buy sneakers every six months, because, you know, your son or daughter's foot gets bigger.
MR. HUTH But the graying population is putting their money into investments. That's their contribution. They are no longer the purchaser.
MR. CONOSCENTI Anyway, the accumulated wealth at that level is not that significant that it's going to make a major dent or be an impetus to the region's economy. But I am looking at the school-age population as being that which is driving.
If we look at the total numbers, yes, they are declining. But a lot of that has to do with the fact that in the 1970's you had zero-growth population trends. So all of those kids have just about filtered out of the system. By 1996, 1997, you are going to see a significant reversal in total school age population, which is going to upgrade the economy back out to the end of the century.
 
Educating Students
 Q . And then many of them will go to college on Long Island?
MR. CONOSCENTI A lot of them will go to college on Long Island. But I think there is a notion in the region that we should keep our students here. I'm not in favor of that. I think if a student wants to go to Kansas to study, that's his prerogative. We wind up with an exchange of people, and I think that's part of the mix.
What I am saying is that I saw this "u" in the economy as coming down and turning around, and I see 1993 with some growth in employment, primarily in the service sector. And I see some activity in construction. The projects that are on line haven't been able to get through, haven't been able to get through the towns. Whether it's a Canon or whether it's an Olympus, those projects are coming due. They are going to be pushed through the towns, and I think the towns, the local government, is being pressured to start making some decisions.
The pine barrens suit, whether we agree with what happened in the appellate court, the mere fact that now the cumulative environmental-impact statement is not required is going to shift the banking industry. The banking industry had sort of redlined that whole area. There were no funds available. If you wanted to borrow money, a developer, to develop 500 acres, in the eight years it was going to take you to get through the planning process, nobody wanted to tie up his funds for eight years, even on paper.
MR. HUTH One thing that we have not directly identified is the growth of the immigrants in New York City and the potential of that, if past patterns continue, to move out to Long Island. And that's a potential positive area in terms of spurring residential construction and the housing market.
 
New Immigrants
 Q . Long Island has had a major surge of immigrants in the last three to five years. Some are working at the lowest level, landscaping and restaurants and so on. Will there be more?
Mr. HUTH It may take a little longer to percolate out, but in New York City, you look in certain areas of Queens, some of the immigrants are owning businesses. They are already getting themselves off the ground. And those people will eventually move to the suburbs.
Q. What missed opportunities or underuse do you observe in Long Island's economic picture?
MS. SCANLON There are a couple of opportunity areas where the Long Island economy is really underdeveloped. One is the whole area of exports. It doesn't matter whether it is exports of goods or of services. Long Island can play a much different role in reaching out.
The second area that seems to me that remains largely undeveloped on Long Island is its tourist business. Only 17 percent of the visitors in 1992 came from "other," meaning some place outside of the metropolitan area.
In the future Long Island could become a place where European visitors or Japanese visitors could come. So there is a whole area that is quite underdeveloped. The infrastructure, the hotel complexes, simply doesn't exist here as it exists other places.
MR. CONOSCENTI If you look at the correlation between Disney World, every time they built a new hotel the tourist industry declined. On Long Island, the way they define tourism is not like in Orlando. If you're from New York and go to Orlando or Miami, you are a tourist. But if you live in Nassau County and you go to Montauk, are you a tourist?
MS. SCANLON Well, they do have the category of visitor. But the point I am trying to make here is I think that it is a largely underdeveloped industry that reaches out to a larger market worldwide. They don't have beaches like Long Island's many places.
MR. CONOSCENTI But most of the beaches on Long Island, except for Fire Island and Jones Beach, are all private beaches, which has been a major problem for the tourist industry.
MS. SCANLON It's about to become public, and that was the point I was going to make.
The other point is a longer term. Once we get out of this recession, and it will end, then I don't think it will be long before the discussion on Long Island will go back to focusing on the cost of growth and what will be possible in terms of making the island livable. And a graying population with more money is the population that drives that discussion. The discussions of growth, the issues of water quality, of what to do with garbage and pollution in the bays and in the ocean.
MR. HUTH That could spur an environmental industry, also.
MS. SCANLON It spurs a whole new set of industries. And there are real issues to be solved as I understand it, ground water, for instance.
And if that recent storm was not the 100-year storm, but the second or third year in a row of major storms, then we will enter a very different public discussion about what must be done. Is it a flight or flood strategy?
 
Political Realities
 Q. Do you think the public officials we have on Long Island are up to considering these issues, these problems in the next five years?
MR. CONOSCENTI . At the town level the public officials are equipped to deal with those issues. The next generation of public officials will be. But in many towns and villages we still have the old-line politicians who worked their way up through the party.
I think on the county level there are people who are trying to change policy and have the wherewithal. Their time will come due in the next years or three years. In Nassau County, Mr. Gulotta, the County Executive, seems to be having a lot of problems. Whoever runs against him, should he win, would be a different type of a politician. I think we are going to see the next generation arrive in the mid-1990's with the kind of politicians that will develop and nurture good ideas.
MR. HUTH I think there has been some awakening among the local officials in terms of the depth of the problems and some of the things that need to be done. The economic-development things I mentioned earlier.
But I think that that process is nowhere near finished. I don't know whether the old guard is adapting rapidly enough or whether they will need to be replaced by kind of a new mind-set, and I wouldn't comment on the politicians per se. But I think that change has to be there.
People are now much more attuned to following these economic issues. They know more about the economy now, they follow what goes on.
 
Extending Bank Credit
 Q. Do you think bank regulations will be liberalized so there is greater lending?
MR. CONOSCENTI The banks got themselves into a bind nationally with a lot of development in real estate.
Q. Then the Government tightened the regulations. The question is are we coming out on the other side of that?
MS. SCANLON Banks did two things this year. One, they had to restore their profit rate. They went practically out of the banking business and they went into Treasury instruments. That's what they've done in 1992. Buying low short term, they are paying 2.5 percent on interest and just making money of the spread.
MR. HUTH Anything wrong with that? It's very profitable.
MS. SCANLON It's been very profitable. It also means we start 1993 in a whole new situation. If the banks don't loan for mortgages, there will be new intermediaries in the market. The mortgage market is a national market.
And the construction-loan market and the loan market will come from some place else. This is one business where water finds it level very quickly. If the small business wants money, it's going to get it some place.
MR. CONOSCENTI You are saying the profitability of the banks in 1993 will be significantly stronger, which will provide an impetus, capital, in the market place? And maybe some form of deregulation in the banking industry?
MS. SCANLON Why do you use the term deregulation? All you are doing is lifting this little bind, this little collar that has been on it. It's not a major problem.
But if the economy recovers, actually we are in an interesting situation in 1993 in this country. There will be more money in search of investment than immediate investment opportunities. Which should begin to lower the long-term rate of interest.
MR. CONOSCENTI Interest rates are already low.
MS. SCANLON It's the long term. That's the one that counts right now. Short-term interest rates are going to go up a little bit. But can you bring that long-term interest rate down from the Treasury bills from 7.4 percent? Can you get that down to 7 and 6.8? That's the one that's going to make a major difference in the housing market and in the investment market.

HEADLINE: Scouts Debating Potential Land Sale

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

 BODY:
TWENTY-FIVE years ago, William O. Field, an ardent environmentalist and director of exploration for American Geographic Magazine, found the perfect buyer for his 1,400 acres of wilderness in Putnam County.
Although state officials wanted the site to add to their adjacent parkland, Mr. Field chose the Boy Scouts of America and gave them a reduced price because the Scouts promised him that the land would remain forever wild. 
 Now Scout leaders in Westchester and Putnam Counties say their own organization has betrayed them, and Mr. Field agrees. More than 500 Scout leaders, supported by a coalition of environmental groups, are trying to persuade the Westchester-Putnam Boy Scout Council to rescind its decision to sell the property, known as the Clear Lake Reservation, to a developer who wants to build a golf course and convention center.
Opponents say they are concerned about potential damage to Clear Lake, which is said to have unusually pure water, and they say they are worried about the threat to the nearby Wiccopee Reservoir, the only source of water for Peekskill.
 
A $4.5 Million Offer
 The property's wetlands and steep slopes, they say, make it unsuitable for development in any case.
The Boy Scout Council has temporarily tabled its plan to sell the property in order to give the Open Space Institute, an Ossining-based land-preservation organization, time to study the proposal, but opponents say they fear the financially strapped Boy Scout Council will be unable to resist the offer of $4.5 million from International Design and Construction of Garrison, an offer three times higher than the property's appraised value.
The offer, contingent on receiving a three-year option, would give the developer time to assess the feasibility of building the golf course and convention center and time to invite investment from other developers. One company that has been asked to join the investment group is Tully Construction of Flushing, Queens, which is seeking approval to build a sludge plant three miles away.
Opponents argue that the Scouts not only should be honor bound to protect the open space but should also heed their legal obligation. "This is a clear violation of the previous owner's intent," said Martin Brech, chairman of the Putnam County Tree Advisory Commission and a member of the Clear Lake Coalition, the citizens group formed to challenge the development plan.
 
A Distrust of the State
 Mr. Field agreed. "This proposed sale is contrary both to my intent when I agreed to sell the land to the Boy Scouts in 1968 rather than to the State of New York, but also it is contrary to the intent of the Boy Scouts when they negotiated with me to buy Clear Lake," the ailing geologist wrote to the Boy Scout Council.
In his letter, Mr. Field claimed that the Scouts promised that the land "would remain forever wild," and he said the organization further agreed, "if it were ever necessary to sell the property, New York State would receive right of first refusal." That condition was written into the deed.
Last week, Peter H. McCallion, a principal in the development company and its lawyer, said the offer to purchase the property would be withdrawn, although he had not yet informed the scouting organization. "We just learned of this potential title problem," he said. "Apparently, the Boy Scouts don't have the right to sell the property until they offer it to the state." He added that the state has a year to respond to an offer by the Scouts.
Although Clear Lake Reservation is bordered on three sides by Fahnestock State Park, Mr. Field said he had feared that the state would not be able to prevent development of the property. He had disapproved of a public beach that the state permitted at the end of Canopus Lake in Fahnstock State Park.
Spokesmen for the Boy Scout Council in White Plains were on vacation last week and the national organization in Irving, Tex., said it was unfamiliar with the details of the plan, but local Boy Scout Council leaders have made their position clear in letters to the membership. Sale of the property would finally end years of worry about "the financial ability of the council to properly maintain and operate its camping programs," wrote P. Paul Nardone, Scouting Executive for the Westchester-Putnam Council. He added that the governing body had approved the sale of Clear Lake by a 2-to-1 margin.
 
Scout Principles at Issue
 The Boy Scout Council owns two other camps in addition to Clear Lake, including Siwanoy in Dutchess County and Camp Read in the Adirondacks. Three years ago, a special task force was appointed to evaluate which camp to sell in order to raise funds to maintain and improve the other two. Camp Siwanoy was offered for sale, but it attracted little interest from potential buyers and an outcry from local environmental groups. Last summer, the offer for the Clear Lake Property arrived.
"Economic times have changed over the years, and Scout councils simply cannot afford to do business as they have in the past," Mr. Nardone wrote local Scout units. "Selling a camp is never an easy decision for anyone to make," he added. "Clear Lake is a beautiful piece of property, but unfortunately as our world changes, we must keep pace."
Some things must never change, outraged Scout leaders replied, arguing that the proposed sale contradicts cherished scouting principles. They point to "Scouting for Boys," the scouting manifesto written by Lord Robert Baden-Powell, who founded the organization in England in 1908 and created the Scout oath.
"Camping is the joyous part of a Scout's life," Lord Baden-Powell wrote, adding, "Living out in God's open air, among the hills and the trees, and the birds and the beasts, and the sea and the rivers -- that is, living with nature, having your own little canvas home, doing your own cooking and explorations -- all this brings health and happiness such as you can never get among the bricks and smoke of the town."
 
'It Can't Be Replaced'
 Save Our Camps, the organization of Scoutmasters and leaders formed to prevent the sale of Clear Lake Reservation or any of the Boy Scout Council's other camping properties, said Clear Lake has particular significance.
"This is 1,400 acres of wilderness," said Jack Palmer, co-chairman of Save Our Camps. "It can't be replaced." No other site in the region allows campers to live so close to nature, Mr. Palmer said. "We are terribly upset our Council has decided to sell our camping property. We are dead set against selling any of our camps."
In November, a second organization, the Clear Lake Coalition, a 30-member group of environmentalists and neighborhood opponents, joined the fight and threatened to picket Boy Scout Council headquarters in White Plains unless scouting executives agreed to meet with the two coalitions.
 
Jeers and Shouts
 The meeting was held two weeks ago, but it accomplished little, said Bill Primavera of Yorktown, one of the participants. He added that the meeting ended in a chorus of jeers and shouts.
At its monthly meeting on Jan. 25, the Boy Scout Council will hear arguments from the two groups urging them to rescind their decision. A 90-day period for the Open Space Institute to complete its evaluation expires on Feb. 20.
"You can be sympathetic to the Boy Scouts," said Peter Borrelli, executive vice president of the Open Space Institute. "When you have got your back to the wall, you do things that are not entirely rational." He added that although the Scouts had been handed the opportunity to sell the property, "they stopped short when they realized the value of the camping at Clear Lake."

HEADLINE: Westchester, the World's 'Golf Capital,' May Get a New Course

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON

 BODY:
DESPITE its belt tightening on other issues, the County Board of Legislators has voted unanimously to authorize $515,000 in bonds for planning a new golf course next to the county-run Mohansic Golf Course in Yorktown Heights. The new course, which would become the county's sixth public course, is expected to cost $10 million and must be approved by voters in a referendum next November.
Andrew A. Albanese of Eastchester, the Board's majority leader, said the new course would be "a great thing for Westchester County" and vowed to campaign for it. "Our golf courses make money for the county," Mr. Albanese said, adding that Westchester "has always been known as the golf capital of the world." The game was introduced more than 100 years ago at St. Andrew's Golf Club in Hastings-on-Hudson. 
 The bond money will cover survey costs, environmental studies and reviews and architectural and engineering design work. The proposed course, which will include an 18-hole course, a 9-hole course, a driving range and a clubhouse, will be built on 400 acres that the county has owned for several decades. Barry Samuel, acting Commissioner of the County Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation, said the land had been purchased with an eye to building an additional course some day.
 
Fastest-Growing Sport in County
 Mr. Samuel said a market analysis by the National Golf Foundation of Jupiter, Fla., had confirmed the need for a sixth course. Calling golf "the fastest-growing sport in the county," Mr. Samuel said 280,000 rounds were played on county courses last year, but that there was an "unmet demand" for thousands more rounds.
Herman Keith, the Democratic minority leader of the Board of Legislators, said he believed a new golf course was needed and that he did not view spending for recreation as "taking money away from the homeless or teen-age pregnancy programs" that serve the poor in his Yonkers district. He added, however, that he hoped the county would be as aggressive in pursuing solutions to homelessness and other problems associated with poverty as it was in acquiring parklands and creating recreational spaces. "You can't live on golf courses," he said.
There are 26 private golf courses in Westchester, most of which charge high membership fees. Fees for playing on county courses range from $12 to $40 a game, depending on the day of the week and whether the player holds a recreation pass. Adele Dowling, public information officer for the Parks Department, said there had been some discussion of allowing a private developer to operate a new course on the land, but this idea had been rejected. "We thought it would be a viable investment for Westchester County," she said.
The new Mohansic course would be the first built by the county in 62 years. Other county-run courses are Dunwoodie and Sprain Lake in Yonkers, Maple Moor in White Plains and Saxon Woods in Scarsdale. Saxon Woods was the last one built, in 1931. Dunwoodie was acquired by the county in 1957.
 
Social vs. Recreational Needs
 Local golfers, who have waited on long lines to play on county courses, have applauded the Board's plan. Augie DeSisto, an avid player who uses the Mohansic course, described sleepless nights waiting to sign up for the most desirable playing times on weekend mornings. "I've been there at 2 A.M. to get a decent time to play the next day," the Ossining resident said. "I've been there 12 straight hours to play a round of golf that lasts 4 or 5 hours."
John Ioris, who owns the Complete Golfer in White Plains, said that despite the recession, his shop had been selling equipment to first-time players and had had a good Christmas season. "The primary hindrance to the growth of the sport," he said, "is the lack of facilities on which to play. The county courses are terribly overcrowded. The county can use several more."
But Frank Squire, who plays in a foursome Saturdays at Dunwoodie, has his doubts about spending for a new golf course. "As a golfer, I absolutely feel we should have a new course," the White Plains resident said. "As a citizen, I'm not that certain. We have social problems that should be taken care of. Whether they outweigh recreational problems depends on where you're sitting."

HEADLINE: Auguring Well;
This Time They Really Mean It

 BODY:
Another year, another attempt to erase the deficit. It has already avoided the knives of Messrs. Gramm, Rudman and Hollings twice, as well as Presidential blades. Fiscal 1993, already under way, is heading toward a deficit of more than $300 billion.
 
Surplus by 1984
 
 Reagan's first budget: March 1981
 During the campagin, Ronald Reagan has promised a balanced Federal budget by fiscal year 1983. But his first budget proposal didn't attempt to predict one until fiscal 1984. It anticipated surpluses after that.

Deficit Gone by 1991
 
Gramm-Rudman-Hollings I: November 1985
 Congress took matters into its own hands. Under the new law, if the budget deficit did not meet a set of shrinking targets, automatic spending cuts would take effect. The goals weren't met, but the Supreme Court took everyone off the hook by declaring the key enforcement tool, automatic cuts imposed by the White House, unconstitutional.

Deficit Gone by 1993
 
Gramm-Rudman-Hollings II: September 1987
 Another, constitutional version. Congress hoped to force Mr. Reagan to agree to a tax hike. He refused, so Congress went ahead, cutting from the military and shifting expenses to meet the first year's target. Subsequent years would be the next President's headache.

Deficit Halved by 1994
 
George Bush's first budget: March 1989
 Even after assuming a rosy growth in the economy and cuts in spending, Bush and Congress had to juggle the books to get this first budget in line.

Deficits Cut by $500 Billion in 5 Years
 
Deficit, reduction agreement: October 1990
 After President Bush submitted a budget for fiscal 1991 that predicted a deficit of $64.7 billion, the Congressional Budget Office came back with an estimate of more that twice that size. In the final agreement, Congress bowed to some spending cuts and Bush broke his "no new taxes" pledge. They managed to trim $500 billion off five years' worth of deficits. But increasing expenses, especially for entitlements, and lower estimates of future tax revenues kept the situation looking grim.

HEADLINE: Business Diary

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Dawn at Last for a Troubled Economy
Recessions are like colds. They may linger a while, sufferers may curse them, but sooner or later they do get better. According to the Commerce Department's index of leading indicators, released last week, the economy's fever has all but passed. The index rose 0.8 percent in November, its second straight monthly advance and its largest gain in 10 months. The index forecasts economic activity six to nine months hence. Its increase "is a very convincing sign that a self-sustaining economic expansion is under way," said Norman Robertson, chief economist at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. Together with other recently released indicators, it means the prospects are good for gross domestic product "to grow at between 2.5 percent and 3 percent for 1993 without any fiscal stimulus," he said. That's good news for the nation's business leaders. Which industries will fare best in 1993? "The capital goods sector, primarily computers and high-technology goods. The strong upswing in spending will also mean a pickup in the industrial equipment sector." 

Awesome. Of Coke and Calories.
For a decade now, the Coca-Cola Company has been been hocking Diet Coke with the same slick slogan: "Just for the Taste of It." In advertising years, that's a millennium. But last week Diet Coke said it would soon fill the airwaves with two new raps: "Taste It All" and "One Awesome Calorie," written by the Lintas New York agency. The old slogan -- whose number is being retired -- was a favorite among the Coca-Cola cognoscenti. Not only did it help propel low-cal Coke to No. 1 among sugar-free brands, it also changed how people feel about the stuff. "One of the all-time greats," said Renee Frengut, president of Market Insights Inc. in Bronxville, N.Y., a market consulting firm. The slogan broadened the drink's appeal and changed the perception that sugar-free sodas were "only for ladies on a diet," she said.
 
What Does the Air Force Want?
In round one, the Compuadd Corporation of Austin, Tex., scored what seemed like a KO by winning the contract to sell 300,000 personal computers to the Air Force. But then Zenith Data Systems, a unit of France's Groupe Bull, coaxed the old Palooka-of-a-contract off the mat by saying the Air Force had not given it enough time to fine tune its bid. That was enough to get the Air Force to rescind Compuadd's contract -- worth $740 million -- and give it to Zenith. Round two was last week, when Compuadd and several other companies protested the Air Force's change of heart, saying Zenith had not given it "best value." After reviewing Zenith's award, the General Services Administration handed the contract back to Compuadd. Zenith did not use enough American parts, the G.S.A. said.. Groupe Bull's Paris spokesman said his company was "shocked," by the ruling.
 
The Canadian-American Skies
They are not exactly clones -- money-losing American Airlines, an industry giant, and money-losing Canadian Airlines International Ltd., an industry small fry. Still, there are synergies. Enough to lure American into taking a $194 million stake in the Canadian carrier. Canadian Airlines will use the cash to acquire new technology. The deal gives American a 25 percent voting interest in the Canadian company and comes with a 20-year contract to help Canadian Airlines with accounting and data processing. American expects to make about $2 billion over the life of the contract. The deal will enable American to expand its airline service business -- a profitable niche in a money-losing industry.
 
Fill-Her-Up Fares
What the airline industry loses on each seat -- thanks to the air-fare wars -- it tries to make up in volume. Why else would seat prices remain cheap with the industry so deeply in the red? That good-for-consumer, bad-for-the-industry strategy is not about to end. Northwest Airlines said last week that it would extend for three months fare cuts to Europe of up to 43 percent. Why continue the cut-rate tickets? "Too many seats," said Candace E. Browning, an analyst with Merrill Lynch.
 
Outsourcing to I.B.M.
Move over Queen Elizabeth II, it was a pretty horrible year for the International Business Machines Corporation too. But unlike the royal family, Big Blue received at least a little cheer at the end of 1992. In one of the largest outsourcing deals ever, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the military and commercial contractor, said it would turn over most of its information and telephone services to I.B.M.'s Integrated Systems Solutions Corporation. The deal -- worth $3 billion over 10 years -- would turn over McDonnell's in-house systems along with 1,450 staff members to I.B.M. McDonnell Douglas said the deal makes sense because it "eliminates the need for ongoing investment in an area that is peripheral to our core aerospace business," said Herbert Lanese, McDonnell Douglas's chief financial officer.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
U.S. Chips a No-Sale in Tokyo
Once he is confirmed, Mickey Kantor, President-elect Bill Clinton's choice for United States trade representative, will have his hands full over the problem of chips -- the silicon variety. In 1991, Japan promised to open its markets to American semiconductors. Negotiators agreed that American companies could have 20 percent of the Japanese market. American suppliers haven't come close. Worse, according to Carla A. Hills, the current trade representative, America's share of the Japanese market actually fell to 15.9 percent in the third quarter from 16 percent the quarter before. What can Mr. Kantor do? Not much under the aggreement. The negotiators failed to include provisions for sanctions if Japan's chip buying fell short.
Making it all even murkier, Mr. Kantor may have to recuse himself from the chip crunching because of a conflict of interest. His Los Angeles law firm, Mannatt, Phelps, Phillips & Kantor, registered with the Justice Department as a paid agent of the NEC Corporation, one of Japan's largest producers of semiconductors.
 
Japan's Enduring Trade Edge
Although its economy is in a slump, Japan's trade balance is still the envy of the world. According to the Ministry of Finance, Japan's current account surplus, the broadest measure of trade in goods and services, surged nearly 50 percent in November to $10.45 billion from $7.05 billion in November 1991. Exports increased by 0.7 percent over last year, but imports were down 5.7 percent, reflecting corporate reluctance to spend in a recession. Don't expect Japan's surplus to shrink anytime soon. A report by the Nikko Research Center Ltd., in Tokyo said there would not be "any significant change in the trend in the trade surplus."
 
Israel Thinks to Sell Its Phones
Technically, Israel has a Socialist government. Socialist governments favor large, state-owned enterprises -- or at least they once did. These days even the Socialists want to sell off Government property, even phones. Last week, the Southwestern Bell Corporation, an American regional telephone company, and Israel's Clal Industries Ltd., a high-tech conglomerate, said they would jointly bid for control of Israel's national telephone company, Bezeq. Abraham Shohat, the Israeli Finance Minister and a Socialist, recommended this month that the Government sell its 75 percent share in the Bezeq telephone monopoly. No price has been set.
 
It's G.M., or Isuzu, or Both
When Isuzu Motors Ltd., said it would stop making passenger cars to concentrate on sport utility vehicles, the General Motors Corporation thought it was the loser. Isuzu -- which is partly owned by G.M. -- produces several cars in G.M.'s Geo line. But when Isuzu said it would allow the Honda Motor Company to sell 20,000 sport utility vehicles each year under the Honda name, Isuzu dealers though they were the losers because they would now have to compete with Honda. But hile Isuzu dealers pine, quality-conscious Honda may not be happy for long. According to a recent study by J.D. Power and Associates, the automobile consulting firm, the Isuzu Rodeo, which Honda will sell, had considerably higher defects per 100 vehicles than the industry average.
 
Layoffs -- in China?
Britain -- the original site of capitalism's Satanic Mills -- may have closed coal pits last year and made plans to let 30,000 miners go, but China? The Worker's State? Last week China laid off 100,000 coal workers, and there were reports that as many as 400,000 more workers would be dismissed over the coming years. The reason for China's capitalist-style cutbacks are the same as those given by Britain's Conservative Party: at today's prices the mines are not economic. The Government said its layoff plans were still being formulated. "We'd like to do these things," said Tan Enli, a director in the Energy Minister.
 
THE ECONOMY
 
The Confident Consumer
Talk about warm and fuzzy feelings about the President-elect. Since the election, the Conference Board's Index of Consumer Confidence has been rising smartly. It climbed to 78.3 in December, from 65.5 in November. (The index was 100 in 1985.) The Conference Board also said its Index of Consumer Expectations -- which measures how confident consumers are about the future -- jumped to 104.5 from 85.7 in November. Last January, the expectations index sat nervously at 68.7. Since confident consumers are more likely to part with their cash than gloomy ones, the rise in consumer confidence could foreshadow increased economic growth. "An increase of such dimension in so brief a time period generally foreshadows significant improvement in the nation's economic performance," said Fabian Linden, head of the Conference Board's Consumer Research Center.
 
Existing Homes on a Sales Roll
Finally, a little pep in the existing home market. The National Association of Realtors said last week that sales of existing homes surged 5.8 percent in November to the highest level since 1986. The adjusted resale rate for November was 19.2 percent above the level of 3.23 million units a year ago. The upturn coincided with a November rise in interest rates on 30-year mortgages to 8.31 percent from 8.09 percent the month before. "Many decided to buy after seeing a spike in interest rates during a time of economic recovery," said William Chee, president of the relators association.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 10, 1993, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A report in the Business Diary column last Sunday about the Compuadd Corporation, Zenith Data Systems and the competition to win a contract to sell the Department of Defense 300,000 computers for use by the Air Force misstated the outcome of the latest round. No award was made. The report also misstated the date of a protest by Compuadd and other companies. It was in September.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TICKER: KO (NYSE) (82%); BULL (PAR) (80%); BK (NYSE) (57%);

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: January 3, 1993
Correction Appended

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 1794 words

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2

 BODY:
Sure, it all seems beguiling now.
All the lively chat about infrastructure and all the intense seminars on spiritual renewal. The slow jogging and fast-food binges, the lip curls and love handles, the New Age networking and the his-and-hers Presidential file boxes full of holiday homework. 
 This is the time of cuddling, coddling and cooing, that brief, heady respite when Americans treat their new President like a newborn babe, regarding every word and step and smile as wondrous. Past sins are forgiven; future sins are unthinkable.
 
A Magazine Elevation
 Time magazine, which put a spooky-looking negative photograph of Bill Clinton on the cover last spring with the tag line "Why Voters Don't Trust Clinton," this week celebrates him as "Man of the Year" with the headline "The Torch Is Passed" and a tone of dizzy worship:
"Clinton's campaign, conducted with dignity, with earnest attention to issues and with an impressive display of self-possession under fire, served to rehabilitate and restore the legitimacy of American politics and thus, prospectively, of government itself."
It would be considered churlish to recall any low points of the Democrat's campaign now. The Clintons, after all, should savor this hour of splendor in the grass and glory in the power. Those who have enjoyed it in the past can testify that it is fleeting. As the maxim goes: "We make our arches out of brick so that after the leader passes through we have something to throw at him."
"America has a manic-depressive cycle with its leaders," said Michael Beschloss, a historian who has studied the Presidency, "and it's a bad thing, because it inevitably sets these Presidents up for a terrible fall.
"For the first 90 days or so, this is a Superman; we tend to find a virtue in every defect. Then, suddenly, there's a pardon of Richard Nixon or a Bay of Pigs, and we're disillusioned."
As soon as a President makes an unpopular decision or pushes a difficult program, a fickle public begins to find a defect in every virtue. And the very same qualities that once charmed can begin to grate.
"In the beginning, Jimmy could do no wrong stylistically," recalled Gerald Rafshoon, President Carter's media adviser. "But then after he made his first hard speech on energy conservation, people began to say, 'What is this thing with the sweater?' "
But that new breeze is blowing again, and among journalists, Democratic job seekers and social savants seeking access to the era of Fleetwood Mac and Big Macs, 'tis the season to be fawning.
 
Reborn Clinton Supporters
 In Washington, the number of cars with Clinton-Gore bumper stickers has grown noticeably since the election. Revisionism about his campaign has set in: just about everything he did is now described as brilliant, even things that received mixed reviews at the time, like his saxophone turn on Arsenio Hall's show.
And in this winter of content, it is now held that America is fortunate to be getting a strong-willed career woman as First Lady and First Adviser, and that the Clintons have gone from having a troubled marriage to a model one.
A panoply of influential journalists were eager to get the hottest ticket in town: an invitation to the Renaissance Weekend in Hilton Head, S.C., not to cover Mr. Clinton but to share intimacies with him in panel discussions closed to the working press -- even though they had to take vow of silence about what the President-elect said in the presence of 1,500 guests.
One who attended, Wolf Blitzer, the CNN White House correspondent, said it was worth the trade-off: "I think there's a difference between becoming friends with someone and attending something that allows you to get a greater perspective on what a person you're covering is like."
Even Mr. Clinton, who struggled with image problems in the campaign, has occasionally seemed abashed at the transition rapture. At the Little Rock economic conference, Robert Kuttner, an economic columnist, told the President-elect: "This has to be the defining moment of your Presidency. It is the President as leader, as explainer, as synthesizer. This is a magical moment and I thank you for including me and for offering this to the country."
To which Mr. Clinton replied, "I hope that doesn't mean it's all downhill from here."
 
Millie and Socks
 And that is precisely the danger.
The vote for President is the most personal of all votes, and Americans are possessive and judgmental about Presidents in the same way they are about movie stars.
"I used to say the White House theme song should be 'Riding high in April, shot down in May,' " said Sig Rogich, President Bush's image adviser for most of the first term. "But it's more like 'Riding high at 8 o'clock, shot down at 9.' "
During the Bush transition in 1988, Mr. Bush's aerobic rounds of sports were seen as evidence that he was a graceful athlete and an energetic leader who would not follow his predecessor's example and sleep through a world crisis. After a couple of years, however, many Americans began to regard these same scenes as a metaphor for a President who had lost touch, a Yankee squire zooming around in a gas-guzzling speedboat in the middle of a war over oil and golfing his way through the recession.
"My advice for the President-elect is to only play golf at night," said Marlin Fitzwater, Mr. Bush's spokesman. "They love Mr. Clinton in the golf cart. I remember when they loved George Bush in the golf cart, until it came to election time, and then that was seen as a distraction and an inability to focus."
Or consider the relative fates of Socks the Cat and Millie the Dog.
"The same photographers who are fawning all over Socks were fawning all over Millie and her pups four years ago," Mr. Fitzwater said. "Now the journalists don't like Millie anymore because they said she chased a squirrel at some event a few months ago and they wanted the Humane Society to come in and find out if Millie was killing squirrels.
"My warning to the Clintons is this: It's just a matter of time before Socks is accused of manhandling the mice in the White House."
 
Ford Was Charming, Until . . .
 Even men who left the Oval Office castigated as milquetoasts and villains had cuddly debuts.
The press was charmed when the new President, Gerald R. Ford, toasted his own English muffins and picked up his newspaper from the driveway. "Ford's Easy Manner Charms Hill," proclaimed a headline in The Washington Star. Then the pardon of Richard M. Nixon shifted the prism and made those same qualities look pallid and un-Presidential.
In "The Making of the President 1968," Theodore White wrote of the "transformation" of Richard Nixon from "the impulsive, wrathful man of the 1950's, so eager for combat and lustful for vengeance, to the man in the White House, cautious and thoughtful, intent on conciliation."
Just as the public has extreme mood swings about their President, so it swings back and forth on what qualities it wants in a President. In politics as in romance, those qualities are often simply the opposite of the ones that bothered people the last time around.
After the stolid Dwight D. Eisenhower, Americans were drawn to John F. Kennedy's youth and flair. But before long, critics began to worry about his ability to lead the nation. "There is a vague feeling of doubt and disappointment about President Kennedy's first term," James Reston wrote in a column in The New York Times on Nov. 15, 1963. "He has touched the intellect of the country but not its heart. He has informed but not inspired the nation."
After Kennedy's death, the nation began to see Lyndon B. Johnson's high-pressure sales tactics and craftiness as virtues that would allow him, in the wake of the tragedy, to "grab the wheel of government and make it go," as a Johnson aide, Harry McPherson, put it.
But when the nation grew disappointed with Johnson, the same qualities were reviled. "His big nose, the way he pulled his dog up by the ears, his showing his abdominal scar -- suddenly he was seen as a fixer, not a leader, an uncouth politician, not a statesman," Mr. McPherson said.
 
From Cardigans to Pageantry
 Americans expelled Mr. Carter, fed up with his cardigans and his frugality and his "de-pomping," as his aides put it. Hugh Sidey of Time magazine wrote that the easygoing Ronald Reagan was repainting the rundown White House and returning "dignity" and "pageantry" to "a nation that craves it."
(The fact that the fawning season lasted longer for Mr. Reagan than it did for most Presidents may hold a cautionary note for Mr. Clinton: the ancient-king model seems to wear better with Americans than the downhome-populist model.)
But eventually, as many Americans grew disgusted with the Reagan era's excesses, the less regal George and Barbara Bush seemed refreshing. Mr. Bush even modestly changed the Presidential signature from the front to the back of the souvenir White House tie tack.
Where the public liked Mr. Bush at first because he seemed far more engaged in policy than the detached Mr. Reagan, they turned to Mr. Clinton because he seemed far more engaged in domestic policy than the detached Mr. Bush.
The same image pendulum will most likely affect Mr. Clinton at some point.
Either when the new President makes some hard decisions or when he fails to, people may begin to chafe at his long-windedness or his permanent campaign or his insider ways or his desire to please everyone or his tortured tangos with interest groups. They might grow tired of his populist festivals, just as they did with Mr. Carter's.
Past and present White House officials suggest that all this first-act attention tends to give leaders a false sense that they are invulnerable.
"Jimmy Carter was no fool, and the guys around him were not naive," said Hodding Carter, a Carter Administration official. "But even so, at the moment it's going on, for that one little minute it lasts, you do sort of think: 'I don't need a boat. I shall cross the Potomac, and I won't sink beneath the waves.' It's human nature."
Clinton staffers say they know that the current mood has all the staying power of champagne.
"I came back to Washington after working for Michael S. Dukakis in 1988 and I was a knucklehead," said Mark Gearan, the deputy transition director. "I came back in 1992 and I was a genius. It makes you realize there are centrifugal forces beyond our control. I guess one is always a knucklehead-in-training."
Skip Rutherford, an old friend of the Clintons who works in the Little Rock transition office, agreed: "We know spring doesn't last year round. We realize there will be some cold, windy days out there. But, on the other hand, we don't need to put on our coats yet."
