SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 1; Styles of The Times

LENGTH: 2919 words

HEADLINE: The Face In the Crowd

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD

 BODY:
CAPRICE BENEDETTI stared fixedly at herself in the mirror, surveying her beauty, and saw that her color was just not right, so she repaired that deficiency quickly. She daubed on a touch more lipstick. Self-absorption is expected of a model. It was late in the day, and she had already changed clothes and makeup a half-dozen times, piling new look upon new look. "O.K.," she said. "I'm the next me."
She bounced out of her apartment building in Manhattan, the doorman nodding to this latest version of her. Quickly, her long legs propelled her into the humming convoy of pedestrians, those who had uncomplainingly lived with the same look all day long. "Some days, I'm changing my face and changing my clothes 10 times," she said. "I'm elegant. I'm casual. I'm chic. I'm downtown. I'm sexy. I'm theatrical. I begin to wonder: Who am I? I'm 10 different people. Where's the real me? You have an identity crisis. Who is this?" 
 As she wove through the crowds, there were, as always, covetous stares, but no sense of recognition. For hers was not a face that many would know.
Caprice, as she is known professionally, is an average fashion model. She is not Cindy Crawford or Naomi Campbell or Niki Taylor, and never will be. She is one of "the other girls." While she makes abundant money, never does her face decorate the covers of Vogue or Elle or Harper's Bazaar. Never has she been the Clairol girl or the Revlon girl. She wallows in the vast anonymity of fashion, her scrupulously made-up face blurring with thousands of others. Was she the one in that sequined dress in the Macy's catalogue? Was it her in the aqua T-shirt on page 132 of the September Allure?
She earns from $150,000 to $300,000 in a busy year, turning up in J. C. Penney and Neiman Marcus catalogues, in commercials for Honeynut Cheerios and Coors beer and in myriad fashion shows. That is astounding money for someone who is 26, and it eclipses the income of many average models, who make closer to $100,000. But Caprice takes on copious work and, after more than seven years, is well connected. In any event, the so-called supermodels can match her income in a month or two and bring in $2 million to $3 million a year.
As a model who will never be a cover girl, Caprice is more typical than atypical of the modeling business. Her orbit is the middle ground of very good but not exceptional models who are the backbone of the industry, the ones who do the grunt work of Seventh Avenue. They make do without the celebrity that anoints the top models. They don't get the megabuck contracts from the cosmetics houses, the acting offers from Hollywood. They don't marry Billy Joel or Richard Gere.
It was a miserable day. Leaden clouds had formed in the sky, offering fair warning of the rain to come.
"Usually, you have the whole city of New York showing up for something like this," Caprice said, walking up lower Broadway toward a smoke-colored tower where she was to try out for a hair-care commercial. Some weeks find her auditioning for as many as 10 commercials, few of which pan out.
When she emerged from the elevator, a half-dozen models were sitting in the waiting area, some of perhaps 200 who would seek the job, and they eyed one another suspiciously. Auditions offer intensities of mood. As always, though, there were familiar faces, available for a nerve-quieting schmooze. Caprice greeted a willowy, tawny-haired veteran of the audition wars.
"So how's married life?" Caprice asked.
"Great. I love it. Are you in love?"
"Was. Broke up."
"Oh, well. Move on."
"Yeah. It's hard."
Caprice is 5 feet 10 inches tall, with short dark hair, hazel eyes, high cheekbones and endless legs. She is beanpole thin, 125 pounds, with a waist just 22 inches around. She wears a size 4 or 6. According to her chart at IMG Models, the agency that represents her for print and runway work and collects roughly 20 percent of her income, she has great skin, good teeth, a good smile, great legs and good hands. She is ardent and full of emotive energy.
Caprice's name was called, and she entered a bare, brightly lighted room. "You always look fab," the casting director said.
She was to speak less than 30 seconds' worth of lines, bragging about how the product had rid her of unwelcome gray hair.
"If you're not comfortable, change the words," the director said. "And don't do too much selling. Make it fun."
She nimbly read through the beginning, messed up, tried again.
"O.K.," the director said. "One more."
She was finished, and the next name was called. " 'Bye," the director said. "Boy, you do look fab."
There was no call back for the hair-product ad. "So you try another," Caprice said.
Illuminated by the street light, Caprice's apartment looked sleek and elegant. Her closets were a constellation of clothing. She owned 20 dresses, 15 pairs of pants, 18 pairs of jeans, 15 evening gowns, 30 blazers, 20 leather jackets, 10 white shirts and 40 pairs of shoes. When they pass from fashion, the clothes go to her mother in Seattle, who is the same size.
Caprice shops at the finest boutiques, with a bent for Armani, Karan, Klein and Lauren, though she adores the Gap and J. Crew for casual clothing. Like any model, she does not find it difficult to spend $15,000 in one spree. While in Milan, Italy, recently, she left her wallet in a cab. Her credit-card company informed her that the person who found it bought $32,000 in clothing in a single day. Caprice concluded that the person had to have been a model.
Women who embark on modeling careers have two dreams sharp in their minds: to be on the cover of Vogue, Harper's Bazaar or Elle, and to land a major makeup contract. Few realize either dream. Were they to come true, they would most likely occur within the first year or two of modeling. The arbiters of beauty tend to make up their minds fairly fast, separating the faces of destiny from the faces of ordinariness.
Caprice's thoughts were drawn repeatedly to these two big dreams, and she knows neither will happen for her. She has appeared inside Elle and Harper's Bazaar, but never in Vogue and never on the cover of any magazine. "Oh, no, I'll never get a cover or a contract," she said. "If that was going to happen, it would have happened. A lot of it is timing. A lot of it is politics. You have to be nice to everyone. I feel often like I'm an ambassador to myself. It just didn't happen for me. My face just wasn't appealing at the time. And they always want new faces. By now, my face is known in the business."
The first couple of years that she modeled, these facts tormented her. When a shoot for Italian Vogue was canceled at the last minute, she was so depressed that she went shopping and spent $4,000. "When I was younger, I acted childish," she said. "I kept wondering, Why doesn't it happen?" Now, rebuffs produce no diminution of composure. When she was recently hired for a L'Oreal advertisement, she said to her agent: "Great. Who did they cancel?"
The model's world pivots around some derailed idea of beauty, for no waist of 22 inches can be maintained by living any semblance of a real life, the sort with an important role reserved for potato chips and hot-fudge sundaes. There is both an excitement and an emptiness to modeling. Caprice confesses to an ambiguity of purpose.
"This whole business is deception," she said, toying with her hair. "It's false advertising. It's total fantasy. How can a 5-foot-5 woman with a pear-shaped body put on a pair of leather pants and a tight shirt and look 5-10, 120 pounds and not pear-shaped? It's a shame. We give women false expectations and we make them feel worse about themselves. I feel guilty at times. I know I'm putting something on that most people can't wear. I know this is just a game."
An ineluctable part of modeling is the pressure to retain your ethereal look against the uncooperating ravages of time. Low-calorie is your god; zits are your devil. Most models starve themselves. They smoke heavily and drink gallons of coffee to throttle their appetites. They tend to be vegetarians. They work out at gyms daily. Caprice is an oddity, blessed with natural thinness. She shuns junk food and fried food, but eats with abandon, rarely works out and doesn't smoke.
Her health has taken some bruising. She developed sinus problems from all the flying she does for catalogue shoots and fashion shows. Her back aches. She has seen an acupuncturist regularly for three years.
The tendentious protocol of her calling prohibits her from revealing the real face behind the layers of makeup. "You can never go out of the house looking bad," Caprice said. "One time at 11 o'clock at night, I ducked out to get something at the deli. I had on sweats, high-top tennis sneakers and stuff on my jaw to get rid of a zit. Sure enough, I ran into a photographer. The next day at the agency, everyone was razzing me: 'Hey, we heard you looked really bad last night.' "
By now, Caprice knows that she not only can't look imperfect, but also can't act anything but cheerful. Two years ago, she was unable to mask her darkened mood. Within a matter of months, her uncle and her grandmother had died and she had broken up with her fiance. She went out on shoots wrapped in gloom. "No one showed the least bit of sympathy," she said. "Everyone said: 'Hey, you're a model. You're not allowed to have feelings. How dare you have personal problems! We pay you to entertain us.' Since I wasn't my bubbly, charming self, I lost an unbelievable amount of business. It was pretty disgusting. In the end, what it comes down to is you are a product, not a person."
"Do that thing with your arm." Click.
"Bring your hands up." Click.
"Try to act like you're hanging out in the front room, thinking about something." Click.
"Beautiful." Click.
Caprice, dressed in a Macy's sport bra, was posing in a rented apartment on Grand Street for a Macy's catalogue. David Herrenbruck, a Macy's photographer, was caressing his camera and barking directions.
"Watch the wrinkles in the bra," chirped Barbara Snyder, the art director for the catalogue. "They threatened me with death if there were wrinkles."
Catalogue work is the bread and butter of Caprice's business. Though hardly glamorous, it is steady work at good pay. At her age, Caprice gets little magazine work, for the fashion magazines crave younger, fresher faces. In fact, one day soon, no one at all will want Caprice's face. To turn 27 is to be very old and in need of another occupation. Caprice is thinking of becoming an actress.
Before the recession tightened budgets, models were routinely ushered to exotic locales for leisurely shoots. Now, pennies are dearer. Not long ago, Caprice wound up in Atlanta in a hotel with ants in the bed. It took an hour to kill them. Dreams of ants crawling in her ears aborted her sleep.
Caprice guessed she knew upward of 100 poses, and rolled out her repertory. She struck a subdued pose, then a beatific pose, then a flighty pose.
"Heavenly." Click.
"Yessss." Click.
Outwardly, Caprice was her familiar ebullient self, though inwardly she was seething. She thought the look was all wrong for the sport bras she was wearing. They had fake eyelashes and her hair was slicked back. Too elegant, she felt. And the side lighting threw shadows on her face. When she saw the pictures afterward, she hated them.
F OR every 1,000 aspirants who walk into a modeling agency, perhaps 10 or 20 will ever model. Sometimes, though, modeling comes to you. Modeling found Caprice in the women's clothing department of the Nordstrom store in Seattle.
She was born in Seattle, and after high school worked as a saleswoman. In March 1985, while on her coffee break, a scout for Marcella's Studio, an Italian modeling agency, spotted her. When he told her she had promise as a model, she thought he was demented. As a lark, she consented to a photography session and, with $300 in her pocket, agreed to journey to Milan and see what modeling might have in store for her.
Jobs arrived in fits and starts. She lived in Milan and Paris, building a portfolio. She shared quarters with other models, sleeping on the floor, eating crackers and cheese. In late 1986, she came to New York and signed with the Elite agency. Before long, she switched to the Ford agency, and last July went to IMG. J. Michael Bloom represents her for television work. Agency switching is common.
There were endless go-sees, appointments to be looked over by prospective clients, but also days of being whisked around in limousines and being fussed over by makeup artists. And she found that shrugging into clothes could reward her with $2,000 a day.
Not every assignment was simple. For Self magazine, she had to wrestle with a male model at the edge of the roof of a hotel in Dallas. It was 12 stories down, and the Fire Department watched with open nets. Once, she did a shoot wearing slinky clothing inside a church in Rio de Janeiro. Residents took umbrage. They hurled bottles and tomatoes. "I got nailed big time in the head," she said.
The business is replete with the need for endless self-promotion and a nimbleness at evading acts of vengeance. "You have to go out on a lot of client dinners," Caprice said. "You have to be seen at the right party or the right restaurant and with the right people. It's silly, but you do it to get a booking. It's a fake world. You have to live up to the image of what people think the model is. And so, you're constantly acting."
Models tell of how, if they switch agencies or enrage a photographer or client, they find themselves the target of unfounded rumors. A couple of years ago, word circulated that Caprice was pregnant and had quit the business and returned to Seattle. She learned about the rumor when she bumped into a colleague who asked her how the baby was doing.
IN the hour before the Arnold Scaasi spring fashion show started, the models were very busy. In the insistent dreariness of a drizzly afternoon, the murmuring crowd filtered into the Celeste Bartos Forum at the New York Public Library. Backstage, Caprice and 14 other models were riveted on mirrors, transforming their faces.
Daubing on blusher, Caprice spoke of runway work: "It's a madhouse. You're back here and you have to put on an outfit in like two minutes, and sometimes the earrings don't work and you rip them off and get another pair, or you get a run in your hose and you have to quickly change hose, and then you hate the outfit you have on, but you've got to go out there and look like you've had all day to get ready and like you'd rather wear nothing more than what you have on."
Caprice had seven "exits," or outfits, to wear. To pulsing music, she paraded down the runway past faces pinched with curiosity. Runway walking is an art of its own. Caprice explained: "You don't walk like a normal walk. You don't walk heel-toe -- you walk toe-heel. The clothes hang better that way. And you have to tuck in your pelvis and lead with your hips. It's all in the pelvis and hips."
On the runway, it was all lush glamour. Backstage, it was grim. Most of the dressers who undressed the models were new and sluggish. "They're just standing there," Caprice said with a moan. Her shoes were a size too big. "How am I going to wear these and look elegant and poised and not trip?" she howled. Toilet paper was the answer. She stuffed the toes with it, then added tape inside to grip her feet. As she headed down the runway, she scrunched her toes together. And her earrings kept falling off.
When the show ended, Caprice dressed in leather pants and a leather jacket and bounded out the side entrance. "That was really unorganized madness," she said. "Sometimes a show goes really smoothly, but often it's like this. Chaos."
The Metro Cafe and Club is on West 17th Street. It was late on a Wednesday night, and the fantasy people were there, projecting unending images across the noisy floor. There are a handful of fashion play spots where models go to connect and advertise that they exist and are not pregnant in Seattle. Among the current spots are Peace, the Playground and the Metro Cafe.
Ferreting her way through the crowd, a melange of chortling thin people, Caprice paused to accept the card of a casting director, to plant a kiss on the cheek of a photographer, to declare to a cosmetics vice president, "Well, don't you look great, babe!"
Everyone was happy to see everyone else. Caprice stoked herself with a glass of champagne. "Networking," she shrugged. "Have to do it."
Naturally, Caprice can't wear just anything when she goes out. A prescribed model look seems to become acceptable for six months, a year, then gets rudely replaced. Caprice and her model friends call the look the Uniform. Of late, Caprice said, the Uniform has consisted of tight black leather pants, high-heel platform boots and a tight leather vest or white shirt. Tonight, Caprice was emphatically in Uniform.
A model wandered over and said, "I want to see 12 movies this weekend, go on a movie marathon."
"Let's do it," Caprice said.
Another model said: "Look how thin Jack looks. Actually, everyone looks thin."
"This place reeks of thinness," someone else said. Midnight, and there was talk of heading to another club. And here, perhaps, was a good place to leave Caprice. She was smiling, giggling. She had a sip of her drink. Across the room was a photographer. She winked and beckoned him over. He began moving her way.

GRAPHIC: Photos: LOOKING GOOD: Though she'll never be a supermodel, Caprice Benedetti's "great skin" and "good smile" help to earn her up to $300,000 a year. (pg. 1); "You can never go out of the house looking bad." "In the end, what it comes down to is you are a product, not a person." Products are what Caprice's face and body have helped to sell. Some days, "I'm 10 different people," she said, adding, "Where's the real me?" "I'll never get a cover or a contract," Caprice said. "If that was going to happen, it would have happened." HEADLINE: Come Join the Fight

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I was distressed to see myself listed in "Calls to Restrict Immigration Come From Many Quarters" (The Week in Review, Dec. 13) as a sponsor of a constitutional amendment that would deny United States citizenship to American-born children of undocumented parents. 
 I do not support any proposal of this sort. Last spring my name was added in error as a co-sponsor of the amendment. On learning this, I immediately requested that my name be removed.
Such an amendment would create a permanent underclass, born in this country but not entitled to the same rights as citizens.
Many civil rights leaders, you maintain, are torn between their conscience and their constituents, as African-Americans worry that immigrants are displacing them from jobs and political power. Our job as leaders is to bring attention to the real causes of unemployment and disenfranchisement among both groups and to insure that they are allies in the movement for economic and social justice.
 
CHARLES B. RANGEL
Member of Congress, 15th Dist., N.Y.
Washington, Dec. 23, 1992

LENGTH: 1212 words

HEADLINE: Conversations/Allan G. Lindh;
Is 1993 the Year of the Big One? Rumblings from a California Prophet

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS

DATELINE: MENLO PARK, Calif.

 BODY:
ALLAN G. LINDH looks the part of a latter-day Jeremiah, with a long russet-and-white beard, a piercing gaze and an absent-minded mien.
And he sounds the part when he warns Californians that the recent earthquakes in the Mojave Desert, among the largest in state history, are a "final warning" that the Big One on the southern end of the San Andreas Fault is just around the corner and that "it's time to act as if the damn thing will happen tomorrow." 
 "Tomorrow" in geological time is a hazy concept, easy to push aside, and Californians consider insouciance about earthquakes a badge of honor. But Dr. Lindh's latest caveats are the most ominous ever issued here. And they were followed by months of frequent aftershocks down south and a flurry of revised scientific predictions, which have made all but the most devil-may-care residents catch their breath.
Still, the chief seismologist at the United States Geological Survey does not see himself as a prophet of doom, but rather as a public educator, someone paid by the Federal Government not merely to delve the mysteries of earthquake science but to instruct people on risk reduction.
"It's not like being Jeremiah," Dr. Lindh said, making room for himself and a guest in an office where the floor and every available piece of furniture is buried under computer printouts, dirty coffee mugs, yellowed message slips and assorted athletic and outdoor gear. "It's like being a high school teacher explaining AIDS to teenagers."
Dr. Lindh says he doesn't enjoy scaring folks. But a little fear goes a long way toward motivating people to prepare for a natural calamity that need not kill them or destroy their property, he said. And it also goes a long way toward persuading public officials that investing in safe buildings and roadways is good business. "A magnitude 8 earthquake in an urban area is going to be a $100 billion event, but it should kill relatively few people," Dr. Lindh said. "It is within our capacity to turn earthquakes into events that, while terrifying, take very few lives. And to some degree we already have done that here in California, thanks to building codes and life style changes."
 
Death by Falling Parapet
 For the citizens of California or other earthquake-prone regions, Dr. Lindh said, safety is simple: a matter of bolting their houses to the foundations to avoid major property damage and paying attention to the "duck and cover" drills that have been part of Earthquake Preparedness Week every April here since 1985.
Consider the person inside an old brick building when the ground starts to shudder. Stay inside the groaning building with your head covered and you'll probably do fine, Dr. Lindh said. But panic and run into the street and you risk being killed by a falling parapet.
Dr. Lindh uses mathematical probabilities, a staple of earthquake science in the United States for nearly a decade, to educate public officials who must decide which problems to solve and which dangers to ease in an era of shrinking resources. "Society is always playing a high-stakes poker game when there's only so much money to spend," he said. "You move some problems to the foreground and others to the background."
The best way to decide where to spend money, Dr. Lindh said, is to quantify hazards in terms of the likelihood they will occur. For instance, the chance of being hit by an asteroid is somewhere between 1 in a million and 1 in a billion "and so not much money is being spent on asteroid shields."
But earthquakes are another matter. While seismologists argue about probabilities, Dr. Lindh said they generally agree that the chance of a major earthquake within the lifetime of a Californian is somewhere between 1 in 2 and 1 in 10. "If the odds of something that can kill your children are 1 in 10, you move it into the foreground," Dr. Lindh said. "If the odds are 1 in a billion, well, we take risks like that all the time."
Earthquake preparedness is harder to sell in Seattle, where Dr. Lindh has spent a lot of time lately trying to convince local residents and officials that they, too, live atop a precarious fault line.
Each "felt" earthquake here in California -- and there have been many in recent years -- is a wake-up call, reminding local officials to review their emergency plans and creating a stampede for batteries and bottled water. "But Seattle hasn't felt an earthquake since '65, so the education process is a much bigger job up there," Dr. Lindh said.
Dr. Lindh, who is 49 years old, came to his career via a long and winding road, similar to the one traveled by Jack Kerouac and his acolytes in the 1960's. Dr. Lindh's bachelor's degree took more than a decade, with stops at Cal Tech, Yale, Washington State, the University of Oregon and the University of California at Santa Cruz. Then, with a dog-eared copy of "On the Road" in his back pocket, he set off to the wilderness.
Living with some homesteaders in British Columbia and trying to earn money to repair a broken truck, Dr. Lindh and a friend were hauling sawdust at $100 a load to a gas well under repair. The rig site was "a scene from hell," Dr. Lindh said, a sea of icy mud two miles off the Alaska Highway. The work was hard and cold for everyone involved, except for one man who sauntered from his warm house trailer to the rig every few hours for a brief look-see.
 
Earthly Comforts
 That man was a geologist and he told Dr. Lindh that it was nice work if you could get it: $100,000 for the winter, with summers off to hunt and fish. It sounded good to Dr. Lindh, who pointed his repaired truck toward Stanford University. Ten years and much procrastination later, he had a doctorate in geophysics and a job at the Federal agency, whose motto is "Earth Science in the Public Interest."
When Dr. Lindh isn't talking probabilities and preaching preparedness, he offers eloquent testimonials to the San Andreas Fault, which tore asunder in Northern California during the Loma Prieta earthquake of 1989 but has not ruptured in the south for over 300 years. That quietude in the south doesn't suggest that the fault is safe, but that it is accumulating stress -- increasing the urgency that something awful is about to happen.
The San Andreas is a fearsome feature of the local landscape, Dr. Lindh said. But it is also the geological source of California's spectacular scenery because it carved the coastline with its harbors, the Sierra Nevada range with its winter snows and the sheltered Central Valley with its lush crops.
And that landscape is not merely beautiful. It is the source of billions of dollars a year in economic benefit, a thought that set Dr. Lindh rummaging through papers, looking for data from a recent lecture. "Ah, here it is," he said, a preacher ready for his finale.
"Shipping, agriculture and oil and gas alone reap $15 billion a year in economic benefit for the state of California," Dr. Lindh said. "A major earthquake, which might cost $100 billion in damage, occurs here every 50 to 100 years. Do the arithmetic and you'll see that the San Andreas gives us many times more than it takes away. So all we have to do is figure out how to invest a fraction of what the fault creates in making this a safer place to live."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Allan G. Lindh near the San Andreas fault. (Michael Tweed for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: True Leadership for the Next Millennium

BYLINE: By Paul Kennedy; Paul Kennedy, professor of history at Yale, is author of the forthcoming book "Preparing For the Twenty-First Century."

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN

 BODY:
As President-elect Clinton, his Cabinet and advisers prepare to take office, concentration on immediate and short-term issues would be scarcely surprising.
Should the North American free trade agreement be accepted? Should more pressure be put on Serbia to cease its "ethnic cleansing" in Bosnia? Can some troops now be withdrawn from Somalia? Should our profligate use of petroleum be curbed by a gas tax? How can the new Administration convince the markets it is serious about cutting the deficit? 
 Add to these challenges the unpredictable crises of the year ahead, and it would seem almost impossible for Bill Clinton and his fellow world leaders to focus on anything other than the problems at hand.
Yet, as we move toward the 21st century there is a compelling need for politicians and nations alike to raise their eyes from day-to-day issues, however pressing and tragic, and devote time to considering our global condition as a whole.
The immediate crises -- among them, turmoil in foreign-exchange markets, ethnic unrest, trade tensions, refugees -- have to be set within a larger context and understood as local manifestations of the way different societies are responding to broad trans-national forces for change. Unless we grasp the larger picture, we have no chance of preparing for the problems ahead, and will most likely find ourselves limited to reactive, damage-control measures when a crisis occurs.
But how, given the kaleidoscopic nature of contemporary world affairs, are we to distinguish the important from the ephemeral? It might help to consider an earlier time in this century when hopes of a new world order were also being overshadowed by economic fears, ethnic jealousies and political paralysis.
In a remarkable article in October 1930 (after the Wall Street crash but before Japan's invasion of Manchuria and the Nazis' seizure power), the Economist of London somberly surveyed contemporary global problems and concluded: "The supreme difficulty of our generation . . . . is that our achievements on the economic plane of life have outstripped our progress on the political plane to the extent that our economics and our politics are perpetually falling out of gear with one another. On the economic plane, the world has been organized into a single all-embracing unit of activity. On the political plane, it has not only remained partitioned into 60 or 70 sovereign national states, but the national units themselves have been growing smaller and more numerous and the national consciousness more acute. The tension between these two antithetical tendencies has been producing a series of jolts and jars and smashes in the social life of humanity."
This is not to imply that another Hitler is lurking around the corner but to suggest that those "antithetical tendencies" noted by the Economist are as much, or even more, in evidence today. With the Western colonial empires gone, the Soviet Union disintegrated and Yugoslavia torn apart, almost three times as many states exist as in the 1930's. All confront the task of reconciling technological change and economic integration with traditional political structures, national consciousness, socio-economic needs and habitual ways of doing things.
As the forces for modernization and integration press against social groups desperately clinging to older ways (French farmers and Chinese bureaucrats, for example ) and in some places are countered by the forces of disintegration (in, say, Slovakia and the Sudan), it becomes clear that we are witnessing a global process, not random incidents.
Furthermore, the task of reconciling economic and political structures will be complicated by trends that were scarcely evident three generations but now threaten to worsen social tensions in all manner of ways.
In the place of the Fascist threats of the 1930's, there are numerous volatile regimes in Asia and Africa, some striving to obtain weapons of mass destruction.
There is also the problem of growing demographic imbalances between rich and poor societies: 95 percent of the projected doubling of the world's total population, from five to 10 billion people, between now and the middle of the next century will take place in developing lands. This has profound implications for the environment, political and social stability, the prospects of sharing diminished supplies of water and woodlands and for migration patterns.
The 1990's are unfolding with vast numbers of ambitious and desperate peasants moving from their strife-torn overpopulated homelands toward the prosperous societies of Europe and North America.
At the same time, new technologies -- completely automated assembly plants, biotech farming and food processing, 24-hour-a-day futures trading -- make traditional jobs redundant, even in developed economies, while further eroding the economic sovereignty of countries. In sum, we again face a "series of jolts and jars and smashes in the social life of humanity," with every likelihood that such shocks will continue.
Given the dimension, complexity and apparent inevitability of these technological and demographic forces, is there really anything that the Clinton Administration can do, especially in light of America's budget deficits, social needs, the shake-out of so many household names in the manufacturing industry, and spiraling health care costs?
Don't U.S. politicians have enough on their hands in simply dealing with domestic problems, from downsizing the military to reviving the inner cities? Isn't grappling with the more than one million people who stream across the Rio Grande each year a task enough, without Mr. Clinton's being required to respond to demographic trends in Africa and Asia?
Certainly, addressing internalneeds is critically important, not just for the Democrats' electoral chances in 1996 but because a more productive, vibrant and confident nation would also be in a better position to contribute to solving global challenges. This does not mean, however, that the U.S. can completely insulate itself from the world's problems.
More than ever before -- much more than in the 1930's -- what happens in the world outside affects America's prospects, simply because we have become so much integrated economically, strategically and politically in global affairs over the past half-century. Unlike Franklin D. Roosevelt, Bill Clinton probably cannot afford the luxury of devoting his first few years of office to domestic renewal alone.
Thus, the broad trans-national forces call for true leadership by the President and Congress and their equivalents elsewhere. Such leadership would display three critical, linked characteristics. The first is a willingness carefully to study and try to understand the truly global nature of the challenges we face. The second is an ability to articulate clearly why it is important to pay attention to external trends and, where necessary, to allocate resources to deal with pressing needs outside our own boundaries. And the third -- the most important of all -- is a commitment to evolve policies, in conjunction with our allies and the appropriate international agencies, to ameliorate and contain global trends that threaten instability and to support measures that encourage sustainable development.
All three attributes -- understanding, explaining, carrying out -- are required. In the absence of one of them there is no prospect of progress.
Supposing that the Clinton-Gore team can avoid being totally overwhelmed by the domestic agenda and is able to comprehend trans-national challenges and persuade America of the need for sacrifices to improve our global condition, what policies would really make a difference? What could be done to ease worries about long-term trends as against simply reacting to regional crises that are their manifestation?
No doubt 100 different replies, involving policies, large and small, could be given in answer to those questions. The danger is that in trying to do everything at once an Administration's energies can become dissipated and attention become unfocused. It is far better to deal with only a few critical issues, giving them the attention they deserve and relegating other policies to a secondary order -- another sign of true leadership.
What might the top four issues be?
The first, admittedly long-term but arguably the most vital of all, is to encourage a reduction in the global population explosion, which is the cause of mass poverty and also feeds into social turbulence from Algeria to India. At a time when tens of millions of married women in the third world, already weakened by bearing three or four children, are desperate to gain access to benign contraceptives (like Norplant), it is unconscionable that our Government -- lumping sensible population-control measures with forced sterilization and abortion -- should continue to deny funds to assist efforts to reduce the demographic explosion.
Improving the condition of women in developing countries, especially their access to education, would be the single most important move to bettering mankind's social condition. This will take time, so why not start now?
Second, intelligent proposals are needed to head off the growing gap between the rich North and poor South, not just on humanitarian grounds but also because of urgent pragmatic reasons. It is inconceivable that Americans and Europeans, a mere 10 percent of the earth's population, will be able to exist as islands of prosperity in a sea of poverty and social strife as the next century unfolds.
A North-South "grand bargain" that included environmental pacts, increases in overseas aid from today's pitifully low percentages, the maintenance of open access to the third world's exports and reduction of fuel use and greenhouse emissions is a fundamental requirement.
Given the past record of failures and inefficiencies in development policies, selling such a deal to the public will be no easy task -- even if we have leaders willing to tell the nation that, while this will surely cost us large sums now, the results of neglect might be even costlier later.
Third, there is need to address a more immediate and more traditional military danger -- namely, the proliferation of sophisticated weapons, some capable of long or medium-range delivery and mass destruction, into the volatile regions of the globe.
What will be increasingly different about future politics as compared with the time when the Economist warned of "jolts" and "smashes" is that poorer countries will come into possession of such weapons and be able not only to inflict dreadful damage on their neighbors but also to carry that destruction farther afield. Do we want to wait until, say, the range of North African missiles extends to Paris and Frankfurt before waking up -- or join instead a serious campaign against proliferation, including sales by our own arms industry?
Finally, because all these considerations will affect America's society and economy in a world of rapid technological change and the disappearance of many traditional jobs, we need to introduce apprenticeship and retraining systems like those in Germany and Sweden and to raise the numerical and literary skills of the noncollege population to those in other advanced economies. We need alterations in the school curriculums -- from grammar schools to elite universities -- to teach about global trends.
More than that, we need politicians who will keep reminding the public of the truly significant developments in world affairs instead of appealing to short-term interests ("no new taxes") and pandering to anti-foreign and protectionist forces.
There must be better ways of responding to the impacts of globalization than restricting food and textile imports from third world countries -- moves that only worsen their problems and send more illegal migrants streaming to our shores. All this involves costs both in money and in political popularity.
Sixty years ago, the coming jolts and smashes in the social life of humanity eventually produced one leader who offered his country only blood, sweat, toil and tears. But Winston Churchill had it easy in one way, since the external threats had become so clear and the need for sacrifices so obvious that he offered the only real alternative.
The challenge for the Clinton Administration is to convince America and our allies that today's global trends, while less immediate a threat to national security than Fascist aggression was, might be equally perilous to our well-being over the long term and thus require equally serious responses. If the new team can successfully respond to the new global agenda -- understanding, explaining and carrying out intelligent policies to meet the changed conditions -- it will indeed have demonstrated true leadership. But that is a big if.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

SECTION: Section 3; Page 25; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1032 words

HEADLINE: At Work;
The Loneliness of the Layoff Survivor

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN

 BODY:
PETER DiToro, a senior consultant at Computervision in Bedford, Mass., is a veteran of what is becoming the combat zone of the 90's. He has survived a half-dozen rounds of layoffs over the last four years and in recounting them, he talks about this group "getting shot" or that group having "a hand grenade rolled under it."
The dramatic shrinking of American industry during this seemingly endless slump has been characterized by large companies laying off thousands of workers. While the focus has been on the plight of the suddenly unemployed, the survivors are left to handle the emotional stress wrought by dramatic changes in the workplace, often with scant attention from senior management. 
 Like passengers who survive a train wreck in which others perished, employees who keep their jobs often experience pangs of guilt and long periods of anger and inability to accept what has happened, before awareness of the new reality sinks in.
Amid the fear and uncertainty, heightened by the constant threat that more layoffs will be coming, perhaps with less lucrative severance packages, those who remain must take on increased workloads, often adding 20 hours or more to their workweeks. Consultants say this often leads to burnout, stress on relationships and finally an employee who is little good to himself or the company.
"Business leaders don't pay much attention to the tensions" after a layoff, said Jim Francek, a human resources consultant based in Norwalk, Conn. "There tends to be a gruff 'They should be happy they have a job' kind of attitude toward the survivors." This attitude is a mistake, he says.
Mr. DiToro, a 45-year-old middle manager and the sole breadwinner in a family of four, understands better than most workers that lifetime employment is no more. Computervision, a maker of computer-aided design software, was until recently part of Prime Computer, once a leading minicomputer manufacturer. Prime acquired Computervision in 1988, just as its own minicomputer business turned sour. Prime left minis and in 1992 folded its remaining operations into Computervision, laying off thousands. The company went from 12,500 employees in 1988 to the current 5,000.
Mr. DiToro has emerged a grizzled pragmatist. "Job security is gone," he said. "I expect a revolution in my career every five to seven years."
He joined Prime in 1987 from a good public sector job, lured by the promise of a cash-rich, employee-oriented company that had never had a layoff, he recalled. Two years later his group of 25 industry marketing specialists was eliminated. Half, including Mr. DiToro, found other jobs within the company immediately. He spent eight months in a new business development group with six others, and then that group was cut.
Mr. DiToro was one of two who survived, moving to a spot with another product marketing group. Eleven months later, the bottom dropped out again.
"They cut a group of 55 down to 15 in one morning," he said. "They just called us into a room in groups of eight or nine and handed us the severance package. My manager was tough, and people were afraid to work for her, but that morning she cried."
WHILE the others went out for a tearful group lunch, Mr. DiToro got on the phone. "I had three interviews lined up by the time they got back from lunch," he said. Forty-eight hours later, he had a job with a group that is now part of Computervision.
"Before the first layoff, there was a lot of fear," he recalled. "Everyone knows something is coming, work stops, you wonder if you should be looking for a job. After the first layoffs, there was a sense of security. People had the attitude they could always get a job. But that has since disappeared."
Mr. DiToro said the layoffs had bred resentment among workers. "People are certainly asking the question 'What's in it for me?' more now."
Alcohol consumption has risen outside the office, he said, and the signs of emotional pressure are evident. A once-dapper manager shows up unshaven, with frayed cuffs.
Nevertheless, morale is generally better now than it was right after the layoffs, he said, with personal variations. Some have taken low-profile jobs and kept their heads down in hope of avoiding future cutbacks, but many of those people are unhappy, Mr. DiToro said. He has continued to stay active and visible, broadening his skills in technology "strategically important to the company," learning programming, for example.
Mr. DiToro said he has been spared any guilt feelings. "I've always believed that you are your own corporation," he said.
"There's no complacency," he said. "Every time I visit a customer, I assume the guy walking in as I'm leaving is the competition. If we ever feel fat and sassy, we'll be making the same mistakes again."
 
 
 
MANAGING THOSE WHO REMAIN
 THREE issues are critical for executives managing employees who have survived a round of layoffs, Jim Francek, a human resources consultant based in Norwalk, Conn. said.
* What is the current reality for employees? What job or jobs are they expected to do? Who is the boss, and how will the employees react to this person?
* What is the corporate vision now? The vision is at the top of the organization, and often employees below do not know what it is.
* Pay attention to the tension. It is unrealistic to expect people to react quickly to layoffs and move on.
"People often feel they are running in place; they feel physically fatigued, and fear is high," Mr. Francek said. "They are happy to have a job but guilty to have one as well."
Quinn Mills, a business professor at Harvard Business School, said managers spend more time on the people getting laid off than on the survivors. "They have to spend time with the survivors, allay their fears, let people meet and talk through the issues," he said. "Change is often good if you bring some newness and spirit to it."
"People can get personal satisfaction if a company builds teams around the concepts of quality and customer focus and sets out a sense of purpose," said Tim Hall, professor of organizational development at Boston University. "But companies are still struggling with how to provide that."

HEADLINE: When Housing Collides With Race and Class

BYLINE: By ANDI RIERDEN

 BODY:
VELMA WILLIAMS divides her life between two worlds. During the day she works as a statistical assistant for the Veterans Memorial Medical Center in West Haven where she has many things in common with her colleagues, most of whom are white. They often laugh together, eat together and share stories about their families. But when the day is done, said Ms. Williams, "We go our own ways, and as a black person mine is to be isolated."
For 16 years Ms. Williams has lived in the Brookside public housing development in New Haven. Situated next to a landfill, the complex is cut off from the rest of the city by a ring of fences and dead-end streets. Residents of the neighborhood say that garbage collection, public transportation and police protection are inferior to other neighborhoods, and that residents who need medical assistance often have a difficult time getting nurses to visit because the area is perceived as dangerous. 
 The mother of a mentally disabled daughter, Ms. Williams describes herself as a warrior for the tenants association, as she fights to expand housing opportunities for minorities. She calls it the toughest battle of her life.
She is among hundreds of residents of public housing complexes and affected neighborhoods who have come forward in public hearings in the past year. Some, like Ms. Williams, have expressed guarded approval, but the hearings also brought out cross currents of fear, bitterness and anger concerning the Housing Authority of New Haven's plan to scatter 183 homes for low-income residents in predominantly middle-class areas of the city. The emotionally charged sessions have often included contradictory testimony that has been critical of the city's housing practices and its commitment to racial equality as well as reflecting conventional ideas about race and class.
 
Arson Fires in Morris Cove
 In late October, two homes associated with the plan were set on fire by arsonists. In one, a 69-year-old woman went running into the streets in the middle of the night after spotting a blaze in her kitchen. The police said that a third fire in a vacant home nearby was related to the other two because the arsonists might have assumed that the Housing Authority owned the building. Two of the fires occurred in the East Shore neighborhood of Morris Cove, which has been the scene of racially motivated incidents over the years. The police have not yet identified any suspects.
But many residents in Morris Cove and other neighborhoods targeted for the plan said the issue had less to do with race than with the Housing Authority's dismal reputation as a landlord and their fears that property values might decline as a result. They point to the city's loss of tax revenue in homes purchased by the Authority when citywide property taxes are expected to rise more than 25 percent in the next three years.
"Most people don't care who lives next door to them, just so they can take care of their home," said a resident of Morris Cove and an opponent of the plan, Paul Maccio. "And when the Housing Authority's involved, everything goes to ruin."
The Authority, which is buying the homes to replace 366 units lost when the Elm Haven high-rise complex was demolished in 1989, is under a Federal mandate to find housing units in mostly white neighborhoods, in order to reduce racial segregation of public housing tenants. The Authority has received $18 million from the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development to acquire 183 of the units.
 
A Widening Chasm
 Lawyers from the New Haven Legal Assistance Association have sued the Authority and the city, charging them with reinforcing housing discrimination and perpetuating a long history of acquiescing to white homeowners. One of the lawyers retained by the Legal Assistance Association, Glenn Falk, said that for decades the city and the Authority have widened the chasm between black and white households by abolishing plans to reduce the number of low-income residents in white neighborhoods, while units proposed for areas with large minority concentrations have cleared with few problems. In the four years since the Elm Haven high-rise was demolished, he added, the Housing Authority has acquired only 11 single-family homes and all of them remain vacant.
The executive director of the New Haven Housing Authority, David Echols, said the process of acquiring homes had been slowed due to the maze of red tape required by the Federal Office of Housing and Urban Development, the lack of available land and the extension of public hearings.
The Authority is in the process of buying 15 additional homes and will begin renting units this month, he said, adding that the tenants will be chosen through a screening process now being developed by a coalition of residents in public housing and from neighborhoods that will be affected by the plan.
In response to residents' complaints about the Authority's management practices, Mr. Echols said that a private company has been hired to oversee the homes. He added that he was tired of residents and politicians using the Housing Authority as the scapegoat for all of New Haven's social and economic woes.
"If job and housing discrimination wasn't such a part of this country's makeup and if poor people had a stronger support system we wouldn't even be in this predicament," he said.
 
Urban Renewal in Background
 To a large extent the city's housing problems can be traced to its aggressive urban renewal programs from the 1950's through the 70's. Designed to stave off the social and economic deterioration of the area, the program, which was considered a national model, evolved into a story of good intentions gone awry. During those years some 10,000 housing units were demolished, uprooting nearly 8,000 households, according to records from the Federal Office of Housing and Urban Development.
While many white people left the city or moved to Westville or the east shore neighborhoods of Morris Cove and the Annex, black residents settled mostly in Fair Haven, Newhallville and the Hill. Between 1956 to 1967 alone, 31 percent of black residents relocated from mixed neighborhoods to predominantly black public housing units. The programs deeply affected the city's demographic patterns, laying the groundwork for much of the racial tension that exists today.
Mr. Maccio, a longtime resident of Morris Cove, said that many families who migrated there from the central city still felt the wounds from that period. Mr. Maccio, who was raised on Legion Avenue in the Hill section of New Haven, described his neighborhood of mostly Italian households as a close-knit enclave of families struggling to survive. Many of the residents, like Mr. Maccio's grandparents, had immigrated from small, isolated villages in Italy and few had had any encounters with people from different ethnic or racial backgrounds, he said. And when they came to New Haven, Mr. Maccio added, "They carried their prejudices and suspicions about outsiders over from the old country."
When the Legion Avenue neighborhood was demolished in the early 1960's to make way for commercial development, Mr. Maccio's family and hundreds of others moved to Morris Cove and other outlying areas. He said the neighborhood, which covers the eastern end of New Haven Harbor, grew into a solid middle-class community with few of the problems of the central city. "No matter what," said Mr. Maccio, "you knew your neighbors and you knew your history."
At the same time, an undercurrent of xenophobia developed among some residents, which gave the neighborhood a reputation as "a place that didn't like outsiders," he said. But at the core of that image, Mr. Maccio said, was a well-entrenched fear of the past. "We had already watched the intellectuals and the politicians concoct a misguided attempt to create a model city and all it did was unglue stable neighborhoods," he said. "Now they want to ram through plans for a housing program whose salient points are still not known."
 
Warehousing and Exclusion
 But the president of the local chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, Haywood Hooks Jr., said that the real victims of urban renewal in New Haven were black residents who continue to be warehoused in public housing developments and excluded from certain neighborhoods.
"I've heard the argument over and over that the public housing tenants don't share the same work ethic as white folks and that many poor people will pay minimal rents for homes comparable to ones that others have worked so hard to buy," he said. "Well, most people in public housing are just as hard-working and responsible. The truth of the matter is that those people out there don't want to see anyone of color coming into their neighborhoods buying better homes."
When Richard Gay and his family moved to Morris Cove in 1979, he said they had no idea that they would not be welcome. But for the next nine years, he said, the family was subjected to dozens of racially motivated threats. Residents once drove by threatening to burn down their house, he said, and later the family dog was poisoned. One Halloween night, Mr. Gay said he sat at his bay window and watched a parade of cars circle his house. In one convertible a man disguised under the clothed head of a white horse stood up and shouted "Niggers, get out."
In 1988 his family moved to a predominantly black neighborhood in New Haven.
But Velma Williams, who is among several plaintiffs named in the Federal lawsuit against the Housing Authority, said they could not let such incidents prevent them from living where they want. "The black family that chooses to live in places like Morris Cove are going to be real trailblazers," she said. "They'll no doubt be scrutinized. But we're used to having to prove ourselves."
On a quiet afternoon in Morris Cove recently, Dorothy Pickop, 88 years old, sat in the English cottage-style house that her father built in 1914, where she has lived all of her life. As a youngster, she said, she used to take the trolley into New Haven to attend the public high school, a trip that took about an hour. She and her sister often swam or rode their boat around New Haven Harbor, or reclined on the balcony of the family's bathhouse and watched the oyster boats dock across the bay. In those days the area was home mostly to summer residents and "good old Colonials," she said. But in the late 1920's more and more Italian families began moving into the area. "I don't remember anybody saying anything about it," she said.
Miss Pickop said she has seen the Cove change from a placid summer resort to a populated residential neighborhood, and she could not understand all the commotion over the Housing Authority's plan to place a few low-income families in her neighborhood. "It would break my heart to think that just because a person has a low income they don't have a nice place to live," she said.

(Photographs by Janet Durrans for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 13WC; Page 1; Column 6; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1699 words

HEADLINE: A BRIGHTER OUTLOOK IN A STILL SOFT ECONOMY;
Spending Is Up, but Jobs Aren't

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
FOR Westchester, 1992 was a most difficult year -- one that many observers of business activity in the county said they were happy to close the books on.
It was a somber year -- a period when bad news clearly overshadowed the few bright signs suggesting that economic hard times might not last forever. 
 Looking back at 1992, economists will remember it as the year when Federal regulators seized three county-based banks, one major department store shut its doors in New Rochelle and another closed shop in Yonkers, when the nation's largest automaker announced layoffs and a plant closing in North Tarrytown and a major international firm packed up its corporate headquarters in Purchase and moved out of town.
Meanwhile, vacancy rates for commercial real estate in the county continued to rise, the construction industry stagnated and corporations continued the painful process of downsizing.
All the while, the lines for unemployment kept growing as many workers in the county lost their jobs -- and in the process, their homes and their confidence in the future, too.
What Frank M. Surdey, an economist with the New York Department of Labor, called the "human side" of a lingering recession included reports by some unemployed workers of months and, in some cases, years without a job and few prospects for re-employment.
It was, Mr. Surdey said, "an extremely difficult time for the labor market."
In the 12-month period ending in October, the county lost 7,800 jobs, down 2 percent from the year-ago period.
The hardest hit was the wholesale and retail sector, where 4,900 jobs were lost. Some retail establishments cut back on hiring; others, like Macy's in New Rochelle and Alexander's in Yonkers, went out of business. Also during the year, manufacturing saw a loss of 3,000 jobs, affecting factory workers like those in North Tarrytown, where General Motors reduced its work force and went to a single production shift. The automaker also announced in February that it would close the North Tarrytown assembly plant in 1995.
In the first 11 months of 1992, unemployment in the county averaged 6.3 percent, the highest average rate for a comparable period since 1977, when it was 7.1 percent for the whole year.
In October, the rate was 6.2 percent, which was the highest for that month in 16 years. The rate in November 1992 was 5.5 percent.
 
A Hopeful Sign
 Although economic indicators, like consumer confidence, suggested that the recession was drawing to a close, Mr. Surdey said the labor situation was a far different story.
"Beyond those indicators, we have not seen an improvement," Mr. Surdey said. "The economy is still soft."
One hopeful sign for workers was the release of figures for the average workweek during October. They showed that the workweek for manufacturing was increasing to 40.1 hours from 39.7 hours in September.
But because job losses for manufacturing grew over the year, those figures could mean little except that fewer workers were putting in longer hours.
But a longer workweek often precedes actual rehiring, so the figures may, in fact, suggest that the recession is finally easing, said Noreen L. Preston, an economic development specialist for the county's Office of Economic Development.
 
'Running a Tighter Ship'
 At best, economists agreed, the unemployment patterns during 1992 reflected changes in employment that will be with the county for years to come.
For one, the economists said, job growth is no longer in the major corporations but in small and medium-size companies that specialize in health care, computer technology and services like personnel, accounting and building maintenance.
For the larger companies in the county, among them some Fortune 500 corporations wrestling with the impact of global competition, survival has become a matter of "running a tighter ship," Ms. Preston said. "They have to focus now on the bottom line."
Among those firms is the Armonk-based computer giant International Business Machines, which in addition to downsizing over the year also announced more severe cutbacks -- 25,000 jobs -- for this year.
The banking industry, too, saw the need to run a leaner and meaner enterprise in order to survive. In February, Federal regulators seized Dollar Dry Dock Bank, which was the largest bank based in the county. In June, the American Savings Bank was closed. Also last year, American National Bank, a credit card institution in Larchmont, was closed by Federal regulatory agencies.
 
An Active Mortgage Market
 For many banks that watched from the sidelines as those events took place, the stories of bank failures so close to home reinforced the need to bring under control some problems that had been simmering for several years. The overall message was that overlending in commercial real estate during the previous decade had finally taken its toll, bank officials said.
For most banks, the mortgage market was active in 1992, with many homeowners looking to refinance existing loans to take advantage of lower interest rates. But consumer lending was down overall, and lending to mid-size businesses was down even more, as many companies eschewed quick growth and followed a straight and narrow path in order to survive challenging times.
The biggest problems facing banks are the glut of unleased and unsold commercial real estate in Westchester and the problem loans that resulted from what is now being viewed as overly optimistic growth in the 80's.
"It will take some time to compensate for the overbuying of the late 70's and early 80's," said Robert C. Hooley, executive vice president and chief lending officer for Peoples Westchester Savings Bank, which is based in Hawthorne.
 
A Few Positive Signs
 The vacancy rate for commercial property at year's end was 22 percent, compared with 20 percent a year ago, said William V. Cuddy, a senior vice president with Rostenberg-Doern Company, a commercial real estate brokerage firm in Purchase.
Private real estate, although still a struggling market, offered some positive signs that the economy was improving, reported Merritt K. Mitchell, president of the Westchester Multiple Listing Service, a division of the Westchester County Board of Realtors.
Housing sales topped the 5,000 mark, bouncing back from an all-time low of 4,431 sales in 1990, Mr. Mitchell said. Single-family homes sold best during 1992, with condominiums running a close second. Sales of cooperatives, however, lagged behind along with multifamily homes.
Sellers were being more realistic about pricing, backing off from the high prices that homes were selling for in the late 1980's, Mr. Mitchell said. And buyers were less fussy in 1992, he said. Those factors, combined with lower interest rates for mortgages, fueled the market.
 
Hardly Any New Building
 But new-home construction flagged, and the construction industry felt the effects, said Ross J. Pepe, president of the Construction Industry Council of Westchester and the Hudson Valley, a professional trade group representing 500 businesses and 40,000 construction workers.
"Aside from some housing and commercial work, there has been virtually no new building," Mr. Pepe said. "The workers are devastated."
"For those depending on the building trade, it has been a dismal year," Mr. Pepe said.
County legislators echoed concerns about a downbeat economy as they turned down requests this year for pay raises from four unions representing corrections officers, nurses and teachers.
"We have to keep faith with the taxpayers," said County Legislator Audrey G. Hochberg, a Democrat from Scarsdale. "These are hard times."
 
Malls Moving Forward
 Voters, too, appeared to shy away from further spending this year, when they turned down a $26.3 million state jobs bond act, dashing the hopes of, among others, construction workers who had hoped the act would generate jobs. But as Harold E. Vogt, president of the 3,000-member Westchester County Chamber of Commerce, said at the time, it was more important to focus on "financial housekeeping" in hard times than to spend more money.
But not all of the news was bad. Ms. Preston of the Office of Economic Development said that while the wholesale-retail sector had suffered, plans moved ahead for three new shopping malls in White Plains. And the Galleria at White Plains, an 880,000-square-foot mall in the heart of the city's business district, announced plans to spend $8 million for a face lifting.
And while the Nestle Food Corporation closed its headquarters in Purchase and merged with a sister company in California, taking with it 400 county jobs, other companies moved into Westchester.
Perhaps the brightest news on that front came from the United States Tennis Association in Queens, which announced that it was purchasing a 110,000-square-foot, four-story office building in Harrison and would move in during the first part of the year.
 
'New Signs of Life'
 The Brown Paper Company, a paper distributor, moved from the Bronx into a 40,000-square-foot building in Mamaroneck. George Little Management Inc., a trade show company, moved to 10 Bank Street in White Plains. The Sony Corporation moved a regional office to Briarcliff Manor. And Reich & Tang, a financial services concern, moved to Tarrytown.
Those moves represented more than 350 jobs for the county, Ms. Preston said. In all, 80 new companies have moved to Westchester during 1992, generating about 2,600 new jobs and softening the blow of corporate restructuring, she said.
"The downsizing has been a real negative," said Margaret S. Soter, director of commerce and economic development for the county, "but, clearly, we see new signs of life in the economy."
Renewed indicators that the economy was picking up could also be seen along North Broadway in White Plains, where a commercial building front was recently renovated to provide access to a new upscale restaurant, Papa Razzi, and a health club.
"We definitely see Westchester on the rebound, especially with the new malls coming in," said Kevin Vouglitois, regional manager for the Back Bay Restaurant Group in Boston, which owns Papa Razzi.

Despite the high vacancy rate in the county, the ability of the building to rent a high proportion of its available space could be an indication that the economy is improving. (David LaBianca for The New York Times) (pg. 15)

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 5; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1430 words

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN MOSCOW: Bush and Yeltsin Sign Pact Making Deep Missle Cuts;
A Last Treaty Of Its Kind

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 3

 BODY:
If nostalgia enveloped George Bush on his 25th and probably final foreign adventure as President, there was also some nostalgia for the old sureties of traditional arms control.
Given its very sweep, the second Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, known as Start II, is likely to be the last agreement of its kind. It represents both the triumph and the limit of two-way negotiations on arms control in a world that is no longer bipolar. 
 The Soviet Union may have been a totalitarian menace, but its military commanders -- especially compared with the military commanders in some of the world's current trouble spots -- were responsible professionals who knew the dangers of the weapons they brandished or faced, and who could largely be expected to keep to the letter of the agreements they signed, however long or hard the negotiation.
 
New Cast of Nuclear Powers
 There was no fuss then about ratification by parliaments or any need to assuage the wounded pride of new states, like Ukraine, that woke up as nuclear powers and started to like the way it looked in the mirror.
Each difficult, incremental treaty on the road to Start II felt momentous -- not because arms were reduced in any meaningful way, but because the gap of ideology and misperceptions crossed by the superpowers was so cavernous and the rope across it seemed so thin.
The treaty is a legitimately momentous agreement, around which President Bush, President Boris N. Yeltsin and their speech writers did their best to spin flourishes of oratory about peace, children, trust and brotherhood. But there was a curious lack of moment.
This odd fact was caused in part bythe haste of negotiation, and in part by Russia's impoverished condition, as an imploded empire reaching for aid and acceptance. Russia's diminished status seemed to intensify Mr. Bush's, even though he is a lame-duck President.
But there is a deep, underlying sense that the new world is not only more complicated, but also considerably more volatile than the old. The end of the cold war straitjacket has meant the start of conflicts based on old nationalisms and economic rivalries, just as the collapse of the old fears of mutual assured destruction and nuclear holocaust has made the world safe for conventional war.
 
Disagreement Over Serbs
 As much as Mr. Bush and Mr. Yeltsin talked of cooperation and partnership, they clearly have their disagreements over how to deal with Serbian aggression in the former Yugoslavia. Mr. Yeltsin must face Russian conservatives and some nationalists who say they feel that he has already betrayed their "Serbian brethren" as well as old Soviet allies in Iraq, Syria, Cuba and elsewhere.
The shelling over Mogadishu, Somalia, while Mr. Bush spent Friday night on an American naval vessel offshore was a reminder of the limits of relief intervention and feel-good gestures that Russian-American amity cannot solve. In Cambodia, where Washington and Moscow brokered a peace treaty through the United Nations Security Council, the Khmer Rouge's blatant defiance of that treaty and their continual kidnapping of United Nations peacekeeping troops promises a future renewal of horrors that could make Serbian behavior seem civilized.
The disclosures of Iraq's long and secret efforts to develop chemical and nuclear weapons, despite intermittent international inspections and despite Baghdad's signature on treaties that should have banned such programs, is a reminder of the actual value of treaties intended to stop the spread of arms. The behavior of Western companies that knowingly sold advanced machinery to Iraq that could be used for weapons-making raises questions about how former Soviet companies and their skilled scientists will act in a free-market system with porous border controls.
 
Future Tasks Cited
 Senior American officials here spoke of the future tasks of arms control, pointing to the Chemical Weapons Convention, scheduled to be signed shortly in Paris, and the effort to extend the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty beyond 1995.
But they also understand how difficult Start II will be to ratify and carry out, even assuming that Ukraine, Belarus and Kazakhstan follow through on their pledges to become non-nuclear states. According to a study by the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, the United States and Russia each employ more than a million people to build, field and maintain their nuclear arsenals. Dismantling these structures will present fundamental political, economic and environmental problems. Dismantling the weapons themselves, plus thousands of tactical nuclear weapons, is full of dangers.
The Harvard study estimates that the Russians will have to destroy 100,000 metric tons of liquid rocket propellant, which explodes on contact with air, as well as safely transport, store and protect the highly prized nuclear material in all those warheads.
Washington has promised direct financial and technical aid to Moscow and Kiev for these purposes, but the cost of dismantling these arsenals safely is likely to be shocking, diplomats suggest, far in excess of the initial American installment of $800 million.
 
Democracy as Arms Control
 One senior American official said wanly that "democracy is the best form of arms control," arguing that democratic nations do not start wars.
But it is always possible, as Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev of Russia made clear last month in his stunning mock speech in Stockholm, that the Russian Government may one day end up in the hands of extreme nationalist, anti-Western politicians or military men who will treat Start II much as President Saddam Hussein of Iraq treated his solemn commitments.
Another American official cautioned that there were limits to Washington's ability to influence events here or even to control how Russia carries out the treaty.
"Both the financial obligations and the willingness to undertake the task are responsibilities that Russia and the other parties are accepting themselves," he said. "It is the Russian people and their leadership in this present instance who want to put some of the worst and most destabilizing aspects of the nuclear age behind us and accept that responsibility. We can help, but we're by no means the principal actor."
 
 
 
LEASHING WEAPONS: 30 YEARS OF PACTS
August 1963 (Limited Test Ban Treaty): Prohibits nuclear testing or any other nuclear explosions in the atmosphere, in outer space and under water.
 
January 1967 (Outer Space Treaty): Prohibits sending nuclear weapons into Earth orbit, placing nuclear weapons on celestial bodies or stationing them in outer space.
 
July 1968 (Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty): Prohibits the transfer of nuclear weapons to other countries and prohibits helping countries without nuclear weapons to make or or acquire them.
 
May 1972 (Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty): Bans space-based defensive missile systems and limits the United States and Soviet Union to one ground-based defensive missile site each.
 
July 1974 (Threshold Test Ban Treaty): The Soviet Union and United States agree to limit underground nuclear weapons tests.
 
June 1979 (Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty): The first formal strategic arms treaty sets an initial overall limit of 2,400 intercontinental ballistic missile launchers, submarine-launched missiles, heavy bombers and air-to-surface missiles, with the ceiling to be lowered in stages later.
 
December 1987 (Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty): Provides for the dismantling of all Soviet and American medium- and shorter-range land-based missiles and establishes a system of weapons inspection to guard against violations.
 
November 1990 (Conventional Forces in Europe Treaty): Originally negotiated between the members of NATO and the Warsaw Pact, the treaty limits the number of tanks, artillery, armored combat vehicles, combat aircraft and combat helicopters that each side is allowed to maintain in Europe.
 
July 1991 (Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty - Start I): Brings the number of Soviet long-range nuclear warheads down from 11,012 to 6,163 and the United States warheads from 12,646 to 8,556.
 
January 1993 (Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty - Start II): Slashes the superpowers' arsenals to a third of their current size. The American arsenal will be cut to 3,500 warheads and bombs, while the Russians will be down to 3,000 warheads and bombs. The reductions are to be carried out by 2003.
 
(Source: Arms Control Association for warhead numbers for Start I and II.)
