HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN MOSCOW: Bush and Yeltsin Sign Pact Making Deep Missle Cuts;
It Would Reduce Atom Arsenals About 75%

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 3

 BODY:
With a flourish of oratory and a dash of wistfulness, Presidents Bush and Boris N. Yeltsin signed a treaty today calling for the most significant rollback yet in the formidable nuclear arsenal of the cold war.
The signing ceremony in the richly embellished St. Vladimir Hall of the Grand Kremlin Palace was the centerpiece of a two-day "working visit" that also marked Mr. Bush's last curtain call in the East-West drama that defined so much of his presidency. 
 The new Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, known as Start II, called on the two nuclear giants to eliminate almost three-quarters of their 20,000-odd nuclear warheads by 2003, scrapping some of their most threatening weapons. President Yeltsin called the treaty "the core of the system of global security guarantees." [Excerpts from the press conference, page A8.]
 
A Major Threat Removed
 The process includes the total elimination of the most formidable weapon yet concocted, the multi-warhead land-based missile. These missiles, which can each launch many separately aimed nuclear warheads, form the backbone of Russia's arsenal. A senior American official declared that in bringing these weapons to an end "once and for all," the treaty would eliminate "that dreaded thing called the first strike."
The treaty, to be completed in two phases, also calls for deep cuts in missiles launched from submarines and bombers, the main pillar of America's nuclear deterrent.
Though by far the most extensive disarmament treaty ever signed, the bulk of Start II was negotiated in a mere six months, compared with the decade it took for each of the earlier strategic arms limitation treaties, known as SALT, and the first strategic arms reduction treaty. The speed of the feat seemed to show what the treaty itself termed "the new realities that have transformed the political and strategic relations between the Parties."
 
'Centuries-Old Dream'
 Neither President skimped on hyperbole in prepared statements read before aides and reporters who had witnessed the signing.
Mr. Yeltsin said: "It is not every century that history gives us an opportunity to witness and participate in an event that is so significant in scale and consequences. The treaty signed today represents a major step toward fulfilling mankind's centuries-old dream of disarmament."
Mr. Bush said: "We meet at the beginning of a new year and at a moment that is also a new era for our two nations and for the world. We stand together today in this great city at the threshold of a new world of hope, a widening circle of freedom for us and for our children."
But the first reaction in the Russian media was a warning not to "pop champagne corks yet." In its report on the summit meeting, a Russian television news program noted that the Ukrainian Parliament seemed to be moving further from ratifying the first Start treaty, a prerequisite for the new one to go into effect.
 
Resistance in Moscow
 The commentary further noted that despite Mr. Yeltsin's assurances to the contrary, the conservative Russian Parliament could also balk at ratifying a treaty that many conservative Russians might view as lopsided in favor of the United States.
There were other dramas that the summit pomp also failed to conceal.
First was the fact that Mr. Bush has only numbered days left in his presidency.
In 17 days, the treaty he signed and the American-Russian relationship that took shape under him would be passed on to President-elect Bill Clinton.
Both presidents stressed that Mr. Clinton had endorsed their efforts, and Mr. Yeltsin announced that he had sent a letter to the next American President urging that they meet "in a neutral place" as soon as possible after the Inauguration.
 
A Good-Bye for Bush
 But Mr. Yeltsin made a point of paying a warm tribute "to my colleague and friend, George," and there were some who thought they spotted a misting of Mr. Bush's eyes when the burly Russian turned to him and said, "Spasibo, George" -- "Thank you, George."
That note of farewell weaved through Mr. Bush's entire trip, first in Somalia, where the President spent New Year's with troops bringing relief supplies, and this evening in Paris, where Mr. Bush was to dine with Francois Mitterrand, the French President.
On his arrival in Moscow from Somalia, Mr. Bush was joined by his wife, Barbara, by James A. Baker 3d, his former Secretary of State, and by Brent Scowcroft, his national security adviser, giving the proceedings the air of a last reunion.
The ornate trappings of past summits were scrapped in favor of a low-key "working meeting" that included only one relatively restrained banquet and the signing ceremony. The only unofficial activity was a brief tour of the Kremlin by the two Presidents and their wives, during which they dropped in on one of the series of annual New Year's spectacles for children.
 
Santa Backs the Treaty
 As the leaders walked in, Grandfather Frost -- the Russian Santa Claus -- intoned, "Today, children, a wonderful treaty will be signed, which will make all our lives easier."
But with Russia closed down for a long New Year's weekend, during which no newspapers were published, many Russians were barely aware that the American president was in their midst.
One who was quite aware was Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last Soviet president. A senior aide to Mr. Gorbachev, Anatoly Chernyayev, expressed dismay to Reuters that Mr. Bush totally ignored his former partner in detente, especially now that the American had "nothing to lose."
 
Standing on the Tank
 But Mr. Bush seemed more keen to claim a new garland than to delve in the past. "Today the cold war is over, and for the first time in history, an American President has set foot in a democratic Russia," he declared.
He then heaped praise on Mr. Yeltsin, "for your unwavering commitment to democratic reform and for the history you've written since the heroic day in August '91 when you climbed atop that tank to defend Russia's democratic destiny."
That kind of tribute was one reason Mr. Yeltsin had pushed for the summit meeting at the start of a new year. He had concluded the last one with a humiliating drubbing at the Congress of Peoples' Deputies in December, when he was forced to jettison Yegor T. Gaidar, a market-oriented economist, as his chief of Government and to name in his stead a conservative manager, Viktor Chernomyrdin.
Mr. Chernomyrdin sat impassively alongside Vice President Aleksandr Rutskoi, another political thorn in Mr. Yeltsin's side, as the Russian President reported that he had "assured" Mr. Bush that the new Prime Minister would continue "on the same road of reforms."
The first question to Mr. Yeltsin by a Russian reporter highlighted another problem he faces, the resistance the increasingly hard-line Parliament might show to ratifying the treaty.
Die-hard Communists and far-right Russian nationalists resent what they perceive as Mr. Yeltsin's kowtowing to the West and have actively resisted his foreign policy, including his disarmament efforts.
"I am not going to conceal from you that a certain part of the deputies are against the treaty," Mr. Yeltsin said. But he insisted they were a minority, and that the treaty would be approved.
Both presidents went to some length to claim that the treaty was fair to both sides. Senior American officials noted that it included concessions not considered before, like letting the Russians peek at sections of the B-2 bomber to see how many nuclear bombs it could carry.
The reductions called for in Start II are to come in two phases: the first within seven years after the treaty goes into effect, and the second by 2003 -- or sooner if the United States can help Russia pay the costs of eliminating strategic weapons.
 
Strongest U.S. Suit
 But Russian critics were certain to decry the total loss of their vaunted SS-18 missile, which can carry up to 10 independently targeted warheads, while America gets to keep a portion of its submarine-based missiles.
Mr. Yeltsin protested that even after the reductions, Russia would have 3,500 warheads, more than any power other than the United States. "This is a powerful shield, which is capable of defending Russia in case of an unexpected aggression from any side," he declared.
"May I simply add that we do not view this as a one-sided treaty at all," Mr. Bush said. "We view it as balanced and I think that history will record it as such."
Even more worrisome was the position of Ukraine. Like Belarus and Kazakhstan, the other republics with nuclear missiles stationed on their territory, the Ukrainian Government has agreed to observe the first Start treaty and to transfer nuclear weapons to Russia for dismantling. But the Ukrainian Parliament has so far failed to ratify Start I, demanding that it first receive ample compensation and security guarantees against Russia.
The Ukrainian President, Leonid M. Kravchuk, who has repeatedly assured Western and Russian leaders that Ukraine will come through, issued a statement today hailing Start II as a "momentous event."
But Mr. Kravchuk gave no date for his Parliament to take up disarmament. Instead, he called for negotiations with Russia on "a wide range of technical and financial questions" related to the nuclear weapons.
 
 
 
ARMS TREATY HIGHLIGHTS
 The Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty signed yesterday by President Bush and President Boris N. Yeltsin calls for a two-thirds reduction in the strategic nuclear arsenals of the United States and Russia by the year 2003. Each side would end up with 3,000 to 3,500 warheads. These are some of the major provisions:
-- A ban on all long-range land-based missiles with multiple nuclear warheads, long regarded as the most destabilizing weapons. That means elimination of Russia's SS-18 missile, the centerpiece of its nuclear forces. Moscow now has 308 of the 10-warhead weapons, and was already committed to dismantle half of them under the arms treaty signed in 1991. The United States would have to scrap or modify its 50 MX missiles, which have 10 warheads each.
-- Russia may retain -- and reuse for basing other missiles -- 90 of the silos that now house the SS-18s.
-- Russia may convert 105 of its 170 SS-19 missiles, which now have six warheads apiece, to single-warhead weapons. The United States' Minuteman III missiles, which carry three warheads, may be modified to carry a single warhead.
-- The United States would have to cut by about half the number of warheads it has on submarine-launched missiles, traditionally the area in which the United States enjoyed the greatest advantage. The number is to drop from 3,456 to 1,728.
-- The United States would grant Russian inspectors access to its long-range nuclear bomber fleet to verify the types and numbers of weapons being carried.

HEADLINE: SOMALI CLAN CHIEFS ARE TO MEET TODAY

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 3

 BODY:
Members of Somalia's most powerful political factions plan to meet here on Monday for talks that are intended to give them a sense of joining in the rescue of their country, the United Nations Secretary General said today.
The fundamental aim of the talks is "to make Somalis feel they are participating in their own national rehabilitation and that the thousands of soldiers and relief workers in their country are not a foreign army of occupation," Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali told reporters who flew to Mogadishu with him for the day. 
 Demonstrations at the United Nations compound today organized by one of the two factional leaders who control Mogadishu forced the Secretary General to cancel a visit to the United Nations headquarters in the Somali capital for his own safety.
Mr. Boutros-Ghali dismissed the rioters, who diplomats and others said had been organized under the banner of Gen. Mohammed Farrah Aidid, as "people who do not want the peace process" because they profit from looting aid convoys or being paid not to.
 
A Rare Meeting of Leaders
 The talks would only be the second time that many of these clan leaders have sat down at the same table since their country sank into anarchy after the fall of President Mohammed Siad Barre in January 1991. The first was a meeting between representatives of nine factions also held in Addis Ababa in December 1991.
"They have no telephones, no faxes, no mail in Somalia," the Secretary General said. "They can't move around or meet each other in safety." So the United Nations chartered two aircraft to shuttle representatives of the fighting factions here from four different locations in Somalia tonight.
The Secretary General said that he would ask the factions to establish a permanent liaison committee based in in Mogadishu to keep up contact with the United Nations.
They will also be asked to offer an agenda for a United Nations-sponsored conference on national reconciliation to be held around April to establish an interim government. That government is needed as a basis for economic reconstruction, he said.
"There has to be some legitimate authority to raise loans, set up a new peace force and re-establish law and order," Mr. Boutros-Ghali said.
 
Seeking a Plan for Disarming
 As part of the reconciliation process, the United Nations will ask 14 factions to agree to a plan for disarming themselves. The United Nations also plans to convene a meeting of potential donor countries and international lending institutions like the World Bank in February to prepare a plan for Somalia's long-term postwar reconstruction.
About the same time, the United States-led force in Somalia is expected to hand over responsibility for internal security and aid distribution to United Nations peacekeepers.
The Secretary General said he envisaged a force of 15,000 to 20,000 that would be heavily armed and aggressive because it would be imposed under Chapter 7 of the United Nations Charter, which allows the Security Council to enforce its decisions by military means. Mr. Boutros-Ghali indicated that such a force would be likely to have a long stay as order was slowly restored.
"We have had peacekeepers now in Cyprus for 28 years" he said.
What makes mediating in Somalia so difficult, Mr. Boutros-Ghali said, "is that the Somalis are not aware of the end of the cold war" and still imagine they can play off the West against the East as they did in the past, enlisting the help of one side or the other in their internal power struggles.
The United Nations role, he said, is not to fight colonialism but to try "to get the world's attention focused on countries like Somalia so they can get the help they need."
On the return trip to Addis Ababa, the Secretary General made a short visit to Djibouti, which is starting a two-year term on the Security Council.

HEADLINE: Summit in Moscow: Comes the Next Generation;
With Yeltsin Overture, Clinton Backs Early Meeting

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KELLY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HILTON HEAD, S.C., Jan. 3

 BODY:
Responding to an invitation for an early meeting with President Boris N. Yeltsin, President-elect Bill Clinton said today that he looked forward to meeting with the Russian leader soon and indicated his support for the arms treaty signed today between the United States and Russia. But he said he had made no decision as to when and where such a meeting would take place.
Speaking to reporters at the Hilton Head airport just before returning to Little Rock, Ark., after a six-day family vacation, Mr. Clinton said he was "very pleased" to have received the invitation from Mr. Yeltsin but added: "I have not made a decision about when we're going to meet and where we're going to meet. I think that is going to depend in part on the timetable of the Congress and the work that I have to do here on the problems of America." 
 Mr. Clinton took pains several times during the brief news conference to indicate strong support for President Bush's policies on Russia and Somalia, the two principal stops on Mr. Bush's journey. Asked whether he planned to make any dramatic changes regarding United States policy on the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty signed today or on Somalia, Mr. Clinton said emphatically no.
"With regard to Russia and Somalia, the two things that are part of the President's trip, I don't think you can look forward to dramatic changes," he said. "I hope we'll see some progress. I hope we can conclude the mission in Somalia successfully. But I've said all along that when the President decided to send our troops there and he said he hoped the main mission would be over by Jan. 20, we couldn't hold him to that and we're doing what we have to do there."
 
Yeltsin Seeks Neutral Site
 Publicly issuing the invitation in Moscow, Mr. Yeltsin called for a meeting with Mr. Clinton in a neutral country as soon as possible and said that a lull in relations between the two countries would be "cause for concern."
Mr. Bush sought to assure the Russian leader, saying: "I've talked to President-elect Clinton enough to know that he is most interested in keeping this U.S.-Russia relationship on the high plane at which it stands right now. And I've told President Yeltsin that I think he will enjoy working with Governor Clinton."
Mr. Yeltsin responded by saying, "I hope that he will take over the baton that was given to him with such grace by President Bush."
The Russian President said he had sent a letter to Mr. Clinton in which he proposed meeting after the inauguration to discuss world problems and bilateral relations.
"There should be no lull in our relations with the new administration, because any lull in the bilateral relations between the superpowers would give cause for concern," Mr. Yeltsin said.
 
Bush Meets with Mitterrand
 Later, in Paris, President Bush repeated his reassurances about Mr. Clinton at a news conference after a farewell meeting with President Francois Mitterrand. "I think Governor Clinton will be a good man to work with," he said. "I'm very much one who wants to see Governor Clinton succeed as President."
Speaking of the message from Mr. Yeltsin, Mr. Clinton said he had received a "a very warm and somewhat lengthy" letter from the Russian President a few days ago, "following up on the communication we had about Start II and about President Bush going to Russia to sign the treaty."
Mr. Clinton said Mr. Yeltsin had "expressed his thanks for my support of the process and for what they're doing. And he asked me to meet pretty soon, either in Russia or in the United States or in some third country."
While saying he had not decided when and where that meeting would take place, Mr. Clinton stressed his eagerness about it. "I do look forward to meeting with him early," he said.
 
Sees 'Big Stake" in Reforms
 "And I do think he is genuinely committed to democracy and to a free and a more prosperous economy in Russia, and I do think the United States has a very big stake in the success of freedom and democracy there. I am very pleased at the progress that has led to the Start II success, and I appreciate the comments both he and President Bush have made facilitating this transition, and I look forward to working with him."
Mr. Clinton, who spoke to reporters in a quick and casual news conference on the airport tarmac, said he was also looking forward to a meeting early on in his administration with Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel, who also recently extended an invitation.
Mr. Clinton also spoke of his scheduled trip to Austin, Tex., this week to meet with President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico. He said that the meeting would be largely for getting acquainted with each other and that he did not expect to get into substantive discussions on the pending North American Free Trade Agreement.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN MOSCOW;
Remarks by Two Leaders: 'My Colleague and Friend, George'

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 3

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a news conference today by President Bush and President Boris N. Yeltsin after they signed Start II, the second Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty. An English-language transcript was provided by the White House.
 
YELTSIN'S STATEMENT
Today the Presidents of the two great powers, the United States and Russia, have signed a treaty on further radical cuts in strategic offensive arms of Russia and the United States, . . . 
 In its scale and importance, the treaty goes further than all other treaties ever signed in the field of disarmament. This treaty is the triumph for politicians and diplomats of Russia and the United States. It is also an achievement for all mankind and benefits all peoples of the earth. The Start II treaty becomes the core of the system of global security guarantees.

 	 	 		. . .	 	From the very outset, the new democratic Russian state has been pursuing a policy of building equal partnership with the United States. Today we have every right to say that relations between the two major powers have undergone a genuine revolution.

 	 	 		. . .	 	We open up real prospects for cooperation based on trust between people in military uniform, between people with military discipline and military thinking. Thus the Start II treaty will change and gradually replace the very psychology of confrontation.
At the same time as President and Supreme Commander in Chief, I can say with absolute certainty the signed treaty strengthens the security of Russia rather than weakens it. . . . President Bush can make a similar statement concerning the security of the United States.
The implementation of the new treaty will not be economically destructive for Russia. We have made our . . . calculations and they show that the proposed reductions would cost us much less than the mere maintenance of the nuclear weapons systems in a safe condition.

 	 	 		. . .	 	I would like to pay tribute to my colleague and friend, George. His remarkable personal and political qualities and competence have contributed to a successful transition from the cold war to a new world order.
I am grateful to him for all he has done to establish new relations between Russia and the United States, for his solidarity and support during the push for the Freedom Support Act, for the Start II treaty. Thank you, George.
I consider it of fundamental importance that the future President of the United States, Mr. Clinton, fully supported the conclusion of the Start II treaty. We can without delay proceed to the direct implementation of this instrument and consider further steps to strengthen global stability, the system of global protection and international security.
President Bush and I have maintained regular contacts with President-elect Clinton. Today's signing ceremony would not have taken place had there been the slightest reason to doubt his solidarity with our endeavors.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
BUSH'S STATEMENT
Today, the cold war is over.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 Mr. President, I salute you for your unwavering commitment to democratic reform and for the history you've written since the heroic day in August '91 when you climbed atop that tank to defend Russia's democratic destiny. And I also want to salute the heroism of the Russian people themselves, for it is they who will determine that Russia's democratic course is irreversible.
Today, as we meet on Russian soil, home to 1,000 years of heritage and history, to a people rich in scientific and creative talent, I want to assure the Russian people on behalf of all Americans, we understand that Russia faces a difficult passage. We are with you in your struggle to strengthen and secure democratic rights, to reform your economy, to bring to every Russian city and village a new sense of hope and the prospect of a future forever free.
Let me say clearly, we seek no special advantage from Russia's transformation. Yes, deep arms reductions, broader and deeper economic ties, expanded trade with Russia, all are in the interest of my country. But they're equally in the interest of the Russian people.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Questions and Answers
Q. Boris Nikolayevich, you have just signed the Start II treaty and you will have to ratify it in the Parliament. . . . What are in your view the prospects for the ratification of the treaty?
A. I am not going to conceal from you that a certain part of the deputies is against the treaty. And they are against anything positive that should take place in Russia. . . .
They -- you could consider what they are because they support Iraq and its aggression. So you understand who they represent. And finally, I would say that fortunately they are -- do not represent the majority of the Supreme Soviet, as most of the Supreme Soviet deputies believe in reason and, of course, they believe in the significance of this treaty. . . .
So if there are any difficulties with the ratification of the Start II treaty, still I am certain that the Supreme Soviet will ratify it.
Q. Mr. President, how confident are you the treaty that you're now going to be turning over to a new administration will be . . . ratified by the Senate? And, Mr. Yeltsin, I'd like to know your thoughts on how awkward is it for you to find yourself suddenly having to deal with a new President in Washington?
Bush. Clearly, I'm not in a position to commit President-elect Clinton, but I can confidently predict that this treaty will be quickly ratified by the Congress. And . . . I've talked to President-elect Clinton enough to know that he is most interested in keeping this United States-Russia relationship on the high plane in which it -- at which it stands right now.
And I've told President Yeltsin that I think he will enjoy working with Governor Clinton. . . .
Yeltsin. I met with President-elect Clinton . . . when Mr. Clinton at that time was a Presidential candidate. . . . He voiced his support for Russia, for the democratic reforms in Russia. . . .
Two days ago, I sent him a letter where I propose that there should be no lull in our relations with the new Administration because any lull in bilateral relations between the superpowers would give cause for concern.
I suggested on the phone to President Bush that after Jan. 20, we -- that is, myself and President-elect Clinton -- should meet . . . to consider different international problems and bilateral relations.

HEADLINE: British Stand On Currency

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: LONDON, Jan. 3

 BODY:
Prime Minister John Major called today for greater international cooperation to avoid the types of currency crises that plagued Britain last year. Mr. Major also said he saw no chance that Britain would soon rejoin Europe's system of linked currency rates any time soon.
In a television interview with the BBC, Mr. Major said monetary cooperation within the European Community might have to be reinforced by closer contact with other powerful world economies, like those of the United States and Japan.
Britain withdrew from the linked-currency system, the European Exchange Rate Mechanism, in September after speculative selling pressure increased against weaker currencies. That pressure came amid turmoil over ratification of the Maastricht treaty on closer European union.

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

The Markets at Year-End
The Dow Jones industrial average set a record for tranquillity in 1992, with the narrowest margin in history between high and low. For the first time since 1986, the Dow had no 100-point days. Yet individual stocks caromed around like overheated molecules. Onetime favorites like I.B.M. collapsed, and others that had seemed washed up, like Chrysler, made impressive gains. [Page D1.]
 Forecasts of lower long-term interest rates are less surprising than the reasons for such projections. Some forecasters are considering what was once unthinkable: a year of low inflation and credible efforts to reduce the Federal budget deficit. [D1.]
 Japan turned out to be the best-performing bond market for American investors last year, but not because of high yields. [D5.]
 
The Economy
Under pressure to select a prominent mainstream economist, President-elect Clinton has offered a seat on the Council of Economic Advisers to Alan Blinder, and Mr. Blinder is said to have accepted. The Princeton economist would serve under Laura D'Andrea Tyson, whose appointment has been criticized. [A1.]
 A record number of boycotts have been called against cities and states. A recent target, Colorado, may have lost $20 million in business since November, when voters approved a measure that prohibits special civil rights protection for homosexuals. [D1.]
 
International
A Berlin painter is living an inventor's dream come true: goo scraped from his truck removes graffiti almost instantly. [D1.]
 Germany's Economics Minister will resign. Jurgen W. Mollemann was caught up in a growing scandal over letters he had signed to help a cousin's business. [A3.]
 
The Media Business
As cable systems expand, figuring out what's on TV is becoming skilled labor. Several companies are competing to provide the next generation of electronic program guides. [A1.]
 People were reading newspapers last year in numbers large enough to suggest the reversal of a long readership slide. William Glaberson: Press Notes. [D12.]
 Acquisition of Hanna-Barbera's program library expanded a crucial asset of Turner Broadcasting: characters that can be marketed as everything from dolls to keychain images. [D12.]
 The Utne Reader has one of the best collections of alternative magazines, which it analyzes, excerpts and reprints. [D12.]
 The Cosmopolitan "girl" is a woman now. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D13.]
 
Today's Columns
A trend toward ever-more-powerful patent claims may be reversing after a decade in which the balance of power shifted toward patent holders. Edmund L. Andrews: Patents. [D2.]
 The outlook for the securities industry is not so promising in 1993, after a year of record profits. Market Place. [D4.]

HEADLINE: Dollar Played a Key Role In Investors' Bond Return

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Japan turned out to be the best-performing bond market for American investors last year, but not because of high yields. The interest rate on that nation's 10-year bond is now around 4.5 percent, while the yield on the American 10-year Treasury note is 6.68 percent.
Rather, the return for Americans was enhanced as falling Japanese rates produced healthy capital gains, and the profits did not suffer from conversion into dollars, which remained steady against the yen. 
 For the year, the total return from the Japanese market in dollars and yen was 11.3 percent, according to The J. P. Morgan Bond Monitor, far better than the 7.3 percent return from American bonds.
The reverse was true for Europe. The dollar rallied there and ate into all of the gains as interest rates finally declined this fall.
To make matters worse, the dollar rose most in countries with bond markets that offered the highest and most enticing yields, turning nice gains in local currencies into losses. In these countries -- Britain, Italy and Spain -- the local currencies were undermined by the currency crisis in September and were devalued sharply as Italy and Britain pulled out of the European Monetary System and Spain remained in but devalued its peseta.
 
Italian Loss the Worst
 In Britain, an 18.8 percent gain in pounds -- the best performance of the year in local currencies -- was turned to a 3.9 percent loss for American investors. In Italy, a 10.2 percent local return was translated to a 14.4 percent loss in dollars, the worst performance for Americans among the 13 markets covered in the J. P. Morgan index. And in Spain, the 6.9 percent return to local investors became a 10.1 percent loss in terms of dollars.
The dollar rally also hurt in Sweden, which cut its indirect tie to the European Monetary System after speculators attacked its currency. The 12.1 percent gain in Swedish bonds became a 12.1 percent loss in dollars.
Investors in French and German bonds were also hurt by the dollar, but not so much. The 11.3 percent gain in French francs was whittled down to 4.6 percent while the return of 13.3 percent in German marks was sliced in half, to 6.2 percent. Germany provided the fourth-best return abroad for Americans; France was fifth.
Second best was the Netherlands, where a 16.5 percent local gain became a 9.5 percent return in dollars, and Belgium ranked third, with a 15.1 percent return at home that brought an 8.2 percent gain for Americans after the translation of Belgian francs back into the stronger dollar.
The Canadian bond market was also a disappointment because of the slump in the Canadian dollar. The translation back into American dollars turned a 9.4 percent gain into a loss of five-tenths of a percent.

HEADLINE: The 'Can You Believe It' Outlook for Rates in '93

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Looking into 1993, the surprise is not that some analysts are forecasting a drop in long-term interest rates. The surprise is in their reasons.
Among traders, economists and investors, there is a willingness to believe in themes, like low inflation, and possibilities, like Democrats doing the right fiscal thing, that have not been credible in the past. 
 This means that some forecasters are including in their outlooks the prospect for what was normally unthinkable: a year of low inflation while the Government works in a credible way to reduce the record Federal budget deficit. With these oil- and-water events coming together, some forecasters see the 30-year bond interest rate falling under 7 percent, into territory it has not seen in decades. The bond ended 1992 at 7.39 percent.
"This is a little bit of wishful thinking," said Alan Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Company Economic Advisors. "But it is an intriguing wild card for 1993."
Mr. Sinai, a participant in President-elect Bill Clinton's economic teach-in last month, is giving the fall below 7 percent a probability of 20 to 25 percent in his forecast for this year. Just four years ago, when George Bush was elected to succeed Ronald Reagan, Mr. Sinai said he would have given such a forecast of deficit reduction and low inflation no more than a 5 percent probablility.
Elliott Platt, the director of economic research at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, is even more optimistic, arguing in his main forecast for the year that the Clinton Administration will have enough success in beginning to tame the deficit that the yield on the long bond should get down to 7 percent by midyear. He holds this view, he said, in part because he decided to ask what could go right this year rather than what could go wrong.
Mr. Platt acknowledges that his forecast is not in the mainstream, and Mr. Sinai says he still thinks that the more likely path for the yield on long bonds is ups and downs during the year but little change once 1993 is over. That would be a repeat of 1992.
Still, these themes are touching most forecasts for the year in some way, meaning there is a big change in thinking on Wall Street about inflation and the Democrats. This has already been positive for the market and is part of the reason that the price of the 30-year bond rallied after the election and the yield dropped from the 7.76 percent rate reached on Nov. 6.
But such views can be fragile, and that means the market this year could face a lot of volatility as each word and deed of the Clinton Administration is weighed to see if this unusual confidence is warranted and each inflation report is studied to see if this faith is misplaced. There will also be the test of whether the political gridlock of the last four years will dissolve to cooperation.
 
Inflation in the Forecast
 Joseph Liro, the chief economist at S. G. Warburg & Company, has the inflation theme in his forecast. He is betting that 2.75 percent inflation, as measured by the Consumer Price Index, along with a slowing of the economy from the 3 percent-plus pace at the end of last year, will help pull the yield on the 30-year bond down to 7.20 percent by midyear.
But he suspects that faster economic growth by the end of the year will push the yield back close to where it is today, as a faster economy ignites a fear of higher inflation. And he is not ready to expect that a Democrat in the White House can work out what he calls "ironclad" deficit reduction with the Democrats in Congress.
"I have more confidence in the inflation story than the new Administration," he said.
But traders and investors all over Wall Street still seem to have a lot more confidence in the new Administration than would have been expected. And many seem to have converted to the newest theory about the Clinton Administration.
Just before the election, interest rates rose after a strong summer rally because of fear that a Clinton Administration would try to stimulate the economy, go too far and jack up the Federal budget deficit and get prices rising again.
 
View Fostered by Clinton
 But now there seems to be an accepted wisdom that says that if the economy shows it is growing well enough on its own, the new Administration will apply much less fiscal stimulus. It is a view that Mr. Clinton and his aides have fostered. But the fact that bond market players -- who are supposed to be the anti-inflation and deficit vigilantes -- are accepting it is a noticeable turn of events on Wall Street.
"This is a very pragmatic Administration driven more by information input than doctrine and dogma," said Mr. Sinai, summing up the view of many when he explained his confidence. "It is an Administration that can change its mind based on information."
A big drop in the yield on the 30-year bond would be quite a change from last year.
While there were sharp ups and downs during 1992 -- from the high of 8.10 percent on April 27 to the low of 7.21 percent on Sept. 8 -- the yield on the 30-year bond wound up at 7.39 percent at the end of last year, the same yield as the year before despite the two big cuts in interest rates by the Federal Reserve, one just before Christmas 1991 and the other in July. And there has not been much more change over the last three years. The yield on the 30-year bond was 7.97 percent at the end of 1989.
Except for the drop in short-term interest rates last year, which touched 30-year lows in the fall, there was also little change elsewhere along the line of Treasury maturities, except for the two-year note.
 
3.07 Percent at Year's End
 The discount rate on the three-month bill ended the year at 3.07 percent, down from 3.84 percent a year ago but above its 2.58 percent low for the year in early October. The yield on the 10-year note, which fell as low as 6.21 percent on Oct. 5, ended the year at 6.68 percent, 2 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, below the 6.70 at the end of 1991. And the yield on the five-year Treasury note, which saw a high of 7.13 percent in March and a low of 5.16 percent in October, ended the year at 6.03 percent, 10 basis points above 1991's close of 5.93 percent.
The basic ingredients of the outlook for 1993 are these:
The economy will continue to grow, but only at a moderate pace. One reason is that companies like I.B.M. and General Motors will still be facing problems of slow sales and too much debt. Cutting costs will mean more layoffs. In addition, individuals will still be trying to pare their debt, which will curb spending. The recessions in Europe and Japan will also curtail growth here as American exporters sell less abroad.
Inflation, as measured by the Consumer Price Index, will stay in the 2 to 3 percent range. Unit labor costs are very low, and the Commodity Research Bureau index is not signalling any bad news on prices.
The Federal Reserve Board will not cut short-term interest rates any further. But it is also not likely to feel the need to raise them until well into the year.
The new Administration, many of the forecasts assume, will go easy on fiscal stimulus and will focus on cutting the deficit, beginning with the 1994 fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1.
 
A Debatable Point
 The Administration might decide to reduce the number of 30-year bonds the Treasury sells as a way to lower the cost of borrowing. Whether there would actually be savings by shifting borrowing to shorter maturities that have lower interest rates is debatable. But a cut in the $10 billion or so of 30-year bonds that have been sold each quarter recently could help hold prices up and yields down, analysts contend.
These basics, which exclude a successful drive to bring down the deficit, produce forecasts that have the yield of the 30-year bond falling a little -- to around 7.25 percent -- to ending the year little changed. The real differences are in the pattern for the year. Some forecasts, like Mr. Liro's, are "U" shaped, with the yield falling close to 7 percent on slower growth and low inflation in the first half of the year while rising again at year's end as the economy picks up some speed.
Others are arched, with yields rising early in the year as the bond market confronts the reality of Mr. Clinton as President and the difficulty of getting things done. But as the year progresses, the economy continues to grow only moderately and the inflation story takes deeper root and the yield on the long bond comes down close to 7 percent.
There is more uniformity on short-term interest rates, which are expected to rise slightly. The timing depends on when the Federal Reserve finally decides it has to prove its anti-inflation mettle again by raising its Federal funds rate.
Together, this produces what traders call a flattening yield curve. That happens when the difference between the yield on the 30-year bond and the 2-year Treasury note narrows. This spread reached a record high of nearly 370 basis points this year but ended the year at 284 basis points, 31 basis points above last year's finish of 254.

HEADLINE: STRICLY BUSINESS;
How the Music Stopped For the Record Hunter

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
People still meander up to the entrance of the Record Hunter on Fifth Avenue between 42d and 43d Streets. They pause before the locked door, and some notice a scrawled sign saying that mail-forwarding forms have been sent to the postmaster. A few read a photocopied statement in the window telling of the financial tailspin of a store beloved by fans of jazz and classical music.
Posted 11 days before Christmas, it tells of overexpanding during a bitter recession that has seen a drop-off in sales of all types of recordings, of mounting losses and shrinking inventories. It speaks of the sadness of closing after 47 years. It ends with a wish: "May you always keep the sound of music alive." 
 Last week, Jay Sonin, the president and owner of the Record Hunter, was inside doing the grim work of taking his final inventory, making sure his final tax bill would be paid and answering the endlessly ringing phone. He wore a sweatshirt and blue jeans and smoked lots of cigarettes. What he seemed to cling to, beneath the numbness, was a bittersweet pride.
"On a per-square-foot basis, we did more business than any record store in the world," he declared. "Every single record company told me that over the years."
 
'Your Last at Bat'
 Mr. Sonin, who is 52 years old and uncertain what he will do next, said without emotion that only his failure, not his years of success, would be remembered. "In life people remember your last at bat," he said.
Perhaps not. "What a tragedy," said George Volckening of Qualiton Imports, an importer of classical records. "To me, it's part of history."
"It was the last of the major mom-and-pop operations," said Larry Palmacci, vice president of sales and marketing for Esquire Records Inc.
Customers particularly share the distress. "I'm really sad," said Irene Soja, a secretary. And Harold Chester, a medical journal editor, said, "It had a certain character to it that the larger franchise stores don't have."
Mr. Sonin's father was in the jukebox business and he himself began working in record stores at age 16. "The only thing to do was get in trouble or go to work," he said of the opportunities in the Brooklyn of his adolescence. "I worked hard."
He worked for wholesalers, for department stores, for the record department of a sporting-goods store.
 
His First Record Store
 By 1964, he had accumulated enough money and experience to buy his first record store, World of Music on Lexington Avenue between 47th and 48th Streets. It amounted to 600 square feet of opportunity. He did well, and in 1973 a credit manager for a major record company asked if he was interesting in expanding. The Record Hunter was for sale.
It was something of an august institution, having opened in 1945, and for years it occupied a spot a few doors down from Carnegie Hall, with opera stars among its customers. But the founder had died, and his wife and son were having a difficult go at the Fifth Avenue location. Creditors were soliciting bids for a replacement.
Mr. Sonin beat out a now-defunct chain of record stores called King Karol. He paid $65,000 for the name, the mailing list, fixtures and the remaining 28 months on the lease. In 1976, he signed his own 15-year lease: $90,000 a year for 7,400 square feet.
"It wasn't an excellent deal," he said. "I made it an excellent deal."
What he did was move forward the storefront, which had been recessed from the building line, to make more space. He created a candy store from a vestibule and rented it. In the store's rear, he made space for an audio-visual department and rented that. His own rent cost was cut in half.
Things went well. He hired a knowledgeable sales staff, many of whom were musicians or music students. He concentrated on classical music, which became 45 percent of his business, compared with maybe 3 or 4 percent for most record stores. Pop was available, but not emphasized -- both because of the image Mr. Sonin desired and because the profit margin was less than on specially ordered classical recordings.
"You don't have to be a genius to sell the Rolling Stones," he said.
 
Big Jump in Lease
 Things started to go wrong in 1989, when Mr. Sonin began to have discussions about renewing his lease in 1991. His landlord wanted $450,000 a year, more than four times what he was paying. He didn't see how he could go above $250,000 and began scouting for another location.
He found one at Broadway and 19th Street, a lively shopping and entertainment area. He spent almost $700,000 to renovate the store. Then one thing after another went wrong.
It took 11 months for the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission to approve his plans. His lease turned out to be for six years rather than the 17 he thought he had negotiated. But Mr. Sonin finally opened there in October 1990.
Though he had expected not to make money at first, he was staggered by his losses. His large advertising expenditures, live bands and sweeping searchlights made no difference. People were just buying fewer records. "People who used to come in and buy four or five compact disks were buying one or two," he said. "And people who bought one or two just weren't coming in."
He was experiencing firsthand an overall trend in the industry. In 1991, the number of all types of recordings sold fell to 801 million from 865.7 million in 1990, the Recording Industry Association of America reported. This year is up only slightly.
 
'A Discretionary Item'
 "A lot of people are out of work, and a lot are afraid of becoming out of work," Mr. Sonin said. "This is a discretionary item."
Pressures mounted as some creditors demanded cash before delivery. The record companies, which pay most of the cost of record store advertisments, became reluctant to do so. Republic National Bank, Record Hunter's major secured creditor, sued for the money owed it.
"Frankly I had no defense," Mr. Sonin said. "I had no money."
The Record Hunter filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Feb. 12, 1992. The creditors committee quickly demanded that it dispose of the money-losing store and try to shore up the Fifth Avenue store.
But even though the uptown store had weathered other recessions, it now faltered too. The record companies' unwillingness to pay for ads stung deeply, but the worst thing was the inability to get merchandise on credit. Saying no to treasured customers became the order of the day as holiday inventories shrank to $200,000 from a normal $1.5 million.
A useless irony is that his Fifth Avenue landlord in 1991 lowered the rent enough to have made his disastrous move downtown unnecessary. Mr. Sonin cut staff and hours and did all the other things a businessman does when his back is to the wall.
"Right up until the end," he said, "I had hopes of turning it around."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jay Sonin, the president and owner of the Record Hunter, which had to close its doors on Fifth Avenue 11 days before Christmas. "On a per-square-foot basis, we did more business than any record store in the world," he declared. "Every single record company told me that over the years." (Edward Keating/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Blue Cross Rates Pose Peril to Small Businesses

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
Already hit hard by the recession, tens of thousands of small businesses in New York State face a heavy new burden in 1993: immediate increases of up to 22.5 percent in the cost of health insurance for employees covered by Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield. For many, it will be the last straw.
Coming atop other large rate increases in recent years in a system many believe has spiraled out of control, the new rates for small groups and their families -- 650,000 people, mostly employed in some 50,000 small businesses in 28 counties in the state's eastern half -- offer a choice of evils for many New Yorkers. 
 Unable to absorb the higher costs and wary of raising prices in competitive local markets, many small businesses operating on close margins are expected to cut or drop coverage for employees, while others will insist workers pay all or part of the increases if they want to continue coverage.
 
'Going to Be Devastating'
 Interviews with business leaders, insurance experts and owners and employees of small businesses in recent days suggest that the impact will be widespread and painful. For thousands already struggling to make ends meet, it could mean sharp reductions, or a total loss, of medical and hospital benefits.
"This is going to be devastating," said Bob Jaffe, director of New Yorkers for Accessible Health Coverage, a coalition of 35 voluntary health groups that advocate reforms in medical care and insurance in New York. "It could force small businesses in a difficult economy to abandon health coverage for their employees altogether."
As many as 200,000 people covered under individual and small-group policies, Mr. Jaffe said, could be priced out of the market and lose coverage because of the increases, swelling the number of uninsured New Yorkers to 2.3 million.
No one knows how many more workers in small businesses will face cuts in their health coverage as the rates go up, but insurance experts and business executives said hard economic times made it virtually certain that hundreds of employers and thousands of employees would be unable to afford the better, more expensive plans.
It was not difficult over the weekend to find confirmation. An East Side optician, who insisted on anonymity, said he probably would have to cancel the coverage he provides for four employees. "People are just going to be dropping out," he said.
While Empire's new bills have not yet gone out, emotional reactions to the new rates seemed to run high. "We are very angry," said Agotha Louis, owner of the Skyline Restaurant, a coffee shop on Lexington Avenue at East 75th Street. "I am so many years paying for that insurance. I'm not going to pay all those thousands."
Among owners and employees of restaurants, groceries, pharmacies, clothiers and other small businesses covered by Empire, distress has been almost palpable since Thursday, when the Cuomo administration, saying it had no choice if the state's health insurer of last resort was to survive, approved rate rises averaging 25.5 percent for 1.4 million individual and small-group subscribers.
The consumers hit hardest by the increases will be 640,000 individuals who buy their insurance directly, rather than as part of a group, and who purchase policies providing major medical coverage and Medicare supplemental coverage, known as Medigap. Some will see their rates go up by 59 percent.
In small groups, Empire says its rates for the most comprehensive major medical family plans are rising 22.5 percent, to $627.95 a month from $512.30; family plans for hospital and basic medical services are going up 19.2 percent, to $251.35 a month from $210.85, while hospital-only coverage for families will rise only 2.7 percent, to $178.35 from $173.70. Rates for less costly coverage of individuals in small groups are going up by comparable percentages.
As the increases took effect on Friday, officials still hoped part of them might be rolled back if Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the Legislature can agree on a state bailout for Blue Cross, which by law must insure all seeking coverage regardless of age or health. But even with an agreement, steep increases are in store for thousands.
Mark Alesse, state director of the National Federation of Independent Businesses, which represents 600,000 small businesses in the nation and 32,000 in New York, predicted a wide range of responses to the new rates. "Those in better shape will absorb the costs," he said. "Others will pass the costs on to their workers or share it with the workers, and some will cut back and give fewer employees coverage or cut back and give no employees coverage."
Most small businesses caught in the economic squeeze probably will not have the option of passing the higher costs on to consumers, Mr. Alesse said. Unlike large corporations, small businesses do not control their markets, and owners know they lose business to local competitors when they raise prices.
"Mom-and-pop stores can't readily pass on costs like that to customers," he said. "They are stuck with the difficult decision of absorbing the costs or passing them on to workers already under a lot of pressure."
Not everyone agreed. Carlos Martinez, the owner of La Estrella Auto Parts, a repair shop on Amsterdam Avenue near 83d Street, who covers himself but not his employees under a Blue Cross policy, said he would raise his prices to pay the higher premiums, just as he did to pay rent increases. "When you want to get more money, you have to raise prices a dollar here, a dollar there," he said.
Most small businesses are expected to pass on all or part of the costs to employees. Since few employees in small businesses are unionized, they will have little say, other than the options of paying, taking less costly coverage or dropping it altogether.
As Mr. Alesse noted, many workers already bear a heavy share of health insurance premiums that have risen 10 to 15 percent a year recently. Moreover, there will be no immediate refuge for most employees in other insurance companies.
In recent years, as insurance costs have risen and consumers have shopped for the best deals, younger and healthier people have found lower rates with commercial insurers -- those that by law may accept or reject applicants on the basis of age, health, occupation or other factors -- and the process has tended to leave Empire Blue Cross with high-risk clients whose health needs are costly and who would not be welcomed by other insurers.
That situation, which Blue Cross calls a gross competitive disadvantage that has brought it to the brink of bankruptcy, is to change in April, when a new state law takes effect requiring all insurance companies to accept applicants equally. It is expected to assure Blue Cross's long-term solvency. But it is unclear how it will affect rates or consumers who want better coverage at lower prices.
In coming months, less obvious effects of the rate increases could arise, business experts say. As the job market improves, some businesses may see valued longtime employees who have lost part or all of their health insurance depart for other jobs, where they can get the benefits.
For the most marginal businesses or those already losing money and facing bankruptcy, experts say, the rate increases could prompt layoffs.
At the Last Pharmacy, at Amsterdam Avenue and 79th Street, Paul Zausner, a pharmacist, and Angelo Colon, an assistant manager, said the rate increases would probably generate a ripple effect on their business, which employs eight people and fills prescriptions for many people covered by Empire Blue Cross.
"There will be a lessening of prescriptions because people will drop their policies -- and believe me, they will," Mr. Zausner said. And Mr. Colon noted that with fewer prescriptions being filled, "one or two workers here might have to be laid off."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Unlike many small-business owners, Carlos Martinez, who owns La Estrella Auto Parts on Amsterdam Avenue near 83d Street, said he would raise his prices to pay the new higher premiums for Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield coverage. (ith Pran/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

NEW YORK CITY
 
BILINGUAL EDUCATION 20 YEARS LATER 
 Two decades after bilingual education was introduced into the New York City school system, its overall effectiveness is still a matter of much debate. Champions of bilingual education assert that teaching immigrant children in their native tongues is essential to their progress. But critics say the program has developed serious flaws, like a testing process that sweeps children into the program who do not belong there, and they say that it keeps too many children in bilingual classes through elementary school and too often exposes them to teachers who themselves struggle with English. A1.
 
DINKINS TO URGE EXPANDED LIBRARY HOURS
Mayor Dinkins will propose in his State of the City Message that service at all 205 branches of New York City's three public library systems be extended to six days a week for the first time since 1947. The initiative, which would draw up to $15 million from the 1994 fiscal budget if approved, would be completed by September, officials say. B3.

UNLIKELY ALLIES IN NEW JERSEY
Mindful of a presidential race in which voters weary of governmental gridlock turned against a seemingly invincible George Bush, and facing an election in 11 months, Governor Florio and Republican legislative leaders in New Jersey begin the new year as uneasy and unlikely allies. After protracted battles over spending, taxes, education and insurance, the Democratic Governor and the Republican leaders reached compromises on several major issues in the last months of 1992. Driven in part by political expediency, both sides are expected to continue their cooperation this year. B6.

In the coming year, a fresh portfolio of traffic-causing projects will get under way in New York City, giving the driver who is concerned about timely travel plenty to fret about. B8.
 
DELAY IN WACHTLER PROCEEDINGS
Sol Wachtler, the former Chief Judge of the New York State Court of Appeals, has requested a new delay in court proceedings stemming from his November arrest on harassment and extortion charges, arguing that he needs more time for "medical testing and treatment." A Federal prosecutor endorsed the request to delay a hearing scheduled for Wednesday until Feb. 5, and Federal Magistrate Stanley R. Chesler is likely to approve the motion, defense lawyers say. B6.
 
LAND EVERYWHERE, BUT AT A PRICE
In Connecticut, a state of rolling hills and farms embedded into the countryside as if they'd sprouted there, Jim Hunter is having a hard time scaring up two acres of farmland. All he wants is a place to sit in the dirt and write his thoughts, to plant enough vegetables to carry him through the winter, and to someday leave to his grandchildren. Mr. Hunter is more than willing to pay for his plot. He has $20,000 to spend, but these days that doesn't seem to go very far. When he asked some Litchfield real-estate agents for advice, they gently suggested he was living in another place and time. Milford Journal, B6.

HEADLINE: Market Place

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane

 BODY:
THE securities industry enjoyed record profits in 1992, but as the new year's trading begins, the outlook is not so promising. Many securities analysts are forecasting lower 1993 earnings for the public brokerage and investment banking firms.
While last year's final totals are not in yet, member firms of the New York Stock Exchange that deal with the public probably reached highs in pretax profits, with estimates ranging to as much as a total $7 billion. That compares with $5.9 billion the previous year. For 1992's first nine months alone, pretax profits grew to $5 billion from $4 billion in the year-earlier period. 
 But such gains are likely to be more difficult in 1993. "I don't think we'll see much change in the stock price of brokers unless we get a blowup in the market," said Perrin H. Long Jr., director of equity research of the First of Michigan Corporation in Detroit. "And I don't think the market as a whole will be higher at the end of 1993 than it was on Dec. 31, 1992."
The brokerage stocks enjoyed a good fourth quarter in 1992, after a dismal performance in the corresponding 1991 period. Retail activity rebounded, led by a surge in smaller issues, and equity underwriting bounced back from lower levels in the third quarter. Nevertheless, the industry is unlikely to repeat the numbers notched in 1992.
Guy Moszkowski, brokerage industry analyst for Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, noted: "On the surface, the trends are still attractive for 1993. But most of the sources of revenue are cyclical and depend on the demand for securities by consumers. The retail investor by and large seeks safety, not risk, and if interest rates stop falling, the momentum to cash in certificates of deposit and money market funds goes away."
These factors and others will undoubtedly affect the earnings of securities firms for the coming year. Anticipated 1993 earnings per share, as projected by security analysts that follow Wall Street's retail-oriented concerns, are generally lower than the 1992 results, which remain estimates until the fourth-quarter figures are actually reported.
"We think a better economy in 1993 should bring higher short-term rates, which would reduce trading profits and issuance of new debt -- and probably slow down issuance of equities," said James P. Hanbury, a securities analyst for Wertheim Schroder & Company. "That's the basic business of the brokerage industry. And therefore revenues will be about 10 percent below last year and earnings will go down, although not by too much."
Among the forecasts of Merrill Lynch & Company's per-share earnings for 1993 are $6.50 by Mr. Moszkowski and Mr. Hanbury and $7.50 to $7.75 by Dean Eberling at Lehman Brothers. Merrill Lynch earned $8.25 to $8.65 a share last year, the analysts estimate.
Earnings of Paine Webber, another big retail broker, are also expected to fall in 1993. Projections include $2.70 a share by Mr. Hanbury, $2.95 to $3.05 by Mr. Eberling and $3 by Mr. Moszkowski. For 1992, the analysts say, Paine Webber earned $3.50 to $3.65 a share.
Looking at the Charles Schwab Corporation's earnings per share in 1993, Mr. Moszkowski expects them to come in at $1.70, Mr. Long at $1.80 and Mr. Eberling at $1.95. Their 1992 consensus estimate, however, is $1.85 to $2 a share.
As Mr. Hanbury sees it: "If the real economy gets better this year, brokers will do less well than companies that make things. My guess is that over all, their earnings will be down 15 to 20 percent."
On Thursday, the last trading day of 1992, the stocks of two of the three big securities firm declined. Merrill Lynch fell 75 cents, to $59.50, and Charles Schwab fell 50 cents, to $26.125; Paine Webber rose 12.5 cents, to $24.375.

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
In the Speech by the Mayor, the Message Will be in the Margins

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
WHAT is the state of a city that allowed a 5-month-old boy to die of neglect, despite warnings, and a Bronx storekeeper to be gunned down defending his family?
Mayor David N. Dinkins's State of the City speech today promises to address two related themes: the welfare of children, who represent the city's future, and the plight of small businesses, which are taxed to subsidize the growing proportion of New Yorkers who cannot afford to pay for municipal services. Yet any agenda that neglects the consequences of guns and drugs can only marginally improve the lot of children or of small businesses in New York. 
 What's a mayor to do? He commands an army of police officers larger than the American force in Somalia, but he lacks the jurisdiction or the mandate to disarm neighborhood warlords. He inherits social problems that are national in scope, but he has to cope at the sufferance of Washington, which has been insensitive, and of Albany, which has been insufficiently responsive (though, as the city's first black Mayor, he has largely escaped blame for publicized cases of child abuse that would certainly have provoked deeper outrage against a white Mayor).
After finishing his first year as Mayor, Mr. Dinkins acknowledged that his discretion had been limited largely to reshaping about two-tenths of one percent of the city's nearly $30 billion budget. "It may be that you affect things at the margins," he said then, "but when things get tight, the margins matter a hell of a lot."
The Dinkins administration has often said that good government is the best politics. That theme is likely to echo in the speech Mr. Dinkins is to deliver today as he begins a mayoral-election year that, coupled with races for local school boards and the first full terms on the expanded City Council, holds the prospect of being as divisive as the last mayoral election appeared to be unifying.
Despite the administration's boast that New York is "roaring" back, Mr. Dinkins will temper expectations by reminding his constituents that the recession continues to inhibit him from providing all the services he promised. Still, he will recite a scorecard of promises made and kept and his vision of those that remain to be redeemed.
His highest priority is to balance the budget. If he has failed so far to achieve fundamental restructuring -- last year's buzzword of government reform -- then he has, at least, avoided the early threat of a state takeover of the city's fiscal prerogatives, defied many skeptics and even won the public praise of some others.
To most New Yorkers, though, a balanced budget is a bulky abstraction. So, while accepting credit for what some people view as an accomplishment and others consider a basic duty, Mr. Dinkins will focus instead on more widely appreciated matters. Despite the toll that the recession has taken on tax revenues, he will recall, his administration began decentralizing government services to deliver them more visibly and, presumably, more effectively -- often in conjunction with a Council that he has begun, if begrudgingly, to accept as a full partner.
First, the administration dramatically expanded community policing as a strategy and started providing the manpower to achieve it. Whether modest declines in recorded crime are attributable to that strategy is arguable. What's certain is that if crime had increased, the Mayor would have gotten the blame.
Responding to state prodding, the city is expanding health-care services at the neighborhood level through a growing program called Communicare. Mr. Dinkins also plans to nearly double the number of so-called beacon schools, which remain open longer and also provide children and their parents with a range of social services. Also, he hopes to find enough funds to let branch libraries open six days a weeks for the first time in decades.
Mr. Dinkins also is proposing to reduce some of the impediments to small businesses, which are not only synonymous with middle-class entrepreneurship but also can create entry-level jobs for the rest of his constituents. Expect some exemptions on commercial-rent taxes and some constraints on ticketing for minor violations.
Expressing hope for the future, the Mayor will hark back to a productive partnership between the city's first Italian-American Mayor, Fiorello H. La Guardia, and a new administration in Washington that helped lift New York City out of the depression by doling out New Deal largess.
The analogy may not be apt. La Guardia benefited, in part, because the Roosevelt Administration preferred him to the Democratic organization controlled by Tammany Hall. And four decades later, when Mayor Abraham D. Beame was seeking a second term, his early support for Jimmy Carter was not returned in kind.
Still, the Clinton Administration and its cast of New Yorkers has the potential to help the Mayor whose political career has been built on surpassing low expectations. Mr. Dinkins was asked once whether his election would raise false hopes that he could never fulfill. Perhaps, he replied, but false hope is better than no hope at all.

HEADLINE: Boycotts Affect Travel Industry

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
At one time, choosing a travel destination involved little more than deciding where to go, how much to spend and the availability of reservations. These days, though, many travelers must also consider whether their destination meets with the approval of family, friends or business colleagues.
Disputes over sexual orientation, reproductive rights, racial slights and other social and environmental issues have spread far beyond the courts and legislative chambers and now involve a record number of boycotts against cities and states. 
 At least 12 destinations are currently targets of boycotts, said Tim Muck, executive director of the Institute for Consumer Responsibility, a Seattle organization that publishes National Boycott News. Boycotts were recently lifted by various groups against Alaska and Arizona, leaving as the prime targets Colorado, Utah and Louisiana, as well as Dade County in Florida.
"Exact numbers are difficult to track with precision," Mr. Muck said, "because some of the groups calling for boycotts are local or small and some of the issues are narrowly focused."
The Professional Convention Management Association, for instance, refused to hold meetings in New York, protesting the city's tax, equivalent to 21.25 percent, on hotel rooms that rent for more than $100 a night.
For the targets of boycotts, the financial stakes are enormous.
Travel and tourism in the United States amounted to more than $360 billion in 1991, according to the United States Travel Data Center, and accounted for almost six million jobs -- more than any retail industry except automobile dealers and food stores. It is the No. 1 industry in 13 states; second or third in 24 others.
For instance, it is estimated that Colorado has lost $20 million in meetings and convention business since November, when voters approved a constitutional amendment that prohibits special civil rights protection for homosexuals. The amendment will also void existing jobs and housing protection for gay men and lesbians in Aspen, Boulder and Denver and job-protection guarantees for state employees. It will bar other localities from passing such measures.
In protest, New York, Philadelphia and Atlanta are among cities that have forbidden their officials to travel to Colorado on business and the National Conference of Mayors canceled a planned meeting.
 
 
'Harder to Know'
 "With so many issues riling so many people," said Sharon Rooney, a spokeswoman for the San Francisco Convention and Visitors Bureau, "it's getting harder and harder to know where to travel on business and pleasure."
The boycotts sometimes work.
Alaska backed down from its plan to kill hundreds of wolves after environmentalists announced a boycott. The 200,000-member Fund for Animals ran newspaper ads asking sympathizers to contact Gov. Walter Hickel "and tell him you won't spend a dime in a state that doesn't give a damn about wolves." At least 7,500 people responded.
Connel Murray, the director of the Alaska Division of Tourism, denounced the fund's newspaper advertisements as "the moral equivalent of a ransom note." But with 20,000 jobs tied directly to its $1 billion tourist industry, Alaska abandoned its wolf-killing plan, and the boycott was lifted.
"Boycotts are sometimes an effective way of making a statement, because you can usually measure the response accurately and quickly," said John Hunt, professor and head of the department of resource recreation and tourism at the University of Idaho.
But many tourism officials contend that boycotts are the wrong way to seek redress for grievances because they hurt businesses and force the layoff of workers who might share the viewpoint of the boycotters.
 
'Hurting Innocent People'
 "Instead of hurting innocent people, wouldn't it be better to put that same power and energy into working within the system to change things?" asked Edward R. Book, president of the nonprofit Travel Industry Association of America, whose 2,000 members include many of the leading destinations, hotels, airlines and travel agencies.
Mr. Book is especially critical of the boycott of Colorado. "Denver, Aspen and Boulder voted nearly 2 to 1 against" the amendment "and they filed legal challenges," Mr. Book said. Because all three communities had ordinances upholding civil rights protections for homosexuals, their suit in Federal court contends that the recent measure violates the equal-protection clause of the Constitution.
"So boycotting Colorado," Mr. Book said, "means harming the people there who don't agree with the vote."
Indeed, the Aspen Gay and Lesbian Community opposes the boycott and still plans to hold its Gay Ski Week this month.
Similarly, the City of Miami Beach believes it is being unjustly punished for the actions of Greater Miami, where the City Commission rescinded a proclamation welcoming Nelson Mandela in 1990 and five mayors from the region criticized the anti-apartheid leader for not denouncing human rights abuses in Cuba.
For more than two years, a black group in Florida called Boycott Miami: Coalition for Progress has urged a boycott of hotels and other tourist attractions, joined by the local National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, although not by the local Urban League.
After the boycott had cost Greater Miami an estimated total of $20 million in direct spending by visitors, and up to $50 million indirectly, Miami Beach adopted a holiday to honor the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and awarded Mr. Mandela a medal in September.
"We did it because the black community felt respect for Mandela and they were entitled to that respect," Seymour Gelber, the Mayor of Miami Beach, said. "And we have borne the brunt of the boycott, because we're the center of the tourism industry in the county."
But the boycott against Miami Beach remains, as part of the larger boycott against Miami and Dade County, and Mayor Gelber regards that as unjust.
"Boycotts are based on the fact that some people have treated other people unfairly, and now we're treated that way," he said. "People have to act fairly to each other whether they are in the minority or majority."
 
An Opposite Tack
 While shunning certain places is a common protest strategy, the National Coalition to Abolish the Death Penalty takes the opposite tack.
"We almost always hold our annual conference in states with the death penalty," said Leigh Dingerson, the executive director, "in order to allow our members to demonstrate or protest against it."
For states and cities, the economic impact of a given action is often hard to assess. For instance, a survey commissioned for Utah's Economic Development Office found that 8 percent of respondents said abortion legislation would influence them not to vacation in Utah and 6 percent said they would be more likely to vacation there.
"The remaining 86 percent said it didn't make any difference," said Rick Davis, president of the Salt Lake Convention and Visitors Bureau, "so we concluded it wasn't worth the money for the promotional effort to persuade people we are a good vacation destination despite our abortion law."
Louisiana's strict anti-abortion law, adopted in 1991, put that state in the midst of controversy, as did the 1991 gubernatorial candidacy of David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klan leader.
A Duke victory could have cost Louisiana $1.2 billion in new investment and $600 million in convention and tourism business, said Tim Ryan, an economist at the University of New Orleans.
Beverly Gianna, the public relations director of the Greater New Orleans Tourist and Convention Commission, said the anti-abortion law had cost the city about $116 million from 17 canceled meetings. In addition, she said, the Modern Language Association, which met in New Orleans in 1988, decided not to hold another meeting there because New Orleans still had "a statute against sodomy."
 
Arizona's Loss
 Arizona, where tourism accounts for 96,000 jobs, knows first hand how devastating a boycott can be. After voters in 1990 rejected a state holiday to honor Dr. King "we lost 166 conventions worth $190 million," said Tony Alba, a spokesman for the Phoenix and Valley of the Sun Convention and Visitors Bureau. That includes the 1993 Super Bowl, which had been scheduled for suburban Tempe.
In November, after intense lobbying by the state's business and tourist industry leadership, Arizona voters approved the holiday.
"The day after the election we sent letters to every group that canceled or would not sign contracts, letting them know the state voted for the holiday," Mr. Alba said. "Even before the letters went out we had calls from some meeting planners saying they're ready to come. So we expect to regain the lost business in 1994, but right now we're still feeling the brunt."
