HEADLINE: Bazaar With the Feel of Bombay, Right in Queens

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
A decade ago, when V. N. Prakash began selling jewelry there, 74th Street in Queens was a modest, unhurried shopping district -- a neighborly cluster of delis and groceries, a tailor, a shoemaker and a stationer, and a bakery that was, to the locals anyway, a landmark.
These days, though, this two-block street in Jackson Heights has become the nation's largest shopping center for immigrants from India -- a bazaar that could be in Bombay, where the smell of masalas wafts from restaurants and groceries, and thousands of people course through store after store buying saris, spices and jewelry and appliances to send to India. 
 "When I first started, everyone was laughing at me," said Mr. Prakash, a native of Bangalore, whose store, Jewels India Jewels, was the first on the block to sell intricate gold necklaces and rings that are fashionable in India. " 'Who would buy this?' they said. Now, look! There are 17 jewelry stores alone. This is like a mecca for Indian people."
 
Mixing Vitality and Tension
 The evolution of 74th Street, which has brought new vitality and new tensions to Jackson Heights, illustrates one way the influx of more than one million immigrants since 1980 has changed a city that is forever shaped and reshaped by immigration.
From the Russians in Brighton Beach to the Dominicans in Washington Heights, the newest newcomers are transforming many of the city's shopping districts. As the immigrants before them did, they are carving out enclaves to cater to their own tastes, creating new versions of Main Street, U.S.A., modeled on the shopping centers they left behind.
This time, however, these enclaves represent a breadth of diversity unparalleled in the city's history. In Queens, a borough once exemplified by Archie Bunker but in fact the city's most ethnically diverse, dozens of these enclaves have appeared in the last two decades.
Some are merely clusters of stores, like the Argentine markets along Junction Boulevard and the West Indian retailers in Jamaica. Others, though, have become fully evolved centers of commerce. There is Little Colombia on the border of Jackson Heights and Elmhurst; the city's second Chinatown on Main Street in Flushing, and the concentration of dozens of Korean shops on Union Street in Flushing.
 
'The Marvel of New York'
 "This is the marvel of New York," said Eric A. Kober, the director of housing, economics and infrastructure for the city's Planning Department. "The vitality that allows these neighborhoods to grow -- it is one of the reasons one can be optimistic about the future of the city."
Not everyone, however, agrees. For some longtime residents in Jackson Heights, the flourishing of the Indian stores on 74th Street -- whatever its economic benefits -- has meant the demise of the mom-and-pop shops they considered their own.
As the new stores, and the crowds they draw, have grown, these residents have also complained of congestion, noise and litter. Once, three years ago, they even held a protest march down the street. And this fall, when Indian merchants asked the city to recognize the district formally by the name many now call it -- Little India -- their anger surfaced once again.
"This used to be an American marketplace," said Joseph Gallo, a resident near the strip and one of 700 people who signed a petition opposing the recognition, which the local community board is still considering. "These merchants have taken over our neighborhood. They have invaded us. And they are just standing there not understanding why we're complaining."
 
Accidental Transformation
 The transformation of 74th Street, which extends from the elevated subway station at Roosevelt Avenue north to 37th Avenue, began almost by accident nearly 20 years ago.
In 1973, two merchants, Subhash Kapadia and Nitin Vora, opened an electronics and appliance store, called Sam and Raj, to cater to the demand for appliances that operate on 220 volts (not the United States standard of 110 volts) to take or send back to India.
Mr. Vora said they chose 74th Street because it offered good space and low rent, not to mention the advantage of being at the confluence of subway and bus lines at Roosevelt Avenue and Broadway. Their success soon attracted other Indian merchants, and by the mid-1980's they replaced the older merchants that closed when their leases expired and rents increased.
There are now 82 Indian establishments on 74th Street and spilling onto 37th Avenue and 73d Street -- including 12 restaurants, 12 groceries, 17 jewelry stores and at least 20 clothes stores with a dizzying array of names like Sari Palace, India Sari Palace, Taj Sari Palace, Popular Sari Palace and Prince Sari Palace. Even the Key Food supermarket, one of the few more traditional stores on the strip, now sells Indian beer.
The transformation has followed a pattern that has occurred around the city for a century, revitalizing shopping strips as older immigrant groups move on, said Frank Vardy, a demographer with the city's Planning Department. "A couple of successful stores, a couple of theaters or restaurants," Mr. Vardy said. "That's all it takes."
 
95,000 Indians in New York
 More than 95,000 Indians live in the city -- 56,000 of them in Queens -- but what distinguishes 74th Street from other shopping enclaves, Mr. Vardy said, is that few actually live in the immediate area.
M. K. Srinivasan, the New York bureau chief of Indian American magazine, said 74th Street attracted the Indian diaspora from the suburbs and even as far away as Massachusetts and Maryland. As an Indian shopping center, he said, it far surpasses smaller enclaves in Chicago and Austin, Tex. "It's very important to Indians," he said. "It gives us a flavor of home."
The other day thousands of people -- from India, Pakistan and Bangladesh -- surged over the narrow street lined by squat brick storefronts with a melange of signs. Giri Heda, an engineer who immigrated 22 years ago, had driven to the strip from his home in Windsor, Conn., with a friend visiting from India, Vijay Pareek, who marveled that a part of New York City could be almost indistinguishable from Bombay.
As he browsed in Shreeji Groceries, an airy basement store on 74th Street, Mr. Heda explained that at least once a month he stocked up on groceries difficult to find elsewhere: masalas, which are mixtures of spices, desserts like revdis and rossogollas and unusual varieties of lentils and rice.
 
Shopping for Friends
 And when he comes, his friends often ask him to pick up things for them. This time, he shopped for five of them. "We can't get this anywhere else," he said, holding several shopping bags. "When we come, it's one stop."
At the Menka Beauty Salon, at the corner of 37th Avenue, hairdressers colored hair and shaped eyebrows with string using a deft technique called threading.
Suseeka Chandrasekar, who works for the Department of Defense, drove two hours from Montville, N.J., to have her hair packed with henna mud, as a love story called "Apradhi" ("Criminal" in Hindi) played on a television. "You can't get this everywhere, you know," she said.
For the most part, 74th Street remains a shopping area only -- the city's largest Hindu temple, for example, is in Flushing -- but the Jackson Heights Merchant Association hopes to expand cultural activities. On Oct. 25, more than 1,500 people, including several members of India's Parliament and Mayor David N. Dinkins, jammed the streets for the neighborhood's first festival celebrating Diwali, the Indian New Year.
"My kids, they won't know Diwali," said Mr. Vora of Sam and Raj, who now serves as the president of the merchants' association. "It's still more a commercial place, but we want to start a tradition."
 
Alienation and Congestion
 That effort -- including the request to designate the strip as Little India -- has once again provoked anger among some longtime residents in Jackson Heights. The designation, they say, would increase their sense of alienation, compound the congestion and attract more businesses to a shopping district already saturated.
Thomas Lowenhaupt, a computer publisher who lives on 75th Street at 37th Avenue, has watched the growth of stores with ambivalence. Unlike some residents, he does not speak harshly of the newcomers -- he frequently eats at the restaurants -- but he does worry about the impact, the congestion and litter, the demise of the older mom-and-pop shops.
"I don't know where it stops," he said. "I guess there's not much I can do, but just sit back and watch. It's evolution."

HEADLINE: Donations Continue To Neediest

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
The recession that has dug in its heels in New York City has not only driven the unemployment rate to more than 10 percent, forcing thousands of people out of work for the first time in their lives. It has also left many of those who still have jobs with gnawing doubts: Is my company safe? Will the economy improve? Do I have enough savings if I am laid off?
With anxiety blanketing the region, many charities are facing declining donations because those who have contributed before are giving more cautiously. But some people are so concerned about the poverty sown by the economic slump that they are disregarding their own worries and giving money to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. 
 "While we would have liked to have given more, we have been experiencing difficult financial circumstances," Karlton A. and Cynthia DeFoe of New Providence, N.J., wrote in letter to the fund in which they enclosed a $25 check. "But we know that there are so many people so much worse off, where finding their next meal is a big challenge, that we want to help even in this small way."
 
'Economic Realities'
 Eric and Jean Dattner of Queens sent $500, but they expressed regret that they could not give more. "Although economic realities force us to cut this year's contribution, we are delighted to once again be a part of this worthy effort," they wrote.
Jennifer Plassman of Brooklyn donated $25. "I have a new baby this year and funds are a little tight," she said. "But I want to keep my own personal tradition of contributing to the fund going. I am hoping to be more prosperous and, therefore, generous in the years to come."
Since the early years of this century, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has come to the aid of tens of thousands of people who lacked food, clothing, shelter and health care. The fund was born in 1911 after Adolph S. Ochs, the publisher of The Times, decided that his readers would be eager to help if they knew about the suffering around them.
The New York Times pays the expenses of the Neediest Cases campaign, so all contributions are given directly to seven charities. This year's appeal, the 81st, ends on Feb. 28.
Several contributors sent money to the fund even though they recently were laid off.
 
A Prayer and a Toast
 "I don't know if I believe what goes around, comes around," Terry White of Manhattan wrote. "But this is not a year that I want to take any chances! As of Jan. 8, I will be without a job. This $100 gift is offered as a prayer and a toast toward a better year for all. Let 1993 be the beginning of plenty, and peace in neighboring streets and homes, and those abroad."
Ruth R. Potischman of Manhattan, who also gave $100 to the fund, said she was in a similar situation.
"This holiday season has not turned out exactly as I'd planned," she wrote. "I was laid off from my job of five years and, although very hopeful, I've yet to land another one. The good news is that I'm in a wonderful marriage and I've got great friends and family -- a lot to be grateful for!"

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
From Mexico South, a Changing Postwar World

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
"Americas" draws attention to the problems and promises of the area from Mexico to the Malvinas, which is now supplying the United States with what will soon be its largest minority. The 10-part series, arranged more or less by theme and country, offers serviceable accounts of the region's post-World War II history, largely through the eyes of people directly affected.
The first hour of tonight's two-hour opener focuses especially on the shake-up in Argentina's traditional class structure by the Peronista phenomenon, which took power from the long-dominant landowners and established a political base among the growing working class. 
 The straightforward if somewhat stiff narration, read by Raul Julia, is abetted by well-chosen newsreels. But the program's freshest material comes from individuals like the landowner who laments the loss of the Argentina that was "one big family."
The right-wing military repression of the 1970's is made vivid through the memories of women whose parents were among "the disappeared," those who were rounded up by security forces in what came to be known as the dirty war, and were never heard from again.
One officer, Gen. Mario Menendez, defends the operation as essential for putting down left-wing guerrillas, although he concedes that what he calls mistakes were probably made. Gen. Menendez returns to tell of leading the forces that were routed by the British in Argentina's Falkland Islands adventure in 1982, which helped bring down the military power in Buenos Aires. Another mistake.
The second hour covers Brazil's transformation in recent decades from economic miracle to economic disaster area. Tumultuous years are seen from the points of view of a union leader, a military officer and a former Finance Minister, among others.
Next week, the subject is the immense migration in the area, with the focus on Mexico. And in subsequent weeks, the series sweeps across Haiti, Chile, Cuba, Nicaragua, El Salvador, Colombia, Peru and other countries, ending up with looks at the Mexican-Americans in California and people from Latin America and the Caribbean in New York City and Miami.
The series is light on ideology, except for a natural bent toward democracy. Combining the color of a travelogue with some analysis of political, social and economic transformations, "Americas" offers viewers in the United States a perspective on what must often seem to be incomprehensible commotions to the south.
 
AMERICAS
PBS, tonight at 9.
(Channels 13 and 49 in New York.)
 
The first two parts of a 10-part documentary series produced by WGBH Boston and Central Television Enterprises for Channel 4, United Kingdom; Judith Vecchione, executive producer; Raul Julia, narrator.

HEADLINE: Struggling Artists -- A periodic look at the quest for success in New York.;
Living the Life of Audition After Audition

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER

 BODY:
One recent Monday, Mark Guin, a 28-year-old actor who moved to New York over the summer, woke up in his third-floor Manhattan walk-up in Clinton, put on in boots, tight jeans and a denim jacket -- "Macho and sensitive at the same time," he explained -- and went to four auditions. After the first, a call back for an out-of-town production of Jon Robin Baitz's "Substance of Fire," he felt energized.
"We got in 40 minutes of work," he said. "It was almost like a rehearsal. It feels good to get that long a run at something." 
 After the second, a five-minute line reading for the role of Hippolytus in Racine's "Phaedra" at the Pearl Theater Company in Chelsea -- "It was like, 'Thank you very much' " -- he was so irritated that unprovoked he snarled at the cabdriver who ferried him downtown to TriBeCa.
There, at a film production company called the Shooting Gallery, was the third audition, which, his agent had told him, was for a 30-minute film. The director was looking for someone "real appealing, mellow and bohemian."
Getting out of the cab, Mr. Guin (pronounced GYOO-in), a lanky, tousled blond with slightly crooked good looks, pulled a prop out of his brown leather shoulder bag.
"That's why I brought these beads," he said, slipping a necklace over his head.
Twenty minutes later, Mr. Guin emerged. The director was a good guy, he said. They'd had a friendly conversation, though not about the film. Instead, Mr. Guin said, he'd been asked to read a scene from the Alain Resnais movie "Hiroshima, Mon Amour."
How come?
"I don't know," Mr. Guin said, shrugging. And he headed uptown for his final audition of the day, at the soap opera "Guiding Light." He was to read for the part of Hart Jessup, who was described to him as a young horseman with a broken heart and a fondness for Yeats. When Mr. Guin got to the midtown studio, the casting director didn't recognize him as the man in the picture his agent had sent over.
"That's always a bad sign," Mr. Guin said, after his 10-minute reading.
As it turned out, Mr. Guin got no parts out of his odyssey and he had no other auditions scheduled the rest of the week. But on balance, he said, he had had enough human contact to make it a good day. By the standards of a young actor new to New York, he was right. Short of a ridiculous Lana-Turner-in-Schwab's stroke of luck, about the best a committed and aspiring thespian can hope for is to get around, be seen, make an impression.
"I will play any part that excites me, no matter what it happens to be in," Mr. Guin said. "I don't feel like that's a compromise. That's what my work is about. Some actors are good enough to make any part exciting. I mean, Robert De Niro could make Hart Jessup a very interesting guy."
If touring the city in search of an opportunity to impersonate someone, anyone, seems an aimless, random existence, ruled by serendipity and the whims of strangers, it is. But this is how young actors pay dues, developing what everyone in the performance world speaks of as the foremost necessity: thick skin.
"Acting demands you be vulnerable emotionally in order to do the work, but have a hide as thick as a rhinoceros to take the rejection," said Don Scardino, a director and the new artistic director of Playwrights Horizons.
Mr. Scardino was among several theater professionals to note that with its high rents, dwindling opportunities and a business atmosphere in which a few high-powered agents control a high percentage of the talent pool, New York City is tougher than ever on newcomers.
"The way actors get work has changed radically," he said. "At one time, you could just make the rounds and get work. There used to be a lot more entry-level agencies. Now you've got superagencies, like William Morris, and they don't want to come near you. There are some mid-range agencies, but they're inundated.
"When we cast a play at Playwrights," he continued. "I might come up with 10 or 12 people who are right for a given part, people I know and have worked with. That's before auditions, before agents' submissions. In the end, there might be a couple of hundred actors who feel they must be seen."
Mr. Guin, who on the basis of some out-of-town work was able to become a member of Actors' Equity, the performers' union, estimated that he had been on 50 auditions without getting a part since moving to New York in July from San Antonio, where he had played Mercutio in a regional theater production of "Romeo and Juliet." He had an agent, Meg Mortimer, who called him after seeing him perform as Lysander in "A Midsummer Night's Dream" with the Acting Company, a touring repertory group. But he said he expected that it would probably take a year before his anonymity in the world of local auditions would begin to give way to a reputation that would precede him.
"I think Mark is a leading man, but he has an edge to him," Ms. Mortimer said. "He's got the natural appeal to do TV, and the acting ability for all three mediums. But you have to invest time, you have to go out on auditions, you have to get close and you have to fall on your face."
In the meantime, like a lot of his compatriots, Mr. Guin is living on meager means with a limited wardrobe and thrift-shop furniture. "I found myself rummaging around my apartment for change a few days ago," he said.
Mr. Guin, a former bicycle mechanic and house painter, is not working and is entitled to a couple of more months of unemployment insurance from the Acting Company job, which ended in March. He admitted to being temperamentally unsuited to the actor's standby -- restaurant work -- and said he would go back to painting when his money ran out.
"New York is where you go to get beat up, to pound the pavement," said Mr. Guin, who began his acting career six years ago as an intern at the Old Globe Theater in San Diego. "I thought of going to Seattle" -- a city with an expanding reputation for theater -- "but then I was told people who go to Seattle end up doing beadwork." Besides, he said, part of the attraction of New York is the idea of overcoming the odds. "They say that in Los Angeles, beauty counts," he said. "In New York, talent does."
 
The Lure of New York
 Television and film work in New York is sparse, and in general the competition for stage roles continues to intensify. Actors' Equity says 41.4 percent of its 35,252 paid members nationwide worked at least one week last year, compared with 47 percent of 27,808 paid members a decade ago. But New York continues to attract young actors seeking to test their mettle.
"Unless someone is a beautiful model type -- because that's the other way of succeeding, to be drop-dead gorgeous -- if you have aspirations for being a real actor, you have to come to New York," said Barry Moss, a partner in Hughes-Moss, the casting agency responsible for "The Will Rogers Follies" and "The Cosby Show," among other stage and television projects. "This is where the teachers are. This is where the atmosphere is. The work ethic here in New York doesn't exist anywhere else."
The work ethic is a funny thing for an unemployed actor. Unlike a writer or musician, an actor cannot ply his trade alone. Mr. Guin describes filling his days with reading, visiting the zoo, talking with actor friends, nursing beers and eavesdropping at local bars. He doesn't watch much television -- he doesn't own one -- and doesn't attend movies or the theater all that often. He can't afford it. He tries to stay away from the phone, particularly after days like the four-audition Monday, so as not to let its silence torment him.
"You try to make it hard to give up," he acknowledged. "You play a lot of head games. You have to want it enough to work hard when you get a chance, but not so much to let it devastate you when you don't.
"It's a drag for anybody to be unemployed. This woman said to me the other day, 'Auditioning is our work.' So you try to make it mean something. But if you take it too seriously, you're doomed. If you get philosophical, it can be dangerous."
 
Plus Side of Humiliation
 "I love hearing horror stories about auditions," he said, telling one about a friend who auditioned for a musical though he was incapable of carrying a tune. "I got the feeling he made a fool of himself on purpose, to steel himself. The humiliation forces you not to take yourself so seriously." His own worst experience, he said, involved being asked to imagine himself a puppy in a pet store.
"That's the sort of thing that would embarrass you if you were 10 years old," he said.
The natural question is why a talented, intelligent young person would put up with this kind of life. "For most actors," he said, "it's more than the pleasure of the crowd applauding. You wouldn't work so hard in rehearsal otherwise. And it's dangerous as hell. You can really make a fool of yourself. Acting is a thrill sport, as much as anything else."
But how was he lured into such a fix? The answer is actually what you would want to hear from an artist. It's the pull of art.
"Acting pulled me in," he said. "It was the first hand that reached out to me when I was having a hard time."
As Mr. Guin tells his story, he was something of a wayward youth. Born in Austin, Tex., he moved to western New York State with his mother and stepfather when he was 5 years old. He did some acting in high school, he said, but it was mainly to impress girls. "It was like sports: a way to be a hero," he said.
 
Expelled From School
 After his mother's second divorce, he was sent to the Taft School, in Connecticut, where he was quickly expelled for youthful indiscretions. "Drinking, having girls in my room, the usual," he said.
There followed a period of transience. He returned to Texas, then moved back north, to New Haven. He enrolled at Vassar for a year, but again, was expelled. Then he rejoined his mother, who had moved to Kalamazoo, Mich., and worked as a bicycle mechanic.
"My mother was auditing a class in religious philosophy at Kalamazoo College, and another person who was auditing was teaching an acting class," Mr. Guin said of the serendipity that changed his life. His mother introduced her classmate, whose name was Brant Pope, to her son. "I was very unhappy at the time," he said. "I took the class, and it was fantastic. It felt right. Brant was a great teacher. He was the one who told me I was an actor. He'd ask relentless questions about characters, and I felt like I was addressing myself through addressing someone else. For the first time I felt I could express something potent in myself."
From Kalamazoo, he went to San Diego, where he won a spot in the master of fine arts program at the Old Globe Theater.
"He auditioned for us, and he was unbelievably green," said Jack O'Brien, the artistic director of the Old Globe. "But also authentic and sharp. He squeaked into the program as the least-qualified and youngest actor. But it goes to show you he had something else going for him. Once he got into the program, he pretty much ate it whole."
 
Finally, a Part
 After two and a half years at the Old Globe, Mr. Guin auditioned for the Acting Company, and spent two years touring the country, eventually playing Romeo for several performances. His tenure with the company ended in March, when lack of funds aborted its tour, and after his stop in San Antonio he decided to try his luck in New York.
Actually, six mostly frustrating months after he arrived here, Mr. Guin's story had a happy ending. In mid-December, he got a job, a good one, albeit not in New York. In a couple of weeks he leaves for Houston, where he'll play George Gibbs in an Alley Theater production of "Our Town."
But it was before that happened, when he didn't know he was on the brink of good fortune, that Mr. Guin sat in a West Side bar late one night and said he still believed in acting as "a noble pursuit, a good path to take through life." Asked where he wanted to be in five years, he responded: "It's so hard to see beyond right now. In five years I just want to be a better actor, and I want to be working. I think that's ambitious as hell."
He tossed back his tequila and grinned.
"I feel very lucky to be in this unfortunate position," he said.

HEADLINE: New Year's in the City

 BODY:
The new year brings hope and fear to the people of New York City. Hope that after 12 years of neglect, urban America will get new help from Washington. And fear that the campaign for mayor will exacerbate the city's ragged race relations and consume the energies needed for renewal.
The two moods are intimately bound. Without more generous and coordinated assistance from Washington, the quality of urban life will worsen. If it does, so will destructive demagogy and the search for scapegoats. 
 Bill Clinton took a conspicuous walking tour through an inner-city neighborhood of Washington after his election. But like George Bush and Ross Perot, he largely ignored the cities' problems during the campaign. Large cities house large concentrations of minorities and the poor that suburban majorities prefer to forget.
But Mr. Clinton showed deep interest in health care insurance, AIDS relief, welfare reform and the plight of children -- issues of urgent concern to cities.
Will his Administration bring only incidental benefit to the cities? Or will it address their needs with full Federal weight? Real relief presupposes a healthier economy; reviving urban America will cost plenty. But cities deserve special attention even in tough times. They need social reforms that reduce welfare rolls, create jobs, build homes. Furthermore, urban ills don't stay within neat geographic lines. Eventually they invade suburbia, enlarging destruction and waste.
The number of New Yorkers subsisting on welfare payments has passed one million for the first time in more than 20 years. The costs of Medicaid continue to surge. The waiting lists for public housing have grown to 240,000 families -- almost as many as the number of apartments already occupied. The story is the same in virtually every large city.
Neglect and wrongheaded social policies aggravated by recession leave cities without the resources to pay for their poorhouse functions. But the poor will not go away -- until they are less poor. Unless Washington acknowledges the care of the poor as a national moral and financial obligation, urban poverty and misery will bankrupt governments and lay waste to urban infrastructure. The barren center of Detroit and other inner-city neighborhoods should be warning enough.
Bill Clinton has little direct experience with urban blight. As Governor of Arkansas he didn't have to exercise leadership over large cities, the struggling shelters of last resort for the nation's poor. But fortunately he has drawn to his side a number of urbanites who do have such experience. If he listens, and finds the resources, cities might begin their climb back.
Not all the remedies depend on Washington, of course. New York's leaders remain set in old and wasteful ways. Mayor David Dinkins has achieved some modest improvements, but the true innovations, like privatization and holding city workers more accountable, still elude New York. Can it reform wasteful civil service laws, write equitable property taxes, get sanitation workers to work a full day for a day's pay, revise rent control, revamp a petty, meddling Board of Education?
Debating such issues would make for a lively and constructive mayoral contest. But continuing racial tension raises the specter of a polarizing campaign. New York and other cities have a strong claim on the national conscience and pocketbook. Yet city leaders cannot hope to press that claim if they do not themselves practice the reform and demonstrate the responsibility they seek.

HEADLINE: New York's Loss: Timothy Healy

 BODY:
Timothy Healy, the warm, erudite Jesuit priest who died of a heart attack Wednesday, was a native New Yorker who rejoiced in the city long at the center of his life. Named president of the New York Public Library just as the economy declined, Dr. Healy badgered city officials to come up with more money, recession or no recession.
They did. Starting today, all 82 branches of the New York Public Library will be open at least five days a week for the first time in more than a decade. 
 Dr. Healy succeeded the flamboyant Vartan Gregorian, who revived the near-destitute library. He built on the Gregorian legacy and then some. Dr. Healy championed the restoration of branch libraries, presided over the expansion and improvement of a library for the blind and guided plans for a new science and business library.
Despite these and other accomplishments, it was Dr. Healy's intellectual and social reach that most struck those who knew him. The former president of Georgetown University and vice chancellor of City University of New York, he was equally comfortable with college students and the rich and powerful, equally knowledgeable about City Hall and the poetry of Virgil.
Dr. Healy didn't stand on ceremony. He wore business suits instead of clerical garb, refused to live in the generous Madison Avenue residence the library provides its president, choosing instead a smaller apartment in midtown, and donated his $100,000 salary to the Jesuit order.
It was Tim Healy's misfortune to preside over the library in difficult instead of flush times. But it was New York's good fortune to benefit from his wise, zestful tutelage.

HEADLINE: Not All Productivity Can Be Increased

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"What Counts Is Productivity and Productivity" (The Week in Review, Dec. 13), a prelude to President-elect Clinton's economic conference in Little Rock, Ark., states that productivity will be the measure of economic success for Mr. Clinton's Presidency. 
 I believe you fail to mention the principal reason that productivity has grown so modestly in the 1980's. During that decade, our economy became more service-oriented, as opposed to a manufacturing-based economy. Many manufacturing jobs disappeared or moved overseas, to be replaced with service jobs.
However, service jobs do not lend themselves easily to productivity improvement. There is no miracle machinery on the horizon that will lead to a service breakthrough.
Doctors, lawyers and accountants have only minimally improved their productivity by using computers, and probably will not achieve greater productivity in the next several years. Other people in the service industry, such as office cleaners, computer operators, salespeople, bank tellers, food service workers and home health care attendants, pretty much reached the limits of their productivity years ago.
 
EDNA BLANCHARD
New York, Dec. 13, 1992

LENGTH: 1177 words

HEADLINE: Under Calm Surface of 1992's Indexes Lay Waves of Turbulent Stocks

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
Philosophers going back to Heraclitus have said that behind seeming permanence lies constant flux, and the course of last year's stock market bears them out. The Dow Jones industrial average set a record for tranquillity, with the narrowest margin in history between high and low. For the first time since 1986, the Dow had no 100-point days.
Yet individual stocks caromed around like so many overheated molecules. Onetime favorites, like I.B.M., collapsed; others, like Chrysler, whose shares had once shriveled to single digits, flourished and were among the leading gainers. 
 Cyclical industries including cars, semiconductors, banking and retailing gave investors the best returns, while the drug stocks and other medical issues that had led the market in past years succumbed to the increasing threat of cost controls.
In an era when individual investors were said to have surrendered their initiative to faceless institutions, they became net investors in stocks for the first time in 30 years. Instead of picking from among thousands of stocks themselves, they tended to sift through the thousands of mutual funds. Net investments in equity mutual funds set an annual record of $68.7 billion through November, already beating the previous record, in 1991, by more than $30 billion.
They overwhelmingly bought small stocks and small-stock funds, giving the Nasdaq composite index a 15.5 percent gain to a record close, more than tripling the gains of 4.2 percent in the Dow and 4.5 percent in the Standard & Poor's 500.
Even the best market timer could have made no more than 8.8 percent on the price of the Dow stocks, or 11.8 percent on the S.& P., because these were their whole ranges last year. Despite the collapse of the Japanese stock market, the stalling of Europe's semi-unified economy, a Presidential election and the economy's delayed comeback in the United States, it was the least volatile year in history. The S.& P.'s average annual range for the last 65 years has been 34.8 percent, or 26 percent excluding the Depression period.
The averages encompassed huge, offsetting gains and losses, however, as individual stocks went manic. "Charles Dow would never have earned a name if his average had such muted volatility," said Thomas McManus, a market analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company. "In 1992, the average didn't tell what the average company was doing."
At the extremes, the Walt Disney Company more than doubled, while the International Business Machine Corporation fell more than 43 percent, erasing $22 billion in shareholder wealth.
Of the Big Board stocks priced at $40 and more -- the supposedly stable institutional favorites -- last year more than one of eight veered at least 3 percent on the average day, said Laszlo Birinyi, whose consulting firm bears his name. In the 1970's, when the market as a whole was far more volatile, only about 1 of 13 stocks bounced around that much.
Mutual fund managers were the quickest draws, accounting for 95 percent of the New York Stock Exchange's net buying but dumping stocks on any disappointment. "The old saying was, 'Buy on the rumor, sell on the news," Mr. Birinyi said. "Last year was, 'Sell on the rumor, then sell on the news, too.' "
Most strategists readily say that in 1993 the market's flow is bound to change. But many are recommending the same investments -- small stocks especially -- that performed well last year. They argue that larger, global companies are more vulnerable to recessions abroad.
Individuals, especially, tend to keep doing what has recently worked best. They are so likely to lose money chasing the hottest stocks or mutual funds that some analysts take their actions as sound indicators of what not to do.
The risks this year may be especially high. Most analysts agree that the market is already expensive. The stocks that constitute the Standard & Poor's 500 cost $24 for each $1 of earnings, and pay an annual dividend of about 2.9 percent. An earnings multiple of at most 16 and a yield of 4 to 5 percent are more typical.
To satisfy investor fancies, Wall Street's hothouses produced $39 billion in new issues, easily a record. But as many of 1991's biotechs wilted, investment firms cultivated new restaurant stocks instead, once again selling as perennials some exotic, expensive blooms whose popularity might not survive another season.
An overpriced market, like an overpriced currency, can persist, however, as it did throughout the last year. Many strategists, including Mr. Birinyi and Steven G. Einhorn of Goldman, Sachs & Company, say individual investors will keep feeding their renewed appetite for stocks, animating the market for years to come.
The recovery might also help corporate profits continue to catch up with the market, as companies have become so efficient that any pickup in business will amplify earnings. Stefan D. Abrams, a portfolio manager at the Trust Company of the West, predicts that the earnings underlying the S.& P. 500 will be more than $26 next year, up from about $22 this year and enough to sustain at least a 15 percent gain in stock prices.
 
Little Room for Disappointment

 
 But all these assumptions about individual investors, the economy, interest rates and profits leave little room for disappointment, said Robert Farrell, a senior investment adviser at Merrill Lynch. Even if interest rates stay low, he says, investors turning over their certificates of deposit this year will find their income little changed. Some will still seek out bonds or stocks but probably not as many as last year, when investors faced the prospect of renewing at much-reduced yields.
Once again, many mutual fund managers can lure customers by trumpeting that they bested the S.& P. 500 last year -- a feat that, if they happened to be running small- stock funds, was as easy as hitting foul shots from 10 feet out, rather than the usual 15.
Many major institutions were shooting from 20 feet out, especially those that invest most of their money in an index of larger stocks. For many pension funds, only a broad range of the biggest stocks can absorb the billions, even tens of billions, that they must invest.
Some fund managers who index their investments are prodding the companies, like I.B.M. and Westinghouse, that are dragging these indexes down. "If you're 400 or below in the S.& P. 500, you're almost guaranteed to get a call from us," said Dale M. Hansen, executive director of the California Public Employees Retirement System, referring to his five-year performance rankings.
Many other money managers say that this year will again reward stock pickers, of issues large and small, over those who stay with an index of major stocks. To say otherwise, of course, could put their own jobs at risk.
Still, as Heraclitus, the ancient Greek philosopher, said, "The oracle neither reveals nor conceals, but intimates," a thought that might chasten any modern-day prophets who claim that the market's 1992 intimations yield clear guidance about the course of 1993.

HEADLINE: Princeton Economist to Be Named To Clinton's Council, Aides Say

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Responding to pressure to name a prominent mainstream economist to the Council of Economic Advisers, President-elect Bill Clinton has offered a seat on the council to Alan Blinder of Princeton University, and Mr. Blinder has accepted, aides to Mr. Clinton and others familiar with the appointment said over the weekend.
Mr. Blinder, whose appointment is likely to be announced this week, would serve under Laura D'Andrea Tyson, a Stanford University economist. Some economists have criticized Ms. Tyson's appointment, arguing that her speciality, industrial and trade issues, has not given her the broad skills needed by a chairman of the council. 
 Mr. Blinder's appointment would help to counter this criticism; he is highly regarded as a macroeconomist, a specialty that carries considerable status in his profession.
 
Effects of Policies on Economy
 Macroeconomists employ mathematical formulas and computer models, among other techniques, in attempts to determine how the economy might respond to particular Government policies or other economic developments. Among the policies likely to be proposed by a Clinton Administration and evaluated by the council are increased spending on public works, an income tax cut for the middle class or a higher gasoline tax. Macroeconomists also try to forecast turns in the economy -- the likelihood of recoveries or recessions.
The chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers has generally overshadowed the two other members, working directly with the President while the others have stayed in the background, their names almost unknown to the public. But as a macro-economist, Mr. Blinder is likely to play a prominent role on the council, since he is considered more suited than Ms. Tyson to performing a crucial task of the council: assessing the impact of proposed policies.
"I will be vastly reassured if Alan Blinder is named to the Council of Economic Advisers," said Paul R. Krugman, a macroeconomist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who had himself been a candidate for the chairmanship. "He would provide the necessary analytical skills that Laura Tyson lacks."
Ms. Tyson came to Mr. Clinton's attention during the campaign and has helped to draft amendments to President Bush's free trade agreement with Mexico and Canada that Mr. Clinton might insist on after his inauguration. These would, in effect, require Mexico to enforce its labor and anti-pollution laws.
 
Worked With Clinton's Campaign
 Mr. Blinder also helped with the campaign, and he spoke on macroeconomic issues at Mr. Clinton's recent economic get-together in Little Rock, Ark. Reached by telephone yesterday, the economist declined comment on the reports of his appointment. During the campaign, he came out in favor of increasing the deficit to finance public works spending, a position favored by many economists who supported Mr. Clinton.
Mr. Blinder, 47, has been an economics professor at Princeton, his alma mater, since 1969. He received his Ph.D. at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and is the author or co-author of three books on economics. If Congress approves his appointment, this will be his first Government job.
No one has yet been publicly identified as a likely candidate for the third seat on the Council of Economic Advisers.
Until Ms. Tyson's surprise appointment last month as chairman, Mr. Blinder had been mentioned in press reports as a leading candidate for the job, along with Mr. Krugman and Lawrence H. Summers, a Harvard macroeconomist who took a leave as chief economist at the World Bank to work with Mr. Clinton's transition team.
Mr. Summers in particular was publicly endorsed for the job by prominent university economists. And his appointment seemed likely until a proposal of his on waste disposal came to the attention of the Clinton camp. It suggested that waste products might be shipped to third world countries, bringing him into disfavor with Vice President-elect Al Gore.
 
Academic Economists' Envoy
 Mr. Krugman and many other macroeconomists, particularly those in academia, have come to consider the three-member Council of Economic Advisers as their "embassy" in Washington. Because they view the council as their chief means of influencing Administration policy, they urged Mr. Clinton to appoint a top macroeconomist who would properly practice their skills and represent their views.
When Mr. Clinton named Ms. Tyson instead, she was publicly criticized by other economists as not only lacking the necessary qualifications for the job but also as favoring managed trade and Government support for key American industries. Neither view is popular among most mainstream academic economists, who generally prefer a minimal Government role in the economy. This disagreement has helped to fuel the criticism of Ms. Tyson, several economists, who insisted that they not be named, said in interviews.
Ms. Tyson declined to be interviewed. An aide said she would not speak with journalists until after her confirmation hearing, which is expected this month.
Her appointment also raised the issue of rankings within the profession. Mr. Krugman and other economists argued that after 12 years of Republican Administrations, the chairmanship of the council should go to one of the Democrats among the ranks of the top macroeconomists.
"Despite what people say about economists always disagreeing with each other, there is agreement on rankings within the profession," Mr. Krugman said.
"There is a pecking order," he continued, citing Nobel laureates in economics like Paul Samuelson, Robert M. Solow and James Tobin as those at the pinnacle in the over-65 generation. All are Democrats. Mr. Blinder, Mr. Lawrence and Mr. Krugman, also Democrats, are ranked among the top 20 or so in the younger generation.
 In some copies, the article also misstated the affiliation of Paul R. Krugman. He is an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, not Harvard.

HEADLINE: The Media Business: Press Notes;
Amid Newspapers' Gloom, The Readers Start to Return

BYLINE: By William Glaberson

 BODY:
Conspiracy theorists in the newspaper industry have long suggested that publishers slyly emphasize signs of gloom. Then, goes the thinking, they can justify cutbacks, price increases and general Scrooge-ishness.
Unfortunately for publishers wedded to the doomsday scenario, 1992 brought some really good news for the news business. 
 People were actually reading newspapers in numbers large enough to lead some analysts to say that the industry's most troubling long-term trend, a decades-long readership slide, may have been reversed. A larger percentage of adult Americans read newspapers in 1992 than read them the year before.
"There's a lot of life in the old mare yet," said Albert E. Gollin, research director of the Newspaper Association of America, the national publishers' organization.
Thirty years ago, more than three quarters of Americans -- 77.6 percent -- read daily newspapers, according to a much cited annual survey by Simmons Market Research Bureau. Simmons has documented a persistent decline over the years, to 62.4 percent in 1990.
A few blips have appeared in readership numbers over the last three decades, but none, Mr. Gollin said, offered the hope of the 1992 increase. Simmons showed a jump from 62.1 percent of adults who were daily newspaper readers in 1991 to 62.6 percent in 1992, representing an increase from 113.3 to 115.3 million readers. Sunday editions drew nearly four million more readers in 1992.
With advertising sales still anemic and profit margins remaining a shadow of their former selves, publishers still have plenty to complain about. With the conspiracy theory in mind, reporters and editors take heed: It may be a bit premature to ask for that raise.
Imitation Is O.K. No Joke.
Joseph B. Meagher, chief executive of Yankee Publishing Inc., was licking his wounds last week after ending up on the losing side of a major free-press pronouncement in late December by a Federal district judge in New York City.
Yankee, based in Dublin, N.H., publishes The Old Farmer's Almanac, which got into a battle in 1990 with New York magazine. New York, in an effort to amuse, illustrated its Christmas cover that year with a likeness of the Almanac's distinctive yellow cover and carried on its theme of imitation through the edition.
Instead of offering typical Almanac fare of "astronomical tables, tides, holidays, eclipses, etc.," New York instead promised "210 gifts for the flush and the broke, the sober and the silly, the vile and the virtuous."
Mr. Meagher and his colleagues at Yankee Publishing didn't get the joke. They sued.
The case pitted The Farmer's Almanac's trademark rights against New York's First Amendment rights. New York won. Judge Pierre N. Laval cleared the way for publishers to imitate each other even when they are not engaging in parody, which courts have recognized as protected by the Constitution. The legal issue, the judge said, is whether a publisher is trying to impart a "communicative message."
The message that New York's editors intended to communicate, the judge ruled, was the comic point that the recession would send trendy New York readers toward the thriftiness supposedly exemplified by The Almanac.
In an interview from New Hampshire, Mr. Meagher said the company is considering an appeal. He said he is still steaming because New York's editors did not ask permission to imitate the Almanac. "They behaved," he said, "like rude New Yorkers."
Told of the slur, Edward Kosner, editor and president of New York, responded: "Tell it to the judge."
For a winner, New York was taking plenty of lumps all around. One part of Judge Laval's opinion suggested that New York's attempt at humor, while not a legal violation, may have been even worse: not funny. Mr. Kosner said that passage of the ruling was "less crystalline" than the rest.
"It was clear," Judge Laval wrote, "New York was making a joke, but it was less clear exactly what the joke was."
Everybody's a critic.
'Saturday Night' Spinoff
Live! From New York, it's a magazine.
Spin, the youth-oriented music-media-politics-pop culture publication, turned its entire February edition over to the cast and writers of "Saturday Night Live." The result is a sort of television show in print and, to hear Valerie J. Green, the general manager, tell it, it is also a demographic dream.
"Special issues sell extremely well on the newsstand, and that attracts a lot of advertisers," she said. Added to that, she said, is the fact that many of the television program's millions of viewers fall into Spin's target young, affluent audience (the average reader of the 305,016-circulation magazine is 23.6 years old). Humor, she said, is a big draw for that group.
So, on your newsstand soon: Spin's spin on a certain female celebrity's recent, very expensive, explicit book (hint: whips and chains are involved).
Also, there are exclusives. One is the true story of Jim Morrison's mother's reaction to the Oedipal rage that helped make him the Lizard King. ("No TV, no telephone. Now go to your room!") Do people who are 23.6 know who Jim Morrison was?
In a way, this year's guest-editor issue is an affirmation of humor after Spin's last guest-editor issue, which was heavily social and political. In 1991, Amnesty International took over an entire edition at the invitation of Spin's editor and publisher, Bob Guccione Jr., son of the Penthouse impresario who broke with the senior Guccione over the direction of Spin several years ago.
There was little demographically appropriate humor, Ms. Green said, in the Amnesty International issue. "What," she asked, "can you basically do with torture and human oppression?"

HEADLINE: POLITICAL MEMO;
Cuomo Eyes Washington For New Set of Reasons

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 3

 BODY:
As he prepares to deliver his 11th State of the State Message on Wednesday, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo stands at one of the most awkward junctures of his political life.
With Bill Clinton's inauguration just over two weeks away, even Mr. Cuomo's most loyal lieutenants concede that the Governor, a Democrat, has diminishing relevance as a national spokesman for his party and his region. All eyes will be focused on Washington this year, with only an occasional glance toward Albany. 
 But in Albany, Mr. Cuomo is girding for yet another year of relentlessly bad news. The state faces a wide budget gap for the fifth consecutive year. And with the Governor determined to avoid tax increases, that means another round of cuts that will come perilously close to the muscle and bone of state agencies and programs.
The Legislature remains gridlocked, with the Assembly controlled by Democrats, the Senate controlled by Republicans, and nonpartisan leadership in short supply. Any chance for significant change died on Nov. 3, when voters maintained the 35-seat majority held by the Republicans in the 61-seat Senate and increased the Democratic majority in the 150-member Assembly to 101 seats from 95.
 
Republicans Seem Unintimidated
 The December battle between Mr. Cuomo and Senate leaders reinforced the notion that the Governor, for all his news conferences and appeals to public opinion, does not intimidate the Republicans in the slightest.
First, they rejected his call for a special session to deal with transportation financing issues, requiring the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to include an April fare increase in its budget. Two weeks later, they balked at the Governor's plan to bail out Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, forcing the Cuomo administration to approve a huge health insurance rate increase for 1.4 million New Yorkers on New Year's Eve.
In this environment, the 60-year-old Mr. Cuomo, who has been Governor since 1983 and has worked in state government since 1975, must decide how he will spend the rest of his life. Mr. Cuomo said last week that he would probably decide by the end of this year whether to run for a fourth four-year term in 1994.
If he completed a fourth term, surpassing the longevity mark of 15 years set by Nelson A. Rockefeller, Mr. Cuomo would leave a statistical legacy even if history gave mixed grades to his record.
Largely because they can think of nothing else Mr. Cuomo wants to do, the Governor's closest advisers assume that he will run unless Mr. Clinton appoints him to the Supreme Court. And Mr. Cuomo does not stop far short of saying so himself.
 
'With Both Fists Flying'
 "What if people told you you're not as popular as you used to be?" he asked himself in an interview. "O.K., so what? They told me I couldn't win in '82, and maybe I can't. But I can certainly go out with both fists flying and that's the way I would want to do it."
"So the only question really is do you believe that you could govern effectively and well for the people of the state and better than the people who might replace you. If I conclude yes, then I would choose to run unless there was something else I could do that would be more significant."
Contributing to the awkwardness of the moment for Mr. Cuomo is the degree to which his future now depends on Mr. Clinton. Only a year ago, Mr. Cuomo was taking Mr. Clinton to task on national television for saying that Mr. Cuomo "acts like" a member of the Mafia.
During the campaign, Mr. Clinton made conciliatory gestures by musing publicly on two occasions about the possibility of appointing Mr. Cuomo to the Supreme Court.
 
Justices May Not Oblige
 But campaign oratory is one thing; governing is another. First there must be a vacancy, and neither Mr. Clinton nor Mr. Cuomo has any control over the retirement schedules of the sitting justices. And Cuomo advisers recognize -- particularly after watching the President-elect select a Cabinet -- that Mr. Clinton may feel great pressure to use his first appointment to nominate a woman, a minority justice or a younger one.
In the meantime, while Mr. Cuomo shows no decline in his formidable energy and enthusiasm for his job, he concedes that he is frustrated by the continuing doldrums of the New York economy, the obstinacy of the Senate, and what he sees as the news media's failure to focus on his achievements.
In such times, Mr. Cuomo measures success not by the enactment of grand new programs, like the Decade of the Child initiatives he proposed in 1988, but by more basic accomplishments like passing a budget that was on time and in balance, holding the line against tax increases, and making spending cuts surgically rather than randomly.
Using that yardstick, Mr. Cuomo declared 1992 "a very good year." But he predicted that 1993 would pose the same challenges.
 
'Repair Work' in 1993
 "Is it going to be fun?" he asked. "No. Is there going to be heartbreak? A lot, yes. It's repair work. It's difficult work. It's keeping the place together."
By necessity, Mr. Cuomo will not propose any expensive new programs in his speech on Wednesday, administration officials say.
Instead, the address is expected to focus on the state's new relationship with Washington. The Governor will continue to use the Legislature as a foil by pushing for political reforms, like public campaign financing, and he will turn up the heat in his calls for a constitutional convention that would let the public circumvent the lawmakers.
Aides said that Mr. Cuomo has also become enthusiastic about a series of technological proposals. One would use the state's Dormitory Authority to finance the connection of every school and university in the state with fiber optics, so that a professor in Buffalo could teach a class with students in Queens. He is also expected to propose creation of a center in Albany dedicated to finding new ways to use technology to make state government more efficient.
 
Bad Mood Since Election Day
 Some Cuomo aides say they have seen no bitterness or second-guessing from the Governor about the fact that another Democrat is about to become President. Indeed, his Washington counsel, Brad Johnson, said Mr. Cuomo was thrilled about "having a Federal partner that we haven't had for 12 years."
But other aides, all of whom requested anonymity, say that Mr. Cuomo has been more irascible than usual since Election Day. They say there are times when Mr. Cuomo seems to crave a spotlight that has all but darkened, even if it means attaching himself to someone else's star.
While traveling in Italy in November, Mr. Cuomo had aides call reporters in New York to lobby for stories about his meeting with a local hero, the Mafia prosecutor Antonio DiPietro. On a trip to Dallas in early December, he called on Ross Perot and then described the meeting at length in news conferences in Dallas and Albany.
He also has rarely missed an opportunity to stress his closeness to the Clinton transition team, whether by noting the number of New Yorkers involved or by drawing comparisons between his economic policies and those of Mr. Clinton.
 
'Basically a New York Team'
 "The economic plan is as close to my plan as if I could have done it myself," he said in an interview last month. "And the team is basically a New York team, except for Bentsen."
When asked at a news conference in December whether he had had any discussions with the Clinton staff about the Supreme Court, Mr. Cuomo said, "I've spoken to a lot of people, including Governor Riley, who's an old friend of mine, and Stephanopoulos and Mickey Kantor and all of those people whose names you see." He said they had not specifically discussed the Court.
While settling in to await word from Mr. Clinton, Mr. Cuomo remains, as always, philosophical about the coming year and about his own future.
"It really turns on your view of life," he said. "How are you supposed to use it? Are you supposed to use it delighting yourself? Well, one simple conclusion could be you're supposed to use it trying to do significant things. Trying to do significant things. That's different than doing significant things. I cannot guarantee that my efforts will succeed. I can guarantee that they will be total, consuming, honorable and oriented toward success. That's all."

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN MOSCOW: Bush and Yeltsin Sign Pact Making Deep Missile Cuts;
A Last Treaty Of Its Kind

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 3

 BODY:
If nostalgia enveloped George Bush on his 25th and probably final foreign adventure as President, there was also some nostalgia for the old sureties of traditional arms control.
 Given its very sweep, the second Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, known as Start II, is likely to be the last agreement of its kind. It represents both the triumph and the limit of two-way negotiations on arms control in a world that is no longer bipolar. 
The Soviet Union may have been a totalitarian menace, but its military commanders -- especially compared with the military commanders in some of the world's current trouble spots -- were responsible professionals who knew the dangers of the weapons they brandished or faced, and who could largely be expected to keep to the letter of the agreements they signed, however long or hard the negotiation.
 
New Cast of Nuclear Powers
 There was no fuss then about ratification by parliaments or any need to assuage the wounded pride of new states, like Ukraine, that woke up as nuclear powers and started to like the way it looked in the mirror.
 Each difficult, incremental treaty on the road to Start II felt momentous -- not because arms were reduced in any meaningful way, but because the gap of ideology and misperceptions crossed by the superpowers was so cavernous and the rope across it seemed so thin.
 The treaty is a legitimately momentous agreement, around which President Bush, President Boris N. Yeltsin and their speech writers did their best to spin flourishes of oratory about peace, children, trust and brotherhood. But there was a curious lack of moment.
 This odd fact was caused in part bythe haste of negotiation, and in part by Russia's impoverished condition, as an imploded empire reaching for aid and acceptance. Russia's diminished status seemed to intensify Mr. Bush's, even though he is a lame-duck President.
 But there is a deep, underlying sense that the new world is not only more complicated, but also considerably more volatile than the old. The end of the cold war straitjacket has meant the start of conflicts based on old nationalisms and economic rivalries, just as the collapse of the old fears of mutual assured destruction and nuclear holocaust has made the world safe for conventional war.
 
Disagreement Over Serbs
 As much as Mr. Bush and Mr. Yeltsin talked of cooperation and partnership, they clearly have their disagreements over how to deal with Serbian aggression in the former Yugoslavia. Mr. Yeltsin must face Russian conservatives and some nationalists who say they feel that he has already betrayed their "Serbian brethren" as well as old Soviet allies in Iraq, Syria, Cuba and elsewhere.
 The shelling over Mogadishu, Somalia, while Mr. Bush spent Friday night on an American naval vessel offshore was a reminder of the limits of relief intervention and feel-good gestures that Russian-American amity cannot solve. In Cambodia, where Washington and Moscow brokered a peace treaty through the United Nations Security Council, the Khmer Rouge's blatant defiance of that treaty and their continual kidnapping of United Nations peacekeeping troops promises a future renewal of horrors that could make Serbian behavior seem civilized.
The disclosures of Iraq's long and secret efforts to develop chemical and nuclear weapons, despite intermittent international inspections and despite Baghdad's signature on treaties that should have banned such programs, is a reminder of the actual value of treaties intended to stop the spread of arms. The behavior of Western companies that knowingly sold advanced machinery to Iraq that could be used for weapons-making raises questions about how former Soviet companies and their skilled scientists will act in a free-market system with porous border controls.
 
Future Tasks Cited
 Senior American officials here spoke of the future tasks of arms control, pointing to the Chemical Weapons Convention, scheduled to be signed shortly in Paris, and the effort to extend the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty beyond 1995.
 But they also understand how difficult Start II will be to ratify and carry out, even assuming that Ukraine, Belarus and Kazakhstan follow through on their pledges to become non-nuclear states. According to a study by the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, the United States and Russia each employ more than a million people to build, field and maintain their nuclear arsenals. Dismantling these structures will present fundamental political, economic and environmental problems. Dismantling the weapons themselves, plus thousands of tactical nuclear weapons, is full of dangers.
 The Harvard study estimates that the Russians will have to destroy 100,000 metric tons of liquid rocket propellant, which explodes on contact with air, as well as safely transport, store and protect the highly prized nuclear material in all those warheads.
 Washington has promised direct financial and technical aid to Moscow and Kiev for these purposes, but the cost of dismantling these arsenals safely is likely to be shocking, diplomats suggest, far in excess of the initial American installment of $800 million.
 
Democracy as Arms Control
 One senior American official said wanly that "democracy is the best form of arms control," arguing that democratic nations do not start wars.
 But it is always possible, as Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev of Russia made clear last month in his stunning mock speech in Stockholm, that the Russian Government may one day end up in the hands of extreme nationalist, anti-Western politicians or military men who will treat Start II much as President Saddam Hussein of Iraq treated his solemn commitments.
 Another American official cautioned that there were limits to Washington's ability to influence events here or even to control how Russia carries out the treaty.
 "Both the financial obligations and the willingness to undertake the task are responsibilities that Russia and the other parties are accepting themselves," he said. "It is the Russian people and their leadership in this present instance who want to put some of the worst and most destabilizing aspects of the nuclear age behind us and accept that responsibility. We can help, but we're by no means the principal actor."
LEASHING WEAPONS: 30 YEARS OF PACTS
 August 1963 (Limited Test Ban Treaty): Prohibits nuclear testing or any other nuclear explosions in the atmosphere, in outer space and under water.
January 1967 (Outer Space Treaty): Prohibits sending nuclear weapons into Earth orbit, placing nuclear weapons on celestial bodies or stationing them in outer space.
July 1968 (Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty): Prohibits the transfer of nuclear weapons to other countries and prohibits helping countries without nuclear weapons to make or or acquire them. May 1972 (Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty): Bans space-based defensive missile systems and limits the United States and Soviet Union to one ground-based defensive missile site each.
July 1974 (Threshold Test Ban Treaty): The Soviet Union and United States agree
 to limit underground nuclear weapons tests.
June 1979 (Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty): The first formal strategic arms treaty sets an initial overall limit of 2,400 intercontinental ballistic missile launchers, submarine-launched missiles, heavy bombers and air-to-surface missiles, with the ceiling to be lowered in stages later.
December 1987 (Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty): Provides for the dismantling of all Soviet and American medium- and shorter-range land-based missiles and establishes a system of weapons inspection to guard against violations.
November 1990 (Conventional Forces in Europe Treaty): Originally negotiated between the members of NATO and the Warsaw Pact, the treaty limits the number of tanks, artillery, armored combat vehicles, combat aircraft and combat helicopters that each side is allowed to maintain in Europe.
July 1991 (Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty - Start I): Brings the number of Soviet long-range nuclear warheads down from 11,012 to 6,163 and the United States warheads from 12,646 to 8,556.
January 1993 (Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty - Start II): Slashes the superpowers' arsenals to a third of their current size. The American arsenal will be cut to 3,500 warheads and bombs, while the Russians will be down to 3,000 warheads and bombs. The reductions are to be carried out by 2003.
(Source: Arms Control Association for warhead numbers for Start I and II.)

HEADLINE: STRICTLY BUSINESS;
How the Music Stopped For the Record Hunter

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
People still meander up to the entrance of the Record Hunter on Fifth Avenue between 42d and 43d Streets. They pause before the locked door, and some notice a scrawled sign saying that mail-forwarding forms have been sent to the postmaster. A few read a photocopied statement in the window telling of the financial tailspin of a store beloved by fans of jazz and classical music.
 Posted 11 days before Christmas, it tells of overexpanding during a bitter recession that has seen a drop-off in sales of all types of recordings, of mounting losses and shrinking inventories. It speaks of the sadness of closing after 47 years. It ends with a wish: "May you always keep the sound of music alive." 
Last week, Jay Sonin, the president and owner of the Record Hunter, was inside doing the grim work of taking his final inventory, making sure his final tax bill would be paid and answering the endlessly ringing phone. He wore a sweatshirt and blue jeans and smoked lots of cigarettes. What he seemed to cling to, beneath the numbness, was a bittersweet pride.
 "On a per-square-foot basis, we did more business than any record store in the world," he declared. "Every single record company told me that over the years."
 
'Your Last at Bat'
 Mr. Sonin, who is 52 years old and uncertain what he will do next, said without emotion that only his failure, not his years of success, would be remembered. "In life people remember your last at bat," he said.
 Perhaps not. "What a tragedy," said George Volckening of Qualiton Imports, an importer of classical records. "To me, it's part of history."
"It was the last of the major mom-and-pop operations," said Larry Palmacci, vice president of sales and marketing for Esquire Records Inc.
 Customers particularly share the distress. "I'm really sad," said Irene Soja, a secretary. And Harold Chester, a medical journal editor, said, "It had a certain character to it that the larger franchise stores don't have."
 Mr. Sonin's father was in the jukebox business and he himself began working in record stores at age 16. "The only thing to do was get in trouble or go to work," he said of the opportunities in the Brooklyn of his adolescence. "I worked hard."
 He worked for wholesalers, for department stores, for the record department of a sporting-goods store.
 
His First Record Store
 By 1964, he had accumulated enough money and experience to buy his first record store, World of Music on Lexington Avenue between 47th and 48th Streets. It amounted to 600 square feet of opportunity. He did well, and in 1973 a credit manager for a major record company asked if he was interesting in expanding. The Record Hunter was for sale.
 It was something of an august institution, having opened in 1945, and for years it occupied a spot a few doors down from Carnegie Hall, with opera stars among its customers. But the founder had died, and his wife and son were having a difficult go at the Fifth Avenue location. Creditors were soliciting bids for a replacement.
 Mr. Sonin beat out a now-defunct chain of record stores called King Karol. He paid $65,000 for the name, the mailing list, fixtures and the remaining 28 months on the lease. In 1976, he signed his own 15-year lease: $90,000 a year for 7,400 square feet.
 "It wasn't an excellent deal," he said. "I made it an excellent deal."
 What he did was move forward the storefront, which had been recessed from the building line, to make more space. He created a candy store from a vestibule and rented it. In the store's rear, he made space for an audio-visual department and rented that. His own rent cost was cut in half.
 Things went well. He hired a knowledgeable sales staff, many of whom were musicians or music students. He concentrated on classical music, which became 45 percent of his business, compared with maybe 3 or 4 percent for most record stores. Pop was available, but not emphasized -- both because of the image Mr. Sonin desired and because the profit margin was less than on specially ordered classical recordings.
 "You don't have to be a genius to sell the Rolling Stones," he said.
 
Big Jump in Lease
 Things started to go wrong in 1989, when Mr. Sonin began to have discussions about renewing his lease in 1991. His landlord wanted $450,000 a year, more than four times what he was paying. He didn't see how he could go above $250,000 and began scouting for another location.
 He found one at Broadway and 19th Street, a lively shopping and entertainment area. He spent almost $700,000 to renovate the store. Then one thing after another went wrong.
 It took 11 months for the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission to approve his plans. His lease turned out to be for six years rather than the 17 he thought he had negotiated. But Mr. Sonin finally opened there in October 1990.
 Though he had expected not to make money at first, he was staggered by his losses. His large advertising expenditures, live bands and sweeping searchlights made no difference. People were just buying fewer records. "People who used to come in and buy four or five compact disks were buying one or two," he said. "And people who bought one or two just weren't coming in."
 He was experiencing firsthand an overall trend in the industry. In 1991, the number of all types of recordings sold fell to 801 million from 865.7 million in 1990, the Recording Industry Association of America reported. This year is up only slightly.
 
'A Discretionary Item'
 "A lot of people are out of work, and a lot are afraid of becoming out of work," Mr. Sonin said. "This is a discretionary item."
 Pressures mounted as some creditors demanded cash before delivery. The record companies, which pay most of the cost of record store advertisments, became reluctant to do so. Republic National Bank, Record Hunter's major secured creditor, sued for the money owed it.
 "Frankly I had no defense," Mr. Sonin said. "I had no money."
 The Record Hunter filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Feb. 12, 1992. The creditors committee quickly demanded that it dispose of the money-losing store and try to shore up the Fifth Avenue store.
 But even though the uptown store had weathered other recessions, it now faltered too. The record companies' unwillingness to pay for ads stung deeply, but the worst thing was the inability to get merchandise on credit. Saying no to treasured customers became the order of the day as holiday inventories shrank to $200,000 from a normal $1.5 million.
 A useless irony is that his Fifth Avenue landlord in 1991 lowered the rent enough to have made his disastrous move downtown unnecessary. Mr. Sonin cut staff and hours and did all the other things a businessman does when his back is to the wall.
 "Right up until the end," he said, "I had hopes of turning it around."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jay Sonin, the president and owner of the Record Hunter, which had to close its doors on Fifth Avenue 11 days before Christmas. "On a per-square-foot basis, we did more business than any record store in the world," he declared. "Every single record company told me that over the years." (Edward Keating/The New York Times)
