LENGTH: 1825 words

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN MOSCOW: Bush and Yeltsin Sign Pact Making Deep Missile Cuts;
It Would Reduce Atom Arsenals About 75%

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 3

 BODY:
With a flourish of oratory and a dash of wistfulness, Presidents Bush and Boris N. Yeltsin signed a treaty today calling for the most significant rollback yet in the formidable nuclear arsenal of the cold war.
 The signing ceremony in the richly embellished St. Vladimir Hall of the Grand Kremlin Palace was the centerpiece of a two-day "working visit" that also marked Mr. Bush's last curtain call in the East-West drama that defined so much of his presidency. 
The new Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, known as Start II, called on the two nuclear giants to eliminate almost three-quarters of their 20,000-odd nuclear warheads by 2003, scrapping some of their most threatening weapons. President Yeltsin called the treaty "the core of the system of global security guarantees." [Excerpts from the press conference, page A8.]
 
A Major Threat Removed
 The process includes the total elimination of the most formidable weapon yet concocted, the multi-warhead land-based missile. These missiles, which can each launch many separately aimed nuclear warheads, form the backbone of Russia's arsenal. A senior American official declared that in bringing these weapons to an end "once and for all," the treaty would eliminate "that dreaded thing called the first strike."
 The treaty, to be completed in two phases, also calls for deep cuts in missiles launched from submarines and bombers, the main pillar of America's nuclear deterrent.
 Though by far the most extensive disarmament treaty ever signed, the bulk of Start II was negotiated in a mere six months, compared with the decade it took for each of the earlier strategic arms limitation treaties, known as SALT, and the first strategic arms reduction treaty. The speed of the feat seemed to show what the treaty itself termed "the new realities that have transformed the political and strategic relations between the Parties."
 
'Centuries-Old Dream'
 Neither President skimped on hyperbole in prepared statements read before aides and reporters who had witnessed the signing.
 Mr. Yeltsin said: "It is not every century that history gives us an opportunity to witness and participate in an event that is so significant in scale and consequences. The treaty signed today represents a major step toward fulfilling mankind's centuries-old dream of disarmament."
 Mr. Bush said: "We meet at the beginning of a new year and at a moment that is also a new era for our two nations and for the world. We stand together today in this great city at the threshold of a new world of hope, a widening circle of freedom for us and for our children."
 But the first reaction in the Russian media was a warning not to "pop champagne corks yet." In its report on the summit meeting, a Russian television news program noted that the Ukrainian Parliament seemed to be moving further from ratifying the first Start treaty, a prerequisite for the new one to go into effect.
 
Resistance in Moscow
The commentary further noted that despite Mr. Yeltsin's assurances to the contrary, the conservative Russian Parliament could also balk at ratifying a treaty that many conservative Russians might view as lopsided in favor of the United States.
 There were other dramas that the summit pomp also failed to conceal.
 First was the fact that Mr. Bush has only numbered days left in his presidency.
 In 17 days, the treaty he signed and the American-Russian relationship that took shape under him would be passed on to President-elect Bill Clinton.
 Both presidents stressed that Mr. Clinton had endorsed their efforts, and Mr. Yeltsin announced that he had sent a letter to the next American President urging that they meet "in a neutral place" as soon as possible after the Inauguration.
 
A Good-Bye for Bush
 But Mr. Yeltsin made a point of paying a warm tribute "to my colleague and friend, George," and there were some who thought they spotted a misting of Mr. Bush's eyes when the burly Russian turned to him and said, "Spasibo, George" -- "Thank you, George."
 That note of farewell weaved through Mr. Bush's entire trip, first in Somalia, where the President spent New Year's with troops bringing relief supplies, and this evening in Paris, where Mr. Bush was to dine with Francois Mitterrand, the French President.
 On his arrival in Moscow from Somalia, Mr. Bush was joined by his wife, Barbara, by James A. Baker 3d, his former Secretary of State, and by Brent Scowcroft, his national security adviser, giving the proceedings the air of a last reunion.
 The ornate trappings of past summits were scrapped in favor of a low-key "working meeting" that included only one relatively restrained banquet and the signing ceremony. The only unofficial activity was a brief tour of the Kremlin by the two Presidents and their wives, during which they dropped in on one of the series of annual New Year's spectacles for children.
 
Santa Backs the Treaty
 As the leaders walked in, Grandfather Frost -- the Russian Santa Claus -- intoned, "Today, children, a wonderful treaty will be signed, which will make all our lives easier."
 But with Russia closed down for a long New Year's weekend, during which no newspapers were published, many Russians were barely aware that the American president was in their midst.
 One who was quite aware was Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last Soviet president. A senior aide to Mr. Gorbachev, Anatoly Chernyayev, expressed dismay to Reuters that Mr. Bush totally ignored his former partner in detente, especially now that the American had "nothing to lose."
 
Standing on the Tank
 But Mr. Bush seemed more keen to claim a new garland than to delve in the past. "Today the cold war is over, and for the first time in history, an American President has set foot in a democratic Russia," he declared.
 He then heaped praise on Mr. Yeltsin, "for your unwavering commitment to democratic reform and for the history you've written since the heroic day in August '91 when you climbed atop that tank to defend Russia's democratic destiny."
 That kind of tribute was one reason Mr. Yeltsin had pushed for the summit meeting at the start of a new year. He had concluded the last one with a humiliating drubbing at the Congress of Peoples' Deputies in December, when he was forced to jettison Yegor T. Gaidar, a market-oriented economist, as his chief of Government and to name in his stead a conservative manager, Viktor Chernomyrdin.
 Mr. Chernomyrdin sat impassively alongside Vice President Aleksandr Rutskoi, another political thorn in Mr. Yeltsin's side, as the Russian President reported that he had "assured" Mr. Bush that the new Prime Minister would continue "on the same road of reforms."
 The first question to Mr. Yeltsin by a Russian reporter highlighted another problem he faces, the resistance the increasingly hard-line Parliament might show to ratifying the treaty.
 Die-hard Communists and far-right Russian nationalists resent what they perceive as Mr. Yeltsin's kowtowing to the West and have actively resisted his foreign policy, including his disarmament efforts.
 "I am not going to conceal from you that a certain part of the deputies are against the treaty," Mr. Yeltsin said. But he insisted they were a minority, and that the treaty would be approved.
 Both presidents went to some length to claim that the treaty was fair to both sides. Senior American officials noted that it included concessions not considered before, like letting the Russians peek at sections of the B-2 bomber to see how many nuclear bombs it could carry.
 The reductions called for in Start II are to come in two phases: the first within seven years after the treaty goes into effect, and the second by 2003 -- or sooner if the United States can help Russia pay the costs of eliminating strategic weapons.
 
Strongest U.S. Suit
 But Russian critics were certain to decry the total loss of their vaunted SS-18 missile, which can carry up to 10 independently targeted warheads, while America gets to keep a portion of its submarine-based missiles.
 Mr. Yeltsin protested that even after the reductions, Russia would have 3,500 warheads, more than any power other than the United States. "This is a powerful shield, which is capable of defending Russia in case of an unexpected aggression from any side," he declared.
 "May I simply add that we do not view this as a one-sided treaty at all," Mr. Bush said. "We view it as balanced and I think that history will record it as such."
 Even more worrisome was the position of Ukraine. Like Belarus and Kazakhstan, the other republics with nuclear missiles stationed on their territory, the Ukrainian Government has agreed to observe the first Start treaty and to transfer nuclear weapons to Russia for dismantling. But the Ukrainian Parliament has so far failed to ratify Start I, demanding that it first receive ample compensation and security guarantees against Russia.
 The Ukrainian President, Leonid M. Kravchuk, who has repeatedly assured Western and Russian leaders that Ukraine will come through, issued a statement today hailing Start II as a "momentous event."
 But Mr. Kravchuk gave no date for his Parliament to take up disarmament. Instead, he called for negotiations with Russia on "a wide range of technical and financial questions" related to the nuclear weapons.
ARMS TREATY HIGHLIGHTS
 The Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty signed yesterday by President Bush and President Boris N. Yeltsin calls for a two-thirds reduction in the strategic nuclear arsenals of the United States and Russia by the year 2003. Each side would end up with 3,000 to 3,500 warheads. These are some of the major provisions:
 -- A ban on all long-range land-based missiles with multiple nuclear warheads, long regarded as the most destabilizing weapons. That means elimination of Russia's SS-18 missile, the centerpiece of its nuclear forces. Moscow now has 308 of the 10-warhead weapons, and was already committed to dismantle half of them under the arms treaty signed in 1991. The United States would have to scrap or modify its 50 MX missiles, which have 10 warheads each.
 -- Russia may retain -- and reuse for basing other missiles -- 90 of the silos that now house the SS-18s.
 -- Russia may convert 105 of its 170 SS-19 missiles, which now have six warheads apiece, to single-warhead weapons. The United States' Minuteman III missiles, which carry three warheads, may be modified to carry a single warhead.
 -- The United States would have to cut by about half the number of warheads it has on submarine-launched missiles, traditionally the area in which the United States enjoyed the greatest advantage. The number is to drop from 3,456 to 1,728.
 -- The United States would grant Russian inspectors access to its long-range nuclear bomber fleet to verify the types and numbers of weapons being carried.

GRAPHIC: Photos: President Bush and President Boris N. Yeltsin exchanging pens after signing the arms treaty in Moscow. (Associated Press)(pg. 1); President Bush, his wife, Barbara, and President Boris N. Yeltsin attending a children's New Year's party in Moscow. When the leaders arrived, Grandfather Frost, left, the Russian Santa, said, "Today, children, a wonderful treaty will be signed, which will make all our lives easier." (Agence France-Presse)(pg. A8)

He had concluded the last one with a humiliating drubbing at the Congress of Peoples' Deputies in December, when he was forced to jettison Yegor T. Gaidar, a market-oriented economist, as his chief of Government and to name in his stead a conservative manager, Viktor Chernomyrdin.
 Mr. Chernomyrdin sat impassively alongside Vice President Aleksandr Rutskoi, another political thorn in Mr. Yeltsin's side, as the Russian President reported that he had "assured" Mr. Bush that the new Prime Minister would continue "on the same road of reforms."
 The first question to Mr. Yeltsin by a Russian reporter highlighted another problem he faces, the resistance the increasingly hard-line Parliament might show to ratifying the treaty.
 Die-hard Communists and far-right Russian nationalists resent what they perceive as Mr. Yeltsin's kowtowing to the West and have actively resisted his foreign policy, including his disarmament efforts.
 "I am not going to conceal from you that a certain part of the deputies are against the treaty," Mr. Yeltsin said. But he insisted they were a minority, and that the treaty would be approved.
 Both presidents went to some length to claim that the treaty was fair to both sides. Senior American officials noted that it included concessions not considered before, like letting the Russians peek at sections of the B-2 bomber to see how many nuclear bombs it could carry.
 The reductions called for in Start II are to come in two phases: the first within seven years after the treaty goes into effect, and the second by 2003 -- or sooner if the United States can help Russia pay the costs of eliminating strategic weapons.
 
Strongest U.S. Suit
 But Russian critics were certain to decry the total loss of their vaunted SS-18 missile, which can carry up to 10 independently targeted warheads, while America gets to keep a portion of its submarine-based missiles.
 Mr. Yeltsin protested that even after the reductions, Russia would have 3,500 warheads, more than any power other than the United States. "This is a powerful shield, which is capable of defending Russia in case of an unexpected aggression from any side," he declared.
 "May I simply add that we do not view this as a one-sided treaty at all," Mr. Bush said. "We view it as balanced and I think that history will record it as such."
 Even more worrisome was the position of Ukraine. Like Belarus and Kazakhstan, the other republics with nuclear missiles stationed on their territory, the Ukrainian Government has agreed to observe the first Start treaty and to transfer nuclear weapons to Russia for dismantling. But the Ukrainian Parliament has so far failed to ratify Start I, demanding that it first receive ample compensation and security guarantees against Russia.
 The Ukrainian President, Leonid M. Kravchuk, who has repeatedly assured Western and Russian leaders that Ukraine will come through, issued a statement today hailing Start II as a "momentous event."
 But Mr. Kravchuk gave no date for his Parliament to take up disarmament. Instead, he called for negotiations with Russia on "a wide range of technical and financial questions" related to the nuclear weapons.
ARMS TREATY HIGHLIGHTS
 The Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty signed yesterday by President Bush and President Boris N. Yeltsin calls for a two-thirds reduction in the strategic nuclear arsenals of the United States and Russia by the year 2003. Each side would end up with 3,000 to 3,500 warheads. These are some of the major provisions:
 -- A ban on all long-range land-based missiles with multiple nuclear warheads, long regarded as the most destabilizing weapons. That means elimination of Russia's SS-18 missile, the centerpiece of its nuclear forces. Moscow now has 308 of the 10-warhead weapons, and was already committed to dismantle half of them under the arms treaty signed in 1991. The United States would have to scrap or modify its 50 MX missiles, which have 10 warheads each.
 -- Russia may retain -- and reuse for basing other missiles -- 90 of the silos that now house the SS-18s.
 -- Russia may convert 105 of its 170 SS-19 missiles, which now have six warheads apiece, to single-warhead weapons. The United States' Minuteman III missiles, which carry three warheads, may be modified to carry a single warhead.
 -- The United States would have to cut by about half the number of warheads it has on submarine-launched missiles, traditionally the area in which the United States enjoyed the greatest advantage. The number is to drop from 3,456 to 1,728.
 -- The United States would grant Russian inspectors access to its long-range nuclear bomber fleet to verify the types and numbers of weapons being carried.

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
In the Speech by the Mayor, the Message Will be in the Margins

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
WHAT is the state of a city that allowed a 5-month-old boy to die of neglect, despite warnings, and a Bronx storekeeper to be gunned down defending his family?
 Mayor David N. Dinkins's State of the City speech today promises to address two related themes: the welfare of children, who represent the city's future, and the plight of small businesses, which are taxed to subsidize the growing proportion of New Yorkers who cannot afford to pay for municipal services. Yet any agenda that neglects the consequences of guns and drugs can only marginally improve the lot of children or of small businesses in New York. 
What's a mayor to do? He commands an army of police officers larger than the American force in Somalia, but he lacks the jurisdiction or the mandate to disarm neighborhood warlords. He inherits social problems that are national in scope, but he has to cope at the sufferance of Washington, which has been insensitive, and of Albany, which has been insufficiently responsive (though, as the city's first black Mayor, he has largely escaped blame for publicized cases of child abuse that would certainly have provoked deeper outrage against a white Mayor).
 After finishing his first year as Mayor, Mr. Dinkins acknowledged that his discretion had been limited largely to reshaping about two-tenths of one percent of the city's nearly $30 billion budget. "It may be that you affect things at the margins," he said then, "but when things get tight, the margins matter a hell of a lot."
 The Dinkins administration has often said that good government is the best politics. That theme is likely to echo in the speech Mr. Dinkins is to deliver today as he begins a mayoral-election year that, coupled with races for local school boards and the first full terms on the expanded City Council, holds the prospect of being as divisive as the last mayoral election appeared to be unifying.
 Despite the administration's boast that New York is "roaring" back, Mr. Dinkins will temper expectations by reminding his constituents that the recession continues to inhibit him from providing all the services he promised. Still, he will recite a scorecard of promises made and kept and his vision of those that remain to be redeemed.
 His highest priority is to balance the budget. If he has failed so far to achieve fundamental restructuring -- last year's buzzword of government reform -- then he has, at least, avoided the early threat of a state takeover of the city's fiscal prerogatives, defied many skeptics and even won the public praise of some others.
 To most New Yorkers, though, a balanced budget is a bulky abstraction. So, while accepting credit for what some people view as an accomplishment and others consider a basic duty, Mr. Dinkins will focus instead on more widely appreciated matters. Despite the toll that the recession has taken on tax revenues, he will recall, his administration began decentralizing government services to deliver them more visibly and, presumably, more effectively -- often in conjunction with a Council that he has begun, if begrudgingly, to accept as a full partner.
 First, the administration dramatically expanded community policing as a strategy and started providing the manpower to achieve it. Whether modest declines in recorded crime are attributable to that strategy is arguable. What's certain is that if crime had increased, the Mayor would have gotten the blame.
 Responding to state prodding, the city is expanding health-care services at the neighborhood level through a growing program called Communicare. Mr. Dinkins also plans to nearly double the number of so-called beacon schools, which remain open longer and also provide children and their parents with a range of social services. Also, he hopes to find enough funds to let branch libraries open six days a weeks for the first time in decades.
 Mr. Dinkins also is proposing to reduce some of the impediments to small businesses, which are not only synonymous with middle-class entrepreneurship but also can create entry-level jobs for the rest of his constituents. Expect some exemptions on commercial-rent taxes and some constraints on ticketing for minor violations.
 Expressing hope for the future, the Mayor will hark back to a productive partnership between the city's first Italian-American Mayor, Fiorello H. La Guardia, and a new administration in Washington that helped lift New York City out of the depression by doling out New Deal largess.
 The analogy may not be apt. La Guardia benefited, in part, because the Roosevelt Administration preferred him to the Democratic organization controlled by Tammany Hall. And four decades later, when Mayor Abraham D. Beame was seeking a second term, his early support for Jimmy Carter was not returned in kind.
 Still, the Clinton Administration and its cast of New Yorkers has the potential to help the Mayor whose political career has been built on surpassing low expectations. Mr. Dinkins was asked once whether his election would raise false hopes that he could never fulfill. Perhaps, he replied, but false hope is better than no hope at all.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN MOSCOW: Bush and Yeltsin Sign Pact Making Deep Missile Cuts;
A Last Treaty Of Its Kind

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 3

 BODY:
If nostalgia enveloped George Bush on his 25th and probably final foreign adventure as President, there was also some nostalgia for the old sureties of traditional arms control.
 Given its very sweep, the second Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, known as Start II, is likely to be the last agreement of its kind. It represents both the triumph and the limit of two-way negotiations on arms control in a world that is no longer bipolar. 
The Soviet Union may have been a totalitarian menace, but its military commanders -- especially compared with the military commanders in some of the world's current trouble spots -- were responsible professionals who knew the dangers of the weapons they brandished or faced, and who could largely be expected to keep to the letter of the agreements they signed, however long or hard the negotiation.
 
New Cast of Nuclear Powers
 There was no fuss then about ratification by parliaments or any need to assuage the wounded pride of new states, like Ukraine, that woke up as nuclear powers and started to like the way it looked in the mirror.
 Each difficult, incremental treaty on the road to Start II felt momentous -- not because arms were reduced in any meaningful way, but because the gap of ideology and misperceptions crossed by the superpowers was so cavernous and the rope across it seemed so thin.
 The treaty is a legitimately momentous agreement, around which President Bush, President Boris N. Yeltsin and their speech writers did their best to spin flourishes of oratory about peace, children, trust and brotherhood. But there was a curious lack of moment.
 This odd fact was caused in part bythe haste of negotiation, and in part by Russia's impoverished condition, as an imploded empire reaching for aid and acceptance. Russia's diminished status seemed to intensify Mr. Bush's, even though he is a lame-duck President.
 But there is a deep, underlying sense that the new world is not only more complicated, but also considerably more volatile than the old. The end of the cold war straitjacket has meant the start of conflicts based on old nationalisms and economic rivalries, just as the collapse of the old fears of mutual assured destruction and nuclear holocaust has made the world safe for conventional war.
 
Disagreement Over Serbs
 As much as Mr. Bush and Mr. Yeltsin talked of cooperation and partnership, they clearly have their disagreements over how to deal with Serbian aggression in the former Yugoslavia. Mr. Yeltsin must face Russian conservatives and some nationalists who say they feel that he has already betrayed their "Serbian brethren" as well as old Soviet allies in Iraq, Syria, Cuba and elsewhere.
 The shelling over Mogadishu, Somalia, while Mr. Bush spent Friday night on an American naval vessel offshore was a reminder of the limits of relief intervention and feel-good gestures that Russian-American amity cannot solve. In Cambodia, where Washington and Moscow brokered a peace treaty through the United Nations Security Council, the Khmer Rouge's blatant defiance of that treaty and their continual kidnapping of United Nations peacekeeping troops promises a future renewal of horrors that could make Serbian behavior seem civilized.
The disclosures of Iraq's long and secret efforts to develop chemical and nuclear weapons, despite intermittent international inspections and despite Baghdad's signature on treaties that should have banned such programs, is a reminder of the actual value of treaties intended to stop the spread of arms. The behavior of Western companies that knowingly sold advanced machinery to Iraq that could be used for weapons-making raises questions about how former Soviet companies and their skilled scientists will act in a free-market system with porous border controls.
 
Future Tasks Cited
 Senior American officials here spoke of the future tasks of arms control, pointing to the Chemical Weapons Convention, scheduled to be signed shortly in Paris, and the effort to extend the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty beyond 1995.
 But they also understand how difficult Start II will be to ratify and carry out, even assuming that Ukraine, Belarus and Kazakhstan follow through on their pledges to become non-nuclear states. According to a study by the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, the United States and Russia each employ more than a million people to build, field and maintain their nuclear arsenals. Dismantling these structures will present fundamental political, economic and environmental problems. Dismantling the weapons themselves, plus thousands of tactical nuclear weapons, is full of dangers.
 The Harvard study estimates that the Russians will have to destroy 100,000 metric tons of liquid rocket propellant, which explodes on contact with air, as well as safely transport, store and protect the highly prized nuclear material in all those warheads.
 Washington has promised direct financial and technical aid to Moscow and Kiev for these purposes, but the cost of dismantling these arsenals safely is likely to be shocking, diplomats suggest, far in excess of the initial American installment of $800 million.
 
Democracy as Arms Control
 One senior American official said wanly that "democracy is the best form of arms control," arguing that democratic nations do not start wars.
 But it is always possible, as Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev of Russia made clear last month in his stunning mock speech in Stockholm, that the Russian Government may one day end up in the hands of extreme nationalist, anti-Western politicians or military men who will treat Start II much as President Saddam Hussein of Iraq treated his solemn commitments.
 Another American official cautioned that there were limits to Washington's ability to influence events here or even to control how Russia carries out the treaty.
 "Both the financial obligations and the willingness to undertake the task are responsibilities that Russia and the other parties are accepting themselves," he said. "It is the Russian people and their leadership in this present instance who want to put some of the worst and most destabilizing aspects of the nuclear age behind us and accept that responsibility. We can help, but we're by no means the principal actor."
LEASHING WEAPONS: 30 YEARS OF PACTS
 August 1963 (Limited Test Ban Treaty): Prohibits nuclear testing or any other nuclear explosions in the atmosphere, in outer space and under water.
January 1967 (Outer Space Treaty): Prohibits sending nuclear weapons into Earth orbit, placing nuclear weapons on celestial bodies or stationing them in outer space.
July 1968 (Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty): Prohibits the transfer of nuclear weapons to other countries and prohibits helping countries without nuclear weapons to make or or acquire them. May 1972 (Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty): Bans space-based defensive missile systems and limits the United States and Soviet Union to one ground-based defensive missile site each.
July 1974 (Threshold Test Ban Treaty): The Soviet Union and United States agree to limit underground nuclear weapons tests.
June 1979 (Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty): The first formal strategic arms treaty sets an initial overall limit of 2,400 intercontinental ballistic missile launchers, submarine-launched missiles, heavy bombers and air-to-surface missiles, with the ceiling to be lowered in stages later.
December 1987 (Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty): Provides for the dismantling of all Soviet and American medium- and shorter-range land-based missiles and establishes a system of weapons inspection to guard against violations.
November 1990 (Conventional Forces in Europe Treaty): Originally negotiated between the members of NATO and the Warsaw Pact, the treaty limits the number of tanks, artillery, armored combat vehicles, combat aircraft and combat helicopters that each side is allowed to maintain in Europe.
July 1991 (Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty - Start I): Brings the number of Soviet long-range nuclear warheads down from 11,012 to 6,163 and the United States warheads from 12,646 to 8,556.
January 1993 (Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty - Start II): Slashes the superpowers' arsenals to a third of their current size. The American arsenal will be cut to 3,500 warheads and bombs, while the Russians will be down to 3,000 warheads and bombs. The reductions are to be carried out by 2003.
(Source: Arms Control Association for warhead numbers for Start I and II.)

HEADLINE: The Boomlet Generation

BYLINE: By Alexander Abrams and David Lipsky; Alexander Abrams is a lawyer. David Lipsky is author of "Three Thousand Dollars," a collection of stories.

 BODY:
Notice to advertisers: Thanks, but no thanks. Draw no conclusions from the Grunge Kids featured in Business Week's recent cover story, "Move Over, Boomers," about selling to people under 30, or from the lead article in The Atlantic last month, which proposes to call all of us "Thirteeners" (the 13th American generation, with all the bad luck the number implies).
There are great differences between people who left college in the 1980's and people leaving college now. If you want to reach our generation, older than 24 and younger than 32, do not address your products to the befuddled characters from the movie "Singles." 
 We have been waiting to be noticed, it's true. We've gotten a bum rap. But we're not the younger Grunge Kids. No one we know listens to Pearl Jam or Nirvana. No one we know read Douglas Coupland's "Generation X" with anything approaching the sympathy and recognition these articles suggest.
Our movies were "Wall Street" and "St. Elmo's Fire" (sad to say). Our music is 10,000 Maniacs and Tracy Chapman and R.E.M. On TV, we watch "Seinfeld," not "In Living Color"; when we saw "Beverly Hills 90210" we were amused at how unironically it treated adolescence. The John Hughes films that spelled us through our own teen-age years were more incisive and subversive, suggesting that high school was just another phase to get through, another party to stylishly attend. Our hero is still David Letterman and we admire (politically) Russ Feingold and Bill Clinton. We are like you.
Call us Boomlets, if you have to call us anything. Generations seem to break down most effectively along the decade of college graduation. We left school under Ronald Reagan in the wish-fulfillment 80's. If anything, we didn't dislike the Baby Boomers' values; we disliked the Boomers for getting all the stuff we wanted. We became adults in a period of economic expansion (fueled, it turned out, in one of the more rotten tricks played on us, by the future earning power of our entire generation), and we were ready to take our piece of the pie.
If we were criticized for nihilism, we were criticized for having no scruples in our pursuit of success, not for having no ambition. Remember the despairing articles they kept writing about us five years ago? We're the ones who bought clothes from J. Crew and Tweeds. We're the ones who had credit cards sent to our mailboxes at college. We wanted to have houses by the beach, Volvos or Saab convertibles in our garages.
There is a line of John Updike's, about his own quiet, ambitious 50's generation: "We saw youth not as a license for freedom, but to act respectfully to our elders and then imitate them at a safe distance." That sounds like us. Our friends are in graduate school or advertising, with smaller apartments than they'd like and less job security than their parents are comfortable with, but we're still waiting our turn. (The only nice thing about the recent articles is that they've made it less confusing to our families why some of us have had to move back home.)
So please, let's do this by decade of college graduation. The only people we know who are like the subjects of these articles are the Cuspers, students who graduated in the last years of the 80's and the first years of the 90's. They're in a bind. The stock market crashed while they were in college, so they've had to jettison one set of values (get ahead no matter what the cost), in favor of another (you can't get ahead, no matter how hard you try). When they're with us, they talk like adults. When they're with kids a few years younger, they talk like Shannen Doherty in "Beverly Hills 90210."
No, it's the Grunge Kids, people who got out of college in the last two or three years, who are hogging all the attention. They were reared with unlimited TV privileges, VCR's and a stunted sense of intellectual curiosity. Their nihilism is true nihilism: They actually don't care where they end up. They are so different from every generation that's ever come before that they've shocked national magazines into action.
But, advertisers, please keep in mind; they're startling to us, too. At parties, we have a great deal to say to people five or 10 years older than we are. We have common ground. But it is hard to find any common ground with people even two years younger than we are. They speak a language similar to ours -- like Australians -- but their cultural references and ambitions are foreign. We'd hate to be classified with them forever.
Any generation that presumes to include both George Stephanopoulos and Marky Mark is simply not functioning as a generation. Imagine Mr. Stephanopoulos showing up for work with Soundgarden blasting out of a Walkman, a nose ring and a "Go, Bill" shoulder tattoo, and you get the idea.
So thanks, but no thanks. The members of the Boomlet generation are like middle children: The people ahead of us, the Boomers, got the inheritance; and now our noisy, younger siblings are getting all the attention. We're getting passed over, with all of our easily identifiable tastes and our irresistible purchasing power.
The difference between the Grunge Kids and us is that they seem never to want to become adults. We do, and are waiting for the economy to give us a chance to become the adults we once hoped we could be. But in the words of the Whos, who shouted to Horton the Elephant in the Dr. Seuss book we read as children, there's something we'd like to say: "We're here. We're here."

HEADLINE: Florida Proposes Broad Health Plan

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Jan. 4

 BODY:
Arguing that he could not wait for Washington to develop a national plan to control medical costs, Gov. Lawton Chiles of Florida today proposed sweeping changes in the state's health-care system that he said were intended to guarantee "full access to quality, affordable health care for every person in Florida" by the end of 1994.
As part of the proposal, called the Florida Health Plan, all 13.5 million residents of the nation's fourth-most-populous state would be offered coverage by nonprofit, state-chartered organizations called Community Health Purchasing Alliances, which would collect health-care premiums and sign contracts with insurers judged to offer the best quality at the best cost. The organizations would be located throughout the state, forming a network of health-care cooperatives intended to encourage competition among providers statewide. 
 "The concept is simple," Mr. Chiles said at a news conference in Tallahassee. "Businesses, individuals and the government pool their money and purchase the best care at the best price. You spread out the risk so that everybody in an area is covered."
 
Managed Competition
 The approach, managed competition, has been promoted by several market-oriented health economists and endorsed by President-elect Bill Clinton, but it has not been tried on a large scale by any state yet.
State officials said hearings would be held around the state this year to determine the extent and level of benefits that will need to be provided under the plan. Mr. Chiles must also convince the State Legislature to endorse several aspects of the plan, including a provision that would exempt the cooperatives from antitrust restrictions. The proposal announced today was the state's response to a mandate last year by the Legislature to have a comprehensive health plan in place by Dec. 31, 1994.
As the Chiles administration announced the proposal today, professional medical organizations and major health providers were guarded in their assessments, particularly about the relationship between costs and quality. And questions remain about how Florida's new plan would mesh with steps the Clinton Administration is expected to take to provide a national health-care plan.
 
Voluntary Enrollment
 State officials said that enrollment in the system would be voluntary but that the combination of lower costs and guaranteed access would encourage individuals as well as corporations to sign up. In the event that an employer chose not to join, they said, individual employees would pay some premiums out of their own pocket, with the remainder paid by state and Federal governments, most likely out of Medicaid funds, if a Federal waiver on the use of the money can be obtained.
Some similar programs that attempt to manipulate the health-care market to harness medical care costs already operate on a limited basis in Orlando, Bradenton and other Florida cities. But Mr. Chiles's proposal would extend health care benefits to an estimated 2.5 million Floridians who he said "have no coverage at all and can't afford to get sick." Officials said most of these people are members of poor working families, and a large proportion of them are children.
Doug Cook, director of the state's Agency for Health Care Administration, said the proposal "would need additional investment" by both the state and Federal governments in its initial phase, estimating the state's maximum contribution at $500 million annually and Washington's at $1 billion. But he argued that "as we guarantee full access, we should be able to reduce costs."
 
No '$10 Aspirins'
 Under a universal health care plan, Mr. Cook said, "there will be no more $10 aspirins" because "the invisible shifting of costs will come to an end." He added that use of the health-care system would become more efficient under the plan because fewer people would resort to "coming through the emergency room door" for basic care. Emergency room care is considerably more expensive than care in a doctor's office.
"We're definitely trying to go toward managed care," Mr. Chiles said in a telephone interview after the plan was announced. He was referring to insurance plans, like health maintenance organizations, in which patients are limited in their choice of doctors and medical decisions are closely scrutinized, an approach some consumers and doctors have resisted. "That's the only way we're going to reduce our costs."
So far managed care plans around the country, while often saving some money, have failed to stem the surge in medical costs, but proponents of the new plan hope that the added element of competition among large groups will squeeze costs even more.
Mr. Chiles also said that "the $31 billion we are now paying for health care in Florida should be enough to run our system if we spend it in the right places."
Gerald M. Soud, a spokesman for the Florida Medical Association, reacting to the proposal, said that although it "appears to reflect many of the health care reform initiatives the F.M.A. has advocated for several years, we do have concerns" whether the changes can be made "without sacrificing quality."
 
'Unachievable' Target Date
 In a statement issued at its headquarters in Jacksonville, Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Florida, a major provider in the state, said that while "competitive managed care is a realistic and proven approach to controlling medical costs," Mr. Chiles' target date "is unachievable." The company also said that "a great deal of work also remains to be done to specify how the Community Health Purchasing Alliances" would "contribute to solving the problems of cost and access."
Mr. Cook said that the Jan 1, 1995, date for implementing the plan was "premised on having a really good and willing partner on the Federal level" who would "either rewrite Federal laws or waive current laws."
At today's news conference, Mr. Chiles, a populist Democrat elected in 1990, said medical costs were rising so rapidly in Florida that the state could not afford to delay action until President-elect Bill Clinton offered the national plan he had promised. He said expenses for public health services now "eat up most of our growth revenue," forcing Florida, which has no state income tax, to limit education, environmental and other programs.
 
'Just Can't Wait'
 "We just can't wait, given what the costs are," Mr. Chiles said.
Like other states, Florida saw the costs of health care skyrocket during the 1980's. Health care expenditures more than tripled in the state, to $31.4 billion in 1990 from $9.4 billion in 1980 and the proportion of the state's gross product spent on medical care rose to 12.8 percent from 8.9 percent.
At the same time, per capita health care expenditures increased 152 percent, to $2,427 annually from $962, and hospital revenue per patient rose 194 percent, to $765 a day from $260. Salaries for state employees rose 64 percent, while the premium for family coverage in the state employee health insurance program increased by a staggering 347 percent, to $3,756 from $840.
Officials on the Clinton transition team have made it clear that they do not favor individual states going off on their own with health care proposals that could upstage and undercut the more sweeping national plan the President-elect has spoken of. But the Florida plan borrows elements from one of the Clinton team's favorite guidebooks, David Osborne's "Reinventing Government" -- for example, the decentralizing of public services.

HEADLINE: Los Angeles's New Police Chief Gains Good Will but Even More Difficulties

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4

 BODY:
In his first weeks in office, the city's new police chief, Willie L. Williams, spent so much time visiting citizen groups, political leaders and police roll calls that some members of the Police Commission that appointed him began to worry if he was getting his job done.
But as he reaches the six-month point in his tenure, at the turn of the year, it is clear that Chief Williams has succeeded in generating good will in much of a city that had turned against its police force under the man he replaced, Daryl F. Gates. 
 The stakes riding on the efforts of Chief Williams are high for both him and the city. With Los Angeles still in shock from the rioting last spring, and with the approach of the two racially charged trials related to the riots, the city seems to be pinning its hopes less on elusive economic and social healing than on improved policing.
The City Council and the Mayor's Police Commission have backed Mr. Williams's plans for the department, and he seems to have won the tentative support of many officers who were backers of his combative predecessor.
 
Better Reception for Force
 "There's a general feeling that people want to support him," said Sgt. Andrew Simon, an officer who still regards Mr. Gates as "a great boss." He said many officers wanted Mr. Williams to succeed "because we want to be able to do our job."
Sgt. Dan Pugel, another officer who was loyal to Mr. Gates, said: "With Gates as the leader, the department was constantly under attack. With Gates retired, the department is being favorably received."
Mr. Gates left office unwillingly last summer in the aftermath of the Rodney G. King police beating case and the resulting riots. He is now the host of a radio talk show, where he has made the decision not to talk about his successor.
With his budget and his manpower shrinking, Chief Williams faces mounting difficulties, and is already scaling back his goals.
"Everyone is expecting him to do some miraculous things, and so far no one has given him anything to do it with," said David Dotson, a former deputy chief who retired shortly before Chief Williams took office.
 
Lifting Morale, a Bit
 In an interview in his office, the new Chief acknowledged that some of the difficulties he faced when he took office had grown more complicated.
He must find new ways to police a violent, restive city teetering on the brink of new disorders, and he must do this while trying to reorganize and reinvigorate an underfinanced, understaffed and demoralized department.
"When I came in, morale was the lowest I've ever seen it in a major police department," said Chief Williams, 49 years old, who was police commissioner in Philadelphia before coming here.
"It may have moved up a notch," he said, but added that morale would be further tested this month when he begins shifting 100 officers from behind desks to street patrol. Already, he has made a number of high-level appointments and begun to restructure the department, shaking its hierarchy down to the secretarial level.
Deputy Chief Mark Kroeker agreed with the Chief's assessment, saying, "I honestly think morale has picked up a little bit, but there remains a malaise out there" that has continued since the uproar over the case of Mr. King, the black motorist whose beating by police officers in March 1991 was captured on videotape.
 
2 Explosive Trials
 And on the streets of the city, Chief Williams said, there are continuing tensions as Los Angeles awaits the two court cases early in the year: a Federal civil rights trial of four white officers who were acquitted of assault last April in the King beating, and the trial of three black men accused of beating a white truck driver, Reginald O. Denny, in the rioting that followed those acquittals.
When a small demonstration in support of the Denny defendants escalated into rock-throwing last month, Chief Williams quickly deployed forces in a sort of textbook demonstration of the steps that might have been taken to choke off the rioting last April 29.
With what seemed like a citywide sigh of relief, civic leaders praised his aggressive response.
But Chief Williams realizes that more serious challenges may lie ahead. Among preparatory measures he ordered that were not taken by Chief Gates, a 16-hour program of riot training is being given to the entire force.
The department is also not trying to go it alone in any future civil unrest. Steps are being taken to improve coordination with neighboring police and fire departments, Chief Williams said, adding, "We have to involve all the agencies: health and human services, water and power, people who have trucks, people who have yards, people who have feeding facilities, people who have housing facilities."
 
Recognizing Inequity
 To supplement the broad emergency plans that Chief Gates had in place, Chief Williams said he was working out contingencies so specific that he had separate plans for handling disturbances after each of the two coming trials.
"Deep down inside of me, I don't believe we are going to have any major civil disturbance," said Chief Williams, who is black. "But I'm not naive enough to believe there won't be some problems. We are a big city and this is, unfortunately, America."
In a break with the good guys-bad guys philosophy of his predecessor, he added: "It's part of the definition of America for the 1990's. We are in a social upheaval. Until we manage that upheaval and share a little more of the American dream with everyone, we are going to have these problems."
Chief Williams's problems begin, as in other departments in the city, with his budget.
 
Short of Money and Officers
 He has not been able to win an increase in the $600 million budget for more staffing and equipment, and he has not been able to sidestep a citywide hiring freeze. He had pinned his hopes on a bond measure that would have allowed the hiring of 1,000 more officers, but last November the voters turned it down by a narrow margin. Chief Williams said he hoped that a similar measure would be put on the ballot in a citywide election this spring but that even if it passed no additional officers would be on the streets until 1994.
With about 30 officers a month retiring or leaving their jobs, Chief Williams said, his force has shrunk to about 7,700, from slightly more than 7,900 when he took office in July
This shrinking force hinders Chief Williams's effort to make a fundamental shift in philosophy that he hopes to bring to the department. To police the city as he would like to, he said, he needs 9,500 to 10,000 men and women.
Where Chief Gates was a pioneer in "professional policing," deploying his small force in specialized units for maximum crime-busting impact, Chief Williams is a leading proponent of "community-based policing" in which officers play a preventive role.
 
Encouraging Personal Contact
 "Right now," the Chief said, "they spend all their time going from call to call to call to call. You hang up the receiver and it's another call. Meanwhile that personal contact, getting out there, is not there."
A recent study of the police department found that only 4 percent of the force was on the street at any time. Chief Williams is determined to move more officers onto patrol duty, but he said even that was not so easy a choice.
"You have to understand that if you're slowing the paper functions, if you're slowing down lab analysis, if you're slowing down training, that's the cost of shifting people," he said. "The resources have not risen."
Chief Williams is also dedicated to, as he put it, making his force look more like the city it polices, with more women and more members of minorities hired and promoted.
And as with other uncomfortable changes, he said, he was telling his officers: "You can go downstairs and you can kick the locker and you can bang your head against the wall, but then you've got to come back upstairs, put on your suit and go out and serve the community."

HEADLINE: Contributing From Windfalls To Help the Neediest Cases

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
The conversation at Gail Furman's dinner party last month was ambling along until it hit a roadblock. Between bites of veal marsala and sips of Beaujolais nouveau, Joan B. Furman, the hostess's mother-in-law, kept insisting that Lena Horne had been married to Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Dorothy Schwartz disagreed.
The two decided on a friendly bet, with the loser treating the winner to dinner at a fancy restaurant. Needless to say, Mrs. Furman soon found herself making reservations at Le Bernadin in Manhattan. But then she and Ms. Schwartz reconsidered. Wouldn't the money be better spent, they thought, if it were sent to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund? 
 "This way, we are doing something very 'of the moment,' something quintessentially New York," Mrs. Furman, an educational consultant in Chappaqua, N.Y., said in a letter to the fund. She enclosed the $100 that she might otherwise have spent on a meal of roast monkfish or sea scallops.
Donations to the Neediest Cases sometimes spring from bets and sudden windfalls. The money ends up assisting seven charities that are helping tens of thousands of people struggling with unemployment, homelessness, drug addiction, child abuse and other maladies.
The fund is now conducting its 81st appeal at a time when social-service organizations across New York City must meet growing responsibilities because of the recession. The Times pays the fund's expenses, so all contributions go directly to seven charities. This year's campaign ends on Feb. 28.
Rebecca A. Pulliam of Manhattan did not need to write a check to the Neediest Cases. She simply signed over the one for $87.50 that she received from New York State for serving jury duty last summer.
"I know it will be properly spent by your fund and appreciate the work you do," she wrote. "As I sent this to you, I think of my two great New York City friends: Rita Smith and Ronnie Hess."
A stroll through midtown Manhattan led to the contribution by Betty Zapolsky of Neponsit, Queens. She was walking on Fifth Avenue near 56th Street when she noticed a folded $20 bill on the sidewalk. She looked around for someone who might have dropped it, but amid the stampeding crowds, her search proved fruitless.
"Thank God I do not need this $20," she wrote. "I feel sorry for the person who lost this money and hope that he or she was also not in great need. Enclosed you will find this $20 plus another $20 I have added as a donation to your fund. May this money fulfill some needs and bring some comforts to the people you help."

HEADLINE: Subsidies For Hospitals Face Threat

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

 BODY:
A case awaiting the ruling of a Federal judge in Manhattan could threaten the system that New York State has used for nearly a decade to help subsidize hospital care and to give Blue Cross and Blue Shield a modestly more favorable rate than other health insurers.
Several insurance companies and insurance industry associations are challenging the system under a Federal law covering employee benefit programs. They contend that the 1974 Federal statue pre-empts the complex state formula under which health insurers pay hospitals for patient care. 
 The litigation before District Judge Louis J. Freeh centers on two sets of surcharges added to the amount billed for some patient's hospital care. One has been in place for a decade; the other was to take effect last April. Judge Freeh heard arguments in the cases in November and is expected to rule in the next few weeks.
 
Similar Case in New Jersey
 Last May, a ruling in a New Jersey case forced the state to abandon surcharges like New York's. New Jersey lawmakers then decided to impose a health insurance tax and borrow more than $500 million a year from the state unemployment insurance fund to pay for indigent hospital care.
The court action comes amid rumblings of financial catastrophe for health-care providers and insurers alike. Last week, the Cuomo administration granted Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, the state's largest health insurer, a rate increase that averages 25.5 percent to stave off a predicted collapse. And as health-care costs have gained prominence on the national agenda, the lawsuits could force New York to follow the example of New Jersey, and abandon containment efforts entirely.
Since 1983, New York has required commercial insurance companies and self-insurance groups to pay a 13 percent surcharge on hospital bills for services to their policyholders. That surcharge has never applied, however, to bills paid by Blue Cross and Blue Shield, health maintenance organizations or Medicaid.
While the surcharge was not imposed explicitly to help pay for the care of indigent or uninsured patients, as the New Jersey surcharge was, it provides more money to hospitals. The Hospital Association of New York State says it brings in $135 million of the hospitals' $16 billion in annual revenue.
Losing the surcharge "would blow up the system," said Carolyn F. Scanlan, the association's executive vice president. In 1991, New York hospitals lost $400 million, she said.
People on both sides of the New York case insist that they do not expect a ruling as far-reaching as the New Jersey one. But several parties to the case said that the judge could go much further than the plaintiffs intended in dismantling the system.
Timothy F. Lyons, a lawyer for the Travelers Insurance Company, one of the plaintiffs, said, "It is possible that the judge could rule very broadly."
 
'This May All Backfire'
 The head of the State Health Department's Division of Health Care Financing, Steven C. Anderman, said: "This may all backfire on the insurers, if the whole system of cost regulation gets thrown out. They could all just face a market system. Then they might pay more, not less."
The Travelers filed suit last May. The Aetna Life Insurance Company, Mutual of Omaha Insurance Company and several insurance industry associations sued in July, and the two cases were combined.
The two more recent surcharges being challenged include an 11 percent surcharge for one year on hospital payments by commercial insurers. and a permanent 9 percent surcharge on hospital bills paid by health maintenance organizations. But the law provided that health maintenance organizations could escape the charge by meeting requirements for cost containment and by enrolling a certain number of Medicaid patients.
 
Surcharges Blocked
 The surcharges were to take effect last April 1, but insurers obtained court orders blocking them until the issue is resolved. State officials said the surcharges would have generated about $60 million in the first year for the state, not the hospitals.
The insurance companies maintain that the entire system of surcharges runs afoul of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, or Erisa, which governs employee benefit programs. The law prohibits the states from regulating such programs, and it provides that the money paid into them can be used only to benefit their members.
On May 27, Judge Alfred M. Wolin of United States District Court in Newark, ruled that New Jersey could not impose surcharges, including a 19.1 percent add-on to subsidize care for the indigent, on Erisa plans. The surcharges violated the act, the judge ruled, because they forced the plans to pay for care for non-members.
The New York dispute is complicated by a fundamental disagreement over the scope of the retirement income act. The state defines an Erisa plan as a self-supporting insurance pool, created by an employer or a labor union, that does not rely on a commercial insurance company to pay claims, although a commercial insurer may be hired to administer the program. Judge Wolin applied the same definition in his ruling.
But commercial insurers maintain that any group health insurance policies purchased for a group of workers is also governed by the law. Several H.M.O.'s and the New York State Health Maintenance Organizations Conference intervened in the case, contending that the same is true of their employee health plans.
By the state's logic, two million to three million people in New York belong to health insurance programs covered by the act. State officials could not provide precise figures because they do not oversee the retirement plans, and because many people are covered by more than one policy.
Insurers, however, argue that the Federal law protects the vast majority of the 5 million New Yorkers who have health coverage through commercial insurance companies and the 2.7 million H.M.O. members.
New York has not imposed the surcharges on Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans, which insure 12.8 million New Yorkers, to help the insurer overcome a competitive disadvantage. As the state's insurer of last resort, it must provide coverage to any applicant. Other insurers, which have five million customers statewide, have more flexibility in setting premiums and choosing customers.
Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, and the New York State Conference of Blue Cross and Blue Shield Plans have intervened in the lawsuit on the state's side.
A state law passed in 1992 will impose some of the same open enrollment requirements on commercial insurers, starting April 1. And other insurance companies say that Blue Cross and Blue Shield should lose its exemption from the surcharge. "The 13 percent was, as we understand it, to reward Blue Cross for open enrollment," said Mr. Lyons, of Travelers. With the new law, he said, "a lot of the reasoning for that has gone away."

HEADLINE: Hope and Constraint

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
The scale of the initiatives proposed yesterday by Mayor David N. Dinkins in his State of the City address demonstrated the large gap between what Mr. Dinkins would surely like to do for many poor and working-class New Yorkers and what the constraints of the city's fiscal circumstances will allow.
The annual address is traditionally upbeat and self-congratulatory, and seldom more so than in an election year. The speech provides a mayor with an opportunity to court constituencies by offering bold new programs, often tailored to meet the needs of people whose support could prove crucial in the mayoral primaries in September and the general election in November. 
 
 
An Array of Initiatives
 Mr. Dinkins, who plans to run for a second four-year term this year, proposed a smorgasbord of initiatives intended to please everyone from working women seeking day care to small businesses hoping for tax breaks.
But the new or expanded programs outlined by Mr. Dinkins in his 43-minute speech were all relatively inexpensive and small-bore, a recognition, no doubt, that the deep and prolonged recession that has defined his mayoralty precludes more ambitious initiatives.
The Mayor's supporters contended that his choices underscored his priorities and represented an important beginning.
In essence, they said, Mr. Dinkins's message was that he did not have substantial new resources to spend, but that he was telling important constituencies that he would spend it on them if he could.
 
'An Excellent Speech'
 "I thought it was an excellent speech," said Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, who is a longtime Dinkins ally.
"This was a speech with specific commitments," she said. "They are not more symbolic than real. They are real first steps."
Critics of the speech -- including some officials who have been generally supportive of the Mayor -- said his address was heavy on oratory but light on substance.
The City Council President, Andrew J. Stein, who is expected to challenge Mr. Dinkins in the mayoral primary in September, said, "There is nothing in the speech that talks about dealing with substantial reform."
 
Coping With Budget Gap
 The Mayor's supporters argued that an administration struggling to eliminate a $1.7 billion budget gap for the next fiscal year, which begins in July, could not afford the kind of dramatic, innovative and, most of all, expensive new programs that would provide jobs for the unemployed or expanded treatment for drug abusers.
Mr. Dinkins said, for example, that he hoped that President-elect Bill Clinton would create a major new Federal job-training program. He also said New York City could not afford to "sit back and wait for what Washington has to offer." And so the Mayor proposed forming a commission to help the city to use more efficiently its existing resources for job training.
Mr. Dinkins did offer some minor new programs and expansions of some city services, which altogether would cost about $25 million a year in the city's $30 billion annual operating budget. These included small grants to open day-care centers, added hours for libraries and expansion of two programs initiated last year -- using selected schools as all-day community centers and new primary-care medical clinics in poor neighborhoods.
 
New Tax Breaks
 He also proposed two new tax breaks, both involving the unusual and much-maligned city tax on commercial rent. These would cost the city about $35 million next year in forgone revenues.
Some advisers to the Mayor maintained that the significance of the message lay in its choices -- the priorities that Mr. Dinkins was selecting in a time of fiscal duress -- and in what they described as one fundamental change: a new effort to recruit more black New Yorkers for the Police Department and to give city residents a built-in advantage in the selection process for police officers.
Ms. Messinger said the Mayor's proposals -- particularly the new city money for libraries, child care and health clinics, along with the tax breaks to be given to small businesses -- were all in areas "where the Mayor would agree we haven't done enough."
"I see it as responsive to neighborhoods and communities that haven't had their share of the pie," Ms. Messinger added.
 
Addressing Needs
 It remains uncertain, of course, whether the poor and working-class New Yorkers whose needs Mr. Dinkins is trying to address will find his efforts sufficient to support him enthusiastically at the polls later this year, as they did in record numbers in 1989.
The Mayor acknowledged in an interview last July that the city's dire fiscal problems had made it impossible for him to meet the expectations of many of the black and Hispanic New Yorkers who backed him ardently three years ago.
"Many have had such heightened expectations of the wonderful things that would be accomplished," Mr. Dinkins said. "But such things could not be accomplished because of the recession and the Federal withdrawal before that."
The Mayor also indicated that his own expectations had grown more realistic, and he said he hoped that his supporters' had as well.

HEADLINE: Senate Republicans Set To Offer Medicaid Plan

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 4

 BODY:
More than a year after Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposed a state takeover of local Medicaid costs, Senate Republican leaders are poised to offer an alternative plan that would force deep cuts in Medicaid by limiting growth in the program to the rise in health-care costs.
Unlike Mr. Cuomo's plan, the Republican proposal would not require local governments to cede a share of local tax revenues to the state. The plan is scheduled to be released publicly on Tuesday. 
 Lobbyists who support the concept of a state takeover of Medicaid costs said today that they were encouraged that the plan puts the Senate on record in support of a takeover for the first time and provides a starting point for negotiations with the Governor and the Assembly. The bad news, they said, is that the plan bears only a faint resemblance to Mr. Cuomo's proposal, meaning the differences will not be easily reconciled. The Assembly, which is controlled by the Democrats, has essentially endorsed Mr. Cuomo's plan.
 
$13.9 Billion for Medicaid
 Under the Governor's proposal, first offered in the fall of 1991, the state would by the year 2000 assume the entire local share of the cost of Medicaid, the main government health program for the poor. In 1991, the last year for which complete figures are available, a total of $13.9 billion was spent on Medicaid in New York, with the Federal Government paying $6.2 billion, or 44.2 percent, the state paying $4.8 billion, or 34.4 percent, and local governments paying $3 billion, or 21.4 percent.
In exchange for the state's assumption of local Medicaid costs, the Cuomo plan calls for the state to take all of the revenue generated by the personal income tax in New York City as well as the revenue generated by up to 1 percentage point of the sales tax in counties outside of the city. The plan also sets annual targets for reducing Medicaid costs.
Local governments presumably would benefit from the Cuomo plan because Medicaid costs, if left unchecked, are expected to grow at a faster rate than local tax revenues.
The Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, and the chairman of the Social Services Committee, Senator Joseph R. Holland of New City, believe that the tax swap is unnecessary, according to the Senate document. Their plan would limit annual Medicaid growth to the average growth in the medical care component of the Consumer Price Index for the previous three years.
 
'Extraordinary Incentives'
 "What the program does is give extraordinary incentives to all of the parties to find a number of ways to bring Medicaid costs down to the C.P.I.," said one Senate aide, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
From 1993 to 2000, growth would be capped between 6.3 percent and 6.5 percent, according to projections in the Senate plan. Mr. Cuomo's plan accounts for average Medicaid growth of about 12 percent for those years.
The difference in spending between the two plans is stark. Under the Cuomo plan, total state and local spending on Medicaid would be about $18.3 billion in 1999. In the Senate plan it would be about $12.3 billion.
Michael J. Dowling, Mr. Cuomo's director of health, education and human services, called the proposal "a diversion" intended to avoid debate on the Governor's plan.
"I just don't think it works," he said.
 
How to Cut Costs?
 The Senate plan provides only a rough sketch of how to reduce costs by the large amounts that would be needed to keep within the inflation cap.
The state would only assume local Medicaid costs if a local government had reached targets in placing Medicaid recipients in managed-care programs, like health maintenance organizations. It also would not pick up costs for local governments that had failed to meet targets for requiring welfare recipients to find work.
In addition, the plan encourages the privatization of long-term care services, tax credits for purchasers of long-term care insurance, incentives aimed at broadening the provision of primary care, and the establishment of "practice parameters" that would make additional medical testing the exception and not the rule for Medicaid patients.

HEADLINE: County by County, a Fight Against Bias

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ISELIN, N.J., Dec. 31

 BODY:
Pradip Kothari still sees the pickup truck riding around town on its enormous tires now and then, and the truck still carries the hand-drawn sneer in the rear window: Dot Buster.
The message, a reference to the bindi, or marriage mark, that some women of Mr. Kothari's Hindu faith wear on their foreheads, is one of a number of slurs and attacks Mr. Kothari has endured over the last couple of years. Once, pellets were shot through the plate-glass windows of his travel agency here; on two other occasions, the windows were shattered with beer bottles. 
 But now, Mr. Kothari and other Hindu immigrants in central New Jersey do not feel as alone in their anger and fear as they once did. Through New Jersey's statewide network of county human relations commissions, Mr. Kothari said, the growing Asian Indian community of northern Middlesex County found a forum for their complaints about anti-immigrant harassment and a means for alerting county and state officials to emerging ethnic tensions on the streets.
The network was formally begun in 1990 when the Florio administration ordered all county prosecutors to help create human relations commissions. It is a vital element in New Jersey's three-year campaign of using education and criminal sanctions against prejudice. The last piece of the network was put into place in November with the first organizing meeting of a human relations commission in Hunterdon County.
Patricia Campbell Glenn, New York regional director of the United States Justice Department's Community Relations Service, said she believes New Jersey's approach has never been tried before.
"I travel around the country quite a bit, and I have not seen this approach anywhere else," she said. "In New York and other states, I know, there are activities of this kind conducted on an official level by the state, but New Jersey is unique in that it has a county-by-county emphasis that is very broad-based."
The county panels, with no staffs, no salaries and no political ties, are made up of the county's top law-enforcement officials, school officials, church and community leaders and representatives of racial and religious groups. They generally meet once a month, and since anyone can ask to speak, they are intended to inform the top county officials about street-level concerns on race and prejudice.
Robert Freda, New Jersey program director for the National Conference of Christians and Jews, which helped organize the commissions in about half the counties, said they are intended to move race relations away from the "swat team" approach to each crisis.
"Historically, broker groups -- civil rights coalitions, affirmative action groups and so on -- are always put together hastily and in a reactive way to some extant problem," Mr. Freda said. "The commissions' purpose is to look at discrimination and prejudice as a low-level infection that is prevalent all over society, and, like oral hygiene, that if you don't look at it regularly you can end up with a problem."
The rise in reports of bias offenses in New Jersey is taken by some officials both as evidence of the seriousness of the problem and as proof that increased official sensitivity to bias issues has meant more care in classifying hate crimes.
At the same time, serious outbursts between groups, like the simmering problems in Crown Heights, have not surfaced in the state, said Paul Goldenberg, head of the Attorney General's office of Bias Crime and Community Relations.
The commissions are part of a broad program by the administration of Gov. Jim Florio to head off racial problems before they surface, as well as to punish the people responsible when they do.
 
Mandatory 'Re-education'
 The state has enacted a tough hate-crimes law that sets tough penalties for offenses like petty vandalism or harassment when they are motivated by hatred or prejudice.
In April the state announced a program of mandatory "re-education" classes for youths who commit hate crimes and for their parents. A month later, Attorney General Robert J. Del Tufo directed all police departments to designate an officer to take complaints of racial or ethnic bias by the police.
And finally, a bill already passed in the State Senate would allow victims of hate crimes to sue their tormentors for personal damages.
"The aim of these programs is to be both preventative and remedial," Mr. Del Tufo said in an interview. "We are resisting the racial and ethnic polarization that exists in society, and at the same time we are getting the word out that on the law enforcement side, we won't tolerate hate crimes in New Jersey."
 
Rode to His Assistance
 Now Mr. Kothari, the owner of Quick Travel agency on Oak Tree Road, is himself a member of the Middlesex County Human Relations Commission. He said it rode to his assistance when his new agency was repeatedly vandalized in 1990.
"There was a time when my people did not walk on the street after 6 P.M.," he said. "When my windows were broken, the police would say, 'Oh, it is just boys doing this; call your insurance agency.' I would say, 'Why is it that only the Indian businesses have to have iron grilles in front of their windows?' And the attitude would be, this is just something that all new immigrant groups have to go through. The human rights commission helped us to overcome that."
According to the Attorney General's office, the number of bias-motivated incidents is increasing steadily. The state reported 824 offenses and 341 arrests in 1990, although the vandals of Mr. Kothari's office were not among those caught.
In 1991, there were 976 reported offenses and 297 arrests. The largest categories of offense all increased: simple assault, like pushing or shoving; criminal mischief, like spray-painting epithets and petty vandalism, and harassment. State officials said the increases are due to both the weak economy, which increases tensions between groups, and a more thorough reporting system.
 
'Not Going to Go to Jail'
 "We find these offenses are more the work of young people and younger adults," said Sharon Ransavage, the Hunterdon County Prosecutor. "We need to look for creative responses to these problems, because after all, they're not going to go to jail."
Lately, the idea of human relations commissions has begun to filter down to the local level, said Nancy Young, an employee of the National Conference of Christians and Jews who coordinated the establishment of the Middlesex County Human Relations Commission. Three years ago, three municipalities in the county had such councils, she said, and today there are 11.
Two weeks ago, when anti-Semitic graffiti were spray-painted on the walls of East Brunswick High School, the East Brunswick Human Relations Council and local school officials organized a human relations forum, set for Jan. 24, to talk about the incident and seek ways to prevent new ones.
"At first, dealing with racial or intergroup tensions in the schools was akin to dealing with drug issues in the 50's and 60's," Mr. Freda said. "You didn't talk to people about the in-built psychology of prejudice, but now it's all the mode."
