HEADLINE: 'Pride and Determination': Excerpts From the State of the City Address

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from Mayor Dinkins's State of the City address yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

 	 	 		. . .	 	Today I want to talk about how we have heard the voices of this city and how we have kept the promises that we have made. Our compact was based on my vision of what this city can be. It is a vision of a government brought closer to the people and their neighborhoods, for throughout my life I have known New York as a community of neighborhoods. We took our first step toward this vision with our Safe Street, Safe City community policing plan. But we didn't stop there.
Using the talents of some of the most creative thinkers in government we put together a series of programs that put our people up front and moved the bureaucracy behind. We promised a government closer to the people and we have kept that promise. New York has been described as an extraordinary hive of the imagination, the greatest house ever built. I believe that the role of government is to help shape this extraordinary house of ours while giving our people the resources they need in order to take control of their lives. It means giving our children, to whom I've dedicated this administration, the love and nurturing they need to take us into the future.
I knew that our city of neighborhoods would flourish and that our children would thrive if we could create a safe city, a compassionate city, a city with a world-class economy. That is the vision I want to present to you today. So I come before you filled both with pride and determination, proud that we have laid the foundation to insure that our city's economy remains world class and poised to take us into the next century, proud that New York is safer today than it was before and proud of course, that all the while we never lost our compassion and our commitment to make life better for all of our residents.
We've done much -- thank you -- we've done much and we're determined to do much much more with your help. Last July we saw the man who would become the nation's President nominated under the dome of our own Madison Square Garden. Bill Clinton and Al Gore represent the kind of change this country needs and wants. And we are already seeing the prospect of a very different kind of government in Washington, D.C.
I had the privilege of addressing the Democratic National Convention, speaking on behalf of New York as well as the other great cities of our nation. At that point of our first term I could think only about the changes that we had begun to see, of how far we had already come and how much further our vision would carry this great house we have built together. Think back to January of 1990. Crime soared out of control, the budget we inherited had more holes than a Swiss cheese, a recession stole our jobs, an indifferent Federal Government took away our hope. Think about how much has changed. Remember how the words financial control board once dominated discussions of our budget.
Today, thanks to our spirit of reform and renaissance that has been reinventing government for the last three years, the foundation of our fiscal house stands solid.
Of course, while this year's budget is balanced, substantial deficits to remain in the years to come and our next budget will require us once again to make tough decisions, the kind of decisions that define this administration. While the aftershocks of a recession and the forecasts of deficits will require us to remain ever vigilant, surely we will leave our fiscal house standing stronger than we found it. Remember how the threat of businesses leaving our city once seemed to plague us. Over the last three years we've saved over 35,000 jobs by aggressively pursuing established and cutting-edge companies and convincing them to stay in New York.

 	 	 		. . .	 	This year we have a new partner. The most important new partner we've gained in a dozen years. We know that the New York State Congressional delegation led by Congressman Charles Rangel will work closely with Speaker Tom Foley and they will continue to hear our voices, so too, will the new head of the powerful Senate Finance Committee Daniel Patrick Moynihan. For too long, however, so many of our efforts had been stymied by the hostile Federal administration. But not only does our new President believe in cities and understand their importance, Bill Clinton knows that New York is the incubator for some of the greatest talent in the country. That's why he's chosen New Yorkers like Bob Ruben and Donna Shalala and Roger Altman and Cliff Wharton and Ron Brown as part of his team to put people first. And also joining that team are former Mayors Henry Cisneros and Fredrico Pena who are committed to urban centers as much as anybody I know. With these new partners, so many of them longtime friends, we can help transform cities like New York into towns called hope.

He said he had delivered on his 1989 campaign promises to be tough on crime and to be a sound fiscal steward. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: HEALTH-CARE COSTS UP SHARPLY AGAIN, POSING NEW THREAT

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4

 BODY:
Spending on health care accounted for more than 14 percent of the nation's total economic output last year, up from 13.2 percent in 1991, the Commerce Department says in a new report. The rise continues a trend that is increasingly seen as a threat to the country's economic health.
The department now estimates the health-care bill for last year at $838.5 billion while it says health spending will total $939.9 billion this year. That would be an increase of 12 percent from last year's total, and the department said that medical spending would continue to go up 12 percent to 15 percent a year over the next five years "unless significant changes in the health-care system occur." By contrast the population growth for last year has been estimated at about 1.2 percent by the Census Bureau.
 
Adding to Business Costs
 The latest projections are higher than those offered by the Commerce Department in December 1991, when it said health spending would rise 12 percent to 13 percent a year in the coming five years. If the new projections are accurate, health spending will easily exceed $1 trillion in 1994. 
 While the latest rise was expected, it adds to the burden on businesses, which pay more than one-third of the country's medical bills. It also tends to increase the Federal budget deficit and swells the ranks of the uninsured, as more people and companies are priced out of the market for health insurance.
The figures underscore the depth of the challenge facing President-elect Bill Clinton, who has made restraining the growth of health-care costs a top priority for his Administration.
Commenting on the new data, Judith Feder, coordinator of health policy for the Clinton transition team, said today, "The growth of health-care spending continues unabated, demonstrating the importance of the reform initiative the President-elect has proposed."
 
Proposals Within 100 Days
 Mr. Clinton has said that, within 100 days of taking office on Jan. 20, he will propose legislation to slow the rise in health costs and to guarantee insurance for all Americans. But there is no consensus even within the Democratic Party about how to achieve those goals.
In the campaign, Mr. Clinton said he wanted to establish annual limits on health-care spending. He said the limits should be enforceable. But he did not say how the limits would be enforced or how medical care would be controlled to stay under the ceilings. At the same time, Mr. Clinton said he wanted to rely on market forces as much as possible, and he praised the strategy of "managed competition," in which large groups seek the most efficient providers, as a way to control costs.
The department said that health spending surpassed 14 percent of economic output last year, but did not give a precise figure. Health care accounted for 13.2 percent of the economic output in 1991 and 12.2 percent in 1990. In 1981 it was 9.6 percent.
The latest figures mean that health care took one out of every seven dollars of the nation's gross domestic product, a broad measure of economic activity that reflects the total output of goods and services by labor and operations in the United States. This proportion is "substantially higher than what is found in other leading industrialized countries," the Commerce Department observed.
Data compiled by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development show that in 1990, when health spending accounted for 12.2 percent of output in the United States, it accounted for 8 percent to 9 percent in Canada, France, Germany and Sweden. The comparable figure for Japan was 6.5 percent, and for Britain it was 6.1 percent.
 
Dynamic Economic Sector
 The Commerce Department found that health care was one of the most dynamic sectors of the economy, with total employment of 10 million in 1992, up 43 percent in just four years. But that growth could be a mixed blessing. The data show that more people depend on health-care spending for their livelihoods, and that implies that the system will be difficult to change because more people have a financial stake in it.
The Commerce Department said that many factors contributed to the rising cost of health care. It mentioned, for example, "the use of sophisticated and high-priced equipment," the aging of the population and the comparatively high earnings of many people in the health-care industry, as well as the "innovative but costly treatment of some illnesses" like cancer, AIDS and heart disease.
Manufacturers of medical equipment vehemently deny that their products add to the total cost of health care and insist that some products save money by reducing the need for surgery and other costly procedures.
Federal, state and local officials say they have tried to contain health costs, but cannot do so without broader changes in the health-care industry.
Federal spending on Medicaid, the program for low-income people, rose 29 percent in the last fiscal year, to $67.8 billion. States share Medicaid costs with the Federal Government, and state officials complain that Medicaid has imposed a crushing burden on them.
The study of the health-care industry is part of a larger report on the American economy to be issued later this month by the Commerce Department. The chapter on health care was made available today by a consumer organization, the Health Research Group of Public Citizen Inc. Dr. Sidney M. Wolfe, director of the Health Research Group, said the new data were "extremely troubling."
The surge in employment in the health-care industry is notable because it came at a time when there was hardly any growth in private employment overall. Data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics show that private employment increased 1 percent, to 90 million in 1992 from 89.2 million in 1988.
Uwe E. Reinhardt, a professor of political economy at Princeton University, said, "Health care accounts for a huge chunk of the growth in gross domestic product registered since the early 1980's."
"In Federal and state government budgets, health care probably displaces investment in education, roads and transportation systems that would be more beneficial for the economy," Mr. Reinhardt said. "But we don't really know whether health spending in the private sector displaces the kind of investments that would cause higher economic growth."

HEADLINE: Iraq Is Reported to Move Missiles Into Areas Patrolled by U.S. Jets

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4

 BODY:
Administration officials said tonight that Iraq had moved surface-to-air-missiles into the enclave in the southern part of the country that is patrolled by United States and allied warplanes.
American officials said they were not sure why Iraq had moved the weapons, described as Soviet-made SA-2 and SA-3 missiles, into the zone, from which Iraqi aircraft are barred. The United States and its allies established the zone in August 1992 in an effort to protect rebellious Shiite Muslims in Iraq's southern marshlands. 
 The movement of the missiles could mean that Iraq is anticipating an American strike against its installations in response to its violations of the zone. But some American officials are concerned that Iraq may be trying to shoot down an American aircraft in reply to the downing of an Iraqi MIG on Dec. 27. The United States said the MIG had trespassed into the no-flight zone.
"The main concern is that Iraq may be trying to bag an American aircraft," said an American official who asked not to be identified.
The movement of the missiles comes during signs that Baghdad may still be intent on testing Western resolve to enforce the restrictions imposed on Iraqi after the Persian Gulf war.
After an American F-16 shot down the Iraqi MIG-25, the general view in the Administration was that Iraq would shrink from further challenges to the United States and allied nations. But American officials said Iraqi planes had continued to probe the edge of the zone, the 32d parallel. One Government official said Iraq had made three incursions into the zone today.
 
Options Include Air Strikes
 It is not clear what, if any, action the Bush Administration is prepared to take in its final weeks. Options that have been discussed in the Administration include staging air strikes against airfields and other targets in Iraq or possibly extending the no-flight zone to cover all of Iraq.
In addition to military steps, the United States could take political steps to try to further blacken the image of the Government of President Saddam Hussein and undercut the case for lifting of economic sanctions against Iraq. One approach that has been considered is to push for a hearing on war crimes by Iraq, citing newly acquired documents on the persecution of Kurds in northern Iraq.
Even after the zone over southern Iraq was established, Iraq kept some surface-to-air missile batteries south of the 32d parallel, but did not operate missile batteries there, a senior American official said. Iraq was warned that activating the radars that guide the missile batteries or otherwise threatening the American, British and French planes that patrol the zone would be considered a hostile act.
But in recent days, American officials said, Iraq has moved more surface-to-air missile batteries south of the 32d parallel while apparently moving to activate the batteries already there, a Government official said.
 
Bid to Protect Iraqi Planes
 Although only a small number of missiles appear to have been moved so far, American officials said, the deployment adds to the potential threat to the American and allied planes. Additionally, the Iraqi action was only recently detected and Americans officials said that it was possible that Iraq was in the process of deploying more of the weapons.
A Pentagon official said that some of the southern missiles had been stationed close to the 32d parallel in a possible effort to protect Iraqi planes that skirt the zone.
This official said the movement of the missiles was not in itself a violation of any restriction imposed by the allies. But he said that if the missiles were deemed by the United States to be a threat to its enforcement of the no-flight zone, it might take military action.
The officials said the Iraqis had also stationed missiles just north of the 32d parallel and had recently sent additional MIG fighters to their air base at Al Jarrah, which is north of the 32d parallel but close to the no-flight zone.
In the northern part of the country, Iraq has deployed a large number of ground troops near the Kurdish enclave. Though the Baghdad Government has described the deployment as part of an exercise, American officials see it as an effort to intimidate the Kurds.
In other moves that have stirred concern, Iraq has sought to hide documents from United Nations weapon inspectors and has delayed moving police posts from territory that a United Nations commission has determined belongs to Kuwait.
On his recent visit to American troops in Somalia, President Bush said he thought that Mr. Hussein was still intent on testing the resolve of United States and it allies, despite the downing of the Iraqi MIG-25.
 
Hussein 'Doesn't Get It'
 "Saddam Hussein is testing something," Mr. Bush said. "I don't know whether he's testing me or President Clinton. It makes me think he doesn't get it yet. The only thing good is when his people do what they should do, get him out of there."
Mr. Bush met with King Fahd last week in Jidda, Saudi Arabia, while traveling to Somalia and is said to have discussed Iraq's actions.
Many American officials say they believe that Mr. Hussein's challenges will increase after Mr. Clinton takes office on Jan. 20, even though the President-elect has warned Baghdad that he is prepared to take tough action to enforce the restrictions imposed after the gulf war.
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney told reporters today that it was likely that Mr. Hussein would continue "pushing right up to the edge as he has from time to time since the end of the war."
"I think it would be a mistake for him to assume that things are going to be any different under Clinton than they've been under President Bush," Mr. Cheney said.

HEADLINE: DEFENDING RECORD, DINKINS SEES CITY AS A SAFER PLACE

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Laying the groundwork for his re-election campaign, Mayor David N. Dinkins declared yesterday that New York City was a safer, more just and more fiscally secure place than when he took office despite a severe recession that has hampered his government.
In a 43-minute State of the City address, Mr. Dinkins defended his record in office, saying he had delivered on his 1989 campaign promises to be tough on crime and to be a sound fiscal steward. He listed a long scorecard of achievements, from a drop in overall crime rates to attracting the Democratic National Convention to establishing an all-civilian board to review complaints of police misconduct. 
 "I come to you filled both with pride and determination," he said. "Proud that we have laid the foundation to insure that our city's economy remains world class and poised to take us into the next century, proud that New York is safer today than it was before, and proud, of course, that all the while we never lost our compassion and our commitment to make life better for all of our residents."
 
Criticism From Rivals
 With two opponents already openly running against him and with a mayoral primary nine months away, the Mayor's third State of the City address in essence set forth the reasons he believes he has earned a second term, knowing full well his opponents would respond with the opposite view.
His challengers -- a Democrat, Andrew J. Stein, the City Council President, and a Republican, Rudolph W. Giuliani, a former Federal prosecutor -- dismissed the speech as empty oratory that did not confront what they see as the major problems the city faces: a faltering economy, an inefficient work force and recurring budget deficits.
Mr. Dinkins, in his address, said he had kept the promises he made to voters in 1989 and then went on to offer a long list of small but politically significant programs, an election-year wish list, that he said would fulfill his vision of "a government brought closer to the people and their neighborhoods."
One of the boldest initiatives in the speech would cost nothing. To encourage recruitment of more black and Hispanic police officers, the Mayor proposed giving candidates for officer extra points on their Civil Service examination if they reside in the city. He also vowed to continue to press Albany to pass a law requiring city police officers to live within the city limits, a line that drew large applause from the audience. "The face of our force should also reflect the face of our city," the Mayor said.
Other initiatives would help establish day-care centers in each of the city's 25 business improvement districts, expand public library hours citywide to six days a week, double the number of community health clinics his administration has promised to build, expand health services to all public schools, and double the number of so-called Beacon schools, which stay open later and offer students social-service programs.
 
Help for Small Businesses
 In what appeared to reflect a desire to appeal to voters who own small businesses, Mr. Dinkins advanced several initiatives to help small businesses. He proposed exempting 28,000 more small businesses from the commercial rent tax and said he would cut back on the summonses issued to mom-and-pop businesses for minor sanitation violations by about 46,000. He also said he would like to grant a 10 percent rent-tax credit to businesses that give to cultural institutions.
"We need to get the government off the backs of small business in this town," Mr. Dinkins said.
He did not say how he was going to pay for these relatively inexpensive programs when the city is facing a $1.7 billion budget gap in the fiscal year, though his aides said most of them could be accomplished through more borrowing rather than using general tax revenues that would increase the shortfall. If the Mayor accomplished everything in his speech, the city would give up about $35 million in tax revenues and would pay for about $25 million in new programs out of the operating budget.
 
A Friendly Audience
 Speaking from a podium at the head of the Citt Council chamber against a backdrop of flags, Mr. Dinkins delivered his speech in a firm voice to a friendly audience of about 500 people, including commissioners, elected officials, lobbyists and his political allies. He was interrupted with applause 46 times.
The longest applause came toward the end of the speech when he spoke with emotion of the promise of opportunity that New York City represented to its residents, old and new, rich and poor, native-born and immigrant.
"I stand before all of you, my friends and colleagues," he said, "ready to share again the dream that only New Yorkers can know, the dream of Manhattan's towers, and the bravery of firefighters, the dream of homeowners and barrio dwellers, the dream of a maid's son from Harlem who became Mayor of this greatest house every built."
The audience stood and clapped for several minutes. "Thank you," he added. "God bless you."
While the Mayor is not required by law to give a State of the City address, most mayors have chosen to use it as a way to announce policy shifts and to gain support in the City Council for their initiatives. Though Mr. Dinkins has not officially kicked off his campaign, the speech included the basic message he will try to hammer home over the next nine months, mayoral advisers said.
It is a campaign that will place Mr. Dinkins's record under intense scrutiny, including city services that were either ignored by the Mayor or touched on lightly in the speech. For instance, the administration's handling of child-abuse cases has come under increasing fire in recent days after a city-appointed panel determined that deep staff cuts among social workers had weakened the city's ability to detect abuse and intervene. The holes in the safety net led to several unnecessary deaths and contributed to a record year of homicides in families already proved to be abusive, critics say.
Advocates for the homeless have also repeatedly asserted that Mr. Dinkins's administration has badly mismanaged the shelter system and has been unable to comply with court orders to provide shelter. A judge recently found the city in contempt of court orders for continuing to allow the homeless to sleep in emergency assistance offices.
 
Fiscal Questions Raised
 Many elected officials in the audience took Mr. Dinkins's remarks yesterday with a grain of salt, saying his ideas -- especially relief for small businesses -- sounded good if they come to pass. But some raised questions about how Mr. Dinkins would pay for the new initiatives.
"I only hope the promises that are made become reality," the Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, said. "The promises and the wish list have to become the product of tomorrow."
He said that while he agreed with Mr. Dinkins's desire to cut rent taxes for small businesses, he would not support doing it by giving a tax credit to them if they give money to cultural institutions. The rent tax should be eliminated, he said, and money for museums and other arts groups should be found elsewhere.
Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, called the speech "very impressive because of the number of specific new initiatives the Mayor was prepared to take even in tough economic times." She said he was at last responding to the needs of some of his core constituents, like small-business owners and working families, whose problems have been largely ignored while the administration struggled with fiscal problems.
 
A Different Picture
 Although the speech was warmly received in the Council chamber, the Mayor's opponents and critics painted a much different picture of his administration's accomplishments.
Mr. Giuliani, the likely Republican mayoral candidate who lost to Mr. Dinkins by a narrow margin in 1989, said that while the administration has been successful in keeping a few companies from moving out of the city, New York has lost more than 400,000 jobs during Mr. Dinkins's tenure. He faulted Mr. Dinkins for not proposing a program to generate jobs. He also said the speech included no plans for cutting the budget deficit or wresting more productivity from city workers.
"His speech attempts to be everything to everybody instead of setting forth priorities and talking about the overall things that would be helpful, like how to get control of the governmental work force," Mr. Giuliani said.
Mr. Stein said keeping libraries open longer would be a minor accomplishment, considering the deep cuts Mr. Dinkins has made in the education budget and the overcrowding in schools. "I think there was some good rhetoric in the speech, but what the city needs is not some good rhetoric but sweeping change," he said.
 
Advantage in Police Exam
 In discussing the Mayor's proposal to give city residents an advantage on the police exam, city officials noted that blacks now account for about 25 percent of the city's population but make up only 12.5 percent of the uniformed police force. Mr. Dinkins called for a major new effort to recruit black officers, including recruitment drives at military bases.
The Mayor also said he had asked senior advisers to create new promotional paths to make it easier for civilian Police Department employees to become uniformed officers. More than 50 percent of the department's civilian workers are black and about 14 percent are Hispanic, according to city officials.
Phil Caruso, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, could not be reached for comment last night on the Mayor's proposals.
Leland T. Jones, the Mayor's press secretary, said the city was studying whether the proposals would require approval by the Legislature. He said municipal officials thought they would probably have to seek legislative approval to give bonus points to city residents on Civil Service exams.
State lawmakers have resisted previous proposals to require officers to live in the city. Legislative leaders said yesterday that they would study the Mayor's new proposals before commenting on them.

HEADLINE: In an Armed Land, Somalis Live and Prosper by the Gun

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Jan. 4

 BODY:
Bashir Aynab Ali got his first assault rifle two years ago, when a relative handed him a stolen AK-47 to join the revolt against President Mohammed Siad Barre.
It was his rite of passage into Somalia's world of the gunman, a treacherous universe of Robin Hood-style thieves of some honor, murderers with no honor, and survival by the barrel of the gun. For the 22-year-old, the gun turned out to be more useful than a baccalaureate. 
 As Somalia descended into anarchy, Mr. Ali's AK-47 guaranteed him employment in one of the country's few growth businesses -- hired bodyguard work. It gave him the power to get food during a famine. And it was a negotiable currency, one that could be exchanged for regular money for life's essentials.
 
Means of Survival
 "I took the gun to save my life," said the slender young man with a scar across his face from a fight. "I took it to survive, for any circumstance I would meet."
Somalia's guns came with the cold war -- aid for President Siad Barre, first from the Soviet Union, then from the United States. When Mr. Siad Barre fell, Government garrisons were overrun, the weapons becoming the looted property of the people.
Before American troops landed here, nine types of artillery pieces were said to be in common use in Mogadishu -- one French, three American and five Soviet.
The gun culture is pervasive, with AK-47's fired into the air in celebration after weddings. Private homes have their own heavy weapons. On the streets, pitifully thin urchins sit in the dirt playing with empty shiny brass AK-47 shells as toys.
When the Americans arrived more than three weeks ago, many Somalis expected disarmament to be a top priority. Prices for assault rifles fell almost overnight from $150 to $50. Now, with the United States military insisting that its mission is to deliver food, many here seem to be virtually demanding that the Americans save Somalis from themselves.
"I think if they are not going to disarm, they should go back home," said Abdu Baffo, an agronomist working with the British branch of Save the Children. "Why did we need the intervention? Because we were unable to sit down and sort out factors by ourselves, and arms are the reason we couldn't do so."
On the surface, conditions look safer. The jeeps armed with anti-aircraft guns and rocket launchers have disappeared from the streets under agreements between warlords negotiated by United States officials. And the market where grenades and ammunition was as prevalent as food has pretty much evaporated in the last few days.
 
Just a Change of Venue
 But Somalis say the looters in the capital have simply moved off the thoroughfares traveled by American troops and into other neighborhoods, where they terrorize local residents.
Many people also admit that they are hiding their weapons at home or under blankets in their cars.
And it still seems as if almost every man and boy owns at least one assault rifle -- people like 16-year-old Assad Abdi Mohammed, whose teeth are stained brown from chewing khat, or Mohammed Jailani, a health official who bought two automatic rifles to defend his home from looters, or Ujer Ali Sheik, a onetime Government clerk who admits that he used to watch for food deliveries and then raid the warehouses, using his rifle as persuasion.
"If there is food I must take it because nobody will ever give it to me," said the 28-year-old father of four, whose face is drawn, aged beyond his years. "I must save my children. When it comes, they will not give it out in a regular way, so you must get it by force."
 
Job Creation
 In a world hostage to guns, even the gunmen dream of deliverance. Young Assad cradles his weapon in his sarong and talks of selling it to the Americans for $500, a fivefold markup over its original purchase price. He reasons that he would then have enough cash to go into business as a money changer.
Mr. Ali says he is ready to give his weapon without payment, though disarmament is clearly a chancy proposition for him in a country where unemployment is the norm. Since he turned 20, he has spent what he had hoped would be his university years surviving by the gun.
In January 1991, as part of a group that stormed an arsenal, Mr. Ali seized 40 weapons, most AK-47's and M-16's, and sold the bulk of them at handsome prices. When food became scarce, he turned to his gun once again.
"There are looters who would break into houses," he said. "I decided only to go with food supplies." Over the last two years, he said, "everybody was using a gun and nobody will tell you that he is a looter."
He insists that he was not a thief but a protector when he rode alongside relief food convoys in a souped-up car full of weapons to ward off other attackers. As payment, he would get four or five sacks of food.
 
Unfriendly Competition
 He said he was the breadwinner for 20 families -- his own family of 16 children, plus neighbors and friends. There were exchanges of fire over the food convoys, he said, his car of gunmen turning against their friends in a second vehicle when the other group tried to make an end run and divert the food trucks.
"We were together and this started a conflict between us," he said, describing how the two carloads fired at each other until the attacker ran out of ammunition and the theft was foiled.
Several weeks ago, in anticipation of the American landing, Mr. Ali modified his line of work. He now rides shotgun as a guard for a friend with a pickup truck. They hire themselves out as a package deal -- a taxi with its own protection.
He is waiting for the day when the Marines will show up to collect his AK-47 along with everyone else's. But he insists that he will give it up only to an American.
"If I give it to a Somali," he said, "he will kill me."

HEADLINE: Wroclaw Journal;
Yes, Class, Once Upon a Time This Was Germany

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WROCLAW, Poland

 BODY:
Here, in the largest city of the lands Poland annexed from Germany in 1945, the advent of democracy since the overthrow of Communism has meant even more than in the rest of the country.
A democratic, even quarrelsome, political life has sprung up. Private stores, loudly advertising the consumer goods of the West, compete for customers along streets whose shop windows for more than four decades hid chronic shortages of nearly everything desirable behind dull, gray displays of empty packages. 
 "The sidewalks are becoming more even," said Juliet Golden, an American who for more than a year has headed a program to teach English to the executives of an engineering and machine-building concern in which a Swiss-Swedish company has invested. Since their liberation from highly centralized control, Polish towns have begun to repair the damages of many years of neglect.
Yet there is another dimension that makes Wroclaw special. For the first time since becoming Polish, Wroclaw (pronounced VROH-tswaff) is free to own up to its past.
 
City Denied a History
 Until the fall of Communism, many say, residents lived in an ancient city that was allowed no history.
"Man needs memory, and here we were not allowed one," said Maciej Lagiewski, director of the Historical Museum of the city. "We were allowed only the stupid Communist history, which leaped from the Piasts to 1945." The Piasts were a Slavic dynasty that ruled over a large region from the 10th to the 14th centuries and created a great Polish empire.
For the first time since Stalin compensated Poland for seizing large parts of its eastern region for the Soviet Union by handing over the German territories of Silesia, Pomerania and part of East Prussia, people in Wroclaw now speak with assurance of their possession of this city of 650,000. This is the same number of residents as in its German days, when it was called Breslau, and most were born here. They no longer need to pretend the city was always Polish instead of German for 600 years.
"There is no culture without history," said Barbara Piegdon, an editor of the local edition of Gazeta Wyborcza, a national newspaper. "The Communists created a myth that we Poles came back here." She stressed "back," which was the heart of the myth.
 
Germans and Poles Go West
 At the end of the war, the German population was expelled westward, and most Poles who settled here came from the eastern territories from which the Soviet Union drove them.
Acknowledging the truth has freed people from the nervousness with which they had greeted German visitors in the past. In 1990, a German Consulate was opened, a major concession in a city in which even German tour groups were viewed with tense caution, as if they were a vanguard of people seeking to reclaim what had been theirs. Consul General Bruno Weber said his relations with Poles at all levels were marked by what he called a special friendliness.
Wojciech Wrzesinski, rector of Wroclaw University, has pointedly reminded Mr. Weber that Germany has failed so far to fulfill his request to open a German cultural institute. This contrasts with the successful effort of the past to remove every German inscription or other reminder of the non-Polish past.
 
Changing Street Names
 For the fifth time this century, Wroclaw is engaged in a wholesale change of street names; 100 so far, the Mayor said. Each period of the city's agitated history has been inaugurated by such mass rechristenings.
The Imperial German names were changed with the proclamation of the Weimar Republic in 1918. There was extensive renaming when Hitler came to power in 1933. All German names were replaced in 1945, and many were replaced after the Polish revolt of 1956.
Other inscriptions of the past have merely been translated. While in the Nazi era, "Jews to Palestine" was a common scrawling on walls, "Jews to Israel" was smeared in big letters on a building near Mielecka Street, which had many Jewish tenants before the deportation of the city's Jews from 1941 to 1943. Breslau had about 30,000 Jews; Wroclaw today has fewer than 100.
 
Restoring a Graveyard
 The museum director, Mr. Lagiewski, said "most people here" criticized him for a commitment he has kept since the 1970's. Beginning almost singlehandedly, Mr. Lagiewski has largely restored the oldest remaining German Jewish cemetery, whose graves, numbering more than 12,000, mainly of the last century, had lain overgrown, vandalized and neglected since the 1930's.
In interviews and random conversations, most people said they were better off now than under Communism, but complained that they had expected greater and quicker improvement from the introduction of a market economy. But all volubly rejected a wish for a return of Communism.
Even the spokesman for the successor to the former ruling party, the Social Democracy Party, said he did not wish for that. "The people are still afraid of us," Czeslaw Cyrul, the spokesman, said. "They think we want to return to Communism. But we say, 'no return to the past.' We are for capitalism. It's the most effective system that has been invented."

"We were allowed only the stupid Communist history, which leaped from the Piasts to 1945." He helped a researcher from Berlin locate a grave in the city's oldest German Jewish cemetery. (Witold Jaroslaw Szulecki for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Northwest Is Laying Off 1,043 More to Cut Costs

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
In a continuing effort to cut costs and conserve cash, Northwest Airlines said yesterday that it was laying off 1,043 workers, or about 2 percent of its work force of 47,000.
The airline, which early last month canceled or deferred the delivery of $6.2 bilion worth of aircraft and arranged $250 million in new loans to strengthen its finances, has been struggling to get through a period of low passenger traffic. 
 Northwest laid off about 2,100 workers in the last year and is seeking to restructure the huge debt it acquired when it was taken private in 1989 in a leveraged buyout led by its current chairman, Alfred Checchi.
The current layoffs will affect mostly flight attendants -- 780 will be dismissed. The rest of the layoffs will come from the ranks of the ground crews and ticket agents. The attendants were hired since March 14, 1992, and are expected to be eligible for severance payments under their contract. Those laid off will be considered on furlough for three years, meaning they would be the first rehired if Northwest expanded its work force again.
 
Fewer Attendants Needed
 The airline said that fewer flights and the replacement of wide-body aircraft with smaller planes on some routes had cut the number of attendants needed. It said that its service should not be affected by the layoffs.
Barry Kotar, a senior vice president, said that "adverse economic conditions and the brutal economic environment of the U.S. airline industry have required us to take aggressive action to reduce costs and improve operational efficiency."
Ron Carey, the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which represents about 8,000 flight attendants at Northwest, said his union would agree to help Northwest attain $300 million a year in concessions like salary and work-rule changes from all its unions, but only if the owners of Northwest also contributed to the solution and if employees were given "the checks and balances they need" to protect what they have sacrificed for the company.
The company has agreed to meet with Mr. Carey today to discuss holding negotiations on new contracts intended to provide substantial savings for the company.
All of the big carriers have suffered because they added too many new planes to their fleets just as traffic growth was slowing considerably; many resorted to price cutting to fill the seats. Most major carriers have also cut back on employment, particularly USAir.
The problems of Northwest have been aggravated by the interest costs and principal repayments on its debt of $3.65 billion.
The airline, in one of the most drastic moves in the industry, has cut orders for 50 A320's and 24 A340's from Airbus Industries, the European airplane maker. It also delayed the delivery of $2.7 billion worth of Boeing aircraft.

HEADLINE: Clinton to Meet Auto Chiefs

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 4

 BODY:
The chief executives of the Big Three auto makers and the president of the United Automobile Workers union are scheduled to meet Wednesday with President-elect Bill Clinton, industry officials said today.
Spokesmen for General Motors, Ford Motor and Chrysler confirmed the meeting but said details would come from Mr. Clinton's staff. A U.A.W. spokesman said he could not immediately confirm the participation of the union's president, Owen Bieber. 
 The meeting in Little Rock, Ark., would come two days before Mr. Clinton is scheduled to meet with Mexico's President, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, in Texas to discuss the pending North American Free Trade Agreement. The Big Three auto makers favor the agreement, seeing economic expansion and opportunity in Mexico. The U.A.W. opposes it, saying it fears thousands of manufacturing jobs will be moved to Mexico.
The Big Three chief executives are John F. Smith Jr. of G.M., Harold A. Poling of Ford and Robert Eaton of Chrysler. Topics for possible discussion, in addition to Mexico, include health care. The Big Three say they have a huge disadvantage on health-care costs, as much as $800 a vehicle, compared with Japanese auto makers.

HEADLINE: Dividends Were Better, but Not Great, Last Year

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
The year just ended brought the first improvement in corporate dividends in years. But because the numbers were already so low, Wall Street is not popping champagne corks just yet.
In 1992, more companies reinstated dividends, announced higher dividends or gave extra dividends than in either of the previous two years. But on the other hand, that number is still the third lowest since comparable figures began to be compiled in 1955, the Standard & Poor's Corporation reported yesterday. 
 Such figures reflect tepid growth in confidence in the economy among corporate executives, and the year ended with some scattered signs of continued revival.
In the last two months of the year, more companies announced extra dividends than had done so at any time since December 1990, providing more hope that dwindling corporate profits are on the mend. November also saw the single-highest monthly jump in more than two years in the number of dividend increases.
 
Reflection of Expectations
 The dividend figures are an important gauge of companies' past performance and future expectations, because dividends are where corporate executives and directors back up their actions and predictions with cash. Companies with poor performance or expectations of significant troubles in the coming year are loath to distribute cash through dividend payments, so such payouts usually reflect confidence of smooth sailing ahead.
The fact that so many companies were seeing greater profit strength throughout the year underscores the almost imperceptible turns of a changing economy as companies begin to throw off the uncertainty of a recession.
And the overall strength of the American economy is reflected in the fact that even in a troubled year there were more than six times as many announcements of dividend increases, reinstatements and extra dividends as there were of dividend reductions and omissions.
The total of 1,703 favorable dividend announcements was the third smallest for any year since S.& P. began compiling figures, larger only than the results of the last two years. But the figure represented a healthy 16.8 percent jump over the results of 1991, the worst year on record. The number of bad announcements also dropped more than 36 percent, to 277, from 437 last year.
"This was an improvement, but it was nothing to write home about," said Arnold Kaufman, the editor of S.& P.'s Outlook newsletter. "While a better dividend year, 1992 was not outstanding by any means."
The ratio of good news to bad was 6.1 to 1, a significant improvement over last year, when the recession narrowed the ratio to 3.3 to 1. But, despite the growth, the results for 1992 were still anemic compared with those of some recent years. As recently as 1988, for example, there were more than 12 positive dividend announcements for every negative one.
The number of companies announcing dividend increases is perhaps the most closely watched of the three possible types of good news for dividends. In 1992, that number jumped to 1,333, from 1,086 in the previous year. That was the lowest for any year since 1971, when Federal wage and price controls held the figures down. Excluding the 1970-71 period, the 1992 figure was the third lowest since 1961.
There were a few indications of uncertainty. For example, the seasonal high for dividend increases is normally from November to February, as more and more companies anticipate good annual profit news. The 121 such increases last month were more than in any December for the last three years, but were significantly fewer than the 146 increases in November.
But fewer companies omitted dividends in 1992, with 146 companies eliminating such payments, compared with a hefty 250 in the previous year.
There was a small increase in the dividends paid on the stocks that make up the S.& P. 500 index as a group. That payout is computed based on what would be received by an owner of all 500 stocks, whose holdings of mostly fractional shares were worth a total of the S.& P. index's stated price, which was $435.38 yesterday.
Mr. Kaufman of S.& P. estimated that the figure for 1992 would be $12.38, up 1.4 percent from the 1991 figure of $12.20.
But he is also predicting a heftier climb in the dividend payouts in 1993, to as much as $13.12 for the year. That growth is not as steep as it may appear: When all of the changes for the year are taken into account, on an annual basis, the S.& P. 500 would have an indicated dividend rate of $12.58, Mr. Kaufman said, a jump of more almost 4 percent over the annual rate of $12.13 at the start of 1992.
"That is one of the reasons we are looking for a larger increase in 1993," he said.
But such increases are going to be less sharp than in the past because of the same forces that are leading to a tepid recovery, including the debt that remains from the 1980's, the budget constraints for Federal and municipal governments, and continued corporate restructurings. "These are all things we expect will hold back economic expansion and dividend actions," Mr. Kaufman said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises on Indications Of Strengthening Economy

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar advanced sharply on world currency markets yesterday, piercing key levels against several currencies.
In Europe, the German mark was troubled after the resignation on Sunday of Economics Minister Jurgen Mollemann, who stepped down in the midst of a scandal. Mr. Mollemann admitted signing letters endorsing a product made by a company headed by a relative. 
 "That was an excuse to sell the mark," said Randolph Donney, research director at Pegasus Econometric Group. Other European currencies also came under pressure, prompting the central banks of German and France to step in to prop up a declining French franc, analysts said.
Supporting the dollar was the general belief that the United States economy is going to fare far better than European and the Japanese economies, Mr. Donney said.
The latest evidence supporting the notion of an recovery was a Government report showing that construction spending had jumped 2.1 percent in November to the highest level in more than two years.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 124.90 yen, up 0.25 yen from Thursday's close. Later in London, it rose to 125.40 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 125.30 yen, up from 124.85 yen on Thursday.
In London, the pound fell to $1.5010, from $1.5140 late Thursday. In New York it cost $1.5000 to buy 1, less expensive than Thursday's $1.5105.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Thursday's late rates, included: 1.6395 German marks, up from 1.6206; 1.4800 Swiss francs, up from 1.4670; 5.5950 French francs, up from 5.5265; 1,530.50 Italian lire, up from 1,472.50, and 1.2816 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2710.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Thursday's late rates, included: 1.6385 German marks, up from 1.6135; 1.4805 Swiss francs, up from 1.4550; 5.5960 French francs, up from 5.5000; 1.8412 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8100; 1,520.50 Italian lire, up from 1,469.00, and 1.2780 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2686.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Contract Prices Drop To Lowest Level in 7 Years

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Gold futures prices fell to their lowest level in seven years yesterday, continuing a downward spiral that began in 1990.
Pushed down by a rising dollar, gold for January delivery dropped by $4.70 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange in New York yesterday, to $328.10. The more actively traded February contract also dropped $4.70, to $328.40. In London, gold was selling at $328.25 an ounce at the afternoon fixing, a drop of $4.75 an ounce from its close on Dec. 30. 
 In recent months, the dollar's strength has prompted selling by gold-producing countries like Australia, South Africa and Russia, and it did so again yesterday.
A stronger dollar encourages other countries to sell gold because it increases revenue they receive for gold. Because gold trades in dollars, a rising dollar amounts to a price increase for these foreign gold producers.
Trading in gold was thin, but gold traders said there were few reasons to expect that gold's slide would end soon.
Denise Giordano, a director and head of the precious metals department at the Swiss Bank Corporation, said that while demand from jewelry fabricators remained good, "fundamental speculators are not holding gold any more."
The absence of speculators "has turned gold more into a jewelry item than a financial instrument," Ms. Giordano added.
Over the last three years, the average price of gold has declined steadily, from $383 an ounce in 1990 to $362 in 1991 and just under $345 last year. After accounting for inflation, gold prices now are at their lowest levels since the mid-1970's, shortly after President Richard M. Nixon took the United States off the gold standard.
Despite the negatives, gold still has further to fall before it reaches the $282-an-ounce price recorded in March 1985. Nevertheless, at current levels prices are only just above the level of $290 to $325 an ounce that analysts say represents marginal production costs.
"Prices of a commodity can dip below that level for a period," said James R. Steel, senior commodities analyst at Refco Inc., the Chicago commodities trading firm. "But it is anybody's guess how long prices could stay below that before we saw a cut in production."
The slide in gold prices "is partly a result of the growing popularity of paper assets, like stocks and bonds," said David Poole, chief economist at Van Eck Associates, a mutual fund manager. Traders and analysts said speculative buyers would likely reappear if gold prices fell further.
"Some people say gold might never come back." Ms. Giordano at the Swiss Bank said. "Never is a long time, but in my 14 years in the market, this is the worst I have seen."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Emmerling Doubles in Size With an Assist From Lintas

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
WHEN a top executive leaves an agency with several clients and employees in tow, turmoil and finger-pointing usually follow, not to mention a lawsuit or two. But in one instance, the departure has been so amicable that the agency involved helped make the migration happen.
Effective this week, Peter Post, the president and chief operating officer of Lintas Marketing Communications, is taking six of the agency's accounts and seven staff members and joining John Emmerling Inc. in New York to create Emmerling Post Inc. Lintas Marketing, which wants to concentrate on marketing services for its large clients like Coca-Cola, is willingly letting Mr. Post depart with its smaller advertising accounts, including Midlantic Bank and Continental Insurance. 
 It is appropriate that the new year should begin with a deal, since a wave of mergers and acquisitions is expected in 1993 throughout the advertising industry as it continues consolidating in the wake of a severe and prolonged recession.
 By reconfiguring itself as Emmerling Post, Emmerling, a 17-year-old shop specializing in media accounts like Reader's Digest and the Magazine Publishers of America, doubles in size, to about $25 million in billings.
"We came up with the name Emmerling Post," Mr. Post said during an interview at the Emmerling Post office, formerly the Emmerling office in midtown Manhattan, "because John thought 'Post Emmerling' meant 'after Emmerling.' "
John Emmerling, who is 55 and had been chairman, president and chief executive at Emmerling, becomes chairman of Emmerling Post. Mr. Post, who is 45, assumes the titles of president and chief operating officer.
"We're purposely not having a chief executive officer," said Mr. Emmerling, who joined Mr. Post for the interview, "because we're equal partners in this venture.
"We're sharing everything," he added, "including an office." Indeed, Mr. Emmerling and Mr. Post are tucking themselves into an office that had previously been solely Mr. Emmerling's.
The formation of Emmerling Post begins the new year auspiciously for Mr. Emmerling. Though 1992 was his agency's "most successful year ever," he said, in November he suffered the loss of the high-profile Newsweek account, with an estimated $3 million to $5 million in billings, to Jerry Inc., Jerry Della Femina's new shop.
Mr. Emmerling and Mr. Post said Emmerling Post would seek to specialize in accounts in four fields: media, financial services, technology and health care. Neither man, of course, would turn away other types of business; Mr. Emmerling remembered how Emmerling opened with the Cookin' Good chicken account: "We took on Frank Perdue head-to-head, with the slogan 'New York is no longer a one-chicken town.' Though he ran Cookin' Good out of town, we gave him a good fight."
The genesis of Emmerling Post was the decision of Lintas Worldwide, the parent of Lintas Marketing, that it could no longer profitably serve the small advertising accounts its subsidiary was handling. Besides Midlantic and Continental Insurance, Mr. Post's other accounts at Lintas Marketing, all of which agreed to move to Emmerling Post, included the Long Island Savings Bank and the Swiss Bank Corporation.
"We never would have asked Peter to leave were it not for this particular situation," Spencer Plavoukos, president and chairman of the Americas zone at Lintas Worldwide in New York, said in a telephone interview.
After various alternatives were discussed for handling the departing accounts, he added, the option of Mr. Post's joining forces with Mr. Emmerling was deemed the best.
"I hold both those guys in high esteem and affection," Mr. Plavoukos said. "I think to the extent there are marriages made in heaven, this is one of them."
In a small-world situation commonplace in advertising, Mr. Plavoukos and Mr. Emmerling once worked together, at Richard K. Manoff Inc. in New York. Also, Mr. Post recalled that a couple of years ago, he suggested that Mr. Emmerling close his agency and join Lintas Marketing.
"But John was more interested in being independent," Mr. Post said. "Thank you, John, for that."
In shedding its small advertising accounts, Lintas Marketing will continue to handle giant multinational clients like Coke, General Motors and I.B.M., concentrating on what are known as integrated marketing communications functions, which include sales promotion, direct marketing and co-op advertising.
Rather than replace Mr. Post, Mr. Plavoukos said, Lintas Marketing would be reorganized so that its offices, in Los Angeles, New York and Warren, Mich., a Detroit suburb, would now report directly to Frank Hoag, the chairman, who divides his time among the three.

HEADLINE: Construction In Nation Up In November

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4

 BODY:
Construction spending in the nation rose in November, the Commerce Department reported today, and a survey of midsized businesses indicated an improving economy.
The department said spending on residential, nonresidential and government construction rose 2.1 percent, to $441.8 billion, from $432.8 billion in October. 
 "I would expect the residential numbers will continue to climb modestly as the housing market continues to strengthen," said David Berson, an economist with the Federal National Mortgage Association. "But some sectors, such as apartments and office buildings, are likely to remain weak for a while because of high vacancy rates."
The survey of midsized companies released today by the American Business Conference also pointed to slow improvement in the January-March quarter compared with the previous three months. Members of the conference predicted modest improvements in key business indicators, including sales and investment.
 
More Employment Expected
 Thirty-four percent of the companies surveyed said they planned to expand employment, up from 25 percent in the last survey; 25 percent expected lower employment and 41 percent forecast no change in the number of jobs.
"Our companies are telling us that in the current economic environment, business success means keeping margins razor thin while emphasizing productivity gains among the existing work force," Barry Rogstad, president of the conference, said. "ABC members don't yet see much room for expansion either in profits or job creation."
November's construction increase was the third in a row, but the department revised its preliminary estimate of a 1 percent gain in October to eight-tenths of 1 percent.
Residential outlays rose 1.4 percent in November, to $193.5 billion, after gaining 2.4 percent a month earlier. It was the fourth straight advance.
 
Almost as Good as October
 Spending on one-family homes rose 3.1 percent, to $126.5 billion, nearly matching October's 3.3 percent advance. Spending on apartments dropped 4.8 percent, the third drop in a row, to $11.8 billion, after a 1.6 percent dip the previous month.
"There have been two areas of real weakness over the past several years -- apartment building and nonresidential," Mr. Berson said. "And for the same reason: There was significant overconstruction during the 1980's and there remains considerable oversupply."
Nonresidential spending, however, did post a 3.1 percent increase, to $87.2 billion, nearly double the 1.6 percent gain in October. But Mr. Berson said he did not expect improvements soon in many areas of this sector, including office buildings and other commercial projects, like shopping centers, which were overbuilt in many parts of the country.
"But as the economy expands," he said, "I would expect other nonresidential areas, such as factories, to pick up as firms begin to spend on plants and equipment."
Government agencies increased spending 3.2 percent, to $122.2 billion, wiping out a 1.7 percent decline in October.
"We would view the increase in public construction as more of a one-month phenomenon" because of state and local budget cutbacks, said Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities in New York.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Construction Spending" shows total construction spending from June 1991 to Nov. 1992. (Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: Banks Must Soon Report Loan 'Fair Value'

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Banks will be required in annual reports issued early this year to disclose for the first time their estimates of the "fair value" of their loans -- a change long sought by critics who have contended that overly generous accounting rules allowed banks to hide losses on bad loans.
Banks now carry loans on their books at their original value if the bank expects to be repaid in full, even if a borrower gets in trouble and the bank would suffer a loss from selling the loan. 
 The new disclosure will be required only as a footnote and will not affect the profits of banks or the capital they have accumulated to absorb future losses. But it could be a harbinger of more far-reaching changes in the accounting rules, which are crucial to customers, investors and regulators trying to measure a bank's strength.
Early indications by accountants and bankers are that the disclosure will not portray banks in a weaker light, contrary to the expectation of some of its proponents. William P. Hannon, partner at KPMG Peat Marwick, a leading accounting firm for banks, said the new rule "is not going to show the banking industry facing new problems."
Properly run banks have already acknowledged bad loans by subtracting a provision for loan losses from their profits, he said. And the new footnote rule, adopted by the Securities and Exchange Commission, gives banks enough flexibility to estimate "fair value" for loans on historical experience, not just the fire-sale price that might be required for quick sale.
That conclusion is much different from the expectation of Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas and chairman of the House Banking Committee, who said in a letter in November to Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, that the fair-value accounting would pierce "accounting camouflage" and "prove numerous banks to be insolvent."
But even if the application of the rule is not as painful as Mr. Gonzalez expects, bankers and other analysts worry that future versions of fair-value accounting rules might be less flexible and require lower estimated values for loans even when a bank has no intention of selling a loan.
Federal bank regulators are expected to announce this month their own proposals for disclosing "fair values" and the Financial Accounting Standards Board, which makes rules for the accounting industry, is working on proposals to make "fair value" the core of bank accounting and not just a footnote. Opponents say that such a policy could discourage banks from issuing any but the safest loans, thereby hurting the economy and making it harder for small- and medium-sized businesses to grow.
 
System Is Criticized
 Those warnings and objections that estimates of loans' fair value may be fraught with error have not stopped the S.E.C., some members of Congress and academic experts from espousing fair-value accounting, also called fair-market-value or mark-to-market accounting.
"Right now we have a bank accounting system that is backward looking, based on costs rather than today's prices," said Lawrence J. White, an economics professor at the New York University Stern School of Business. "It's a system that presents too many opportunities to understate losses from bad loans and to understate the severity of the problems at a troubled bank."
In 1990 and 1991 the General Accounting Office, responding to Congressional requests for studies about the causes of the savings and loan debacle and rise in bank failures, issued reports concluding that bank accounting rules made it too easy for bankers and regulators to overlook or ignore losses on bad loans.
Bankers and regulators concede there are abuses of historical cost accounting, but, in the phrasing of Winston Churchill, they say it is the worst system, except for all the others.
Mr. Greenspan said in a speech in November that the issuing of loans to a bank's local customers that could not be readily sold (and for that very reason would probably be worth less than their face amount) "is the competitive reason for banks' existence." To measure such a loan by its market value, the price it might fetch in a quick sale, "is a misapplication of accounting principles," he said.
 
The Current System
 The system now used, and favored by bankers and their regulators, says loans should be carried at the bank's best estimate of the payments it will receive from the borrower. When a loan becomes troubled, banks subtract from their profits an amount, called a loan-loss provision, based on the shortfall in repayment they expect, plus some additional amount to cover problems not foreseen. When a loan gets too dicey, it is written off as a loss in whole or in part, and the write-off is subtracted from reserves.
In 1990 and 1991, banks got a hint of fair-value accounting when Federal examiners prodded them to report their losses on commercial real estate loans more quickly than they wanted. Bankers would have preferred a slower-paced disclosure of their losses, similar to what regulators allowed for loans to less-developed countries (where five years elapsed between Mexico's 1982 default and the large provisions for losses made by banks in 1987).
The delay would have given banks time to wait for real estate markets to improve, or to accumulate capital so they could more easily absorb the losses without creating the kind of alarms that depressed bank stock prices so badly in 1990.
Regulatory zeal in attacking bad loans "scared the flexibility out of the banking system and made banks unwilling to help other companies who were not in default through the tough times," said Joseph Blair, executive director of the Massachusetts Industrial Finance Agency, a state-sponsored agency.
 
A 'G.N.P. Cruncher'
 The experience of the last few years led David C. Cates, chairman of Ferguson & Company, a Washington consulting firm, to conclude that "a mark-to-market accounting rule would be a real G.N.P. cruncher." He said there was a legitimate need for more information about the quality of banks' loans, but that need could be satisfied through less drastic means than a new accounting system.
Bankers, at any rate, are concluding that the new footnote in annual reports to be issued in March will not reveal them to be weaker than the official financial reports. They note that many personal loans, like those for credit cards, are worth more than their face value because they carry high interest rates. In the case of weak loans, losses have already been acknowledged. And banks whose credit ratings have fallen will be able to report a gain on long-term bonds issued at lower interest rates.
William P. O'Halloran, chief financial officer at Suntrust Banks Inc., a banking company in Georgia and Florida, said the sharp drop in interest rates in the last few years would improve banks' financial picture in the new footnote. For example, loans issued with fixed interest rates before or during the period of declining rates could be worth more than 100 cents on the dollar, assuming that the borrower's credit quality has been stable.
At Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, Thomas E. Jones, chief financial officer, said "people may be surprised" that the footnote to its annual report would not support some analysts' assertions that ordinary accounting rules have allowed it to conceal losses on commercial real estate loans and overstate its financial strength.
Mr. Jones said that after write-offs of loans and foreclosed property totaling $2.8 billion since the end of 1990, Citicorp's $6.5 billion of troubled commercial real estate loans and foreclosed commercial properties are carried on its books at 55 to 60 cents for each dollar of the original loan.

HEADLINE: Mayans Had a Middle Class, Too

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

 BODY:
Digging deeper, clearing away thickets of misconception and finally deciphering obscure glyphs, archeologists are developing striking new images of the ancient Mayans of Central America as a people with a more richly textured society than previously imagined.
No longer are they idolized as an exceptionally peaceful people; their kings made a habit of bloody wars of conquest. Their agriculture was not so primitive; they practiced intensive farming sufficient to feed large urban populations. Their art and technology were not necessarily derived from the powerful cultures of temperate Central Mexico; on their own the Mayans evolved an innovative, vibrant civilization in the tropical lowlands. 
 Now evidence is accumulating to support another transformation in thinking. The Mayans, it appears, did not have an invariably simple social structure divided sharply between the rulers and nobles on top and the multitude of poor working peasants. As some kingdoms prospered, new excavations reveal, the gulf between the two disparate groups began to be filled with a growing middle class.
Some of the most persuasive clues for the existence of a Mayan middle class emerged last year from the tombs and ruins of Caracol, which was the capital of one of the major Mayan kingdoms in what is now Belize. Archeologists said similar evidence is being found at sites in Guatemala and the Yucatan of Mexico.
The new findings not only challenge conventional ideas about a rigid, two-tiered Mayan society, but also undercut a widely held belief that the collapse of the classic Mayan civilization, one of archeology's enduring mysteries, was brought about, in part, by a widening gulf between the rulers and the ruled that led to revolt.
In an announcement of the most recent studies of Caracol, Dr. Arlen F. Chase and Dr. Diane Z. Chase, anthropologists at the University of Central Florida in Orlando, said yesterday that an examination of burial practices and nonroyal workshops and living quarters showed the presence of a large, flourishing middle class in the city throughout the late classic period, from A.D. 550 to 900. If anything, they concluded, the elite and the commoners of Caracol were growing closer over this time.
"There was a large middle group who lived very much in the manner of what we thought was reserved for the nobility," Dr. Diane Chase said. "This is something we have absolutely no doubts about."
The Chases, a husband-and-wife team, and other experts cautioned that the Mayan situation should not be equated with the economic and political status of modern middle classes. Nor is there clear evidence for much social mobility in Caracol. Members of the middle group seem to have been civic administrators, overseers, leading warriors, bone-setters and skilled craftsmen.
Dr. Jeremy A. Sabloff, a Mayan specialist at the University of Pittsburgh, described the Caracol discoveries as exciting and important, "part of a whole change in Maya archeology, in which people are seeing that the older, simpler models are just not sufficient to explain what we are finding in excavations."
Dr. David Friedel, a Mayan archeologist at Southern Methodist University in Dallas, said new research elsewhere was producing evidence of "social rankings below the level of kings in all the well-recorded capitals." One of the current challenges for archeologists and scholars of Mayan hieroglyphics, he said, was to understand the symbols of power used by several different ranks within the elite and to identify those in power and the relation of others to them.
The Chases suspect that the Caracol middle class arose in the wake of military success, beginning in 562 with the conquest of Tikal, another important Mayan city-state in what is today Guatemala. Victory brought wealth and rapid population growth, which scholars now recognize as a motivation for much Mayan warfare in the classic period, from A.D. 250 to 900. From a detailed survey of a Caracol site, covering 55 square miles, an extensive digging, the Chases estimate the city's population may have reached 180,000, making it one of the largest in Mayan history.
 
'Clincher for Hypothesis'
 About 70 formal tombs have been investigated at Caracol over the last eight years, including two intact royal tombs found last year. One tomb, determined to be 1,600 years old, contained the remains of a ruler and another individual, along with a large number of ceramic vessels and jewelry. A painted text dated the construction of the second tomb to 686. It held the remains of four members of a royal family, all resting on a plaster floor covered with jade flakes.
"Those two tombs were the clincher for our hypothesis," Dr. Diane Chase said. She and her husband had already outlined their ideas on the growing middle class in a book, "Mesoamerican Elites: An Archeological Assessment," published last summer by the University of Oklahoma Press. Before these discoveries, the researchers said, it was widely believed that Mayans buried their dead rulers and royal families in ways that differed significantly from the rest of the population. Instead, comparison of these tombs with nonelite burials showed a number of shared practices: the interment of more than one person in the same chamber and the use of identical ritual materials.
The Mayans did not bury their dead in secluded places like cemeteries, but in special buildings that were part of their living complexes. "They had the dead 'live' with them," Dr. Arlen Chase explained. "The dead may have even been formal participants in rituals carried out by their living descendants."
The royal tombs at Caracol may have been somewhat larger than those of the middle-class dead, and more elaborately decorated and inscribed with detailed hieroglyphics. But otherwise, the royal dead were treated much like the others.
Two things were happening, the Chases concluded. More nonelite people could afford to adopt some of the jewelry and ritual customs of the elite, and the elite seemed to make no great effort to maintain some of the more conspicuous class distinctions.
 
Workshops Provide Clues
 In other excavations at Caracol, the Chases identified workshops where craftsmen made jade and shell ornamentation, including rings, necklaces, pendants and earflares, apparently for the growing middle class. The artisans' stone tools were still in some of the shops.
"If these artisans were making things only for elite households, the workshop would be near the elite households," Dr. Diane Chase said. "When we found areas we suspect are workshops, they are not located there, but along the roads leading away from the center. These people were producing things being used by more ordinary people."
Archeologists working with Dr. Arthur Demarest of Vanderbilt University in Nashville have sought to delineate social stratification at Dos Pilas, another large Mayan city-state in Guatemala. They examined patterns of variations in the architecture, masonry, pottery, burials and grave goods at more than 400 households.
Dr. Demarest said the findings supported the middle-class hypothesis, showing "a kind of continuum between rich and the poor, without any sharp breaks in the levels of wealth."
 
Evidence Against Revolt
 Archeologists said the evidence from earlier sites was too sparse to determine if Mayan societies had a substantial middle class before the sixth century. Mayan prehistory extends back to 1200 B.C., but it was the classic period from A.D. 250 to 900 that saw the peak of Mayan civilization, symbolized by the magnificent temples, tombs and pyramids. From the end of the classic period to the arrival of Europeans, the Mayan cities went into a steady decline.
The last recorded date on a monument at Caracol is 859, and the city seemed to be totally abandoned by 1050. From the ruins, archeologists said, it appears that Caracol met a violent end.
But if the Chases are right, Caracol and other Mayan cities were not doomed by a peasant revolt against the elite. Both the peasants and the nobles -- as well as a middle class that had known periods of prosperity -- were probably victims of the increasingly frequent and widespread warfare that, according to the new thinking, contributed to the collapse of one of the great pre-Columbian civilizations.

HEADLINE: Mr. Dinkins's Hopeful Vision

 BODY:
Mayor David Dinkins of New York laid out some reasonable plans and priorities in his State of the City address yesterday. Relief from taxes and regulations for small businesses. Longer library hours. More after-school community centers. More community-based health clinics. More day care, more programs for infants and children, more help for battered women.
The speech was the Mayor's opening re-election shot, and he used it to underscore his long-held priorities -- fiscal stability, public safety, health care and the welfare of children -- and explain how he wanted to build on them. 
 Seen purely as goals -- what the Mayor would like to do -- his proposals are worthy. Exempting more small businesses from the commercial rent tax would help those businesses and New York's competitiveness. If the city can afford the $30 million in estimated lost tax revenues, that plan makes sense.
So do the Mayor's plans to bring additional health care into the public schools, create more Beacon community centers and expand Communicare, City Hall's new community health clinics.
But realizing his "vision for 1993 and the years ahead" will be more difficult than presenting it. Though the costs of the programs amount to a modest $60 million, the city faces a sizable budget gap that will demand difficult choices. What will the Mayor cut or shrink to pay for his new initiatives?
Politically, he may not have been wise to present a cheerful picture as the recession continues and labor leaders seek a bigger share of city revenues. Or to propose new and expanded social programs even as the city's social services agency suffers a management crisis. They are not likely to succeed unless Mr. Dinkins makes it his responsibility to work out the chronic problems in the troubled Human Resources Administration -- the agency that should be running many of those programs.
The Mayor took proud credit for past achievements, and, giving him license for election-year hyperbole, he deserves much of the credit he claims. Now he has to give the public a better insight into how he will turn his new vision into reality.
