HEADLINE: Bill Clinton, Environmentalist?

 BODY:
As Governor of Arkansas, his record on the environment was fair to poor. As a Presidential candidate he let Al Gore do most of the talking on environmental issues. Yet many hope that Bill Clinton will become the "environment President" George Bush promised to be but wasn't. It's more than a hope. It's a challenge -- maybe even bigger than Mr. Clinton imagines.
No issue inspires more heat and hyperbole. No country spends more money -- $130 billion -- and imposes more regulations to keep itself clean. But money and laws have not achieved consensus. America is swarming with green activists -- and with energetic critics who believe that the cleanliness crusade exacts too great a toll in jobs and economic growth. 
 Mr. Clinton's opportunity is to bridge the gap with sound policies, shrewd management and smart politics. That means ending bureaucratic turf wars, thereby enabling government to fulfill its historic role as custodian of the nation's natural resources. It means setting priorities that reflect real, not imagined, risks. It means sticking to well-articulated goals.
Mr. Bush did none of these things, staining what began as a noble effort to atone for the eight lost years of Ronald Reagan, whose environmental views oscillated in a narrow band between indifference and hostility. Mr. Reagan hired Ann Burford not to run the Environmental Protection Agency but to gut it. He hired Donald Hodel as Energy Secretary. Mr. Hodel is chiefly remembered for suggesting that the way to deal with ozone depletion was to apply stronger suntan lotion.
Starting fresh, Mr. Bush named a respected environmentalist, William Reilly, to run the E.P.A. He strengthened the Clean Air Act and committed the U.S. to phasing out ozone-destroying chemicals. He banned oil drilling in several sensitive offshore areas for 10 years.
In time, however, the twin demons of recession and election-year politics turned him around. The trees and clean air he had once rhapsodized about became sinister obstacles to economic growth. With Dan Quayle as his point man, he invited business to undercut Congressional mandates.
Mr. Bush tried to open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge for oil drilling and permitted wasteful logging in the national forests. He was probably right not to be bulldozed into signing a costly global warming treaty based on incomplete science. But his cramped attitude toward the international Earth Summit in Rio de Janiero badly damaged his claim to global leadership on environmental issues.
Mr. Reilly disappointed some of his old friends by not quitting. He chose to suffer and negotiate. He defeated John Sununu's efforts to weaken the Clean Air Act, saved Mr. Bush from reversing his pledge to protect the nation's wetlands from developers, dragged the President to Rio. On balance, the country is probably lucky he stayed.
So now Bill Clinton finds himself in the same nasty political cauldron. So far he has done little to disappoint the environmentalists, who are delighted with his key appointments -- Carol Browner at E.P.A. and Bruce Babbitt at Interior. He also publicly differs with Mr. Bush on most issues. His energy strategy favors conservation and efficiency over production. He says he'll protect forests and wetlands and urge the reauthorization of the controversial Endangered Species Act.
He's also made it clear, however, that on one crucial issue -- the heavy Federal regulation favored by many environmentalists -- he's keeping his own counsel. He agrees that industry, unregulated, rarely performs acts of spontaneous virtue. He agrees with Mr. Gore that regulation, properly conceived and applied, can force cleaner technologies without threatening profits or jobs.
At the same time, he concedes that businessmen are easily disheartened by complex regulations. He also seems receptive to the notion that market forces -- tax incentives to encourage energy efficiency, for example, or taxes that reflect hidden environmental costs -- might produce the same environmental bang for fewer bucks.
All this suggests an open mind. It also suggests that Mr. Clinton has determined that he will never achieve his objectives unless he persuades people that environmental progress can yield social and technological benefits at least equal to the costs.
But first, of course, Bill Clinton must persuade Bill Clinton that the environment really does matter. This, after all, is a man who courted the Arkansas poultry industry, a world-class polluter of that state's rivers and streams; a man who, by his own admission, winked at pollution to attract industry and jobs to a poor state.
He now claims to have seen the light. Inspired by Mr. Gore, he asserted bravely during the campaign that trading off the environment for jobs was a "false choice" -- that a cleaner America need not be a poorer America. That's hard to sell to Detroit and the oil companies, harder still to sell to the loggers in Oregon.
Politically, George Bush's way was the easier path. Mr. Clinton's way is harder but there's brighter promise at the end. If only he can see it.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CLINTON AIDES URGE FREER HAITI POLICY

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton's top aides presented him today with a proposal for a new policy on Haiti that would make it easier for Haitians to apply for political asylum in the United States while at the same time discouraging a mass exodus from the impoverished Caribbean nation, staff members said.
The proposed policy, which is to be announced before his inauguration and would later be made formal in an executive order, would set up an enlarged system to process asylum cases at a number of points inside Haiti, on the American military base at Guantanamo Bay and in third countries in the region. 
 Over the long term, the Clinton Administration would support and bolster efforts by the United Nations and the Organization of American States to resolve Haiti's political crisis, which resulted from the ouster of Haiti's first freely elected President, the Rev. Jean Bertrand Aristide, in a military coup in 1991.
 
Current Policy on Immigration
 But Mr. Clinton, who met with his aides today to discuss the proposed policy, would also emphasize that he will enforce current immigration policy, which prevents Haitians escaping poverty from seeking asylum in the United States and offers protection only to those fleeing political persecution, the aides said.
Mr. Clinton does not seem prepared to ease the standards currently applied by the Bush Administration to decide whether an applicant has genuine fear of persecution.
"The main goal," one transition official said, "is to keep Haitians in Haiti."
 
Meeting in Little Rock
 The plan was discussed today in a meeting in Little Rock that included Mr. Clinton; his Secretary of State-designate, Warren M. Christopher, the Defense Secretary-designate, Les Aspin; the national security adviser-designate, Anthony Lake; his deputy, Samuel Berger, and Brian Attwood, who handles liaison between the Clinton team and the State Department.
Mr. Clinton plans to announce the new policy before he takes office -- perhaps later this week -- in the hope of heading off a flood of Haitians seeking to enter the United States.
Asked at a news briefing in Little Rock today whether Mr. Clinton was poised to announce a plan on Haiti, George Stephanopoulos, his spokesman, said, "Obviously, it's something we have to do relatively soon."
He declined to say whether the Clinton team was drawing up a plan. "The Governor's been looking at the issue throughout the transition, as has the entire foreign policy team, and he'll have some announcement to make soon," he said.
 
Criticism of Bush
 During the campaign, Mr. Clinton criticized the Bush Administration's policy of turning back boat people without determining whether they are eligible for entry into the United States as political refugees. Since Mr. Bush issued his executive order last May, more than 5,000 Haitians have been returned home.
In Haiti, his words were widely interpreted as a signal that he would welcome them to the United States and stirred many to begin preparations to leave as soon as he takes office. The Immigration and Naturalization Service has received reports that Haitians have already built 600 boats -- each capable of carrying 100 people -- and are building 100 more for use by would-be immigrants.
The prospect that more than 100,000 Haitians could set sail on the 600-mile trip to southern Florida soon after Mr. Clinton takes office has prompted the President-elect's foreign policy team to draft a policy aimed at persuading them to stay where they are.
 
An Urgent Matter
 The issue is of such concern that Mr. Clinton has decided to break his pledge not to interfere in American foreign policy before he takes office.
As part of the new asylum process, the executive order will substantially increase the number of consular and immigration officers to expedite processing of the applications, Mr. Clinton's aides said. The order would encourage private refugee organizations, as well as the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, to actively participate.
In a confidential memorandum presented to the Clinton transition team and the State Department, the High Commissioner, Sadako Ogata, and her staff announced their intention to increase the commission's presence in Haiti, to monitor human rights and to help find a political solution. But the memo asked that all governments in the region, including the United States, be ready to admit asylum seekers and establish procedures to evaluate their assertions of persecution.
Mr. Clinton's aides and representatives of private refugee organizations acknowledge that there is no guarantee that the Clinton plan will work.
It will not relieve the country's economic desperation, a major reason for the fears of a huge exodus, largely because it will not lift a 15-month trade embargo that was imposed by the Organization of American States to force out Haiti's military junta.
 
Lifting of Sanctions Opposed
 Mr. Clinton's aides argue that lifting the sanctions would be seen as rewarding the military-backed regime, and say they would consider moving to lift the embargo after a process to restore the legitimate Government is under way. The embargo has worsened the plight of Haiti's poor and in doing so, ultimately encouraged more of the country's citizens to seek refuge in the United States.
As part of the policy, Mr. Clinton would try to boost a fledgling effort by the United Nations to seek ways of restoring a legitimate government to Haiti. Last month, the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali appointed Dante Caputo, a former foreign minister of Argentina, as his personal representative in Haiti.
Mr. Caputo met in Haiti two weeks ago with top officials in the military-backed government, including Prime Minister Marc Bazin and the army chief, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, and with supporters of Father Aristide, the ousted President.
The Haitian military opposes the restoration of Father Aristide's Government, and Mr. Caputo has no authority to negotiate a political settlement. Rather, his mandate is simply to report back to the United Nations General Assembly. The Assembly's recommendations, unlike those of the Security Council, are nonbinding.
Mr. Clinton will also have to deal with the perception that the United States has a double standard in granting political asylum and that many more Cubans who apply as refugees are warmly welcomed, while fewer Haitians seem to qualify.
Mr. Clinton is also expected to endorse an increase in the number of human rights monitors, particularly in the countryside, and to publicly detail and denounce widespread human rights abuses.
These measures, and the notion of having consular officials spread through the countryside to process asylum requests, are intended to reduce the need for Haitians to go to a central area to seek asylum. Many Haitians fear that by reporting to such an area, they will be identified by government officials and punished afterward if their asylum request is rejected.
The Clinton plan was drafted by Mr. Attwood, the chief liaison between the Clinton team and the State Department. Many of the ideas contained in today's proposal were first presented in an options paper prepared last month by Representative Stephen R. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn.

HEADLINE: Bonds of Tyranny Prove Slippery For Dissident Fleeing From China

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Jan. 5

 BODY:
The surprising thing about Zheng Yi is that he turned out to be as successful as a fugitive as he was as a writer.
When Mr. Zheng, a well-known author, was made the target of a nationwide search three and a half years ago, almost no one would have bet on his escape. Mr. Zheng had been a leader of the 1989 Tiananmen Square democracy movement, and the Government had branded him a "most wanted" outlaw and distributed posters with his picture and description. 
 But in an odyssey that speaks volumes about the loosening of controls in China in the 1990's, Mr. Zheng, who is 45, ran circles around the police and finally escaped the country. He is to arrive in New York on Wednesday, on a plane from a secret location outside China where he has been hiding.
Mr. Zheng's feat would probably have been impossible in the Maoist era, and it reflects the emergence of a more mobile and pluralistic society in which Chinese repression is often impotent. Try as it might, China is no longer very successful at being a police state.
Under Mao, Chinese sometimes turned their family members over to the police, but not a single person betrayed Mr. Zheng in his three and a half years on the run.
Just the opposite: in the same way that sympathetic Chinese hid Communist Party members before the 1949 revolution, fed them and moved them along their way, so ordinary citizens in the 1990's were willing to risk imprisonment to shelter Mr. Zheng and other Tiananmen fugitives.
 
An Interview in Hiding
 "It's a fundamental difference from earlier times," said Mr. Zheng (whose full name is pronounced juhng ee). "There were about 100 people who knew my identity -- knew my name and knew about the arrest warrant -- and yet they helped us."
Relaxed and bubbling with energy as he sat on a couch beside his wife, Bei Ming, Mr. Zheng spoke in a five-hour interview in his hiding place outside China while awaiting a United States visa. A condition of the interview was that the location not be disclosed for fear of damaging relations between China and the place that gave him refuge.
Several hundred other dissidents who were active in the Tiananmen movement also managed to escape from China, some on their own and others on a modern Underground Railroad. Most of their escapes were kept quiet, in part because the host countries feared that publicity would antagonize Beijing.
Mr. Zheng may be the last of the fugitives to escape; no more are known to be still on the run in China. But just last fall, about a dozen members of an underground rights organization successfully fled the country after the secret police discovered their identities and moved to arrest them.
 
A Little Help From His Friends
 Fugitives like Mr. Zheng were successful because in today's China they were able to obtain forged identity cards and blend in with the tens of millions of other Chinese who now travel from place to place. They were also able to make deals with fishermen who smuggle people and goods.
But the element that everyone who escapes emphasizes is the overwhelming support they receive.
"I couldn't have done it by myself," said Mr. Zheng, a stocky man with unruly hair and a vigorous laugh. "Lots of people helped, and I didn't even know many of them beforehand. In three years on the run, only one person refused to help."
Ms. Bei, Mr. Zheng's wife, a 36-year-old writer and scholar who was with her husband for the last two and a half years, interjected: "People from all walks of life helped us. There were intellectuals, workers, peasants, private businessmen, soldiers, police, journalists, officials, even prostitutes."
 
Her Successful Search
 Ms. Bei (whose name is pronounced bay ming) was arrested after the Tiananmen crackdown and imprisoned for eight months. After her release, she accomplished what the police could not: she found her husband.
It took her four months of traveling around the country, constantly followed by secret-police officers, before she made the right contacts and was given a passage on the underground railroad. Finally, in the summer of 1990, Ms. Bei was smuggled into the town where her husband was hiding.
After three days in isolation to make sure she had not been followed, her guardians led her to the safe house where Mr. Zheng was staying. In a room full of friends, new and old, they were reunited.
"The only problem was that he was disguised really well," she said. "I didn't recognize him."
 
Disillusioned With Communism
 Mr. Zheng was once an enthusiastic Communist. During the Cultural Revolution, from 1966 to 1976, he was one of the millions of Red Guards wreaking havoc in the country. Then he became disillusioned with Communism, particularly when he was sent to live in a village, and he later attended university and became a writer in the central city of Taiyuan.
His works, often sympathetic portrayals of the countryside, became famous. One of them, "Old Well," was made into a prize-winning film.
Mr. Zheng and Ms. Bei were visiting Beijing when the Tiananmen democracy movement began in April 1989. Mr. Zheng immediately rose to the forefront, and he was among the first to propose a student hunger strike.
After army troops crushed the protests on June 4, 1989, killing hundreds of workers and students, Mr. Zheng promptly went into hiding. Ms. Bei, who was a Communist Party member but who had edited the Tiananmen movement's unofficial newspaper, lived quietly at home in Taiyuan in the belief that she would not be arrested.
The police did detain her, however, and released her only in the spring of 1990. She set out to find her husband.
 
It Was Once Hard to Get Lost
 "I traveled by train, bus, taxi, tractor, rickshaw and rail cars, but even when I lost my followers and disguised myself, they would find me again," she recalled.
It has always been far more difficult to disappear in a Communist country than in a Western one. All Chinese must show identification cards when renting hotel rooms or buying train tickets, and normally it is impossible to work or rent an apartment without a local residence permit. Two confidential personnel files are kept on every urban resident, and these are supposed to be examined by officials before providing anyone with a job.
This system of controls is breaking down, however.
China is an increasingly mobile and economically sophisticated society, with more hotels, trains and long-distance buses. Out-of-towners no longer attract suspicion, and privately employed Chinese with no regular job are ubiquitous. It is no longer true, as it used to be, that there is no place to hide.
 
True Photos, False Names
 The boom in free enterprise means that there are now private businesses that do not always bother to examine personnel files or ID cards; money is enough. Moreover, a booming market has emerged in recent years for false documents and residence permits.
False ID cards are normally expensive, for police officials must be bribed to issue them, but sympathizers gave Mr. Zheng and Ms. Bei forged papers free. The new cards used their real photos -- as they had disguised themselves -- but used different names.
While on the run, Mr. Zheng and Ms. Bei traveled widely, living in villages and cities in many provinces. They declined to provide any details for fear of getting friends in trouble.
For the same reason, they say little about how they disguised themselves. But Mr. Zheng said that for a time he worked as a carpenter, pretending to be a half-witted peasant who spoke only a country dialect.
"That was the hardest thing -- not speaking standard Mandarin when I opened my mouth," he said. "So at first, whenever anybody asked me a question, I would have to pause and think about how to answer it in dialect."
He said, however, that the pauses proved useful, for they contributed to the image of an idiot.
 
A Dream of Being Published
 Mr. Zheng used his time to write two books: one about cannibalism during the Cultural Revolution, the other an indictment of the Communist Party since its founding in China more than 70 years ago. Acquaintances smuggled out copies of the manuscripts to friends in the United States, with instructions to arrange for them to be published.
"I figured that I'd stay in China, living underground for years while publishing abroad," Mr. Zheng said. "That would infuriate the party."
The problem was that his friends abroad worried that publication would lead the security forces to step up their hunt. So they held off publication, and Mr. Zheng finally decided that if he wanted his books published, he would have to leave China.
Mr. Zheng and Ms. Bei plan to return to China as soon as they are confident that they will not be arrested.
"I'm optimistic," he said. "Within three or five years, China will change and we'll be able to go back."

HEADLINE: New York Fed's President Resigning

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
E. Gerald Corrigan, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, announced yesterday that he would resign in August after more than eight years in that post and 25 years with the Federal Reserve.
Mr. Corrigan, 51, said at a news conference that he planned to seek a job in private industry where "I'll try to limit myself to working six days a week, instead of seven." But he did not elaborate on his career plans. 
 As president of the New York Fed, Mr. Corrigan is the second-most-prominent person in the Federal Reserve after its chairman, and he has been in the middle of financial turmoil ranging from the third-world debt crisis to the stock market crash in 1987.
 
'Crucial Role' After Crash
 "He played a crucial role providing the psychological reassurance for a few critical days after the stock market crash," said Paul A. Volcker, the former Federal Reserve Board chairman.
At the news conference, Mr. Corrigan said the period right after the crash was his most memorable on the job. "In terms of my pulse rate, that one takes the prize," he said.
Mr. Corrigan's successor will be chosen by the board of the New York Fed, which is made up of bankers and other executives from the region, and must be approved by the Fed's board of governors. The position has an annual salary of about $250,000. Mr. Corrigan said he expected a new president to be named before he left.
The New York Fed is one of 12 banks that make up the Federal Reserve System, but it has a special role because its region includes many of the nation's largest banks and securities markets. In addition, it conducts the Treasury's debt auctions.
Mr. Corrigan has long ties to Mr. Volcker, who brought him to Washington as an aide in 1979 and acted as his mentor.
"Gerry has a good conceptual understanding of the financial world, but most importantly he knows how to get things done," Mr. Volcker said. "That's a rare quality in the bureaucratic world in which he has grown up."
Alan Greenspan, the current chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, also praised Mr. Corrigan. "His contributions to monetary and financial policy, to banking supervision and regulation and to international cooperation and coordination in these areas are legion," Mr. Greenspan said in a statement.
Mr. Corrigan, discussing his tenure, said he was particularly proud that he called attention to the risks in the payment system that transfers money between banks. As the volume of transactions has increased, especially across borders, Mr. Corrigan and others have worried that the failure of one bank could cause problems for other banks that did business with it and trigger a financial crisis.
Financial regulators, prompted by the Group of 30, a financial study group to which Mr. Corrigan belongs, have produced several ways to reduce this risk. Among the proposals accepted in a number of countries is one to eliminate paper stock certificates, thereby shortening the time to settle securities transactions.
"We have succeeded in getting financial institutions here and abroad to focus on the plumbing of the banking system," he said.
Mr. Corrigan has become prominent among international central bankers and is chairman of the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision, a group of central bankers that has worked to create uniform worldwide standards for bank capital. He also made a widely noted speech last year warning of the risk to the banking system of complex new transactions, like interest rate swaps, that do not appear on a bank's balance sheet.
Still, under his tenure as head of the New York Fed, the Federal Reserve has been criticized for Treasury auctions in which Salomon Brothers submitted some false bids to buy more bonds than it was allowed, and for not clamping down sooner on the scandal-ridden Bank of Credit and Commerce International. At the news conference, however, Mr. Corrigan insisted that "If it wasn't for the Fed, there is a pretty good chance that B.C.C.I. would still be in business."
Mr. Corrigan joined the New York Fed in 1968 as an economist. After working with Mr. Volcker in Washington, he was president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis from 1980 to 1985.
Mr. Corrigan said he wanted to remain active in policy debates and that he eventually intended to write a book on the issues raised by his experiences at the Fed.
Mr. Volcker suggested that Mr. Corrigan might have a future running one of the banks that he regulated.
"He is very well suited to running a big institution that had problems," Mr. Volcker said. "All his life he has being dealing with problems in a very methodical way."
While members of the Federal Reserve board of governors are prohibited from later working in commercial banks, there is no such restriction on the presidents of the Federal Reserve banks.
The New York Fed board is expected to look widely for candidates to succeed Mr. Corrigan among officials of the Federal Reserve, other Government agencies and possibly in the private sector.

HEADLINE: Bush, in West Point Valedictory, Offers Principles on Use of Force

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 5

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Bush's address to West Point cadets:
Let me begin with the hard part. It is difficult for a Navy person to come up to West Point after that game a month ago. 
 But I watched it. Amazing things can happen in sports. Look at the Oilers, my other team, that took it on the chin the other day.
But I guess the morale of -- moral of all this is that losing is never easy -- trust me -- I know something about that. But if you -- if you have to lose, that's the way to do it. Fight with all you have, give it your best shot, and win or lose, learn from it and get on with life. And I'm about to get on with the rest of my life.
But before I do, I want to share with you at this institution of leadership some of my thinking, both about the world you will soon be called upon to enter, and the life that you've chosen.
Any President has several functions. He speaks for and to the nation. He must faithfully execute the law, and he must lead. But no function, none of the President's hats, in my view, is more important than his role as Commander in Chief. For it is as Commander in Chief that the President confronts and makes decisions that, one way or another, affects the lives of everyone in this country as well as many others around the world.
And I've had many occasions to don this most important of hats, and over the past four years, the men and women who proudly and bravely wear the uniforms of the U.S. armed services, have been called upon to go in harm's way, and have discharged their duty with honor and professionalism.
 
Time of Great Promise
 I wish I could say that such demands were a thing of the past, that with the end of the cold war, the calls upon the United States would diminish. I cannot. Yes, the end of the cold war, we would all concede, is a blessing. It is a time of great promise. Democratic governments have never been so numerous. What happened two or three days ago in Moscow would not have been possible in the cold-war days.
Thanks to historic treaties such as that Start II pact just reached with Russia, the likelihood of nuclear holocaust is vastly diminished. But this does not mean that there is no specter of war, no threats to be reckoned with, and already we see disturbing signs of what this new world could become if we are passive and aloof.
We would risk the emergence of a world characterized by violence, characterized by chaos, one in which dictators and tyrants threaten their neighbors, build arsenals brimming with weapons of mass destruction, and ignore the welfare of their own men, women and children. And we could see a horrible increase in international terrorism, with American citizens more at risk than ever before.
 
 
. . .
 Two hundred years ago, another departing President warned of the dangers of what he described as "entangling alliances." His was the right course for a new nation at that point in history. But what was entangling in Washington's day is now essential.
And this is why at Texas A&M a few weeks ago, I spoke of the folly of isolationism and of the importance, morally, economically and strategically of the United States remaining involved in world affairs. We must engage ourselves if a new world order, one more compatible with our values and congenial to our interests, is to emerge. But even more, we must lead.
 
When U.S. Should Act
 Leadership: well, it takes many forms. It can be political or diplomatic, it can be economic or military, it can be moral or spiritual leadership. Leadership can take any one of these forms or it can be a combination of them. Leadership should not be confused with either unilateralism or universalism. We need not respond by ourselves to each and every outrage of violence. The fact that America can act does not mean that it must.
 
. . .
 Sometimes, sometimes the decision not to use force, to stay our hand, I can tell you it's just as difficult as a decision to send our soldiers into battle. The former Yugoslavia, well, it's been such a situation.
There are, we all know, important humanitarian and strategic interests at stake there, but up to now it's not been clear that the application of limited amounts of force by the United States and its traditional friends and allies would have had the desired effect, given the nature and the complexity of that situation.
Our assessment of the situation in the former Yugoslavia could well change if and as the situation changes. The stakes could grow. The conflict could threaten to spread. Indeed, we are constantly reassessing our options and are actively consulting with others about steps that might be taken to contain the fighting, protect the humanitarian effort and deny Serbia the fruits of aggression.
Military force is never a tool to be used lightly, or universally. In some circumstances it may be essential. In others, counterproductive. I know that many people would like to find some formula, some easy formula to apply, to tell us with precision when and where to intervene with force.
 
 
. . .
Criteria for Force
 But to warn against a futile quest for a set of hard and fast rules to govern the use of military force is not to say there cannot be some principles to inform our decisions. Such guidelines can prove useful in sizing and indeed shaping our forces, and in helping us to think our way through this key question.
Using military force makes sense as a policy where the stakes warrant, where and when force can be effective, where no other policies are likely to prove effective, where its application can be limited in scope and time, and where the potential benefits justify the potential costs and sacrifice.
Once we are satisfied that force makes sense, we must act with the maximum possible support. The United States can and should lead, but we will want to act in concert, where possible, involving the United Nations or other multinational grouping.
 
 
. . .
 But in every case involving the use of force, it will be essential to have a clear and achievable mission, a realistic plan for accomplishing the mission, and criteria no less realistic for withdrawing U.S. forces once the mission is complete.
Only if we keep these principles in mind will the potential sacrifice be one that can be explained and justified.

HEADLINE: Citibank Rethinks Its Lending

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Citibank, which made more than its share of lending mistakes in the 1980's and paid a severe price for its laxness, is altering its lending rules and procedures in hopes of cutting loan losses.
Executives at the bank, the nation's largest, are not saying exactly how lending standards are changing or whether Citibank will continue making giant loans, like those exceeding $200 million that it made in the 1980's, without selling a large part of them to other lenders, as most banks do. 
 Still, the new procedures do promise uniform lending standards across the bank and a new commitment by top management, including the chairman, John S. Reed, to spend more time discussing large loans and to keep closer track of how much risk the bank is taking in particular industries or regions.
 
Guidelines Not Always Followed
 "I think we have always had a lot of first-rate lenders," said William R. Rhodes, the vice chairman. But he said the loan officials were too often undermined by the willingness of top management -- many of them no longer with the bank -- to exceed the bank's guidelines on concentrations of loans for commercial real estate and highly indebted companies.
Losses in both areas have been heavy, particularly in commercial real estate, which has accounted for write-offs of $2.8 billion since the end of 1990. Citicorp's total loan write-offs soared to $4.9 billion in 1991, from $1.5 billion in 1987.
The write-offs were humbling, disclosing that Citicorp's management, despite high praise in the 1980's from Wall Street analysts, failed to manage adequately its lending to businesses. Even after losses were evident in 1990, Citicorp was slower than some other banks with large loan losses, like First Fidelity in Newark, to adopt a uniform loan rating system and begin studying more carefully the riskiest borrowers.
Although Citibank's losses from loans declined during the first three quarters of 1992, analysts say it will be a few years before they can tell whether the new system is effective.
The changes at Citibank began to take shape a year ago when Mr. Rhodes was named head of a special task force, which spent three months interviewing retired Citibank executives and talking with other banks like Deutsche Bank and Chase Manhattan to learn their procedures for controlling lending risks. According to Mr. Rhodes, the task force was appointed without any prompting by regulators or Citicorp's board.
Under the new system, the five-member management committee meets twice a month with Robert Martinsen, head of the credit policy committee, to determine how much risk the bank should take in particular industries and regions of the world, and how those risks might change as economic conditions change.
Besides Mr. Reed and Mr. Rhodes, the committee members are H. Onno Rudding, the vice chairman in charge of corporate lending; Paul J. Collins, vice chairman, and Pei Yuan Chia, head of consumer banking.
The committee is also charged with monitoring loans to very large customers or other special situations. Mr. Reed, for example, is directly involved in handling some of the largest commercial real estate loans, while Mr. Rhodes deals with loans to less developed countries.
With the changes comes a new role for the credit policy committee, a group of about 10 senior lenders headed by Mr. Martinsen, 58. Instead of approving or denying every loan above $25 million as in the past, the committee will concentrate on assessing the overall risk of Citicorp's loan portfolio, the largest of any bank in the country.
Other large banks also have credit committees that consider loans above a certain size or a certain level of risk. As at Citibank, those committees develop and refine systems to rate loans according to risk. Besides helping a bank avoid loans that will turn bad, these ratings allow banks to spot problems sooner, usually before default occurs, and change prices so that higher-risk borrowers pay higher interest rates and fees.
Mr. Martinsen embarked on a program of training and writing loan policy manuals so that standards would be uniform in all parts of the bank. Using the standards that are in place or will be soon, all existing and potential business loans in the 90 countries where Citibank operates will be rated on a 10-point scale. A 1 rating will correspond to an extremely low-risk loan to a triple-A-rated borrower and a 10 will correspond to a loan that would have to be written off as a loss in whole or in part.
Most of Citibank's loans are rated 3 or 4, the bank says, but officials declined to discuss trends in ratings or loss experiences in different categories. They also declined to describe the risks of lower rated loans, particularly the 6 rating, which at other banks with a 10-point scale corresponds to loans that require special attention, or the 7 rating, which would be deemed "substandard" by Federal bank examiners and would require that a sum be subtracted from the bank's profits and set aside as a reserve against possible losses.
 
'Talking in the Same Language'
 "Our history as a very decentralized company was a problem that had to be changed so that everyone could be talking in the same language," Mr. Martinsen said. He noted that Citibank's corporate lenders in North America already had a similar 10-grade rating system, but that it was not always properly used and was not extended to operations worldwide.
Under the new system, the credit policy committee will be involved only with the unusual loans that might breach standards regarding loan quality or concentration on a particular borrower or industry. Lending officers have been warned that they should no longer try to "beat the system" by submitting questionable loans that they know may be favored by some members of the committee.
While the credit policy committee will no longer have as tight a grip on every sizable loan as it had in the past, Citibank is compensating by making the heads of its 15 business groups more involved in lending. Each of these executives is responsible for adhering to loan standards and avoiding risky concentrations of loans in their business group. Responsibility for individual loans falls to lower ranking executives, but the head of each business group must answer for the group's performance at the monthly meetings with Mr. Reed and the others on the management committee.
 
Deciding the Limits
 By more clearly identifying who is responsible for lending mistakes, Citibank has become comfortable with a general increase in the lending limits assigned to each of the 500 "initials," or officers empowered to make loans. Under the new system, lending limits vary by the riskiness of the loan, with a 1-rated borrower allowed the highest dollar amount. As in the past, every loan will require three sets of initials.
Beyond mere reorganization, Mr. Martinsen said the revival of what bankers call "credit culture" was intended to refocus on the judgments of lenders trying constantly to balance the desire to earn profits by making loans and the desire to avoid loss by not making loans that are too risky.
"We have to instill the idea that credit quality is more important than profit opportunities that come with big risks," Mr. Martinsen said. In the past, he acknowledged, "we were profit driven to the point of not being as prudent as we should have been."

HEADLINE: Bush Vetoes Not Forgotten As 103d Congress Convenes

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5

 BODY:
The 103d Congress convened today and Democratic leaders promptly set about establishing legislative priorities to demonstrate that they can work with a Democratic President by re-passing bills President Bush vetoed.
A bill requiring employers to grant workers unpaid leaves for family and medical emergencies emerged at the top of the list. Both Houses scheduled early action on it, and President-elect Bill Clinton's choice as chief of staff, Thomas F. McLarty 3d, called for action "as early in the session as possible." 
 The House did not escape its traditional opening-day wrangling over rules, with Republicans accusing Democrats of bullying them. But the Democrats maintained enough unity to gain passage of a measure giving five delegates from American Samoa, the District of Columbia, Guam, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands votes on amendments on the floor.
 
Compromise Over Bill
 But to hold their own majority, the Democrats watered down the measure. The proposed rule, which finally passed on a 221-to-199 vote, provided that any time the delegates votes decided an issue, there would immediately be a second ballot in which the delegates would be prohibited from voting.
Other than the rules fight, it was a day of traditional formalities -- swearing in new members, notifying President Bush that Congress was in session and reviewing procedures for Wednesday's counting of the electoral votes that will show Mr. Clinton defeated Mr. Bush.
Discipline was generally relaxed. The Senate tolerated applause from the galleries when new members were sworn in. In the House, children of lawmakers sat on their parents' laps.
In the House, Republicans talked of the need for "reform and renewal," as Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the minority leader, put it. He said the House had to adhere to the basic principle that the rights of the minority were "equal in dignity and importance and in no way subservient to the principle of majority rule."
The House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley, replied that the public was indeed impatient "with the pace of reform and change." But the Washington Democrat said the public's impatience was not over House procedures but over substance and the failure of Congress to legislate solutions to national problems.
The Senate's brief session ended without a word on legislation or national problems. Newly elected and re-elected senators were sworn in and went off to each other's celebrations, while some Republicans went back to their offices to prepare for the confirmation hearings of Mr. Clinton's Cabinet choices, which begin Wednesday.
Senator Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, told a news conference that the efforts he was coordinating to research the nominees were intended to be constructive.
"We're certainly not out with a hatchet to get anybody," he said, although he expressed concern that the Federal Bureau of Investigation was not being given enough time to investigate Cabinet nominees thoroughly.
Mr. Foley's speech, after his election to a second full term as Speaker, offered the fullest description of Democratic legislative hopes available.
Speaking of the national frustration with Congress, he said, "There is an impatience that we have not moved fast enough or effectively enough to deal with the national deficit, to deal with our economic system and its advancement and growth, to deal with the problems of our health system that deny still to millions of Americans adequate and affordable health care, to provide educational opportunity for all of our citizens, to reduce crime and to attack the problems of drugs and other social ills."
But no legislation that profound is on the early short list. For the most part, the list includes measures that have been thoroughly debated and on which Democrats are in basic agreement.
Beyond the family leave bill, other measures given priority designations included a bill to expand voter registration by requiring states to allow voters to register when they obtain drivers' licenses or social services and one to broaden the research agenda of the National Institutes of Health, especially in matters of women's health and prostate cancer.
Mr. Bush had vetoed the registration bill last year, saying it could increase voter fraud and he vetoed the measure on the institutes because he said it allowed the use of aborted fetus tissue in research on Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's disease and diabetes.
The family leave bill was designated H.R.1, as the first bill introduced in the House in the new Congress. Representative William D. Ford, the Michigan Democrat who heads the Education and Labor Committee, said he hoped it could be signed in Mr. Clinton's first month in office.
The bill would require businesses with at least 50 workers to give their employees up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave when there is a birth or adoption in the family; seriously ill children, parents, husbands or wives need care, or the workers themselves have serious illnesses.
 
Importance of Legislation
 Mr. McLarty wrote to Congressional committee chairmen that Mr. Clinton considered the bill "a critical recognition of the importance of families and of the need to enable family members to support and care for one another."
The bill is expected to come before a House subcommittee next week, and then the full committee before the end of this month. In the Senate, it will be introduced Jan. 21, have a hearing on Jan. 22 and be voted out of the Labor and Human Resources Committee on Jan. 26.
The labor committee plans the identical timetable for the institutes of health legislation, which Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, said would be designated S.1 once it was introduced.

HEADLINE: NEC, in Strategy Shift, Is Entering PC Price War

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Japan's personal computer market, which has remained remarkably insulated from the fierce price-cutting elsewhere, finally seems to be facing a price war of its own.
The NEC Corporation, which controls more than half the personal computer market here, said today that it would soon introduce a new line of personal computers with prices about half those for its current models. 
 The action comes after NEC has insisted for months that it would not engage in any price wars. Analysts interpret the move as a recognition by the company that it will lose its hold on the market unless it responds to lower-priced competitors, including American companies like Compaq Computer, that have entered the Japanese market with products honed in the savage price battles in the United States.
"It's an interim recognition of the pricing trends," said Michael Jeremy, analyst with Baring Securities in Tokyo. "It seems that within the company, the lobby for maintaining market share has won out over the lobby for maintaining profits or revenues."
In October, Compaq introduced machines in Japan that sell for about half the prices of those from NEC and other Japanese companies. The International Business Machines Corporation introduced inexpensive models shortly thereafter and Apple Computer and Digital Equipment cut prices. The Dell Computer Corporation is planning to announce its entry into the Japanese market later this month.
Until now, NEC has pooh-poohed the challenge from Compaq, noting that the Houston-based company has little distribution in Japan and that there is far more Japanese software available for the NEC computers. "Unless you have comparable functions, we don't see any need to lower our prices," Tadahiro Sekimoto, the president of NEC, said last month.
Still, a spokesman for NEC acknowledged today that growing price competition caused the company to accelerate its plans to introduce newer low-priced models. But, he said, the main reason for the lower prices was greater manufacturing efficiency and more advanced technology.
 
Prices: $2,000 to $2,400
 NEC said its new machines, which it expects to introduce around the end of this month, will be based on the Intel Corporation's 486 series of microprocessors and have entry level prices of 250,000 to 300,000 yen, or about $2,000 to $2,400.
That is still higher than the price of roughly $1,600 for Compaq's least expensive 486-SX machine here, but far cheaper than what NEC has offered until now. NEC's least expensive desktop computer with a 486-SX microprocessor now has a list price of 548,000 yen, or about $4,400, while its least expensive 486 notebook machine costs 348,000 yen, or $2,800.
NEC is being threatened by more than just low prices, however. Its machine is not compatible with the standard originally set by I.B.M., which is now used by most of the world's personal computers. "I still think they haven't addressed the major problem," Mr. Jeremy said, referring to NEC's proprietary system.
Compaq, I.B.M. and the other American companies are offering I.B.M.-compatible machines using DOS/V software, a Japanese adaptation of Microsoft's operating system.
Several Japanese companies are also now offering DOS/V machines, making the software a contender to become the standard that may unseat NEC's approach. As an acknowledgment of that trend, Fujitsu Ltd., which also sells a proprietary system here, recently said that it might also introduce I.B.M.-compatible machines in the Japanese market.
NEC, which has sold more than 5.7 million of its 9800-series personal computers, says it has no intention now of selling I.B.M.-compatible machines in Japan. As a practical matter, the company cannot afford to abandon the customers who bought its machines.
But analysts say NEC could face an increasing risk because competitors that adhere to the I.B.M. standard can potentially undercut NEC's prices by buying disk drives, video displays and other components that are made in huge volumes, while NEC must make specialized components for its machines.
No other nonstandard personal computer has survived, with the exception of the Apple Macintosh. But the Macintosh has unique features in its software that the NEC machine does not have. And Apple sells the computer throughout the world to achieve its large volumes.
Still, NEC has considerable strength, and many Japanese customers will stick with it because of its base of software, wide distribution and service.
While a price war could hurt the profit margins of NEC and other manufacturers, it could give a boost to personal computer sales, which have been sagging because of Japan's economic slump. In the six months that ended in September, unit sales of personal computers in Japan fell 9 percent, compared with the corresponding period a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Effects of Segregation Told in a Trial

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 5

 BODY:
Lawyers seeking to integrate Hartford's schools with suburban ones offered evidence today from some of the best-known studies on the effects of segregation on black students: studies of a 25-year desegregation program in Hartford and its suburbs, Project Concern.
The studies' main author, Prof. Robert L. Crain, has testified about Project Concern in school-desegregation cases across the nation. Their findings, he said today, are the "central national evidence" that segregation perpetuates itself -- that children who attend segregated schools live segregated lives as adults. 
 "Segregation proved to have long-term harmful effects," testified Professor Crain, a sociologist from Teachers College at Columbia University. It discouraged black students from completing high school or college, led them into segregated, low-level occupations, and limited their contact with whites.
The focus on Project Concern brought into the open many of the uncomfortable ironies of the lawsuit being heard here, which in challenging the racial and economic segregation of Hartford's schools is seeking a desegregation plan covering the city and 21 surrounding towns.
 
State Defends Its Role
 While the plaintiffs say the studies of Project Concern prove the harm of segregation, the State of Connecticut, the defendant in the case, argues that the very existence of Project Concern shows that the state has been trying to promote integration.
The segregation that divides Hartford, where schools have a minority enrollment of 90 percent, from its suburbs, where schools are 90 percent white, is found across the North and West, where the migration of Southern blacks in the 1950's and 60's speeded the movement of whites to the suburbs.
Lawyers for the state say that the state did not cause the residential segregation, but that it has tried to combat the growing segregation of schools in Hartford.
Isn't Project Concern the oldest desegregation plan in the nation sending children across city lines, Alfred A. Lindseth, an Atlanta lawyer hired by the state, asked Professor Crain. "Can you think of any in the entire country that have been continuously in effect for over 25 years?"
 
Larger Program Backed
 "There may not be any others," Mr. Crain replied. "When this was done in 1966, it was a pretty important program."
For the civil-rights lawyers arguing the suit, however, the results of Project Concern are crucial evidence that a much larger integration effort between Hartford and its suburbs would benefit the city's children.
The children who stayed in Project Concern through graduation from suburban high schools, Mr. Crain testified, not only had more years of college education, but were more likely to live in mixed or white neighborhoods, have friends who were white, and work in an integrated environment, while being less likely to perceive discrimination around them.
And while Project Concern is a source of pride for many people in Hartford and its suburbs, its small scale is evidence of how limited the region's desegregation efforts have been. Only 680 children attend suburban schools through the program, down from a high of 1,175 in 1978. The city's schools have 25,700 children attending them.
 
State Agrees With Suers
 This suit is also unusual in that the state agrees with the goal of those who are suing it: improving the education of Hartford's children by integrating them with children from surrounding towns. The state wants to achieve that goal voluntary or legislatively, not by court order.
But as lawyers for the state question Project Concern, a desegregation plan that meets one of the state's own main requirements, that a plan be voluntary, they unavoidably raise doubts whether the common goal -- integration -- carries any benefits.
"Weren't these schools all white?" Mr. Lindseth asked of the suburban schools taking part in Project Concern. "So isn't this really a study of how blacks do in a white school, not a desegregated school?"
In Project Concern, children from schools in the predominantly black North End of Hartford are invited at random to attend schools in other towns. Parents and the children can reject the invitation, or choose to return to city schools at any time.
 
Efforts of the City
 In the program's first years, the city not only made a great effort to see that all those selected took part, but also, at the insistence of the research director of West Hartford's schools, Edward Riedy, set up an experiment. A comparable group of children who stayed in city schools was identified as a control group.
Professor Crain's studies located students from the program's first years, and those from control groups, and questioned them about their years of college, their jobs, and their attitudes. Most were in their early 20's, and so, little difference in income or job status was found.
But in many other measures, he said, the Project Concern graduates were much more positive about participating in an integrated world, and were much more optimistic about their prospects for promotion at work.
The students who attended Hartford's segregated schools, he said, lacked a network of friends in the larger, white work world to point them toward job openings, had a harder time, in their language and dress, presenting themselves to employers, weren't relaxed with white supervisors, and were angrier and less able to deal with the demands of integrated settings.
 
'A Tough Desegregations Plan'
 Asked by Marianne Engleman Lado, a lawyer with the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc., if students suffered any negative effects from Project Concern, Professor Crain said no.
Asked if desegregation was stressful for blacks, he replied emphatically, "Yes." Project Concern, he said, had few participants, so they were isolated, the suburban schools had few black teachers, and many children had long rides to school.
"This was a tough desegregation plan," he said.

HEADLINE: Olympus Headquarters Is Opposed

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MELVILLE, L.I., Jan. 5

 BODY:
Despite promises of tax relief, new jobs and modern office buildings in a campus-like setting, some residents of this Long Island community are fighting plans by the Olympus Corporation to build its North American headquarters here.
The dispute mirrors the rejection several months ago by residents of Brookville, L.I., of plans for a new headquarters for the Canon Corporation, another Japanese camera and optical equipment company. Homeowners here, like those in Brookville, say they fear that commercial encroachment will depress their property values and increase traffic. 
 Canon decided to remain at its headquarters in Lake Success and perhaps look elsewhere. Olympus has already abandoned two other proposed sites on the Island because of zoning regulations. It started to look elsewhere when the State Department of Economic Development came up with the Melville site on the 516-acre Long Island Developmental Center, a state campus for the mentally retarded, most of which will close in April.
 
'Can't Afford to Lose'
 "We can't afford to lose this one," said James L. Larocca, president of the Long Island Association, the region's largest business and civic group. "It would send out the wrong message to the international business community and be a severe blow to the Island's economic future."
Olympus, which has been an employer on Long Island for almost 25 years, would like to consolidate its consumer and scientific divisions in a new headquarters here in Melville. The move from its cramped quarters in Lake Success would support 1,122 permanent full-time jobs, providing salaries of $55 million a year, according state officials.
Construction of the new headquarters on 53.7 acres of the state-owned property would generate another 1,163 temporary construction jobs, adding $58.8 million in payroll and other expenditures to the economy, state officials said.
But at a public hearing this afternoon sponsored by the State Department of Economic Development, residents who live near the proposed site expressed doubts about promises of tax relief and said more tax revenue would be generated if homes were built on the land.
 
A 99-Year Lease
 The builder, the Parr Development Corporation of Ronkonkoma, L.I., would pay an estimated $9.3 million to the state for a 99-year lease on the property with an option to buy after the 10th year for a nominal sum. Financing for the $40 million construction project would be provided by the Suffolk County Industrial Development Authority. Olympus would be given a 10-year tax abatement that would decrease each year. Taxes paid to the county by Olympus would reach $650,000 by the 11th year.
The Olympus headquarters would be set low in the middle of the site, surrounded by trees that would hide it from view to passing motorists. "Why are they doing this to us," said Patricia Lerner, who has lived in a home in neighboring Dix Hills for 24 years. "I would rather they make homes here.
"They say that Olympus would bring jobs. But many of the people who work for Olympus already live in Nassau and Suffolk County and would drive here instead of Lake Success."
Mrs. Lerner said that most homeowners were willing to give up the tax benefits the Olympus headquarters would bring. She said that many of the homes surrounding the state center were built on one-acre lots. About 10 years ago, she said, they sold for between $500,000 and $600,000, but now, because of the recession, were selling for half that amount.
 
Support for Project
 Mrs. Lerner was among about three dozen residents who came to the hearing in the auditorium of Building 9 of the Long Island Development Center. She and her friends were outnumbered by a crowd of more than 300 people, many of them construction workers who came to support the project.
"We need jobs," said Mike Simca, an electrician and resident of Melville. "If I don't get work soon, I may have to sell my house and leave the Island."
Mr. Larocca said the recession had cost more than 100,000 Long Islanders their jobs. "These are extraordinary times and require extraordinary measures," he said, backing the state's move to override local zoning ordinances in supporting the project.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS -- ADVERTISING;
The N.H.L.'s Pitch to Go Prime Time

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
"HE shoots! He scores!" is a familiar refrain at National Hockey League games. Now the league, long considered woefully lagging in the competition for fan and sponsor dollars, is firing off a round of ambitious advertising and promotion efforts. Whether the league can score in a glutted sports market and a weak economy is as problematic as wondering when the New York Rangers will win another Stanley Cup.
"This is all part of a process, a marketing process, to accelerate the growth of the game," Steve Ryan, the president of N.H.L. Enterprises Inc. in New York, the league's marketing arm, said in an interview yesterday. 
 "The key will be to expand our base and reach what we're calling the action-sports fans."
A decade ago, the N.H.L. and the National Basketball Association shared a plight: how to sell sports that were perceived as having limited appeal. Through a series of shrewd marketing moves, the N.B.A. built a popularity rivaling that of football and baseball, while hockey remains mired in an arena of also-rans.
The N.H.L.'s difficulties were aggravated by one of the worst broadcast-rights agreements ever signed by a major-league sport. Though coverage has remained strong in Canada, where hockey is considered as integral an aspect of the national identity as Anne Murray, a deal with Sports Channel America, a secondary cable-TV network, kept N.H.L. games off the air for the last four years in many parts of the United States.
"You could have hidden Patty Hearst with that deal," said Brian T. Murphy, editor and publisher of the Sports Marketing Letter, a newsletter in Westport, Conn.
But it did have a positive side, he added: "The N.H.L. can effectively put its mistakes behind it because they were mistakes made with virtually no one watching."
Mr. Ryan agreed about the "value of network television for a sport," adding that "it has topspin in so many areas -- the development of stars, of licensing, of image. It truly becomes an advertising vehicle."
So, starting with the 1992-93 season, the N.H.L. shifted its coverage in this country to ESPN, a cable network available in 61 million households, compared with Sports Channel America's 16 million. The league has also hired its first commissioner, Gary Bettman, who, significantly, was lured from the N.B.A.; assumed control of its merchandise-licensing operations, and signed new sponsors like Gillette and Kellogg to join hockey stalwarts like Anheuser-Busch and Coca-Cola.
And the N.H.L. agreed last month to sell expansion franchises to two entertainment marketing powerhouses, the Walt Disney Company and the Blockbuster Entertainment Corporation.
"If you look at the quality of organizations investing $50 million in the N.H.L.," Mr. Ryan said, referring to the fees Disney and Blockbuster will pay for the franchises in Southern California and southern Florida, respectively, "you'll find they're companies with the reputation of being very prudent investors in terms of return on equity and return on investment."
Next comes a series of celebratory television commercials by Arnold Fortuna Lawner & Cabot in Boston, which will begin running Jan. 15 during national hockey telecasts in the United States and Canada, including those on ESPN as well as games in local markets. The spots, which will receive the equivalent of at least $2 million of national air time, will carry the theme "Share the glory."
"One of the classic packaged-goods research techniques is to study why people enter and exit your franchise," Mr. Ryan said, using jargon that might dismay someone who knows that the Rangers' last Stanley Cup came in 1940, but typifies the new marketing-oriented approach that top N.H.L. executives believe they must pursue.
"And what we saw," he added, "is that one of the early-on ways for people to enter our franchise is sharing -- friends share tickets, a husband brings his wife or daughter."
Intriguingly, the spots eschew the elements expected in promoting hockey, like a rapid-fire pace, a breathless, staccato-voiced narrator, and endless brawls on ice. Instead, they assume a gauzy, feel-good tone reminiscent of the movie "Chariots of Fire"; game footage is rerun in slow motion, and the announcer works at a classical-music radio station in Boston.
"There's heritage and sweat, talent and skill, all the things we need to highlight," said Richard B. Emerson, executive vice president and general manager of division operations at Arnold Fortuna, who joined Mr. Ryan for the interview.
"The best way to present that," he added, "is in a way that elevates the brand N.H.L."
Mr. Ryan said that Arnold Fortuna, which was awarded the assignment in September, was recommended by its "creativity and street smarts."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In an effort to gain fan and sponsor dollars in the glutted sports market, the National Hockey League is firing off an advertising and promotional campaign. Wayne Gretzky, left, is seen in a new commercial. (Arnold Fortuna Lawner & Cabot)

HEADLINE: Bill Would Hold Fed More Accountable Politically

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Challenging the autonomy of the Federal Reserve banking system, the chairman of the House Banking Committee introduced legislation today that would hold the central bank more accountable politically for crucial decisions on monetary policy.
Under the proposal, presidents of the Fed's regional banks would be nominated by the President and confirmed by the Senate, rather than being selected largely by bankers from within their own ranks, as they are now. Regional bank heads are among the members of the Fed's Open Market Committee, which makes the Fed's monetary decisions. 
 Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who heads the Banking Committee, said he did not seek to "politicize" the Fed, which by controlling interest rates wields tremendous economic power.
 
More Representative Fed?
 Instead, he said, his aim was to make the Fed more representative of the population. As things stand, he said, "women and minorities have little or no say in the conduct of our nation's monetary policy and in bank regulation." He added, "We simply must change the method of selecting Federal Reserve Bank presidents so that the old-boy network gives way to a more diverse representation."
Five of the 11 regional bank presidents join the seven politically appointed governors of the central bank on the Open Market Committee.
Mr. Gonzalez has long criticized what he calls the "inbred" process of naming regional bank presidents, who at present are elected by a nine-member board of directors at each bank. These directors include three members appointed by the board of governors and six elected by member banks in each district. The legislation would add three more directors appointed by the board of governors, requiring that these directors not be drawn from the banking industry.
His legislation, which would make other changes, including providing videotapes of the meetings where the Open Market Committee sets monetary policy, is sure to be opposed by the Federal Reserve Board.
 
Administration View Not Clear
 It is not clear how the Clinton Administration would view the legislation. Mr. Gonzalez, having led the criticism of the Bush Administration's prewar policies toward Iraq, has become better known.
"With all this Congressional pressure building for reform of the Federal Reserve System, the central bank will face its toughest challenge in years," said Karen D. Shaw, a banking analyst, in a report published today by her company, the Institute for Strategy Development.
"Crucial to maintaining its current structure will be support from the new Administration," she said.
The legislation is also likely to be seen as increasing pressure on the Fed to stimulate the economy by easing its monetary policy.
Congressional Democrats have recently questioned whether the Federal Reserve has been restricting growth in the money supply, and whether such a policy might choke off the fledgling economic recovery.
With Mr. Clinton considering stimulating the economy by increased spending and tax incentives, a crucial question is whether the Fed will counter with higher interest rates to fight inflation.

HEADLINE: Bank Rates Down a Bit In New York

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The average yields offered on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit for the week beginning today are slightly lower in the New York market but about the same in other areas compared with the previous week, according to latest survey by The Bank Rate Monitor.
Deposit rates are expected to remain close to current levels through at least the first half of the year. Mortgage rates, which are closely tied to long-term Treasury issues, are still falling. The 30-year fixed rate is at the lowest level since October. 
 Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Monitor, said interest rates were not shifting because some people in the market were buying the notion that the Clinton Administration would contain inflation, refrain from pouring money into programs and work to reduce the deficit.
At the Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills on Monday, average discount rates were down modestly. The auction is widely regarded as a signal of changes in deposit rates by banks.
The average rate at auction was down 7 basis basis points on a three-month Treasury bill, to 3.15 percent, and down 10 basis points for a six-month bill, to 3.28 percent. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
In the New York area, the average money market account is down about a basis point, with the slide now a month old. The average rate for a three-month certificate is down to 2.82 percent, from 2.85 percent a week ago. Meanwhile, the average yield on a six-month certificate is less than 3 percent, to 2.99 percent from 3.01 percent the previous week.
For the most part, commercial banks are pushing rates down more sharply than the savings banks. The bank with the sharpest changes in C.D. yields from the previous week is the Republic National Bank, which is lowering the yield on its three-month certificate 24 basis points, to 2.89 percent, and 25 basis points on its six-month C.D., to 3.05 percent. Citibank, meanwhile, is dropping the yield on its bank money market account by 15 basis points, to 2.10 percent.
Outside the New York market, yields at 20 large banks are steady as they have been for the last month, with the average yield on a money market account unchanged at 2.68 percent and the average six-month certificate unchanged at 3.03 percent.

HEADLINE: Review/Theater;
A Performance Montage of East-West Troubles

BYLINE: By MEL GUSSOW

 BODY:
On a sweeping pictorial canvas, "Deshima" spans four centuries of troubled East-West relations, moving from the first arrival of Dutch trading ships in Japan to the purchase by the Japanese of van Gogh's "Sunflowers" for $39.9 million. From the perspective of Ping Chong's far reaching performance piece, Japan found a symbolic certification for its world economic supremacy through the acquisition of masterpieces of Western art. In other words, it has become the land of the rising "Sunflowers."
In previous works like "Kind Ness" and "Nosferatu," Mr. Chong has dealt incisively with American and European myths and traditions, and in others he has soared into the futuristic. Rarely has he approached subjects of an Asian nature, a fact for which he fully compensates in "Deshima" (at La Mama Annex). This is an ambitious attempt to probe ancestral roots as well as ancestral trade routes and to dramatize the reverberations between disparate cultures. He studies economic as well as political imperialism. As Mr. Chong sees it, Japan staked an early claim to most-favored-nation status in Asia. 
 Balancing the portrait, he illustrates the plight of Japanese-Americans during World War II with a poignant monologue about a family about to be uprooted and placed in an internment camp. Faced with an insultingly low offer for a treasured Oriental dinner set, the mother of the family smashes the china plate by plate, to the horror of an opportunistic antiques dealer. That's valuable china, he insists, but apparently it is not valuable enough to be bought for a fair price.
In characteristic fashion, the author creates a composite portrait that is scenic, poetic and eclectically choreographic. With a painterly eye for revealing detail, he constructs a nonsequential performance montage with layer upon layer of facts, images and inferences. Re-evoking a reference from "Maraya," an earlier journey into archeology, he has actors slide a pyramid on stage bearing the words tempus fugit, a truism in the case of Mr. Chong. He is one of the quickest moving of conceptual directors, keeping audiences on constant alert.
With its visual density, the work is related to that of Robert Wilson and of Meredith Monk, a past collaborator with Mr. Chong. But it has the author's signature as a documentarian with a puckish sense of humor. He places a high value on the lessons of history, retrieving and refining information so it achieves artistic weight.
In the play, he expresses an internationalist view as forays are made between countries "in the name of God and of profit," a phrase that is eventually abbreviated to "in the name of profit." The attitude that the West represents civilization and everything else is barbaric is especially subject to question during the time of Columbus's quincentenary. To the Japanese of the 17th century, the Dutch were the barbarians, and they were quarantined on the island of Deshima. The idea of quarantine, of one culture isolating another, is a recurrent theme.
Under Mr. Chong's precise direction, the actors move freely among the myriad characters, with Michael Matthews unifying the production as the narrator. Mr. Matthews also stands in for van Gogh, who is quoted as having said that Arles would be the Japan of the future. What he could not know was that his Arles would be in the Japan of the future. As an artist ravaged by his artistic isolation and fated to be exploited by others, van Gogh becomes the emblematic go-between in Mr. Chong's venturesome cross-cultural exploration.
 
Deshima
 
Conceived and directed by Ping Chong, in collaboration with Michael Matthews; set by Watuko Euno and Mr. Chong; lighting by Thomas Hase; costumes by Carol Ann Pelletier; projections by Jan Hartley and Mr. Chong; sound by Robert Bosch and Brian Hallas; Javanese dance choreographed by Deena Burton; dance captain, Ching Gonzalez; voice-over by Margot Hoyt; Virlana Tkacz, production manager; Bruce Allardice, managing director. Presented by La Mama E.T.C. and Ping Chong and Company. At 74A East Fourth Street, East Village.
 
WITH: Deena Burton, Barbara Chan, Ching Gonzalez, Brian Liem, Larry Malvern, Michael Matthews, Emerald Trinket Monsod, Dawn Saito and Perry Yung.
