HEADLINE: Food Notes

BYLINE: By Florence Fabricant

 BODY:

Feed a Cold
A ticket to the Caribbean is one way to help dispel a cold. Empire Kosher Poultry is offering a more economical and traditional remedy. 
 Anyone who sends in the label from any cold medicine will receive a recipe for chicken soup and a coupon worth 75 cents toward the purchase of an Empire kosher chicken. The offer is good through the end of January. Labels should be sent to Bubby, Empire Kosher Poultry, Box 165, Mifflintown, Pa. 17059.
Chicken soup is one culture's nostrum. Saturday classes at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden will examine some others. On Jan. 23 from 1 P.M. to 4 P.M., for example, the topic will be herbs for making teas and other cold remedies. The fee is $32 for members, $37 for nonmembers.
On Feb. 27 from 10:30 A.M. to 2:30 P.M., the subject will be South American and Caribbean cures (without the travel), based on the herbs and plants sold in botanicas in East Harlem and elsewhere in the city ($26 for members, $31 for nonmembers).
The healing plants of the American Indians will be explained on March 6 from 12:30 P.M. to 4:30 P.M. ($39 for members, $45 for nonmembers). For more information: (718) 941-4044.
 
In Toques and on Skis
 On Sunday, beginning at 10 A.M. at Windham Mountain in the Catskills, chefs in toques and white jackets will compete in the annual Chefs Ski Race. The event, in which several hundred chefs from New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Pennsylvania and Maryland are competing, is the mid-Atlantic regional for a race that began at Hunter Mountain in the Catskills 17 years ago and has now become an international competition.
Starting at 3 P.M. there will be a cocktail party with a cash bar for those who attended the race or participated in it. Some seats for the awards banquet, held from 4 P.M. to 6 P.M., are available to the public at $25 a ticket. Reservations: (800) 858-7669. The race is sponsored by the Grand Marnier Foundation, and proceeds will be donated to City Harvest, a nonprofit organization that feeds the homeless in New York City.
 
The Chef as Star
 The stars have Michael Ovitz; now chefs have Shep Gordon. Mr. Gordon is the president of Alive Enterprises in Beverly Hills, Calif., a company that manages rock stars, among others. It has now added a division called Alive Culinary Resources to manage and promote chefs.
Among the clients that have already been signed are Wolfgang Puck, the owner of Spago, Granita and Chinois on Main in the Los Angeles area; Pino Luongo, the owner of Le Madri and Coco Pazzo in Manhattan, and Roger Verge, the owner of the Michelin three-star Moulin de Mougins in the south of France.
 
A New Market
 Moursy's Market, 1439 First Avenue (75th Street), has recycled the space once occupied by R. Bildner & Sons, a chain of fancy supermarkets based in Boston. The new market, with an ambitious selection of meat, produce, prepared foods, cheeses, cured meats and cookware, takes a decidedly Italian point of view.
On the right side near the entrance is a wall of pasta, olive oil, tomato sauce and canned tomatoes. Worth noting are the 35-ounce cans of Fara San Martino imported San Marzano plum tomatoes, $2.89 each.
Last week, the produce was in good condition, at typical Upper East Side prices, and the bakery department had good breads and Italian pastries, some of them garishly decorated.
Moursy's has an enormous array of prepared foods, ranging from mundane tuna salad to excellent eggplant salad with penne, good hot or cold ($5.98 a pound); dense but tasty meatballs ($5.50 a pound), and colorful, well-seasoned Stromboli bread stuffed with either meat and peppers or vegetables ($6 a pound). Even the excellent potato knishes ($2 each) are given an Italian touch with a topping of pine nuts.
Most of the cheeses are sold already cut and wrapped in plastic, not the best treatment, and the clerks are reluctant to provide slivers for tasting. The aged grana padana, similar to Parmesan, was beginning to turn hard and waxy, something that does not happen when the cheese is cut to order from a large wheel. This cheese was $11.98 a pound, compared with $9.98 a pound for the rather young Parmigiano-Reggiano, usually the more expensive cheese.
Cured meats were a varied lot, with salamis in better shape than the hams, some of which were dry.
The cookware shop on the lower level carries an array of pots and utensils, good for filling in for emergencies, especially since Moursy's is open late. Hours are 7 A.M. to 10:30 P.M. Monday through Saturday and 7 A.M. to 10 P.M. Sunday. Free delivery from 68th Street to 82d Street between East End and Third avenues. Telephone: (212) 288-7565.
 
Restaurants by Phone
 CALLING 777-FILM provides information about movies. Now, there's (212) 777-FOOD -- (212) 777-3663 -- to help with dining out. This new restaurant directory for Manhattan is called Food Phone, and it provides an extensive menu of options for the cost of a local call.
The type of cuisine, neighborhood and price range can be selected by pressing the appropriate numbers on a push-button phone. Once a restaurant is chosen, a brief and enthusiastic description follows.
Food Phone was created by three friends who met at Brooklyn Law School. Three thousand restaurants are now listed, but each will soon be asked to pay $35 a month to continue its listing.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Strategies for Treating the Nation's Drug Scourge

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:

Reckoning
Drugs, the Cities and the American Future
By Elliott Currie
405 pages. Hill & Wang. $25.
 
The Making of a Drug-Free America
 Programs That Work
 By Mathea Falco
 255 pages. Times Books. $22. 
 Drug abuse is a major domestic problem that the Clinton Administration will inherit. It cannot be separated from the growing cost of health care and any future national health programs. Obviously, answers cannot be found in "lock 'em up and throw away the key" oversimplifications, or in slogans like "Just Say No." In recent years, Nancy Reagan urged that drug abusers be considered accomplices to murder; Daryl F. Gates, the former Los Angeles police chief, proposed that illegal drug users be shot, and William Bennett, who briefly served as the director of drug control policy in the Bush Administration, said that anyone who sold drugs should have his head cut off.
Two thoughtful new books grapple with the drug problem in more mature ways. Both take wider and deeper looks at the causes of drug abuse, suggesting that the country's sundered economic, educational and social fabric needs attention and repairs.
 In "Reckoning," Elliott Currie, the author of "Dope and Trouble: Portraits of Delinquent Youth," who has taught sociology and criminology at Yale and the University of California at Berkeley, emphasizes the need for job training and jobs. In "The Making of a Drug-Free America," Mathea Falco, an Assistant Secretary of State for International Narcotics Matters from 1977 to 1981 and a visiting fellow at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, says that solutions can be found in improved education and treatment programs.
Ms. Falco's recommendations for freeing Americans from the drug scourge place greater emphasis on private and community efforts, especially through education. She holds that school prevention programs can reduce the likelihood of children's using drugs; that neighborhoods and local police officers, working together, can drive dealers off the streets; that businesses can create programs to reduce drug use among employees. In her opinion, business and civic leaders can forge antidrug coalitions to transform communities.
Legalization of drugs isn't the answer, Ms. Falco maintains, because legalizing drugs for adults while prohibiting their use by minors would actually stimulate drug use among young people, since drugs would become new symbols of adult status.
"The two most powerful reasons for recent declines in marijuana and cocaine use among educated, affluent Americans are health concerns and increasingly negative social attitudes about drugs," she writes. "Holding on to these gains and extending them into higher-risk groups will require intensive prevention, education and treatment campaigns. The drug laws play a critically important role in this effort by conveying social values and defining the limits of permissible behavior. Legalization would signal a fundamental change in American attitudes, implying tolerance rather than disapproval of drug use."
One of the most valuable sections of "The Making of a Drug-Free America" is a listing of private and public organizations all over the country that are fighting drug abuse. Among those in New York City are the Vera Institute of Justice, the Phoenix House Foundation and the New York State division of substance abuse services.
Mr. Currie writes: "To mount a comprehensive attack on the roots of drug abuse, we must be tough-minded enough to acknowledge the need for fundamental change and pragmatic enough to plan for the long term. We must acknowledge that the drug crisis reflects a deeper crisis of culture and spirit, of family and community, as well as of material well-being."
At times, Mr. Currie's high-minded solutions sound like Presidential campaign promises in 1992 and 1932, including a return to some New Deal programs. He sees a fundamental need to reconstruct community life in the United States. His proposals include raising the quality and skill levels of jobs in private industry. He wants to link inner-city students with good jobs that will take them off the drug-infested streets. He thinks that raising minimum wages would help working teen-agers and working women to rebuild family life.
Mr. Currie looks back to the Depression years, when unemployment was high and one-third of the nation was ill fed, ill clothed and ill housed, and finds a model program in the National Youth Administration. "Until its funding was cut off shortly before World War II," he writes, "the N.Y.A. housed, fed, schooled and employed hundreds of thousands of young people -- most of whom would now be considered at risk for drug abuse and delinquency, many of whom were homeless, illiterate or badly nourished."
And how are such vast Federal social programs to be financed? Mr. Currie suggests a better tax system that would place the burden on the wealthy, preventive public health care that would lead to greater savings and "seizing the peace dividend" so that money going to the military would now be shifted to domestic programs.
After reading the well-intentioned generalities in "Reckoning," this thought comes to mind: Drug abuse will have to stand in line with other domestic needs.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Messier, Neilson Continue Their Feud

BYLINE: By JENNIFER FREY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RYE, N.Y., Jan. 5

 BODY:
Unemployed and unhappy, Roger Neilson went to breakfast this morning and added more weight to his attack on Mark Messier.
Clearly pleased by the recent turn of events, Messier went to practice and called a players-only meeting to, among other things, refute Neilson's accusations about his commitment to the Rangers' program. 
 Later, in what is sure to add insult to Neilson's injury, Messier heaped praise on Ron Smith, only one day after Smith was named to succeed Neilson in the Rangers' head-coaching job.
The other players, meanwhile, blamed themselves for the team's problems, staunchly defended Messier, and passed along apologies to Neilson for not playing up to par most of this season.
 
A Clean Slate
 And Smith? He valiantly tried to pretend that the baggage attached to this year's edition of the Rangers didn't come with his new job.
"Unless you're face to face with the problem, you're far better off not making assumptions," Smith said, when asked how he would contend with the fallout from the Neilson-Messier rift. "I couldn't allow myself to be influenced by what I know. I can pretty much predict that it's going to be a solid relationship with the players for the second half."
While Smith ran the ice at practice for the first time this morning, Neilson had brunch with a group of local reporters only a few miles away. Exhausted after a sleepless night, Neilson appeared sadly resigned to his fate, rather than bitter or angry. But, when pressed, he went as far as to question Messier's near-sacred relationship with his teammates along with Messier's commitment to the team.
 
Lack of Leadership
 Neilson, who responded to Monday's dismissal by personally accusing Messier of failing to adequately perform his captain's duties, said today that several players had made him aware that there was a big problem inside the Rangers' locker room more than six weeks ago, and that some had indicated the source of that problem was a perceived drop in leadership from Messier.
"There was no question that it came out that Mess wasn't leading the way he was before and he was such a fabulous leader before in everybody's eyes that it bothered guys," Neilson said. "I guess it bothered everybody in different ways."
After today's practice, Messier argued that he has been the same this season as his entire career. And several of his teammates, although conceding that there has been a serious lack of team cohesiveness, refused to place the blame on Messier.
 
'Everybody Changed'
 "When you have 25 guys that are frustrated, that's obviously going to have an effect on the team," said forward Doug Weight. "But I don't think that can be put on Mark's shoulders or Roger's shoulders. As the team went down, everybody changed. Maybe Mark quieted up a little bit, but it's unfair, really, to just say Mark changed.
"Let's face it, this whole team changed. It's unfair to put Mark on the spot because he's the captain and he's the one with all the weight on his shoulders. We weren't doing our jobs."
Messier said: "I felt at the time that it might have been best to sit back and analyze what was going on, to just watch the situation. I'm only who I am. That's who I have been my entire career. I think everybody has to make a commitment, I've said that since I've been here."
 
Team Unity Stressed
 Commitment and team unity seemed to be the big themes of the players-only meeting, along with an instructional "what it takes to win the Stanley Cup" pep talk by Kevin Lowe, who has won the cup five times. The new coach was not invited and did not seem in the least concerned, congenially discussing all the "enthusiasm and energy" he saw during practice.
When asked to discuss Smith's potential impact on the program, Messier sounded like an endorsement video, calling Smith's inital statements "music to my ears" and describing the new coach as, among other things, "intelligent" and "articulate" and "able to speak with authority."
Messier tried to focus on what he called the "good times to come" for the Rangers' program. He praised Smith's style, "He likes lots of hustle, a lot of puck pursuit, and I feel that's the way you have to play." And he raved about the previous night's 3-3 tie with the Devils, "I had a good feeling all night and I haven't felt that for a month or so."
Neilson went back to packing boxes for his return home to Peterboro, Ontario. He was supposed to fly out today, but late Monday night, he was forced to take his dog Mike to a Manhattan animal hospital.
"I think it was about three in the morning when I was driving back from Manhattan," Neilson said. "I got lost and somehow ended up on the West Side Highway. I guess it was just one of those nights."

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Mr. Yeltsin on Line One

 BODY:
Boris Yeltsin telephoned on Monday to invite Bill Clinton to an early summit meeting. Mr. Clinton took the call but put the request on hold. He'd love to meet, he said, but not until he presented his domestic agenda and persuaded Congress to get cracking on urgent business at home.
It was the right response. Mr. Clinton is well aware that the call conveyed more than a polite invitation. It signaled Russia's continuing need for American help and reassurance as it lurches toward democracy. It was a reminder, too, that Mr. Clinton cannot long ignore pressing matters of foreign policy. 
 Even so, he has no reason to allow foreign policy to drive urgent domestic needs into the background. First things first, he says, not only to Mr. Yeltsin but to anyone who insists that he has to attend to foreign policy first.
He doesn't. With the end of the cold war, the President of the United States need not react to every crisis in every corner of the world. He can set his own pace by defining a more discriminating foreign policy for the post-cold-war world. He can do that by building on what he has said and done as a candidate and as President-elect.
Mr. Clinton clearly has no wish to slight Mr. Yeltsin or his problems. During the campaign, he urged Mr. Bush to assist Russia's attempts to move to freer politics and markets. Nor is he oblivious to the connection between Russia's domestic reform and America's: "A small amount spent stabilizing the emerging democracies in the former Soviet empire today," he declared, "will reduce by much more the money we may have to commit to our defense in the future."
He obviously understands Russia's problems and knows that they won't wait forever. In time he must also attend to the slaughter in Bosnia, the languishing Middle East peace process and the need to curb arms proliferation, beginning with Ukraine and the other nuclear republics of the former Soviet Union.
Indeed, there's enough on his plate, at home and abroad, to justify the occasional diplomatic snub. He properly spurned Prime Minister John Major of Britain, whose Government meddled in the Presidential campaign. Mr. Major and other foreign leaders who wanted early meetings had to settle for telephone calls.
The exception is President Salinas of Mexico, whom Mr. Clinton will meet before his inauguration. The focus of their discussion, a pending treaty that would set up a North American Free Trade Area, underscores the importance Mr. Clinton attaches to expanding trade on his own terms.
His major foreign policy task, however, is not to meet with this leader or that but to shape a post-cold-war foreign policy that will allow him to keep the focus on domestic policy. That means getting ahead of future crises by carefully defining his criteria for U.S. economic and military involvement abroad. Otherwise his agenda will be driven by a succession of foreign policy crises, and desperately needed domestic projects will once again be put off.

HEADLINE: United Way Needs a Period of Scrutiny

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "United Way: Leaner and Needier" (editorial, Dec. 17): United Way's problems owe less to the recession and past scandal at the fund-raising organization than to its lack of definition and canvassing methods. 
 The $3 billion in annual contributions that the organization receives comes nowhere near financing its thousands of social service and health care agencies. Public money makes its survival possible.
But such is the state of our information that no one knows the overall mixture of private and public funds needed to operate chapter networks. Nor has anyone tested the assumption that some agencies might be better off if entirely financed with either public or private funds.
What we do know is that United Way's canvassing methods are as outdated as its image, in your words, "as an arm of the Establishment." For at least a quarter-century, United Way has depended mainly on corporate contributions and giving by employees -- even as companies, and with them hundreds of thousands of jobs, have left the country.
Stockholders in corporations frequently ask (but infrequently receive answers to) the question, Why should executives have authority to make corporate gifts without stockholder approval? Meanwhile, employees seldom refuse when asked for a pledge by a superior who holds their job at his or her pleasure. Resentment among stockholders and employees boils over in a hard economic time.
United Way will become more useful after its operations are analyzed and openly debated by board members, executives, volunteers, fund raisers and other professionals, including sociologists and social psychologists. That is, change can occur only when United Way abandons a closed-shop mentality.
The model can be the in-depth discussions that President-elect Clinton activated to analyze economic problems. And if United Way devotes enough thought and effort to the task of change, it should avoid a future spectacle of a major national institution humiliated by inept and corrupt management.
 
MILTON GOLDIN
Tarrytown, N.Y., Dec. 18, 1992
 
The writer heads a fund-raising consulting organization.

HEADLINE: Before We Let World Bank Squander More

 BODY:
To the Editor:
While we concur with "The World's Poor Need Bill Clinton" (editorial, Dec. 19), that the world's poorest countries need assistance, and that President-elect Clinton should lead the effort, we do not think that the World Bank's International Development Association is the best mechanism for providing this aid. In "World Bank War on Pollution Faces Ever Sharper Criticism," (news article, Nov. 12), you note growing criticism of the World Bank's environmental and human rights record. 
 Before agreeing to provide $18 billion more to the bank's International Development Association, taxpayers in the United States and other donor countries should be aware that these problems are systemic and that without major reforms the money will continue to be wasted on environmental and social disasters.
Three years ago when the World Bank asked donor countries for the last multibillion-dollar replenishment of these funds, it agreed with its donors to support environmentally sound projects, alleviate poverty, insure greater public access to information and to promote public participation. The bank's promises proved worthless; it continues to finance schemes that are documented financial, environmental and social failures, and to withhold most information on its activities.
Last summer an internal review of the bank's $140 billion loan portfolio (led by Willi Wappenhans, World Bank vice president) showed that, according to the bank's own criteria, 37.5 percent of recently evaluated projects are failures, up from 15 percent in 1981.
The most alarming aspect is economic: according to the Wappenhans report, nearly four-fifths of the financial conditions in World Bank loans -- 78 percent -- are not complied with. The bank's economic appraisal is viewed by many staff, according to the same report, as a "marketing device for securing loan approval," and confidential surveys of bank professionals show that "only 17 percent of staff interviewed felt that analytical work done during project preparation was compatible with the achievement of project quality."
World Bank water projects, such as the infamous Narmada dam in India cited in your Nov. 12 article, are among the worst offenders. According to the Wappenhans report, 42 percent of continuing water supply and agriculture projects are encountering serious implementation problems.
But the bank is preparing to finance still more of these losers on a gargantuan scale. Witness the number of dam and water projects in the pipeline: the Bangladesh flood action plan, the outer islands power project in Indonesia, the Lesotho Highlands water projects in South Africa and possibly the titanic Three Gorges Dam in China.
There is little concrete evidence in the bank's practice and priorities that critical habitats or the rights of poor and tribal people will be better protected in future projects. Most of these dam projects will create hundreds of thousands of new poor and homeless by forcibly displacing people from their lands. Millions of people have been left worse off economically after World Bank-financed projects than they were before.
To dump $18 billion more into the lap of such an institution, without total reform and housecleaning from top to bottom, is financial folly.
The world's poor do need Bill Clinton to promote their interests and those of United States taxpayers by refusing World Bank demands for more funds without serious structural reforms. Furthermore, we hope that the new Administration will appoint an environmentally and socially aware representative to the World Bank's board of executive directors, who will make institutional reform, project quality and financial accountability top priorities, rather than increased lending.
 
DEBORAH MOORE
BRUCE RICH, LORI UDALL
Washington, Dec. 23, 1992
 
The writers are, respectively, staff scientist, director and staff lawyer in the Environmental Defense Fund's international program.

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
The Lapel Pin Thing

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

 BODY:
To: President-elect Clinton
Re: the Inaugural
Dear Bill, 
 That sounds too informal, doesn't it? After all, I'm not an F.O.B. (Friend of Bill) and for a long time I wasn't even an S.O.B. (Supporter of Bill). But I am related by marriage to a C.O.B. (Contributor of Bill) and so I have come into possession of this lovely inaugural mailing.
First off, thanks for the beautiful big engraved invitation. When we opened it we thought we were being invited to the wedding of the daughter of the Sultan of Bahrain. Then we read it over and concluded that we were being invited to the inauguration of someone named William Jefferson Clinton. Whew! No wonder you settled on that simple but elegant all-occasion nickname.
However, since I am related by marriage to a lawyer, who knows how to read fine print, I soon learned that this inaugural invitation only served to "welcome our participation in any of the public events." We had to sit the kids down and explain that what that really meant was that we could take our sleeping bags down to Pennsylvania Avenue and stake out a position on the parade route, and that while we would be willing to do that for Stones tickets in July, we would not be doing it for Bill in January.
The kids were not disappointed, however, because with the engraved invitation was an invitation to buy souvenirs. Someone on your inaugural team must have known how deep the lust for embossed hats and commemorative key chains runs in the American spirit because the flier prominently features a sterling silver saxophone pin, "shown actual size."
Now, I bring all this up, Bill, because this sort of thing -- let's call it the saxophone lapel pin thing -- is going to be a problem for you. It is a fine line between being Presidential and purveying novelty items, between folksiness and dignity, between promising and delivering. And it is time to start drawing that line, before you invite a Boy Scout troop in for Sloppy Joes in a fit of bonhomie and then discover you're already scheduled for lunch with John Major.
Our faux invitation, for instance, brought to mind that testy "bean counters" criticism of women's groups just before the holidays. The problem was that you raised expectations with those folks. When you talked about an administration that looked like America, they thought of the America in which half of us are female. They did not think of the America in which women get a few visible appointments and then everyone congratulates himself on filling some minority quota even though we actually happen to be the majority.
(This view was represented by the editorial cartoonist who showed a bunch of animals saying, "We believe President-elect Clinton's cabinet appointments do not reflect America's diversity -- they're all humans." In other words, it's only a small step from pushy women to pushy dogs and horses.)
This same syndrome may attach to your economic conference. Some number crunchers complained that all those biz whizzes sitting around in a circle was nothing but public relations. Oh, pooh. Public relations is just what the economy needs right now. You got a lot of expectations going with all that talk; Toys "R" Us did a booming Christmas business on Super Nintendo and Puppy Surprise. Now you have about 90 days before anyone says, "All he's done about the economy is hold that stupid conference."
It's not an easy road you'll walk two weeks from now. You're going to have to balance hope and reality, insiders and outsiders, the long haul and the quick fix. And you'll have to try to be approachable without being ridiculous. On your shoulders lies heavy the burden of answering a question never before asked in this nation: Can a man wail on "Arsenio" and lead the free world?
But one cautionary note to begin with: It may be that on that triumphant trip from the Capitol to the White House, the one Jimmy Carter walked hand-in-hand with Rosalynn to show what a regular guy he was, you'll be tempted to stop off for a Quarter Pounder with cheese, a gabfest with a table of nurse's aides and a magnanimous offer of jobs -- for everyone! On the house! It may feel right. It may feel new generation. But when that spirit moves you, Bill, keep moving.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Ukraine Finds Nuclear Arms Bring a Measure of Respect

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Among disarmament negotiators, nuclear missiles are measured by their ability to destroy. In Ukraine, they are increasingly being measured in terms of dollars and respect, and the perception may well hold the key to the success or failure of the strategic arms treaty signed this week in Moscow.
"Our deputies don't care where these things are aimed," said Serhiy Holovaty, a leading voice in the Ukrainian Parliament's commission for foreign affairs. "They know that they must get something for them." 
 Others might not put it quite that bluntly. But when the question of nuclear missiles arises -- whether with the urbane President, Leonid M. Kravchuk, or the harshest of nationalists -- that is roughly the bottom line.
 
Ratification of Treaty
 The issue will become critical in the next weeks when the Ukrainian Parliament is scheduled to take up the question of ratifying the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, known as Start I, which calls on Ukraine to dismantle all 176 missile launchers and silos on its territory. Unless Start I comes into effect, Start II is a dead letter.
[The head of a Ukrainian delegation visiting Washington said his Government was seeking security guarantees from the United States before getting rid of its nuclear weapons, The Associated Press reported.
["We hope these guarantees will be in the form of declarations at the highest political levels," Deputy Foreign Minister Boris Tarasiuk said.]
In an interview, Mr. Kravchuk reiterated his certainty that the treaty would be ratified -- but only if the deputies received international guarantees of Ukraine's security and satisfactory compensation. He reportedly set out this position in a letter to President Bush on Tuesday.
But exactly what that means, and whether Moscow or the West are prepared to meet Ukraine's conditions, is likely to make for a tense debate, the outcome of which cannot be foreseen.
At the heart of the question, less tangible but perhaps even more important than issues of money or security, is a growing frustration among Ukrainian leaders at being taken for granted, at being treated as an appendage of Russia.
In interviews with Mr. Kravchuk and several key players in the debate, there was an invariable complaint that Ukraine was not being taken seriously in Russia or the West, and the implication that without its inherited nuclear might, Ukraine might lose its last claim to attention.
"They are afraid of being written off," said a Western diplomat who has dealt closely with the issue. "The attitude they sense from Russia and Washington is, "Give us your missiles and go to hell."
The sense that the world had not properly appreciated Ukraine as an independent state cropped up like a refrain in the interviews, reflected in constant reminders that this was a nation of 52 million, with a territory the size of France, with the third-largest nuclear force in the world.
"I have a right to defend the interests of my people," Mr. Kravchuk argued in the interview. "We should not be accused of defending the interests of my people, we should not be pressured in the mass media. I see these reports that Ukraine is trying to play on something, to speculate on this.
"No. It wants a just resolution of this issue. We want not to look foolish, not to get applauded for giving up our missiles and then forgotten."
 
Grabbing the Assets
 Coupled with that was the complaint that Russia had grabbed all the assets of the former Soviet Union -- foreign properties, diamonds, nuclear weapons -- and that Ukraine would no longer tolerate that.
Like many of his colleagues, Mr. Holovaty recalled angrily that Ukraine had let Russia take away all its tactical nuclear weapons without any compensation, or any idea where they ended up.
"As someone with influence in Parliament on this issue, I can tell you that Ukraine has been so burned by Russia in financial and economic matters that after a year of this we will not lightly give up any more assets," he said.
"We would never give up the nuclear weapons now, at least without something in return. We don't want to be the fool. The U.S. needs to understand this, to take into account the psychological factor."
Maj. Gen. Vladimir Muliava, the leader of the Ukrainian officers' association, said: "We don't seek to join any bloc or to have any nuclear weapons; we'll never attack anyone. But the time has come for the world to look at Ukraine's position. For too long, the world has neither seen nor heard Ukraine."
 
Blackmail Charge Denied
 But the notion that taking such a position could be interpreted as a form of nuclear blackmail prompted impassioned denials.
"We know the rockets are aimed at the U.S.," said Genrikh Altunian, a deputy who made a name under the Communist Government as a political dissident, "but we have no other rockets. We are in a difficult situation. I understand the concern of the U.S., but the U.S. must appreciate the concern of Ukraine."
According to Ukrainians and diplomats here, the United States and Russia have been slow to appreciate the depth of Ukraine's determination not to release its nuclear potential cheaply.
Ukraine's original Declaration of Sovereignty, adopted in July 1990, declared that it would be "nuclear free," and the pact forming a Commonwealth of Independent States left strategic weapons under Moscow's control.
 
Agreement in Lisbon
 In May , Mr. Kravchuk signed an agreement in Lisbon pledging Ukraine to the Start I agreement, which was signed by Mr. Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in July 1991, five months before the Soviet Union fell apart. In the so-called Lisbon protocols, Ukraine, Kazakhstan and Belarus, the newly formed states, agreed not only to give up all their nuclear missiles in accordance with Start I but also to adhere to the nonproliferation treaty banning them from ever having nuclear weapons.
But then deputies began to have second thoughts, and the notion grew that there was no reason to cede to Russia an asset that had potential value as a source of income and as a source of respect.
A clutch of nuclear hawks, who include militant nationalists seeking power for Ukraine and hard-line Communists, began to argue that perhaps Ukraine should remain a nuclear power.
One of the latter is Maj. Gen. Vladimir Tolubko, a commander in the strategic forces who is also a deputy. Known as a powerful orator, General Tolubko has harangued the Parliament with arguments like, "As a military man, I believe that without nuclear arms, a state's defense cannot be sufficiently effective and trustworthy."
 
Economic Perils Seen
 On the other pole are deputies who argue that Ukraine should not risk its standing with the West by delaying ratification of Start I. Boris Tarasyuk, a deputy Foreign Minister and chairman of the National Committee on Disarmament, warned Parliament in an interview with "Voice of Ukraine" that failure to ratify the treaty could lead to a cessation of economic and relief aid and even trade sanctions.
Most deputies are thought to support ratification, but only with appropriate guarantees of security and compensation.
Mr. Kravchuk made clear in the interview he would not bring Start I before the Parliament unless he had concrete proposals. A practiced and cautious politician, the President avoided words like "conditions," but he left no doubt that this is what he meant.
"I can say with even more certainty than before that this document will be ratified, but possibly with some additions, some elaboration, on three issues," he said.
The first was a guarantee of security. Mr. Kravchuk said it should be made by nuclear states first, which "in my view should take note that the third largest nuclear power was voluntarily rejecting all this."
 
Security Guarantees Sought
 "I'm not ready to say what form this should be, but a declaration would calm the population, it would be easier for me to present this to the Supreme Soviet," Mr. Kravchuk said.
But members of Parliament were more specific about the guarantee, insisting it should be a treaty signed by the United States and Russia.
The demand has frustrated some American officials, who have been prepared to issue general assurances, but not to enter into any sort of formal defense treaty with Ukraine.
The second demand was compensation. Again, neither Mr. Kravchuk nor the deputies offered any specific figures. Washington has already offered Ukraine $175 million out of the $800 million appropriated in the bill to help former Soviet republics disarm, but Mr. Kravchuk said this was a "drop" compared to Ukraine's needs.
Officials made clear the demand for compensation was aimed primarily at Russia. Mr. Kravchuk and Mr. Yeltsin are to meet later this month, and dividing up the costs and proceeds from dismantling nuclear warheads and selling the nuclear fuel is one of the main topics they are to take up. Ukrainians believe the nuclear fuel from dismantled rockets could fetch up to $5.5 billion, and insist they should know what their share is.
 
Disposing of Toxic Fuel
 The third condition was environmental. The Ukrainians have raised the argument that the 130 SS-19 missiles on their soil carry extremely toxic liquid propellant, and that Ukraine simply does not have the technology or the funds to dispose of the fuel.
"If we were rich, we would never pose such questions," Mr. Kravchuk said. "But our economy is in crisis. There is a fall in production. Can we independently decide this problem? No, that's clear to all."
Again and again, Mr. Kravchuk insisted that Ukraine was true to its intention to give up nuclear weapons. But he rejected a suggestion that the debate was in any case hypothetical, since Ukraine had no control over the missiles and could not aim them.
The 46 SS-24 missiles, each with 10 independently targeted warheads, he said, were assembled in Ukraine and could be used by Ukraine.
"This is power," he said. "We want to get rid of it, but it's not hypothetical."

The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: January 7, 1993

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 1465 words

HEADLINE: CLINTON BACKS OFF HIS PLEDGE TO CUT THE DEFICIT IN HALF

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Responding quickly to new projections of larger deficits from President Bush, President-elect Bill Clinton appeared today to back off his campaign pledge to cut the Federal budget deficit in half in four years.
Mr. Clinton said the Bush Administration had camouflaged the magnitude of the deficit. 
 In Little Rock, Ark., Mr. Clinton said the new figures, issued today by the White House as part of Mr. Bush's final budget, were an "unsettling revelation." But in the campaign, Mr. Clinton was repeatedly told by his advisers that the deficit would be larger than acknowledged by Mr. Bush or assumed by Mr. Clinton in his campaign manifesto.
 
Billions and More Billions
 Mr. Clinton and his aides seemed to be using the new estimates of the deficit from the Bush White House to begin revising Mr. Clinton's campaign promises. The Clinton stance also suggested the possibility that the President-elect wanted to lay early political groundwork for unpopular measures to cut the growth of spending, or even perhaps to raise some taxes.
Aides to Mr. Clinton said that he still wanted to halve the deficit, but that it would probably take more than four years to achieve that goal. "It would be imprudent to go too far on deficit reduction so you put the economy in a tailspin," said a member of Mr. Clinton's transition team.
Mr. Bush's budget for the fiscal year 1994, which begins Oct. 1, shows Federal spending of $1.5 trillion, equal to nearly one-fourth of the nation's total output of goods and services. It shows a deficit of $292.4 billion in 1994, rising to $305 billion in 1997.
By contrast, in his last report to Congress, in July, Mr. Bush said the budget deficit would decline to $274.2 billion in 1994 and to $236.7 billion in 1997. The new estimate of the 1997 deficit is $68 billion higher than the estimate made by the White House five months ago. The actual deficit for the fiscal year 1992, which ended three months ago, was $290.2 billion, a record.
 
Both Sides Vulnerable
 "We now can see the full magnitude of the debt we will inherit and the challenge that we must confront," Mr. Clinton said.
It was not clear how far Republicans would go in asserting that Mr. Clinton was embracing a weak excuse for softening his promise. They could argue that since the $68 billion discrepancy is far short of half the projected deficit, learning of it today is insufficient reason to back away from the pledge. If they did, Democrats would counter with examples of number-juggling by the departing Administration -- as indeed they were already doing today.
The projected deficits for 1995 and beyond are higher than previous estimates by the White House, but are still based on the unrealistic assumption that spending for a wide range of domestic programs will be frozen in the next five years, with no allowance for inflation.
Unpublished estimates by the Office of Management and Budget show that if these programs are allowed to grow with inflation, there will be much larger deficits, around $400 billion a year in 1997 and 1998.
Publication of the new budget figures by the Republican Administration, and the swift response by the Democrats, echoed their debates in the 1992 campaign and foreshadowed battles over the economy.
Democrats have suggested for some time that the Bush Administration deliberately underestimates the deficit, while Republicans have long charged that Democrats offer a far more expensive slate of programs than the nation can afford.
The White House had suggested that Mr. Bush's final budget would be a dull, routine, apolitical exercise by a lame-duck Administration. In fact, the budget set off a political brawl over the nation's fiscal problems, with a skirmish over the candor of Mr. Bush and his budget director, Richard G. Darman.
 
Of Circles and Squares
 Democrats described Mr. Darman's work as duplicitous, bizarre, unrealistic and fanciful. They said that he had understated the amount by which Federal spending and the budget deficit will grow in coming years, and had therefore understated the problems bequeathed to Mr. Clinton.
In a separate chapter of the budget, which reads almost as if the 1992 election had not occurred, Mr. Darman boasts about the performance of the economy and mocks some of Mr. Clinton's proposals.
Referring to the economy, a decisive issue in the 1992 election, Mr. Darman says dryly, "Growth has not been as strong as one would have wished." Employment, retail sales, industrial production, personal income and consumer confidence are all rising, Mr. Darman says.
Mr. Darman describes Mr. Clinton's vision for America as "a circle that cannot be squared," and declares, "The math does not work."
Mr. Clinton, in a book-length version of his campaign manifesto, published in September, said, "Our plan will cut the deficit in half within four years."
But today Mr. Clinton said: "The unsettling revelation -- however camouflaged -- is that the projected deficit for 1997 has grown by $60 billion, and that, if left unchecked, it could soar above $400 billion near the end of the decade. This sounds the final warning bell. This endless pattern of rising deficits must stop."
 
Leery in Little Rock
 In Little Rock, George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's communications director, was repeatedly asked whether, in view of the new numbers, the President-elect would carry out his pledge to cut the deficit in half in four years. Mr. Stephanopoulos offered noncommittal answers:
"I think we have to address those challenges of the budget deficit and the investment deficit."
"These numbers show that the defict is far worse than anyone has been telling us for a long, long time."
"What this shows is that the numbers are different from what we heard during the campaign, but we are still committed to achieving reductions in the budget deficit."
 
'A Confusing Irrelevance'?
 Senator Jim Sasser of Tennessee, chairman of the Budget Committee, said Mr. Darman had used bookkeeper's gimmicks to obscure the problems facing Mr. Clinton. Of the document issued today by the White House, Mr. Sasser said: "It's not a budget. It's an irrelevance. And it's a confusing irrelevance at that."
But Republicans said Mr. Clinton's estimates were also unrealistic. "It's obvious Clinton's plan won't cut the budget deficit in half," said Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, ranking Republican on the Budget Committee.
Mr. Bush's final budget offers sobering projections for some of the Government's solemn commitments:
*Outlays for Social Security will rise 39 percent, to $396 billion in 1998 from $285 billion in 1992.
*The cost of Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly and disabled, will double in six years, to $236 billion in 1998 from $116 billion in 1992.
*Federal spending on Medicaid, for low-income people, will more than double, to $156 billion in 1998 from $68 billion in 1992.
*Interest payments on the Federal debt will rise 55 percent, to $308 billion in 1998 from $199 billion last year. The debt itself, the accumulated total of all Federal borrowing, will rise more rapidly, to $4.8 trillion in 1998 from $3 trillion last year.
Ronald Reagan's last budget, sent to Congress in January 1989, and Mr. Bush's first budget, in January 1990, both said that the Federal budget deficit would be eliminated by now. They projected modest surpluses for 1993, 1994 and 1995.
 
A Perfunctory Letter
 There is no evidence that Mr. Bush played a significant role in decisions about the budget document published today. The President's Budget Message is a perfunctory letter to Congress; the contents of the document come from Mr. Darman and his staff.
Mr. Darman suggested today that Mr. Clinton had taken the idea of "investing in America's future" from prior Bush budgets. If Mr. Clinton really cares about such investments, Mr. Darman said, he will "slow the growth of the consumption portion of the Federal budget" by limiting the growth of Federal benefit programs like Medicare and Medicaid.
Mr. Darman called again for a limit on the growth of such programs, under which benefits are available to all applicants who meet certain eligibility criteria. Those programs grow automatically under existing law because of inflation, population growth, the aging of the population and other factors.
The proposed limit on the growth of Federal benefit programs, also known as entitlement programs, would save $15 billion in 1994 and a total of $358 billion from 1994 through 1998, by Mr. Darman's calculations. The White House did not specify how those savings should be achieved. Far more modest proposals to trim Medicare, farm subsidies, student loans and other forms of largess have provoked an uproar on Capitol Hill.

HEADLINE: As Daily News Nears Sale, Foes and Challenges Await

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON

 BODY:
Mortimer B. Zuckerman is expected to complete his purchase of The Daily News this week, which could lead to a newspaper war in the country's largest city and challenge the conventional wisdom that New York cannot support four newspapers.
In an industry that is part production-line grit and part blue smoke and mirrors, the arrival of Mr. Zuckerman as the would-be savior of the bruised Daily News could give the 73-year-old newspaper new life and the city a new publisher with a history of winning influential friends and making bitter enemies. 
 It could also ignite an angry and tangled fight with and among labor unions, because Mr. Zuckerman has no agreement with one of the newspaper's 10 unions, the New York Newspaper Guild. The guild represents writers and editors as well as advertising and circulation employees. The new publisher plans to have subordinates tell about 175 of of the guild's 540 members that they no longer have jobs, according to people in Mr. Zuckerman's camp and in the union. The notifications could begin as early as this morning.
The volatile union situation is only one of a series of challenges facing Mr. Zuckerman, a multimillionaire real-estate developer who also owns U.S. News & World Report and The Atlantic magazine. He must stabilize a bankrupt newspaper that lost $100 million during the last 10 years.
After a tortuous acquisition process, news-industry analysts are saying: Now comes the hard part. Mr. Zuckerman's promise to revitalize The News amounts to a test of whether a big-city mass-circulation tabloid can prosper into the next century.
"Somehow, will he pull off a miracle?" asked Gary Hoenig, editor of News Inc., an industry publication that covers the business of newspapers.
 
A Spur to Competition
 Financial success, if it occurs, could deliver a big payoff. Mr. Zuckerman has the chance to revive a powerful newspaper franchise in time to profit from an economic recovery. That could give The News the chance to regain its aggressiveness as a news organization, spurring new competition among all the city's newspapers.
In an interview this week, he said he would build The News by capitalizing on what he called the newspaper's niche as a practitioner of street-smart journalism for ordinary New Yorkers. "It is my intention," he said, "to have it remain a popular and populist tabloid speaking with the voice of New York to the average working family of New York."
He outlined what he described as a simple strategy. Advertisers, he said, would be drawn by a quality editorial product and a growing circulation. He said that by cutting labor costs and making other savings he had reduced costs to the point that he expected The News, which has been losing $7 million a year, to be profitable from his first year of ownership.
But even if he gets through what is certain to be a difficult transition, he will confront many of the same problems that whittled away The News's strength for decades. Though it still has a circulation of almost 800,000, many of its readers have aged and moved away from the city. The pool of advertisers eager to appear in an urban mass-circulation newspaper steadily declined from the days in the 1940's when the daily newspaper sold 2.4 million copies.
Signs of a New York City news battle are likely to come soon, not just at The News, but also at The New York Times, The New York Post and Newsday, each of which will need to defend against the new News. Coverage at all the newspapers, said Newsday's publisher, Robert M. Johnson, will be as good in 1993 as it has been in some time, if not better.
But newspaper readership habits are hard to break and hard to create, and no matter what happens in the next months, it is likely to be some time before Mr. Zuckerman's long-term success can be measured.
 
No Editor Yet
 Mr. Zuckerman has not yet named his editor. He has talked with several news executives in the United States and Britain. Most of the candidates, people in the industry said, are journalists with experience in what might be called serious tabloids, newspapers that blend coverage of social and policy issues with a tabloid style, which employs short articles, snappy writing and bold headlines.
Mr. Zuckerman's choice of an editor matters less than it would at many publications, because he is expected to be immersed in the details of news decisions at the start. At U.S. News & World Report, which Mr. Zuckerman purchased in 1984, he and an associate, Fred Drasner, split the management funtions.
Mr. Drasner, a former lawyer, concentrates on business concerns at U.S. News and Mr. Zuckerman has focused on editorial operations, spending one day a week at the magazine's Washington headquarters. U.S. News has been widely cited as more vigorous in recent years and its advertising pages have increased.
 
Drasner as Co-Publisher
 Mr. Drasner is to be the co-publisher with Mr. Zuckerman of The News and Mr. Zuckerman said he would divide the duties in the same way with Mr. Drasner. Mr. Zuckerman said he was committed to improving The News's political, investigative and economic coverage.
Mr. Zuckerman, who is 55 and unmarried, was born in Canada, the only son of a successful tobacco and candy distributor who died when he was a teen-ager. He started a fortune that has been estimated at several hundred million dollars in the Boston real-estate business.
His fame has come, however, as much from his active social life, which has included dating Gloria Steinem and other accomplished women, and from development controversies he stirred up in Boston and New York as from what his friends say are significant business and journalistic accomplishments.
The best indication of the direction Mr. Zuckerman is likely to take at The News may be the types of serious political and economic topics Mr. Zuckerman has written about in U.S. News. Some journalists who know Mr. Zuckerman well said his interests are likely to help shape a newspaper that tries to break news about important subjects.
"Mort is a serious guy," said Ken Auletta, the author and longtime Daily News columnist. "I think he's going to make it a better paper." Mr. Auletta, who has sometimes bickered with Mr. Zuckerman publicly, is part of a group of well-connected people, including media celebrities and Mr. Zuckerman, who have played a regular Saturday softball game for years not far from Mr. Zuckerman's summer home in East Hampton.
 
The Dangers of East Hampton
 Mr. Zuckerman's connections to that group, some say, provide both benefits and dangers as he takes over a newspaper whose readers may have views of life different from those prevalent at chic Long Island beach parties.
The benefits are that Mr. Zuckerman has social connections with some of the region's most powerful people and to influential writers and editors. The dangers are that "Long Island chic" would probably fail as an editorial policy for The News. Some journalists say they have warned Mr. Zuckerman that he must remain keenly aware of the character of the newspaper he is buying.
Jerry Nachman, the former editor of The New York Post, said he was explicit with Mr. Zuckerman when the two talked recently. He said his advice was: "Sell the house in East Hampton and get out of the influence of those awful people, especially his media friends. Never take advice from anyone who earns over $42,500 a year."
 
Same Strategies
 Although Mr. Zuckerman's purchase of The News is likely to spur greater competition over local coverage, a Zuckerman-owned News preserves the relative competitive standings of the newspapers in New York City. In interviews this week, the publishers of each of the other major New York newspapers said Mr. Zuckerman's arrival would dictate that they retain strategies that have governed for years.
Mr. Johnson of Newsday acknowledged that when The News appeared to be near death during its long strike two years ago, Newsday thought it might benefit from a "windfall." But he said New York Newsday's parent, the Times Mirror Company, remained committed to a long-term plan that he said calls for New York Newsday to break even in 1995.
At The New York Post, long considered the most endangered of the New York newspapers, Peter S. Kalikow, the publisher, said The Post is "poised to do O.K." in new competition in the city. He said an imminent agreement with an investor would give The Post the capital to modernize its printing equipment.
At The New York Times, Arthur Sulzberger Jr., the publisher, said he welcomed the prospect that The News could return to financial health, partly because it could be an important journalistic voice in New York. "I want The Daily News to exist and I want it to exist for a whole lot of reasons," Mr. Sulzberger said.
Conventional analysis in the newspaper industry has long held that The Times benefits if The News is strong because The News operates as a buffer, keeping New York Newsday from attempting to compete with The Times for its higher-income and better-educated readers.
 
A Series of Critics
 Mr. Zuckerman has collected a series of critics over the years who view him with much the same bitterness now emerging from some members of the Newspaper Guild, which has accused Mr. Zuckerman of unscrupulous tactics. Some of them say that despite his experience with magazines, he does not understand the values of journalism, operating in the news sphere with what they say are the deal-making values of the real-estate business.
One critic is David Halberstam, the author and journalist, who has questioned Mr. Zuckerman's motives ever since the two fought over Mr. Zuckerman's plan to build a tower south of Central Park that a group of prominent New Yorkers, including Mr. Halberstam, opposed.
"He likes to think of himself as a journalist," Mr. Halberstam said. "He's not. He's a real-estate person who has bought a series of very vulnerable publications and it gave him a social legitimacy that he very, very badly wanted."
In the interview this week, Mr. Zuckerman said suggestions by Mr. Halberstam and others that he is interested in publishing because of the social entree it provides were "stupid" and motivated by the "vindictiveness of certain people." He cited praise of U.S. News & World Report's improvements and that it had surpassed both Time and Newsweek in advertising pages as evidence of his record as a publisher.

HEADLINE: Tokyo Journal;
Finally, Prince Finds a Bride: A Harvard Woman

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Japan's longest-running soap opera, the search for a bride for Crown Prince Naruhito, ended tonight with the disclosure that the country's next Empress will be a decidedly modern Japanese woman. She is a 29-year-old Harvard graduate who has spent her short career as a diplomat handling some of Japan's most delicate economic disputes with the United States. 
 Though the official announcement of the Prince's engagement to Masako Owada is not expected for two weeks, the Japanese press said he would be married in May or June in a giant state celebration.
In a country looking for a joyful interlude to a dreary winter of economic downturn and political scandal, the news touched off a rush of excitement that could be seen on the street corners of Tokyo.
Crowds grabbed for single-sheet extras rushed onto the streets by the country's biggest newspapers, which decided tonight to terminate a total ban on reports about the Prince's seemingly endless quest for romance. But the palace, clearly irked at the news leak, kept silent.
 
The Right Size, Too
 For believers in the sacredness of Japan's imperial family, the engagement of the 32-year-old Crown Prince helped to assure the line of succession in a family that has reigned if not ruled for 1,300 years and traces its lineage to mythological emperors of 2,600 years ago. It brought an end to a search that was so long, so tortured and so scrutinized that it was the subject of mild ridicule as well as heartfelt sympathy for a young man trying to find a bride.
Miss Owada has long been rumored as a leading candidate because she fits most of the rigid requirements of the Imperial Household Agency, which runs the lives of the royal family. She comes from one of the country's most prominent families and she is an internationalist, fluent in English, German and French.
Perhaps most important, she is an inch shorter than the Prince, who is 5 feet, 6 inches tall.
She will also be the first person with a career ever to become a Crown Princess. The current Empress, Michiko, became the first commoner to become a Crown Princess when she married Akihito in 1959.
While she is widely expected to resign from the Foreign Ministry before her marriage, Miss Owada is wholly unlike most of the demure women who have ascended to the throne. She went to public high school in Belmont, Mass., and did not return to Japan full time until after she graduated from Harvard College in 1985.
In a country that still sends proper upper-class women to learn the intricacies of tea ceremony and flower arranging, she has been immersed in negotiations over semiconductors and arguments over what rules should govern foreign lawyers seeking to practice in Japan.
Her family is almost as well known in Washington as it is in Tokyo; her father, Hisashi Owada, is Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs, the country's most senior career diplomat, and most likely will serve as Japan's next Ambassador to the United States.
"It's pretty amazing when you think about the stereotype of a Japanese empress," a friend of Miss Owada said tonight. "Masako has a lot to talk about with Hillary Clinton."
Miss Owada has stayed out of sight for the last two days. As hundreds of Japanese reporters swarmed around her family's house tonight in a wealthy Tokyo neighborhood, her mother, Yumiko, said through a house intercom system that her daughter "is in bed with a cold."
Unlike Britain's royalty, Japan's imperial family is largely cloistered.As a result, no one knows how big a voice the son of Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko -- and grandson of Emperor Hirohito -- had in the decision. But friends of Miss Owada have said he has pursued her since they met at a diplomatic reception in 1986.
In past interviews, Naruhito said only that he was looking for a woman who "shares my values," once commenting he was not interested in anyone who would "go on a shopping spree at Tiffany's."
The problem has been finding a woman willing to enter what should be a Japanese fairy tale: Many prospects have been scared away by a job that makes the pressures facing the Princess of Wales look as easy to swallow as a piece of sushi.
The Japanese press reported tonight that Miss Owada first turned down the Crown Prince's proposal after a meeting at a duck-hunting ground in October, but that after he pressed, she agreed three weeks ago.
As every elite family in Japan knows, Empress Michiko quarreled with her mother-in-law and was widely criticized in the aristocracy, which resented her commoner roots. In 1963 she was hospitalized for an abortion and what the Imperial Household Agency said was "great mental strain."
No one is likely to know what assurances of better treatment, if any, Miss Owada received. "I think everyone who knows her is quite worried," a friend said tonight.
But hardly all of the problems in finding a suitable bride were the palace's fault; racy weeklies here have long blamed the Crown Prince himself. He has been described as overly serious and lacking passion.
The Japanese press often takes delight in quoting the full title of his graduation thesis at Gakushuin University: "Some Remarks on Maritime Transportation in the Seto Inland Sea in the Medieval Period.
In 1990 the search for a bride seemed to enter a desperate pass after Naruhito's younger brother, Prince Akishino, married Kiko Kawashima, a student. Japanese reporters staked out the homes of every rumored candidate. Finally the palace prodded the Japanese press into a vow of silence, saying the "privacy of the prospective candidates must be protected."
But in recent days, word of the engagement spread, and soon got to the press. Tonight, at a hastily called meeting of top newspaper editors, the decision was made to rescind the ban, and with characteristic Japanese precision the news flooded across television and news wires at precisely 8:45 P.M.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Crown Prince Naruhito's long quest for a bride has apparently ended with the disclosure that he will wed Masako Owada, a 29-year-old Harvard graduate who works in the Foreign Ministry, is fluent in four languages and, not unimportantly, is an inch shorter than the 32-year-old Prince. (NHK-TV and Associated Press)

HEADLINE: 2 States, 1 Target;
Cuomo and Weicker Differ in Attack On Systems of Bias by Local Wealth

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 6

 BODY:
In Albany and Hartford, two Governors used their annual State of the State addresses today to suggest new ways to battle the historic problems created by the side-by-side coexistence of rich and poor school districts.
Each addressed a different aspect of the crucial issue of education. Mario M. Cuomo of New York focused on the way wealth is tapped to pay for education. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut confronted the educational disparities that inevitably result when white students attend schools in affluent suburbs while minority students attend schools in poor urban areas. 
 But each, in a sense, suggested that part of the solution was to seek a broader financial base than the traditional school district, which has been so central for so long in the way Americans make decisions on educating their children.
Mr. Cuomo suggested that money for schools should come from countywide income taxes rather than, as currently, from property taxes assessed school district by school district, a system that allows wealthy communities to raise more for their schools than poor ones.
 
Killing White Localism
 Mr. Weicker said that Connecticut's school system should be subdivided into six large regions, eliminating the district-by-district system that has allowed white communities to send their children to predominantly white schools.
While the two Governors were speaking this afternoon, the most fundamental issues that have long plagued school systems, like race and class, were at the forefront in both state capitals.
Mr. Cuomo asked the Legislature to change a state law to allow counties to create a personal income tax so that the burden of paying for the schools could be shifted from property taxpayers to income taxpayers.
Governor Cuomo said his primary intent was to create a more equitable system of taxation by replacing a regressive tax with a more progressive one.
Mr. Cuomo said he had not decided whether the counties or the state would devise a formula for distributing the money to individual school districts. But he said that either one could guarantee that poor districts receive more help than they get now, when they are limited to what they can raise from their own property taxes.
And Mr. Weicker suggested redrawing the state's educational map to create six regions that would have to find ways to desegregate their schools. The proposal represented his response to a major lawsuit that charges Connecticut with maintaining de facto segregation in its schools.
The lawsuit argues that the Hartford schools, which are 90 percent minority, receive far less financial support than heavily white schools in the suburbs. It is being tried now in Superior Court in Hartford.
Rather than responding defensively to the lawsuit, which was filed by the families of 17 children from Hartford and West Hartford, Mr. Weicker made a strong case for reparations.
"If you are poor, if you are a minority, and if you live in one of our cities, you start the game at a disadvantage," he said.
Mr. Weicker then provided a detailed proposal for the creation of the six regions, setting deadlines for them to reduce "the racial and economic isolation of all students on a school-by-school, regionwide basis."
Politicians in New Jersey also have been waging a bitter fight over school financing. Just last month, Gov. Jim Florio and Republican legislative leaders reached a compromise that replaced the existing school aid system with a new one.
The decisions of both Governors to unveil proposals that will have little cost, at least in the short term, reflected the tenacity of the recession that still grips the region.
But the methods used by Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Weicker to sell their ideas provided a stark contrast between a pair of Governors at different stages of their careers.
Mr. Weicker, who is beginning the third year of his first term, was the poet on Wednesday. He devoted the vast majority of his speech to the problem of racial inequity in the state's schools, speaking movingly about "a Connecticut of promise, as seen in its suburbs, and a Connecticut of despair, as seen in its poverty-stricken cities."
By contrast, Mr. Cuomo, who began his 11th year in office, seemed to issue his school proposal almost as an afterthought. It received two paragraphs in his 156-page message to the Legislature and one paragraph in his somewhat rambling 59-minute speech. It took even the state's Education Commissioner, Thomas Sobol, by surprise.
"It really was unexpected," said Mr. Sobol, who said he could not support the proposal until dozens of questions were answered. "It's interesting but it's going to take a lot of work to figure out."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: News Analysis

HEADLINE: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: The President-Elect;
Auto Makers Ask Clinton to Limit Imports of Mini-Vans From Japan

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Leaders of the Big Three American auto makers today pressed President-elect Bill Clinton to limit Japanese auto imports into the United States.
Harold A. Poling, chairman of the Ford Motor Company, John F. Smith, Jr., president of the General Motors Corporation, Robert J. Eaton, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, and Owen Bieber, president of the United Auto Workers, spoke with Mr. Clinton and Vice-President-elect Al Gore at the Governor's Mansion, in a meeting they requested before Mr. Clinton completes his economic plans. 
 Auto industry officials said the executives had wanted to make certain that Mr. Clinton fulfills his campaign pledge to raise the import tariff on Japanese-made mini-vans and sport utility vehicles by designating them as trucks, which would sharply increase their price and make them less competitive.
They were also seeking from Mr. Clinton a change in the regulations that would require Japanese cars assembled in the United States to contain more American-made parts to qualify as domestically made and avoid certain tariffs.
In addition, the auto executives asked Mr. Clinton to relax his goal of increasing fuel economy standards to a fleet average of 40 miles a gallon by the year 2,000, and suggested a tax on gasoline instead, officials said. This would still promote energy conservation but without requiring the auto makers to build smaller cars, which they believe the public will not buy.
Mr. Poling told reporters after today's meeting that Mr. Clinton stood by his demands for better fuel efficiency. "He was desirous of improved fuel efficiency, but he did not want to do anything detrimental to the auto industry," he said.
Mr. Clinton did not comment specifically on the auto makers' request, but issued a statement after the meeting in which he said he and Vice President-elect Gore viewed the session as a "fresh start on how business, Government and labor a can work together."
Another topic at today's meeting was the North American Free Trade Agreement. Here the auto makers and the labor unions are on opposite sides. The manufacturers like the agreement, which is very favorable to them, while the auto workers are worried that the agreement will result only in more jobs moving to Mexico.
The American International Automobile Dealers Association issued a statement tonight calling on Mr. Clinton to reject the auto maker's protectionist demands, saying that "Clinton should understand that stricter import quotas and higher tariffs will result in increased automobile prices."
Mr. Clinton's own economic advisers are divided and are scheduled to meet here on Thursday to begin narrowing the options for Mr. Clinton's proposals.

HEADLINE: THE NEW PRESIDENCY: The White House Staff;
Advisers Looking Askance At Pledge for 25% Staff Cut

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
As President-elect Bill Clinton's advisers get closer to becoming White House staff members, they are growing dubious about his campaign promise to cut that staff by 25 percent.
Transition officials now say it could take months for the new Administration to meet that goal, if it does so at all. 
 The pledge that Mr. Clinton made as outsider campaigning against Washington bloat appears to be bumping up against Washington reality. One difficulty is that by law some positions cannot be eliminated; another is Mr. Clinton's own desire to create some new jobs in the White House, especially ones that would deal with the economy.
And then there are the political considerations that led to the creation of many jobs in the first place.
"It's doable," said one official involved in the transition planning. "The question is what political price one has to pay to do it."
 
Already a Retreat
 Some analysts said Mr. Clinton might feel less pressure to cut positions because he had already backed away from campaign urgings that Congress cut its own staff by 25 percent.
The Clinton aides insisted they were not retreating from the pledge regarding White House staff members. But they acknowledged that they were pursuing approaches that might make the cuts more cosmetic than real.
First, there is the question of which staff is to be cut. In his criticism of President Bush, Mr. Clinton never specified if his 25 percent pledge applied to the 400 or so people who make up the President's closest personal staff or to the larger Executive Office of the President, which has about 1,800 full-time positions.
Recognizing that cuts would be easier from a large pool, transition officials said the reductions would likely come from the xxecutive office.
 
Some Cuts, More Shifts
 Casting a wider net would also bring in more jobs that are considered dispensable. Topping the list for elimination, officials said, is the Council on Competitiveness, a group headed by Vice President Dan Quayle that reviews regulations with an eye on cutting costs to industry.
Other cuts will not really be cuts but reshufflings outside the White House. For example, Clinton aides said they hoped to move the Office of National Drug Control Policy, which has more than 100 staff members, into other agencies, like the Justice Department.
Officials also said they planned to shift some White House slots to the Democratic National Committee.
But even those efforts would only be small steps toward meeting the 25 percent goal. The Council on Competiveness, for instance, has just four full-time positions; the rest of its staff was borrowed from other offices.
 
Priority for Budget Posts
 Whatever cuts those moves produce may be offset by Mr. Clinton's desire for a staff that both is large enough to handle the demands of a new Administration and includes some new positions, like his Economic Security Council. In addition, Mr. Clinton is reluctant to make cuts in the largest executive office agency, the Office of Management and Budget, because, as an adviser put it, "it's the only agency responsible for the budget and the deficit is bigger than ever."
The uncertainty over how to cut the White House staff comes at a time when Mr. Clinton is preparing to announce who will fill the top tier of the executive branch as well as most other top sub-Cabinet positions.
Transition officials said Mr. Clinton had tentatively agreed to a new White House structure in which there would be two domestic policy advisers. The purpose of that arrangement is to create a space for Carol H. Rasco, a Clinton adviser on education and welfare issues in Arkansas, alongside Bruce Reed, the longtime favorite for the post. Mr. Clinton has been pressed by women's groups to include more women in upper echelons of his Administration.
Officials also said Harold M. Ickes Jr., who was New York State chairman for the Clinton campaign during the primaries last year, appears to be headed to serve as deputy chief of staff under Thomas F. McLarty 3d.
Clinton aides, under the direction of Mr. McLarty, said they hoped to move quickly on their reorganization to avoid what happened to President Jimmy Carter; he cut the White House staff months after many people had been hired, forcing them out of jobs.
 
'Swollen and Inefficient'
 But some Clinton advisers said it could be months before they resolve how to make the cuts.
"I think it may be a harder task than they anticipated," said Richard C. Holbrooke, a former assistant Secretary of State who led a bipartisan commission that gave Mr. Clinton recommendations on reorganizing the White House. "But I think they're headed in the right direction. They're inheriting a White House that's become swollen and inefficient, according to its own staffers who talked to us privately."
Mr. Holbrooke's report cited a "title creep" in the White House, in which there are now 20 "deputy assistants to the President" and 42 "special assistants to the President."
In a paper for the conservative Heritage Foundation that is being read by transition officials, Donald Devine, a director of the Office of Personnel Management in the Reagan Administration, contends that trimming the White House staff is critical.
"The whole monstrosity of staff at the White House chokes off efficient decision making," Mr. Devine said in an interview. "The Cabinet should be providing the staff for the President, not a bunch of relatively low level career people."
In the end, however, it may be hard to know whether or not Mr. Clinton fulfills his promise, because it is almost impossible to calculate the actual size of the White House staff. The staff is supplemented by hundreds of people called "detailees" who are temporarily dispatched from other agencies.
Referring to such staff members, Stanley E. Collender, a specialist in the Federal budget at Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm, said, "They could make it look like they've cut the White House by 50 percent and have more people there than ever."
But Mr. Clinton's pledge sounded earnest on the campaign trail. As he repeated his promise to cut a staff that "Republicans have ballooned," he would tell audiences, "I want to set an example."
