HEADLINE: Aid Urged for Dislocated Workers in Arms Industry

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Echoing themes endorsed by the Clinton team, a Federal commission today sharply criticized Government programs meant to help thousands of dislocated employees of military contractors.
The Defense Conversion Commission recommended that existing programs be strengthened and better coordinated with local communities to cope with the 960,000 jobs in private industry that are expected to be lost from the weapons makers from 1991 to 1997 as a result of military cutbacks. 
 But the seven-member panel, made up of senior officials from the Defense, Commerce and Labor departments and the Council of Economic Advisers, also concluded that current military cuts were less severe in size and pace than those that followed World War II, the Korean War and the Vietnam War, although their effects were pronounced "in a few states and some localities."
California, Connecticut and Texas have been particularly hard hit by the cuts in military industry jobs, the 85-page report said.
 
Role Seen for U.S.
 President-elect Bill Clinton and President Bush have diverged greatly in their views of how to help these dislocated workers, as well as over what role the Government should play in helping military contractors adjust to smaller Pentagon budgets.
Mr. Clinton and his designated Secretary of Defense, Les Aspin, advocate a greater government role in retraining laid-off workers and continued production of several major weapons systems, like attack submarines and fighter aircraft, to keep that technology readily available in times of crisis.
Many of the commission's recommendations mirrored principles that Mr. Clinton has supported, including a closer integration between military technology and the commercial marketplace and improved programs for laid-off workers.
"The Federal Government needs to do a much better job of integrating existing programs with the local communities," David J. Berteau, the commission's chairman, said in a telephone interview today.
 
Prospects of Contractors
 Barring mergers or acquisitions, the commission said, the top 25 Pentagon contractors should remain financially sound and should be able to manage the military cutbacks successfully.
The commission recommended that savings from the military cuts be invested in vital services and installations, like transportation, and other crucial technologies.
The panel also proposed that the Government take steps to promote the use of technology with both military and commercial applications. This would satisfy military requirements at lower costs and maintain a technologically advanced industrial sector.

HEADLINE: Stock Funds Did Well, Relatively

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
Despite a strong fourth-quarter performance, stock mutual funds showed less hefty gains in 1992 than in recent years. But in an era of low interest rates, the returns were still sizable enough to leave investors grinning.
Pushed by a 9 percent jump in the last quarter, stock mutual funds posted an 8.9 percent gain for the year, Lipper Analytical Services reported yesterday. The results were far below the brawny rise of 36 percent in 1991, and also below the average compounded annual returns of 15.6 percent in the last 15 years and 11.1 percent in the last 30 years. 
 But the performance was still much better than the gains for the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index, which rose about 4.5 percent, not including dividends, and about 7.6 percent with dividends reinvested. That performance is attributable in part to the fact that the S.& P. 500 does not include many small stocks, which as a group did better for the quarter and in the year than larger ones.
With low interest rates during the year, the returns on stock funds also exceeded those on certificates of deposit, money market funds and fixed-income funds, and also exceeded the inflation rate.
"We think that the 1992 year performance is going to be more like what we are going to see in the future than the rate for the last 15 years," said A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical Services. "I think people will treat the results as fairly good, particularly in comparison with other investments."
Mr. Lipper said he also believed the 1992 results were below normal in part because the 1991 performance was so spectacular. The Federal Reserve's decision to cut the discount rate to 3 1/2 percent in the closing days of 1991 may have contributed as much as 6 percent to 9 percent of that year's growth.
"One could argue that action might have moved some performance into 1991 that under other circumstances might have been in 1992," he said.
The biggest winners for 1992 were stock funds that invested with financial services concerns. With Wall Street posting all-time record profits and savings and loans beginning to show signs of recovery, the stocks of financial services companies boomed during the year, and funds that invested in them enjoyed a heady ride.
Financial services funds that Lipper studied grew an astonishing 35.2 percent in the year, reflecting 15.8 percent growth in the fourth quarter. Four of the top five mutual funds for the year invested in the financial services industry, and such funds have been among the top five leading categories for eight of the last 10 years.
Funds that invest in science and technology companies saw the second- biggest performance of 1992, with returns of 13.5 percent for the year and 17.7 percent for the fourth quarter.
For the fifth year in a row, stock funds made up of smaller, growth-oriented issues outperformed funds that invest in companies with larger capitalizations. For the year, small-company growth funds posted returns of about 12.5 percent, with almost all of that performance coming from the fourth quarter's growth rate of about 16 percent.
"The first six months of the year looked pretty grim," said Michael DiCarlo, portfolio manager of John Hancock Special Equities Fund, the second-best performing fund for the quarter and the 18th best for the year. "It was for those people who were patient and stayed with the program of investing in emerging growth stocks that did well."
Mr. DiCarlo added that the weak economy was more favorable for small, growth-oriented, as opposed to larger, value-oriented, stocks, which are generally bought because of their assets or prospective earnings.
 
Some Hot Initial Offerings
 Some of the year's hottest investments were initial public offerings, and some fund managers found profits in offerings that Wall Street snubbed. William Dutton, portfolio manager of Skyline Special Equities, the seventh-best fund for the year, said he invested in two initial offerings in 1992 -- Younkers Inc., a department-store chain, and First USA, a credit card issuer -- that had returns of more than 100 percent.
"Both were I.P.O.'s that were not at all hot," Mr. Dutton said. "Their prices had to be cut to get the deals done, but after they came public they both had very good performance."
International funds were hit by the worldwide economic slowdown and the value of the dollar. For the fourth year in a row, domestic funds outperformed international funds, largely because of currency movements. According to Lipper, 25 of the 28 currencies the firm tracks weekly underperformed the dollar for the year.
But the performance of individual international funds depended greatly on the areas of the world on which they focused. Pacific region funds, Latin American funds, and others posted small gains, while Japanese equity funds were the biggest losers for the year, dropping more than 21 percent.
Gold-oriented funds, overall losers for the last 10 years, were the second-worst performers. These funds, hit hard by sinking gold prices, lost 14.6 percent in 1992; they lost 9.2 percent in the last quarter.

HEADLINE: Reflections on the Scars Of the Old Budget Fights

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Every morning when he looks in the mirror, Richard G. Darman said today, he sees a tiny scar on his forehead, the remnant of a fall he took outside a McDonald's restaurant in the autumn of 1990, at the height of the struggle over the budget between the Bush Administration and Congress.
The scar reminds him of the battle wounds of the last two years as President Bush's budget director, Mr. Darman said at an unusually ruminative meeting with reporters. 
 With the President interested mostly in foreign affairs and the Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady, diffident to the point of obscurity, Mr. Darman dominated the Government's economic and domestic policies to an extent that no other unelected official has in decades. No proposal was offered, no measure was advocated or vetoed without Mr. Darman's involvement.
But the pressures were such that, at least for the last two years, he almost never spoke out in public, never defended himself on the record, never illuminated his guiding philosophy.
 
No Work to Do
 This morning, his final budget delivered, Mr. Darman had no work to do for the first time he could remember. As he met with about two dozen reporters around a table in his conference room, he reflected on the years past like a soldier home from the wars.
No one else in the Administration has taken so much hostile fire, and probably no one else has so few supporters.
Conservatives vilify him for supposedly persuading Mr. Bush to break his no-new-taxes vow, and many Republicans say that caused the President's defeat on Election Day.
Democrats in Congress say Mr. Darman's arrogance and stridency contributed to the sour relationship between the White House and the Capitol.
Many civil servants quit their jobs at the Office of Management and Budget saying they could not work with him, and many who stayed say Mr. Darman gave them no respect and made them feel like slave labor.
Reporters found him sometimes inaccessible, other times manipulative.
 
Governmental Savvy
 But no one ever questioned his intellect, his drive or his mastery of the intricacies of Government.
Making enemies, Mr. Darman asserted, was inherent in his job. He said: "If you're an O.M.B. director who tries to assume any power in a context of scarce resources and a context of ideological strife, with all the large stakes, you will find yourself at just about the dead center of maximum conflict."
But he said no one should feel sorry for him. "If you were to ask me would I do it over again, the answer is, Absolutely," he said. "Yes, it's been tough. But I would have had to be a fool not to know that on the way in."
Being a fool is one of the few things Mr. Darman has never been accused of. Rare for a Republican, he is interested not only in the power of Government but also in its inner workings, and today he scorned people who adopt an "anti-government spirit."
Asked whether he thought the country was on firmer fiscal footing now than when Mr. Bush took office, Mr. Darman first refused to answer, saying he would seem self-serving. But after his deputy, Robert E. Grady, held forth on how the 1990 budget agreement had restrained Government spending, Mr. Darman could not resist.
 
Powerless Over Some Things
 "There are so many things that affect the outcome over which you have no control," he said.
For instance, he had no influence over the Federal Reserve Board, which sets interest rates. And, he said, the Democrats, who run Congress, thwarted him at every turn, and much of what he hoped to accomplish would have had a better chance in a second term.
Most important, he said, in another four years he thinks he could have persuaded the Government to put a ceiling on mandatory spending, which includes expensive programs like Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid.
In other words, things probably are worse now than they were in 1989, but it is not his fault.
When Mr. Darman talked today about policy, he was as self-possessed as usual, talking about mandatory spending and "high-growth" budgets and "maximum deficit amounts."
But when he was asked about himself, his face became strangely flushed, his hands shook, his lips quivered and he laughed awkwardly.
Now 49 years old, he has spent nearly all adult life in the Government, working at the budget office, in the White House and in a half-dozen other agencies. When Democrats were in the White House, he taught about government at Harvard University. He once told an interviewer that his only ambition was to hold high Government office.
He said he had no idea what he would do when he had to leave office. Politically, he said, the country is at a crossroads with new coalitions being sorted out, and he would like to play a part. He does not plan to drop out of public life like David A. Stockman, Ronald Reagan's budget director and Mr. Darman's friend, who is now an investment banker. "I find it almost impossible to imagine I would decide to do that," he said.
"But certainly in the current context," he conceded, given the enemies he has made, "I couldn't expect to have a great deal of influence."
Rumors have it that he is planning a book. In fact, one Washington author said he saw a part of a Darman manuscript called "Adventures in Wonderland" in an editor's office in New York.
But Mr. Darman said he had no contract for a book and had not decided whether to write one.
He certainly does not want to write anything that might inhibit his returning to Government, he said. And then he added, "I'm obviously someone who cares a lot about Government."

HEADLINE: Schools Need Race Balance, Weicker Says

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., in a State of the State speech that focused almost entirely on the deep racial divisions in Connecticut's public schools, today urged legislators and local school leaders to begin a voluntary integration effort that would give urban and suburban districts roughly equal racial mixes by the 1999-2000 school year.
The backdrop of the speech, which Mr. Weicker repeatedly acknowledged, is a court case in which minority students from Hartford have sued the state, arguing that racially segregated schools violate the State Constitution's guarantee to equal education. Testimony is under way in that case, with a decision expected sometime this year that could, if the students prevail, mandate sweeping changes. 
 Mr. Weicker did not say that accepting his proposal would short-circuit a court order, but he clearly held out that hope.
 
Ambition and Caution
 "A court-run school system is not for Connecticut -- its children, or its adults," he said. "If we fail to act, the courts, sooner or later, will do that which by election was entrusted to us."
Many legislators acknowledged that the Governor, with his sweeping denunciation of racial and economic balance in Connecticut's public schools, had taken moral leadership on the issue.
The plan, while ambitious in its goals, was cautious in its particulars. Although it calls for creating six educational regions in the state where integration would be achieved by crossing town lines, local control of schools would be maintained, the Governor said, and the plan would include no sanctions against towns that failed to cooperate.
But critics and supporters alike said the speech broke new ground by proclaiming that a system of mostly white suburban schools and mostly minority urban schools was, in itself, harmful to the state and all its children and that the state should act to set things right. That view contradicts the state's position in the lawsuit, in which it has maintained that segregation is a result of housing and immigration patterns and that the state has no responsibility to correct the problem.
"The racial and economic isolation in Connecticut's school system is indisputable," Mr. Weicker said. And though the causes of that inequity might be disputed, he added, in the end it really does not matter. "What matters is that it is here and must be dealt with," he said.
John C. Brittain, a lawyer for the students, said the speech undercut the state's position entirely.
"I don't see why I wouldn't call the Governor tomorrow as a witness," he said, though he quickly added that he did not plan to do that for reasons involving executive privilege.
Under the plan, which has yet to be drafted into a formal legislative proposal, the racial composition of every school system in a region would eventually have to match that of the region as a whole. Thus, New Canaan, a predominantly white town in Fairfield County, would have to increase its minority enrollment to roughly 35.3 percent while Bridgeport, with a predominantly minority population, would cut its minority enrollment to 35.3 percent.
 
'Social Engineering'
 Reaction in the legislature ranged from open skepticism that local communities would ever voluntarily resolve racial divisions without economic or other sanctions by the state, to fear that sanctions may yet emerge as legislators pick up where Mr. Weicker left off.
"I really don't want to see us move in the direction that would put some sort of racial, social engineering as the goal," said Representative Paul J. Knierim, a Republican from Simsbury, and the ranking minority member on the Education Committee. "I don't think it should be our objective to try to make all school districts have the same statistical racial or ethnic makeup regardless of settlement patterns," Mr. Knierim said. "I'm fearful that that's the Governor's thrust with this."
But Hartford's Mayor, Carrie Saxon Perry, a staunch supporter of the students' lawsuit against the state, called the proposal a "clarion call" that was more important for its tone and its basic premise than for the plan itself, which she said did not go far enough.
Lawyers for the state have argued in the lawsuit, called Sheff v. O'Neill, that poverty is the main problem causing poor performance in urban schools, not racial isolation.
 
Motives Questioned
 But Mr. Weicker said again and again in the speech that racial isolation is itself a handicap and that the state government has to be the forum for addressing it and coordinating local efforts.
"That's the key," Ms. Perry said. "Not the plan per se, but his acceptance of the responsibility that we have to take some ownership of the pain out there -- he's made that linkage."
The 30-minute speech, which was full of florid turns of phrase -- several of which seemed directly lifted from Mr. Brittain's opening address in the trial three weeks ago -- clearly struck a raw nerve among some legislators. Many raised the specter of forced cross-district busing, even though Mr. Weicker disavowed that idea as doomed to failure. Others rejected the Governor's overall goal as wrongheaded.
Others clearly suspected Mr. Weicker's motives, suggesting that he was grandstanding to influence the trial, and that when push came to shove in the legislature, he would not be there to back up his plans, as he was in 1991, when he proposed and insisted upon -- through several budget vetoes -- the creation of a state income tax.
"He said he's not trying to skew the Sheff case, but his address today clearly attempted to do that," said the House minority leader, Edward C. Krawiecki Jr., a Republican from Bristol. "What he was trying to put is another piece of evidence, outside the courtroom, before the judges and all the attorneys that are arguing this case -- that look, the legislature and the executive branch are prepared to roll up their sleeves and go to work."
Under the plan, local school officials and municipal leaders in the six educational regions would be responsible for drawing up a plan that would address racial and economic imbalance. Some regions might want to consider magnet schools, or school choice, Mr. Weicker said, or perhaps a full merger of some districts if only in the interests of administrative efficiency.
The state's Education Commissioner, Dr. Vincent L. Ferrandino, said that just getting local communities talking about regional racial imbalances would be something of a revolution. Dr. Ferrandino, a Weicker appointee, also said the state's goal was not strictly racial mixing, but rather a full rethinking of education, staffing and curriculum to enhance education for urban and suburban students alike.
 
Sharp Disparities
 Although there are 166 school districts in Connecticut, about 80 percent of the state's minority students are concentrated in just 18 urban districts. The state's three largest cities, Bridgeport, Hartford and New Haven, have enrollments of more than 80 percent minorities. And 136 of the school districts are more than 90 percent white.
Mr. Weicker stressed in his speech that the specifics of the legislation would not be proposed until next month and that the six regions would also have full control of the process, subject to approval by the State Board of Education, whose members are appointed by the Governor.
But with an issue so capable of arousing fear and suspicion, just leaving things open-ended was enough to raise the anxieties of some legislators.
"I think there's a fear of integration," said Nancy Wyman, a Democrat from Tolland and the co-chairwoman of the legislature's Education Committee. "People say 'I don't want my kids bused into somebody else's area' -- it's a major fear of the public and in this building."

HEADLINE: Cuomo Proposes Tax on Incomes To Aid Schools

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposed today to allow localities to finance schools using income taxes instead of property taxes, a move he said would ease the burden of the property tax on people with low incomes and address the disparities between rich and poor school districts.
After years of failing to persuade the Legislature to change the state school aid system to give more help to poorer districts, Mr. Cuomo's proposal marks a new approach to the school finance problem, one of the state's most complicated political and governmental issues. 
 The proposal was part of the State of the State Message Mr. Cuomo presented to the Legislature today. Republicans, who control the state Senate and have blocked all of Mr. Cuomo's previous efforts to overhaul school financing, did not reject Mr. Cuomo's plan outright, a development that the Governor's aides said was encouraging.
The Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, a Republican from the wealthy Long Island community of Oyster Bay, said he agreed with Mr. Cuomo that it would be better to finance schools through income taxes.
But unlike Mr. Cuomo, who proposed to let each county decide whether to make the shift, Mr. Marino said it should be done statewide or not at all. The Governor's plan would provoke an endless series of bruising local battles over which system to use, Mr. Marino said.
"I have a problem with letting each district decide whether it will use property taxes or income taxes," Mr. Marino said in a news conference. "I think we ought to discuss a statewide approach."
The Nassau County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, a Republican who is close to Mr. Marino, said that he detected an ulterior motive in the Governor's plan -- to shift political responsibility for levying the new taxes on to the counties.
"What the Governor is trying to do is hold the line on state taxes by passing along the state's obligation to localities," Mr. Gulotta said.
Mr. Cuomo also used his address to answer critics of the state's finances by proposing a reorganization of the way the state borrows money. Under his plan, the state would reduce its dependence on borrowing by quasi-governmental agencies, creating a new authority that could borrow money under tighter voter scrutiny.
The Governor presented his programs in an 59-minute address that was notable for the lack of new spending initiatives. With estimates that the budget deficit for the year that begins April 1 could be as high as $4 billion, even Mr. Cuomo's aides acknowledged that the centerpiece of his economic development program -- more than $25 billion in capital spending over five years -- was little more than a reconstitution and repackaging of previous plans.
 
A Sign of Frustration
 Mr. Cuomo has been trying throughout his tenure to force the Legislature to agree to changes in the financing formulas for the state's public schools, which poor districts complain penalize them at the expense of rich districts. But he has always been unsuccessful, and today's plan seemed to be a sign of his frustration at his lack of success.
The proposal could affect 718 school districts around the state, but would do nothing to address the complaints of New York City and Yonkers that they receive too little education aid from the state. Both cities already have income taxes, a portion of which they use to support education. Most other states finance their school districts using real-estate taxes.
Mr. Cuomo said his proposal, which he will present to the Legislature in the form of a bill by April 1, was also aimed at addressing concerns of many voters about spiraling property taxes, particularly at a time when incomes have barely increased at all.
"Instead of some elderly woman living in a house all by herself with the assessment theoretically going up every year because the value goes up every year," the Governor said, "instead of her having to pay more and more for the schoolchildren, why not an income tax? At least it's more progressive. At least it has a closer relationship to what you're able to pay."
But his plan took many people by surprise and left his aides scrambling to provide details of how it would work in practice.
"It fosters progressivity and equity, but it leaves a myriad of practical questions to be addressed and answered," said Thomas Sobol, state education commissioner. "I don't know how we plan to do this."
In Westchester County, Dr. Anthony L. Mazzullo, superintendent of the Greenburgh Central School District and president of the Lower Hudson Council of School Superintendents, said he would welcome changes in a system that he said placed undue burdens on people who may have large homes but small incomes. "People are being taxed out of their homes," he said.
 
Levying Tax as Surcharge
 Under the Governor's proposal, each county would be allowed to hold a voter referendum to determine what system it preferred for its school districts: the income-tax or the property-tax system.
If the county decided to switch to the income-tax system, the taxes would be levied as a surcharge on the state income tax. The state would collect the money and give it back to the county to be distributed among local school districts according to a formula set by either the county or the state.
Mr. Cuomo presented the education plan as part of an array of proposals mapping out his legislative agenda for the coming year. Among his plans, he said, are the appointment of a special commission to investigate school district salaries, a renewed effort for a constitutional convention that would propose changes in laws governing politics and ethics and expansion of efforts to alleviate state prison overcrowding.
Many of the legislative proposals have been introduced in previous years, only to fall prey to the legislative gridlock that so often paralyzes Albany. Saying that November's election had showed that the people were tired of inaction, the Governor challenged the Legislature to work harder in the coming year.
Today's speech came at a time of scaled-back expectations for Mr. Cuomo, who saw his presidential ambitions die in 1991's budget morass and who has suffered a series of disappointments in recent months, including the voters' rejection of his $800 million jobs bond act in November.
 
Clapping His Own Hands
 The State of the State address is usually a chance for the Governor to burnish his fine oratorical skills and to speak graciously to the Legislature, with whom he is feuding more often than not. But today even those opportunities appeared to elude him, as his Teleprompter malfunctioned several times and the usually voluble Mr. Cuomo appeared to search for words.
And at one point, when the standing-room-only audience in the stately Assembly chamber was applauding one of his proposals, he stopped speaking and began to clap his own hands together. "I have discovered that this is easier to do than to write a bill," he said, rather snappishly. "This you can do, we can all do, that's easy. Monkeys do that."
He quickly included himself in the unflattering characterization, but not quickly enough to assuage members of his legislative audience, who began to grumble audibly. Senator Charles D. Cook, a Republican of Delhi, was so disgruntled that he gave the usually charismatic Mr. Cuomo perhaps the worst insult imaginable. "I think it is the most boring speech I have ever heard from the Governor," he said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Chairman Steps Down At Macy's Western Unit

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Daniel B. Finkelstein, chairman of R. H. Macy & Company's West Coast division, has suddenly resigned, marking the end of what had once been seen as a family dynasty at the retail company.
Rudolph J. Borneo, president of the division and a graduate of Macy's executive training program, will serve as acting chairman of the division until a successor to Mr. Finkelstein is hired, the company said. 
 Mr. Finkelstein's departure from the financially struggling division was no surprise to Macy's suppliers, company insiders and industry consultants. In fact, many of them had expected his resignation to follow more closely that of his father, Edward S. Finkelstein, who resigned as chairman of Macy shortly after the $6.5 billion company filed for bankruptcy protection last January.
Daniel Finkelstein's brother Mitchel resigned in November as head of Macy's product development and sourcing offices in Hong Kong. In a brief statement issued yesterday, Daniel Finkelstein said that in the short term, at least, he would join his father and brother in developing a specialty retail and apparel venture in the Far East.
His wife, Susan, vice president in charge of the West Coast division's personal shopping service, has no plans to leave the company, a Macy spokesman said.
Advisers to the company and to its creditors said Mr. Finkelstein's resignation was not entirely voluntary, and Mr. Finkelstein's statement did not address the issue. His appointment in 1989 at the age of 34 as chairman of what became the company's West division had created dissension as more experienced merchants were passed over. The division consists of 53 Macy's and Bullock's department stores, with combined annual sales of about $2.5 billion.
Mr. Finkelstein himself was apparently sensitive about his filial relationship to the corporate chairman: he always insisted that his name be pronounced fink-el-STINE, although his father's name is pronounced fink-el-STEEN.
He was among the five highest-paid executives at Macy, receiving salary and other cash compensation amounting to $533,286 in the year that ended Aug. 1. He was also an equity investor in the management-led buyout that took Macy private in 1986.
 
California Woes
 The advisers said the poor performance of the stores in the West gave the company a convenient excuse to oust him. The deteriorating economy in California has had a deleterious effect on Macy's business there. Christmas sales in Northern California were 5 percent below 1991's holiday sales, which were notoriously bad.
And the division has struggled with a new computerized system for managing inventory and a new process of buying and allocating merchandise that Macy has implemented to cut costs and better control inventories.
Edward Finkelstein's rise to power at Macy first became apparent on the West Coast, when he overhauled the Macy's store on Union Square in San Francisco, the flagship of the West division. He banished the store's bargain basement and filled the space with a gourmet food shop and novel kitchen wares. He called the department the Cellar, giving Macy's a more glamorous image and sending competitors scrambling to copy the concept.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Nationsbank Card Features a Savings Plan

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Nationsbank Inc., the country's No. 4 bank, said today that it was introducing a credit card that would enable card holders to build their savings when they make purchases.
The card program, a joint venture with Start Inc. of Herndon, Va., will provide each holder of a Nationsbank-Start Visa or Mastercard with a tax-deferred annuity administered by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company of New York. 
 Each time the card is used, Nationsbank will pay up to 1 percent of the total purchase price to the annuity. Some merchants participating in the program will make additional payments of up to 6 percent of the total purchase to the annuity.
 
Dual Function
 "Until now, you've only had two choices with your money: You could either spend it or save it," said Lawrence S. Andreini, chairman of Start, a private company formed in 1988 to create the annuity program. "You could never do both at the same time."
Kenneth D. Lewis, president of general banking for Nationsbank, based in Charlotte, N.C., asserted that the new card was the only one to provide a savings plan for users. "We look forward to making savings easy," he said.
In addition to Nationsbank, about 18 retail and service companies offer rebates to the annuity under the Start program. These include the MCI Communications Corporation, the Hertz Corporation, GE Capital Small Fleet and Spiegel Inc.
The card will carry a $35 annual fee, which will be waived if purchases exceed $2,000. Holders can choose a card with either a fixed rate of 16.9 percent annually or a variable rate.
Nationsbank said it would market the program initially through 350 branches in metropolitan Washington, Baltimore, Houston and Columbia, S.C. The company said it expects to market the program nationwide by the end of March.
Nationsbank and Start declined to discuss details of their arrangement. Still, analysts said the deal could help Nationsbank increase its market share.
"The game that's going on in the credit card business today is to take business away from your competitors," said Dennis F. Shea, bank analyst with Morgan Stanley Group Inc. "This kind of program puts pressure on the institutions that don't offer any kinds of incentives to credit card holders.
"This is kind of a neat idea because it potentially attracts higher-net-worth people."
 
Fees Appealing
 Mr. Shea noted that some credit card incentive plans, such as a low-interest rate card offered by the Wachovia Corporation of Winston-Salem, N.C., encouraged card holders to pay for purchases on an extended basis.
"I would suspect that this kind of plan will attract people who will pay off most of their purchases at the end of the month, and Nationsbank probably will make their money out of the transaction processing fees," he said.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money Market Funds Show Seasonal Increase in Yields

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Still affected by seasonal pressures, yields offered by tax-exempt and taxable money market funds were up in the latest week.
The latest survey by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report shows tax-exempt yields moderately higher for the week that ended Tuesday. 
 Assets of tax-exempt funds fell by $1.9 billion, to a total $97.4 billion, as the average number of days left to maturity of securities being held in tax-free fund portfolios dropped to 58, from 59. This is in line with the seasonal situation, because as yields rise, analysts noted, portfolio managers shorten positions in order to take advantage of the increases.
The seasonal factors include investor tax strategies and "window dressing" by portfolio managers trying to build up their funds' returns as year-end comparisons are made.
The seven-day average compounded yield for tax-exempt funds rose 9 basis points, to 2.83 percent, while the average seven-day simple yield rose by 8 basis points, to 2.79. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent. Donoghue's statisticians calculate that over a 30-day period, the compounded yield has averaged 2.45 percent and the simple yield 2.48 percent.
Ignoring state taxes, the taxable bond equivalent of the seven-day compounded yield this week for someone in a 28 percent tax bracket was about 3.93 percent, and about 4.10 percent for the 31 percent bracket.
From its survey of tax-exempt funds with assets greater than $100 million, IBC/Donoghue's said the Calvert Tax Free Reserves/ California Money Market Portfolio outperformed the group, to yield 3.72 percent.
Walter S. Frank, the chief economist at IBC/Donoghue's, predicted that the seasonal pressures would persist through the end of the month. Once the pressures abate and yields start to fall, there should be a flow of cash into the money market funds, since yields there will be slower in dropping than in many other comparable investments.
The municipal bond sector will also add to the flow of cash into the funds, as a heavy redemption of municipal securities puts money into investors' hands. Some of that money will go at least temporarily, if not permanently, to money market funds, which are a popular place to park cash for short periods.
For the week ended yesterday assets of taxable money market funds declined by $6.4 billion, to a total $459.5 billion, with institutional funds down by $5.3 billion and retail funds down $1.1 billion. The seven-day compounded yield on taxable funds rose 9 basis points, to 2.96.
 
Shortening Maturities
 Donoghue's analysts said the average days left to maturity of securities in taxable money market portfolios fell to 56, from 57.
Olde Premium Plus Money Market Series, distributed by Olde Asset Management Inc. in Detroit, was the top-yielding general-purpose fund with assets of more than $100 million. The fund was yielding 3.78 percent at the end of the week.
Banks that compete directly with money market funds for investor money barely raised the average yield offered on their money market accounts, to 2.77 percent from 2.76 percent, according to The Bank Rate Monitor.

HEADLINE: United Air Announces Huge Cuts

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Citing chaotic industry conditions and annual losses of hundreds of millions of dollars in recent years, United Airlines yesterday announced a package of layoffs, salary cuts, fewer flights and other measures aimed at cutting operating expenses by $400 million a year.
Stephen M. Wolf, United's chairman and chief executive, described the industry's ills as "well documented" and "pervasive," pointing especially to the fare wars led by carriers like Continental Airlines, Trans World Airlines and regional competitors that are operating in bankruptcy and benefiting from court orders cutting their costs. 
 Separately, in a letter to President-elect Bill Clinton calling for immediate appointment of a national commission to study the industry, Mr. Wolf also complained about the impact of trade barriers limiting international expansion and outdated airports and support facilities.
"These problems will not be solved simply by a resurgence in the economy," Mr. Wolf said in the letter.
 
Industry's Biggest Cutback
 Analysts and industry consultants called United's retrenchment the most comprehensive yet announced in the hard-pressed industry, although not necessarily more far-reaching in the long run than measures that have been announced in stages at major competitors like American Airlines and Delta Air Lines. United is the second-largest domestic airline after American, which recently set $300 million in cost savings as its goal for 1993.
"United's action is a significant but consistent move," said Daniel Kasper, an industry consultant at Harbridge House in Boston. "The major airlines have all concluded that they cannot wait for the economic recovery and must get closer to profitability now."
United said it will lay off 2,800 employees, or about 3 percent of its workforce, by the end of the month. Some of the layoffs will come from scaling back domestic service, although the company did not release details on which flights would be cut and which airports abandoned. The company hopes a voluntary severance plan will create openings for a portion of those now in line to be laid off. In addition to the layoffs, the company will not hire 1,900 new employees it had planned on adding this year, starting with 251 flight attendants currently in its training program.
 
Following the Delta Lead
 United's pay cuts follow the lead of Delta's last fall. Mr. Wolf's salary will be reduced by 15 percent, or about $100,000, from about $670,000 this year. Ronald W. Allen, his counterpart at Delta, took a $100,000 pay cut, to $475,000. Both airlines are cutting the salaries of all other managers by 5 percent. United's 11 outside board members are having their $20,000 annual fees cut 10 percent, or half as much as their counterparts at Delta.
Union representatives said that Mr. Wolf had scheduled a meeting next week with them to seek what the company called "similar sacrifices" to those imposed on its managers.
"We will be meeting tomorrow with the International Association of Machinists and the pilots' representatives to discuss what, if anything, we are willing to do," said Diane Tucker, president of the council representing the airline's 18,000 unionized flight attendants. "We're very concerned about the company."
United accompanied today's announcement with new warnings to Wall Street that the airline projected a large fourth-quarter loss and the earnings could be driven even deeper into the red if the company records a charge of nearly $1 billion to meet new accounting rules covering obligations to retirees for medical benefits. The company has already lost $165.9 million in the first three quarters of this year.
Investors appeared sobered by the warning and, analysts speculated, some may have interpreted the entire announcement as a sign that United's management was gloomier than it had been about the prospects for 1993. United's shares fell $1.125 today, to $123.875, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. But analysts took a more favorable view.
"It's a no-nonsense approach and should be seen positively," said Candace Browning, who follows the industry for Merrill Lynch Global Securities. "They had told analysts they wanted to keep costs flat. People who listened realized they would have to do something like this to meet that goal."
The cutbacks are largely separate from any that may result from negotiations United announced last month with the Boeing Company, its chief aircraft supplier, to reduce commitments to buy 433 new aircraft in the coming years. United said that it hoped to convince Boeing to delay delivery of some of the 55 aircraft it is scheduled to receive this year. It has increased the number of aging aircraft it plans to retire to 40 and is also considering grounding 10 747-SP's, an aging class of small, gas-guzzling wide-bodied craft. The result would be little or no increase in the fleet of 545 aircraft.
 "We are going to continue to grow United Airlines, but at a slower rate," Mr. Wolf said. He said that overseas operations remained profitable and that the company's strategy of expanding abroad, which has already made it the nation's largest international carrier, was sound.

Northwest Union Stake
 ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 6 (Reuters) -- Northwest Airlines' six unions will seek about an 80 percent equity stake in return for a proposed $900 million investment in the ailing airline, people familiar with talks between the union and company said today.
 In addition, five positions on a 15-member company board would be designated for the unions, a person familiar with the talks said. The company now has 13 board members.
 Northwest's unions pledged the $900 million investment through contract concessions in November. They outlined demands for the investment to Northwest's president, John Dasburg on Tuesday, and further details were discussed today.
 "It will be money we're putting into the corporation," said Curt Kruse, spokesman for the Air Line Pilots Association. Union representatives will meet with the company to hammer out more details about the proposal in the next several days.

HEADLINE: BEDFORD JOURNAL;
Seeking the Quaint, Town Says No to Neon Signs

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG

DATELINE: BEDFORD, N.Y.

 BODY:
MICHAEL GASPERINO has a red-and-white neon sign that boldly advertises one of his convenience store's biggest bargains: "Ham & Egg on Roll with Coffee $1.25."
But after roughly 20 years of faithful illumination in the front window of his shop here, the 4-foot-by-4-foot sign has been forcibly relegated to the cellar, where it is now surrounded by bags stuffed with discarded soda cans. 
 In late November, citing a nine-year-old Bedford zoning ordinance that many shopkeepers say they had never heard of, town officials ordered Mr. Gasperino's shop, the Bedford Hills Delicatessen, and 33 other establishments to remove their neon signs immediately or face fines of up to $250 a week.
The officials said the crackdown was mounted, in part, to maintain the "sleepy" image of this community made up of three hamlets tucked in the woods of northern Westchester County. But some shop owners have protested that the recently dusted-off ordinance strips them of one of their most distinctive and least expensive forms of advertising, a particularly sharp blow in tough economic times.
"They want to keep this a quaint, little, traditional town," said Mr. Gasperino, 35 years old. "And that's all fine and dandy. But that doesn't help us pay our taxes or our rent."
Since November, 32 of the businesses, which are mostly mom-and-pop operations, have taken down their signs, albeit grudgingly. But two -- Berner's Jewelers and the Katonah Image, a photography shop -- have refused to comply, town officials said. As a result, their owners have been issued summonses to appear in town court on Jan. 27 or face the possibility of arrest.
Sound like a petty dispute?
Not to Lawrence E. Dwyer Jr., the Bedford town supervisor, who said the anti-neon campaign was carefully orchestrated to immunize this 312-year-old town -- which is made up of the hamlets of Bedford Hills, Bedford Village and Katonah -- against what he believes is an increasing proliferation of neon and glitz in some surrounding communities.
"We like our hamlets to slow down," he said. "We like our hamlets to sleep. We like our hamlets to have a quiet charm about them.
"Neon is not part of what we are."
It's not that anyone would mistake Bedford for Las Vegas.
The most prominent signs removed from windows here included those in which neon tubing was twisted into the shape of a yogurt cone, a pair of eyeglasses and a clothes hanger. Some merely said, "Open." Two were functioning clocks.
Similar ordinances exist in other municipalities -- Westport, Conn., and Carmel, Calif., among them -- but the knowledge that they are not alone has proved to be of little comfort to the shop owners here.
"People will often ask where my store is at," said Robie Burke, an optician whose window used to display an oversized pair of neon, John Lennon-style glasses. "I'll say, 'Just look for the pair of red neon eyeglasses in the window.' "
"I think it'll definitely affect the business," he said, cradling the unplugged, $600 sign in his hands.
Carol Kiley, whose two sons own Katonah Image, the photography shop, said its multicolored sign -- which advertises laser copies, Canon products and the fact that the store is open -- is needed to attract customers to the shop, which is outside Katonah's main business district.
As the sign continued to burn in the window at midday, Ms. Kiley said the business would absorb the fines, if it came to that. "We're die-hards," she said.
Mr. Dwyer, the town supervisor, said that he was sympathetic to Ms. Kiley's concerns, but that it would be difficult to make exceptions to the rule. Both he and Jeffrey Osterman, the town's planning director, said that the ordinance was written for public safety as well as aesthetics. Neon signs, they contend, are more likely to distract drivers because they are brighter thean the more traditional "box" signs lighted by concealed bulbs.
Town officials argue that they, too, are sensitive to the struggling economy, but that they want to attract a particular kind of shopper, someone lured by Bedford's colonial ambiance, not by a sign visible from Route 117. "Our primary goal for our business district is not regional shopping," Mr. Dwyer said.
Toni Palmer, who works at the Taconic Correctional Facility, one of two women's prisons on the outskirts of town, said Mr. Dwyer's logic is lost on her.
"Come on," she said, while waiting at the Bedford Hills train station. "Unless it has naked ladies or something really obscene, or unless it's super big, I don't see where a sign will affect the town."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
A Shake-Up at Williams-Sonoma

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 6

 BODY:
In an apparent management shake-up, Williams-Sonoma Inc., a retailer of kitchenware and other home and garden items, today announced the resignation of its president and chief operating officer, Kent Larson, and its senior vice president and general merchandising manager, Glen Senk.
Williams-Sonoma, which is based here, had losses in the first three quarters of 1991 but says it expects to return to the black in its fourth-quarter results. 
 Mr. Larson's appointment as an executive vice president of First Bank System Inc. in Minneapolis was announced within hours of the Williams-Sonoma statement.
First Bank said Mr. Larson would direct the personal trust operations of its St. Paul subsidiary, First Trust National Assocation, starting Feb. 8.
Mr. Senk was said to have resigned to pursue other business interests and was not available for comment.
 
Chairman to Assume Duties
 Williams-Sonoma said it did not plan to hire a president; W. Howard Lester, its chairman and chief executive, will take over the president's responsibilities.
"We, as most retailers, have had a difficult past two years during the recession," James E. Riley, Williams-Sonoma's senior vice president and chief financial officer, said in a telephone interview. He said the management shuffle was "an effort to try and streamline our organization to best respond to some of these pressures."
While Williams-Sonoma opened 40 stores in 1991 and 26 stores in 1992, it plans to only open 3 to 6 stores this year, Mr. Riley said. He added that the company had had a very strong Christmas and should be "strongly in the black" for the fourth quarter. "Williams-Sonoma during the month of December performed at a higher rate than in the past two years," he said.
Williams-Sonoma operates 214 stores in three chains: Williams-Sonoma, which sells specialty kitchen utensils; Pottery Barn, which sells lower-cost housewares, and Hold Everything, which sells closet organizers and related goods. The company also has five catalogues, which include the three retail outlets' goods, plus Chambers, for bathroom supplies; Gardener's Eden, for gardening, and the California Closet Company.
Janet Joseph Kloppenburg, an analyst with Robertson Stephens & Company in New York, said the company's difficulties lay not with the Williams-Sonoma flagship, but with Pottery Barn and Hold Everything, "which have been plagued with fundamental problems." Pottery Barn and Hold Everything's "sluggish sales indicate their merchandise really hasn't been in line with consumers' desires," she said.
As part of the realignment, Williams-Sonoma said Gary Friedman, senior vice president for retail operations, had been promoted to executive vice president and would assume additional merchandising responsibility for the retail division, including Williams-Sonoma, Pottery Barn and Hold Everything. Pat Connolly, senior vice president for mail order operations, will assume full responsilibity for the mail order division. They will both report to Mr. Lester.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up on Iraqi Tensions And German Rates Rumor

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished higher against key currencies yesterday, strengthened by increased Iraq-Americantensions and a rumor that Germany's central bank might ease interest rates.
Gold prices advanced marginally after hitting seven-year lows earlier in the week. At the Commodity Exchange in New York, bullion for current delivery fetched $329.80, up $1.10 from Tuesday. The 4 P.M. spot price quoted by the Republic National Bank was $329.65, up 45 cents from the same time Tuesday. 
 Brokers focused on an ultimatum to Saddam Hussein to remove his missile batteries from the no-flight zone in southern Iraq, a sanction imposed in the aftermath of the Persian Gulf war.
"I think the saber-rattling against Iraq was what helped the dollar," said Hillel Waxman, chief foreign exchange dealer at the New York office of the Bank Leumi Trust Company.
 
Haven for Investors
 Rising international tensions tend to support the dollar because it is a favored haven among global investors.
Some traders also attributed the dollar's strength to a rumor that the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, might ease interest rates at a regularly scheduled council meeting today.
Wary of inflation, the Germans have maintained high interest rates in the face of tremendous pressure to drop them by trading partners who have seen their own currencies weaken as a result. The higher a country's interest rate, the more attractive its currency.
"The minute the Germans make a significant cut in interest rates in the short term, it's probably the beginning of a long-term trend," said John Nelson, vice president and chief foreign exchange dealer at the New York office of the ABN-Amro Bank. "We're not looking for how much they cut, but whether they cut."
Nonetheless, others said the rumor seemed to conflict with remarks yesterday by the Bundesbank president, Helmut Schlesinger, who said Germany's fight against inflation continued to be the priority.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 124.84 yen, down 0.41 yen from Tuesday. Later in London the dollar fetched 125.08 yen. By the time trading concluded in New York the dollar was worth 125.15 yen, up from 124.85 yen Tuesday.
The pound closed at $1.5410 at in London, weaker than its $1.5445 value late Tuesday. Later in New York the pound fetched $1.5420, weaker than its $1.5500 value Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with rates late Tuesday, were: 1.6340 marks, up from 1.6255; 1.4877 Swiss francs, up from 1.4720; 1.27995 Canadian dollars, up from 1.27725; 5.5650 French francs, up from 5.5475, and 1,526.00 Italian lire, up from 1,521.10.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Worrying About That Old Enemy

BYLINE: By Sylvia Nasar

 BODY:
NEVER mind that many Americans can't decide whether the recession is really over, let alone how robust the recovery will be. The hard money crowd at the Federal Reserve is already on to the next battle: inflation.
No sooner was the election over than Fed policy makers evidently decided, albeit tentatively, to lower targets for money supply growth. That's not the same as clamping down on money growth, but it is a signal of shifting priorities and future intentions. 
 Are they out of touch? Suicidal? Last year's inflation rate, 2 to 3 percent, was lower than in any year (barring fluky 1986 when oil prices plunged 20 percent) since the Beatles left Liverpool, and forecasters expect it to stay that way a while. Meanwhile, Henry B. Gonzalez of Texas, the populist chairman of the House Banking Committee, is looking for excuses to push legislation to increase Congressional supervision of the Fed.
Actually, the Fed is just doing its job.
Even though the 1980's knocked the wind out of nearly two decades of chronic inflation, the problem can't be solved once and for all. Like the common cold, inflation keeps coming back.
"Whenever you've got a paper money standard," said Ben Bernanke, an economist at Princeton University, "all that stands between you and inflation is the central bank's willingness to keep low and stable money growth rates."
Inflation flares when the economy is running flat out. For the last couple of decades, says Robert J. Gordon at Northwestern University, the danger zone lies below 6 percent unemployment and above 82 percent factory utilization.
Economists will disagree on when the Fed should tighten -- or how much -- to keep inflation from reviving. With unemployment at 7.2 percent, factories running at only 78 percent of capacity and the prospect of a mild expansion, even the most hawkish of inflation hawks don't expect an inflation problem for at least the next year or so.
What does seem clear is that the two-decade episode of creeping inflation can mainly be traced to missteps by past administrations and the Fed. "Inflation is made in Washington," said William Poole at Brown University.
The mistake he's referring to: Government follows expansionary policies -- fiscal or monetary -- too long, pushing even after the economy has no room to grow. That mistake was made frequently in the 1960's and 1970's with the result that inflation vaulted from 2.5 percent a year to 10 percent.
Traditionally, Democratic administrations have been more prone to this sort of error than Republican ones, and none was guiltier than the Carter Administration. The severe recession that followed the first oil crisis ended in 1975, but recovery stalled in 1976. Inflation had fallen sharply and was thought to be heading down further. With unemployment close to 8 percent, the Carter White House put pressure on the Fed to pump up the economy in 1977 and 1978. A new, more virulent round of inflation followed.
The trouble is that the terms of the trade-off aren't all that great. Wishful thinkers used to believe that tolerating a little more inflation could buy them a lot more growth and much lower unemployment. Now they know better.
"Suppose you're willing to tolerate 4 to 5 percent unemployment," Professor Bernanke said. "You could pump things up, get a one-time gain in output. But then you go back to a normal rate of growth. The trade-off is between a couple of points of inflation forever and a one-time benefit in the short run."
Probably the biggest reason for welcoming a watchful attitude on the inflation front is that Americans paid a high price to curb inflation -- most notably the severe recessions in the mid-70's and early 80's. "Just about every postwar recssion came about in response to rising inflation," Professor Poole said.
A new study underscores just how costly it was to unwind the inflationary spiral. Steven G. Cecchetti, an economist at Ohio State University, figures that each time inflation was knocked down five percentage points or so -- in the mid-70's, and in the early 80's -- it ultimately cost Americans an entire year's worth of national income.
"People's incomes ended up much lower than they would have been, " Professor Cecchetti said, because output was lost along with jobs and business opportunities.
President-elect Bill Clinton hasn't made known his views on inflation and Fed policy. But his team is surely anxious to avoid the mistakes of the Carter Administration. And, the Democratic supply siders, like their Reagan counterparts, sense that higher growth in the long run will come only from increasing productive capacity.
It remains to be seen whether the Clinton Administration will live up to its own oratory. In the meantime, be thankful that a vigilant Fed is worrying about something that nobody else is.

HEADLINE: Theater Suffering After Film Boycott

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
The theater industry in New York City is an unexpected victim of the Hollywood film boycott that ended more than a year and a half ago, according to a new study of the city's theater business, to be released today.
During the boycott, a bitter nine-month stalemate between Hollywood producers and New York film unions, the major studios virtually shut down film making in the city. Not only has the number of movie productions in New York been sharply reduced ever since, the report says, but the boycott has also caused a lasting talent drain of actors and production and technical workers, many of whom have moved to the West Coast. That exodus has reduced the available pool for theater in New York as well. 
 Although the boycott was settled in May 1991, "film making hasn't picked up, and that's affected the theater business in New York," said Jack L. Goldstein, a co-author of the report, which surveyed businesses, producers and suppliers working on Broadway shows as well as the city's nonprofit theater companies.
 
Following the Work
 In the survey, 80 percent of the theater agents and 60 percent of the booking agents cited the lingering effects of the film boycott as a serious problem. "The talent people say they're having a difficult time in casting because so many actors have moved," said Mr. Goldstein, the former executive director of the nonprofit group Save the Theaters. "The faces go where the film work is."
"It was an eye-opener to us to see that the theater and film industries are so closely related," he said. He added that many theater businesses surveyed were concerned that the effects of the boycott would continue, and some worried that they would have to leave New York.
The report, titled "1982-1992-2002: A Generation of New York Theater," was prepared by Exploring the Metropolis, an independent, not-for-profit research organization financed with grants from foundations and individuals. Its findings are to be presented at a news conference at the Showbiz Expo East, a three-day entertainment-industry convention at the New York Hilton Hotel. Among those scheduled to attend the announcement are Luis R. Cancel, the City Cultural Affairs Commissioner; Barbara J. Fife, the city's Deputy Mayor for Planning and Development; Rocco Landesman, the president of Jujamcyn Theaters, and Ron Silver, the president of the Actors' Equity Association.
 
Thousands of Businesses at Stake
 The study is believed to be the first attempt to tally the total number of theater businesses in the city and to survey their problems and prospects. It has identified 1,600 theater-industry businesses, compiled from a variety of sources that included business directories, contact books, word of mouth and even the Yellow Pages. "The universe of such businesses in the city may be as high as 2,000, but we were unable to trace all of them because they move and change names," said Eugenie C. Cowan, the director of Exploring the Metropolis and the report's other co-author.
The number of such businesses has declined about 15 percent in the last decade, according to the report.
The researchers surveyed more than 250 suppliers, theater operators, producers, publicity agents, booking agents, unions and service organizations. They did not specifically survey the Broadway theaters owned or operated by the Shubert Organization, the Nederlander Organization and Jujamcyn Theaters, since the League of American Theaters and Producers compiles statistics for those theaters.
Mr. Landesman, of Jujamcyn, said yesterday that the lingering effects of the film boycott on Broadway productions were "difficult to assess" but that "it does seem to me that more and more of the actors that we want to hire have moved to Los Angeles." He added, "We've also lost quite a few good designers to movies, for they move where the work is."
Of the businesses surveyed, 35 percent had been operating for 10 years or less, and 28 percent had annual budgets between $150,000 and $500,000. Not surprisingly, an overwhelming majority of the businesses surveyed, 87 percent, were in Manhattan, most of them in the traditional theater district, ZIP codes 10036 and 10019, from 42d Street to 59th Street west of Fifth Avenue.
The most serious problem identified by theater operators and independent producers was the decline in financing from corporations, foundations and government. They said the recession had sharply reduced investment capital for commercial operations and adversely affected the number of nonprofit theater productions.
According to the report, support from the city's Department of Cultural Affairs has remained relatively steady, declining to $1.25 million in 1992, compared with $1.35 million in 1989. Theater grants from the National Endowment for the Arts dropped sharply to $1.6 million in 1991, from $3.2 million in 1981.
The study found that the cost of a typical showcase production, the presentation of a new work at an Off Off Broadway theater, was $13,200, compared with $105,340 for a typical Off Broadway musical and $1,078,100 for a typical Broadway play.
"That's surprisingly high," said Mr. Goldstein, referring to the Off Off Broadway figure, which covered theater rental, lighting, music and other production expenses, but not the services of actors, set designers, costume designers or lighting directors. For an Off Off Broadway showcase, their work is generally donated.
 
Small Spaces Breed New Work
 There are 185 nonprofit theater companies in the city, the report said, including institutional theaters with their own facilities and producing organizations that rent space. The report's survey of 103 of those companies found that they mounted 459 productions, of which 393, or 85 percent, were new works.
According to the Alliance of Resident Theaters of New York, nonprofit theater in the city grosses $100 million a year and generates $300 million to $400 million a year for secondary businesses.
The League of American Theaters and Producers reported last June that Broadway had grosses of $290 million for the 1991-92 season. Estimates of the yearly economic impact of Broadway on the city have ranged from $1 billion to more than $3 billion, according to industry sources.
The report, however, gave particular attention to the value of the city's smaller performance spaces. Among the companies surveyed, 97 percent of new works were produced in theaters with 499 seats or fewer. More specifically, 65 percent of the new work was produced in houses counting 99 seats or less.
The study found that of the theater companies surveyed, 75 percent rented their performance space, 13 percent owned it, 7 percent shared it and 5 percent were operating in donated space.
 
Optimism at a Premium
 The study raises the concern that, despite the box-office success of the 1991-92 Broadway season, New York's franchise on theater is eroding because the recession has reduced attendance and public financing of the arts.
When asked about the future of the theater industry, 56 percent of those surveyed gave the prospects as only fair, in comparison to poor (23 percent) or good (14 percent).
"We saw this as a call for help," Ms. Cowan said.
But not everything is bleak. "A very positive aspect of the study was that many people said they are looking for creative ways to present more and better theater in the city," she said.
